column2: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -The former president of the International Boxing Club and four underworld figures were indicted and arrested today on charges of trying to extort control of the world welterweight boxing champion, Don Jordan.

Late summer weather is predicted for today, although a little cloudier than yesterday, with the temperature again approaching yesterday's high here of 84.2 degrees. None theless, autumn arrives at 3:09 P. M., Eastern Daylight Time.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- The Giants' pennant hopes suffered another staggering blow today -- and it came when least expected.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Voice of America's broadcast verision of the heated San Francisco exchange between Premier Khrushchev and United States labor leaders came in clearly and without jamming, Moscow listeners said today.
Darius Milhaud's particular brand of melody will be heard in a Broadway show for the first time.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 -- The A. F. L.-C. I. O. warned both parties today that labor would no longer be impressed by "campaign platforms that are merely contrived to bait the innocent."
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 22 -- The New York State Thruway Authority was accused today of permitting inadequate and discourteous service to stranded motorists.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 -- Los Angeles citizens appeared today to be having some serious second thoughts on two counts about their reception of Premier Khrushchev last Saturday.

KHRUSHCHEV never made it, but the New York Football Giants did. The gridiron heroes are currently encamped at Disneyland, quartered in the motel there. They need no security guards to watch over them. The only guards they worry play in the line of the Los Angeles Rams, the Giants' rivals on Saturday night in Walter O'Malley oversized joss house, the Los Angeles Coliseum.

YESILKOY, Turkey, Sept. 22 -We are only just beginning to witness the political repercussions of this decade's scientific revolution. It will be years before the world's governing systems are able to adjust to practical implications of the exploding world of physics.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The leaders of the Conservative and Labor parties contesting the coming general election set out today on 2,000-mile road-and-rail campaign speaking tours.

This writer, an agricultural economist, would like to add a word of caution to any interpretation of the recent drastic revision of China's output figures for 1958 as evidence of some kind of fraud or deception on the part of officials of that country.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 -- After winging merrily away to a three-run lead in their first turn at bat tonight, the Dodgers went into a tailspin, and wound up losing to the seventh-place Cardinals, 11-10.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved a new operating agreement for the Railway Express Agency, Inc., to run fourteen years.
A spokesman for the Consolidated Edison Company declared yesterday that it was "urgently in need of an increase in rates" for its electrical services.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that Premier Khrushchev's disarmament proposal left an important question unanswered. Assuming that the nations of the world abolished their armed forces. Mr. Herter asked, how can peace be maintained if someof them still insist "on going to war with each other, even with knives?"
James J. Cochran has rejoined the Kudner Agency, Inc., as a vice president and supervisor on the account of Renault, Inc.

The Transit Authority said yesterday that it would run five Daily Double special trains to Aqueduct race track on weekdays and eight on Saturdays. This more than doubled the number of trains planned for the service when the track opened on Sept. 14.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Following is a transcript of a talk by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter today at a luncheon given for him by the United Nations Correspondents Association and of a subsequent question-and-answer period:

The property used as a parking lot at the northwest corner of First Avenue and 111th Street has been sold by Irving Wenig to Harry Horwitz, realty operator. It fronts seventy-five feet on the avenue and 225 feet on street, in the block south of Jefferson Houses, Pearce, Mayer Greet and Oscar Gothelf were the brokers in the sale.

Uris Brothers, builders, announced yesterday that they had obtained financing through the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company for a twenty-story and penthouse office building to be constructed on the blockfront on the west side of Third Avenue from Fifty-first to Fifty-second Street.

COON RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 22 -- Mrs. Elizabeth Garst, 58-year-old wife of Roswell Garst, who invited Premier Khrushchev to Iowa, plans to show the Premier's wife "how ordinary folk live in a small town" in this country.
TRIBUTE to composers continue to be something of a standard staple in the field of television specials, and last night it was the turn of the late Jerome Kern to be honored over Channel 4.

Seven youths charged with the latest teen-age slaying here heard a magistrate assert yesterday that such killings could be stopped by more parental teaching of the Ten Commandments -- among them, "Thou shalt not kill."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -The National Broadcasting Company agreed today to dispose of its wholly owned television and radio stations in Philadelphia by the end of 1962.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 22 -- The appointment of five Convocation Fellows of Brown University was announced today by Dr. Barnaby C. Keeney, university president.
Election of Paul Bienvenu and D. Ross McMaster as directors was announced by the Bank of Montreal. Mr. Bienvenu is president of Catelli Food Products, Ltd., and Mr. McMaster is a Montreal lawyer.
HONOLULU, Sept. 22 -- Representatives of sixty-nine airlines were urged today to "keep open and flexible minds" on fares and rates.
General Motors' Corvair and Chrysler's Valiant will go on display at dealer showrooms next month, rounding out the compact-car presentations of the Big Three auto companies.

In recent years there have been some who have expressed concern because the rate of New York City's population growth has slowed down. Perhaps these persons will find consolation in the findings of the City Planning Commission, in a new survey, that since 1900 the city has made a "remarkable record" of population gains compared with other large cities of the nation.

TRENTON, Sept. 22 -- Senator Thruston B. Morton predicted here today that the West would furnish Laos with manpower as well as arms if such aid were required to halt Communist aggression in that nation.

The appointment of Daniel Gutman, dean of the New York Law School, as hearing officer for the Transit Authority was announced yesterday by the agency. He was sworn in to the $15,000-a-year post last Thursday.

The little Orchestra Society will present concert versions of four seldom-heard operas, as well as other music, at its four Town Hall concerts of the 1959-1960 season. The Liitle Orchestra Society's founder and conductor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Government arranged today to pay about half the $27,346,000 cost of building two cargo ships for Pacific Far East Line, Inc., of San Francisco.

The New York Adult Education Council, Inc., will receive the proceeds of the Oct. 20 evening performance of "The Gang's All Here," starring Melvyn Douglas. The play is scheduled to open at the Ambassador Theatre on Oct. 1.

With Bobby Ussery urging him throughout, Mrs. Wallace Gilroy's Jet Fuel, returning $28.20 for $2, equaled the New Aqueduct track record of 1:11 for six furlongs in winning the Miracle Handicap by half a length yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Unaccustomed to another team's taking an American League pennant, the Yankees tonight gained an 8-4 triumph over the Washington Senators while watching the scoreboard tell the tale of the White Sox' big achievement in Cleveland.

The so-called outer seven nations, outside the European Economic Community, must improve their economic strength and expand the free-trade area, Dr. Bruno Kreisky, the new Austrian Foreign Minister, said last night.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The] stock market continued its idownward t,'end here today iwith losses of t,p to a shilling (14 cents) predominating.
Despite recent subway delays, the Transit Authority said yesterday, there were 500 fewer such incidents from March through August of this year than in a similar period of 1958.
MONTREAL, Sept. 22 -- The Canadian National Railways and the Canadian Pacific Railway announced plans today for sharp cuts in passenger fares.

IF more Chanel fashions are found at Altman's in the next two weeks than in any other store, the person responsible is Altman's fashion coordinator, Mrs. Betty Dorso. During preliminary discussions of the store's Fete Francaise -- a store-wide tribute to France that begins next week -- it was Mrs. Dorso who pointed out that Mlle. Gabrielle Chanel, the dress designer, had influenced American fashion more than any other couturier in recent years.
COMMACK, L. I., Sept. 22 -- New York State's first agreement to pay a part of the interest on public school bonds was announced for the Commack School District today.

Stravinsky will conduct three of his own works in a series of concerts to be presented this season by Columbia Records, it was announced yesterday by Goddard Lieberson, president of the company. The Stravinsky works will be recorded by Columbia immediately after the concerts.
DES MOINES, Sept. 22 -- There are about forty Soviet correspondents and a dozen newsmen from Eastern Europe traveling in the Khrushchev press party.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- For the fourth consecutivemonthFrance, in August, exported more than she imported. The net favorable trade balance -- the excess of exports over imports -- for the month was the franc equivalent of $23,000,000 on exports of $294,000,000 and imports of $271,000,000.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Sept. 22 (AP) -- The "Draft Rockefeller for President in '60" club here chose a promotion committee and distributed campaign buttons last night.

Playing at top form, the United States chess champion, Bobby Fischer, defeated Paul Benko of New York yesterday in the tenth round of the challengers' tournament at Bled, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

The formal appointment of Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen as Special Assistant to Secretary Herter will give pleasure to everyone knowing his high qualifications. He will act as an adviser to the Secretary of State on Russian affairs.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 22 -- The visit of Premier Khrushchev to the United States is being labeled in preliminary appraisals here as pretty much of a failure.

The twelfth annual Grand Prix Road Races of Watkins Glen, N. Y., will be run Friday and Saturday over the 2.3-mile closed course on the outskirts of that town. This will be the last, except two, of the 1959 national point meetings under the banner of the Sports Car Club of America.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy suggested today that responsibility for developing a nuclear-powered airplane be taken from the Defense Department and placed with the Atomic Energy Commission.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22 -Milwaukee's Braves won a big one tonight. This was the one they had feared the most. All along, the Braves reasoned that if they could get past the Pirates' Harvey Haddix the road ahead would be smooth and lead to a third straight National League pennant.
One of the city's better-known art movie theatres has joined managerial hands with one of the more enterprising local theatrical circuits.

Although some difficulties remain to be overcome, the field of urban redevelopment offers the real estate and financing industries a tremendous potential for expansion, the nation's mortgage bankers were told yesterday.

George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, accused Premier Khrushchev yesterday of harboring anti-Semitic prejudices and of keeping anti-Jewish quotas in education and employment.
A new puzzle arose yesterday in investigation of the death of Mrs. Lynn Kauffman, who disappeared from the Dutch passenger-freighter Utrecht en route from Boston to New York last Friday night.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- A new week, and a new line.

COON RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 22 -- Roswell Garst, whose corn development properties Premier Khrushchev will visit tomorrow, is no more an Iowa dirt farmer than Mr. Khrushchev is a simple shepherd turned coal miner.
TOKYO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev is being described in Japanese newspapers as a powerful personality who will leave his mark on the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -President Eisenhower prepared today for his two-day conference with Premier Khrushchev by conferring for eighty minutes with his top diplomatic. military, intelligence and scientific advisers.

TUNIS, Sept. 22 -- The broad principles of a response to President de Gaulle's proposal for Algeria have been decided by the Algerian nationalist provisional government, according to a nationalist communique issued here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 -- The merged labor federation cleared the way today for establishment of compulsory machinery for arbitrating inter-union disputes. The decision marked a major break with the tradition of union autonomy. It reflected a recognition by warring craft and industrial unionists of the necessity for subordinating their internal feuds in the light of mounting employer resistance and the impact of the new labor law.

Hilton Hotels Corporation has obtained a line of credit with the First National Bank of Boston and ten other institutions making available up to $25,000,000 at 5 1/4 per cent interest in the next seven years.
Liquidation of the September position and a report of a higher Ghana crop estimate caused selling of cocoa futures yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange.

GENEVA, Sept. 22 -- A further cutback in Western European hard coal production did not prevent unsold pithead stocks from soaring to a record of 61,500,000 metric tons at the end of June, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

One more blow has been struck for good dental health in New York City. Speaking before the American Dental Association, City Council President Abe Stark has disclosed that he is in favor of fluoridating the city's water supply and thus protecting our children's teeth.

General Mills, Inc., is expanding its pet food activities through the acquisition of the American Crabmeat Company, Inc., Boston, manufacturer of a canned cat food. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed in an announcement yesterday by A. Z. Kouri, executive vice president of consumer foods of the big flour-milling company.

Reservations are still available for the Ballo di Roma, to be held tomorrow at the Savoy Hilton for the benefit of Boys Towns of Italy, Inc. They may be obtained from Mrs. Helen Arena at the beneficiary's national headquarters, 38 East Fifty-seventh Street.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The General Assembly barred Communist Chinese membership in the United Nations today for at least another year.

THE fish and game bureaus of New York, Maine and Vermont, fully alert to the fact that hunting seasons were not far away, weighed in with some details about their domains. What they had to say was not much out of the ordinary except in one instance. Part of New York State will have a season for wild turkeys.
SANTOS, Brazil, Sept. 22 -The "boom of the broom" began formally this morning along the smoke-covered waterfront of this big port city.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 -- As the clock above the scoreboard at Municipal Stadium reached 10:45 tonight the Chicago White Sox clinched their first American League championship in forty years.

The United States Court of Appeals, although divided on a number of issues, yesterday upheld a lower court dismissal of a suit brought by a former Brooklyn College student. The student, who had been dropped for disciplinary reasons, had sued for reinstatement.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The General Assembly agreed today to give a full airing to Premier Khrushchev's proposal for total disarmament within four years.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodeisa, Sept. 22 -- The difficulties of promoting racial partnership in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland have been emphasized by three recent events.

NEWARK, Sept. 22 -- Five 18-year-old youths were held today in the bombing of a church last night. The homemade missile was thrown through a hole in a window of the True Way Church of God in Christ Jesus.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 -- An increase in the dividend rate paid by the Los Angeles metropolitan area savings and loan industry appears more probable with each passing day.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The National Agricultural Advisory Commission recommended today elimination of Federal acreage controls on wheat and a new system designed to reduce wheat price supports.
Stocks attempted a rally yesterday, fell when they failed to push it through and ended the day with three hours of peaceful trading at rising prices. There was a nominal net loss for the day.

PARENTAL pram pushing gave Barbara D'Arcy her first sniff of the musty interiors of antique shops. Once Miss D'Arcy, now Bloomingdale's interior decorator, was old enough to manage under her own steam, she followed in her parents' footsteps.

" Paris is ready." These words were spoken by a long lines telephone operator yesterday seconds after a call to the French capital was placed in New York. "Hello's" were exchanged over a 4,400-mile system, built at a cost of $40,000,000.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 22 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey tonight called for an "unfailing pursuit of the goal of universal disarmament." He warned, however, that the free world must maintain "an invincible shield of defense" until such a goal was attained.
The mother of a Second-grade Brooklyn pupil was arrested yesterday on a charge of simple assault against a teacher in her classroom.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 -- California lawyers came to the support of the United States Supreme Court today.

DES MOINES, Sept. 22 -Premier Khrushchev was introduced today to the hot dog. He ate it and said: "We have beaten you to the moon, but you have beaten us in sausage-making." The incident occurred at the Des Moines Packing Company.
DES MOINES, Sept. 22 -Premier Khrushchev got a warm welcome to Iowa today and promptly suggested that meetings of world leaders once or twice a year would be very useful.
" BRONCO," the new Western series on Channel 7, got off to an entertaining start last night.
Two gunmen shot the operator of a check-cashing service at a paper-box plant in Maspeth, Queens, yesterday and robbed him of $10,000.

It's like the weather. Almost every investor is talking about the decline in stock prices these days but they are not doing much about it. One of the best places to get a perspective of market weather is in a chart of the averages.
MIAMI, Sept. 22 (AP) -- A tropical storm became a hurricane today 100 miles east-southeast of San Salvador in the Bahamas. Its peak winds of 100 miles an hour moved northward over the Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Endorsement by fifty-one Senators of the holding of a 1964 world's fair in Washington was announced today by Robert E. McLaughlin, a commissioner of the District of Columbia.

Although the June 26 world title fight between Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson fared rather poorly in the matter of gate receipts, it was a successful venture for holders of the closed-circuit television, radio and movie rights.
Governor Rockefeller leveled criticism last night at the form that much of the direct debate with Premier Khrushchev has taken in this country.

As a result of the tour of the United States which, despite his complaints about "isolation" and "house arrest," has brought him in contact with more American people of all walks of life than is afforded to most visiting heads of state, Premier Khrushchev seems to have made at least one important discovery which could have a salutary effect on his forthcoming talks with President Eisenhower and on Soviet-American relations.

Elizabeth Pharron, a contralto from California, sang a debut performance at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. Her program, which began with early Italian songs, also included the aria "Non piu di fiori," from "La Clemenza di Tito," Brahms and Purcell groups, Richard Cumming's
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points up to 1 point off yesterday, after holding in a narrow range. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.)
Three more leading manufacturers of viscose tire yarn cut the price of the fabric yesterday. On Monday, the Industrial Rayon Corporation reduced the price of its products 4 and 5 cents a pound.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (AP) -- A Municipal Court judge has closed to the press and public further hearings in a case involving a mother who is trying to regain custody of her daughters and take them behind the Iron Curtain.

The Pioneer Youth of America, Inc., will sponsor a theatre party at the Oct. 8 performance of "Much Ado About Nothing" at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre. Proceeds will benefit the group's Pioneer Youth Camp at Rifton, N. Y.
Hope was expressed here last night that Congress would vote funds for camp and other programs to combat spreading gangsterism among teen-agers.
NUTLEY, N. J., Sept. 22 -- More than 2,000 employes went on strike at the research laboratories of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation here this morning.

GARDEN CITY, L. I. Sept. 22 -- A New York City detective, Jack Dowling, who is a member of the Mahopac Golf Club, led the metropolitan qualifiers today for the United States Golf Association's senior championship.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- The pennant victory of the Chicago White Sox tonight capped a long, laborious rise out of the doldrums by one of the American League's charter clubs.

HAIFA, Israel, Sept. 22 (Reuters) -- David Ben Haroush, 35-year-old leader of Jewish immigrants from North Africa, was sentenced to prison for two years today for his part in riots in Haifa's Wadi Salib slum area July 9 and 31.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Baker, the tiny squirrel monkey who made a 300-mile trip into space in the nose cone of a rocket, today moved into a new air-conditioned home, complete with picture window.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Britain rejected today a proposal by the Soviet Union that an international conference be convened without delay to deal with the crisis in Laos.
The B. F. Goodrich Company, which last year spent a sum estimated at $11,000,000 for advertising, has realigned its agency set-up and assignments.
A fire in the locomotive of a New Haven Railroad train yesterday delayed New Haven and New York Central trains outbound from Grand Central Terminal for as much as an hour and a half.

Last week the prolonged merger discussions between the Tidewater Oil Company and Skelly Oil Company collapsed. Yesterday, George F. Getty 2d, president of Tidewater, explained at a special press conference that Tidewater terminated the merger discussions chiefly because the appraised asset value of the company's common stock exceeded its market price.
A new, versatile office intercommunications system described by its manufacturer as "humanized" was introduced yesterday by Dictograph Products, Inc.
Occasionally a brief statement is made which summarizes years of struggle and points to the beginnings of physical achievement.

" The Financial Follies of 1959," the eighteenth annual musical show satirizing business, industry and finance and written and produced by the New York Financial Writers' Association, will be presented on Friday evening, Nov. 20, in the grand ballroom of the Astor Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The barriers of masculine resistance are crumbling and it appears that American women will soon be allow to visit Antarctica.
A sharp upturn in industrial production by nations of the European Economic Community (common market) was forecast in a report released yesterday by the commission of the six-nation group.
A SECOND world - wide bridge tournament for United States Government personnel has been scheduled for this year, following the success of last year's.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter will meet tomorrow with close relatives of five American citizens still imprisoned in Communist China.
DES MOINES, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the welcoming address of Gov. Herschel C. Loveless of Iowa and the reply of Premier Khrushchev on his arrival at the Des Moines Airport today.

That The Times left unreported the death of Monte M. Lemann must surely be due to one of those rare mishaps in the comprehensive newsgathering by what has been rightly characterized the nation's greatest paper of record. You could not have left unnoticed by choice the end of so notable a life.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 22 -- The football world took little note nor long remembered what John Yovicsin said or did at Gettysburg, but since he came to Harvard from the little Pennsylvania college as head coach two years ago, Crimson grads the country over have had their biggest awakening in years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Defense Department has decided to push the development of a huge launching rocket that shows promise of reducing the Soviet lead in the space race.

BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, Sept. 23 -- A last-minute decision by railway workers to keep the country's trains running softened the impact of a scheduled two-day general strike that began last midnight. The work stoppages are expected to be wide-spread, however.
Following is the schedule of Premier Khrushchev's tour of the United States for today and tomorrow, with a summary of the rest of the program (all times regional):
VIENNA, Sept. 22 -- The Soviet Union's atomic energy delegation startled scientists and diplomats from seventy nations today with a harsh denunciation of the United States.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 22 -- Two leaders of the ruling Congress party in Sikkim said today that the small Himalayan state should join India immediately, the Hindustan Times of New Delhi reported.

VIENTIANE, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Laotian Government disclosed today that it had avoided accusing Communist North Vietnam of aggression in documents put before the special United Nations fact-finding committee.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 22 -- President Francois Duvalier hailed his recent victory over an invasion attempt in a broadcast today commemorating the end of the second year of his six-year term.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 22 -Two women were killed in freakish car crashes in Westchester County today.
BASLE, Switzerland, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Two leading music critics praised today Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic.
A three-month campaign of fire prevention in the home was opened yesterday by Mayor Wagner at a City Hall ceremony.
A new season of talk is dawning on Channel 13 after a summer of rehash and rerun.
GROTON, Conn., Sept. 22 -- The atomic submarine Patrick Henry, designed to fire ballistic missiles under water and on the surface, was launched today. She is the second ballistic-missile submarine.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Legislation granting the consent of Congress to an interstate compact establishing a New York-New Jersey Transportation Agency has been signed by President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Neither excessive over-all demand nor union-won wage gains were mainly responsible for the most recent period of inflation in the United States, it was reported today after a detailed study of the 1955-57 period.

NOW that summer is over, cooking schools here are getting down to serious business. Students who enroll soon will, in the main, find themselves finished with their course in time to impress their family or friends with a Thanksgiving dinner grand luxe.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- New influences in the market for grain futures today were not what they had seemed to be. Wheat weakened on a factor that had been described as bullish while soybeans were strong on an outlook that had been viewed as bearish.
BOSTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- An economist has forecast a long-term rise in American textile production between now and 1970.

The New York State Harness Racing Commission yesterday suspended Charles Fitzpatrick Jr., an owner, driver and trainer, for one year. Fitzpatrick was ordered to forfeit the $25,000 first-place money his horse Speedy Pick won in the National Pacing Derby.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Sept. 22 -- Nicholas Petrulli, the 38-year-old sheetmetal worker who renounced his United States citizenship while in the Soviet Union and later changed his mind, returned to his home here today "very tired and very nervous.''
Governor Rockefeller was the guess of honor yesterday at a Circus Saints and Sinners luncheon that presented skits lampooning his tax program and depicting his "plans" to move into the White House.
DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Ingemar Johansson arrived in Detroit by plane from London today.
HONG KONG, Sept. 22 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China said today that difficulties between communist China and Japan "are not insurmountable."

DES MOINES, Sept. 22 (AP) Following are the texts of speeches by Gov. Herschel C. Loveless of Iowa. Henry Cabot Lodge and Premier Khrushchev at a civic dinner here tonight. Mr. Khrushchev's speech was directly read for him by his translator:

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 22 -- Claud Ambrose Cardew, 89-year-old retired District Commissioner, an uncle of Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, was found stabbed to death in his bed at home in lonely Ncheu, in the Central Province of Nyasaland, early today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Civil Service Commission today ordered dismissal of three Utah Road Commission members. It found they had violated the Hatch Act by collecting political funds from fellow workers.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 -- With two Broadway stars in the leading roles, the San Francisco Actor's Workshop started the Ford Foundation's program for playwrights tonight.

Sixteen housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration have designated Oct. 20 as the marketing date for issues of public housing bonds totaling $102,145,000. The obligations will come due over forty years.

The rally in United States Government securities petered out yesterday after four trading sessions of rising prices. But investment grade corporate bonds and local Government obligations continued to gain.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Navy released today the first drawings of the radiotelescope now under construction near Sugar Grove, W. Va.

WEARING well-tailored trousers and shirt of non-beatnik brown, Yves Montand sang of love and life last night at Henry Miller's Theatre. Te sang in French, but the audience didn't seem to notice it since he explained each song in only slightly fractured English.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that he hoped nothing would be done in the United Nations to prejudice the "just and peaceful solution for Algeria" contained in President Charles de Gaulle's plan.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 -- The last obstacle was removed today for a return of the International Longshoremen's Association to the mainstream of American labor.

The city Youth Board said yesterday it had noticed tension mounting for more than three weeks in the south central Bronx, where the latest gang murder took place on Monday afternoon. But, board officials said they had lacked the manpower to saturate the area in an effort to prevent a serious clash.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- A signal borrowed from the Soviet Union's Sputnik III officially opened a $24,000,000 business equipment exposition today.

FOR the first time, the annual Children's Carnival at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, is being held outdoors. Protected by a huge plastic dome designed by Buckminster Fuller, the seventeenth annual show opened to the public yesterday.
DUNKIRK, N. Y., Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Alco Products, Inc., said today that it had received an order to build the steam generator for an 11.4 megowatt nuclear power reactor planned at Piqua, Ohio.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- About 200 university students from:the United Arab Republic who were enrolled in Russian schools last year will reportedly complete their studies in the United States.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 22 -- The United Arab Republic and its sympathizers are reaching a new crescendo in criticism of Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq.

New York University will resume its social work courses for the new academic year on Friday with an almost totally new teaching body that was said yesterday to assure the future status of the program.

Despite mergers, the biggest banks in the country are barely maintaining their share of the nation's deposits, M. A. Schapiro Co., bank stock dealers, report in the latest issue of their publication, Bank Stock Quarterly.
Events today: Peter Jensen, organist, St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel; Broadway and Fulton Street, 12:30 P. M.; Lise Schneider, pianist, National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, 8:30.

"THE MERMAID MADONNA,"* by Stratis Myrivilis, who is known as the leading living Greek writer, makes the ways of an old world new. In this novel, half legend and half commentary, Mr. Myrivilis shows us how the tumult that stirs a small Aegean community reflects the turmoil of the universe.
ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The State Conservation Department set the dates today for special open seasons on deer in ten counties.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Consumer Price Index declined by one-tenth of 1 per cent last month after having risen for four consecutive months.
A Federal narcotics agent told a City Council committee yesterday that the "biggest" and most skillful "dope peddlers are in New York City."

COON RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 23 -- Premier Khrushchev indicated in a farmyard conference with Adlai E. Stevenson today that there were prospects for fruitful negotiation between the United States and the Soviet Union.

President Eisenhower, in a message made public here yesterday by the White House, described the fall campaign of the United Fund and Community Chest as "an enterprise which I believe is in the finest tradition of American generosity."
Despite calls for unity, new bitterness flared among Manhattan Democratic factions yesterday as they prepared for the meeting of their county executive committee today.

You remarked editorially on Sept. 19: "* * * if Mr. Khrushchev really wants to improve relations, why doesn't he improve them?" In line with this thought may I suggest one very simple way in which he could improve relations with the United States with a single brief statement.
In his Press Club discussion Khrushchev stated that Lenin advocated the "coexistence" of communism and capitalism. This was, of course, a purposely misleading statement on his part.

NEWARK, Sept. 23 -- A suit to require the Port of New York Authority and its bondholders to pay Federal taxes on income from "proprietary enterprises" was filed in the Federal District Court here today.
AMES, Iowa, Sept. 23 -- Thousands of students cheered as Premier Khrushchev drove up to Iowa State College today.
President Eisenhower warned yesterday that free collective bargaining might be on trial in the steel strike. He appealed anew for stronger efforts to end the walkout.

WARSAW, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The sale of meat in Warsaw was restricted today because of difficulties in buying animals for slaughter and the demands of the export trade, the Polish agency P. A. P. reported.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 23 -- Knight Pilot, driven by Stanley Dancer, scored a three-quarter length victory in the Commander pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The time for the mile-and-one-quarter race was 2:38 4-5.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 23 -- For a length of seven blocks, on Saturday and Sunday, streets in the center of New Canaan's business zone will be lined with paintings, sculptures, architectural models and photographic prints representing the best work of Fairfield County amateur and professional artists.

WENTWORTH - BY - THE-SEA, N. H., Sept. 23 -- Members of the Wool Manufacturers' Council of the National Textile Association today criticized the recent announcement by the State Department that it would renegotiate the tariffs on wools and worsteds with Great Britain.

TUNIS, Sept. 23 -- Algerian nationalist leaders here gave evidence today that they want the widest possible support for the response they have drafted to President Charles de Gaulle's plan for self-determination in Algeria.
THURMONT, Md., Sept. 23 (AP) -- In this town of about 2,000 population the police chief is a six-footer named James Dubell. In fact, Mr. Dubell is the entire police force -- and he's a mite worried.
BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, Sept. 23 -- Sir Robert P. Armitage, Governor of Nyasaland, appointed four new African members of the Nyasaland Legislative Council today.
Life insurance companies are among the largest financial backers of the United States merchant marine, a survey conducted by the Institute of Life Insurance disclosed yesterday.

The problem of the revolutionary leader who enters politics after the triumph of his revolution is always difficult. Greece and Cyprus are seeing this now in the attempt of General Grivas to make political capital of his reputation as the leader of the Greek Cypriote underground against the British for four years.
THE night before last, at the Bridge House, Henry Enoch's venerable bridge club. William Dunlop was dealt the following hand:
MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The Soviet press softened its criticisms today of the United States handling of Premier Khrushchev's tour and once again described his travels in glowing terms.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- President Eisenhower received today the B'nai B'rith President's Medal, the highest award of the Jewish service organization, for his "positive efforts for peace on freedom's terms -- peace with justice and dignity."
DARJEELING, India, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Tibetan sources said today that 50,000 guerrillas were fighting Chinese Communists in a new surge of rebellion.
Increased Federal controls over firearms, other weapons and the illicit narcotics traffic were urged yesterday by Mayor Wagner and Governor Rockefeller.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The use of Civil Defense sirens last night to herald the Chicago White Sox' first American League title in forty years touched off a Federal investigation today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Democratic Advisory Council urged the Eisenhower Administration today to make prompt use of Premier Khrushchev's disarmament proposals "as a basis for negotiation by our Government."

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- A French Government spokesman expressed general satisfaction today over a statement yesterday by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter interpreted here as sympathetic to President Charles de Gaulle's plan for settling the future of Algeria.

LEO RITTER suspects that he is probably the only furrier in New York with a fruit-bearing apple tree outside his window. Certainly, the last thing a visitor to a showroom in the somber fur district expects to find is an orchard.

Osamu Takeda is a man with a mission -- to restore the prestige of the Japanese spaniel in his native land. This ancient breed, the favorite of Japanese nobility for centuries, almost disappeared from Japan during World War II.

In a drive to get voters to approve the $500 million bond issue next November the Board of Education recently released a report on physical facilities in which it declared that 366 city school buildings must be replaced or modernized.
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Sir Winston Churchill asked the people of Britain tonight to trust the Conservative party to preserve their well-being at home and the orderly conduct of their relations abroad

A small park in Brooklyn Heights was named yesterday for Dr. Edward Robinson Squibb, who was too conscientious to accept more for land he sold the city than he thought it was worth.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Prices of grain futures worked into a broad general advance today on the Board of Trade, with soybeans among the leaders for the second successive time.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -- The head of the local Hungarian Freedom Fighters was found beaten today in Golden Gate Park.
Capt. Joseph B. Fallon of the Boston Police ruled out homicide yesterday in the death of Mrs. Lynn Kauffman, whose body was found on Spectacle Island in Boston Harbor last Saturday.

COON RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 23 -- Mme. Nina Petrovna Khrushchev disappointed the citizens of this town of 1,700 today by failing to pay them an expected visit. She decided to accompany her husband instead on a tour of the Garst farm.

At a luncheon on Oct. 6 the Visiting Nurse Service of New York will honor a new executive director, Miss Anna Fillmore, and formally open its 1959 fund-raising campaign for $508,000. The event will take place at the organization's headquarters building, 107 East Seventieth Street.

A professional blaster trying to dispose of four leftover sticks of dynamite by burning them set off an explosion that jarred West Ninety-third Street yesterday afternoon. At least sixteen persons were injured by the concussion and by flying glass as several hundred windows were shattered.
THE chairman of the Senate subcommittee investigating juvenile delinquency is perhaps better known as a leader in the fight for a Federal civil-rights program.

ATLANTA, Sept. 23 (AP) The president of the teamsters told a news conference that the union would return to federated labor if it were recognized as an autonomous unit. However, he said that if the teamsters were again affiliated with the A. F. L.-C. I. O., "we could not accept an amendment that a man could not exercise his rights under the Fifth Amendment."
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 23 -- The automobile industry was urged by the American Automobile Association today to provide more efficient safety devices for motor vehicles.
COON RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 23 -- When Premier Khrushchev arrived at the Garst farm here today, everything was wired for sound but the hogs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Frank Leahy, former Notre Dame football coach, denied today that he had pocketed any of the profits from lucrative stock sales for a Denver oil and gas concern.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Seventeen of the world's major coffee producing nations reached final agreement today on an export control agreement. The pact, repreesnting a further advance toward a world-wide coffee price stabilization accord, is aimed at holding prices firm by balancing supplies with demand. It is expected to be signed formally tomorrow.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Frank Lane, general manager of the Indians, reversed his field today and renamed Joe Gordon as field manager for two years.

THE winning dish in the eleventh annual "Pillsbury Bake-Off" was for a Mardi Gras Party Cake. It was made by Mrs. Eunice Surles of Lake Charles, La., who received the top prize of $25,000. Her recipe follows:

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., Sept. 23 -- A lot of good fishing and weather are going to waste here because there aren't enough fishermen. It was true today and it probably has been true every weekday since Labor Day.
COON RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 23 -- "I don't know if it'll do any good, but we all hope it will. I guess it can't do any harm."

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- The center of attraction at Wrigley Field today when Chicago met San Francisco was neither a Cub nor a Giant. It was Al Lopez, the manager of the American League's champion White Sox. Lopez was accompanied by Bill Veeck, the Sox' general manager, as they occupied a box near home plate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Owners of United States savings bonds are advised by the Treasury that there is nothing they need do with their old securities to make sure that the new and higher interest rates apply.
ARCHITECTS and interior designers agreed Tuesday evening that they could not quite agree.

As an American who loves America and its tradition of fair play and good sportsmanship I was deeply ashamed of the childish, petulant and spiteful behavior of so many of our people in "greeting" Khrushchev.

The International Longshoremen's Association celebrated its first day of membership in the merged labor movement yesterday by making "cuts all along the line" in its demands for a new waterfront labor contract.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Wilson Co., deadlocked in negotiations with the United Packinghouse Workers Union, today put into effect a 10 1/2 cent-an-hour pay rise and other benefits that the union had rejected.

Homer Carnagey, in his letter printed in your Sept. 19 issue, objects to the questioning of Mr. Khrushchev by members of the Press Club. I assume he must also take exception to the questioning at the Economic Club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Yankees helped the Washington Senators wind up their home business for the season tonight and little Bobby Richardson helped make it a losing affair for the Nats.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A spokesman for the families of five Americans imprisoned in Communist China reported today that President Eisenhower might bring their plight before Premier Khrushchev.

BUTLER, Pa., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said tonight that the United States must not be lulled by Premier Khrushchev's visit into accepting a "live and let live" agreement with the Communists.
PARIS, Sept. 23 -- The Government took a small step today toward restoring good relations with French war veterans.
COON RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The folks out here in Iowa set a mighty nice table today for Premier Khrushchev.
ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The cost of a higher education has risen as much as 51 per cent in New York State over the last six years.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 23 -- Leaders of India's ruling Congress party conferred here today on a proposal to divide the state of Bombay into two. The purpose of the division would be to avoid a repetition of the bitter riots of 1956 in which hundreds were killed.
HYANNIS, Mass., Sept. 23 -- Walter F. Munford, president of the United States Steel Corporation, was in Cape Cod Hospital here tonight with knife wounds in the abdomen.
TRENTON, Sept. 23 -- A mysterious affliction has claimed fifteen victims in South Jersey in the last ten days, and six have died.

Many companies have indicated recently an interest in having their officials enter politics. Last week the Ford Motor Company announced an educational program to equip employes for political and community activity. It also said employes elected to political office could maintain their seniority and other benefits if they desired.

MIDDLETON, England, Sept. 23 -- The British equivalent of a whistle stop in an election campaign is a dusty lot in the center of this mill town on the main road from Manchester to Rochdale. On three sides sprawl red brick mills, on the fourth runs the busy highway.

The City Stores Company, which includes the Franklin Simon and Oppenheim, Collins stores units, national retail store organization, reported yesterday increased sales for the twenty-six and fifty-two week periods ended on Aug. 1. Earnings for the year were less than those of a year earlier, while the loss in the half-year period this year was half that a year earlier.

At a special meeting yesterday at Cleveland, Ohio, stockholders of Eaton Manufacturing Company approved an increase in the authorized capital stock from 3,000,000 shares of $2 par value each to 10,000,000 shares of $1 par value, and a two-for-one split of the $2 par value stock.

Increases in Blue Cross rates, the small representation of labor on the board of directors, limitations on the coverage given, the low wages paid to non-professional hospital employes -- underpaid staffs and allegedly underserved patients -- have combined to create a dream of do-it-yourself grandeur in the minds of New York labor union leaders.

IT is a far cry from the grape vines of Madison Avenue to those of Rockland County, but Everett Crosby knows much about both. Ten years ago, he was a successful script writer for radio and television. In 1950, he forfeited the world of electronics for vineyards on the towering slopes of High Tor.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Ireland advocated today the establishment of a nuclear-free zone in Central Europe that would be guaranteed by a permanent United Nations military force. Frank Aiken, Irish Minister for External Affairs, made the proposal.
The Reform branch of Judaism began an unusual four-day campaign last night to bring unaffiliated Jews into the synagogue.
DES MOINES, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Premier Khrushchev consoled a weeping mother today and promised to let her two children in Soviet Lithuania rejoin her.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23 -- Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic showed Belgrade tonight how music can be played. In their first of two concerts in Yugoslavia, the musicians, despite the handicap of an acoustically poor hall, gave a performance of such shimmering beauty as to evoke almost awe in the hearers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- President Eisenhower signed the "third-try" housing bill today without comment. He had vetoed two earlier bills mainly on the ground that they called for too much spending.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Jordan's chief delegate told the General Assembly today that the Arab states were united in opposing Israel's claim to a right to use the Suez Canal.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 -- Roger Craig pitched the Dodgers back into a tie for the National League lead tonight by shutting out the Cardinals, 3 -- 0, on five hits.

VIENNA, Sept. 23 -- The atomic powers were urged here today to turn over the job of inspecting and safeguarding their own projects for peaceful use of nuclear energy to the two-year-old International Atomic Energy Agency.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 16:

Pullman, Inc. expanded its operations into another field of activity through the acquisition yesterday of the 110-year-old Swindell - Dressler Corporation. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

Governor Rockefeller has performed a public service by calling attention to the fact that in the sometimes sharp debates between Premier Khrushchev and his questioners the real issue between East and West has become obscured by Communist terminology.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The Federal Government announced today that it had allocated 150 scholarships to fifty state agencies and fourteen universities to train teachers of mentally retarded children.

Gasoline inventories in the nation resumed their seasonal decline last week after a post-Labor Day rise the week before. The continuing high level of stocks was reflected, however, in a new series of price cuts in the mid-Continent region, where major refiners trimmed wholesale prices to 12 cents a gallon, a cut of 1/4 cent.
Copper prices rose yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange. It was final notice day for the September position. Eighty notices were issued and were well received.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -- Twenty-five maritime unions formally established a united front today, ending a feud that had once been the bitterest in all labor.
"Eat the bread and the salt, but also speak your mind," said Premier Khrushchev as he traded barbs with his luncheon hosts in Los Angeles.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Two players shared the lead after the first eighteen holes of the New York State Senior Golf Association's fall tourney today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -- George Meany punctuated a fiery debate tonight over Jim Crow practices in unions by a shouted denunciation of the merged labor federation's only Negro vice president.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 23 -- The Planning and Zoning Commission has approved a 164-acre site for a $700,000 municipal golf course here.

Two books by James A. Michener, one nonfiction, the other fiction, will be published in the next two months. On Oct. 1, the Charles E. Tuttle Company of Rutland, Vt., will issue "Japanese Prints From the Early Masters to the Modern."
There is a pressing need for a "quality house," a better kind of home than is now being built, the nation's mortgage bankers were told yesterday.

COON RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 23 -- Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov said today that both Soviet and United States security officials were to blame for overzealousness in measures taken for Premier Khrushchev's safety.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The press and political worlds of Washington paid affectionate tribute to Walter Lippmann today on his seventieth birthday.

WASHINGTON, Sept 23 -- A special Federal Communications Commission examiner rejected today charges that improper influence had figured in the award of Boston television Channel 5 to The Herald-Traveler Corporation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Italy rebuked Austria today for having brought up the question of South Tyrol in the United Nations. Foreign Minister Giuseppe Pella said that the situation there was a purely domestic Italian issue and not the concern of the world body.

PITTSBURGH, Thursday, Sept. 24 -- Premier Khrushchev, happily clutching a bronze key to the city, was greeted by a crowd of 7,000 in downtown Pittsburgh early this morning when he arrived from Iowa for a brief visit.
Two luxury food shops will open on the upper East Side today under the sponsorship of Daitch Crystal Dairies, Inc.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 23 -- A Peronist - Communist labor front called out more than 2,000,000 workers today in a general strike against the economic policies of the Frondizi Government.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23 -- With three solid singles in the eighth inning, the Pittsburgh Pirates rocked the National League pennant race tonight from here to Milwaukee and points farther West.
Nine members of the Television Information Committee will meet here today to elect a director for the industry's joint effort to tell America that TV is better than ever.

A retired Army nurse wrote a note yesterday appealing for more understanding of juvenile gangs. She bequeathed her jewelry to help the younsters and then stepped out of the window of her nineteenth-story hotel room.
FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- A 30-year-old United States Army private, sentenced to death in 1951, was hanged today for the murder of a Korean civilian.
A new comedy spoofing the last days of the Trojan wars, called "Homer's Follies," is being readied for Broadway presentation this season.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- The filming of movies abroad by American producers was a subject of considerable discussion here today.
Eddie Arcaro had to do an ultra-vigorous job of fore-and-aft larruping at Aqueduct yesterday to get the 2-5 Irish Jay home by a neck in the $35,300 Demoiselle for 2-year-old fillies.

CAIRO, Sept. 23 -- A group of students and workers estimated to total 3,000 to 5,000 marched through Cairo today to protest the execution in Baghdad last Sunday of thirteen "leaders" of the Iraqi revolution.
Commercial bankers in New York State want an end to the freeze on bank holding companies, but no changes in the State Banking Law, the New York State Bankers Association said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Arrangements for a possible multiple play-off for the National League pennant were made today when representatives of the three clubs involved met with the league president, Warren Giles.
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Customers of the Consolidated Edison Company here were asked to conduct a sit-down strike today because of a new 10-cent charge on bill collections.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 23 -- American schools were severely criticized here today as having failed to meet current demands. They were praised for past contributions but taken to task for their performance in the face of an upsurge in education.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Trans World Airlines and United Air Lines complained today that improper attempts had been made to influence the Civil Aeronautics Board against them in a New York-San Francisco nonstop service case.

A group of governmental and civic leaders in New York and New Jersey charged yesterday that "arbitrary" action by the Federal Bureau of the Budget threatened the economic progress of the seventeen-county metropolitan area.
Newspapers have taken stock of the contribution they made last spring toward increasing the sales of automobiles and have concluded that they did a good job.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 23 -- Influenced by the success of Louisiana State a year ago, more and more football coaches are planning to substitute by teams this year, though few are blessed with sufficient talent to field a third defensive unit of Chinese bandits.
PECONIC, L. I., Sept. 23 -- Eight-year-old Sandra Swiatocha learned today that she will get to display her giant pumpkin in public after all.

Directors of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company increased the quarterly dividend on the present common stock yesterday with the declaration of 60 cents a share for payment on Nov. 2. In previous quarters shareholders received 55 cents.

TROY, N. Y., Sept, 23 -- The Democratic state organization, given by factionalism and still smarting from its 1958 defeat, demonstrated tonight that it still has powerful allies in pivoted industrial states.
Bond prices were little changed yesterday.
The legend of George Washington and the cherry tree seems to have made a lasting impression on Melvin Tuller.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- A campaign is being started this week to bring to United States polar research a maximum of university talent.
The city's Health Department is planning to change tactics in its rat-eradication program.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Two police officers shouldered their way through dozens of anxious investors besieging the Mayfair office of the State Building Society for infor mation or to withdraw their investments. Neither was forthcoming.
GENEVA, Sept. 23 -- The United States and the Soviet Union are to work together on a five-nation committee to study the problem of radio communications with outer space.
LONDON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Maria Callas received a five-minute ovation tonight after a concert performance at London's Royal Festival Hall.

American Machine and Foundry Company's "international atomic school" at Greenwich, Conn., is now working with the Atomic Energy Commission's division of international affairs in training foreign nuclear engineers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce laid before President Eisenhower today a proposal for helping American business men compete more effectively with the Communist economic offensive.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Defense Department reorganized its space program again today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Rudy Ellis withstood Rory Calhoun's body attack with ease tonight and won the decision in a ten-round fight for his eighth straight triumph.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- The San Francisco Giants, desperately striving to hang on in the National League's pennant race, were virtually eliminated today. And once again it was a two-out homer that sank them, this time in the tenth inning.

Harry Canelstein, New York and Florida realty investor, has sold the one-story motorboat showroom building at 281-83 East 161st Street in the Melrose section of the Bronx. The structure, 50 by 200 feet, is occupied by a motorboat dealer.

Irving Maidman, realty investor and builder, has purchased the New York warehouse and office building of Morningstar Paisley. Inc., at 627-29 West Fiftieth Street running through to 622-30 West Fifty-first Street, between Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues.
The mountain of paper work involved in the distribution of the New York Telephone Company's 9,000,000 telephone directories in the metropolitan area will largely be eliminated next month.

The president of the American Council for Judaism, Clarence L. Coleman Jr., yesterday called the proposed sale of Israeli bonds in synagogues during the forthcoming High Holy Days of Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur a "desecration."
CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 (UPI) A gunman who threatened to blow up the family of a bank manager in an attempted robbery shot and killed himself today when cornered by the police.
The 1960 line of Ford Motor Company trucks was introduced here yesterday. More than 480 models will be available, according to Wilbur Chase, truck-marketing manager for the company's Ford Division.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury, declared today that it would be inconsistent with the nation's basic ideals for the Government to use its powers to guarantee a record-breaking rate of growth, year after year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 James R. Hoffa has ordered all units of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to take immediate steps to oust convicted felons from their payrolls.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The 1960 campaign opens in earnest tomorrow in Wisconsin.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Panama taxed the United States with discrimination here today, while Guatemala charged Britain with colonialism.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Boston and Maine Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to postpone payment on some of its first mortgage bonds maturing in 1960 and 1961, subject to approval of 75 per cent of the bondholders.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 -- The Federal Government moved swiftly today to bring to court five alleged racketeers charged with conspiring to gain control of Don Jordan, the welterweight boxing champion.

On the eve of his talks with President Eisenhower at Camp David, in Maryland, it is clear that Premier Khrushchev has not changed his attitudes on the key issues outstanding between the Soviet Union and the United States.
An engine breakdown on the Boston-bound Merchants Limited in the Bronx at 5:15 P. M. yesterday delayed forty-five commuter trains carrying almost 40,000 passengers.

A RESPECTABLE anthology of nineteenth and twentieth century sculpture and drawing emerges when the exhibits at the Fine Arts Associates Gallery, 41 East Fifty-seventh, and the Peridot Gallery, 820 Madison at Sixty-seventh Street, are put together.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Members of the House of Representatives have started fanning out on their annual inspection trips at home and abroad.
Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, last night challenged Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa to debate the $500,000,000 school-bond issue on television.
The aviation industry has drawn kind words, for a change, from some local citizens who have been fighting the battle against aircraft noise.
COON RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 23 -- Premier Khrushchev has maintained contact with Moscow by means of elaborate communications and a substantial entourage.

The increase in consumer prices, as measured by the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which had proceeded without interruption for the four months April-July was interrupted, momentarily at least, in August. The index for August shows a nominal downturn from the July high of 124.9 to 124.8. That is, by one-tenth of a point, or about eight one-hundredths of 1 per cent.
COON RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- A telephone rang today on the wall of United Press International's temporary newspictures headquarters in a barn on Roswell Garst's farm.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 23 -- A group of world scholars emphasized today the continuing importance of the study of the humanities and ancient classics in the modern world.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad the last several years has been making ends meet largely by disposing of surplus railroad property and equipment no longer needed for train operation. Yesterday the carrier sold its Van Nest repair shops in the Bronx to the Consolidated Edison Company for $3,000,000.
Twenty-seven men and boys and an arsenal were seized in the Bronx last night as the police headed off a gang war resulting from the fatal shooting of a teen-ager Monday at Morris High School.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office reported yesterday that it was investigating the possibility that the home telephone of Charles E. McGuinness had been tapped.

An Italian producer of polypropylene fiber and plastics announced yesterday that it would market textile-cut staple fiber in Italy at about 60 cents a pound. The price here by Reeves Brothers, Inc., one of the American companies producing a similar product, is almost double that amount.

Electric power production fell to a four-month low of 12,779,000,000 kilowatt hours in the week ended last Saturday from 13,109,000,000 kilowatt hours the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
Prices for stocks staged a long-awaited rally yesterday, adding about $3,600,000,000, or 1.23 per cent, to the market value of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange.

Ingmar Bergman's "The Magician," in the first three weeks of its American premiere engagement at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, has grossed $33,438, reportedly breaking all box-office records in the theatre's twenty-eight-year history.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 1 to 13 points (5 to 65 cents a bale) yesterday. July was the weakest month.

ROCKY COLAVITO of the Cleveland Indians made a bad play and the alert, swift-moving White Sox capitalized on it to score the winning run. The crowd booed Colavito with jeering intensity. He was brooding in front of his locker after the game when a gentle hand pressed against his shoulder.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 -- Charles S. Desmond of Buffalo was nominated today to run in this fall's election as both the Democratic and Republican candidate for chief judge of the Court of Appeals. He is now the court's senior associate judge.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Seven men indicted for a conspiracy to defraud Teamster Local 107 surrendered to the police today. Moments later they were released on bail pending a hearing on their contention that they had been denied due process of law.

An agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation shot a man early in an altercation that followed an automobile chase. The pusuit started when the agent's car was sideswiped on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, the police said.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 23 -- In the first military briefings here in forty-eight hours, the Laotian Army said today that fighting had continued during the last few days in Samneua and Luang Prabang Provinces.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses has revived a six-year-old plan for widening the streets around Washington Square Park. He says he will not approve closing the roads through the park unless the plan goes through.
Carmine G. De Sapio was re-elected New York County Democratic leader yesterday. There were ten votes in the Tammany executive committee for him and six abstentions.
Development of a plastic film strong enough to be used for flexible gasoline tanks in automobiles was announced yesterday by the B. F. Goodrich Industrial Products Company.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 24 -- Humanistic studies may properly be broadened to embrace cultures and civilizations previously neglected, speakers told a meeting of world scholars today.
