MOSCOW, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther was accused in a Soviet statement today of spreading fantastic inventions in telling of exchanges at the San Francisco meeting of United States labor leaders with Premier Khrushchev.

WENTWORTH - BY - THE-SEA, N. H., Sept. 24 -- Members of the National Textile Association at the concluding session of its 105th annual meeting today were given an encouraging picture of the industry's outlook, Seabury Stanton, president of Berkshire-Hathaway Inc., and the group's new chairman, said that conditions had changed in the past year and that the textile industry was now showing improved profits.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 24 -- An aftermath of Premier Khrushchev's visit was that it dramatized charges of immorality by critics who are much more feared in Hollywood than is the Soviet Premier.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 24 -- A burst of speed in the final sixteenth enabled Laura Scott, driven by Frank Darish, to score a one-and-one-half-length victory over Major Prim in the Mount Auburn Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24 -- The forty-eight-hour general strike called by the Peronist-Communist labor command withered today in its second day, despite attempts by terrorists to keep up public alarm.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies has set its highest fund goal $21,250,000, for its 1959-60 campaign.
The Stork Club management filed a $4,000,000 suit yesterday in Manhattan Supreme Court against two restaurant workers' unions and seventeen individuals.
Your editorial of Sept. 17 concerning the results of the New York Democratic primaries misses two important points.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The odds in favor of a Conservative party victory in the Oct. 8 general election appear to be shortening and the Labor party is gaining confidence in its ability to win.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies contributed a refreshing note to the baseball scene today. Officials blamed the club's last-place finish on the players and rehired Manager Eddie Sawyer for another year. Terms of the new contract were not disclosed.

The Gulf Oil Corporation has announced the election of R. O. Rhoades as chairman. Mr. Rhoades, formerly executive vice president, succeeds David Proctor, who will retire on Sept. 30 after forty years with Gulf.
Six semi-finalists were selected yesterday in the Leventritt Piano Competition. They were chosen from sixty-three talented young pianists who entered the contest.
Premier Khrushchev has affirmed on his trip to the United States that while "the time is not ripe yet" the day may come when Jews and other citizens will be permitted to leave the Soviet Union.

IT must be easier to write solemn novels than humorous ones. If it weren't, surely more novelists would invoke the comic spirit. The varied spectacle of human living provides ample material for comedy and the comic approach to life and art is not only venerable; it is venerated. Nevertheless, most supposedly humorous novels are flat and clumsy, altogether lacking in subtlety and wit.
ALBANY, Sept. 24 -- Governor Rockefeller passed a key test for Presidential aspirants today. He got photographed wearing a fireman's helmet.
STONE HARBOR, N. J., Sept. 24 -- Robert Rice, a 30-year-old marine engineer of Miami, Fla., will have an eighty-room hotel all to himself for the next six weeks.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Tibetan guerillas are waging war against Communist China's troops with knives, old firearms and whatever weapons they can capture, an elder brother of the exiled Dalai Lama said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Humberto Robinson, a pitcher for the Philadelphia Phillies, told authorities today a cafe owner had offered $1.500 to him to throw the second game of last Tuesday's double-header with Cincinnati.
BRADFORD, Pa., Sept. 24 (AP) -- A volatile anesthetic exploded during an operation yesterday and a 24-year-old mother was killed, a hospital official said today.

NYACK, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- A group of Marine Midland bankers directors and advisory board members from all parts of the state toured Rockland County today. They were shown available industrial and business sites here in a movement to bring industry into Rockland.
The Greater New York Hospital Association announced yesterday a program to reduce unnecessary hospitalization.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Following is a list of those attending a dinner given here tonight by Eric Ridder, publisher of The Journal of Commerce, for Premier Krushchev:

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Buddy Dial, a 1958 all-America end from Rice and the New York Giants' No. 2 choice in the last National Football League draft, was claimed today by the Pittsburgh Steelers.
Federal, state and city mediators were asked yesterday to take an active part in lagging waterfront contract talks.
A new library-classroom building, the Adele Lehman Hall-Wollman Library was opened by Barnard College at an informal ribbon-cutting ceremony before classes yesterday, the first day of the semester.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today issued orders barring five major cigarette makers from paying discriminatory promotional allowances to favored retailers and vending machine operators.

Kings County Judge Samuel Leibowitz called on Mayor Wagner and other officials yesterday to discourage migrants "from all parts of the country and the Caribbean" from coming here until the city had overcome crime-breeding slums.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office was criticized yesterday for not having advised Carmine G. De Sapio's primary opponent before the election that his home telephone might have been tapped.
A scientific instrument company has good news for persons who dread getting medical check-ups because they fear "the needle" used in making blood tests.
The 200 contestants in the thirty-fourth annual World's Championship Rodeo took over Madison Square Garden last night.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., Sept. 24 -- The open boats that put out of this port will be devoting themselves mainly to cod from now on. Other bottom fish are still here, but they're not so numerous as they had been and the rugged vessels of the party fleet are ranging farther.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 -- Mme. Nina Petrovna Khrushchev was entertained here today by a rhythm band of patients in the new children's hospital.
DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 24 -- The 1960 standard size Ford will be the longest, lowest and widest in the fifty-six-year history of the Ford Motor Company.

Pearl Primus, American dancer and anthropologist, has been appointed by the Government of Liberia as the first director of a performing arts center to be set up in the capital city of Monrovia, in affiliation with the University of Liberia.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Mrs. Golda Meir, Foreign Minister of Israel, denounced the United Arab Republic today for refusing to permit Israeli ships or cargoes to go through the Suez Canal.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 24 -- The head of the New Jersey School Superintendents Association expressed the hope today that "New Jersey will not be the last state in the nation to adopt the broader tax base -- sales or income -- on which a fairer system of school support can be built."
The 1960 Pontiac, with sixteen models in four series, will go on display at dealer showrooms next Thursday.

Business loans by the larger New York City banks rose $51,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. However, loans to finance companies, factors and other business credit companies dropped $158,000,000.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- A divorce decree and an out-of-court property settlement today ended the marriage of the Clarke Jelkes.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 24 (AP) -- An Atlas-Able moon rocket exploded during an engine test today. The mishap postponed a United States effort to reach the moon, as the Soviet Union has done, and prompted a study of other space probes planned for this fall.
A 26-year-old Belgian woman who had arrived in this country the day before was shot but not seriously wounded by an intruder yesterday.
The city was accused yesterday of "dragging its feet" in putting into effect a plan to provide treatment for adult narcotics addicts.

Senator Thruston B. Morton, Republican national chairman, promised Governor Rockefeller yesterday that he would "try to run a completely fair convention" for the nomination of a Presidential slate next year.

The TXL Oil Corporation cleared $3,156,438 in the nine months ended Aug. 31, after providing $730,000 for estimated Federal income taxes, the company said yesterday. This compared with $2,534,998 earned in the period of the preceding year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- About 700,000 fans swarmed over State and La Salle Streets today to pay tribute to the American League champion Chicago White Sox. Under a shower of ticker tape and paper streamers, a fleet of convertibles, preceded by thre bands, carried the Sox president, Bill Veeck; Mayor Richard J. Daley and the baseball club's vice president, Charles Comiskey, at the head of a victory parade.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Cuba's Minister of State declared today that his country did not have to choose between capitalism and communism and preferred to follow its "own road."

New York voters yesterday were urged to approve an amendment to the State Constitution that would permit the lease or transfer of the State Barge Canal to the Federal Government. Three committees of the New York Chamber of Commerce made the appeal.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- John Ahern, a 64-year-old Buffalo banker, won the New York State Senior Golf Association's fall tournament today at the Westchester Country Club.

YOU will just have to hold your breath a little bit longer. The frenzied National League pennant race was in a state of suspended animation yesterday. No games were played. The day off gave the jittery contenders a chance to gather their strength and quiet their jangled nerves, the last pause before plunging into the pressure cooker of the final three days of the season.

TRENTON, Sept. 24 -- The United States Public Health Service today ordered two of its physicians and a veterinarian to aid state health officials in their investigation of a mysterious affliction that has killed six persons. Nine other persons have been made ill in the ten-day outbreak.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Premier Khrushchev returned to Washington tonight with a call for talks with President Eisenhower based on reason and not force.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- August exports, seasonally adjusted, fell back a little from those of July but maintained a pace sharply higher than in the first half of this year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The approval of contracts for architect and engineering services for the Government's first three saline water conversion demonstration plants was announced today.
HONG KONG, Sept. 24 -- The Peiping radio said today that the United States' stand against the admission of Communist China to the United Nations "has become increasingly unpopular."
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- If the Khrushchevs came here to learn something about America, a first prize for effort and perhaps achievement should be awarded to 24-year-old Sergei.
BORDEAUX, France, Friday, Sept. 25 -- A French DC-7 airliner bound for West Africa crashed, burned and exploded here late last night. Fifty-three of sixty-five persons aboard were reported killed.

EXPRESSIONISM is a house of as many mansions as meanings. The particular aspeect explored in tthe current show of paintings at Galerie St. Etienne, 46 West Fifty-seventh Street, is its early twentieth-century Austrian and German manifestation, a question of nerves and psychological insight, with Kokoschka as the chief investigator.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., Sept. 24 -- The seecond year of private school began today for 440 white pupils. The segregated classes are sponsored by the Warren County Educational Foundation.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 24 For the second time this month a Wesleyan University chapter of a national fraternity has severed its connections with a parent body over discrimination issues. This was announced today by the university.
The 1959 volume of national advertising through July was 7 per cent above last year's level.

"Unions and Union Leadership," a compendium of views and comments by newspaper reporters, educators. economists, sociologists and psychologists, will be published Wednesday by Harper. Among the topics discussed are: the status of the labor movement today, where it is headed, bargaining relationship between unions and management, racketeering, Communist infiltration, the Negro worker and government intervention.

Unremitting dissension in Democratic ranks in Queens virtually ended the last hope last night for the nomination of a bipartisan slate of candidates for the Supreme Court in the Tenth Judicial District.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 24 -- The Laos conflict has been transformed into a war of propaganda.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 24 -- Mrs. Pat Cici of Lido and Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood gained the final round today in the Women's Long Island Golf Association match-play championship at the Nassau Country Club.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Guenther Fritz Podola was sentenced to death today for the murder of a London detective July 13.
The third annual tour of houses sponsored by the Nassau-Suffolk Division of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation will take place Tuesday afternoon. The tour will be repeated on Oct. 6.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Navy has proposed the establishment of a unified command on military space and missile development that would be operated directly under the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

Paul Keres and Tigran Petrosian, two of the four Russians in the world challengers' chess tournament at Bled, played an uneventful draw in the eleventh round, according to a report last night from Yugoslavia.
DES MOINES, Sept. 24 -- A Soviet educator has made a concrete proposal for an exchange program in the field of peaceful use of atomic energy, an official at Iowa State University said today.

Four industrial buildings fronting for 400 feet on Newtown Creek, Long Island City, Queens, have been purchased by the Harrison Products Corporation, the world's largest manufacturer of plastic containers for the cosmetic trade.

A black market in babies -- believed to be a million-dollar-a-year business with loan-shark and policy racket sidelines -- was uncovered yesterday in Brooklyn, according to District Attorney Edward S. Silver.

Norman P. Mason, administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, yesterday hailed as a victory for President Eisenhower and the housing industry the $1,000,000,000 housing bill that the President signed on Wednesday.
The Rabbinical Council of America yesterday criticized the American Council for Judaism for its assertion that the sale of Israel bonds on the Jewish High Holy Days was a desecration."
ALBANY, Sept. 24 (AP) -- New York lagged behind most other states in post-war growth, but retained its first-place standing in population and other major economic areas.
North Little Rock, Ark. North Little Rock, Ark., is planning the sale of $5,350,000 of water and electric utilities bonds on Oct. 9.

MONTREAL, Sept. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Dutch tanker Duivendrecht today entered the St. Lawrence Seaway equipped with a brand new power winch which her captain contended was unnecessary and would not normally be used.

Beau Shah, Mrs. Vernon Cardy's half of the favored entry, won the Bushwick hurdle race at Aqueduct by two lengths yesterday. Finishing second in the test of about two miles and a half was the Tower Hill Farm's Langton Breeze, the other part of the entry, trained by Michael Walsh.
Each morning at an abandoned North River pier near Canal Street, a mellow man named John Henefy appears, whistles, and then watches as twenty-five cats jump out of the woodwork.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Horace Stoneham, owner of the San Francisco Giants, said today that he had a recent phone conversation with Leo Durocher, "but we didn't discuss his coming to the club."

HAVANA, Sept. 24 -- The Cuban Government early this morning imposed an ad valorem (according to value) tax of 30 to 100 per cent on hundreds of imports and drastically tightened restrictions on foreign exchange.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- A political tempest with two storm centers gathered force here today when two state investigators held closed hearings in the Rockland County Courthouse on alleged election irregularities.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 24 (UPI) -- A band of fortune seekers who struggled for six months to salvage a sunken tanker raced against a hurricane threat today on their way to port with their valuable prize.
WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 24 -- Town officials were non-plussed today to learn that there is already a sewer line servicing Burr Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev was urged today by thirty-five self-styled American political liberals to join the United States now in a United Nations effort to banish poverty and disease from the earth.
Gilbert and Sulivan's "The Mikado" will make its first appearance with the New York City Opera on Thursday, as a feature of the second week of its current season.

Trading increased on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and aggregate market values advanced about $3,100,000,000, or 1.72 per cent. At the close, the market as a whole was 7.15 per cent below its historic high of Aug. 3

The nation's electric utilities were offered yesterday further price cuts in the cost of equipment for prdoucing electricity. General Electric Company announced at a press conference in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that it was cutting prices on its entire line of power transformers by more than 5 per cent, effective on Sept. 28.
The Italian Line announced yesterday that it would build two 35,000-ton passenger liners for its New York-Mediterranean service.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 -- The Russian words at today's luncheon at the University of Pittsburgh were Premier Khrushchev's, but the English words and American accent came from Mr. Sukhodrev.
TUNIS, Sept 24 -- Three Ministers of the Algerian nationalist provisional government left here todaly, indicating that its preparation of a response to President de Gaulle had been completed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Increased rail shipments of coal to steel-producing centers last week was reported today by the Association of American Railroads. It was interpreted as an indication that steel companies anticipated an end to the strike within the next few weeks.
The Director of Pediatrics at the Kings County Hospital Center charged yesterday that two infants had died there, one in 1958 and one this year, because of a shortage of nurses.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Following are the texts of addresses by Gov. David L. Lawrence of Pennsylvania and Premier Khrushchev at a luncheon today at the University of Pittsburgh:

RICHARD ALDRICH, in his biography of Gertrude Lawrence, reminded readers how recently it was, as time goes, that the theatre was felt to be not quite the place for well-brought-up young ladies. An exception was the concert hall, where it was possible to taste the forbidden joys of theatregoing in surroundings of extreme respectability.
IN 1948 "The Gladiola Girl" was the most priceless item in "Lend An Ear."
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Surgeons tonight failed to save the lives of five-day-old Siamese twin girls who were born sharing the same heart and liver.
The rally in the bond market moved forward again yesterday after a two-day breathing spell in United States Government securities.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Following are excerpts from a policy statement before the General Assembly today by Mrs. Golda Meir, Foreign Minister of Israel and from a reply by Dr. Farid Zeineddine of the United Arab Republic:
[DE it fish, fowl or meat, the I L) food shopper bill find an encouragingly wide range of offerings this week-end.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A small export volume of corn was the only major commercial influence in the grain futures market today, and prices on the Board of Trade finished steady to weak.

A proposal offered by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to purchase the Government-owned telephone system of the Virgin Islands will be submitted on Monday to the Legislature at St. Thomas for ratification.

The American dollar, long a symbol of financial strength, has been called "weak" lately by some economists. Some have even talked of a possible "devaluation" of the dollar. Yesterday, with some strong statemens, Dr. Marcus Nadler, consulting economist to the Hanover Bank, refuted this stand in a study published by the bank.

Whatever we may think of the Soviet regime of cruel dictatorship, one formidable fact stands unshaken: there can be no peace on this planet without the cooperation of the Soviet giant. This paramount concern guides our President in his untiring efforts to prevent a world-wide disaster. An overwhelming majority of Americans are endorsing the President's policy regardless of party affiliation.
HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 24 (AP) -- A Hungarian protest was lodged here today against the exclusion of East Germany from the world modern pentathlon championships.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Air Force general who was relieved of his command in Iceland after an incident involving Icelandic officials and a United States Air Force guard, has a new job.

CAIRO, Sept. 24 -- King Hussein of Jordan will join President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and King Saud of Saudi Arabia in talks next month to discuss the growing menace of communism in the Middle East.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 -- Soviet correspondents accompanying Premier Khrushchev on his tour of the United States have suggested that the Soviet position on some international questions is flexible.
Columbia will open its sixty-ninth football season tomorrow against Brown at Providence. The verbal campaign got under way yesterday at John Jay Hall on the Morningside Heights campus.
MILAN, Italy, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The audience at Milan's Teatro Nuovo last night warmly applauded six young American singers in their European opera debuts.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Adios Butler set a world record in winning the $76,582 Little Brown Jug today. He also swept pacing's Triple Crown and became the biggest moneywinning 3-year-old pacer in harness racing history.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Sept 24 -- Two major real estate transactions involving parcels in which the municipality has a financial interest and costing $6,000,000 have been approved here by the Mayor and Council.

Two theatre parties this autumn will benefit the Henry Street Settlement, 265 Henry Street. They will be at "Heartbreak House" on Oct. 22 at the National Theatre and a preview of "Fiorello!" on Nov. 17 at the Broadhurst Theatre.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad reported yesterday a deficit of $1,375,583 for August. This compared with a deficit of $195,677 for August, 1958.

The Atlas Corporation has relinquished its interest in the Transocean Corporation of California, a holding company that owns Transocean Airlines, Inc. The transaction, announced yesterday by Floyd B. Odium, chairman of Atlas, involves the cancellation by Atlas of $12,000,000 of Transocean debt, with the remaining half-million debt to be paid later.

A small truck went out of control on the Manhattan Bridge yesterday morning and struck a BMT express train crossing to Brooklyn. The accident disrupted Brooklyn-bound train service for almost two hours.

Mayor Wagner formally asked President Eisenhower yesterday to request the Bureau International des Expositions in Paris to authorize a world's fair in New York in 1964. The Mayor also asked the President to invite foreign governments to participate.

Every yachtsman knows how embarrassing it is to fall overboard. This can happen from slippery decks, from out of the rigging, from trying to gaff a fish or when trying to leap from one craft to another over a wide space that really needs two jumps instead of one.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- A 24-year-old Ohio woman was assured by Premier Khrushchev today that her mother and brother would be permitted to leave Lithuania and return to the United States.
A long-range step toward relieving overcrowded schools in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was taken yesterday by the Board of Education.

The nation's security must not depend on periodic "crash" defense programs, but on a long-range continuing program, Mark W. Cresap Jr., president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, warned in an address prepared for delivery last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The first phase of Premier Khrushchev's visit -- the phase of generalities -- is over. The second phase -- the testing of those generalities -- will begin tomorrow in a three-day conference between President Eisenhower and the Soviet leader at Camp David in the Catoctin Mountains of Maryland.

A PLEASANT sharpness in the Roman air foretold the coming of autumn one recent morning as Signora Anna Benaglia set out to shop for groceries. Warning the family's frisky young boxer to get back inside, she closed the hall door and entered the self-service elevator.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Like the second All-Star baseball game, Premier Khrushchev's second arrival in Washington today was one spectacle too many for a single season.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Federal District Courts are so far behind in work it would take sixteen years at the present rate to clean up the backlog, Chief Justice Earl Warren said today.
A play and a musical, both written by Andrew Rosenthal, have been earmarked for production.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 24 -- A pennant will be at stake in the week-end series that get under way at Chicago tomorrow afternoon and here tomorrow night.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP) -- India's Ramanthan Krishnan and Australia's Neale Fraser and Rod Laver today reached the semi-final round in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament.

Average member bank borrowings declined 200 million to 859 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Average excess reserves rose 70 million to 566 million. As a result, average net borrowed reserves -- excess reserves less borrowings -- declined 270 million from the level of the week before to 293 million.
MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 24 -- The Long Island State Park Commission's contention that it controls the air over Jones Beach has been challenged by Robert Jones, a pilot of Bethany, Conn.
OTTAWA, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Bank of Canada interest rate fell today to 5.85 per cent from 6.13 last week with the sale of $100,000,000 in ninety day Government Treasury bills.

A paraphrase, "Infinite mischief in a small room." is the judgment brought to mind by Hosni Khalifa's letter (published Sept. 8) on Egypt's Suez Canal policies. The Arab States' press counselor has kept his comments brief, but they have not been the less filled with harmful intent.
The spot price of domestic sugar advanced 5 points yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange to 6.55 cents a pound, the highest since July. 1957.
VIENNA, Sept. 24 -- The United States presented today a program for strengthening the activities and prestige of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

The Port of New York Authority refused yesterday to go through with a scheduled sale of $25,000,000 of long-term bonds on the ground that the interest cost designated by the bidders -- 4.5915 per cent -- was excessive.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Frank Leahy, former Notre Dame football coach, said today he had been falsely accused of making up to $400,000 by selling oil stocks to friends, relatives and acquaintances.

UTICA, N. Y., Sept. 21 The Unitarian Universalist Church of the Reconciliation has been ousted from the Council of Churches of Utica and Oneida County. Inc., because it will not accept "Jesus Christ as divine Lord and Savior." The church has been a council member for thirty years.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 16 -- The strike of steelworkers in the United States has proved a boon to South Africa's steel industry.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Government estimated officially today that its budget for the current fiscal year was still in balance.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev missed an opportunity today to see the gulf that separates the Americans and Russians in their views. He missed an impromptu debate at the Mesta Machine Company plant.
AN absorbing, informative account of juvenile delinquency was presented by station WRCA-TV last evening.

ARRAS, France, Sept. 24 -- In the face of rebel hesitation and French Right-wing opposition. President Charles de Gaulle reaffirmed today the principle of self-determination for Algeria "as the only way out" of the present conflict.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York, a large and influential shipping group, has backed the development plans for the lower East River waterfront proposed by the city's Department of Marine and Aviation.

"We are old enough to know better," 17-year-old John Rosario said yesterday. He was one of the ten Young Sinners gang members who were booked by the police for preparing to use flaming gasoline bombs in a battle between two street gangs over the slaying on Monday of a Bronx schoolboy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- Titus Haffa, multimillionaire industrialist, filed suit in Superior Court today asking $10,000,000 for libel and defamation of character. The suit was based on a "Playhouse 90" television program depicting the 1929 St. Valentine's Day Massacre in Chicago.

HYANNIS, Mass., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Walter F. Munford, president of the United States Steel Corporation, accidentally suffered an abdominal wound yesterday while putting away a kitchen knife, a district attorney said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The United States and the Soviet Union are nearing agreement on closer cooperation in the peaceful development of atomic energy, Administration officials disclosed today.

HAVANA, Sept. 24 -- The Cuban revolutionary army has captured thirty former military men of the Batista regime in the Organos Mountains of Pinar del Rio Province about eighty miles from Havana. Among the group captured was said to be an American, but so far no names have been issued.
MOSCOW, Sept. 24 -- Pictures of a radiant Premier Khrushchev about to down a hot dog appeared on Moscow's front pages this morning.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The attention of financial circles here remained fixed today on the Jasper affair.
DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A jurisdictional dispute between two mailers unions halted publication of Detroit's three daily newspapers today.

Out of the A. F. L.-C. I. O. convention in San Francisco this week have come developments which will strengthen organized labor at a time when it is very much on the defensive and will also work in the interest of the public.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev gave a big bear-hug greeting tonight to Van Cliburn, the pianist who scored a triumph in Moscow last year by winning the Tchaikovsky piano competition.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- The Los Angeles Dodgers slipped quietly into this Windy City today and, shortly after noon, hustled out to Wrigley Field for a lengthy batting and fielding drill.

The recall of Ambassador Bohlen from the Philippines to take a special post in the State Department in the field of Russian affairs has met with general and deserved approval. He is obviously highly qualified and is taking this new State Department assignment as an act of pure patriotism.
Prices of futures in the cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 5 points off yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24 -- In The Game in 1957. Yale drubbed Harvard so mercilessly that the shades of Lorin Deland and Percy Haughton were whirling in agitation. The 54-0 beating was the worst suffered in the history of this ancient football rivalry, dating from 1875.

Senator John F. Kennedy proposed yesterday that the Senate investigate the national steel strike.

THE buyers at Lord Taylor are an adventurous group. This year, forty-eight of them almost circled the globe to select the fashions and home furnishings that compose the store's fourth International Show of Imports. No country has a monopoly, for twenty-two of them are represented.

The London Times suggested recently that the English convert a number of ships into correction institutes for juvenile delinquents.

The British electoral campaign is gaining momentum. The elections of Oct. 8 are less than two weeks off; the "big guns" are booming: the door-to-door canvassing is in full stride; manifestoes, proclamations, speeches are pouring out at a great rate, but there is yet to develop any hot issues, any dramatic incidents or, in short, anything new -- except, perhaps, the Jasper financial scandal.
The Air Force plans to shoot a ballistic missile across the path of the Explorer VI paddle-wheel satellite today.
The presidents of two union locals were indicted yesterday on charges of extorting $20,00 over a five-year period from the Hearst Publishing Company, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Former President Truman reminded Kansas Democrats at their dinner last night fat Wichita that there also were strikes in the steel industry while he was in the White House. "But," said he, "I didn't sit around and wait for the country to go to pot. I settled them."
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Sept. 24 -- The right of the Zoning Commission here to determine the "highest and best" use of residentially zoned property has been upheld by the Superior Court in Bridgeport.
DES MOINES, Sept. 24 -- The image that Iowans had of Premier Khrushchev today was that of a backslapping salesman who wasn't able to sell his bill of goods.
Louis Hausman, currently an executive of the Columbia Broadcasting System, was appointed yesterday to the new post of television's official answer man.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The stock market arrested its decline here today, helped by the rally on Wall Street. However, movements were mixed and generally small.
TODAY the European championship tournament at Palermo, Sicily, which has been going on for two weeks, will come to a close; and the accompanying bridge hand comes from that tournament.
The proposed merger of Texaco Inc., and the Superior Oil Company of California was abandoned yesterday because of opposition from the Department of Justice.

Paul Keres of the Soviet Union, tightened his hold on first place yesterday by defeating Paul Benko of New York in the twelfth round of the world challengers' chess tournament in Bled, according to a report received last night from Yugoslavia.

WATKINS GLEN, Sept. 25 -- As a prelude to tomorrow's twelfth annual Sports Car Grand Prix of Watkins Glen, two races were run this afternoon, and all of the more than 250 entries practiced on the 2.35-mile course.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Following are the texts of toasts by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter and Premier Khrushchev at a luncheon given today by the Secretary:
Trading in commodity futures yesterday on most New York exchanges was dull. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

The New York Central Railroad showed a $3,863,684 deficit last month, which it attributed to the loss of traffic resulting from the steel strike. In August of 1958, the system had a net income of $274,777.
MIAMI, Sept. 25 (AP) -Miami's Hurricanes overwhelmed Tulane tonight, 26-7. Fran Curci's sharp passing and a hard-running backfield highlighted the victory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- The Air Force said today that the Olin-Mathieson pilot plant at Lewiston, N. Y., would produce boron compounds for high-energy fuel research at least through the rest of this year and probably until sometime in 1960.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 25 -- The leaders of India's ruling Congress party voiced "grave concern" today about Chinese Communist claims to "large areas" of Indian territory. They said any incursions "must be resisted."

The Superior Oil Company probably will abandon further drilling in Venezuela until it can dispose of its present surplus production there, H. B. Keck, president, said at a special stockholders meeting in Los Angeles yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Preliminary talks on expanding exchanges between the United States and the Soviet Union of experts and information in health and medical research will start tomorrow at the National Institutes of Health.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 25 -- Grand R. Volo, driven by Billy Haughton, beat Victory Dinamic by a head in the $11,500 Bay Ridge Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 25 -- Governor Rockefeller's "nonpolitical week-end in New Hampshire got more political by the minute today.
Bond prices continued strong yesterday and the market showed price gains for the week running to more than a point. Bond distributors could bid bood-by to a rugged summer without regrets.
Two thousand persons gathered at Carnegie Hall last night to observe the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the Communist party of the United States.
The future queen of Italy's merchant marine, the 33,500-gross-ton liner Leonardo da Vinci, will make her debut here next July.

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 25 -- The Town Court was notified today that it had won an award from the American Bar Association for general court excellence in 1958. The two judges that sat that year failed to win reappointments from Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff on July 1.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 25 -- A company of Government troops was said to have been ambushed by rebel forces yesterday in Luang Prabang Province, leaving three dead and twelve wounded. Four rebels were reported killed in the action.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 25 -- Southern Jewish leaders called on Jewish communities in the South today to take "a positive stand" on race relations and law enforcement.

Thus far no clear motive seems to have been established for the assassination of Ceylonese Prime Minister Bandaranaike. The most plausible theory that has been advanced is that he was shot by a disgruntled advocate of the "Eastern" school of medical practice because he did not take a sufficiently firm stand to give this school complete precedence over Western medicine.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 25 -- Gov. David L. Lawrence declared tonight that abandonment of the responsibilities of citizenship to politicians and officeholders was harmful to government and to the people it served.

Little Augie Pisano, an underworld figure since his association with Al Capone in the Prohibition rackets, was found dead last night with a woman on a tree-lined resi dential street in Jackson Heights, Queens.

BEIRUT, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Demonstrators clashed with Lebanese army troops two blocks from the Iraqui Embassy as hundreds of spectators crowded windows and balconies to watch. A stray bullet cut the power line leading into the Embassy building.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Mme. Nina Petrovna Khrushchev held her first scheduled press conference today and provided a glimpse into her private life.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Chief Justice Earl Warren warned today that "if the judiciary does not become forward-looking and willing to accept new methods, they will be forced on them by the Congress."

Hermann Oberth, rocket pioneer and author of "Man Into Space," looks forward in his new book, "The Moon Car," to the day when man will explore the moon. He presents his ideas of a conveyance that will meet the problems of fuel, terrain, extremes of temperature and low gravity.

In a large rectangular room of the Central Plaza Annex on East Seventh Street yesterday, three young men and a young woman were rehearsing a scene from Shakespeare's "The Tempest." The only props were several chairs, two raised platforms and two overhead electric fans.
ALBANY, Sept. 25 -- Following is the text of the statement on juvenile delinquency approved by the Board of Regents at its meeting here today:
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Joey Glimco, president of the Chicago Taxicab Drivers Union, was named today in two indictments charging him with perjury in applying for his driver's license.
Some people plunge into the jungle and come back to civilization with enough hair-raising stories for a lifetime or, at least, for a new adventure book.
TWO fashion designers and a pianist are now turning their attention to women musicians in an effort to find a pretty, practical and uniform solution to concert dress.
Premier Khrushchev's visit to the United States has been reported as a Soviet triumph by radio and press in the Communist satellite countries of Eastern Europe, according to Radio Free Europe.
FOR close on to forty years Samuel Simon Leibowitz, now 66 years old, has startled courtroom audiences and news readers with legalistic didoes and startling utterances.
HYANNIS, Mass., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Walter F. Munford, president of the United States Steel Corporation, suffered a stroke yesterday in Cape Cod Hospital.
The newly founded Film Center of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street, has announced its first screen programs of the season.
COLOMBO, Sept. 25 -- Ceylon's armed forces patrolled this capital after the wounding of Prime Minister Bandaranaike.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams are 4-point favorites over the New York Giants tomorrow night in the opening game of the National Football League son for both teams.
A small but important segment of the Long Island Expressway will be opened without ceremony in Roslyn Tuesday at 11 A. M.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Vyacheslav P. Yelyutin, Soviet Minister of Higher and Secondary Specialized Education, painted a glowing picture today of the colleges and advanced technical schools in his country.

NEWARK, Sept. 25 -- Five New Jersey contractors, including a former Essex County Republican chairman, were indicted today on charges of conspiracy in submitting bids for a multi-million-dollar sewerage program.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 -- The future of the Paraguayan dictatorship headed by Gen. Alfredo Stroessner is being shaped in several cities.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Saturday, Sept. 26 -- Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike died today of bullet wounds inflicted yesterday by an assassin.
For the first time man has been able to "see" through the dust clouds to the heart of the galaxy of which he is a part with sufficient clarity to distinguish the structure of that region.
IF you have Milton Berle as a guest you don't need a host.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The feature of the further moderate improvement in the stock market here today was the rise of 3 shillings (42 cents) in Imperial Chemical Industries. A large increase in the half-year dividend by Britain's biggest industrial chemical concern was announced after the close Thursday. The response today added 38,000,000 ($106,400,000) to their market value.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 25 -- The United States Embassy announced today that, from the time American economic assistance began in 1951 until last Aug. 31, India received $1,792,700,000.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 25 -- The United States formally assured the West German Government today that its German policy remained unchanged.
MOSCOW, Sept. 25 -- Premier Khrushchev was shown as a jaunty, smiling and perspiring ditchdigger in a Pravda cartoon today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Yugoslav Government has advised the United States through diplomatic channels here and in Belgrade of its hope that President Eisenhower might visit Yugoslavia soon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Spokesmen for the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area won encouragement today in their fight for accurate governmental measurements of metropolitan growth as a guide to planning for the future.
DUNKIRK, France, Sept. 25 -- President Charles de Gaulle continued to score heavily in popularity today on the second day of a four-day swing through northern France.
ITALY won the European Team Championship for the fourth year in a row in the annual tournament that ended at Palermo, Sicily, yesterday afternoon. Great Britain won the Women's Team Championship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Morton M. Mendels and his "better half" have spent the last twelve months making plans to receive more than 500 guests from the four corners of the world next week. Among their guests will be ministers of cabinet or near-cabinet rank from sixty-eight nations.

Oklahoma, Auburn, Southern Methodist, Army, Wisconsin and Ohio State, all ranked among Louisiana State's chief rivals for national preeminence, open their football seasons today against opponents qualified to put them to searching tests in most instances.
Congressional leaders interested in maritime matters and a Federal shipping official sailed for Europe yesterday on a fact-finding mission on steamship conferences and rate-making practices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The atomic-energy chiefs of the United States and the Soviet Union drafted plans today for closer cooperation between their two nations in the peaceful development of nuclear energy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency said today that it had suspended an airline pilot for dozing at the controls of a passenger plane bound from Bermuda to New York.
Premier Khrushchev's tour of the United States has produced a world-wide controversy on whether the Americans have been too rough on him.

The Eisenhower Administration's great expectations for a balanced budget in the present fiscal year may turn out to be one more bright dream gone aglimmering. It happened last year and it can easily happen again.

The Avco Corporation, a maker of aircraft engines and equipment and missile components, had substantially larger sales and earnings in its third fiscal quarter ended on Aug. 31 than in the 1958 period, the report disclosed yesterday.

The Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on an appeal from a ruling that upheld the election of Carmine G. De Sapio as a Democratic committee member in the Thirty-third Election District of the First Assembly District.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Negro member of President Eisenhower's Civil Rights Commission said today passage of anti-discrimination laws was needed to break down racial prejudice.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- President Eisenhower filled today three of the five lieutenant generals posts in the Marine Corps by recess appointments subject to Senate approval.

HONOLULU, Sept. 25 -- Delegates of the International Air Transport Association's traffic conference have worked in closed sessions, this week in an attempt to reach agreement on the extension of economy-class fares. Such fares are now restricted to North Atlantic flights.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- A deadlocked labor dispute is threatening to delay the scheduled opening of the Philadelphia Orchestra's sixtieth season next Friday. Subscribers were informed today by mail.
The New York Yankees clinched third place in the American League by defeating the Baltimore Orioles, 5 -- 2, at the Stadium last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May) announced today secondary market buying prices or par to 98 for the new 5 3/4 per cent Federal Housing Administration insured mortgages.

A variety of offerings is scheduled for the public capital market next week. Slated major offerings of debt securities amount to $146,500,000, with state and municipal borrowings accounting for a major part.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Pierre Wigny, Belgian Foreign Minister, assured the General Assembly today that his Government was moving ahead swiftly with plans to organize a democracy in the Belgian Congo.
YORK, Pa., Sept. 25 (AP) A dental care group insurance plan is being tried out here.
A special crew of cleaning men was assigned yesterday to eradicate scribblings of gang defiance from the walls in the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25 -- As loose as any eighth-place club that cannot move up to seventh or down to ninth, the Phillies upset the Braves, 6 -- 3, tonight and almost crushed Milwaukee's hopes for a third straight pennant.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The sudden illness of a dozen Oklahoma players two days before their opening football game with Northwestern took on an air of mystery today. Several of the Sooners were stricken after eating a fruit salad in a Chicago night club last night.

MOREHEAD CITY, N. C., Sept. 25 (AP) -- An Asheville couple, who had lashed their life jackets together, were rescued at dawn today from the treacherous waters off Cape Lookout. They had been in the sea for twenty hours.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Eisenhower was reported ready tonight to impress upon Premier Khrushchev the determination of the United States and its allies to uphold all their rights in West Berlin.

The Arab-Israeli conflict over Palestine has erupted anew in the United Nations in a battle of words centered for the present on the Egyptian blockade of the Suez Canal for Israeli shipping but also suggesting graver implications.

Cuba, as expected, has cut down on imports and exchange facilities. Some such measures were inevitable to meet a heavy balance of payments deficit for 1959 which Premier Castro evidently expects to be in the neighborhood of $175,000,000. The fall in the price of sugar, in tourist expenditures and in foreign investments aggravated the normal trend.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 25 -- A program to insure that its scientific right hand knows instantly what its left hand is doing has been started by the Air Force's Air Research and Development Command.

GENEVA, Sept. 25 -- The outlook for the Western European coal industry is still dim although the seasonal rise in demand in the coming quarter is expected to be higher than at the end of last year, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe said today.
Military policemen at First Army Headquarters on Governors Island today will celebrate the eighteenth anniversary of the establishment of their corps.

The Congregational Christian Churches began a campaign last night to raise $7,500,000 in the next two years to strengthen the denomination's higher education facilities.
TALLINN, Estonia, Sept. 22 -- The Soviet Union appears to have donned kid gloves in the handling of the affairs of its western annex the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 25 -- A woman's right to transform herself from a brunette to a blonde was upheld in Central Traffic Court here today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved off 3 points (15 cents a bale) to 2 points up yesterday, after holding in a narrow range. The near October contract showed the only loss.

THE effort to bring jazz and non-jazz to some sort of common ground was continued last night at Town Hall in a concert given jointly by the Beaux Arts String Quartet and the Modern Jazz Quartet.

LAST winter's ice and sleet so isolated The Barn at Ben Robyn, then in Huntington, L. I., that its complete line of Jamaican furniture and accessories has been moved from the farm to 143 East Sixty-second Street.

Operations of Atlas Plywood Corporation are "moderately profitable" and the outlook is optimistic, a company official said, following the annual meeting in Boston yesterday. He said management was counting on establishing itself in more dynamic industries through acquisitions.
The critical East and Gulf Coast longshore situation deteriorated further yesterday.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. (UPI) -- Fresh fruit stains should be treated while still fresh and damp. This advice comes from the Extension Service of Rutgers University's College of Agriculture.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Pakistan proposed today that the General Assembly call a special session within two years to bring about a reduction of armed forces and conventional weapons among the eighty-two member states.

A race every bit as thrilling as the seething National League showdown is in prospect for thoroughbred racing fans at Aqueduct today. The Woodward Stakes will be run for the sixth time, and among the candidates in the mile-and-a-quarter event are the three best horses currently in training in this country.

The International Sports Fund will benefit from a dinner to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor on Wednesday under the joint sponsorship of the Council on Islamic Affairs, Inc., and the People-to-People Sports Committee, Inc.

BURSA, Turkey, Sept. 25 -- The imminent return of Ambassador Bohlen as Secretary Herter's principal Russian adviser is welcome news. Bohlen is not only a particularly able diplomat who has made a lifetime study of Russian affairs, Russia and Russian, a language he speaks with remarkable fluency.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- One of this week's patents covers a conveyor system designed originally to transport passengers between New York's Times Square and Grand Cenral Station in a train of cabs. The "Carveyor" was proposed to take the place of the present shuttle trains.
The Government yesterday moved once more against Henry Miller's long-banned novels "Tropic of Cancer" and "Tropic of Capricorn."

ROME, Sept. 25 -- The Benedictines, the oldest order of monks in the West, have elected a new Abbot Primate at the College of St. Anselm on the Aventine Hill. Pope John XXIII approved their choice today.
Ned Lewis, a motion picture photographer with 1,200 films to his credit, is going to Atlantic City next week for the world premieres of his latest movies -- twenty-six of them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Senate Antitrust subcommittee has subpoenaed records of three major New York banks and eight investment companies in an effort to find out whether they exercise any control over drug manufacturers.

Economic unification of Europe's six-nation common market so far has chiefly dealt with industrial integration. This is just a starting point for larger things to come, according to the German-American Chamber of Commerce.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 -- Without even being able to strike a blow in their own defense, the third-place Giants saw the National League pennant they thought was theirs a week ago slip farther out of their grasp today.

PLANDOME, L. I., Sept. 25 -- The Westchester golf team today won the Myra D. Paterson Trophy in the thirtieth contest of the series, which is sponsored by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, at the Plandome Country Club. The team of ten scored 38 1/2 points to lead Long Island, which scored 33, and New Jersey, which scored 18 1/2.
Passengers on two jetliners bound from London to New York yesterday morning found themselves on circuitous journeys because of foggy weather in Iceland. The planes were due here early this morning.

LAST night's special attraction over Channel 4, "An Evening With Jimmy Durante," was a fairly conventional hour of television variety. At times diverting but nothing particularly new or inventive.

John E. McCarthy, the president of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, is very much concerned these days with the question of whether Fifth Avenue is turned into a one-way thoroughfare. CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Under cover of a leaden sky, the National League pennant race took a most extraordinary turn today.

The normal July to August increase of some 10,000 jobs in Minnesota was turned by the steel strike to a loss of 13,000, the State Employment Security Department reported. Non-farm jobs, which totaled 918,993, rose 6,051 from August, 1958, but were well below the August record of 939,386 set in 1957.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 -- The investigation of the mysterious death of Mrs. Lynn Kauffman returns to New York City next week, and to seven pieces of luggage that may tell the story of a tragic romance.
TUNIS, Sept. 26 -- Two incidents on the Algerian border last night cost the life of a Tunisian civilian and left a Tunisian soldier wounded, the Government announced here today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 -- The New York Giants beat the Los Angeles Rams, 23-21, on Pat Summerall's 18-yard field goal with less than two minutes to play tonight in a National Football League opener before 71,297 spectators in Memorial Coliseum.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 26 -- Decrees putting the Belgian Congo on the way to self-rule are ready for approval by the Government and King Baudouin.
As an educator I am disturbed by the comparatively amateurish approach of the United States to the position of leadership into which our country has been forced.

THIS somewhat daffy baseball season reached a new peak of lunacy in Cleveland the other day. Like a man caught in a revolving door, Joe Gordon was out and then in as manager of the Indians. The guy pushing the door in both directions was Frank Lane, the general manager.

Retail activity was pronounced in the Kansas City area in the week ended Sept. 19, stimulated by the movement of fall and winter wearing apparel. Cooler temperatures coupled with widespread promotions spurred the movement of coats and suits.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A major controversy is shaping up between the Government and the nuclear industry over a move by the Atomic Energy Commission to establish strict new safety standards for atomic workers.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Negotiators called a weekend recess in efforts to end the two-week-old strike of 2,000 moldmakers against the glass-container manufacturing industry.
TRENTON, Sept. 26 -- Just ten years ago a small group of parents of mentally retarded children met here to discuss ways and means of educating and training their offspring.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. (UPI) -- The Department of Agriculture has asked wool producer groups to submit by Oct. 8 their views and recommendations on the wool incentive price level for the 1960 marketing year.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- If Premier Khrushchev had hoped to shake the West with his "total disarmament" proposals, he has failed completely. If he sought to persuade the neutral, uncommitted peoples of the Soviet Union's earnest, everlasting peaceful intentions, he may have partly succeeded.
The 1959 Spirit Gold Medal Award will be presented to Clifford S. Laube, it was announced yesterday by the Catholic Poetry Society of America.

CHANDIGARH, India, Sept. 26 -- Both Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and his daughter, Mrs. Indira Gandhi, president of the ruling Congress party, sharply criticized the Communists today for resorting to violence in politics.
CHAMBER music, both new and old, will be featured this season in two series of concerts, the "Pollikoff Readings" in Manhattan and the Chamber Music Associates in Brooklyn.

ON any person who desires such queer prizes, New York will bestow the gift of loneliness and the gift of privacy. It is this largess that accounts for the presence within the city's walls of a considerable section of the population; for the residents of Manhattan are to a large extent strangers who have pulled up stakes somewhere and come to town, seeking sanctuary or fulfillment or some greater or lesser grail.

To the Travel Editor: I should like to take issue most heartily with Thomas G. Morgansen's letter in regard to H. B. Cantor's proposed $50 fare to Europe [on 6,000-passenger four-day superliners]. I think it a magnificent plan! Mr. Morgansen must have a hearty appetite, indeed, to feel that he could eat enough in four days to make up the difference between $50 and $174.

A GIRL AND A GUITAR (United Artists). Lee Schaefer, singer, and Jim Hall, jazz guitarist, in still another tack with folk melodies. Their arrangements are anathema to the purist, but there is no denying that a fine "torch-song" mood is built and sustained effectively.

A two-day auction on Thursday and Friday at Rock Hollow, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Dowling of Ardsleyon-Hudson, N. Y., will benefit the Youth Consultation Service. The service since 1909 has helped troubled and distressed girls 14 to 25 years old.
AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Justice Felix D. Aulisi of the State Supreme Court today ordered a recanvass and recount in two Amsterdam primary election contests.
Another chapter in trans-Atlantic travel will open on Oct. 10 with the scheduled introduction of the Boeing 707-321 Intercontinental jet on the so-called blue-ribbon route.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- In his remarkable odyssey in America this week, Nikita Sergeyevich Khrushchev made only one concession to the United States. The Soviet Union's political system, its moon rockets, its cement, and even its corn, he insisted, were all superior to ours, but we made better hot dogs.
ATLANTA, Sept. 26 -- Ninety-five years ago Atlanta lay in ashes, grim testimony to the truth of General Sherman's assertion that "War is hell."

WARETOWN, N. J., Sept. 26 (AP) -- A woman was killed and a family of five injured tonight when their car collided with a pick-up trick and careened off into another car. The police said the driver of the truck sped away from the scene, but was captured shortly afterward.

IN the final week of its season the New York City Ballet offered quietly what in most companies and by tradition is a great event, namely, the debut of a new Odette in "Swan Lake". In this case it was Patricia Wilde, and the results -- to come to the point at once -- were altogether admirable.

DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Early Wynn scored his twenty-second victory and John Callison batted in five runs with a grand-slam homer and a double today, as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Detroit Tigers, 10--5.

MADRID, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- Five men were sentenced to prison terms ranging from six months to twenty years here yesterday on charges of activities against the security of the state, the Spanish news agency CIFRA reported today.

A tea in the interest of the Child Study Association of America will take place at Gracie Mansion on Tuesday. Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, co-chairman of the association's benefit committee, will be hostess.

New York labor fired another broadside last Sunday in its running battle with Blue Cross and the voluntary hospitals over administration of hospital services here. Harry A. Van Arsdale Jr., president of the New York City Central Labor Council, announced it would consider the possibility of organizing a comprehensive medical plan under direct union auspices.

THAT mammoth, conglomerate state known as Alaska has been basking in more than the Midnight Sun this summer. The Brothers Warner, with Edna Ferber as guide, have focused the glare of Hollywood on the frosty Forty-ninth.

VIENNA, Sept. 26 -- Hungary's Communist regime has finally permitted the rebirth of the Hungarian Writers Union, a center of the agitation that led to the Hungarian revolt in 1956. The union had been banned since early 1957.

WHILE the baseball world is buzzing about the proposed Continental League, the big leagues of men's style have been overwhelmed (conversationally, if not numerically) by a relative newcomer called the American Continental suit.
A branch store in Westchester will be opened tomorrow by Plummer, Ltd., of 734 Fifth Avenue.

THIS first flight by Stuart Mitchner is the winner of the Thomas Y. Crowell College Novel Contest, which makes the publisher an accessory to the novel -- an especially serious offense since the author is a minor (age 20).

At 10 o'clock tonight Soviet Premier Khrushchev is to board his jet transport, homeward bound. Thus will end an historic episode in international relations -- an episode which has unfolded in two phases.
MADRID, Sept. 17 -- The Spanish Government has passed up a chance to cooperate with French, British, West German and Italian interests in the exploitation of rich iron ore fields in northwest Africa.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Thirty-two nations have sent thirty-eight women to the fourteenth General Assembly, of whom seventeen have full delegate status. The rest are alternates.

The bullfights Mr. Graves writes of are like the ones presented for the tourists on Majorca, where Mr. Graves has been residing. These resemble a mainland corrida like a Class D baseball game does a major league encounter.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 26 -- Dartmouth's Indians, who are hoping to repeat as Ivy League champions, had a rude awakening today when they fell before a hard-charging Holy Cross eleven, 31 - 8, at Memorial Stadium.

GREENLAWN, L. I., Sept. 26 -- Ch. Storm's Donner, a 3-year-old Doberman pinscher owned by Peter Mehlich of New York, gained the best-in-show award in the Suffolk County Kennel Club's twenty-first annual event today at the Greenlawn Recreation Center.

Although the philosophy of racial "partnership" in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland at least points to a nobler goal than that of apartheid in the Union of South Africa, the attainment of that goal has been newly set back by several developments.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Everybody likes Chris Herter. And this is a most unusual situation for a Secretary of State.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 26 -- When the Braves take the field at County Stadium against the Phillies tomorrow at 1:30 P. M. (3:30 New York time), it will be for all the marbles. And, as almost everyone knows, the Braves, having gone this far, would hate to lose all the marbles -- people might talk.
Ecuador has lost about $7,000,000 in revenue through discriminatory consular fees, the American Merchant Marine Institute, Inc., said this week.

A STATE institution for mentally retarded children is an unusual setting for a novel, but then Martin Russ' second book is an unusual tale. Once again, the ability to find absorbing human interest in the dark backwaters of human experience is the hallmark of an original and sensitive talent.

AS his large and devoted audience well knows, Eddie Wilson, dedicated collector of valuable junk, is also drawn, as the bee to the flower, to animals. Of all the pets which he has collected in previous adventures, the only permanent one is Louella, a parrot of reasonably amiable disposition and speech.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Only a decade ago the status of forestry in Iraq was relatively desperate. Today that country has a running start on its neighboring states in this facet of the long-term development projected for the Mediterranean region.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Sept. 26 -- President Eisenhower and Premier Khrushchev interrupted their discussion of world problems this afternoon to visit the President's farm and country house near here.

THE Twenties -- the "dizzy" decade 1919-29 -- have become such a byword for reckless living and for souliess extravagance on every level that it is hard to remember the keen intellectual activity in art and literature that existed alongside the follies.

COLOGNE, Germany, Sept. 26 -- A shiny aluminum arm dipped into the pool of hot soybean oil and delicately flipped a doughnut on to a shiny aluminum tray. A pretty girl skewered half a dozen doughnuts with a deft jab, rolled them in a pan of powdered sugar and thrust her doughnut-festooned weapon across the counter.
Changing habits in the American way of life have caused a change in the use of money.
Humor is gaining stature in advertising.

THE 1959 national convention of the Photographic Society of America, the national organization of amateur photographers, will meet Oct. 6-10 in Louisville, Ky., for a varied program of lecture, how-to-do-it demonstrations and

BRAVO for George Braziller, Inc.! For the first time American artists have been treated by a publishing house with a respect and faith heretofore reserved for their French counterparts. The firm has produced six excellent monographs (starting The Great American Artists Series), placed the prices low and set the print order high (50,000 for each paperback edition).

WE land-locked lubbers should be forgiven our envious twinges when we read Roderick Haig-Brown's most recent book on fishing. As a nature writer, he is authentic; as a fisherman, he rates among the world's most capable.

ALTHOUGH it is doubtless true that some of Sir James G. Frazer's theories of fifty years ago have not stood the test of time and the approaches of later anthropologists I feel that Stuart Chase, in his review of "The New Golden Bough" (Book Review, Aug. 30) does Sir James an injustice in his remarks on Frazer's methods.

The Brunswick - Balke - Collender Company has announced the acquisition of the T. J. Noonan Company, Boston, a distributor of hospital, medical and laboratory supplies. The transaction involved Brunswick common stock valued "in excess of $1,000,000," according to a spokesman.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The managing director of the International Monetary Fund said today that there was more foreign confidence in the dollar now than was the case six months or a year ago.

THE small home greenhouse is becoming more popular every year. It is not uncommon to see one nestled against a dining room window, connected to one end of a toolhouse, or standing in the open in the back yard of a plant-loving family.
An excited Eddie Arcaro couldn't find enough words to express his admiration for Sword Dancer after the Brookmeade 3-year-old had won the Woodward yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Recent teen-age violence in New York and other cities brought a demand from J. Edgar Hoover today for "an all-out counterattack against vicious young thugs."

IN the 131-year-old city of Columbus, Ga , a town on the bank of the Chattahoochee River with a population of 85,000 whites and 40,000 Negroes, the Rev. Mr. Robert Blakely McNeill, 44, endured with faith and patience the slow progress of convalescence following a coronary suffered June 10.
Only three full days are left in which a crippling East and Gulf Coast waterfront strike can be postponed or prevented.

IT must be said at the outset that the milieu portrayed by Herbert D. Kastle in his second novel -- the world of commercial photography from fashions through beer to cheesecake -- is as faultlessly authentic in the rendering as one of Richard Avedon's studio cameras.

To the Travel Editor: My wife and I recently had the dubious honor of being "displaced persons" at London Airport for four and a half days. Since we were going to be in London 48 hours before plane time, we had confirmed our flight (from London to New York) at Geneva at the office of another airline since our airline did not have an office in that city.

Between mid-July and mid-August employment in the Philadelphia metropolitan area dropped 9,500 to 1,679,000. The loss was attributed to the steel strike. Otherwise, statistics of the Bureau of Employment Security of the Pennsylvania State Employment Service indicated that total employment in the area would have risen by at least 8,100.

A total of 88,800,000 pounds of acetate yarn and rayon was shipped by United States producers in August, according to the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. This is a decline of 1 1/2 per cent from the July figure of 90,100,0000 pounds.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 26 -- When this city's two new elementary schools are opened this winter their upper-grade pupils will already have a proprietary interest in the buildings. Under the supervision of Donald Rogers, the art supervisor, and Robert Nelson, the art teacher, the pupils are preparing tile murale depicting Norwalk historic events.
ROSETTA, Egypt, Sept.21 -- Agrarian reform and the celebration of an 1807 victory over the British struck the Delta countryside here simultaneously last week.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- The Government was preparing today to ban the Communist party following a week-long wave of labor violence by Communists and followers of Juan D. Peron, the exiled former dictator.

ROBERT RAYNOLDS tells that he was asked by his children to write this book for them -- and for their children. He has dedicated it to his wife, their mother. He has had a successful career as a novelist: his first book, "Brothers in the West," won the Harper Prize Novel contest in 1931.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 26 (AP) Texas A. and M. made an early lead stand up and upset Michigan State, 9-7, before a crowd of 49.509 today.

READERS who have met the Pierce family -- settlers in the wind-swept Panhandle of Texas -- in two earlier books, will draw real satisfaction from this third story (complete and enjoyable without the others), which centers about Carolyn.
ZERMATT, Switzerland, Sept. 23 -- This is the story of a tourist who decided to climb the Matterhorn.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah -- West of the Continental Divide, there has been a sudden awakening this year to the beauty autumn brings the region. It coincides, in many parts of the West, with as pleasant a season as scenic-minded old-timers can recall.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The British election campaign boiled over today after an abrasive exchange of letters between the chief strategists of the Labor and Conservative parties.

JOHN BRENNAN of the New Hampshire State Planning and Development Commission appears to be a man who knows a silver lining when he sees one. He has been able to find good in the hot, disagreeable summer. It was fine for fall trout fishing, he says.
The academic year at Fordham University will be started today with a solemn mass to the Holy Ghost, a traditional service celebrated annually to ask divine blessing as classes start.
HONG KONG, Sept. 26 -- The Chinese Communists began operating today the first blast furnace of a huge new steel complex under construction at Paotow, 400 miles northwest of Peiping.
" Madama Butterfly," with a familiar cast headed by Elizabeth Carron and Jon Crain, had its first performance of the season by the New York City Opera Company at the City Center yesterday afternoon.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Cornell marched 80 yards in the last four minutes today for a touchdown that resulted in a 20-15 victory over the Colgate eleven.

VIENNA, Sept. 26 -- The International Atomic Energy Agency took a cautious step today toward its goal of becoming a major channel for the distribution of nuclear materials to under-developed countries.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Sergei N. Khrushchev is not the only son of a high Soviet official now in the United States.
The battered body of a 49-year-old Queens woman was discovered early yesterday morning in a vacant lot through which she often had walked on her way to work.
RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 23 -- King Mohamed V is faced with a grave domestic dilemma and his decision may determine the general politico-economic orientation of Morocco for years to come.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Southern California's speedy sophomore backs, breaking away behind a burly line, last night defeated the University of Pittsburgh, 23 -- 0.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Sept. 26 -- President Eisenhower summoned his most articulate spokesman on the subject of "butter vs. guns" to the Camp David talks today. He evidently had the task of spelling out in the simplest terms why the United States wants an arms limitation agreement no less than Premier Khrushchev.

" In six easy lessons" used to be a favorite American education come-on. Is it obsolete? will it be replaced by the promise of "six hundred hard lessons" now that effort, discipline and homework are fashionable?

A group of eminent scholars from various parts of the world, meeting at the University of Michigan, have given a new emphasis to the study of the "humanities." This is the fifth general assembly of the International Council for Philosophy and Humanistic Studies. These men are naturally conservative. They are not "reformers" nor do they have a solitary axe to grind.

The shadow of obsolescence that has menaced the United States maritime industry is being dispelled by the current ship replacement program, Frederick H. Mueller, Secretary of Commerce, said in a letter made public last week.
