In his sensible article, "To Bridge the Scholarship Gap," (Sept. 13), Fred M. Hechinger stresses the need of more scholarships, of scholarships based on need, of more realistic pricing for college services and also the contributions of loans. In my opinion he is right on every point.

THERE are four miles of painting and more than 4,500 objects in the fine arts section of the Fifth International Biennial Exhibition of Sao Paulo, which opened this week. Forty-five countries have sent samplings of their paintings and sculptures, drawings and prints.

A total of 937 oceangoing ships of 1,000 gross tons or more was in the country's active merchant service on Sept. 1. This was twelve ships less than the number active a month ago, it was reported by the Maritime Administration.
FALL is here, but so is the end of outdoor swimming. It is time to settle down the exposed pool for winter and protect it from the rigors of cold weather.
Bill Summers of the American League and Frank Dascoli of the National were chosen yesterday by Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick as senior umpires for the 1959 world series.

Members of the Italian Historical Society of America were disturbed yesterday by reports that some residents of Staten Island were opposed to naming the new bridge across the Narrows the "Verrazano Bridge."

TWO stamps in commemoration of World Refugee Year will be issued by the United Nations on Dec. 10, Human Rights Day. They will replace, this year, the customary Human Rights series. Reidar Tvedt, director of the U. N. Postal Administration, made public last week the design of the 4-cent red and 8c blue.

MOSCOW, Sept. 26 -- The Soviet press in recent days has found its own -- and various -- ways to cover Premier Khrushchev's United States tour. The following imaginary letter from a Soviet correspondent in the Khrushchev party tells his friends at home what was written about the visit. It is based on dispatches that appeared in the Soviet press.

In an address to the International Council for Philosophy and Humanistic Studies at Ann Arbor, Mich., this week Sir Charles Webster, former president of the British Academy, said today's scientists are unaware of the great contributions of ancient cultures to modern society.

EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 26 -- Dick Thornton's heady quarter-backing and passing and Ron Burton's electrifying runs charged up Northerwestern for a 45-13 triumph today over Oklahoma, the nation's second-ranked football team.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 26 -- Rutgers beat Princeton today for the second year in a row. A 34-yard touchdown pass followed by a conversion pass for 2 points in the opening period sent the Scarlet on the way to an 8-to-6 triumph.

From his youth S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike was a prominent leader in Ceylon's struggle for freedom. The struggle culminated in the island's independence in 1948 as a member of the British Commonwealth. Three years ago, Mr. Bandaranaike came to power as Prime Minister at the head of a coalition of Socialists, Trotskyites and devout Buddhists.

PREMIER Khrushchev's visit to the United States and President Eisenhower's projected return visit to the Soviet Union have been widely interpreted as historic steps toward easing the tensions of the cold war. These personal exchanges may well have far-reaching diplomatic consequences.

The role of the independent voter in the 1960 Presidential elections was debated yesterday by representatives of the Socialist Workers party, the Communist party of New York State and the United Independent-Socialist Committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Senator Wayne Morse. Democrat of Oregon, has called a speech by Ahmad Shukairy, Saudi Arabian delegate to the United Nations, further proof of Saudi Arabia's anti-Semitic policies.

THE exhibition opening Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art will send emotions flaring and controversy raging The really heated arguments are not likely to involve questions of specific and relative esthetic excellences although there is plenty of room for that debate in a show which ranges from masterpieces to mediocrities.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Bill Carpenter, the lonely end; Joe Caldwell and Bob Anderson picked up today where they left off under Earl Blaik last November as Army opened its football season under its new head coach, Dale Hall. As a result, the cadets routed Boston College, 44 -- 8.

Matthew H. Ross, president of the Central Synagogue at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, announced yesterday the opening of a $600,000 fund-raising campaign.

The color creeps in, down from the north, along the ridges and in the valleys where night coolness flows like water. The sumac is first to color, as always, but the dogwood is seldom far behind. Then the viburnums are tinged with purple, the ash shows yellow and blue, the elm is touched with rusty-russet. And the maples, from swamp to rocky hilltop, blaze with every shade of red and yellow.
LAWRENCE, L. I., Sept. 26 Rallying for two touchdowns in the final quarter the Lawrence High football team topped White Plains in the weekly school television game, 14 -- 13, on Horn Field today.
DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 26 -- The Danbury Fair will open for its 90th year next Saturday and continue through Oct. 11.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 26 -- The conference of governmental delgates on a South American free trade zone has decided that the idea is good but the time is not yet ripe for a formal treaty.

A study of the changing potassium content of the aging human body is described in the Sept. 18 issue of Science by Dr. E. C., Anderson and Dr. W. H. Langham of the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory of the Atomic Energy Commission, operated by the University of California.

To the Travel Editor: What Dr. Huffman wrote about Georgia speedtraps is absolutely true. Last year I was stopped in Woodbine, Ga., and charged with speeding. The officer gave me the usual fiction about posting bond for a trial to be held three weeks later. If I didn't post bond, which was forfeited when I did not return for trial, jail until trial. I paid and left by an unmarked, dirt road.

TUNIS, Sept. 26 -- Ten days after President de Gaulle's speech promising self-determination to rebellious Algeria, a major question remained unanswered: Is the French chief prepared to talk peace with the Algerian nationalist leaders?

BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Ronnie Bull, a spindle-legged sophomore halfback, propelled Baylor to a 15 -- 7 victory over Colorado University today. He scored two touchdowns in his first collegiate football game.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- In ten days of touring this country Premier Khrushchev has blown both hot and cold on negotiations with America. This week-end will determine whether a middle way to agreement can be found.
A loquacious gunman who tells hold-up victims he needs $60 a day to support his narcotics addiction was sought yesterday in the robbery of a terrified Bronx couple Friday night.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26 (UPI) -- A surprisingly muscular Harvard University football team constructed a five-touchdown lead at Soldier's Field today before resting on its laurels and reserves to defeat the University of Massachusetts, 36 -- 22.

Commonwealth Edison Company has announced a $65,000,000 increase in its estimated capital spending for the period from 1959 to 1962. The company said this action will increase by $40,000,000 the amount of new financing previously planned for the period.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- Mayor George Christopher, a Republican, may have picked up sonic votes from Premier Khrushchev, the world's top Communist, in his campaign for re-election.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Sept. 26 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California dumped a bitter attack on the Republican Administration in the middle of a conference of Western Governors, Republicans and Democrats, here today.

Francis Smith, a fat and totally incompetent officer, had been ordered by Gen. Thomas Gage to lead some 700 men in a surprise march and destroy military stores and gunpowder assembled by the rebellious provincials at Concord Village, five miles west of Lexington.
A different attraction is winning attention in the mutual-fund field these days.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 27 -- There will be a ball game here at County Stadium tomorrow afternoon. This is true because the Braves, keeping pace with the Dodgers, defeated the Phillies, 5 -- 2, today before 48,642 fans, this town's greatest turnout in history.

EARLY English music for voices and virginals filled Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Mme. Nina Petrovna Khrushchev bade Mrs. Eisenhower farewell at the White House today and obtained her assurance that she would "probably" go to Moscow with the President.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 27 -- A new course for the Uruguayan economy is charted in an exchange reform bill that has been submitted to Congress. The bill envisages one free convertible rate for the peso in place of controlled exchange.

Mrs. Golda Meir, Foreign Minister of Israel, warned yesterday that her Government could not and would not acquiesce in Egyptian interference with free navigation through the Suez Canal. "We demand exactly the same rights that every other country has, Mrs. Meir said.

John Jacob Niles, a pioneer in bringing American folk song to the concert stage, made one of his rare appearances Saturday night as part of a "folk festival'' at Town Hall.
GENEVA, Sept. 27 -- The men of the French-speaking canton of Neuchatel gave their women equal political rights in cantonal affairs in a referendum today. The vote was 11,240 to 9,738.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 -- Johnny Unitas, the hard-working quarterback of Balitmore's National Football League champions, constantly carries a thick, black leather-bound loose-leaf notebook. The book contains every one of Baltimore's 136 offensive plays.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The question of repayment of the Soviet Union's lendlease debt from World War II will be reopened as a result of the Eisenhower-Khrushchev meetings.

The fight against tuberculosis has reached a stage comparable to being inside the ten-yard line in a football game, according to Dr. Thomas N. Sheen, president of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.

WOODSTOCK, Vt., Sept. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller went into Vermont this morning for a hastily arranged conference with Republican leaders.

In an effort designed to encourage qualified high school teachers in the fields of both science and mathematics, the National Science Foundation recently announced a program of summer fellowships for secondary school teachers of these subjects. Beginning next summer, and continuing for as many as three successive summers thereafter, several hundred awards will be made in these areas of academic study.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- The Hungarian Communist party published today its blueprint for total communization of the country.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 -- The nation's inventories of finished steel are estimated at less than 11 million tons. This compares with a minimum requirement of 14 million to 16 million tons. Further, this week is expected to see widespread curtailment at manufacturing plants because of steel shortages.
VENICE, Italy, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A capacity audience in the fashionable La Fenice Theatre of Venice cheered a concert last night by the New York Philharmonic directed by Leonard Bernstein.
The first religious service of Columbia University's 206th academic year was held yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel on the Morningside Heights campus.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- An effort will be made here this week to persuade the United Nations to consider the recent revolt against Communist rule in Tibet.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- With Bobby Joe Conrad scoring 25 points, the peppery Chicago Cardinals reeled off seven long touchdown drives today to trounce the Washington Redskins, 49 -- 21.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The grain futures market had moments of both strength and weakness last week but new influences lacked significant force and prices finished little changed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Air Force said today it expected the Discoverer V satellite to be destroyed by re-entering the earth's atmosphere tomorrow, Tuesday or Wednesday.

The General Tire and Rubber Company turned in a strong performance in the nine months ended on Aug. 31 with sales 50 per cent ahead of the 1958 level and earnings about four times as large. The sales and earnings for the three-quarter period also surpassed those for every full year in the company's history.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- The president of the New York Stock Exchange denied today that the disarmament proposal made by Russia's Premier Khrushchev had been responsible for a downward stock trend on Wall Street.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- With the spotlight focused on the tangled affairs of the Jasper Group and a Conservative election victory appearing less certain caution marked the stock market last week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad Company has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for a Government guarantee on a $500,000 loan.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Mason Rudolph fired a 2-under-par 69 today to win the $40,000 Golden Gate golf championship with a 72-hole total of 275.

"SUNDAY SHOWCASE" last night began on Channel 4 its two-part adaptation of "What Makes Sammy Run?" the Budd Schulberg classic on the all-American rat. It was an impressive and arresting start, marred only by a bewilering awkardness in suspending the completion of the story until next Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The main result of Premier Khrushchev's visit to the United States is that it produced agreement to talk some more. This, at least, is the general view here.

CHANDIGARH, India, Sept. 27 -- India's ruling Congress party circulated today a revised draft of a resolution accusing Communist China of having violated the five principles of peaceful coexistence and noninterference.

A 31-year-old ex-convict was captured early yesterday shortly after he had allegedly attacked a woman judo expert and a girl in the Midwood section of Brooklyn. The judo expert threw the man over her shoulder but he escaped. The girl's screams were finally what helped to capture him.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- The National League today thundered down to the wire for its third dead heat in fourteen years.

TORRE ANNUNZIATA, eighteen miles south of Naples, is the "City of Macaroni." The sun-baked factories in that city, which has the blue Mediterranean at its front door and Vesuvius towering in the rear, are major contributors to the 1,300,000 tons of pasta products Italy makes each year.
An attempt to salvage $75,000,000 worth of metal cargoes resting on the bottom of gulf and Caribbean waters, will soon be made by a Florida company.

Dr. Stanley Spector said yesterday he was convinced that his young secretary and research assistant had been murdered and her body hurled from the passenger freighter Utrecht into Boston harbor.

The agreement by the United States and the Soviet Union Saturday to conduct joint research on diseases was praised here yesterday as good for both countries.
Civic groups in this city and state are continuing to choose sides on the school-bond issue in next November's state-wide vote.

The formation of a library devoted to works by and about the Presidents of the United States was announced yesterday by the Theodore Roosevelt Association.

Having entered its second decade with rising new industry and trade, Israel now has a hopeful prospect of gaining economic self-sufficiency within the next five to ten years.

THE consumption of cottage cheese in this country has increased almost 80 per cent in the last ten years. This information comes from a recent survey conducted by the Department of Agriculture.
The New Yorker Hotel, the largest in Manhattan, has been sold to Alexander Gross, realty investor and hotel operator, and Charles W. Cole, the former general manager.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr. with his International, Aileen; Horst Orbanowski with his Atlantic, Ann, and Gunnard H. Faulk with Triton II among the Lightnings scored their second victories of the week-end today as sixty-seven sloops raced in the fourth post-season regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 27 -- In a picnic-type atmosphere on a day in which an estimated 13 000 thronged the show grounds. Blanche E. Reeg's Scottish terrier, Ch. Blanart Bewitching. scored her most important triumph today.
HYANNIS, Mass., Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Walter F. Munford, president of the strikebound United States Steel Corporation, took a turn for the worse today and was placed in an oxygen tent.

American maritime unions have been advised to restrain their ambitions to organize 380 Greek-crew ships already covered under labor agreements signed by the Panhellenic Seamen's Federation.

A TELEVISION adaptation of "Body and Soul," the 1947 motion picture that starred John Garfield, was the opening vehicle last night of the "Dupont Show of the Month" over Channel 2. In the main it was a grade-B tape.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28 -- Show business was upstaged here by baseball today. The first play-off game between the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Milwaukee Braves received top billing at movie studios.

IN these days of soaring prices, it is pleasant to report that wedding gifts have stayed within the realm of reason. In fact, it is still possible to find an assortment of handsome gifts for under $15.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Explorer VI, the paddle-wheel satellite, has taken the first television pictures of the earth from space and has discovered a new intense belt of radiation girdling the earth. These scientific findings, which open new possibilities and problems in the exploration of space, were reported today by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in describing the preliminary re sults obtained from the 142-pound satellite launched Aug. 7.

Steamship, passenger agents said yesterday that they hoped airline executives attending the Honolulu conference of the International Air Transport Association would correct a "misstep" taken last month.

Earnings of Safeway Stores, Inc., for the thirty-six weeks ended Sept. 5, increased 6.17 per cent and sales were 6.85 per cent above the 1958 level, the company disclosed yesterday.

The West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association announced yesterday its intention of paying a 3 3/4 per cent dividend rate on savings for the quarter beginning Oct. 1. The institution is the first in the metropolitan area to announce a 3 3/4 per cent rate.

A special project started three years ago to raise the cultural and educational level of underprivileged pupils has produced "startling" results, Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald said last night.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 28 -- Welfare aid by the New Canaan Auxiliary of Children's Services of Connecticut will gain from the organization's fifth annual dinner dance on Saturday at the Wee Burn Country Club in Darien.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Sept. 28, -- The prosecution began presenting evidence today in the trial of Malcolm Richard White, a Chester industrialist, for first-degree murder. White shot and killed Alfred F. Dugan, an organizer for an independent union, last Nov. 13.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 28 -- The storm about the execution of thirteen Iraqi Arab nationalist officers has rolled up a few thunderclouds here.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- South Africa defended its practice of separating the white and non-white races today as a "policy of peaceful coexistence."

There is reported to be some reluctance in certain quarters to bring the issue of the assault on Tibet into the current session of the United Nations. The reason given is that it has been hoped that this could be the "Assembly of Peace," and that therefore bitter controversy should be avoided. The reason is ignoble. What shall it profit the United Nations if it accepts peace with dishonor?

More than 50,000 products priced from 1 cent or less to $4,000 were shown yesterday at the opening of the National Hardware Show in the New York Coliseum. Some 8,000 hardware store owners and buyers toured exhibits of more than 1,000 manufacturers sprawled over 300,000 square feet of floor space.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Treasury bill rate rose sharply this week to a post-war record, just slightly below the historic high set during the bank holiday of March, 1933. The Treasury disclosed tonight that the average discount rate on $1,100,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills was 4.194 per cent.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 28 -- The guarded optimism with which West Germany greeted the Eisenhower-Khrushchev communique yesterday gave way to confusion and nervousness over the President's news conference remarks on Berlin today.

TWENTY-NINE species of warbler have been observed on a single day in Central Park. Their music competes valiantly with what comes out of portable radios carried by stroller's who sociably share their love of nature with their devotion to the electronic arts. Here you have a fine meeting ground for the elementals of John Kieran's new book, a wonderful portrait of our town called "A Natural History of New York City."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The newly wealthy nations of Europe were told gently but firmly today that they must adjust their trade and foreign aid policies to conform with their affluent status.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The United States took the lead at the midway point of the world modern pentathlon today with 7,664 points. The Soviet Union, the defending champion, was close behind at 7,560.
A long-term lease has been negotiated under which Station WVOX will move and consolidate its facilities in the fourteen-story Pershing Square Building at 270 North Avenue in New Rochelle, N. Y.

RAYMOND MICHALSKI, basso from Bayonne, N. J., made his appearance in a song program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. A recipient of the William Matheus Sullivan Award, he has performed with Opera '59 and with opera companies in Philadelphia and New Orleans.

The new huddle and split formation that the Columbia football team used in defeating Brown Saturday was the topic of chief interest to the coaches and newsmen attending the weekly luncheon of the Football Writers Association yesterday at the Manhattan Hotel.

A leading fighter for integration told police chiefs from all over the United States yesterday that no matter what their personal views were, the responsibility for peaceful integration lay directly on their shoulders.

An antibiotic that some medical authorities believe can cause incurable deafness has been used by the Department of Hospitals here for the last eight to ten years, a spokesman for Dr. Morris Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals, acknowledged yesterday.
The disarmament proposals submitted to the United Nations by Russia on Sept. 18 are significant because of the apparent acceptance by the Soviet Union of the need for total and universal disarmament.

The stand-by contestant whose charges of fraud set off investigations last year into television quiz shows filed a $750,000 suit in Supreme Court yesterday on the ground that his reputation had been damaged on a Jack Paar presentation.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 28 -- The day was dull and dismal. So was the ball game. The Dodgers beat the Braves, 3 to 2, in the moisture-laden air that hung over County Stadium today and nothing stirred, neither the flags atop the masts nor the crowd. A disgracefully small gathering of 18,297 watched in apathy.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Charley Grimm, who has served two terms as manager of the Chicago Cubs in the past twenty - seven years, signed today for a third crack at the job.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- James R. Hoffa said today that a preliminary survey showed twenty five officers or employes of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters were subject to removal by the new Landrum-Griffin labor law.

In 1954, Nikolai Khokhlov, a Soviet espionage agent, defected to the West and revealed the activities of the M. V. D., Soviet spy system. He gives an account of the events during the few weeks between his first contact with American authorities in Germany and Moscow and his defection.
TUNIS, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a communique made public today by Ferhat Abbas, Premier of the Provisional Government of Algeria, in unofficial translation from the French:
MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (AP) Pravda placed reams of American praise for Premier Khrushchev before its readers today.
PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 28 -- A wind tunnel that can generate velocities almost nine times the speed of sound for testing missile models was shown here for the first time today.

"Sweet Love Remember'd" identifies a play written by Ruth Goetz. With her husband, Augustus Goetz, who died Sept. 30, 1957, at the age of 56, Mrs. Goetz collaborated on four Broadway plays. The title of the widow's newest work stems from Shakespeare's twenty-ninth sonnet.
STEVE ALLEN began another season from a new location last night. His variety show, formerly originating on Sundays in New York, will be seen this season on Monday evenings from Hollywood.

The seven buildings that constitute the blockfront on the west side of Eighth Avenue between 119th and 120th Streets have been sold to the Elba Management Corporation by Embassy Associates, of which Seymour M. Tannenbaum and Burton A. Goldberg are principals.

SMALL, round pumpkins with an orange rind and a stubby dark green stem are now piled on the sidewalk before Balducci's produce market, 1 Greenwich Avenue, corner of Avenue of the Americas. They also are making a pretty appearance in other stores here.
The market for fixed-interest securities had a case of anticipatory indigestion yesterday.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 28 (UPI) -- The Navy dropped a tracking device into the eye of Hurricane Gracie today, enabling trackers to establish the exact position of the hurricane eye at all times.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., Sept. 28 -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, came to the aid tonight of his New Jersey Senate colleague, Clifford P. Case who may face a primary contest for renomination next year.

Roger Vadim, French director responsible for many of the Brigitte Bardot vehicles including "And God Created Woman," has been signed to a multiple-picture deal by Paramount Pictures. M. Vadim is in Hollywood discussing the as yet unannounced first picture.

NICE, France, Sept. 28 -- In sports in Europe spectacle is the thing. Sometimes this takes the form of playing anthems and waving flags, sometimes the form of costumes and ritual, as in bullfighting or the medieval pageants so popular in Italy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The House Un-American Activities Committee issued a document today called "The Crimes of Khrushchev."
Governor Rockefeller watched yesterday as concrete was poured down a chute into the first of 870 tubular piles that will support the new University Hospital.

New York's Summer Festival for 1959 was termed a success yesterday, with all kinds of businesses gaining benefits. Five million visitors came to the city, according to the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

It is indeed heartening to find that the lead editorial of Sept. 22 praised the proposals of British Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd for complete, universal disarmament with an effective international control organization sufficiently armed to keep the peace.

Members of the dance committee for the eleventh annual La Fete des Roses to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Oct. 15 have been announced. Mrs. Alexander M. Laughlin is chairman and Mrs. Frederick A. Melhado and Mrs. Augustus G. Paine 2d are vice chairmen for the dinner dance, which is being underwritten by Parfums Caron, for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York.

Two New York detectives spent seven hours yesterday questioning the officers and crew of the Dutch passenger-freighter Utrecht, from which a professor's secretary plunged to her death in Boston Harbor.
PARIS, Sept. 28 -- The preliminary impression of the Eisenhower-Khrushchev communique in informed French circles was favorable.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- President Eisenhower said today that Premier Khrushchev had removed any threat to a negotiated settlement of the Berlin problem.
Mayor Wagner asked the Commissioner of Hospitals yesterday for a report on a charge that two infants had died at Kings County Hospital Center because of a shortage of nurses.
Former Gov. W. Averell Harriman said yesterday that he thought the visit of Premier Khrushchev "has alerted the American people to the seriousness of the Soviet threat."

A contract to purchase the five-and-one-half-story apartment building at 1531-33 Jesup Avenue in the Bronx has been made by Ehrlich-Corso, Inc., realty investors and operators. They are buying the property from a client of Abraham L. Garber, lawyer, for cash over mortgages of about $150,000.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Sept. 28 -- Once upon a time, in the season when the autumn sun is still very bright and the return to school seems particularly dull, a spirited boy and his pals could go hunting in the forest for dragons.
Commonwealth Edison Company reported yesterday sizable gains in operating revenues and net income for the eight and twelve months ended on Aug. 31.
ALBANY, Sept. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller will make thirty-two public appearances during October, all but three of them in this state.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- More babies were born in the United States during the first seven months of 1959 than in the corresponding period of any prior year.
Rodeo performers brought the sun back to Bellevue Hospital yesterday as a hundred cowboys and cowgirls returned for their annual performance for young patients.
Greenwich Village is at present a tense, troubled area.

The Fire Department's drive for education in fire prevention will be intensified this fall to take account of apparently increasing fire hazards. Fire Commissioner Cavanagh has announced a three-month education campaign to open in the East Bronx, Harlem and in the Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brownsville and East New York areas of Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Officials of the State Thruway Authority met with union representatives today to discuss for the first time the union's demands for recognition and for a contract covering toll collectors and maintenance workers.

The Little Augie Pisano murder mystery took a new turn yesterday. It was disclosed that the slain 62-year-old racketeer had been a partner in a concern that received $190,000 worth of state-financed building work at Yonkers Raceway in 1958.
The growing reponsibility of a museum in a changing world was called a challenge yesterday by Alexander M. White, president of the American Museum of Natural History.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Changes in this country's food-distribution system will be a major premise in the plea of three large meat packers for Government permission to deal in other foods and operate retail markets, it was indicated here today in Federal District Court.

Earnings of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation this year may amount to $20,000,000 or more, Harold E. Churchill, president, said yesterday. Losses of the company in the last five years have run as high as $43,000,000 a year. In 1958 the operating deficit was $13,390,937.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- A massive relief program was started today for a million victims of what was termed the worst typhoon in Japan's recorded history.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 28 -- Roya Direct. driven by Stanley Dancer, beat Coast Dale by three-quarters of a length tonight in the Class A pacing feature at Roosevelt Raceway.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Arthur Levitt, the State Controller, still declines to reimburse state employes for tips they leave while traveling, even though the State Attorney General has ruled such claims vaild.
CAIRO, Sept. 29 -- Leading archaeologists will arrive here this week for a conference on how to save ancient Egyptian treasures from being flooded when the Aswian High Dam is built.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A Republican Congressman has gone to the assistance of the ousted Democratic postmaster of Gouverneur, N. Y.
Pat Hingle, the actor who is still recuperating from injuries suffered in a fall last February, will star on a "United States Steel Hour" drama Nov. 18.
A native son who has found greener pastures at Cape Ann, Mass. -- "the ocean and fields are so close" -- was back in town yesterday with binoculars and magnifying glass.

FRANK HAMBRECHT of Irvington, N. Y., left the house with a .38 strapped around his waist and said, "I'm going to do a bit of pistol shooting. Why don't you come along?" The reporter went and so did Charles Leining also of Irvington.
MOSCOW, Sept. 28 -- With a well-pronounced "okay," a broad smile and a wave of his fedora. Premier Khrushchev walked into the warm embrace of his colleagues and people today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- United States District Judge Matthew F. McGuire today dismissed a suit by Representative Charles O. Porter of Oregon to force the State Department to give him a passport for travel to Red China.
Commodity prices charted a downward course yesterday on most New York exchanges in dull and featureless trading.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The United States is dropping nearly 2,000 soda pop bottles into the Atlantic. It wants to find out where the current will carry them.

Hurricane and typhoon are different words for the same thing in different places. Both types of storm are cyclones, for the winds move circularly -- clockwise in the Southern Hemisphere, counterclockwise in the Northern.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- W. Wilson White, first head of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, will leave the job at the end of this week.
A painting by Andrew Wyeth has been sold to the Philadelphia Museum of Art for $35,000. The purchase was ratified by the museum's board of governors yesterday afternoon.
The Soviet Union's Minister of Higher and Secondary Education has denied reports that Moscow discriminates against Jews in educational opportunity.

The Boston Edison Company is offering holders of its common stock subscription rights to 271,553 shares of new common stock at a rate of one share for every ten held. The subscription price is $56.75 a share.
The directors of General Mills, Inc., declared a quarterly dividend of 30 cents a share on the company's new common stock yesterday. It is payable on Nov. 2 to holders of record Oct. 9.

DENVER, Sept. 28 -- Despite widely circulated statements by its officials, the Soviet Union does not want to set up a true exchange of public libraries and reading rooms with the United States, George V. Allen, director of the United States Information Agency, said here today.
Ground was broken yesterday for Stapleton Houses, a 693-apartment public housing development at Broad Street and Tompkins Avenue, Stapleton, S. I.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- Following is an official English translation, distributed by Tass, Soviet press agency, of Premier Khrushchev's speech in Moscow today on his return from his visit to the United States:

CAPE CANAVERAL Fla., Sept. 28 (UPI) -- A Polaris test rocket spiraled out of control and tumbled end over end into the Atlantic Ocean today. It was the sixth United States missile failure in two weeks.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- President Eisenhower plans to leave this city Thursday for Southern California. He is determined to break up the cold he picked up on the return trip from Europe.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 28 -- The television and radio fellows had exclusive rights to Larry Sherry for some thirty minutes after he had pitched the Dodgers to victory over the Braves today. However, that did not stymie the interviewers in the Los Angeles dressing room.

The Pennsylvania Railroad said yesterday that the steel strike had cost it $22,500,000 of revenue through the end of August. It attributed a deficit of $3,491,800 last month directly to the strike. In August of last year the system cleared $3,288,609.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 28 -- Cancers have been produced in young mice by inoculating them with cell-free material from human cancers, the 1959 Clinical Congress of the American College of Surgeons was told today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization declared anew today its determination to stand by its obligations to Laos.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- The Government predicted today that Americans would smoke a record of 465,900,000,000 cigarettes this year despite charges linking tobacco use to cancer.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 28 -- A multi-sided political fight appeared to be looming in Ceylon today as the body of the assassinated Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike was taken to the House of Representatives to lie in state. Mr. Bandaranaike was fatally shot Friday by a Buddhist monk.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 28 -- The Dodgers took a fresh stride toward that elusive National League pennant today and this one could be a big one.

BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- An African told a commission of inquiry here today that white prison officers had torn out the hair and beards of African prisoners and had made them stand naked for eight hours.
CHARLESTON, S. C., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Intermittent rains and rising winds lashed the Georgia-South Carolina coast tonight as the leading elements of Hurricane Gracie neared land.
Daniel J. Riesner announced yesterday that he would step aside as secretary of the New York County Republican committee when the committee held its reorganization meeting tomorrow.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 28 -- Several speakers at a United States Senate subcommittee's hearing here testified today that Federal legislation was required to cope with the serious problems of migratory farm labor.

CHANDIGARH, India, Sept. 28 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that India's approach to cooperation between nations with differing economic and political systems had received a "setback" because of Communist China's "hostile" attitude.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 -- The musicians of the Philadelphia Orchestra did not report today for rehearsal for the season's opening concert Friday afternoon at the Academy of Music.
The high cost of not waiting to be paid is going higher. Yesterday Carroll G. Moore, counsel to the factoring division of C. I. T. Financial Corporation, gave the reason.
The president of the New York City Central Labor Council gave hearty endorsement yesterday to the current appeal of the Greater New York Fund.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 28 -- A spokesman for the United Nations fact-finding subcommittee announced today that the team would fly to the scene of fighting in the northern provinces of Laos Thursday for five days of investigation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Grandfathers are softies even though they occupy positions of world importance. President Eisenhower confirmed this today.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 28 -- Neil H. McElroy, United States Secretary of Defense, said today that "aggression can be a possibility in the Orient as long as continuous Communist Chinese adventurism exists."
TRENTON, Sept. 28 -- The death of an 11-year-old boy today brought to twelve the toll in a suspected outbreak of equine encephalitis in south Jersey.
A leading dressmaker and a manganese miner are considering corporate marriage.

IN her new play, "The Confederates," Vina Delmar traces the tragic events of the Civil War through a series of vignettes personalizing the relationships and emotional conflicts of Jefferson Davis' Cabinet.
LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 28 -- The Sultan of Brunei promulgated today the first written Constitution for his rich little sultanate in the northwest part of British Borneo.

In the coming British elections it will be an upset indeed if the Member for Woodford is not returned to the Commons. He is former Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill and he is standing for the Commons for the twentieth time.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point (5 cents a bale) up, to 2 points (10 cents a bale) off yesterday.
Metropolitan Opera subscribers have received application forms for tickets to the opening night production of "Il Trovatore" on Oct. 26, it was announced yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Len Matthews of Philadelphia scored a unanimous decision over Paulie Armstead of Los Angeles in a ten-round lightweight bout tonight.
The new 4,500-deadweight ton cargo ship Ammon, owned by the Royal Netherlands Steamship Company will make her maiden appearance here early in November.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The general election campaign in Britain reached the halfway mark tonight with the contest much closer than was anticipated when the race began.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- President Eisenhower summoned representatives of the steel industry and unions today to meet separately with him at the White House on Wednesday. He threatened Government action unless there was an early agreement.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 28 -- The Royal Norwegian Yacht Club skippers gained the lead on the first day of races with representatives of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club and the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 28 -- Each year, for the last twenty years, the Stamford branch of the American Association of University Women has made it financially possible for an outstanding girl graduate of Stamford High School to enter the college of her choice.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 29 -- The exchange of visits between Khrushchev and Eisenhower was made desirable by establishment of a true balance of terror. Five years ago it was still conceivable, in the event of open conflict, that Russia could have been totally destroyed without being able to totally destroy the United States. This is no longer imaginable.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Wheat and rye futures scored gains on the Board of Trade today but other grains turned downward.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- Pablo Casals, the 'cellist, will conduct a master class in the 'cello and violin at the University of California at Berkeley, next spring, it was announced today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Al Lopez, a nice guy who finished first, will continue as manager of the weak-hitting, fair-fielding, good-pitching Chicago White Sox.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 -- The Dodgers raised the roof -- but mildly -- today after winning the National League pennant. The drinks were soft, but the spirit was 150-proof.
The market for fixed-interest securities turned around again yesterday.
Mrs. Steven Rockefeller, who came to the United States from Norway two years ago to learn English, is continuing her study of the language at Columbia University.

Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation announced yesterday that 36 per cent more natural gas would be available in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area for winter heating requirements. The additional supplies are the result of the opening of a new storage field at Leidy in north central Pennsylvania, completion of gathering lines to offshore wells in the Gulf of Mexico and the dual pipe crossing under the Hudson River near Seventy-second Street.
Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner offered proposals last night to combat, respectively, the problems of the aged and of the young.

BRUCE CARRITHERS, bass-baritone, sang a debut song program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. A native of Illinois. Mr. Carrithers has sung in church choirs here and toured with the "Men of Song" ensemble.

A nation, like an individual, can sometimes be its own worst enemy. That grand little democracy of Uruguay is now showing how blithely it can coast downhill to an economic crash that is quite unnecessary. Political intrigues, petty quarrels, party and personal maneuvering have been blocking economic and fiscal measures that could straighten out national problems quickly and without much austerity.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has started mailing proxy statements to stockholders for a special meeting to be held at noon on Nov. 10 at 100 West Tenth Street, Wilmington, Del., to consider revisions in the company's system for executives' incentive compensation.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Sept. 29 (AP) -- David Eisenhower, the President's 11-year-old grandson, says Premier Khrushchev "seemed like a nice man."

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Senator Russell B. Long testified today that his uncle Gov. Earl Long, had to be forcibly relieved of a "dangerous weapon," a pocket knife. before he was flown to a Texas psychiatric ward last May.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The stock market threw off most of the despondency of Monday and closed with a preponderance of minor gains here today.

HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Joe Ingraham granted a judgment of acquittal yesterday to defendant convicted by a jury in an oil map case viewed as a test of a Federal copyright law.
VANCOUVER, Sept. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Shareholders of the Powell River Company yesterday overwhelmingly approved a merger with its giant forest industry rival, MacMillan Bloedel.

The resignation of Dr. John E. Ivey Jr. as executive vice president of New York University was announced yesterday. He will be succeeded by Dean George D. Stoddard of the university's School of Education on an interim basis for the current school year.
The Transit Authority yesterday invited an investigation of its "record and performance by competent and impartial railroad experts and engineers."
Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz made public yesterday a letter of apology he has received from the Rev. W. Eugene Houston, minister of the Rendall Memorial Church, a Harlem congregation.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Sept. 29 -- Boarding school faculties always take pride in the many sons of the alumni who matriculate at the schools. It's one of the intangible rewards for teachers as it represents approval and appreciation by graduates of past generations.

THE Museum of Modern Art's "New Images of Man" show, which as of today you may go to see has had enough advance publicity to take the edge off most shows. There is plenty of edge left, although its image of modern man, i. e., Freudian and existentialist man (remember existentialism?) is not the panorama of violence, guilt-agony and loneliness that advance notices have lead us to expect.
HATTIESBURG, Miss., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- A justice of the peace ruled today that Clyde Kennard, a Negro, was guilty of possessing whiskey and reckless driving. Mr. Kennard was fined $600 and costs.
LONDON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- World rubber consumption outstripped production by 2,500 long tons (2,200 pounds each) in July, the International Rubber Study Group has reported.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Hugh B. Patterson Jr., publisher of the 1958 Pulitzer Prize newspaper, The Arkansas Gazette, Little Rock, was elected today president of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association.
WOMEN want to spend $324 for a living room sofa and $94 each for the two easy chairs to use with it. They would prefer them first to be comfortable, then simple in design and, finally, durable.

Admirers of Willie Shoemaker's riding style saw him bring home five winners at Aqueduct yesterday, including Prince Lewker in the featured one-mile Harbor Acres. The "Shoe" rode in seven of the nine races.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 29 -- A move from the top of the stretch enabled Pleasant Lady, driven by Johnny Wilcutts, to score a three-quarter-length victory over Gogo Boy in the feature pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

The United States chess champion, Bobby Fischer, and Vassily Smyslov, a former world champion from the Soviet Union, met for the second time yesterday in the fourteenth round of the world challengers' tournament in Bled and adjourned after forty-one moves according to a report from Yugoslavia.
DETROIT, Sept. 29 -- With its first small car, the Falcon, still a week away from public introduction, the Ford Motor Company announced today that it would market a second small car in the spring.
WACO, Tex., Wednesday, Sept. 30 -- A plane carrying twenty-seven passengers and a crew of six exploded in the air sixty-five miles east of here last night.
ITALOPHILES, of whom there are many among American bridge players, may wish to turn their heads the other way while the bidding and play of today's hand are recounted.
PAW PAW, Mich., Sept. 29 -- Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. toured farms and worker housing facilities today in his investigation of migratory farm labor.
TUNIS, Sept. 29 -- "Now is the time, if ever, for the United States to exert its efforts for peace in Algeria," a leading Algerian nationalist said today.

ALBANY, Sept. 29 -- Hurricane Gracie will have an effect on the bird seasons that lie immediately ahead in New York State if its blows are directed far enough north. That's what Clayton B. Seagears, head of the Conservation Department's Division of Education, said today.

An inspector of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity died of a gunshot wound, apparently self-inflicted, yesterday morning a few hours before he had been scheduled to testify before a Kings County grand jury investigating bribery.
HOWARD GREER has a whimsical streak a yard wide. Having established himself as a master of decolletage, the California designer gives a droll wink and does just the opposite.

THERE was no doubt about last night's most exciting television: the exhausting four-hour melodrama starring the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Milwaukee Braves over the American Broadcasting Company's network.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- The Government has rejected an appeal by Mrs. Morton Sobell, the wife of a convicted atom spy, to live with him in Atlanta Federal Prison long enough to conceive a child, the Justice Department said today.
Public Service Commissioner Francis T. Mylott was found guilty yesterday of drunken driving. His driver's license was revoked.

Tickets are still available for the Oct. 7 preview performance of "Cheri," which will benefit the Child Adoption Service of the State Charities Aid Association. They may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street. The play starring Kim Stanley is scheduled to open at the Morosco Theatre on Oct. 12.

The winners of this year's Caswell-Massey awards for excellence of design in men's sportswear and accessories include Maurice Tumarkin, president of Baker Clothes, New York, and Brioni of Rome. The winners were announced yesterday at a fashion show at the Four Seasons restaurant.

A United States Court of Appeals finding that a confession was coerced by police brutality paved the way to freedom yesterday for a man convicted of the felony murder of an off-duty patrolman in the Bronx in 1950.

Ten Governors of states hard hit by the steel strike urged President Eisenhower last night to name a special personal representative to serve as impartial chairman in an effort to end the costly tie-up.

With its capital freshly raised from $10,000,000,000 to $21,000,000,000, and with a record of 242 loans of more than $4,500,000,000 to show for its fourteen years of operation, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) is now a seasoned performer in its assigned field and is evidently in business to stay.
Advertisers were told yesterday that their prospects of obtaining greater results from newspaper ads were being darkened by faulty copy, media and marketing decisions.

For two active hours stocks pushed upward yesterday, then they relaxed for the rest of the session. The net result was a gain of about $1,900,000,000 in the aggregate market value of shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

DETROIT, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Ernst Kern Company, a 77-year-old Detroit department store, which its president said had been failing in recent years, is seeking permission to conduct a "going out of business" sale.

James S. Rockefeller was named chairman and chief executive officer of the First National City Bank of New York yesterday, Richard S. Perkins, chairman of the executive committee, and George S. Moore, president.
ALBANY, Sept. 29 -- Initial progress in providing 370 new air-conditioned coaches for the commuter railroads serving New York City was reported today by the Port of New York Authority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission suspended today until March 1 a proposed $9,580,000, or 25 1/2 per cent, a year wholesale natural gas rate increase by the Trunkline Gas Company, Houston, Texas.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 29 -- The Indian Government made public today a new political map showing the 2,500-mile-long border it claims with Chinese-controlled Tibet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said to today that freedom was the most powerful force on earth and imposed on individuals "responsibilities commensurate with the rights and privileges it guarantees."
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The Conservative party's electoral hopes were raised today with indications that preparation has begun for a summit meeting with the Soviet Union.

A report that the Department of Agriculture will permit cane refiners to buy and process over-quota sugar beginning on Oct. 1 for storage until Jan. 1, 1960, depressed domestic sugar prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

BRUSSELS, Sept 29 (AP) --Measures to fight the dangers of Soviet dumping on world markets of primary commodities will be proposed to the conference of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), parliamentarians in Washington Nov. 16 to 21, Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, told reporters here today.
The cats living on an abandoned North River pier near Canal Street will be admitted this week to the Bide-A-Wee Home, an organization on East Thirty-eighth Street that cares for "friendless animals."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 29 -- The Brazilian Coffee Institute announced tonight the sale of 80,000 bags of coffee valued at $3,000,000 to East Germany.

ROME, Sept. 29 -- Pope John XXIII, in an encyclical, has asked Roman Catholics everywhere to recite the rosary with particular devotion in October, praying that "the men responsible for the fate of great as well as small countries" may "carefully evaluate the grave tasks of the present hour."

The Budd Company has purchased the Lewyt Manufacturing Corporation. Edward G. Budd, Jr., president of the acquiring concern, announced yesterday. He said that the Lewyt Corporation, which makes vacuum cleaners and other home appliances, was not affected by the transaction.

MOSCOW, Sept. 29 -- Less than thirty-one hours after Premier Khrushchev's return from a thirteen-day visit to the United States, the 65-year-old Soviet leader climbed back into his TU-114 turbo-prop airliner for the journey east. The plane took off at 9:58 P. M., Moscow time.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission has licensed low-power operation of Commonwealth Edison's nuclear power reactor in Grundy County, Ill.
IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Sept. 28 -- The world's greatest concentration of nuclear reactors is growing steadily in the sagebrush country of southeast Idaho.

Favorable weather and economic conditions in the quarter that ended on Aug. 31 resulted in increased unit sales in all principal product departments of the Beatrice Foods Company, which yesterday reported record volume for the period.

The chief executive of the United Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. told a nation-wide group of Hungarian churchmen last night that whatever their personal feelings about the Soviet Union, they should encourage all possible communication with Communist political leaders and the people they rule.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 29 -- This island nation paid its respects to a dead hero today.

The one, two finish of Walter Hansgen (Lister-Jaguar) and George Constantine (Aston Martin) in the Watkins Glen Prix last Saturday means that these star drivers must meet at least once again to decide the 1959 championship in Class C Modified.
We were interested in your Sept. 21 editorial "Labor Union Hospitals?"
A 24-year-old jobless cook and ex-convict was arrested last night on charges of homicide and robbery in four recent muggings, one of which resulted in a woman's death.

The return of the New York Philharmonic from its tour of Europe and the Middle East and the start of the orchestra's 1959-60 season will be observed at a gala opening night on Oct. 15 at Carnegie Hall.

In the communique issued in Paris on Sept. 3 after their conversations, President Eisenhower and Premier Segni of Italy said: "In view of Italian interests in East-West problems and of the contribution which Italy can give to their solution. President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Segni will resume their consultations in Washington immediately after the visit of the Soviet Premier to the United States."
At the time he was murdered last Friday night, Little Augie Pisano was under subpoena by the Senate rackets committee in its investigation of a New York union.
TRENTON, Sept. 29 -- Deaths from encephalitis and suspected encephalitis increased to thirteen today as the affected area expanded toward the heavily populated metropolitan region.
A sixty-minute video tape of the Takarazuka Dance Theatre was made yesterday for future use on the "Ed Sullivan Show."

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Three witnesses said today that on Nov. 13, during a wildcat strike against the Chester Cable Corporation, Malcolm R. White, president of the company, lured Alfred F. Dugan, organizer for an independent union, to a lonely road outside Chester.

LIBERTY, N. Y., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- An increasing flow of population from urban to suburban areas of the state is causing complex problems that may require state and Federal aid before they are solved. Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today.

The United States Maritime Administration stepped into a $1,000,000,000 breach yesterday. It offered insurance coverage to American flag vessels and "certain other ships" for a forty-eight-hour period for which commercial marine underwriters have refused to accept responsibility.
An old source of trouble on the waterfront -- the question of who should load trucks on piers -- was removed yesterday.

The Marion County Building Authority of Indianapolis, Ind., has sold $32,000,000 of rental revenue bonds to a syndicate headed jointly by Blyth Co., Inc., and Halsey Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 4.149 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- President Eisenhower set himself an unusually heavy appointment schedule tomorrow in hopes of leaving late in the afternoon for an eight-day vacation in Southern California. But White House aides said his departure depended entirely on the force and direction of Hurricane Gracie.

CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Production of crude oil in Alberta rose to 424,443 barrels a day for the week ended on Sept. 21, the Alberta Oil and Gas Conservation Board reported today.

Hugh W. Long Co., Inc., underwriters of Fundamental Investors, Diversified Investment Fund and Diversified Growth Stock Fund, announced yesterday the election of Thomas J. Herbert as president and director, succeeding Hugh W. Long, who was named chairman.
CHARLESTON, S. C., Sept. 29 -- Hurricane Gracie slammed across the Atlantic coastline today a few miles southwest of here and raked the state's mid-section with high winds and torrential rains.

What will the new women members be like in Britain's House of Commons to be elected on Oct. 8? Many of the women now sitting will doubtless retain their seats and the new women members, if any, will have to be pretty able and very eye-catching to equal the Commons' present woman contingent. Vigorous, colorful and sometimes very able women have become a Commons tradition.
The Youth Consultation Service will benefit from a two-day auction to be held on Friday and Saturday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Dowling in Ardsley-on-Hudson, N. Y.
One of the three railroads in the Consolidated Railroads of Cuba group showed a profit in the year ended June 30, according to figures released yesterday. The other two showed losses.
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Walter W. Williams wants barbecue ribs for his 117th birthday.
GARRY MOORE'S weekly entertainment began a new season on Channel 2 last night in pleasant, engaging style.

The First National City Bank of New York has leased the easterly half of the ground floor and part of the second floor in the new seventeen-story building at 125 Maiden Lane. The twenty-year lease calls for an aggregate rental of more than $1,750,000. It was negotiated by Collins Tuttle Co., renting agent and co-owner of the structure with National Properties, Inc.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 30 -- Premier Khrushchev arrived in Peiping today to attend Communist China's tenth anniversary celebration.

In a message to the finance ministers of sixty-eight nations now meeting in Washington as governors of the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the International Finance Corporation, President Eisenhower has urged approval of an American plan for a billion-dollar International Development Association designed to enlist accumulating capital in Europe and Japan in helping less developed countries.
" Big Sweep! Gran Limpieza! Bring a Broom and Sweep With Your Neighbors!"

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Erie and the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western railroads today urged the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve a merger of the roads. But strong opposition was voiced by another railroad and by dissident Lackawanna stockholders.
" An independent regulatory commission is not competent in these days to regulate a vital national industry in the public interest."

DENVER, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A snowstorm buried the Rocky Mountain area today, smashing tree limbs and power lines, snarling traffic and leaving many homes, schools and business houses without electric power.

TWO specialty food shops are the newest members of the Daitch Shopwell chain. Opened last Thursday, they are situated at Madison Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street and at Third Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street. The decor is pleasing and the contents of the shelves should help make entertaining at home a simple undertaking.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- In war or peace, man will have to learn to live with increasing amounts of radiation, Dr. Shields Warren, pathologist from Harvard University and the United States representative on the United Nations Scientific Commission on the Effects of Radiation, said here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The State Department disputed today an intimation by Premier Khrushchev that the United States Government had winked at an effort to cool off his reception in Washington.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Thailand's "impressive economic progress" proceeded haphazardly in the past but could be accelerated in the future, a nine-man team from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) has concluded after a year of surveys and analyses.

Stockholders in Mack Trucks Inc., approved yesterday the merger and consolidation of the Northeast Captital Corporation, a holding concern, into Mack Trucks. The vote was taken at a special meeting here in the Statler Hilton Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Internal Revenue Service has proposed to revise its rules on the non-deductibility of lobbying expenditures in tax returns.
MOSCOW, Sept. 29 -- Premier Khrushchev endorsed today President Eisenhower's statement that there would be no time limit on the renewed East-West negotiations on Berlin.

ROME, Sept. 29 -- Premier Antonio Segni and Foreign Minister Giuseppe Pella left by air his afternoon for Washington, where they will stay for three days as President Eisenhower's guests at Blair House. They will be in New York Saturday and Sunday before flying back to Rome.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Iraq called on France today to accept the offer of the Algerian Provisional Government to negotiate a cease-fire and conditions for self-determination in Algeria.

JEANETTE SCOVOTTI, a lyric coloratura from New York, gave a Town Hall recital last night as the fourth award winner of the New York Singing Teachers' Association. Accompanied at the piano by Frederic Popper, she sang a well-chosen program that avoided banality.

America's commuting population comes in for consideration in a light-hearted study by Jerome Beatty Jr. He calls it "Show Me the Way to Go Home." Crowell will issue it next Wednesday. The commuting areas discussed are Chicago, New York, Philadelphia and Boston.

TALLINN, Estonia, Sept. 20 -- As the train rolls slowly over a hydroelectric dam on the Narva River on its way from Leningrad to Tallinn, a traveler is unaware of having crossed the border that once separated the independent republic of Estonia from the great land mass of Russia and the Soviet Union.

If man is to survive in the nuclear world he must become more socially conscious and improve his sense of values, according to seven speakers in a symposium yesterday on the Future of Man. The alternative, they said, is extinction.
IF "The Power of Darkness" were in need of a subtitle, "The Power of Leo Tolstoy" might very well serve.

TODAY is the deadline for applications by parents who were supported by sons or daughters who have died within the last twenty years and who plan to file for full retroactive benefits under an amendment to the Social Security law.
HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Iron Curtain countries dominated the world modern pentathlon championships Tuesday as Russia took the over-all team lead and a Hungarian won the swimming event.
MONTREAL, Sept. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Two Canadian aluminum companies have signed a fifteen-year agreement with Kobe Steel Works of Japan to provide technical knowledge on aluminum fabrication.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board decided today to seek criminal contempt action against five officials of the United Mine Workers Union because of dynamitings and violence in the Kentucky coal fields.
TOKYO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Japan plans to import $2,328,000,000 worth of food, materials and commodities in the six months starting Thursday, the Government said today.
HAVANA, Sept. 29 -- Premier Fidel Castro said today that Cuba was prepared to industrialize without outside help if necessary.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 29 -- A Japanese company is to build a 1,000,000 ($2,800,000) nickel smelting and refining plant at Bindura in the Mazoe Valley of Southern Rhodesia, it was announced today.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 -- Two former Peronist policemen accused as torturers completed four years of asylum in the Paraguayan Embassy here today.
New vehicles that float on air and rifle cartridges that fire two or three bullets instead of the conventional one are among the new weapons undergoing experimental development by the Army.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 -- Pressure mounted today for sweeping revision of Argentina's union organization law to reduce the power of leaders of last week's Peronist-Communist national strike.
Cus D'Amato failed to appear as ordered yesterday before the New York State Athletic Commission, which is investigating the promotion of last June's heavyweight title bout.
A port-crippling dock strike at midnight tonight on the East and Gulf Coasts was threatened yesterday.

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 29 -- Dr. Charles Fore Wilkinson Jr., chairman of the Department of Medicine at the Post-Graduate Medical School, New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, shot and killed himself with a rifle here today.

The Southern California Gas Company sold yesterday $30,000,000 of twenty-five year first mortgage bonds to investment bankers headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc. The price was 101.039 for obligations bearing a 5 3/8 per cent coupon.
Record revenues and earnings were reported by two airlines yesterday.

Twelve minutes before the passenger-freighter Utrecht sailed from Boston on Sept. 18 a call for help was heard from the cabin of Mrs. Lynn Kauffman. Mrs. Kauffman's body was found on a near-by island several hours later.
When the Los Angeles Dodgers scored three runs in the ninth yesterday it forced the first extra-inning game in play-off history.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 1 to 5 points (5 to 25 cents a bale) yesterday. Prices fluctuated in a narrow range all day.
OTTAWA, Sept. 29 (Canadian Press) -- The 25,000-member Canadian Association of Consumers declared today an all-out war on gift coupons given with purchases, popularly known as trading stamps.

In a letter published Sept. 9, David K. Webster wrote regarding the Mexican "bracero" program: "* * * to procure at taxpayers' expense cheap foreign labor * * * is one of the worst disgraces of our times."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 -- With a performance that would appeal to every dramaturgist in Hollywood, the Dodgers and Braves staged a suspense thriller in O'Malley's Chinese Theatre here today. This could have been ripped from an old script used for "The Perils of Pauline." The ex-Brooks were rescued from the edge of the cliff by a three-run rally in the ninth to tie the score.

Queens Republicans have put to work a battery of International Business Machines electronic computers to show the individual home owner in the borough how much his real estate tax has risen under a Democratic administration.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Senator Estes Kefauver charged today that electrical equipment manufacturers apparently followed a "gentleman's agreement" in submitting identical bids to the Tennessee Valley Authority and public utilities.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 29 -- The defending champion, Ernest B. Fay of Houston, who appeared to have virtually clinched the United States 5.5-Meter championship with three victories in the first four races, committed a foul today and withdrew.
TRENTON, Sept. 29 -- The opposition of the powerful Democratic organization of Hudson County has placed the proposed referendum to provide relief for commuter railroads in serious jeopardy.

Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine Ambassador to the United States, said yesterday that the legend of Western supremacy had been destroyed among African and Asian peoples by the Soviet Union's imperialist expansion and space triumphs.

The Public Education Association urged the leaders of the three major political parties in this state yesterday to urge their organizations to support the $500,000,000 school bond issue on Election Day.
The political problem of China, which has intruded into other international scientific efforts, now threatens to becloud man's view of the stars.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 29 -- Surgeons at the National Heart Institute have reported making the first direct measurements of the effects of drags on the muscular action of the living human heart.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- The Security Council and the General Assembly elected Dr. Ricardo J. Alfaro of Panama to the International Court of Justice today.
BOSTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- The discharge of a clubhouse attendant by the Boston Red Sox set off speculation today that Ted Williams would retire.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- The Licensed Tugmen and Pilots Protective Association and an independent group representing Canadian pilots have agreed to band together to halt foreign skippers from acting as their own pilots in bringing in ships to Great Lake ports.

Your correspondent Robert P. Wolff, in your issue of Sept. 25, questions the capacity of this nation to disarm. He bases his skepticism upon the probable opposition of undoubted vested interests in the military establishment, and in the aircraft and other industries with military contracts.
