UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- The record of the Trujillo regime was defended in the General Assembly today by the Foreign Minister of the Dominican Republic.
Five years ago, the New York Stock Exchange found that more than three-quarters of the adults in this country could not define a common stock adequately or describe the function of a stock exchange.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 29 -- Jerome Robbins' "Ballets U. S. A." was hailed today as a "refreshing" American cultural export and a "colossal success."
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- An Argentine-Chilean dispute flared anew today when a Chilean officer led twenty soldiers in three jeeps across the Argentine border into Salta Province.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- A bitter fight is developing in the General Assembly over the Soviet bloc's attempt to recapture the seat on the Security Council that it lost to Japan two years ago.
A director was appointed and an office was opened yesterday for the Bloomingdale Neighborhood Conservation Project.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Temperatures in the sun's atmosphere may run as high as 190,000,000 degrees Fahrenheit about ten times hotter than previously estimated, Navy scientists reported today.

CORNWALL, Ont., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The St. Regis Reserve Indians have threatened to levy a toll on all automobiles using the St. Lawrence River bridge here unless the St. Lawrence Seaway Authority pays them $45,000.

It is quite true, as Foreign Minister Eric Louw told the General Assembly of the United Nations, that in the Union of South Africa "organized attacks by whites on nonwhites have never yet taken place." It is also true that the racial problem in the Union is "far more difficult and complex" and is recognized as such by some critics of the policy of apartheid.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Harrison Flippin of Ardmore, Pa., again set the pace in the United States Senior Women's Golf Association championship today.

At a special meeting of the Chapman Valve Manufacturing Company held yesterday in Indian Orchard, Mass. stockholders approved a proposal for the acquisition of the company's assets and property by the Crane Company.
WASHINGTON. Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Earl Warren, wife of the Chief Justice of the United States, opened the new Lord Taylor store in residential Chevy Chase today by making her first "speech."
The police booked three teenagers yesterday on homicide charges in the fatal stabbing early Sunday morning of Roosevelt Bennett, 34 years old, on a Brooklyn tenement roof.

Concerned over the centralization of the legitimate theatre in New York and the general lack of opportunities for burgeoning professional actors, three prominent show people have taken steps to remedy these conditions.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Plans for a new United Nations library were submitted today for consideration by the General Assembly. A Ford Foundation grant of $6,200,000, approved by the trustees last June, will make the new facility possible.

Joint inspection teams from three city departments have found 779 building violations in a second round of "cellar-to-roof" inspections of thirty-eight buildings in the Chelsea area in Manhattan and the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
Six new foreign-made features have been acquired for United States release by Films Around the World, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

Future construction contracts awarded last month fell 11 per cent below the 1958 level, according to a survey made by F. W. Dodge Corporation. George Cline Smith, vice president and economist of the construction news organization, said the steel strike was a factor in the decline.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 -- The Dodgers today brought a National League pennant to Los Angeles in the city's second year in major league baseball.

HE was only a poor Irish immigrant with next to no education, but he had a rich uncle who gave him a start and that was all William Johnson needed. He was about 18 years old when he landed at Boston in the Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1737 or 1738.
Your Sept. 24 editorial states that "The issue that has split the world apart is dictatorship vs. democracy, rule by force by a few vs. rule by consent of the governed * * *."

A committee of police chiefs said in a report yesterday that there was a "frightening prospect" that James R. Hoffa might become "one of the most powerful law-enforcement figures in the United States" if policemen were organized into unions.

William Hayden found a five-foot boa constrictor curled about an ash can outside his apartment house at 190 Waverly Place yesterday morning. He joyfully seized it to add to the decor of his apartment.

Directors of Carpenter Steel Company yesterday declared a 100 per cent stock distribution. For each share held the company will give one share on Oct. 30 to holders of record of Oct. 13. A similar share-for-share distribution was made in January, 1956, by the Reading, Pa., steel producer.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he was still opposed to any residence requirement for persons seeking relief.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Dr. T. F. Tsiang, representative of Nationalist China, denounced Communist China today for "the recent tragic events in Tibet" and urged a General Assembly debate.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower took a break from talks about international tensions and the steel strike today to trade horse stories with the world's champion cowboy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Government officials here are following closely Premier Khrushchev's visit to Peiping. They are looking for hints about the present status of Chinese-Soviet relations.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 29 -- The United Nations fact-finding group, which leaves for the north Thursday, inspected a Government exhibit of captured weapons today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Secretary of the Treasury told the world today that the United States hoped a rise in exports would reduce the big deficit in its balance of payments, but he reserved the right to take action if this did not come about.

The board of the Distilled Spirits Institute has scored the United States Small Business Administration for refusing to make loans or loan guarantees to vendors of alcoholic beverages, Robert W. Coyne, president, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- George Edward Allen, the President collector, was in his usual ebullient spirits today.
Devereux C. Josephs was honored last night for encouraging large corporations to contribute to the country's eighty-two medical schools.
A complete outfit for Dick Tracy could be ordered this week at a hotel here, with the possible exception of the two-way wrist radio. One salesman said he could produce even that for the right person.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Sept. 29 (AP) -- May Britt, Swedish-born actress, today divorced Edward Gregson, onetime actor, ending a nineteen-month marriage. Judge Allen T. Lynch granted the actress an interlocutory decree on grounds of mental cruelty after hearing her testify that Mr. Gregson suggested she get the divorce.

A dinner party at the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow night will mark the fifteenth anniversary of the National Council on Alcoholism, a voluntary health agency for the prevention and treatment of the disease of alcoholism.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Ambassadors of the Atlantic alliance predicted today that withdrawal of the Soviet threat to Berlin would lead to a summit conference before President Eisenhower goes to Moscow next spring.

GENEVA, Sept. 29 -- A leading Greek Orthodox prelate said here that the Eastern Church would "never participate in any conversation with the Roman Catholic Church which does not have as its eventual aim the inclusion of Protestants."

The Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company issued a commitment for a first mortgage loan of $2,600,000 on an apartment house to be constructed at 799-805 Park Avenue, northeast corner of Seventy-fourth Street.
Leslie C. Overlock has been elected vice president of marketing of Smith-Corona Marchant, Inc., typewriter and office equipment company.
Like the rest of the 1960 General Motors line, the styling of the standard-sized Chevrolet has been toned down. It is basically a face-lifting of 1959 models.
Mayor Wagner returned a soft answer yesterday to former Senator Herbert H. Lehman's implied criticism of his efforts to restore internal peace to the Democratic party.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 29 -- Yale University named the Rev. Sidney Lovett executive vice president of Yale-in-China today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines has developed a simpler method for producing tungsten and molybdenum powders suitable for use in alloys, especially steels.
The Child Study Association of America has contracted to sell its five-story building at 132 East Seventy-fourth Street and has bought a larger building at 9 East Eighty-ninth Street.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 29 -- Princeton starts its quest for the Ivy League football championship it lost to Dartmouth last year with its invasion of Columbia's Baker Field on Saturday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Increased receipts at livestock markets across the country today forced hog prices on the Chicago market to their lowest point in more than three years.
WOODFORD, England, Sept. 29 -- Sir Winston Churchill told his constituents tonight that there were signs of hope for a world longing for peace.

SINCE other people were acquainted with the spiritual torment of Vincent Van Gogh, the passion of his life cannot be described as lonely.
PEIPING, Sept. 30 -- Premier Khrushchev's arrival this morning was not publicized and he rode into the city virtually unrecognized. There were no parades, no banners and no mass turnouts.

The stock market in September experienced its biggest loss in more than a quarter of a century. Prices, as measured by The New York Times combined average were hammered down repeatedly and ended with a decline of 22.64 points, the largest since September, 1931.
Advice to advertisers translating their English ad copy into foreign languages -- Atencion! Achtung! and Prenez Garde!

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare said today that the Uinted States expected to reach firm agreements on joint medical research projects with the Soviet Union by Jan. 1, when the current cultural exchange program expires.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 1 -Deaths in the typhoon that devastated Central Japan last week-end are expected to exceed 5,000, making this the most disastrous storm in Japanese history and one of the worst recorded anywhere.
Unchanged in price since last year, but substantially restyled, the 1960 Cadillac will go on display in dealer showrooms tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Sept 30 -- President Eisenhower hinted bluntly today at a crackdown on steel management and union leaders if they failed to end the industry's crippling strike by Thursday of next week.

Associate Justice John M. Harlan of the United States Supreme Court swore in Henry J. Friendly as a judge in the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, covering New York, Connecticut and Vermont.

Louis Tannenbaum, who has been director of advertising and sales promotion at Gimbels New York and branch stores since March, 1954, announced yesterday that he would resign the post Nov. 1. He previously had served sixteen years as advertising manager at Macy's New York.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (PA) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices farmers received for crops and livestock remained unchanged in the month ended Sept. 15.

The A. O. Smith Corporation reported yesterday that the brisk recovery in the auto industry, together with the company's diversification and improved operating efficiency, had resulted in record sales and earnings in the fiscal year that ended on July 31.
WACO, Tex., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Federal investigators combed through fragments of a new airliner today seeking the cause of a mid-air explosion that killed thirty-four persons last night.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The stock market continued its recovery here today.

The Israel Bond Organization started a three-month special campaign last night to sell $6,000,000 in Israel bonds in the metropolitan area. The proceeds will help aid in the consolidation of Israel's economy.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark, Sept. 30 (AP) -- All-white Raney High School here was liquidated today. Officials pledged liquidation funds to the support of other white, segregated schools.

Swelled by several sizable refundings, the amount of bonds called for redemption in September before maturity rose to $25,041,000 from $7,482,000 in August, and to the largest amount for any month since June, when $68,065,000 was redeemed.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Sept. 30 -- President Eisenhower arrived here late today to begin an eight-day vacation in the hope that the hot and dry climate would rid him of a stubborn head cold.
The name of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund was inscribed yesterday in gold letters on marble on the list of benefactors of the New York Public Library.

The recent strike at seven voluntary hospitals has increased public awareness of the need of these nonprofit institutions for community support, the general chairman of the United Hospital Fund's 1959 appeal said last night.

The four-story unoccupied dwelling at 244 East Forty-eighth Street, on a plot about 18 by 100 feet in the Turtle Bay area, has been sold by Augusta J. London to Joseph L. Ennis Co., Inc., operators. It was the first sale of the property in thirty-seven years.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Communist China began today the celebration of a decade of the People's Republic.

CHICAGO, Sept 30 (AP) -- Led by soybeans, the grain futures market rallied today to finish mostly higher. Foreign demand and short-covering lifted soybeans as much as 3 cents bushel at times on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Eisenhower has indicated, in talks with Premier Antonio Segni of Italy, that relaxation of Western defenses would be premature.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- The National League finally having got around to selecting a standard bearer, the 1959 world series will get off to its delayed start tomorrow at Comiskey Park before a crowd expected to hit 49,500.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 30 -- A Government spokesman declined today to rule out the possibility that Bonn will accede to a negotiated change in the status of Berlin.
HONG KONG, Sept. 30 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China congratulated Premier Khrushehev in Peipingtonight on the success of his visit to the United States "as an envoy of peace."

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad is about to ask for increases in commuter fares into Grand Central Terminal that may average as much as 40 to 50 per cent above existing levels.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30 -- The movie industry, which has been under intermittent attack recently for paying too much attention to sex and violence, was grateful today for faint praise without damns.

Stocks retreated yesterday on a broad front. Market values on the New York Stock Exchange fell $3,300,000,000 and September closed with the largest one-month loss since September, 1931.

Mrs. Brandon Reid, chairman for the United Nations Ball to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor on Oct. 22, has announced committee chairmen for the event. The United States Committee for the United Nations will benefit.

George L. McKenna, retired assistant chief and former deputy commissioner of the New York City Fire Department, died yesterday in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, Queens, after a short illness. His age was 77. He lived at 242-15 Forty-fourth Avenue, Douglaston, Queens.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 30 -- Dehydrated and supercooled puppy hearts have been restored and have resumed beating again in other dogs, the American College of Surgeons was told today.

CHICAGO, Sept, 30 -- A ruling that may affect the whole national economy will be handed down in United States District Court on Friday after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The decision by Judge Walter J. LaBuy will chart the future of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., interest in General Motors Corporation, a holding of 63,000,000 shares of stock worth $3,000,000,000.

A daring step has been taken by Allen Drury, author of "Advise and Consent," which has reached the top position on the best-seller list. He has chosen Loring Mandel, who has not had a play on the stage previously, to adapt his novel, newly published by Doubleday.

DETROIT, Sept. 30 (AP) -The Chrysler Corporation laid off 10,000 workers at plants in Michigan and Indiana today because of a shortage of body stampings. The shortage resulted from a labor dispute at the company's plant in Twinsburg, Ohio.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Students at ninety-two New York colleges will share a Federal loan of $2,787,098 this year.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The Sun Insurance Office, Ltd., the oldest insurance concern in the world, and Alliance Assurance Company, Ltd., announced terms today for a 50,000,000 ($140,000,000) merger.
Mrs. E. Barry Ryan's Middle Brother, the 13-20 favorite, scored a four-length victory at Aqueduct yesterday in the $28,500 Lawrence Realization.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would soon ask "well-qualified and impartial" transportation engineers to tell him whether public safety was being jeopardized because of defective equipment and operation of the city's subways.
LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP) -Sweden's Dan Waern ran his sixth under-four-minute-mile tonight at a meet in White City Stadium before 30,000 spectators. His time was 3:59.7.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -The Defense Department plans to construct the world's largest radar antenna in Puerto Rico to explore the solar system and develop a defense against ballistic missiles and satellites.
Your Sept. 26 editorial "Low Wages in New York" deserves special attention.

Like an anxious housewife who dusts the parlor just before company is due, the banks for years have engaged in "window dressing" on the final day of each quarter. That is, they have repaid their borrowings from the Federal Reserve and from other banks to give the impression that they habitually remain out of debt.

HARMON, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- The New York Central today restored the confidence of a little girl which had been badly shattered last month. Susan Keane, a 5-year-old blonde from Paramus, N. J., rode this evening with the engineer of the Twentieth Century Limited from Grand Central Station to the point here where the railroad's westbound trains change from electric to Diesel engines.
DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 30 -- In this year of relatively minor styling changes of mediumprice cars. Mercury and Edsel have drastically redesigned their 1960 models.
Livingston and Newark are at the opposite ends of Essex County in New Jersey, but they are linked by tax problems that are common to fast-growing suburbs across the country.

A fifth name has been added to the role of those this country has undertaken to honor as Champions of Liberty in other lands. The occasion is the first issue of two new stamps in the series established in the summer of 1957.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Prices for live hogs turned downward again today, dipping 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds to a new three-year low on the Chicago livestock market.
The first half of the world championship challengers' chess tournament concluded yesterday at Bled, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

Cuban journalists are putting up a brave fight for true freedom of the press, and they deserve, and will have, the support of the free press everywhere. For the respected newspaper Diario de la Marina and for columnists in the afternoon paper Avance to be attacked publicly and violently by Premier Castro because they were critical of certain Government policies is shocking.
CAIRO, Sept. 30 -- The United Arab Republic, which has been on Communist China's side many times m the past, opened a retaliatory attack on Peiping today.

The new investment market in September moved at the slowest pace of the year to date. Offerings to the public of new bonds here dropped to the lowest figure since last December; stock issues were the lightest since last November.

The Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization has informally rejected a petition by the Joint Committee for American-Flag Tankers for an investigation into the Government's transportation policies on oil imports.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The face of this sprawling old city, like the political character of much of its electorate, is constantly being changed. The changes are the despair of the antiquarians and at least half tile politicians.

Mrs. Bruce A. Gimbel, chairman for the eleventh annual benefit dinner dance for the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue, will meet at the Plaza this morning with executive board members and benefit committee heads to work out final plans for the event.

Most of the 48,000,000 suburbanites in the nation have two things in common: They dislike taxes and they face new and greater ones. In the current year 116 major tax changes have been made by states, more than in any year since World War II, according to the Tax Foundation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Some diplomatic visitors to the higher levels of the State Department yesterday forenoon thought they detected an anxiety which, in the circumstances, strongly suggested that official American faith in Soviet promises is fortunately still a very fragile plant.
Directors of the Campbell Soup Company increased the quarterly dividend yesterday for the second time this year with the declaration of 45 cents a share for payment on Oct. 31.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Domestic sugar producers are holding a series of closed meetings in Washington to discuss changes in the United States Sugar Act.
Longshoremen along the South Atlantic and Gulf Coasts struck early today and dockers in East Coast ports were expected to follow.

THE New York State Conservation Department expects a storm from Westchester County to break any day. It is because of the special hunting seasons that have been established there in an effort to reduce the number of deer.
TALLINN, Estonia, Sept. 19 -- "Here in Estonia you will see something that is completely unique in the Soviet Union -- new private homes going up by the hundreds in every city."
That so few people were killed by Hurricane Gracie when it overwhelmed the South Carolina coast is a truly fabulous example of how well human beings can now cope with the rampaging forces of nature.

Twelve boys returning home from a gang skirmish were arrested on a bus in Broad Channel, Queens, yesterday. They were carrying in a box two daggers, two hatchets, a meat cleaver, a blackjack, a chain, a toy gun and some .32-caliber ammunition.

With Nikita Khrushchev himself in attendance, Peiping today celebrates the tenth anniversary of what is officially called the Chinese People's Republic but which we call Red China. The conquest of the mainland of China by the armies of Mao Tse-tung in the late Nineteen Forties was one of the major formative factors shaping the modern world, contributing to many of the tensions of the past decade and still posing many unsolved problems.
At dawn tomorrow, New York time, the moon will pass between the sun and earth, causing a shadow to race from New England, across the Atlantic Ocean and Africa, to the Indian Ocean.
Residents and business men in the Bellevue area received support from an unexpected source yesterday in their fight to halt the Bellevue South Title I project.

Paul M. Jones, 55 East Fiftyfourth Street, has become the East Coast representative of Ansteth Imports. Robert Ansteth, an American designer, lives in Honolulu and commutes regularly to Japan to buy new furniture and accessories and to direct the supervision of articles designed by him.
DETROIT, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers today named Bill Dewitt as president in a drastic shake-up of their front office.

In his address to the U. N. General Assembly on Sept. 18 Premier Khrushchev called Formosa a province of China which must eventually be incorporated into the People's Republic of China. Permit me, as a native of Formosa, to refute this line of Communist propaganda, which unfortunately seems to have misled many otherwise knowledgeable Americans.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Khamphan Panya, the Foreign Minister of Laos, gave the General Assembly today a detailed report of North Vietnam's "aggression" against his homeland.

Diplomats, political leaders and scientists from seventy nations are meeting in Vienna to give new strength and scope to the International Atomic Energy Agency, launched with such high hopes two years ago to realize President Eisenhower's "atoms for peace" plan. The high hopes are still far from fulfillment, but considering the vastness of the project, the agency has already made, in the President's words, significant if still modest progress.

VIENNA, Sept. 30 -- The United States and the Soviet Union have tentatively agreed to exchange visits by their atomic energy chiefs as a first step in achieving closer cooperation in the development of peaceful atomic energy, informed sources in Vienna said today.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 30 -- The Skipjack, the world's fastest submarine, banked, rolled and leaped through the depths of the Atlantic today in the first public demonstration of her speed and maneuverability.

The old days when student nurses might talk to ambulance horses but were discouraged from conversing with internes, were recalled here yesterday by one who graduated as a nurse from New York Medical College and Flower Hospital fifty-four years ago.

THE Edgar M. Leventritt Foundation last night took a big step toward turning its annual competition for young instrumentalists into a major-league affair. But it still has a long way to go to challenge such contests as those in Brussels and Moscow for international attention.
Full-bodied, rich-textured tone and technical fluency were the solid virtues disclosed by Robert Sayre, 'cellist, at his Town Hall recital last night.
DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 30 -- Top officials of the Ford Motor Company said today that the company could produce cars through Nov. 15 in spite of the steel strike.
Twenty-three persons who attended the 1957 Apalachin underworld meeting lost a series of pre-trial motions yesterday. They will go to trial Oct. 26 on charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 30 -- The United States team captured its third straight Skoal Trophy regatta championship today by defeating the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club team, three victories to one.

As a daily reader of your paper as well as our own local papers, I have had occasion to watch the television occasionally in connection with Mr. Khrushchev's tour of the United States. I am, of course, an advocate of what is generally styled "freedom of the press" as opposed to government control of the press.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- France told the United Nations General Assembly today that "combat, violence and terror" would not bring Algeria independence.

The Boston Edison Company sold yesterday $15,000,000 of thirty-year, first mortgage bonds to investment bankers led by Halsey, Stuart Co. The price was 100.3199 for bonds bearing 5 1/4 per cent interest coupons.

With the solution of the steel strike still in the offing, one begins to wonder if we in our labor and management relations have not out-lived one of our oldest and perhaps most basic tools, collective bargaining.

LITTLE girls and boys will be wearing shoes from France this fall if Best's has its way. The store has assembled for children 2 to 7 years old a collection of imported shoes that is as markedly Gallic as the Eiffel Tower.
THE 61-year-old Boston lawyer who heads the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, has a battlecry -- subsidy.

Mississippi sold $5,000,000 of highway bonds yesterday to Ira Haupt Co. and associates. The net interest cost to the state was 3.998. The securities are-being reoffered at prices to yield 3.3 to 4 per cent. John Nuveen Co. submitted the closest competing bid, which would have resulted in an interest cost of 4.0234.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson's name will be on the Democratic Presidential primary ballot in Oregon next May regardless of his desires, a newly formed group announced today.

In other years yesterday might have been the opening day of the world series in Yankee Stadium. But yesterday no ball players warmed up on the infield, no outfielders shagged flies and no bright flags and pennants whipped in the breeze.

The United Nations International Children's School scholarship fund will benefit from a five-performance film festival Saturday through next Tuesday. It will take place at the Murray Hill Theatre on Thirty-fourth Street east of Lexington Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -The Supreme Court was asked today to strike down as unlawful the Administration's ban on travel to Communist China.

THERE is a gallantry about Roy Campanella's "It's Good to Be Alive"* that is almost beyond human understanding. But it is the very humanity in these pages that makes us see that he and others who have gone through what he has gone through create the highest standards of the human spirit.

The address by Foreign Minister Couve de Murville before the General Assembly of the United Nations yesterday was in the great French tradition. Liberty, democracy, civilization in the best and broadest sense of the word and an idealism that represents all we in the West are fighting to preserve were all there, and truly there by right of accomplishment and example.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from the speech in the General Assembly today by Maurice Couve de Murville, French Foreign Minister:

Dr. Richard Day, director of pediatrics at Kings County Hospital and a professor at State University Medical School, has publicly stated that in his "personal opinion" two infants died at the hospital because of a shortage of nurses.
Bernard Newman was unanimously re-elected New York County Republican leader last night. He immediately pledged himself to a campaign to make tile Republican party dominant in Manhattan.
Following is a list of passengers and crew aboard the Braniff Airways plane that crashed Tuesday night near Buffalo, Tex.:
Southbound service on the IND subway was delayed twice in yesterday's morning rush-hour by passengers who pulled emergency cords.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 -The Governors of New York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware today named a sixman committee to draft a proposal for an interstate-Federal compact for the Delaware River basin.
Two radical and opposed aproaches to the problem of community growth are illustrated by New Haven, Conn., and Sterling Forest, N.Y.
LONDON, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from the official English text of Premier Kkrushchev's speech at a reception in Peiping today, as supplied by the Soviet press agency Tass:
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 30 -- A flying scooter with a bicycle seat and handlebars atop its circular base was unveiled yesterday at Princeton University's James Forrestal Research Center.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -The Eisenhower Administration has not made any change in its Berlin policy as a result of the President's conversations with Premier Khrushchev, officials said here today.
The city's new Health Code became effective today, replacing the Sanitary Code, a ninety- three-year-old collection of health regulations last revised in 1914.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister of External Affairs, told the General Assembly today that Australia believed in free passage through the Suez Canal "without exception."
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, beat Hugh Ditzler of Berkeley, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, today in the second round of the seventieth annual Pacific Coast tennis championships.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 -Pennsylvania and Dartmouth meet in the first showdown game of the Ivy League football season Saturday here on Franklin Field.

One of the rarest breeds in the world is the Italian greyhound -- a little dog with a long history. A favorite in the days of ancient Pompeii, and so beloved that two statues honor him in the Vatican, this toy dog has become so rare that only 186 were registered with the American Kennel Club in 1958.

" The Last Angry Man," Columbia's adaptation of the novel by Gerald Green, co-starring Paul Muni and David Wayne, has been scheduled to open simultaneously on Thursday evening, Oct. 22, at the Fifty-second Street Trans-Lux Theatre and the Forum, Broadway and Forty-seventh Street. Proceeds from the performance at the Trans-Lux will go to the Beth-El Hospital in Brooklyn, where many of the scenes were filmed.
TRENTON, Sept. 30 -- The deaths from encephalitis and suspected encephalitis in New Jersey stood at eighteen tonight and the total number of cases rose to twenty-eight.
BOSTON, Sept. 30 -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation began promoting the sale of nuclear power plants today. The techniques being employed are similar to those for household appliances.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- A threeday-old unofficial strike of truck drivers threatens widespread disruption among Britain's industry and the temporary unemployment of at least 50,000 workers.

THIS is indeed proving a difficult season in television; Perry Como returned last night, voice and engaging personality as true as ever. But, after a bright and inventive opening, his show was a disappointingly lackluster affair.

A number of executive changes are being made at Hornblower Weeks, investment banking house and member of the New York Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday by Joseph T. Walker Jr. Effective today Mr. Walker becomes the concern's senior partner, relinquishing his post as chairman of the executive committee, which he held eleven years.

John C. Paige Co., Inc., insurance broker, has leased the twenty-fourth floor in the thirty-one-story building nearing completion at 110 William Street. The company will move from 111 Broadway. The lease was negotiated by Cruikshank Company, renting agent for the new structure.
TO what extent is practice necessary to an expert bridge player?

The community of Bay Shore, L. I., is about to become an important shopping area. A planned shopping center will have a Macy branch, and a Sears, Roebuck Co. unit is scheduled to be opened next Thursday.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Top management of the Erie and the Delaware Lackawanna and Western Railroads were quizzed in depth today by opponents of the roads' proposed merger, but held firm to their expressed belief that the plan would benefit stockholders, customers and the general public.

Gasoline inventories in the nation rose 114,000 barrels in the week ended on last Friday to 180,896,000 barrels. This compared with 180,782,000 the week before and 173,481,000 a year ago, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., Sept. 30 -- Funds to operate Warren County public schools for the rest of the year were voted today after a tie vote of county supervisors was broken.

ALGIERS, Sept. 30 -- President Charles de Gaulle was accused of "treason" here today in a public statement by Pierre Lagaillarde, Deputy from Algiers in the French National Assembly and a key figure in the European uprising here May 13, 1958.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Unanimous or near-unanimous support built up today for the proposed International Development Association among the member governments of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -President Eisenhower's direct plea to union and industry leaders for a swift end of the steel strike represented his first use of a technique that became familiar in the administrations of Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman.

Seatrain Lines, Inc., called upon the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to protect it from "unlawful" rate proposals by railroads. The continuance of the steamship operator's New York-to-Savannah service is at stake, it said.
Hurricane Gracie blew up a storm of buying yesterday in potato futures dealings on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- The full resources of scientific detection were used by the prosecution today in the firstdegree murder trial of Malcolm R. White, Chester industrialist.
The Douglas DC-7, the fastest commercial passenger plane until the jetliners made it a "slow" aircraft, has assumed a new role in transportation -- as an airfreighter.
Harold Huber, a character actor of stage, screen, radio and television, died Tuesday while undergoing surgery in the Jewish Memorial Hospital. His age was 49. He lived at 245 East Eightieth Street.
Harmon H. Cardozo has joined the commercial-leasing department of William A. White Sons. He was formerly with Braislin, Porter Wheelock, Inc.
A 38-year-old articulate intellectual was installed last night as a New York County Republican district leader.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Mrs. Harrison Flipin of Ardmore, Pa., extended her victories to a record five in succession as she won the United States Senior Women's Golf Association championship again today.
HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 30 -Dartmouth, preparing for its Ivy League opener with Pennsylvania on Saturday, was heartened by the return of Captain Bill Gundy to contact drills today.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30 -The Minister of the Economy, Alvaro C. Alsogaray, left today for Washington to press Argentina's request for further financial aid from the United States and Europe.

Premier Khrushchev told a group of leading American business men last Thursday night that large private credits would have to be given to the Soviet Union if American industry wished to receive large Soviet orders. He said his country was willing to pay the going rate of interest.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 30 -- State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz advised Special Assistant Attorney General Edwyn Silberling today that no further funds would be sought to continue the investigation of corruption in Suffolk County.
At least ten persons were killed yesterday when a tornado ripped through a community near Charlottesville, Va., that had-already taken a buffeting from torrential rains brought by Hurricane Gracie.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) off to 6 points (30 cents a bale) up yesterday.

IN "The Villa of Mme. Vidac," the comedy-drama by Franz Spencer that opened last night at Carnegie Hall Playhouse, some rather strange transactions are conducted. To boot, the people who frequent the establishment, as it is called euphemistically, are no less bizarre.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A retired Government geologist who inherited a small fortune in 1948 has refused to tell Senate investigators whether he gave money to Communist causes.

CARLSTADT, N. J., Sept. 30 -- The Meadowlands Regional Planning Board was told tonight that by diking 8,500 feet of the Hackensack River a saving of $38,500,000 could be achieved in the reclamation of 3,850 acres.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Air Force said today that it would build a $15,000,000 underground combat center at White Horse Mountain in New York's Hudson Valley.

WARSAW, Sept. 30 (UPI) -Marian Zielinski, a lieutenant in the Polish Army, won the featherweight title in the world weightlifting championships tonight by defeating Isaac Berger of Hollywood, Calif., the defending champion.
The market for fixed-interest securities moved ahead yesterday in all sectors.

SOMEONE reckoned recently that the average man spent three years of his life partaking of food. It is reasonable to assume that a great deal of that time is spent in eating vegetables, most of which have been cooked for such a length of time and in such an abundance of water that they are neither appetizing nor particularly nutritious.
Rosh ha-Shanah, marking the Jewish New Year 5720, will be ushered in tomorrow at sundown by Jews here and over the world.

Hope that the Metropolitan Regional Council could attain official tri-state recognition as a governmental entity waned last night. Nassau County continued to oppose becoming part of "any junior United Nations."

HAVANA, Sept. 30 -- Diario de la Marina, Cuba's leading newspaper, lashed back at Premier Fidel Castro today. Avance, an influential afternoon newspaper, joined in the criticism, which Diario began Monday.

The three finalists in the twentieth annual Leventritt Award competition from a field of sixty-three appeared on stage last night in Carnegie Hall. Two and a half hours later, and after three concertos and a breathless wait in the wings and on stage, Malcolm Frager was declared the winner.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 30 -The Shore Farm's Mayor Joe, paying $54.70 for $2, scored a victory in the Blackstone mile and one-sixteenth pace before 16,756 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. His time was 2:11 2/5.
HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 30 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union won its third modern pentathlon world championship today by capturing first place in the twoand-a-half-mile cross-country run.

Wall Street was humming yesterday with stories of the unusual arbitrage situation in the two common stock issues of Studebaker-Packard. The regular common closed at 17 3/4 a share, the when-issued common -- which will not become available until January, 1961 -- at 13 1/2 a share.
DENVER, Set. 30 -- Differing views on Latin-American population growth were heard today by the United States National Commission for UNESCO in convention here.

UNITED, NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Agricultural production around the world resumed its post-war upward curve in 1958, after a slight dip in the preceding season. The global output was 4 per cent above each of the two previous year's marks, the Food and Agricultural Organization reported today in its 1959 review of The State of Food and Agriculture.
The American Jewish Congress declared in a report yesterday that the New York City school integration program, despite its shortcomings, could, serve as a guide for other Northern cities.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 30 -- The Indian Government has granted a further extension of six months to The Associated Press to sell its news service to the Times of India.
Soviet scientists appear to be threatening the Western lead in another field that has long been conceded to be almost the "private stock" of the United States and Great Britain -- electronics.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Manufacturers Light and Heat Company offered testimony today designed to show it was due a rate of return between 6 3/4 and 7 per cent on natural gas sales.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Maurice Couve de Murville, the French Foreign Minister, told the General Assembly today that disarmament was inconceivable without a reduction in international tension.

Argentina's brilliant and dynamic young Minister of Economy, Alvaro Alsogaray, arrived in Washington yesterday. He is seeking more financial aid from the United States and the International Monetary Fund and will also sound out possibilities for more American investments in Argentina. It is to be hoped that this visit will be a success.

ROME, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Three United States officers who complained about alleged Turkish brutality to four American prisoners have been transferred from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's base in Izmir, Turkey, according to information here today.
THE seasonal premiere Wednesday of "This Is Your Life" resulted in a maiden voyage that must have left Ralph Edwards, its host, feeling like the skipper of the Titanic.

VIENNA, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Austria's Jewish community issued an urgent appeal to the Government today to make good its promises of compensation to victims of the Nazi era living in Austria as well as abroad.
The Rockefeller Plaza Outdoor Ice Skating Pond will open tomorrow at 10:30 A. M. for its twenty-fourth season.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Ted Kluszewski, the hero of the first world series game at Comiskey Park today, is a 6-foot 2-inch, 245-pounder who has slugged 259 home runs in twelve years in the majors. And these figures do not include two he hit in all-star competition in 1954 and 1955.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Feuding has broken out here between a United States delegate and a Philippine delegate over what the Filipino regards as a slighting reference to one of his countrymen.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1 -- Tiny metal clips can save lives among surgical patients in crucial danger of a "blowout" in an artery of the brain, the American College of Surgeons was told today.

Earnings of the Magnavox Company in its first fiscal quarter ended on Wednesday rose 75 per cent over those in the like 1958 period. Sales increased 50 per cent. This estimate was given yesterday by Frank Freimann, president, in an address here before the New York Society of Security Analysts.

The directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority announced yesterday that it planned to build a plant to house the world's largest steam turbine-generator. The group also said, at Knoxville, Tenn., that it had awarded the world's largest coal contract to provide fuel for the giant power producer.

IN his introduction to his newest book, "The Holy Sword: The Story of Islam from Muhammad to the Present," Robert Payne says that, "as far as I know, it is the first attempt to write a reasonably complete cultural history of the Arab conquests from the beginnings to the present day.
Babies are no longer left on the doorstep, but the New York Foundling Hospital, which celebrated its ninetieth anniversary yesterday, still cares for 150 abandoned infants every year.

The United Hospital Fund has opened its appeal for this year for contributions to the support of the eighty-two voluntary hospitals in New York. Its goal, $3,000,000, is modest, considering the needs. These hospitals supply about 60 per cent of the hospital care in New York and operated last year with a deficit of $24,000,000.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 1 -- When The Taft School band goes through its repertoire at the Big Red's three home football games this season, two songs are going to be musts. The tunes are "Dixie" and "With a Little Bit of Luck."

The New York Times of Sept. 29 reports Dr. Colin G. Clark as saying that those economists who estimate Russian growth at 6 per cent or more a year "should know better." The report conveys a belief on his part that the American economy has really been growing and is likely to grow as fast or faster than the Soviet.
TUNIS, Oct. 1 -- "To let the present chance for peace in Algeria slip away would be criminal," President Habib Bourguiba said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 587,079 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A loss charged to Hoyt Wilhelm of the Baltimore Orioles, who had pitched to only one batter in a game with Washington on Aug. 16, was confirmed officially today.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Opponents of the proposed merger of the Erie Railroad and the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad decided today to petition the Interstate Commerce Commission for a full breakdown on the nature of long-haul business they might lose to the merged road.
The American Hungarian LIbrary and Historical Society, 352 East Eighty-fourth Street, is sponsoring the debut performance here Sunday of the Philharmonia Hungarica. It will be held at Carnegie Hall.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Delegates from seventy locals of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen's Union chose an eight-man committee today to direct negotiations with the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- The Government charged today that the merger of the Pabst Brewing Company and the Blatz Brewing Company violated antitrust laws and asked a Federal court to dissolve it.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Oct. 1 -- The Writers Guild of America, which is made up of movie and television writers, has issued a strike order against independent movie companies effective Oct. 10.
Ports along the East and Gulf Coasts were shut down yesterday by a strike that stunned union leaders, waterfront employers and mediation officials.
ALBANY, Oct. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the Federal Government today to give the state surplus land suitable for work camps for juvenile delinquents.

Four walk-up apartment houses in the Bronx are involved in a series of purchases and resales reported by Geisinger Germain, realty operators. The deals involve the properties at 288-90 East 152d Street, 1631 Grand Avenue and 1884-88 Belmont Avenue.
LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Britain's Comet IV jet airliner helped the British Overseas Airways Corporation's dollar earnings to soar 32 per cent in the last year, the airline said today.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 1 -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim again faces political difficulties.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 1 -- The Montclair Property Owners Association announced today that it had petitioned the Town Commission to withdraw its urban renewal program.
The arraignment of Willem Marie Louis van Rie, accused of the murder of Mrs. Lynn Kauffman aboard a Dutch ship in Boston harbor, was postponed yesterday for five days.
Little Augie Pisano was a nervous and "very excited" host who broke up a dinner party to keep an appointment in Queens the night he was slain with a former beauty queen.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- For his two home runs today, Ted Kluszewski earned two new cars. But he can't collect, says Ford Frick, Commissioner of Baseball.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The sixty-eight member nations of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund approved today establishment of a new lending agency, the International Development Association.
A meeting of the Bronx County Republican committee broke into an uproar last night when an insurgent delegation sought to block the election of the organization's candidates.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Robert Moses, chairman of the State Power Authority, said tonight that a delay in settlement of the nation-wide steel strike would endanger construction schedules calling for delivery of the first Niagara power early in 1961.
CAIRO, Oct. 1 -- Prominent visiting archaeologists spoke glowingly today of new cultural offers by the United Arab Republic to encourage excavations in Egypt.
September sales of the eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area rose 1 per cent above the 1958 level, a survey by The New York Times indicated yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Both sides in the world series were in agreement today on one point. In their respective cubicles that serve as dressing rooms, the Dodgers insisted they were actually not so bad as they seemed to be in the curtain-raiser, and the White Sox figured the National League champions couldn't be so bad.
Mayor Wagner rejected yesterday any attempt to bar Puerto Rican and other migrants from the city.

FOR the passionate Gilbert and Sullivan buff the last few years have been lean and arid. While listening to their prized recordings and raising their own voices in the cherished tunes, they have dreamed no doubt of the D'Oyly Carte Company, which has not been here for quite a while.

Dr. Allen B. DuMont again has won national honors for power-cruiser predicted-log tests of navigation. The tabulation was completed yesterday by Donald R. Rimbach, vice chairman of the Cruising Racing Commission of the American Power Boat Association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The number of workers on strike or made idle by strikes is estimated to have passed 1,000,000.
LEICESTER, England, Oct. 1 -- In this red brick monument to nineteenth-century taste and industry, it is the young workers who make the old-line socialists and labor leaders despair.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Wheat futures prices declined on the Board of Trade today after a mid-session rally fizzled.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members idle in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, warehouses and Great Lakes ore carriers. The strike began July 15 after the old three-year contract had been extended for two weeks at the request of President Eisenhower.

A North Atlantic and coastal forecast bulletin, providing information hitherto available only to the Navy, will be given starting Monday to all cargo ships and passenger liners leaving New York Harbor.
MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 1 -- A suit to halt dredging in Cold Spring Harbor and obtain $750,000 for the Town of Oyster Bay was filed in State Supreme Court here today.
ATHENS, Oct. 1 -- The League of Red Cross Societies announced today that three new national Red Cross societies had been accepted as members. They are from Ghana, Liberia, and Outer Mongolia.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 1 -- Navy flies tomorrow to Dallas for the game that will establish just how good a football team Wayne Hardin has developed in his first season as head coach.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Treasury set a 5 per cent interest rate on a new borrowing today for the first time since 1929.
Mostly clear skies were expected this morning for those in this area who intend to watch the sun's eclipse.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 5 to 14 points (25 to 70 cents a bale) off yesterday, with the old October position showing the most weakness.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Labor Department removed New York City and ten other major labor market areas today from its list of places with critical unemployment.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- The White Sox got off winging today in their first world series in forty years and virtually left the Los Angeles Dodgers at the post. Al Lopez' Go-Go Gang crushed the National League champions, 11 to 0, in the opener of the 1959 classic before a roaring crowd of 48,013.
MOSCOW, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Moscow newspapers offered the Soviet public two different pictures of the United States today.
A tall, bony youth with thin fingers, alert eyes and a face scarred by somebody else's razor relaxed long enough yesterday to discuss what it was like to lead a juvenile gang, quit and reform.

When Capt. William Vincent Bradley was elected president of the International Longshoremen's Association in 1953, shortly after its expulsion from the American Federation of Labor because of racketeer domination, he reportedly was as surprised as everyone else.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The United States Government believes that a summit meeting will be the next step in Western negotiations with the Soviet Union, a well-informed source said today.

The State Chamber of Commerce urged a vote of yes yesterday on Amendment 6 in the Nov. 3 election. The amendment would permit the Federal Government to take over and improve the State Barge Canal system.

Ookie, a 240-pound infant walrus sporting a bristling mustache, checked in at the Aquarium at Coney Island yesterday. Ookie got her name because of her habit of crying out "Ook! Ook! Ook!" The Aquarium director, Christopher Coates, said she was "the only Pacific walrus in the world in captivity."
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Tony Lema, an also-ran all year on the professional golf circuit, took the opening-round lead in the $20,000 Centennial open today with a 7-under-par 65.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Reconnaisance satellites of the future will be able to photograph enemy territory by starlight and detect ground objects as small as two feet in diameter, an Air Force researcher predicted today.
Mozart's "Cost fan tutte" will be performed by the New York City Opera for the first time next Thursday at 8 P. M.

An eighteen-story apartment building is planned for the 16,000-square-foot site at 225 East Fifty-seventh Street, which has just been acquired by Aaron Diamond. The plot, which extends through the block to 220 East Fifty-eighth Street, was sold by the 225 Realty Company in a transaction negotiated by Henry Hart Rice, vice president of James Felt Co., brokers.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- The Women's Tri-County Golf Association won the fifth annual best-ball team match from the Garden State Women's Golf Association today, 21 1/2 to 8 1/2. They played over the Scarsdale Country Club s hilly course in a steady downpour.
HARTFORD, Oct. 1 -- Democrats took over control of county government today for the first time in Connecticut history.

Of all Khrushchev's boasts, threats, distortions and arrogance, what infuriated and saddened me most was his brandishing a model of Lunik I when he arrived as a guest, and his sarcastic presentation of a duplicate model of the Lunik to President Eisenhower.

The price of world sugar (quotations on supplies destined to countries other than the United States) soared yesterday in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The July and September positions climbed to new highs for the life of the contracts and the October futures equalled the old high.

THE chairman of the New York Shipping Association, Alexander Paul Chopin, likes to remind reporters seeking information on his activities as chief negotiator for the employers of New York longshoremen that, "I used to be a newspaper man myself.

The Health Insurance Institute reported yesterday that surgery for the treatment or detection of cancer had become one of the most common procedures among all types of surgery performed in the United States.
THERE has never been a restaurant better keyed to the tempo of Manhattan than the Four Seasons, which opened recently at 99 East Fifty-second Street.
An indictment of parents who have "abdicated their authority over their children to the television set" was made yesterday by District Attorney John M. Braisted Jr. of Richmond County.

Betty Comden and Adolph Green, who presented songs and sketches on Broadway last season in "A Party," will star in the same production next month as a feature of station WNTA-TV's "The Play of the Week."

It took thirteen years, but the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) has made the grade with Standard Poor's Corporation, one of the major security rating services. This week it raised the bank's bonds from A1 to A1+, the highest rating outside of United States Government bonds.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Six union pickets paraded around the Internal (Revenue Service headquarters today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) George Meany charged today that James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, was nullifying the effectiveness of wage protection under the Walsh-Healy Act.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- Leonard Bernstein added a new success to his triumphal tour through Europe tonight when a music-loving Berlin audience gave him and the New York Philharmonic a ten-minute standing ovation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Government said today it would investigate to determine whether imports of transistors were threatening to impair national security.

PARIS, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- A Paris magistrate postponed a decision today in a libel suit brought by Avery Brundage, the president of the International Olympic Committee, against a French sports magazine. The judge said he would give his ruling Nov. 22.
IN 1944, Gerard Schneider was converted to abstraction; he has remained loyal ever since, as his exhibition at the Kootz Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, at Seventy-ninth Street, demonstrates.
ALTHOUGH "The Gang's All Here" begins like a raffish and amusing cartoon of American politics, it gradually settles down to something graver.
A new Manhattan Jewish congregation will hold its first service at 6:30 P. M. today in temporary quarters in the assembly hall of the Fifth Avenue Hotel.
HONG KONG, Oct. 1 -- As the Chinese Communist regime celebrates this week the first decade of its rule, China's division between two governments remains the country's bitterest unresolved problem.

Per Jacobsson has demonstrated more than abundantly the wisdom on the part of the directors of the International Monetary Fund four years ago in inviting that world-respected economist of the Bank for International Settlements to come to Washington to assume the post of managing director of that giant agency for currency stabilization.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he had tentatively selected a qualified engineering firm to investigate charges that the facilities and equipment of the city-owned subway lines had been so neglected that they were unsafe.

FALL brings not only brilliant foliage, but also the opening of duck seasons. Maine and New Hampshire begin theirs next week on Oct. 9. Vermont's starts on Oct. 10. Upstate New York's starts Oct. 16 and the season in this area Nov. 14.
Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, said yesterday that new Federal legislation was essential to prevent the wholesale elimination of railroad passenger service.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The United States District Courts in New York State did not make any dent in their backlog of cases in the year ended June 30, according to a report by the director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts.
TOKYO, Oct. 1 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi called upon the nation's Leftist leaning press today to support his determination to strengthen the military alliance with the United States.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced today that Furukawa Chemical Industries Company of Tokyo had dedicated the world's first commercial plant that would use the Standard of Indiana process for making polyethylene and copolymer plastic.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Oct. 1 (UPI) -- A contract for $188,402,905 has been awarded to Western Electric Company, Inc., of New York for research and development work on the Nike-Zeus anti-missile system, the Army said today.
What is a voluntary, hospital? During the last century, public-spirited men have donated money and time to the building and maintenance of nonprofit hospitals.

The Manufacturers Trust Company reported yesterday net operating earnings of $17,231,808, or $3.42 a share, for the nine months ended on Sept. 30. This was an increase of 158 per cent from the $14,880,132, or $2.95 a share, reported for the 1958 period.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- The Sudan and Libya appealed to France today to accept an offer by the Algerian rebel government to begin discussions on the application of self-determination.
Former President Herbert Hoover praised the engineering profession yesterday as "the foundation of security in our defense and the increase of our standards of living and comfort."
Alcoholism is steadily increasing in the United States at the rate of about 200,000 persons each year. Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said last night.
Business loans by the larger New York City banks rose $85,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
SHORTLY after 9 o'clock last night, the houselights dimmed in the Grace Rainey Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and, one by one, New York's top models glided gracefully across the stage.
HAVANA, Oct. 1 -- The sale of 330,000 long tons of sugar to the Soviet Union was announced last night by the Cuban Sugar Stabilization Institute.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Charles Dillon Stengel, a man of many letters (most of them hard to understand), made a clean steal of the pre-game show at Comiskey Park today. Though unaccustomed to being out of uniform at a world series, Casey seemed to relish being on the outside looking in.

Government agencies seeking to cope with juvenile delinquency problems among Spanish-speaking people have adopted the wrong approach, the national director of the American Association of Spanish - Speaking People asserted yesterday.
The Metropolitan Opera either lost $528,873 or made $3,150 last season, depending on how you keep accounts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A labor leader, noting James P. Mitchell's promise last April to eat his hat if unemployment figures in October did not fall below 3,000,000, tonight asked the Secretary of Labor "When will you perform?"

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- The winner of the foursome tournament staged by the United States Senior Women's Golf Association today was determined indoors. Three teams had posted 80's over the South course of the Westchester Country Club in the rain and wind.

" We'd like to wish Buff (Donelli, Columbia coach) an eight-won, one-lost season." That was the jesting remark of Bill Stryker, Princeton University's publicity man, as he spoke at the weekly Columbia luncheon in John Jay Hall at Morningside Heights yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- American consumers were deeper in debt at the end of August than ever before $47,910,000,000 -- the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The Labor party pledged today the abolition of the purchase tax on clothes, furniture and many household goods in a bid for victory in the general elections.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1 -- Negotiations to end the steel strike moved into the showdown stage today under the whip of President Eisenhower's call for a settlement by next Thursday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Mink stoles were almost as plentiful as Dodger crying towels at the opening game of the Los Angeles-Chicago White Sox world series today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Out in the bleachers sat the man who umpired a sandlot game for Hank Greenberg, the couple who stood in line for more than a day and the Brooklyn fans who came to see their Dodgers, all waiting for the world series to start.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 1 -- President Eisenhower cooked and golfed today as he began an eight-day vacation in the Southern California desert country.
AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced plans today for a $30,000,000 synthetic rubber plant in India.
Singing a Bach unaccompanied motet on a hot evening is enough of a test for a student choir. Singing it twice in one day would almost seem like madness.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 1 -- Justice Samuel W. Eager of the state Supreme Court dismissed today a New Rochelle woman's fourteen-year suit to recover $95,074.68 from the Soviet Government on an unpaid note.
A patrolman who was exonerated of charges of stealing six police pistols has flied a $2,000,000 false - arrest suit against the City of New York.
ZOMBA, Nyasaland, Oct. 1 -- The Government of Nyasaland hopes to convince the country's Africans that federation with Northern and Southern Rhodesia is good for them.

The Port of New York Authority succeeded yesterday in negotiating the sale of S25,000,000 of its 30-year consolidated bonds at a net interest cost of 4.3749 per cent. The authority had turned down a bid last week that would have established an interest cost of 4.5915 per cent for the issue.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Army announced plans today to discontinue some establishments and to reduce activities at others.
The Suez Canal Authority is being run completely on economic and "nonpolitical" lines, Col. Mahmoud Younes, managing director of the authority stated yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Bar Association proposed today a revolutionary idea to reduce the trial load in criminal courts. A special panel of lawyers would act as judge and jury for persons accused of minor crimes.
CAIRO, Oct. 1 -- The United Arab Republic attack on Communist China became more than propaganda warfare today.
The stairway of a Harlem tenement collapsed yesterday as the landlord appeared in court on a summons charging fifty-nine violations of the city's housing law.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Clubwomen are being asked to visit juvenile courts in their home towns and find out how they work.
HOLMDEL, N. J., Oct. 1 -- Preparations are being rushed here for testing earth satellites as mirrors for long-range telephone and television communications.
Final arrangements are being made for the ninth annual Titian Ball for the benefit of the Italian Welfare League, which will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Oct. 10.
Edward Ochab, Poland's Minister of Agriculture, arrived yesterday for a two-week study of agricultural methods.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 1 -- More than 400 residents voted unanimously at a town meeting last night to accept a forty-two-acre estate as a gift to the town for a public park.

The International Longshoremen's Association, with 70,000 members on strike in piers along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, from Searsport, Me., to Brownsville, Tex. The strike began Oct. 1, after Southern dockers had refused to extend their old contracts. The union's North Atlantic District, which had agreed to a contract extension to Oct. 15, repudiated the extension and walked out, too.

The licenses of John F. Schroeder of Oakfield, N. Y., an owner-trainer-driver, and Andrew John Palumbo of Rochester, N. Y., an owner, were revoked yesterday by the chairman of the New York State Harness Racing Commission, Robert A. Glasser.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- James R. Hoffa said today that a survey of two-thirds of the locals in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters had disclosed no union officials holding office in violation of the new labor-reform law.
ROME, Oct. 1 -- The Opposition press in Italy accused President Eisenhower today of bad manners for going off on a holiday immediately after his first meeting with Premier Segni.
ALBANY, Oct. 1 -- New York's legislative leaders have proposed holding a nation-wide conference of their counterparts in Albany and New York City in December.

The staff of the New York Public Library deserves the thanks of all citizens of New York for the imagination and competence shown by continued and varied exhibits to supplement its normal services. Such displays are timely attempts to enrich our knowledge and to link the past with the present by means of the many pictures and documents which the library preserves.

PEIPING, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- Premier Khrushchev of the Soviet Union grasped in vain at a dove of peace today as service men and gaily-costumed civilians paraded through Peiping in a mammoth celebration of the tenth anniversary of Communist rule in China.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Share prices surged ahead in the stock market here today after a cautious start.
A dramatization of Dostoevski's "Notes from Underground" is scheduled to open at an off-Broadway house in March.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service introduced today a new income tax form designed to make tax-paying easier, if no less costly, for 17,000,000 Americans.

HONG KONG, Oct. 1 -- Peng Chen, member of the Chinese Communist party's Politburo and Mayor of Peiping, singled out Premier Khrushchev for special mention in his keynote speech for the anniversary fete today.
TRENTON, Oct. 1 -- No new cases or new suspected cases of eastern equine encephalitis were reported in New Jersey today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- On John H. Davis, head of the United Nations' aid agency for Arab refugees, said today that the assistance program had averted "disaster." He called for its continuance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Army medical men have prepared and tried on some of their own staff members a vaccine against the type of encephalitis that has broken out in New Jersey. But they do not know how good it is.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Navy showed one of its newest research ships today. It is a seagoing laboratory designed to explore all angles of submarine detection under water.

POST-MORTEM is a bridge term borrowed from medicine, and since today's hand led to several post-mortems it is appropriate that it should have been played by a physician and reported by a bridge teacher who writes about bridge for a medical journal.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson took note today of an assertion by Oregon backers that they would place him on their state's Presidential preference ballot despite his opposition.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 -- The Dodgers put world series tickets on sale at Memorial Coliseum today and thousands of happy fans snapped them up as if they were passports to Paradise.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- "Go, go, go," came the deep-throated roar from the White Sox fans, startling every steer in the Chicago stockyards. So the Go-Go Gang took off. If the Los Angeles Dodgers are interested, they went thataway.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- A fire that swept the massive stone railroad station here on May 18 has brought woe to 700 commuters who still lack shelter. But it may result in a new marine recreation center for the village.
New Yorkers who were prepared for a blast from Hurricane Gracie yesterday got only a rainy day. Other parts of the country, however, were not so fortunate with the weather.

An Army proposal to move troops and dependents overseas by air rather than ship could cut military sea transport passenger requirements by bout 70 per cent. This would involve several hundred thousand more military passengers flying overseas by air each year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The United States Government showed Premier Antonio Segni of Italy today that he was welcome here and that Italy's importance in the Western alliance was fully recognized.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- In the rush of the great nations to produce nuclear weapons capable of agonizing mass destruction, and now to find means to turn them into the utilities of peace, their Governments have paid small attention to the limitation of a more dangerous instrument for the destruction of civilization that is swiftly being assembled.

The lives of many shut-in persons will be brightened with the aid of the proceeds realized from a benefit theatre party on Oct. 22. Sponsored by the National Recreation Association at 8 West Eighth Street, it will take place at the performance of "The Gangs All Here" at the Ambassador Theatre. The play opened last night with Melvyn Douglas in the leading role.

Winter is approaching, according to the calendar, which contradicts last week's heat and humidity. Pleasure boatmen, unless they are fitting out for the joys of a cruise south down the intracoastal waterway, are beginning to haul out and store their outboard and inboard craft.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 1 -- Prime Minister Wijayananda Dahanayake, in a statement issued less than two hours after the funeral of his predecessor, S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike, appealed to the people of Ceylon tonight to help him solve problems "which have been caused by our own weaknesses."
The result of the protracted search for a new agency by C. H. Masland Sons, Inc., is "no decision."
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Judge Walter J. LaBuy revised today the time at which he will announce his ruling in the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., antitrust case.

The recent use of a high-school entrance as a battleground for juvenile gangs and the hold-up perpetrated upon a teacher in a classroom of children are a gloomy foreshadowing of more violence and crime in and around our schools unless some drastic preventive steps are taken.
Prescription drug insurance would be unrealistic without a reduction in drug costs, consumer and health insurance groups told a state legislative committee here yesterday.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 1 -- A New York ship broker who commutes from the Rowayton Station here has petitioned Mayor Irving C. Freese for relief from driving delays caused by a school bus.
The Montecatini Mining and Chemical Company, Ltd., Italy's largest manufacturer and distributor of chemical fertilizers and allied products, has reported the most successful half-year in its history.
The memoirs of the Nazi submarine chief Admiral Karl Doenitz, just published in the United States, are provocative reading for anyone interested in tilting lances over questions of wartime ethics.

Olivetti, of Italy, will acquire a substantial, if not controlling, interest in the Underwood Corporation as the result of an 88,707,500 transaction. A joint announcesment yes terday by Adriano Olivetti, president of the Italian company, and Frank E. Beane. Underwood persident, said that Olivetti had agreed to purchase 405.000 shares of Underwood common at $21.50 a share.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- The silence of the French Government on the Algerian rebels' terms for peace and self-determination represents a pause for reflection and not a snub, according to well-informed French sources.
Stocks turned a rout into moderate advance yesterday. Down sharply in the morning, they reversed themselves on rumors that a steel strike settlement would be announced before the end of the day.
MANILA, Friday, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Leon Maria Guerrero is this nation's youngest Ambassador, but he is a veteran of the diplomatic service.
The Treasury's announcement of a four-year and ten-month 5 per cent note caught the market for fixed-interest securities by surprise yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of Naval Operations, has expressed the readiness of the Navy to render the same kind of support in Laos it gave in the Taiwan and Lebanon crises.

TRENTON, Oct. 1 -- Taxable real estate in New Jersey has a true value of $26,700,000,000 or $1,300,000,000 more than a year ago. This was disclosed here today in a table of equalized evaluations made public by the State Division of Taxation.
HARTFORD, Oct. 1 -- Leaders of business and industry were urged today to establish mental health centers for their employes.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The report of today' livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Two collections of Boris Pasternak's poetry will be published this month. The University of Michigan is issuing today a volume called "Poems," translated and edited by Eugene M. Kayden. On Oct. 23, Putnam will publish "The Poetry of Boris Pasternak," translated and with an introduction by George Reavy.

Ancestor, a 10-year-old geiding, won the $16,850 Broad Hollow Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday by a head from his entry-mate, Darubini, with a $10.20 mutuel return. Both are trained by D. M. (Mike) Smithwick, Ancestor for Mrs. Ogden Phipps and Darubini for June H. McKnight.

" PLAYHOUSE 90," which opened its season last night over Channel 2, consistently has displayed a fondness for topical drama. Its premiere, "Target for Three," was suggested by the Cuban revolution and its conclusion may prove annoying to Fidel Castro: Blind mob rule may ead only to another oppressive dictatorship.

Rosh ha-Shanah, the observance of the Jewish New Year 5720, will begin at sundown today with services in temples and synagogues.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 1 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits asssured Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today that the United States "will never sell out Berlin."

OTTAWA, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Canada's economic upswing continued in the second quarter, with the gross national product running at a rate of $34,700,000,000 a year, 2 per cent above the first-quarter level.
The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., announced yesterday that its "bus of the future" would be exhibited today at City Hall. But a spokesman for the Transit Authority immediately cried "foul!"
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Evidence tending to support Malcolm R. White's plea that he had fired in self-defense mounted today at his first-degree murder trial.

Chaminade, which put on the most successful weekly show in the Catholic High Schools Football League last season, will make its television debut today with three star members of the cast slated for bit roles.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Moscow radio is conducting a global campaign of propaganda keyed to "peaceful coexistence and friendly cooperation."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) -Calvin Griffith, president of the Washington Senators, said through a spokesman today that he had no plans to move the club to Minneapolis in 1960.
