Two scientists -- an American and a Briton -- reported achievements here yesterday that appear to add new dimension to the meaning of life.

Buick has added station wagons with three rows of seats to its 1960 line, which will go on sale Thursday. The styling is virtually unchanged from the 1959 car, with its sharp, modernistic delta-wing rear-end effect.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- An appeal by the Justice Department of Federal Judge Walter J. LaBuy's ruling on the du Pont case appeared certain today.
The facade of the Stewart Building at 280 Broadway, at Chambers Street, a landmark for 112 years, will soon become a memory.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Premier Antonio Segni of Italy warned today it would be a grave mistake for the Western alliance to weaken its military defenses now.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Oct. 2 -The Peace River Power Develop ment Company, an offshoot of the Wenner Gren interests, announced the first part of its plans today for the development of the British Columbia interior to produce hydro electric power.
GREENPORT, L. I., Oct 2 -- A spongy plant previously unknown on the Eastern Coast has contributed to the ruin of this year's scallop crop in the bays of Eastern Long Island.

" The General Foods Kitchens Cookbook," a compendium of more than 1,000 tested recipes, will be distributed by Random House on Nov. 16. The first printing will total 1,200,000 copies. Relatively few major offerings are scheduled for the public capital market next week. Major offerings of debt securities on the calendar total $66,350,000, with two borrowings, a corporate and a municipal, accounting for most of the volume.
VIENNA, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Budapest radio broadcast today a proposal for direct negotiations between Communist Hungary and the United States for improvement of their relations.

A device that may make championship bridge games resemble correspondence matches in chess was given its first American test yesterday in a contract bridge game at the Cavendish Club of New York.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Emotional stress, usually associated with job responsibility, is the chief cause for heart disease in young adults, Dr. Henry I. Russek of Staten Island, N. Y., contends.

BOSTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Garrett H. Byrne, Suffolk County District Attorney, said tonight that he would ask a grand jury to indict Willem van Rie for murder in the death of Mrs. Lynn Kauffman of St. Louis.

Fred Trump's recent letter concerning the proposed Warbasse cooperative contained a number of assertions which we cooperators believe to be contrary to the facts. He states that he decided to build Warbasse because of his concern for the "overburdened taxpayer."

KING'S LYNN, England, Oct. 1 -- The rich fields and sturdy towns of East Anglia, drowsing in the autumn sun, seem oblivious to politics. Yet the Oct. 8 general election can be won or lost in its two counties, Norfolk and Suffolk.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Britain's gold and convertible currency reserve rose by 13,000,000 ($36,400,000) in September, the Treasury announced today.

THE thrifty food shopper has been looking to the porker recently for assistance in keeping within her budget. Ham, in particular, has been light on the purse these past weeks. Consequently, the old question -- to cook or not to cook the ham -- constantly has raised its ugly head.
A man leaped from the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday into the East River 175 feet below and was pulled from the water in critical condition.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Donald N. Yates, commander of the Air Force missile test center, was named Department of Defense representative today for Project Mercury support operations.
The Hamilton Watch Company said yesterday it had dropped plans to acquire Wallace Silversmiths, Inc., of Wallingford, Conn.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Poland advised the United Nations today to recognize the existence of the two Germanys and thus seek a "final solution" by working for harmonious relations between them.

PANAMA, Oct. 2 (AP) -President Ernesto de la Guardia Jr. charged last night that some United States officials were determined to block his country's "rightful demands" for a larger share of benefits from the Panama canal.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- At least the Dodgers won't be bringing frustration to California with them tonight. They gleefully jettisoned that disagreeable cargo in the seventh inning today. Just as they seemed doomed to bow again to the White Sox on this surprisingly pleasant autumn day they struck back in desperation and won the ball game.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) -Soybean futures received strong support on the Board of Trade today and prices advanced more than a cent a bushel on all deliveries. Wheat, corn and oats advanced fractions and rye climbed as much as a cent on the distant July delivery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The inventor of a solar heater that was patented this week has studied his subject -- the sun's energy -- for sixty years. He hopes that in arid regions of the Southwest his heater will produce steam power as cheaply as coal will produce it in Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Average wholesale primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent to 119.2 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Ports on the East and Gulf Coasts remained shut down by a strike for the second day yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- State Department officials dismissed today as untrue reports published in West Berlin that President Eisenhower and Premier Khrushchev laid the basis for a Berlin agreement in talks at Camp David last weekend.
The Northwestern Wildcats, as wondrous to Chicago football lovers as the White Sox are to their adoring baseball clientele, hold the center of the stage again today.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 2 -- The freezing of blood and blood components may ultimately provide the answer to the medical profession's growing needs for them, a Navy medical officer said here today.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 2 -- Dean Acheson, former Secretary of State, leveled stinging criticism today at President Eisenhower's attempt to reach an accommodation with the Soviet Union on Berlin.

DENVER, Oct. 2 -- William Faulkner, Nobel prize-winning novelist, declared today that humanity would survive both communism and democracy. With measures now being put into effect, Venezuela is reported moving toward a more balanced economy that will extend more generally the benefits of the nation's great wealth.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members idle in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, warehouses and Great Lakes ore carriers. The strike began July 15 after the old.three-year contract had been extended for two weeks at the request of President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Government today rejected an industry plea for higher tariffs on imports of cobalt, and for a quota system on imports. Leo A. TORONTO, Oct. 2 (Canadian Press) -The Ford Motor Company of Canada announced today that it had added three Canadian business leaders and one of its own top executives to its Board, raising the number of directors to thirteen.

Puccini's "La Boheme" came back into town last night, a fine vehicle for the energetic talents of a young New York City Opera cast.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 2 (AP) -- A motion directing three persons to answer questions before a Federal grand jury investigating the Apalachin crime meeting was denied today by Federal District Judge Harold P. Burke. He acted on the basis of previous United States Supreme Court decisions.

Vestal, N. Y., central school district number one plans to offer $3,315,000 of bonds on Oct. 14. The bonds are dated Nov. 1, 1959, and mature on Nov. 1, 1960 to 1988.

With five helicopters overhead, the Army Engineer dredge Essayons sailed into New York Harbor yesterday. It received the city's official welcome and praise for a job well done.

Pakistan's projected land reform is going into operation. The first group of farmers has now received title to the distributed properties. It is hoped that at least 100,000 farm families can be reached in the near future. What has been thus far a blueprint is being transformed into a reality.

School has begun again, and for some this is a good thing, if not for all. Those opposing will not be permitted to rise for tabulation, for the regulations prohibit mass demonstrations during school hours.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Loans of the new International Development Association will go only to countries that pursue sound economic policies, Eugene R. Black, president of the World Bank, said today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Sidney E. Rolfe, an economist and financier, said today that a corporation he now controls would try to complete in two and a half years a $41,000,000 redevelopment of the New Haven Railroad station and its surroundings here.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 2 -Orange County Judge Edward M. O'Gorman refused today to grant a directed verdict of not guilty or to dismiss the indictment in the first-degree murder trial of Malcolm R. White, Chester industrialist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that the average price support loan level for 1959 crop burley tobacco would be 57.2 cents a pound. It was 55.4 cents for the 1958 crop. Burley was supported at 90 per cent of parity in both years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -Treasury officials were pleased by today's reports of small-investor response to the Government's new offering of 5 per cent notes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The seventeen-county New York-northeastern New Jersey area was assured today that it would continue to receive full and accurate Government statistics to guide its metropolitan growth.
VILNA, Lithuania, Sept. 14 -- There is a passive calm in this thousand-year-old city that belies its long and stormy history.
PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Press correspondents, including several foreigners, voted in the French National Assembly today.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Share prices continued to advance on a wide front today on the London stock market. Gains, particularly among the industrials, were smaller than on Thursday but trading was more active.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Charley Neal, the hero of the second world series game, is a little man with remarkably big power. The 28-year-old native of Longview, Tex., started the season, his fourth with the Dodgers, standing 5 feet 10 inches and weighing 170 pounds.

Word that the Treasury had set a 5 per cent interest rate on a Government security for the first time in thirty years sent individuals hurrying to their banks yesterday to place subscriptions. The deadline is Tuesday.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 2 -- When Iraq quit the Baghdad Pact that coalition sought to recover from the shock by a series of political and propaganda moves. The United States, although it did not join the alliance, did join all its committees. Furthermore, we signed bilateral defense agreements with the remaining Asian members, Turkey, Iran and Pakistan.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 2 -- The New York Philharmonic gave its only performance in Norway tonight. The concert, which was sponsored by the United States Embassy, was regarded as the music event of the year.

Thousands of East Coast residents herded their children to vantage points early yesterday to see the eclipse of the sun. Many enjoyed the unaccustomed serenity of the dawn, but few saw what they had come for.

MOZART: Piano Concertos Nos. 11 in F (K. 413) and 20 in D minor (K. 466); Rudolf Serkin, pianist, and the Marlboro Festival Orchestra conducted by Alexander Schneider (Columbia). Admirable performances, illustrative of Serkin's combination of virility and poetry; but the recorded sound is second-rate, with the orchestra thin-sounding and the piano often clangorous.
TO see "The Three Sisters" again at the Fourth Street Theatre is to be moved again, not merely by the melancholy experiences of the characters, but by the purity of Chekhov's mind and soul.

THE action of this novel of political violence in Martinique, which won the 1958 Prix Renaudot and received much acclaim in France, takes place in 1945. The young poet who wrote it (the book is a first novel) now lives in Paris: at the time of which he speaks, he was 15.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 -- A rapid-transit system using buses was proposed for St. Louis this week in a twenty-year plan aimed at relieving traffic congestion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Sitting at their desks cluttered with problems as well as papers, high officials of the twin institutions of Bretton Woods, N. H. -- the World Bank and International Monetary Fund -- have been allowing themselves of satisfaction feeling a this week.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 3 -- The New York team dominated the doubles and singles matches during the second day of the Lesley Cup matches to win the quadrangular competition from Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Quebec with 49 points at the Garden City Golf Club today.
Apropos the discussion in your letters columns of articles on juvenile delinquency, it is time to review the part our courts have played in this problem, and how they got the way they are.

Department store sales extended their gains in the week ended Sept. 26, as fall buying stepped briskly ahead. Sales for September were up about 8 per cent and the nine-month cumulative increase for the district was 7 per cent above 1958 levels. Merchants pointed out that sales in the last quarter of 1958 were well above the average of the third quarter and a repetition is not expected this year.

CURIOSITY may have killed the cat, but the agility with which young Danny Dunn's curiosity gets him into and out of fantastic situations should make him last through some several more intriguing books by Messrs. Williams and Abrashkin.

USING flowering shrubs for color, instead of relying so heavily on perennials, has its advantages. Many kinds, when imaginatively placed, will give the same effect as perennials. In addition, shrubs are easier and cheaper to maintain than perennials -- and many varieties produce an abundance of flowers suitable for cutting.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members idle in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, warehouses and Great Lakes ore carriers. The strike began July 15 after the old three-year contract had been extended for two weeks at the request of President Eisenhower.
Soviet scientists, whose achievements have often won the respect of their Western colleagues, have recently come up with some ideas that have set their fellow scientists agog.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, Oct. 4 -- The Soviet launching of an 'interplanetary station" emphasized in dramatic terms once again that the United States is still lagging far behind in the space race, which is two years old today.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct, 3 -Virginia's public school integration, expanded to eighty-six Negro pupils in five localities this year, has proceeded quietly and without incident in the first three weeks.

NATURE moves in circles; Art in straight lines. The natural is rounded; the artificial is made up of angles. A man lost in the snow wanders, in spite of himself, in perfect circles; the city man's feet, denaturalized by rectangular streets and floors, carry him ever away from himself.

" THE WAR LOVER" is a fascinating novel of wartime flying. It tells the story of a Flying Fortress and its crew from their arrival at a British base during the great bombing raids on Germany to the moment, five and a half months later, when they are forced down in the Channel on their way back from their twenty-fourth mission, a raid on Schweinfurt.

The stock market recovered after a sharp sell-off in midweek, closing higher for the second successive week. Rumors of an early settlement of the steel strike buoyed sentiment on Thursday, but when no agreement was shown by Friday, traders became more cautious, particularly in view of the pending court decision on the disposition of General Motors stock by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.
FLORENCE, Ky., Oct. 3 (AP) -Two front-runners, Little Fitz and Las Olas, ran off with the two $5,000 handicaps at Latonia today as the track topped its final Saturday card with a split feature.

FEW house plants equal the gaiety of hardy bulbs which are potted in fall and forced into bloom indoors during the winter months. New ideas for forcing make it possible for even city apartment dwellers to enjoy spring bulb blossoms in winter.

The Government last week announced that the Treasury would issue a four-year-and-ten-month note carrying 5 per cent interest. The move caught the fixed interest securities market by surprise. Intermediate-term issues, which had been rising in price earlier in the week promptly moved downward.

A bridge engineer, a newspaper editorial writer from Boston and a Professor of Psychology were among the thirty-nine participants in a Poets' Forum yesterday at Marymount College, 221 East Seventy-first Street.
BOSTON, Oct. 3 -- An inexpensive method of solving metropolitan transportation problem is being developed by two researchers at Boston College.

VENUS IN SPARTA. Louis Auchincloss. (Fawcett-Crest. 35 cents.) Another of Mr. Auchincloss' expertly observed, smoothly rendered reports on the mores of Manhattan's upper crust. This time he is telling about Michael Farish, banker, whose discovery of his wife's infidelity provokes him to go and do likewise.

Greater Cleveland department store sales in the period ended Sept. 19 advanced to a level 27 per cent above the rather poor year-ago week and reflected a later Labor Day holiday this Year. This was the largest year-to-year rise reported for any metropolitan area in the fourth district, although almost all communities reported substantial increases and the district total was up 20 per cent.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Jet Propulsion Laboratory flew engineers tonight to its Goldstone tracking station in the Southern California desert in an attempt to track the Soviet cosmic rocket.

The review of Peter Fleming's "The Siege at Peking" parenthetically repeats the fiction that Peking is now called Peiping. The city's name has been Peking, which means "northern capital," through most of the last 500 years, while the city was the capital of China.

A central jury pool has been set up in the New York County Courthouse in Foley Square to supply jurors to the State Supreme Court, Surrogate's Court and Court of General Sessions.

THE aims of the forty-two artists participating in the Stable Gallery's "New Sculpture" exhibition are far too diverse for them to be considered a "school" or even to suggest any one direction or another. Ideas here are passed through every sort of imaginative and technical sieve and the general impression, one of romantic eclecticism, testifies to an age when rigqd or exclusive styles have been broken down into esthetic attitudes.
The proposal of Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz to discourage migration into the city until crime-breeding slums could be eradicated was attacked again yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower's sister-in-law, Mrs. George Gordon Moore, and her husband have been dropped from the 1960 edition of Washington's unofficial "Social List," out today.
Two United States shipping companies claimed trans-Pacific sailing records for cargo vessels last week.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Archbishop Stepinac of White Plains upset Chaminade of Mineola, L. I., 8-0, today in a Catholic High School Football League game.
Members of the diplomatic corps of various Mediterranean countries are expected to attend the Mediterranean Ball on Oct. 17.

Plant expansion news dominated district economic life in week in which hurricane Gracie took a large property toll in the Carolinas. Lone Star Cement Corporation announced it will spend $6,500,000 on its Norfolk, Va. plant expansion.
Murray Hill will make a bid Wednesday to return to the days when it was center stage in the theatrical business and Times Square was just a horse car stop.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector -- 4 recent visitor asked Premier David Ben-Gurion whether he had read Leon Uris' novel "Exodus."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- A six-man advisory panel of educators and business men has recommended sweeping changes in higher education in Pennsylvania to meet the challenge posed by double enrollments expected by 1970.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 3 -- Rutgers. an impressive victor over Princeton last week, encountered some unexpected difficulty today before passing to a 20-to-8 triumph over Connecticut before 7,500 spectators.
The men's board and the women's committee of the United Epilepsy Association are completing plans for their first educational luncheon, which will be held Thursday at the Plaza.

HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 3 -- Dartmouth College announced this week that regular exchanges of literature between the world's largest polar libraries had been arranged. One is the Stefansson Collection at Dartmouth and the other is the Arctic Institute, Leningrad, Soviet Union.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 1 -- The approach of the first general elections for the Belgian Congo has been marked by reports here of two separatist movements and threats by two parties to boycott the elections.

HOPKINTON, N. H., Oct. 3 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon broke ground symbolically today for his entry into the New Hampshire Presidential primary in 1960. The symbolism was expressed by his detonating a small charge of dynamite on the Rice Farm here.

With the possible exception of a volcanic eruption, no event in nature is more awesome than a cyclonic storm. These gigantic whirlwinds, known in some areas as hurricanes and in others as typhoons, are often several hundred miles wide.

THE Second District, Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., will present Course IV, Flower Show School for Exhibitors and Judges, on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday at the Community Reformed Church, 90 Plandome Road, Manhasset, L. I. The course is open to members and nonmembers.
IF things work out according to a rather daring plan conceived by Richard Rodgers, the sound of music in "The Sound of Music" will be stereophonic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- There is general agreement here that President Eisenhower "bought time" in his talks with Nikita S. Khrushchev. But as in the case of Walt Alston of the Los Angeles Dodgers, who came from behind yesterday in the world series, the question asked is: What is he going to do with the time gained?

TOMORROW'S opening of the grouse, woodcock and squirrel season will bring to part of Putnam County the first application of a New York State experiment in public hunting on privately owned lands.

THERE never was a king quite like Maxmilian -- we hope. He did just what he pleased, his manners were very bad and if he didn't get what he wanted, he flew into rages. And he got away with it, too, because he had a wishing stone and could have anything he wanted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission charged forty-two jobbers of automotive products in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana today with unlawful price discrimination practices aimed at freezing out competition.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- The University of Chicago will dedicate on Monday its new four-building Law Center. Vice President Richard M. Nixon, a lawyer by profession, will give the dedicatory lecture Monday night.
The Government was expected yesterday to move soon for an eighty-day "cooling off" period in the bitter East and Gulf Coast dock strike. It may do so by invoking the Taft-Hartley Act.

IN the entire repertory of cuisine there is probably nothing more elegant than a galantine. It is a work of art, not as enduring perhaps as a Picasso, yet far more suitable for fall and winter buffets.

GEORGIA and the Carolinas are costly states for the vacationist traveling south, particularly along Highway 301. For several winters past I have been watching the Travel Section of The Times for information regarding speed traps.

The Port of New York last month maintained its record-breaking pace in ship traffic for ocean-going vessels. During September a total of 2,334 American and foreign vessels entered and left the port.

IT is hardly a secret that the playwright need not necessarily stand and wait these days for Hollywood's golden touch. The latest addition to an ever-burgeoning list of writers whose works are being snagged by the West Coast's avid purchasing agents before reaching Broadway stages is Garson Kanin.

An explosion of an underground electrical transformer tore a hole last night in Central Avenue near Mott Avenue, in the business district of Far Rockaway, Queens, slightly injuring ten persons. The blast shattered most of the windows in the block.

Bobby Fischer, the champion of the United States, defeated Paul Keres of the Soviet Union in the fifteenth round of the world championship chess challengers' tournament at Zagreb yesterday, according to Yugoslav news sources.

LAST week in this space, an article on the state of painting struck a blue note with the suggestion that the art might be on its last legs. The exhibition "New Images of Man," which opened Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art, does little to brighten that prospect.

A theatre benefit at the Dec. 18 performance of "Goodbye Charlie" at the Lyceum Theatre is being arranged by the Women's Committee of the New York City United Service Or ganizations Committee. The proceeds will go toward the $1,600,000 New York goal of the U. S. O.'s national campaign to raise $11,500,000.

Tempted of the Mooring Stable led all the way to win the Beldame Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The result was gratifying to the favorite players in the throng 52.521. for Tempted, who ran as an entry with Endine of the Christiana Stable, was the strong choice, and paid $5.50 straight.

IN the evening the vast reaches of corn -- thick and yellow and bursting with an ironic prosperity -- turn to gold and a brief hazy aura settles over the prairies. All across the land farmers are harvesting record crops in wheat and corn fields, and filling the gleaming sheet-metal storage bins that are the oddest hybrid of our times.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Minnesota's Gophers, after fourteen defeats in sixteen games, smashed Indiana, 24 -- 14, today. A wide open attack left the Hoosiers paralyzed until it was too late.

Mr. Randall was a big business man (steel) and a frequently reactionary one ("my record was not good," "inexpressibly naive" are the sorts of descriptions of himself with which his book is sprinkled).

AUSTIN, Tax., Oct. 3 (AP) -- The high flying Texas Longhorns shook three backs loose for 40 yard touchdown scampers and used a bristling defense today and defeated California, 33 -- 0. The Longhorns won their third straight shutout.

" Very good business" was the word last week from the resident buying offices. Many store representatives were in the city to make commitments for merchandise for holiday selling. Fur-trimmed coats continued to be good sellers, along with evening wear in luxurious fabrics.

Va. -- The first shots to initiate the centennial of the Civil War will be fired this month in this dramatic town, where John Brown's famous raid -- the subject of the local commemoration -- came in 1859 as a shocking and bloody precursor to the hostilities that broke out eighteen months later.

SYRACUSE, N Y., Oct. Oct. 3 -- There was no doubt about the all-around power of Syracuse today. In one of Syracuse's greatest modern-day football performances, the Orangemen stopped Maryland by 29 -- 0 before a gathering of 30,000 at Archbold Stadium.

The word "cider" has come down through Greek and Latin from an ancient Hebrew term for strong drink, an intoxicant. We have softened both the word and the substance, and without a hardening adjective the cider we know today is the tanged-sweet juice of the apple, especially in October. True, cider can be potentiated.

THE public and private affairs of that philosophical panhandler, William Godwin, are an endless delight to read about, however trying they may have been in the flesh. Like Coleridge and Bronson Alcott, Godwin had a hypnotic effect on his listeners, hard to recreate from written records.

HERE is a gem of a first novel by an Irish writer who knows how to remove all barriers between her readers and her characters. From the moment Eilis Dillon shows us her little group of young people arriving in Galway -- where they change trains for Keel -- we are drawn into their lives.
Jewelry and furs valued at $34,000 were taken Friday night from the twentieth-floor apartment of an advertising consultant who lives at 40 Central Park South, the police reported yesterday.

NESTLED in the foothills of the Santa Monica Mountains, some forty-five miles from Los Angeles and near the fashionable Malibu Beach colony. Camp 3 seems quiet and serene under nature's lavish hand. The sun's rays slant across lovely mountain vistas to great live oaks and cedars.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- (Reuters) -- Croydon, one of the world's oldest airports, has fallen victim to London's suburban sprawl. It was closed last Wednesday after a three-year fight to keep it open.

The New York Rangers are looking to Andy Bathgate, most valuable player in the National Hockey League last season, to put them "in the money" once again. They are setting their sights on a respectable finish in the 1959-60 campaign plus a berth in the Stanley Cup play-offs.

An entirely new styling theme and substantial engineering changes have been incorporated in the standard-sized 1960 Fords, which go on sale Thursday. The Ford is the only one of the "popular-priced" lines to use a new body shell -- the compartment in which the passenger rides -- this year.
VALLEJO, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Another nuclear-powered submarine, the Theodore Roosevelt, slid down the ways at near-by Mare Island Naval Shipyard today.
An all-out drive on the educational problems of underprivileged children was urged yesterday by the National Scholarship Service and Fund for Negro Students.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Lynn Kauffman's diary, a record of the forty-three-day Singapore - to - Boston voyage that ended in her death, will be placed before a grand jury on Monday, investigators said tonight.

MIAMI BEACH -- A refitted cruise ship, the 7,170-ton Franca C. owned by the Costa Line of Genoa, Italy, and at present cruising in the Mediterranean, will enter the Caribbean-West Indies service from Port Everglades near here early next month.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- Pennsylvania's football renaissance was established beyond peradventure today as the Quakers defeated Dartmouth's defending Ivy League champions, 13 -- 0, on Franklin Field.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- The University of Southern California, with victories over teams from the Midwest, East and Far West, loomed today as a contender for top rating in the national football picture.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- The General Assembly is expected to end its over-all debate on world problems Tuesday and then begin to tackle specific world problems, many of which have vexed the international organization for years.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I. -- Summer visitors who wonder what happens to a resort town after Labor Day will have an opportunity to see for themselves and at the same time take part in a special "Indian Summer Week-end" here.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 3 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of the Economy, returned from the United States today with a declaration to West Germans that they must devote more of their economic resources to the aid of under-developed countries.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Oct. 3 -- Voters here will go to the polls Tuesday to decide whether the Mayor and Council are to be recalled or are to complete their terms, which expire in May, 1961.

ANDRE GIDE excelled as a novelist, diarist, dramatist, critic and essayist, but, like other writers of his nation, from Hugo to Camus, he was first of all a man of letters, whose primary masterpiece was the distinctive personality he conveyed in a variety of literary forms.
Princeton's smart single-wing forces gave Columbia's young and eager team a thorough lesson in hard-nosed football yesterday.
Five National Football League games are scheduled for today, the second Sunday of the league's fortieth campaign.

THE Prime Minister of India has spent much of his lifetime studying what makes Jawaharlal Nehru tick and so far this expert has come up with no better analysis than the common one that he is a very complex individual, "a blend of East and West at home nowhere."

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- The essential new fact this week about Algeria is that the deadlock between France and the leadership of the rebel National Liberation Front, which has lasted for nearly five years, has been broken.

BRAHMS: Symphony No. 1; Eduard van Belnum and Concertgebouw Orchestra (Epic).A warm, beautifully-paced performance. The tempos are traditional, but the supple playing and general orchestral sheen make the interpretation anything but academic.

THERE are very few stories, especially for children of the middle years, which deal so forthrightly with the friendship between a Jewish child and a Christian child as this one does. Frankly purposeful, it has its obvious moments, but it avoids the sickly sweetness of induced tolerance.

The camera is the Optima, which will be available initially in the East starting later this month. The price will be $79.95.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Tilyou Christopher's English-bred Amerigo won today's mile and one-sixteenth Ocean City Handicap at Atlantic City race course.

A New York Reform rabbi proposed yesterday that Judaism openly seek converts.

William Faulkner, author of "Sanctuary" and other novels, and poet laureate of Yaknapatawpha County, Miss., is no thoughtless optimist. The book called "Sanctuary," in fact, as he himself has said, was "the most horrific tale" he could think of.

ONCE a purely feminine diversion on a small scale, the fashion show in America has become a form of lavish fun.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 -- Los Angeles is a city full of excitement these days. Most of it has to do with the Dodgers, the White Sox and the world series, but the fashion business is doing it's share to stir up things, too.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Fred Haney resigned tonight as manager of the Milwaukee Braves of the National League.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Techniques in politics change. It used to be that you could win in this roguish business by demonstrating that you were a high-minded country boy who didn't go fancy in the big town or get hoodwinked by a lot of foreigners.

In a far-reaching decision, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second District has ruled that the Internal Revenue Act of 1939 -- the one that still covers lease-back agreements -- does not mean what the Internal Revenue Service says it means.
ST. GEORGE, Bermuda, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The freighter Mormacteal steamed into harbor today, conqueror of the two great perils of the sea -- fire and hurricane.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 4 (AP) -- An airliner with twenty-five persons aboard led a lost student-pilot to a safe landing today twenty minutes before his single-engine plane would have run out of fuel.

The pastor of the Rendall Memorial Presbyterian Church in Harlem apologized to his congregation yesterday for using his pulpit for "personal vilification and vituperation."

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The stock r arket soared in an unexpected streak of independence last week and shook off the anxiety it had been suffering under the influence of discouraging election forecasts.

Ten years of new school construction at the rate of $100,000,000 a year would leave the city with only a "nominal" need for new schoolhouses thereafter, Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald said yesterday.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Oct. 4 -- The students were in a gay mood today at The Lawrenceville School. Yesterday, the Lawrentians opened their football season with an impressive 39-0 victory over Perkiomen. The outcome has bolstered confidence in the team all over the campus.

DINAH Shore resumed her Sunday evening variety hour last night over Channel 4; hers was a spirited and tuneful affair that also contained quite a surprise. Ingemar Johansson, the heavy- weight boxing champion, turned out to be an engaging stage personality with an attractively shy and diffident manner.

Just fifteen years ago -- during the last half of September, 1944 -- Adolf Hitler startled his top generals with a dynamic plan to break out of the Ardennes Forest. "The Last Word," television program on which Dr. Bergen Evans, John Mason Brown and others discuss the use and abuse of the English language, faces another cancellation.

Judge Samuel Leibowitz deserves the congratulations of every New Yorker for having had the courage to voice publicly sentiments which so many of his fellow citizens hold and have been too timorous to express. WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Government is giving up its fight to keep postcards of Francisco Goya's painting, "The Naked Maja," out of the mails.

Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent for 63 Vesey, negotiated the lease.

A chamber music concert that began in Greenwich Village with Bach yesterday ended across town in Peter Cooper Village with Beethoven because the police contended it was all just cabaret entertainment.
The appointment of Dr. Morris Schaeffer as director of the Bureau of Laboratories of the city's Department of Health was announced yesterday by Dr. Leona Baumgartner, Commissioner of Health.

When President de la Guardia of Panama made his "state of the nation" speech to the National Assembly he plucked a few feathers from the American Eagle's tail. This is normal procedure for most politicians in Latin America. When it is done with relative gentleness and moderation, as happened this time, we can feel a sense of relief.

Luz Morales, an attractive young Philippine soprano, made her local debut Saturday night in an Interval Concert at Carnegie Recital Hall. She was accompanied by Gladys Celeste, a young and capable pianist also from the islands.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Robert Kramer, a Duke University law professor, took over last week as Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- There are no soft touches in the National Football League. The Giants learned this sad lesson all over again today. Their stern teachers were the Eagles.
Two brothers were arraigned yesterday on charges of urging their German shepherd dog to bite a passer-by who had apparently accidentally brushed against one of the brothers.
Two-thirds of the cast were new in last night's repetition of Stravinsky's "Oedipus Rex" at the City Center.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Air Force is preparing a modest cut in the operations of its globe-circling Military Aid transport Service, apparently in response to complaints by commercial airlines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- United States officials had admiration and congratulations today for the latest Soviet space feat. They voiced hopes that powerful rockets now under development would put this country back into the space race in the early Nineteen Sixties.
Not everyone in the mutual fund industry approves of the recent spurt in sales of shares in mutual fund management companies.
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The Labor party's chief spokesmen denounced the Conservative party's record at home and abroad tonight as the British election campaign entered its final and perhaps decisive days.

That jury service involves what seems to be a useless waste of time everyone with experience knows, and those who haven't served have probably been told so -- with feeling. The dreary hours spent in stark assembly rooms waiting to be called on a case is apt to be a lasting impression.
The city has announced plans for another park in Abingdon Square, sometimes called the gateway to Greenwich Village.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 -- Don Drysdale was a man on a tight rope for most of the scorching afternoon. The wire was jostled constantly and violently, but he never lost his balance and plunged into the yawning pit below. It could happen only in this land of fantasy and make-believe. He was pitching an unbelievable eleven-hit shutout.

When we huddle into those proposed bomb shelters that will protect us like a tough outer shell against atomic attack we shall bear a strong resemblance to the turtle and the oyster. William A. Shea, the chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Baseball and chairman of the Founders Group of the Continental League, yesterday indicated a growing lack of cooperation between the major leagues and the new circuit.

After discounting the usual requests for one-way tickets home, service men recently polled by the American Red Cross about what they would like most for Christmas said that the "taste of home" would be the perfect gift.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 5 -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, is here for discussions with major studio producers on the current problems of film censorship.

Frederick B. Ayer Associates, Inc., the world's largest aircraft dealer, announced yesterday that it had reduced the price $50.000 each on sixteen Convair 240 planes it is offering for sale.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 5 -- Democrats scored an upset in Bethel today as voters in eleven Fairfield County towns went to the polls.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Negroes demonstrated in front of the Lincoln Elementary School here today to demand its closing. The group asked reassignment of the pupils, who are predominantly Negroes, to near-by schools attended largely by white children.

The International Longshoremen's Association. with 70,000 members on strike in piers along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, from Searsport, Me., to Brownsville, Tex. The union's North Atlantic District, which had agreed to a contract extension to Oct. 15, repudiated the extension and walked out, too.
TORONTO, Oct. 5 -- The six valuable paintings stolen from the Toronto Art Gallery have been found wrapped in heavy paper in a private garage here.

Shirley Booth will star in a ninety-minute drama to be staged early next year by "Ford Startime" over the National Broadcasting Company television network.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 -- Like a monster that emerged alive from one of those Hollywood horror movies, The Thing gave shudders and thrills today to the largest crowd in world series history. The Thing is the grotesque screen at the left-field end of the misshapen ball field laid out in the Coliseum.

New York railroads said yesterday that railroad full-crew laws in this state required the employment of 2,242 more men than were needed for the safety of the public and the train crews. The cost of the extra men was put at $14,755,447 a year.

Conrad Cooper, chief negotiator for the twelve companies; four attachments to that statement; a reply to the companies by David J. McDonald, steel union president, and a supplementary statement by Mr. McDonald.

Production of raw steel in plants not affected by the nationwide steel strike held unchanged last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. Output was 362,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, representing operations of 12.8 per cent of the industry's total capacity.

Because Columbus Day, next Monday, and Yom Kippur coincide this year, and because Temple Emanu-El lies midway in the line of march up Fifth Avenue, the traditional Columbus Day parade will undergo some revision.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- It may well be that if Prime Minister Macmillan had not told the British people last week that a summit meeting was "all set" (he agrees he used this expression of the absolute), the White House Press Secretary would not have felt obliged to contradict him and thereby give the Labor party a new issue in the closing days of the British general election campaign.

Committees have been meeting under the chairmanship of Mrs. Donald S. Stralem to work for the success of a theatre party for the benefit of the Austen Riggs Center, a mental health treatment center in Stockbridge, Mass.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Wet weather over the Midwest growing area resulted in good demand for soybean futures on the Board of Trade here today.
A 12-year-old Brooklyn boy was shot and killed yesterday while he and a friend were playing with a pistol they had found in a bedroom closet.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Adam Rapacki, Polish Foreign Minister, urged today that Poland be elected to the Security Council on the ground that this would help reduce international tension.

WILLIAM MASSELOS' piano recital at Town Hall last night was wholly admirable. If Americans were not so self-conscious about their art and artists, there would be unquestioning acceptance of this pianist's station among the ablest in the business, and people would hurry to hear him as eagerly as some latter-day sensation from abroad.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members idle in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, warehouses and Great Lakes ore carriers. The strike began July 15 after the old three-year contract had been extended for two weeks at the request of President Eisenhower.
TOKYO, Oct. 5 -- The Korean war has been renewed, on a small scale, within the walls of a Japanese prison.
BUFFALO, Oct 3 -- A steel worker, one of 30,000 in this area out on strike for nearly twelve weeks, summed up the effects of the long shutdown.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 -- As California's high-fashion designers continue to unveil their collections for next spring to store buyers and top merchandising executives from all over the country, sometimes the most spectacular show is to be found in the audience.

Stockholders in Standard Brands, Inc., at a special meeting here yesterday approved proposals to split the company's common stock two-for-one and to increase the authorized common shares to 10,000,000 from 5,000,000.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 6 -- The Communist party is being challenged for control of professional organizations in Iraq and it is losing in the early stages of this struggle.
HONG KONG Oct. 6 -- Communist China began a campaign of praise for the Russian "moon" shots today and coupled it with jeering remarks about-launching failures in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The International Cotton Advisory Committee has predicted that exports of United States cotton will pick up sharply during the marketing year that began Aug. 1. A sharp drop was shown in the preceding year.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 -- This Western metropolis has had its first world series -- a stunning three-day spectacle -- but it hasn't won it yet.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Malcolm Richard White testified in his own defense today on the sixteenth day of his trial in Orange County Court here.

LIKE all famous men, Salvatore Ferragamo of Florence looks back on his shoe-designing career with mixed emotion. The man who once made the round, stubby-looking toe popular and who created Wedgies, Signor Ferragamo now believes that nothing in the world will replace the tapered, high-heeled pump in his affection.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Oct. 6 -- The Mayor and Council here were removed from office today in a bitterly fought recall. It was said to be the first such election in New Jersey involving an entire governing body.

TOKYO, Oct. 6 -- The United States armed forces in Japan have completed a week of intensive operations for typhoon relief and rescues. These have saved possibly hundreds of lives and made thousands of new friends for the men in khaki.
The Most Rev. Joost de Blank, Anglican Archbishop of Capetown, South Africa said last night that when politicians interfered in theology the church had "no alternative but to resist."

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 6 (UPI) -- An Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile was fired over the full range of 5,500 miles down the Atlantic today. It was followed by a 1,700-mile shot of a medium-range Thor.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Israel declared today that her offer to negotiate a Palestine peace settlement with the Arab states had been rejected.
WEST YELLOWSTONE, Mont, Oct. 3 -- A spectacular transformation of nature's "plumbing system" in Yellowstone National Park has resulted from the severest known earthquake to shake the area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that the United States held the Soviet Union responsible "to a degree" for the actions of China and other Communist-bloc nations.
The latest United Nations debate on Suez again confronts that organization with two separate issues, both of which go straight to the core of its being.

ALBANY, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A delegation of teen-agers in the state is opposed to curfews and to lowering the legal working age. The group objects to going steady, unless the aim is marriage, and it opposes early marriages.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Alva Kelley was never one to be discouraged when he was football coach at Brown, and he continues to be his cheerful self in his first season at Colgate.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- The Soviet Union charged today that "discrimination" in the United Nations against the countries of Eastern Europe was damaging the prospects, for international peace and undermining the reputation of the world organization.

At a reported cost of $15,000,000, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Ben-Hur" may be the most expensive movie ever made, but it is not the longest. After trimming and retrimming the 1,100,000 feet of photographed film to a final 19,000 feet, Metro has clocked the length of "Ben-Hur" at three hours and thirty-three minutes.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Donald M. Ferguson, the president of the Australian Tennis Association said today the United States would head a campaign within a year to have Davis Cup matches played on a surface common to all nations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A Colorado insurance man said today he bought 51,420 shares of Hamilton Oil and Gas Corporation stock after he had heard that Frank Leahy, former Notre Dame football coach, was joining the company. He resold most of it at a profit, he said.

The Phoenix Steel Corporation (formerly the Barium Steel Corporation) announced yesterday that it had received an offer from a group of British manufacturing concerns to build Phoenix' proposed $44,000,000 steel plant on the Delaware River in Burlington and Florence Townships, N. J. Financing would be provided primarily by four large British banks, with the proffered credit guaranteed by a British Government agency, the announcement said.
HONG KONG, Oct. 6 -- Observers here believe that Communist China has recently embarked on a distinctly intransigent foreign policy.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- V. K. Krishna Menon of India told the General Assembly today that his nation would negotiate peacefully with Communist China over their disputed border.
Benjamin Cymrot, suspended executive officer of the old Bureau of Real Estate, was dismissed "from the service of the city" yesterday by J. Clarence Davies, Commissioner of Real Estate.

WHEN William Dean Howells died in 1920 at the age of 83 he had been an author for sixty-three years and an important and influential writer for nearly as long. He had written more than 100 books -- poetry, plays, farces, autobiographies, travel essays, criticism, short stories and novels -- and he was not even tired. He was still writing books.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 6 -- The United States will "very soon" overtake the Soviet Union in the field of space travel, Prof. Herman Oberth, German rocket expert, predicted today.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Yale University announced the appointment today of a special committee designed to insure good relations between students and the city of New Haven.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Most Americans, except for a curiously assorted vocal minority, seem to agree that President Eisenhower deserves the nation's and the world's gratitude for having broken through the diplomatic deadlock and opened the door to a possible liquidation of the cold war.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 6 -- As The Hill School's varsity football squad practiced on Dell Field this afternoon, the thermometer registered 80 degrees in the shade. No one knew what it read in the sun and no one seemed to care.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 6 -- The six-nation European atomic energy pool, Euratom, entered into two agreements here today for a $10,000,000 peaceful atomic energy exchange program with Canada.
The outbreak of equine encephalitis among humans in New Jersey appeared last night to be on the wane with no new cases or suspected cases reported since Monday.
A proposed National Cultural Center on the Potomac will be an asset for all the performing arts and for national prestige as well, an international music conference was told here yesterday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 6 -- A frontier dispute appeared today to be building up between Pakistan and Communist China.

Dr. and Mrs. Lewis Byrne Robinson of 131 East Sixty-fifth Street and Quogue, L. I., will give a dinner in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria before the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball on Dec. 21 to honor their daughter, Miss. Lenore Margaret Robinson.

News turned the stock market yesterday. It had opened with a decline and had been drifting steadily downward when word came that President Eisenhower had made the first move toward invocation of the Taft-Hartley Act in the longshoremen's wage dispute.

Joey Adams, comedian and author, was installed as president of the American Guild of Variety Artists yesterday morning at the New Yorker Hotel. Mr. Adams recently defeated Penny Singleton in a bitter election.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The possibility that the radioactivity of water can be reduced by algae was indicated in a single sentence of a pamphlet issued today by the Public Health Service.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court ordered today the discharge of a special grand jury convened in Philadelphia to investigate Local 107 of the Teamsters Union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Premier Adnan Menderes of Turkey said today that Premier Khrushchev's anxiety to end the "cold war" had not resulted in a slackening of Soviet pressure and propaganda in the Middle East.

ALBANY, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- The State Conservation Department said today that it would "stand pat" on its decision to permit a ten-day open season for taking anterless deer. The program was "based on facts obtained by men who have spent their lives studying deer habits," a spokesman said.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- In the midst of the latest Soviet successes in space, the United States is curtailing its scientific space program as a result of Congressional budget cuts.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Paul Thompson 2d of Northeast Harbor, Me., won today's race in the International One-Design Class yacht championship.
Watching the Channel 7 television program, "Everything Goes," can be a doleful experience, like seeing old friends in trouble.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- The National Labor Relations Board split 3 to 2 today in its first interpretation of the new labor-reform law.

Continuing its advances in the small-car field. American Motors will offer a three-seat station wagon with side-opening rear door in the Rambler line that goes on sale Wednesday. Prices are unchanged from 1959.

IF water chestnuts become hard to find, the kitchens of Sara Lee may well be responsible. This concern is using the vegetable for its latest product, which is not a water chestnut cake. It is a frozen prepared main dish called Chicken Sara Lee.
A committee meeting to complete plans for the Around the World Fashion Show will be held in Mrs. Herbert L. Wisner's home at 815 Park Avenue this morning.
An official of the New York Central Railroad testified yesterday that the state's railroad "full-crew" laws required the employment of 816 "excess" men at an "annual cost of $5,916,609.24.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just returned from a visit to England, where I was much impressed with the recent developments in British highway transportation. As we all know, the small automobile and the motorcycle are becoming increasingly common abroad. It has apparently been felt necessary, with the smaller engines, to reduce the efficacy of the mufflers in the interest of power conservation.

A group of New Yorkers who were active a year ago in promoting Nelson A. Rockefeller's candidacy for Governor announced yesterday the establishment of a Rockefeller for President Citizens Information Center.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A Federal judge held here today that the Government could not deport Chinese aliens to Taiwan (Formosa) against their will because the United State did not consider Taiwan a part of China.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 6 -- Federal, state and local experts discussed the effect of commercial jet operations on airports and communities today. The occasion was the annual State Airport Development Operation Conference.
Otto L. Nelson Jr. announced yesterday that the State Commission on City Governmental Operations had staked out five areas of New York City's government for field studies.

Earnings of factory workers in this city range from "high to low" in comparison with other manufacturing centers of the country, a preliminary report in a city Labor Department survey indicated yesterday.
DENVER, Oct. 6 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut said today that he was alarmed over what he described as a "sudden flare-up of activity to get business into politics."

Shareholders in the Reynolds Metals Company yesterday approved an increase in authorized common from 13,500,000 shares to 20,000,000 for a three-for-two split of outstanding common. The action took place at a meeting in Richmond, Va. The increase and split become effective on Oct. 13.

Wayne County, Michigan yesterday sold $26,000,000 of water bonds to Northern Trust Company and the First National Bank, both of Chicago, and Goldman Sachs Co. The group bid 100.008 with 4 1/4 and 4 per cent coupons to set a net interest cost to the county of 4.084 per cent.
IN an age that runs to superlatives, it is difficult to single out the truly rare talent. Such is Emeric Partos, Bergdorf Goodman's exceptional fur designer.

LONDON, Oct. 6 (Reuters) -- Britain's Jodrell Bank radio-telescope picked up signals on one of the two frequencies used by the Soviet satellite's transmitters for all but four minutes of the two-hour signaling period today.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Stock market prices advanced here today, although the demand remained selective and the majority of gains were in pennies. The trading was very active with the heavy demand absorbing a rising volume of profit taking.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: C. L. Sulzberger's article in The Times (Sept. 28) is yet another proof of the fantastic misconception in certain American circles about the true state of affairs in Iran.
The formal establishment of a citizens' committee to win public support for the $500,000,000 school bond issue, was announced yesterday.
Here is a letter written to one of the United Hospital Fund's member hospitals: " Last Monday we brought our baby daughter home after an eleven - weeks stay.

Mayor Wagner has asked J. Anthony Panuch, his special adviser on housing problems, for an early report on establishing a central relocation bureau. It would find homes for persons displaced because of public improvement projects.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 -- A year ago Pennsylvania was in a good position to whip the Princeton Tiger early in the first quarter. Dan Sachs, Princeton's star tailback, was injured about that time and Penn hopes were running high.
A new literary award to encourage the writing of novellas, or short novels, on a contemporary theme adaptable for motion pictures has been announced.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- The body of Little Augie Pisano, former gangland associate of Al Capone, was placed in a crypt at noon today following a brief committal service in the mausoleum at nonsectarian Frencliff Cemetery.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of the executive order signed this morning by President Eisenhower in which the Taft-Hartley Act was invoked in an attempt to end the dock strike:

Mrs. Michael P. Grace, chairman, has announced plans for a Grand Opera Ball for the benefit of Boys Towns of Italy, Inc. The fete, which will take place at the Sheraton-East on Nov. 10, is being sponsored by a distinguished group of Americans and Italians.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Oct. 6 -- A team of American scientists arrived today on the island of Zanzibar in the Indian Ocean, off the northern coast of Tanganyika, to study the possibilities of setting up a satellite-tracking station there.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Sheep raisers have voted overwhelmingly to continue a program of wool and lamb promotion through deductions from Government subsidy payments, the Department of Agriculture announced today. The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, soon will announce a formal agreement to continue the program through 1961.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Kenneth H. Tuggle, Chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, today disputed accusations that his agency had been permitting "wholesale" discontinuances of passenger train service.

The military housing program, a key to service morale, was one of the victims of the belated Congressional zeal for economy at the last session.
It was no day for football.

George Frankenthaler of New York and John F. Sembower of Chicago, named by President Eisenhower yesterday as members of the fact-finding board in the dock strike, are lawyers who have specialized in labor arbitration.

Nineteen years is a long time for a playwright to wait for his script to reach the stage. But Francis Gallagher, author of the new off-Broadway hit "Vincent," which opened last Wednesday at the Cricket Theatre, has had the endurance.

The Dancers, an invitation group, began its twelfth season last evening with a dance in the St. Regis Roof. Under the direction of Mrs. Conrad Thibault, the group will hold a dance there the first Tuesday of each month during the season.

The latest Soviet rocket into space continued its distant journey yesterday, its final path and fate still somewhat uncertain. But while the world waits to learn the final outcome of this project, it is useful to recall that the importance of scientific research is not always proportional to the size or length of the headlines that research evokes.
The market for fixed-interest securities improved yesterday. Despite selling by savings banks, prices were marked up 1/3 to 1/2 point in the over-the counter market for corporate debt securities.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 7 -- The Soviet Union's new satellite has passed the moon and presumably has begun to study at least a part of its hidden face.
BOSTON, Oct 6 (AP) -- A bachelor who few suspected was wealthy left $17,000,000 to charity.

The Circuit Court of Appeals has reversed a ruling that restored 125 tugboat oilers to their jobs last June. At the same time, it continued an injunction preventing unions that represent tugboat workers from striking to protest the dismissals.

A VISIT to the state-owned Three Rivers Game Management Area near Baldwinsville, N. Y., last week-end prompted the thought that Syracuse hunters were luckier than most others in large cities. For them there was no problem of where to hunt. Fourteen miles from the city were 2,512 acres of woodlands, fields and ponds.
John D. Rockefeller 3d said last night that society must support the arts as it did the "accepted responsibilities" for health, welfare and education.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today a 1960 national peanut acreage allotment of 1,610,000 acres, the minimum allowed under law.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Even the Treasury building itself was swamped today -- relatively speaking -- by Americans eager to lend their money to the Government at 5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Business sales and inventories fell in August, partly because of the steel strike.

This is a significant week in the Big Eleven, the unincorporated but de facto conference of Eastern independents rated as major football powers by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Two of Saturday's games pair the four teams voted most likely to succeed in this formidable regional group.
Major differences appeared yesterday between an unofficial Russian diagram of the Soviet moon vehicle's flight path and calculations made by scientists in this country.
ALTHOUGH "The Great God Brown" was originally produced in 1926, it remains as avant-garde as any play of the century. Beckett and Ionesco have gone no further afield.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 6 -- The big, wide, wonderful world of night harness racing is taking on a slightly tarnished look. Unless something is done to prevent doping incidents, betting tip-offs and other questionable practices uncovered recently at various tracks, the sport may recede to the pre-starting-gate era.
" Important weaknesses in the management controls over ocean transportation activities" has been ascribed to the Military Sea Transportation Service by the General Accounting Office.

ALBANY, Oct. 6 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of 999 persons who passed the examination for admission to the Bar given last July 8 and 9. A total of 1,938 took the test.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Following are the texts of the unofficial translation of a speech in the General Assembly today by Vasily V. Kuznetsov of the Soviet Union and of a reply by Henry Cabot Lodge of the United States:
PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Twenty-eight prizes and scholarships were awarded tonight for works on display in the first International Biennial Art Show of Paris for artists younger than 35 years old.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 -- A "summit" conference here tonight between top industry and union executives led to another breakdown in efforts to end the twelve-week-old steel strike. The new stalemate appeared to doom President Eisenhower's hope of avoiding use of an eighty-day injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act to reopen the struck mills.

GUY FARMER, the lawyer who heads the board of inquiry appointed by. President Eisenhower in the dock strike, has one thing in common with Premier Khrushchev of the Soviet Union. Both can say, "I was a miner once myself."

LONDON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Friedrich Grunwald, key figure in the H. Jasper Co. real estate deals tangle that rocked the London Stock Market recently arrived by plane from Israel today. "I have come back to clear my name," he said.

DETROIT, Oct. 6 -- More than 500 staff members and officers of the United Automobile Workers have paid a total of $106,000 to the Internal Revenue Service in back income tax adjustments, it was reported today.
Measures to stimulate American business interest in economic expansion of Asian nations were recommended yesterday at the twelfth annual Far East Conference.

Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey called on the City Council yesterday to "put responsibility back in the home" by notifying parents of their youngsters' membership in gangs and fining them in eases of juvenile vandalism.
The Board of Elections disclosed yesterday that it had stricken 85,152 names from the registration rolls in the last year.
Blood will be given to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today at the Twentieth-Century Fox Film Corporation, 444 West Fifty-sixth Street.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 6 (UPI) -- Sid W. Richardson, Texas oil producer, left the bulk of his vast wealth to a nonprofit religious and educational foundation that bears his name, his will disclosed today.

Guests at a dinner sponsored by the Society for the Rehabilitation of the Facially Disfigured in the Basildon Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on Oct. 15 will hear discussions of the advancement in reconstructive plastic surgery.
TULSA, Okla., Oct. 6 (UPI) -- The Arkansas River at Tulsa continued to drop slowly today, but tired volunteers still fought the river at its soggy and weakening west bank.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 to 13 points (10 to 65 cents a bale) higher yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 -- Crashing a picket line usually does not come under the heading of a dress buyer's or fashion reporter's duty. But anyone who wanted to see one of the "newest and hottest" California collections last night had to do just that.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Oct. 6 -- Legislative leaders were seeking tonight to convene an extraordinary session of the State Senate and Assembly. The meeting would be held to act on a measure upon which the fate of the commuter railroad-relief referendum appears to hang.
The Fire Department yesterday began a stepped-up program of instruction in fire prevention and fire-fighting techniques in hospitals throughout the city.

The six-story apartment house at 13-15 Sheridan Square, has been sold by Angelina Perrotty, Alfred J. Maruccia and Salvatore J. Ragone to Sheridan Properties, Inc. The building has forty-five apartments. Viscardi Viscardi represented the sellers and Jack Newton Lerner was counsel for the buyer.
GENEVA, Oct. 6 -- President Eisenhower's "warm greetings" were transmitted today to the executive program committee of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
BOSTON, Oct. 6 -- The name Unitarian Universalist Association was proposed today by a joint merger commission of the two denominations.

The United States Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on an appeal by the Government from a lower court decision upholding a 1955 stock repurchase agreement between the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and a New York-Chicago investment banking group.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- The president of the United States Chamber of Commerce indicated here today that the United States should not yet "buy" any over-all changes in the Soviet Union's attitude.

American Export Lines announced here yesterday the extension of its regular cargo services between North Atlantic ports in the United States and the Mediterranean to two additional ports in North Carolina.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Air Force said today that 40 per cent of the fuel production capacity for its Minuteman missile program had been wiped out in last night's explosion at the Hercules Powder Company plant in Kenvil, N. J.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service has issued a ruling to clarify provisions of a-1951 law relating to the tax treatment of patronage dividends paid to members of cooperatives.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- A United Air Lines executive from the company's national headquarters here inspected and flew in a new French twin-jet passenger airliner at this city's Mid way and O'Hare Airports yesterday and today.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 -- The Dodgers missed their first grab at the brass ring of the world series today. But their loyal, red-blooded fans did not take it unduly amiss.

Confidence that Western Europe's two free-trade groups will work out a cooperative agreement by early 1960 was expressed yesterday by Gunnar Lange, Swedish Minister of Commerce.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Allow me to congratulate you most heartily for your editorial of Sept. 28 on the Puerto Ricans and the problems of juvenile delinquency in New York. Record sales for September were reported yesterday by Sears, Roebuck Co., big mail order and retail concern.

Commodity futures continued to move in narrow ranges on light volume yesterday in the New York markets, awaiting further news on the dock strike. If the dock strike should continue, a tight supply could develop in many imported items.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- R. A. Butler, Home Secretary, canceled today the date set for the execution of Guenther Fritz Podola and ordered the case referred to the Court of Criminal Appeal.

ELIZABETH CITY, N. C., Oct. 6 (UPI) -- A 50-foot yacht bound from New York to Miami caught fire and sank today in the Alligator River near here. The two persons on board wore saved.

ORADELL, N. J., Oct. 6 -- Tax Assessor Henry L. Fenner has threatened to withhold the filing of a tax list unless he gets a $900 increase in the $2,700 annual pay for his part-time job. He is also in the real estate and insurance business.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 -- With one convulsive shudder the White Sox freed themselves from the snake pit today. They climbed clear of the horrors of Walter O'Malley's Chinese torture chamber as a result of one unprepossessing run in the fourth inning. But they were tormented fiendishly in the eighth before completing their escape to the sanity of Chicago.

The money market is guessing that small investors may take $750,000,000 to $1,000,000,000 of the Treasury's $2,000,000,000 offering of new 5 per cent notes.
