Queen Frederika's Fund will benefit from an invitation preview of "Greek Costumes and Embroideries" at French Co.'s Galleries, Madison Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, on the evening of Oct. 20 and from the exhibition, which will run from Oct. 21 through Nov. 7.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- Delegates of Western nations welcomed today the proposal of the Soviet Union for a United Nations conference to exchange information on the exploration of outer space.

A stock argument of Communists (including Khrushchev) is that capitalistic nations cannot disarm without mass unemployment and catastrophic depression, and hence such nations are bound to be "warmongering," militaristic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's largest, threw his support today behind a proposed merger of the Erie, and the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroads.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 7 -Premier Abdul Karim Kassim was wounded in the shoulder early this evening when "a vicious hand" fired several shots at his car, the Baghdad radio announced tonight.
The legalization of the Peronist party in Argentina was recommended here yesterday -- by Gen. Pedro E. Aramburu, a bitter political enemy of Juan D. Peron, the former dictator.

Supreme Court Justice Sidney A. Fine yesterday upheld the right of the city to amend a statute granting tax abatements to landlords who bought old properties and rehabilitated them. The rehabilitation was done with the understanding that the landlords would receive the tax benefits.

Bailey W. Diffie's letter in the Sept. 28 Times suggesting that we give New York Puerto Ricans the special economic status they get in Puerto Rico or something akin to it is impractical, to say the least.

A Year-round Matter Love and spring have become so companionate in the minds of our romantic nation that sometimes we appear to have forgotten that true love is a year-round matter. True lovers, at least, never lose sight of the fact.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 7 (UPI) -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today he had asked the United States Supreme Court to uphold his right to close integrated-threatened schools as inherent to a state's chief executive.
Charles Lott Schenck, a retired vice president of the National City Bank of New York, now the First National City Bank of New York, died yesterday at his home, 1158 Fifth Avenue. He was 90 years old.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) off to 5 points (25 cents a bale) up yesterday. Volume was light.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- A thirty-foot statue of the Virgin Mary was placed atop a 150-foot cliff here today beside the new Cross Westchester Expressway.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 7 -- Israel is maintaining her boycott of the Egyptian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission. The boycott has been in effect since the Sinai campaign in 1956.

HONG KONG, Oct. 7 -- Premier Chou En-lai acclaimed today the first decade of Communist rule in China as a period of "heaven-shaking changes" during which China's millions "have turned from slaves in a hell on earth into fearless masters of their own destiny."

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The French Government prepared today to seek formal Parliamentary backing for its Algerian policy. It seeks thus to strengthen its hand in dealing with French extremists, the Algerian rebels and United Nations debate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- John A. McCone, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, will leave tomorrow for a ten-day tour of Soviet atomic energy installations in the first step toward closer United States-Soviet cooperation in the peaceful development of nuclear energy.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 7 -- A delegation of striking steel workers from the Los Angeles area arrived today to make a personal appeal to President Eisenhower against "Government strikebreaking" through use of the Taft-Hartley Act process.

WESTFIELD, N. J., Oct. 7 -The New Jersey and WestchesterFairfield women's golf teams played a tie today for the second time in the thirty-four-year history of their cup matches at the Echo Lake Country Club.
In the Sept. 30 and Oct. 1 issues of The New York Times Osgood Caruthers describes his impressions of his trip to Tallinn, the capital of Estonia.
NEW SHREWSBURY, N. J., Oct. 7 -- The pilot of an Army light plane was killed and his passenger was critically injured today when the single-engine plane crashed near here.
A proposed 1960 capital budget of $631,920,569 was made public by the City Planning Commission yesterday. The commission also outlined a $1,934,616,210 capital program for the years 1961 to 1965.

Pat Hingle will return to Broadway as the star of "The Deadly Game," due next February. It will mark his first stage appearance here since he created the name role in "J. B.," Archibald MacLeish's Biblical allegory based on the story of Job.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- Willem van Rie, 30-year-old radio operator on the Dutch passenger-freighter Utrecht, pleaded not guilty to a murder charge today in the death of Mrs. Lynn Kauffman, 23, a passenger. He was granted a stay of trial for three weeks.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Warner Wilcox, representing Long Island Sound, won today's fourth race for the world championship of International One-Design class yachts. But the race for the title narrowed down to two men -- Bermuda's Bert Darrell and Herman Whiton of Oyster Bay, L. I.
TRENTON, Oct. 7 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner made a second attempt today to rally the powerful Democratic organization of Hudson County behind the commuter railroad relief referendum.
A Waterfront Commission regulation originally designed to keep Communists and criminals off the waterfront threatened yesterday to immobilize passenger -ship operations in this port.
The Federal Aviation Agency plans soon to establish the equivalent of a small helicopter airline here to test helicopter instrument flying.
The controversial Soundview Title I project in the Bronx, presumed dead during the summer, was pronounced alive by Mayor Wagner yesterday. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The United States Court of Claims decided today that a small group of Alaskan Indians was entitled to payment for more than 20,000,000 acres of land taken from its ancestors by the white man.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -Soybeans, by far the most active commodity on the Board of Trade in recent days, advanced nearly 2 cents a bushel today as increased demand came into the futures market late in the session.

Most dogs like to ride in automobiles and many a family vacation isn't complete unless Towser goes along. Finding places to stay overnight where a dog will be a welcome guest is no longer a problem. Although it hasn't made the bestseller list, there is a booklet -"Touring with Towser" -- which is distributed as a public service to thousands of dog owners every year by the Gaines Dog Research Center, 250 Park Avenue.

EDGEWATER, N. J., Oct. 7 -- The murky bottom of the Hudson River here is getting what amounts to a twenty-fourhour-a-day vacuum cleaning that is expected to have far-reaching effects not only on this old port but also on the Hackensack Meadow, three miles away.

SHEBOYGAN, Wis., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Nick Vrckovic, former member of the United Auto Workers Union, was sentenced today to six months in the Sheboygan County Jail and fined $250 and costs for beating two non-striking Kohler Company workers five years ago.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif. Oct. 7 -- President Eisenhower tonight instructed Attorney General William P. Rogers to seek a Federal court order to end temporarily the week-old pier strike that has tied up shipping in ports along the Atlantic and Gulf Coast.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 7 (AP) -- The National Guard Association of the United States demanded today that steps be taken to re-evaluate the qualifications and continued usefulness of Air Force Gen. Curtis E. LeMay.

" We're going against a real good ball club Sunday, but I feel a lot better about our situation." That was Coach Jim Lee Howell's observation yesterday after watching his New York Football Giants step through a two-hour workout at Yankee Stadium.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- A sullen, gray sky hung over the Loop today. This bustling metropolis went about its business in somber fashion. The party was over. Gone was the dazzling sunshine, the warmth, the verve and the electric sparkle that was Los Angeles. The world series has reverted to normal again.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 7 -- Cheering and stamping by the audience at last night's program in the Stockholm Concert Hall marked another triumph for Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic on their tour of Europe.

President Eisenhower has done well to waste no time in his invocation of the Taft-Hartley Law procedures in the dock strike. None of the reasons for having gone slow in the steel strike apply to the longshore situation.

Secretary of State Herter has now made it plain beyond the possibility of further doubt that the Western powers are determined to stay in West Berlin until Germany is reunited. Taken in the context of the Western position as a whole, this means that the Western powers will continue to press for German reunification in freedom as the key to a European peace settlement, which in turn is the key to disarmament.

Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union strengthened his lead in the challengers' chess tournament at Zagreb yesterday. He defeated Fridrik Olafsson of Iceland in an eighteenth-round match, according to a report received from Yugoslavia.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 7 -- A female rhinoceros has won a landslide victory in an election in Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city. And she doesn't even live there.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 8 -- Premier Khrushchev has said that he looks forward to a continued exchange of views with Western leaders at a summit meeting, "which evidently will be held this autumn or winter."

Charles Haring and Walter E. Bronston Sr. have been elected directors of Northern Properties, Inc., of Hartsdale, a new Westchester land development company headed by John E. Marqusee. Mr. Haring is a Westchester home builder. Mr. Bronston is president of Industrial Enterprises, Inc., of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The National Broadcasting Company disclosed tonight that the producer of a nationally televised quiz show had been discharged because he refused to swear that contestants had not been given advance answers to questions.
The trial of Frankie Carbo for undercover managing and match-making of professional fighters was adjourned yesterday in General Sessions Court to Oct. 26.
A number of churches in the city held special services yesterday for the National Day of Prayer.

Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury, appeared before the House Ways and Means Committee last June 10 to discuss the problem of public debt management in general and in particular the legal interest rate ceiling in effect at that time on both Treasury savings bonds and marketable securities with a life of five years or longer.

Stocks dusted with the glamour of the space age swept ahead in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange but the list as a whole stumbled and made no progress. The market averages registered a small loss on the day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Those professional carpenters of foreign policy planks in Democratic platforms, Philip B. Perlman and Thomas K. Finletter, must be "viewing with alarm" this prospective task at Los Angeles next July -- unless, like the Chevalier Bayard, they were born without fear.
Frederick H. Mueller, Secretary of Commerce, urged Asian nations yesterday not to "by-pass" private enterprise in their zeal for economic progress through governmental efforts.

UNITED NATION'S, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- Dr. Victor A. Belaunde, president of the General Assembly called on all governments today to make the World Refugee Year a success by helping to solve the dilemma of the world's homeless refugees.
Although the Russians proposed on Tuesday a United Nations forum for the exchange of space exploration results, they are also reported willing to rejoin a nongovernmental approach to the problem.
A realignment of top executives of the General Foods Corporation was announced yesterday.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Oct. 7 -- With a four-under-par 66, Jim Turnesa of Elmsford, N. Y., moved into the lead for the Metropolitan Professional Golf Association championship today.
MOSCOW, Oct. 7 -- The new Soviet satellite is still flying away from the earth and will begin its return trip Saturday.

THERE is a definite harmony between the flavors of food and the regions where food is grown. Many beer producers contend that the quality of their brew depends on the water they use; the makers of Cognac point with valid pride to a chalkiness in the soil for the superiority of that drink's flavor.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 -- Now that most of the formal openings are over, store buyers who are here to view California's spring fashion collections are busy placing orders. For the most part the recipients of these orders are the established "name" houses and the bright new concerns.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 7 -Eleven passengers on a two-car New Canaan Branch Line commuter train of the New Haven Railroad were injured, none seriously, today in a collision with an empty two-car train here.
SANDS POINT, L. I., Oct. 7 -Two barge captains were saved in a violent squall in Long Island Sound last night and a third lost his life when he apparently refused to leave a mongrel dog on his barge.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 7 -- Plans were completed today for a new White Plains public library that will have a minimum number of windows to provide maximum wall space for books.

The high cost of borrowing is catching up with business. In its regular quarterly report on interest rates, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York notes that the big banks here charged an average of 5.09 per cent on short-term business loans during the first half of September.

BAGHDAD, Oct. 7 (UPI) -- A medical bulletin issued several hours after the shooting said Premier Kassim had suffered only a flesh wound and a fractured shoulder. It declared he had been struck by "three bullets in non-vital parts of his body."

Directors of General Tire and Rubber Company yesterday increased the quarterly common dividend to 25 cents from 17 1/2 cents and also declared a 2 per cent stock dividend. Both dividends are payable on Nov. 20.

TWO stimulating avocations were open to all in the crucial years when Franklin Delano Roosevelt was President. He was a tremendous hero to those who admired him, a tremendous villain to those who did not. The election returns rather decisively indicated which side was dominant in his America.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- The most discreet and modest political banner of the British election campaign is a small strip of gummed paper proclaiming "Another Liberal."
Investors waited for steel-strike action yesterday and stock prices moved down slightly under a combination of uncertainties.

Ryszard Bakst a Polish pianist, gave an all-Chopin program last night in Town Hall. He is in this country as part of the first artist exchange with Poland. Anton Kuerti, the American pianist of Polish descent, will be his counterpart in Poland.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) -- The United States and Mexico have completed negotiations for an agreement permitting Mexican nationals to perform agricultural work in this country.

AMONG the stalwarts faithful to the neo-plastic tradition -- the austere right-angle styled founded by Mondrian -- Ilya Bolotowsky is one of the most adventurous. That is, in his show at the Grace Borgenicht Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, near Seventy-eighth Street, Mr. Bolotowsky ranges far afield, using a broad scale of color when his fancy dictates, and unorthodox composition as well.

VIENTIANE, Laos. Oct. 8 -- A United Nations fact-finding team returned from a one-day visit to the royal capital of Luang Prabang today after questioning villagers and talking with Army leaders in that area.

MONTREAL, Oct. 8 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens got off to a flying start in defense of their National Hockey League championship tonight. Two goals by Andre Pronovost, a second-stringer, helped them down the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 1, in the season opener for both teams.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- A solid, extremely mobile line that Coach Lefty James appraises as his best in five years carries Cornell's hopes of making a strong challenge for the Ivy League football championship this season.
A young man twice pushed a young Bronx mother against a glowing apartment-house furnace yesterday morning while trying to rape her at pistol point.
HEARTY breakfasts of bacon and eggs will not be as expensive this week-end. Both foods show good price declines, with sliced bacon shedding 6 cents a pound and large eggs down 6 cents a dozen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Clarence G. Morse, Maritime Administrator, endorsed today a proposed international convention limiting the damage liability from nuclear accidents aboard atomic-powered merchant ships.

The city began yesterday to floodlight some playgrounds and small parks where teen-age hoodlums loiter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Eisenhower flew back today from his desert vacation, his cold much improved. The President was smiling and tanned as he stepped from his jet transport at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., at 3:20 P. M.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 8 -- Cacareco, Brazil's political rhinoceros, continued to pile up a heavy vote today as the tally in Sao Paulo's municipal elections neared completion.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Most grain futures finished with gains in fractions on the Board of Trade today despite a flurry of profit taking late in the session.
Salt Lake City said yesterday that it would seek competitive bids next Wednesday for $5,500,000 school district bonds, maturing from Feb. 1, 1961, to 1971. The bonds will be dated Nov. 1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Eisenhower will be on hand at the Washington National Airport tomorrow to welcome President Adolfo Lopez Mateos of Mexico on his arrival for a four-day state visit.

Recent restrictions by Cuba on a wide range of imports were described yesterday as a phase of the austerity program aimed at improving the nation's economy.

John Gronon has joined ALCO Products, Inc., Schenectady, as chief project engineer in the nuclear power engineering department.

Jean Pierre Aumont has been signed to star in "The Other One." This was verified yesterday by Leonard Sillman, producer of the Lucienne Hill version of Colette's novel, "La Seconde."

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- So acute was the ticket situation for the Windy City end of the world series that some enterprising, albeit larceny-minded, fellows decided to print their own. A group headed by Roy M. Cohn, a member of the New York law firm of Saxe, Bacon O'Shea, has acquired control of the Lionel Corporation, manufacturer of model trains and electronics and electro-mechanical devices.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct, 8 -- Walter P. Reuther said today that there was a need for a political realignment in the nation.
LONDON, Friday, Oct. 9 -- Prime Minister Harold MacMillan's Conservative party won a smashing victory in yesterday's general election, one that may alter the pattern of British politics.

The 1960 Edsel is a far cry from the first cars of that name introduced by the Ford Motor Company three years ago. Cut back to one series this year and radically changed in styling, the Edsel is competitive ein price with the top models of Ford, Chevrolet and Plymouth.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Oct. 8 -- A department store was opened here this morning by Sears, Roebuck Co., It is the chain's first new store in the metropolitan area since World War II.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The sun beamed down cheerfully at the start of the game. By the time it was over even Chicago's sky had donned mourning of dark black. In the last half of the ninth the tears, a sprinkle of rain, came. The beloved White Sox had lost the world series.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Government put a $2,700,000,000 limit today on Federal payments to states for highway construction in the current fiscal year.

American composers and librettists have had a particularly rocky time of it, for though the lyric theatre has won increasing popularity across the land it has not had the resources to venture widely on native works. But if American opera is to achieve maturity it must produce its own repertory.

Registration for this year's election began yesterday in New York city. A total of 37,484 new names were added to the voting lists, bringing the total to 2,623,274.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Nearly everyone in the dressing room of the all-conquering Los Angeles Dodgers had a theory as to why they had become the champions of all the baseball world late today.

Robert H. Reno's letter published Sept. 29 offered a reasoned plea for implementation of a world peace through law program. In addition to the items he mentioned there is one crucial area where the United States should legislate.
The corrugated*box Industry is operating at peak levels and the outlook for the industry i "quite optimistic," Clarence N. Smith, the new preident of the' Fibre Box Association, said yes-i terday.
ABERDEEN, Md., Oct. 8 -- The Army, which lost its Air Corps a decade ago, is nevertheless prepared to take to the air again with Army-piloted, rocket-armed helicopters.

Your report on Sept. 30 that Senator Kefauver assailed electrical equipment manufacturers for submitting identical bids to the Tennessee Valley Authority focuses upon a similar problem confronting individual consumers today.

Your statement of Oct. 3 that the one drawback of the newly approved International Development Association is its governmental character struck me as somewhat inaccurate in both its historical and current significance.
The ponderous beefeaters of football known as the New York Giants will turn to dimpled knees and twirling skirts to please the customers this season.

The two five-story apartment buildings at 850 and 854 Bronx Park South in the Bronx have been sold by John Cultrini to a client of Jacob Serota, lawyer. The Wishnow Horowitz Real Estate Company was the broker in the transaction.

Whitney North Seymour, President-elect of the American Bar Association, said yesterday that the spirit of brotherhood -- an essential tenet of all great religions -- helped to assure a "courageous and independent bar, nourishing and defending an independent and incorruptible judiciary."
ACCORDING to Michael Flanders, whose voice is deeper than Donald Swann's, which is more like a treble, composers are all too willing to sing their own songs at the drop of a hat.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad accumulated more legal woes yesterday.
ALBANY, Oct. 8 -- Three items will be added to the state's compulsory motor vehicle inspection beginning next Feb. 1. They are tires, windshield wipers and glass.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- The 107 musicians of the Philadelphia Orchestra went into belated rehearsal today following the settlement last night of a ten-day strike.

BROILING and frying chickens, now so tender, meaty and inexpensive, have all but crowded their elders in the poultry family out of the picture. Yet it is the fowl, stewing chicken or the newer bro-hen that is best for richer-flavored fricasees and soups.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Twenty-nine world swimming records, twelve of them by Americans, have been approved by the International Swimming Federation.

The New Dramatists Committee will benefit from a theatre party to a preview performance o "The Warm Peninsula" next Friday and an after-theatre supper party in the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza. The Joseph Masteroff play starring Julie Harris, June Havoc and Farley Granger is scheduled to open at the Helen Hayes Theatre on Oct. 20.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- Roger C. Damon, a senior vice president, was named president and chairman of the executive committee of the First National Bank of Boston today. He joined the bank on his graduation from Yale University in 1929.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- More than $68,000,000 was pledged today for two United Nations programs to aid under-developed areas. About half the amount was in the United States pledge.
Willie Shoemaker, the 104-pound Texan, added the Aqueduct riding lead to his national leadership yesterday with five winners in six chances.

SAN MARINO, Oct. 8 -- This mountain-top republic passed heavy prison sentences today on its former Communist andt Left-wing Socialist rulers, who were found guilty of illegally dissolving the Grand and General Council (Parliament). The sentences are subject to appeal.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The United States Eighth circuit court of appeals reminded Dollarway, Ark., school officials today that the way was still open for Negro pupils to file additional complaints "in case of any unconstitutional application" of the Arkansas pupil placement laws.
Supreme Court Justice Sidney A. Fine has denied a motion by the city to dismiss a suit by a group of landlords. They had complained that an amendment to the city's 1956 tax abatement law was invalid.

Sales of the Scott Paper Company in the quarter ended Sept. 30 rose to a record high, according to a report by Thomas B. McCabe, president. Earnings also showed a substantial gain over the 1958 level.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- A record volume of business was done on the stock exchange here today as investors anticipated a Conservative victory in today's general election.
City Council President Abe Stark and the city's five Borough Presidents joined yesterday in a statement supporting the school bond proposal.

The thirtieth anniversary meeting of the Regional Plan Association witnessed what was perhaps the significant beginning of constructive reaction to the somewhat pessimistic findings of the three-year New York Metropolitan Region Study, proposed by the association, directed by Dr. Raymond Vernon of Harvard and financed by Rockefeller Brothers and Ford funds.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 8 -- The army and the police appeared to be in full control of Baghdad today following the failure of an attempt to assassinate Premier Abdul Karim Kassim last night.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 8 -- President Arturo Frondizi was reported today to have decided to keep Peronists off the ballot again in the next Congressional election.
The Consolidated Edison Company asked the Public Service Commission yesterday to rescind its order suspending a general 1 per cent increase in rates for New York City customers.

A drop of $45,000,000 in savings deposits at the larger New York City banks provided the first glimpse yesterday of the effect on commercial bank thrift accounts of the Treasury's new 5 per cent note offering.

ROME, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Cries of "Viva Fascism" set off at wave of fist fights early today during Rome's first showing of Roberto Rossellini's new film, a story of anti-fascist partisans. The picture, "Il Generale Della Rovere," shared the first prize at the Venice Film Festival a month ago. It marked Signor Rossellini's comback after a series of failures.
BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Oct. 8 -- The athletic program at Blair Academy is thriving this season.
The National Grass Roots Opera Company made one of its rare New York appearances last night in "Die Fledermaus" at the Hunter College Auditorium.
The eight-day strike by 70,000 longshoremen on the East and Gulf Coasts was halted at 7:05 o'clock last night by an order of a Federal court here.
C. J. LaRoche Co., Inc., has hired two executives for marketing posts.
CEDARHURST, L. I., Oct. 8 -- Doug Ford, a member of the 1959 United States Ryder Cup team, won the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today for the third year in a row.
TUNBRIDGE WELLS, England, Oct. 8 -- Just before 7 A. M. today, in the coach house of the old Dunorlen estate here, Robert Oldroyd showed an open ballot box to two poll clerks to prove it was empty.

OTTAWA, Oct. 8 (Canadian Press) -- The Bank of Canada interest rate declined for the third week in a row today by one-quarter of 1 percentage point to 5.50 per cent with the sale of $100,000,000 in ninety-one-day Treasury bills.
A teen-age couple who came here from upstate to get married ended up in the hands of the law yesterday for stealing an automobile.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Specific Government authority is lacking to impose settlements of the strikes which inflict the heaviest damage on the public welfare. The weakness is emphasized by the limited and inconclusive processes of Section 206 of the Taft-Hartley Act.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Oct. 7 -- The political leader of Tanganyika's 9,000,000 Africans is confident that Tanganyika will have self-government next year.
LONDON, Friday, Oct. 9 -- Transport House, the Labor party headquarters, was emotionally shaken early this morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Frank Chapot of the United States Equestrian Team, riding Trail Guide, captured the Gen. W. H. Abendroth Trophy for the first international jumping event of the six-day Washington international horse show at the National Guard Armory tonight.
The Ford Motor Company's entire first-quarter production of 97,000 Falcons has been committed, James O. Wright, vice president of Ford announced yesterday.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 8 -- Suffolk County Judge Lloyd P. Dodge was indicted today on charges of conspiracy, taking an unlawful fee and subornation of perjury to rezone Brookhaven Township properties for special uses.

Plans to modernize the fivestory store and apartment building at 133 Lexington Avenue to provide a group of small suites have been announced by Harry Fechter, Nat Schneider and Martin Spector, real estate operators and investors.
James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, met secretly here yesterday with the two top negotiators for the striking United Steelworkers of America.

Meetings are being held at Carleton House to plan for the evening performance of the new musical, "Take Me Along," at the Shubert Theatre on Nov. 18, which will benefit the Institute of World Affairs, Inc., 527 Madison Avenue.
Stockholders of the American Machine and Foundry Company approved a two-for-one split of the common stock yesterday.
CONCORD, N. H., Oct., 8 (AP) -- William G. Saltonstall, educator and Republican, became general chairman today of New Hampshire's draft-Rockefeller-for-President forces.

Civilian Conservation Corps camps as a way of reducing the criminality of New York City youth were warmly supported by Mayor Wagner and Governor Rockefeller. In Albany the Board of Regents requested the Commissioner of Education to render "the fullest assistance to the plan for establishing work camps for delinquent youths."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Dr. Djalal Abdoh of Iran will leave here Saturday for the British Northern Cameroons, where he will supervise a plebiscite in which the 129,000 male voters of that trust territory will decide its future.
ROME, Oct. 8 -- The Vatican is raising the pay of its 3,000 employes by the equivalent of $2,400,000 a year.

A SURE sign of autumn is the rise in demand for house paint. "From now until Thanksgiving is our biggest season," Evan Janovic says. Mr. Janovic is a partner of Emil Janovic Son, a paint shop at 1299 First Avenue, between Sixty-ninth and Seventieth Streets. The store has been a fixture in this block since 1888.

The Savings Banks Associa-' tion of the State of New YorkI yesterday canine out against anyl relaxation of the 2-year-old freeze on bank holding companies unless savings banks and savings and loan associations were accorded wider branch privileges.

A new pleasure boat creation that just about flies on detachable aluminum "wings" is the latest development produced jointly by Grumman Aircraft and Reynolds Metals. They use hydrofoils. The hydrofoil principle is not in itself new, but bringing it down to the size of small outboard-powered pleasure craft is an accomplishment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Eisenhower will be asked soon to referee another major conflict in the nation's space program. At issue are the fate of the Saturn, a gigantic rocket engine, and of the Army Ballistic Missile Agency at Redstone Arsenal, Huntsville, Ala., with its team of space and rocket scientists headed by Dr. Wernher von Braun.
Columbia's new muddle-huddle spread and shift will be put to an interesting test against Yale in their Ivy. League football game in the Bowl at New Haven tomorrow.
The New York State Harness Racing Commission yesterday cleared a Detroit stable of any "wrongdoing" in a race at Roosevelt Raceway last week.

ORANGE, Conn., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Massachusetts women golfers easily retained their tri-state team golf championship today at Race Brook Country Club. The Bay State squad scored 45 points to 27 for Connecticut and 9 for Rhode Island.

Governor Rockefeller urged the non-Communist nations last night to insist that the Soviet Union meet certain conditions before they agreed to any expansion of East-West trade. The purpose of the conditions would be to prevent Russia and her Communist satellites from using East-West trade to disrupt and undermine the economies of the free nations for political ends.
Pan American World Airways will connect New York and Los Angeles with jet service starting tomorrow -- by way of Europe, the Middle East and Asia.

THE new "Cosi fan tutte" is the happiest production ever put on by the New York City Opera Company. If the town offers a better musical buy than this Mozart revival, which opened at the City Center last night, this deponent knoweth not where it may be found.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Warner Willcox led for the entire eight miles today as he gained his second victory in the International One-Design yacht championship.

A report on marriage conflicts, problems, failures and possible solutions will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Nov. 9 from 11 A. M. to noon.
The market for fixed-interest securities marched ahead strongly in all sectors yesterday, bolstered by enthusiasm for the Treasury's new 5 per cent note.
Directors of the Minute Maid Corporation yesterday voted a quarterly common dividend of 25 cents, payable on Oct. 30.
CAIRO, Oct. 8 -- General Kassim received few words of sympathy or cheer out of Cairo today.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 8 -- The Bundestag [parliament] engaged in heated debate for four hours today and adjourned with no decision whether Bonn should try to open diplomatic relations with the Eastern European countries.

MANY recherche items that facilitate the running or decorating of a house have the homemaker in a dilemma. Although most of these accessories can be found in large department stores or small specialty shops here, they sometimes are hidden in obscure corners.

The State Banking Department will sponsor a bill in the next session of the Legislature to establish criteria for approval or disapproval of future bank margers, G. Russell Clark, State Superintendent of Banks, said yesterday.

For a New Yorker to find himself a mere visitor in the city that has been his home-lot for many years, with a fixed and familiar place of residence, is an oddly disconcerting experience. It is one of being homeless, where in all his goings and comings on business or pleasure there was always a place to start out from and to go back to that was his own -- be it ever so homely.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Dan Enright, an originator of television quiz shows, told House investigators today that the fixing of quiz shows had been "a practice for many, many years."

In an election victory exceeding all forecasts, the Conservative party of Prime Minister Macmillan has won a firm new mandate to rule Britain for a third five-year term with an approximately doubled majority in Parliament.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members idle in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, warehouses and Great Lakes ore carriers. The strike began July 15 after the old three-year contract had been extended for two weeks at the request of President Eisenhower.

Crewmen and terminal personnel of the Sixty-ninth Street Brooklyn Ferry, who threatened last month to go out on strike, will vote Thursday on a city-sponsored formula that may settle a contract dispute.

Despite the prolonged steel strike, the business outlook continues bright. That is the conclusion of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its latest monthly survey of economic conditions. The San Francisco Film Festival appears to be gaining in stature, despite the fact that Hollywood producers so far have failed to support it. At the annual Albert Lasker Awards luncheon of the American Public Health Association this week two special awards were announced. They were presented to Senator Lister Hill of Alabama and Representative John E. Fogarty of Rhode Island for "extraordinary public service."

Following is a list of the dead and injured in yesterday's bus-truck crash near New Brunswick, N. J. All but one of the girls killed and injured were residents of New Jersey.

Reports that cocoa-bean grindings for the third quarter in the United States and Great Britain were sharply below last year's level induced active selling of futures on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday.

State and county law enforcement officials in New Jersey were pressing an investigation today of the bus and truck collision that killed ten persons and injured twelve others early yesterday morning.

THE passing of Carnegie Hall from the New York musical scene, of which it has been a landmark since 1891, now appears to be only a matter of time. The hall is accepting no bookings beyond May 15, 1960, the date of the season's final Sunday afternoon concert by the New York Philharmonic.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The Conservative party, boasting its largest post-war parliamentary majority, has resumed the Government of Britain supremely confident that its smashing election victory on Thursday reflects not only national endorsement of its policies at home and abroad but popular rejection of such purely socialist aspects of the Labor party's program as nationalization.

The most stringent and austere defense budget since the end of the Korean war confronts the armed services in the next fiscal year, which begins July 1, 1960. Major cutbacks, limitations and socalled stretchouts are already being projected, even though the final budget figures are not likely to be approved by the President until December.
Walter I. Baumann estimated last week that in his forty years with the Holland-America Line he had traveled 100,000 miles.

The New York District Attorney's office moved yesterday to bring James D. Norris Jr. here to testify in the trial of Frankie Carbo, an underworld figure accused of illegal boxing activities.

IT is election year in an American state -- not any particular state, just one of the fifty, done in composite; an average sovereignty, perhaps west of the Big River. WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -Negotiations for the construction of an intermediate-range ballistic missile base in Turkey have been completed.

A week from this Tuesday the third Parliament in the reign of Queen Elizabeth II will assemble. COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo -- Nothing happens the way it should up here where the air is thin and all the certainties are precarious to say the least. Who would have thought that it would start snowing hard on Sept. 25 and keep at it for one solid week?

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 10 -- A strong University of Delaware team employed a powerful running attack to roll to a 26-8 victory over undermanned Lafayette College here today. The victory, third for the Blue Hens, boosted their hopes for a Middle Atlantic Conference championship.

HAVANA -- Cuba is pinning her hopes for a renewal of her former lucrative tourist trade on the convention of the American Society of Travel Agents which will meet in Havana from next Saturday through Oct. 25.

A COMPOST pile is very simple to build. Nature does most of the work. Composting has been going on for millions of years in every woods and field.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, -- Within four years of the first newsprint production in New Zealand, plans have been made to expand the industry by more than double. A second major British paper company will join the enterprise, which will be by far the largest single industrial complex in the country.

Dr. Jung certainly does not imply that fragmentation, decay and "meaninglessness" are positive values, as suggested by Mr. Rich, but "destruction is the result of inadequacy."

Trucking executives from all parts of the country are moving westward this week. Their destination is Los Angeles, where the twenty-sixth annual convention of the American Trucking Associations begins a week from today.

ACCOMPANIED by broadsides of high praise from English critics, A. E. Ellis' "The Rack" has now been published here. The accolades seem almost wholly deserved. Nixon.

The Lever Brothers Company has acquired the assets of the Dinner Ready Corporation, it was announced yesterday. Dinner Ready, with headquarters at 40 Gansevoort Street, produces and distributes frozen meat specialties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that compulsory union membership is unconstitutional if dues money is used for political purposes without the consent of union members.

Y., Oct. 12 Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr.'s Aileen, the International Class champion of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound was credited with the victory in the annual "layup" race off Larchmont YC today after two boats that finished ahead of it were disqualified following a protest.

Paul Keres of the Soviet Union won both of his adjourned games yesterday in the world chess challengers' tournament at Zagreb, according to a report received through Yugoslav news sources. His two victories kept him in second place behind Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union, who is firmly established in first place.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Hog prices turned higher on the Chicago livestock market today.

Under the leadership of defense issues, including missile makers, aircrafts and electronics, stocks rose briskly yesterday, adding about $1,700,000,000 to the market value of issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

TORONTO, Oct. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's trade deficit is being financed on a very unstable basis, Lester B. Pearson, leader of the opposition Liberal Party in the House of Commons, said today in an address to the International Business Systems Conference.
ALGIERS, Oct. 12 -- A group of French paratroopers on leave clashed with Moslem civilians here last night after six other paratroopers had been wounded in a terrorist attack.

NEWARK, Oct. 12 -Fordham Prep's Joe McGovern was the individual victor and his school took team honors in the second annual Essex Catholic Invitation Cross-Country Meet today at Branch Brook Park. Fordham Prep scored 81 points, seven less than the runner-up, Chaminade High School of Mineola, L. I.
Ingemar Johansson, heavyweigth boxing champion of the world, will play a former fighter who is sought by two hired gunmen in a television dramatization of Ernest Hemingway's "The Killers."
The police seized twenty youths in Brooklyn yesterday as they were assembling for a battle against a rival gang. About ten other gang members escaped.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Two riders were injured at Garden State Park today. Robert E. Corle and an apprentice, James Bennett, were sent to Cooper Hospital with possible fractured shoulders and collarbones.

WASHINGTON Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider two decisions on June 8 that upheld contempt convictions of Lloyd Barenblatt, former Vassar instructor, and Willard Uphaus, operator of a New Hampshire summer camp.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 -- Forty Hollywood film writers did not report for work this morning. The Writers Guild of America strike against fifty-six independent film companies began at 12:01 A. M. Saturday. This, however, was virtually the only sign that the strike was in progress.
The Citizens Union, a nonpartisan civic organization, listed its preferences yesterday for two General Sessions judgeships. Two vacancies are to be filled this year.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- The construction of the $40,000,000 Cross Westchester Expressway is eight months ahead of schedule, according to a report by state engineers.

A management contract yesterday was termed the first step by W. R. Grace Co. toward substantial stock ownership in Gonzalez Chemical Industries, Inc., of Puerto Rico.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- White citizens of South-West Africa enjoy "a monopoly of social advancement" as a result of the South African Government's policies there, a petitioner told the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee today.

The farm equipment industry thinks things will be good for it in 1960, but that it will take a lot of hard work and some luck to make it turn out that way. They were excellent -- this year. That, with variations, seems to be the prevailing view at the annual Farm Equipment Convention being held at Montreal.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 12 -- The state police said this afternoon that they intended to file a manslaughter charge tomorrow against the drive whose truck smashed into a bus Friday killing ten persons. He is Roscoe Poe, 54 years old, of Brooklyn.

MANILA, Oct. 12 -- The United States signed a memorandum of agreement with the Philippines today settling most of the problems involved in revision of the military bases treaty between the two countries.

Plans were announced yesterday by the Park Department for developing a 2.34-acre park in the new Lincoln Square development on the West Side. It will be known as Damrosch Park, in honor of the noted musical family.
The Columbus Day parade was the order of the day on Fifth Avenue yesterday, while one block east, on Madison Avenue, new advertising campaigns made the news.

The New York State A. F. L.C. I. O. protested yesterday what it called "damaging changes" in recent months in the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law.

Tempted of the Mooring Stable registered a convincing victory in the $57,200 Ladies Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old daughter of Half Crown remained at the head of the pack all through the mile and five-sixteenths event to score by more than two lengths over the Wheatley Stable's High Bid.
Innovations in body construction and engineering are featured in the 1960 Plymouth line. In styling, the cars are a throw-back to the highly successful sharp rising fin theme of three years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Chairman Doerfer of the Federal Communications Commission has told the Harris subcommittee of the House there is nothing specific in the act creating the F. C. C. that would enable the commission to proceed legally against the fixers of TV quiz shows and other financial beneficiaries who knowingly cooperated.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 12 -"The World of Carl Sandburg," an adaptation of Mr. Sandburg's poems for theatrical presentation, by Norman Corwin, had its premiere here tonight. Bette Davis and Gary Merrill are co-starred.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members idle in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, warehouses and Great Lakes ore carriers. The strike began July 15 after the old three-year contract had been extended for two weeks at the request of President Eisenhower.
IN many of the twenty novels that Alec Waugh has written, the leading characters in the book go out to eat together at least once.
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The Bank of England disclosed today that a working party had been set up to try to evolve a code of conduct in battles for control of a company.
CORDOBA, Argentina, Oct. 12 -- President Arturo Frondizi turned to his wife Elena today and said with a sweep of his hand: "Do you see now why I fight for industry?"

LONDON, Oct. 12 (UPI) -The official Soviet press agency Tass took issue today with a United States National Planning Association report that Russia could not overtake the United States living standard in the forseeable future.

THERE is no such thing as an indispensable man. Yet Bert Bell came closer to it than most in his role as commissioner of the National Football League. He was an extraordinary person and he did an extraordinary job. No commissioner in any sport was better equipped than he for the handling of his appointed task because he brought to it a matchless blend of intelligence, courage, background and personality.

A totting up of the subscription and allotment figures on the "new money" offering by the Treasury of 5 per cent notes shows that the results exceeded even the high expectation created by the reports of widespread withdrawals of holdings by individuals from savings accounts in order to participate in this tempting return on Government securities.
HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Project Saturn, key to the United States' leap into space, has been barely rocking along on a forty-hour, keepdown-the-overtime week.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Burglars looted four associated jewelry stores in London last night and escaped with a haul that may amount to the equivalent of more than $500,000. Scotland Yard indicated it was the biggest burglary on record in London.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Two adult whooping cranes, the first to complete the 1959 migration, have arrived at the Aransas National Wildlife refuge in Texas.
LONDON, Oct. 12 (UPI) -The Soviet Union will shoot the first man into space in the spring, The London Daily Herald reported today.
Eigthy thousand celebrators of Columbus Day paraded gaily up Fifth Avenue yesterday with massed flags flying, plumed drum majorettes strutting and fifty-five bands playing.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- In the desert, a water finder is a wonder man. John Ramsay, a British engineer, has been roaming an area of thousands of square miles of desert stretching from the Turkish border to Saudi Arabia, with many new water wells to his credit -- and one major defeat at the hands of nomadic women.

The Department of the Interior has announced changes in the regulations that will permit states to select mineral lands in lieu of other lands granted to them by the Federal Government. The proposed regulations would carry out the provisions of a 1958 law.

ROME, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- Premier Antonio Segni's moderate faction retained today the lead over Foreign Minister Amintore Fanfani's "center-left" wing in the election of delegates to the Christian Democratic party convention.
ASHEVILLE, N. C., Oct. 12 -- Southern Governors refrained today from endorsing any Presidential hopeful in the absence of a clear indication of the region's popular sentiment.

DOBBS FERRY N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Investigators were seeking the cause today of a fire last night in one of the residential buildings of Children's Village. Damage at the institution for 300 delinquent and mentally disturbed boys exceeded $15,000.

ONE underserving butt of World War II humor was that hero of food rationing, canned luncheon meat. It was fed to troops with such monotonous regularity that it became as familiar as an old sock -- and just as much maligned.
TORONTO, Oct. 12 (Canadian Press) -- A. V. Roe Canada, Ltd., and consolidated subsidiaries had net profit in the year ended on July 31 of $5,820,937, compared with $8,283,071 in the preceding year.

"Manhunt," the weekly series that began last night on Channel 5, is a Southern California relative of "The Lineup." Instead of having the hilly streets of San Francisco as its setting, it takes place along the palm-lined thoroughfares and waterfront of San Diego.

A joint statement in Manila of the Foreign Minister and the United States Ambassador indicates that substantial progress has been made on the question of United States bases in the archipelago. All of the problems have not yet been solved, and it would be unreasonable to expect that they should be. But some of the largest obstacles to fuller agreement have been removed.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 (AP) -The training of Soviet space men has been described for the first time in some detail by the magazine Ogonek. The training appears designed primarily to simulate conditions of rocket flights up to 300 miles.

Mayor Wagner's zeal for City Charter reform has been intermittent rather than compulsive. But now he has returned to the subject again and we hope he carries through. A bill creating a Charter Revision Commission has been waiting in the City Council since January.

The steel industry this month is commemorating the 100th anniversary of one of its more important inventions -- the "cold rolling" of iron and steel. This is a process that strengthens and hardens iron and gives it a bright, smooth surface.
That scooter daubed with the names of sixteen countries outside 158 West Forty-fourth Street has taken its rider 21,000 miles around Latin America and into the United States and Canada.
LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP) -Insurance men from fourteen nations will get together in London tomorrow to discuss cooperation against atomic risks.

UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Federation of ItalianAmerican Societies wants Governor Rockefeller to halt the state investigation of vice and crime here because "it has been a continuous source of embarrassment and harassment to the people of Italian extraction."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -President Eisenhower tried today to coax a baby elephant to take its vitamins. An American newspaper publisher charged last night that United States relations with Latin America were hampered by poor diplomatic appointments.

The military strength and global scope of the Communist threat have produced a situation in which 40 per cent of the American armed forces are serving in foreign countries, Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer. Army Chief of Staff, said last night.

A Japanese nuclear-ship mission to the United States will be led by Toshiki Sakuri, president of Mitsubishi Nippon Heavy Industries, Ltd., and chairman of the Shipbuilders Association of Japan.
ROME, Oct. 12 -- (UPI) Pope John XXIII made apologies today in Italian for his first public attempt to speak English. He said that the vowels tripped him up but that he would keep trying to learn.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 -- A first look at Soviet laboratories has convinced the chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission that both countries would profit from a modest program of collaboration in the non-military development of nuclear energy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Navy honored three civilian scientists today for their direction of International Geophysical Year campaigns. The Army presented cash awards and decorations to eight civilian employes for outstanding contributions in their fields.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Treasury officials said today that they would be cautious about trying to repeat their whopping success in selling new 5 per cent notes to individual investors. Louisiana State and Northwestern remained one, two yesterday in United Press International's major college football ratings, but Texas replaced Southern California in third place.

A 21-year-old youth was stabbed to death yesterday afternoon on Riverside Drive near Seventy-third Street in full view of holiday strollers. He was walking with a friend when attacked by an unidentified assailant.
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The stock market turned irregular here today after Friday's recordsmashing session.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Oct. 12 -A 21-year-old senior who has worked his way through school since becoming an orphan at 15, has been elected president of the student council at Stevens Institute of Technology.
DETROIT, Oct. 12 (AP) -Three of the five American auto manufacturers have reached normal production on 1960 cars.

ROME, Oct. 12 -- Almost the first thing a spectator notices upon entering Olympic Stadium here is that the playing field is surrounded by a deep concrete moat. The only access to the field is provided by ramps at the four corners that are covered by thick wire grating.

Someone in the Nashville area has a white bowling ball, but there is little likelihood that he will be able to use it. The white ball belongs to Don Carter. It was taken by a spectator during a match in the Tennessee city recently.

Two boys who escaped from a Westchester institution Saturday were arrested early yesterday for robbing a taxi driver in Greenwich Village. They were accused of taking his change holder with $2.90 at knife-point.

BERLIN, Oct. 12 -- In East Berlin last week, Otto Winzer, a Deputy Foreign Minister, was talking with a group of visiting newsmen about Germany's reunification.
Homeless newborn babies who are in good health in city, state and voluntary hospitals will soon be placed in foster homes under a new plan announced yesterday by the Department of Welfare.
A PERFORMANCE of stunning and enveloping power, Judith Anderson's memorable interpretation of Medea, was brought to New York television last night in a brilliant scheduling innovation on Channel 13.

LET'S be-fair about this. Let's not fall victim to the obvious and characterize "Mis-guided Tour," a new revue that opened last night at the Downtown Theatre, as a mis-guided excursion. Let's put it this way: "Mis-guided Tour" is a pedestrian entertainment, well-meaning in its intention but devoid of wit, urbanity and good comic sense.
Samuel Rubin and Irving M. Nason of the Bronx real estate concern of Rubin Nason have dissolved their partnership and each will conduct his real estate business individually.
An American traveler lately returned from the Soviet Union has brought a report of the firing of a synagogue and the cottage of the caretaker at a Jewish cemetery in Malakhovka, a suburb of Moscow.
LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Britain's trade gap -- the excess of imports over exports -widened in September.

Constable Norman Niblo, a strapping member of the police force in the City, London's financial district, opened a goodwill patrol of the United States under promising circumstances here yesterday.

Another important step toward a solution of the Algerian problem has been taken by the French Government through Foreign Minister Couve de Murville. In a statement televised in New York he has extended what amounts to tacit de facto recognition of the Algerian National Liberation Front (F. L. N.) as the belligerent with whom France wishes to negotiate a cease-fire as an essential condition for a referendum on Algerian self-determination.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Four securities concerns were expelled today from membership in the National Association of Securities Dealers on the ground that they had violated its rules of fair practice.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Modern drugs have opened the way to successful treatment of tuberculosis patients in the home without the need of sustained hospitalization, the World Health Organization reported today.

A youth who had been sought for questioning in the death of a 27-year-old Puerto Rican on the lower East Side last Friday surrendered to the police yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, the city of "The Angels," as well as movie stars, swimming pools and sunshine, has, in recent year, become the spawning ground for many of America's brightest fashion talent. Much of the credit for this goes to one of the nation's outstanding designers, James Galanos.

The Metropolitan Opera will open its seventy-fifth season on Monday, Oct. 26, with a roster of 109 singers, of whom thirteen will be making their first appearances with the company.

Once again, as so often in the past, the United Nations General Assembly is embroiled in bitter battle over an election to a seat in the Security Council, with Poland and Turkey as the present contestants. Thus far, after twenty-five ballots, Poland, the candidate of the Soviet bloc, is in the lead, but since neither side is able to muster the two-thirds majority necessary for election the result is deadlock.

Sales volume in September of the nation's major retail chains and mail order companies was 8.9 per cent above the level of the like 1958 month. For the first nine months of the year sales were above the 1958 level by 9.8 per cent.

Before the start of the National Football League season, Jim Lee Howell, the head coach of the Giants, said he thought the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Cleveland Browns were the teams to beat for the Eastern Conference crown. Now, at the quarter-mark, Howell has revised his thinking.
LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Oct. 13 -- American and British scientists, who are gathered here to discuss problems of controlling thermonuclear reactions, spent the day inspecting two very special machines.

THE eighty-eight "Great Master Drawings," open to the public today at Knoedler's and continuing through Nov. 7, compose just about as delightful an exhibition as you are likely to find in some time, unless you are conditioned to the standard of side-showmanship as the measure of an exhibition's merit.

Arrangements have been made by Richard Barr to become an independent Broadway producer. Until recently a partner of Charles Bowden and H. Ridgely Bullock Jr., Mr. Barr is preparing Alec Coppel's melodrama "The Joshua Tree" for a New York opening on Feb. 24.

The visit of President Lopez Mateos of Mexico to the United States (he is with us in New York today) is proving refreshing as well as valuable. Here is a Latin-American leader of a very important country who is friendly and self-assured. Therefore, he can and does talk frankly. This is the sort of relationship we want, ideally, to establish with our democratic "Good Neighbors" in the hemisphere.

JEFFERSON DAVIS may have been an able and conscientious executive, but he has never enjoyed the popular hero-worship granted by posterity to Robert E. Lee and to a lesser extent to Stonewall Jackson. Nostalgic Southerners who still mourn the Lost Cause speak of Davis with respect but not with affection. Some even omit the respect.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 13 -- More than 100 persons have been arrested in connection with terrorist acts believed to have been part of a plot to overthrow the Government.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 13 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer closed the door today to any change in West Germany's policy toward Eastern Europe.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Frank Reagan resigned today as head coach of Villanova's football team, which has dropped four games in a row. He will continue as athletic director.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The United States Government does not expect a summit meeting to be held before January at the earliest.

PARIS, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The International Automobile Association today set the schedule for 1960 auto racing. It also made two minor changes in the point system that determines the world champion driver.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 4 -An impasse appears to have developed in the southern Maldives, where the British are using rebel labor to complete an air base against the Maldivian Government's wishes.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 13 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted two electrical concerns and their presidents today on charges of making illegal payments to a former official of an electrical union.
PALISADES, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Katharine Cornell set sail today in a beautiful pea-green yacht on wheels for a five-week tour of "Dear Liar" with Brian Aherne.

Y., Oct. 13 -- Global trade in paper and paper products has edged its way into the category of heavy industries, according to the consensus of a recent conference in Rome under the auspices of the Food and Agriculture Organization. Experts from sixteen countries, including the United States, participated.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 13 -- A striking phenomenon of the post-war period has been the political role of military leaders in newly independent Asian lands. For better or worse, the army has interfered or seized the governing reins in Jordan, Lebanon, Syria, Iraq, Pakistan, Burma and Thailand.

THE gayest deception ever played on the home owner opens today at the Coliseum. For the price of a ticket ($1.50 for adults and 50 cents for children under 12), a series of hoaxes is perpetrated on viewers.
DETROIT, Oct. 13 -- The Post Office Department unveiled here today a semi-automatic electronic letter-sorter capable of directing 43,000 letters an hour to 399 destinations.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Mell G. Underwood today accepted nocontest pleas from five manufacturers of steel hand tools and four of their executives to charges of conspiring to fix prices.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Three young Americans expressed today what they called "the desperate hope" of the natives of South-West Africa for international action to relieve them of racial oppression.
Commodity futures trading continued dull and featureless yesterday on the New York exchanges. Price movements were slight in most markets.
ALBANY, Oct. 13 -- New York's legislative leaders announced today that the proposed National conference of their counterparts from other states would be held here in early December.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A Federal Power Commission expert told a Senate-House Economic subcommittee today "there is little likelihood" Russia can overtake the United States in electric power production in the next twenty years.

Mrs. Edward Ewen Anderson, chairman for the annual luncheon of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York, and Mrs. Albert Francke Jr., association president, have announced that Governor Rockefeller and Pauline Frederick will speak at the fete.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- A u10,000 ($28,000) reward was offered today for information leading to the recovery of $500,000 worth of jewelry stolen by thieves who systematically went through four London stores over the week-end.

ROME, Oct. 13 (UPI) -Americans have responded with so much compassion and generosity to fill the needs of the world's less fortunate peoples that the United States has become "the Good Samaritan of the world," Cardinal Spellman said today.
E. A. Snow, manager of the advertising department at Procter Gamble, has been elected vice president-advertising.

HAVANA, Oct. 13 (AP) -Communications Minister Enrique Oltuski Ozacki said last night that the American and Foreign Power Company so far had not shown sufficient reason to justify suspension of a Government decree reducing electricity rates.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 13 -Thousands of Indian traders continue to face considerable difficulties in Tibet. And Kashmiri Buddhists who have been living for many years in Tibet undergoing religious training in monasteries are still being prevented from returning to their homes in Ladakh Province of Kashmir State.

A new look is taken at everyday life in the Soviet Union in a volume titled "The Future Is Ours, Comrade." The author, who writes under the name of Joseph Novak, lived as a Russian citizen and traveled widely in Russia in the period after Stalin's death.

The Government figures on employment and unemployment both traditionally show a seasonal decline in September, as does that of the total labor force. The principal factors behind this typical behavior of the statistics for September are the withdrawal from the labor market of many temporary workers of the age group 14 years to 24 with the reopening of school and the first signs of a tapering off of the number of outdoor jobs.
Rakish, long-sweeping fins set off the silhouette on the 1960 line of Chrysler cars, the top medium-priced line of the Chrysler Corporation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13 -- Unscored on in three games and tied with Pennsylvania for the league leadership, Yale plays Cornell at Ithaca in the big Ivy attraction of the week. This is one of the few games the country over Saturday that will match undefeated teams.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 13 -United States armaments manufacturers have begun to pour massive amounts of capital and technical experience into the reviving West German arms industry.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The strong demand for industrial shares continued in the stock market here today and prices forged ahead.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt urged in effect yesterday that Communist China become a member of the United Nations.

The General Electric Company reported yesterday that a strong third quarter raised earnings for the first nine months of this year to a new record for the period. Sales almost equaled the peak reached in the first nine months of 1957.

WHEN M'sieu Philippe Henri Watson first signed with the New York Rangers as a player, he could speak hardly a word of English. Now he knows all the words, including some not normally used in polite society. A delightful French-Canadian accent, however, continually betrays his antecedents.

The State Liquor Authority has transferred sixteen investigators from upstate to help the city staff of twenty-five conduct a clean-up drive of bars and taverns patronized by prostitutes and homosexuals.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 13 -- The prohibition movement in Norway has suffered a serious setback. In a local plebiscite yesterday ten of twelve prohibitionist towns elected to introduce liquor. In six other towns, already "wet," voters chose to stay that way.
When Detective Patrick Twomey came out of the Police Headquarters Annex at 400 Broome Street at noon yesterday, he spotted a barefoot man, wearing pajama bottoms and a T-shirt, chasing another man.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday the development of a method of fabricating large metal objects from tungsten, molybdenum and other high temperature-resistant metals and alloys by means of a commercially feasible powder metallurgy technique called "continuous powder compaction."
BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- A twoman subcommittee of the United States Senate opened here today a seven-city inquiry into the problems of the aged and aging.

ABILENE, Kan., Oct. 13 -President Eisenhower called on the free nations of the world today to join the United States in a long-range program to provide a better life for the less-privileged peoples of the globe.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -Led by soybeans, grain futures finished mostly higher on the board of trade today.

The Soviet-United States film exchange, which has been advancing through the thaw in the "cold war" as ponderously as an ice-breaker for more than twenty months, will become a reality in a few weeks. On Tuesday, Nov. 10, there will be simultaneous premieres of the American film, "Marty," in Moscow and the Russian-made "The Cranes Are Flying" at the Dupont Theatre in Washington.
Two Guys From Harrison, Inc., a leading self-service discount store chain, and O. A. Sutton Corporation, Inc., makers of fans, air conditioners and heaters, agreed yesterday to merge.

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 13 -A prototype of a standard cargo container that can be shipped without reloading by land, sea or air was shown today at the annual convention of the National Defense Transportation Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Calvin Griffith, the president of the Washington Senators, today said he soon would act on what he called an enticing proposition to move his American League baseball team to Minneapolis.

The settlement of law suits brought by the directors and stockholders of Williams-McWil liams Industries, Inc., against Sinclair Robinson, former president and director, and some of his associates has been approved by New York State Supreme Court Judge Henry Clay Greenberg.

The State Rent Commission, hoping to encourage landlords to rehabilitate apartment buildings in the city, is making it easier for them to obtain rent increases if they make major improvements in their properties.
The first of four meetings to develop a program to improve West Seventy-sixth Street will take place tonight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- A new technique to correct the abnormalties in vision that follow some cataract operations was described here today in an exhibit at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology at the Palmer House here.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 13 -John W. Nance, Democratic candidate for Oyster Bay Town Supervisor, charged today that the Town Board had passed special legislation for a homebuilding concern that had resuited in a $500,000 saving for the developers.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Stevenage, a new town built in the Hertford countryside to house British industrial workers, moved today to solve its youth problem before the problem really arises.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -State Department officials said today that there had been public announcements by several United States companies of participation in West German arms production, chiefly the role of Lockheed and General Dynamics in production of the F-104 fighter aircraft.

Final arrangements are being made by members of the Thrift Shop Committee of the Women's Auxiliary of the Presbyterian Hospital for the benefit on the afternoon of Oct. 27. An illustrated talk on "Modern Trends and the Role of the Decorator" will be given by Elisabeth Draper in the Cosmopolitan Club at 129 East Sixty-fifth Street.

As a historian I am not interested in either politics or propaganda; but, frankly, I am surprised to learn of the new historic idea put forth by Li Thian-hok, in a letter published Oct. 1, who says "Formosa and the Pescadores have never been an integral part of China historically.''
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A Republican study committee presented today a sweeping plan envisioning a Gross National Product of goods and services totaling $900,000,000,000 a year by 1976.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) Before leaving the White House for Abilene today, President Eisenhower received three red oak trees as birthday gifts from the Republican National Committee and the party's campaign committees of the House and Senate.
HONOLULU, Oct. 13 -- Some forty to fifty delegates representing airlines in the Western Hemisphere met here today in an attempt to avert a possible rate war on routes between North and South America.

Charles Van Doren arrived here yesterday amid an uproar over his whereabouts and arranged to accept a subpoena ordering him to appear at the Congressional investigation into rigged television quiz programs.
A bipartisan slate for five new places on the City Court in Brooklyn was criticized yesterday by the Citizens Union as "judicial appointments by local party leaders."
THE popular "Chiquita Banana's Recipe Book" has been revised. The latest edition offers a number of new recipes while retaining many of the old favorites.
The Association of Stock Exchange Firms has announced the following nominations for its board of directors:

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- The French Government made a further overture to the Algerian rebels today. It again offered their leaders safe conduct to come to France to discuss a cease-fire and assured them of their right of participation in a free political life in Algeria.
An international conference will open in Washington tomorrow with the avowed purpose of banishing military activity from an entire continent -- Antarctica.
Jeering, embittered tenants at the site for the Penn Station South housing project complained to Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack last night of inhuman treatment.

Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Ancestor staged a playback of his Oct. 1 victory in the Broad Hollow Steeplechase Handicap when he took the fifty-first running of the Brook. Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.
WHEN Ray Lawler's "Summer of the 17th Doll" was introduced here two seasons ago by an Australian company it seemed shrill, overwrought and graceless.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 13 -- A former member of the Brookhaven Town Board pleaded guilty today to charges of having taken $13,500 in bribes to rezone properties for special uses.
The voters of the state were urged by the City Council yesterday to approve the proposed $500,000,000 bond issue for school construction at the Nov. 3 election.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- The Orange County District Attorney subjected Malcolm R. White, Chester manufacturer, to cross-examination for nearly the whole court day today on his plea that he was unable to remember important facts bearing on his innocence or guilt in killing Alfred F. Dugan last Nov. 13.
Production of raw steel in mills not affected by the steel strike continued at the same rate last week for the third consecutive week.
MIAMI, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Gardner Cowles, president of Cowles Magazines, Inc., and The Des Moines Register and Tribune Company, today was elected chairman of General Development Corporation.
Bond prices moved slightly lower yesterday.

NEWARK, Oct. 13 -- The $75.97 that was recovered from two youths who held up a commuter bus last Feb. 27 may benefit three charities if the victims agree to a proposal by the United States Attorney's office here.

The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) is moving to acquire Leonard Refineries, Inc., a Michigan refining and marketing concern. Charles E. Spahr, president of Ohio Standard, and Reid Brazell, president of Leonard, announced yesterday that the two companies had signed a contract providing for Ohio Standard to exchange 324,582 shares of its common stock for Leonard's assets.

I have read with great interest and appreciation your excellent editorial which focused much needed attention on the problems of hemophilia and the work being done by the National Hemophilia Foundation.
The State Commission of Investigation scored Mayor John F. Ryan and the police of Ithaca yesterday for permitting illegal gambling.
SO you think you have seen everything? Well, unless you have seen the Philippine dance company, Bayanihan, which S. Hurok brought to the Winter Garden last night, you couldn't be more mistaken.
The Appalachian Mountain sports car rally on Nov. 6, 7 and 8, with headquarters at Hershey, Pa., again will decide the national championship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Gov. Price Daniel of Texas urged the Supreme Court today to fix the state's seaward boundary three marine leagues out into the Gulf of Mexico -- ten and one-half miles -- and let Texas have the minerals out to that line.

The steel strike board of inquiry is rendering a conspicuous public service in the inventive way it is applying the Taft-Hartley Law to the present situation. And we congratulate the President on appointing a board whose members could be counted on to act so.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Twelve more ballots failed today to break the deadlock between Poland and Turkey in their race for a seat on the Security Council. The contest will be resumed in the General Assembly Monday.
The Metropolitan Opera Guild, Inc., will be the beneficiary of the premiere of the new production of "The Marriage of Figaro'' at the Metropolitan Opera House on Oct. 30.
The two Soviet stars, Mikhail Tal and Paul Keres, gained decisive victories in the twentyfirst round of the challengers' chess tournament yesterday, according to a report from Yugoslavia.
Pedestrians will no longer have to employ a wary eye and a nimble foot when the city's new street - cleaning trucks come splashing by.
