THE fashion largesse that Bergdorf Goodman has distributed to its exacting customers for many years is about to include the younger set on a really grand scale.

People who like Central Park, with or without Shakespeare, have been pleased to observe a marked sprucing-up of late. Nowhere has this been more noticeable than in the Conservatory Garden on the east side of the park at 105th Street,

GENEVA, Oct. 13. -- The Nansen Medal for outstanding work on behalf of refugees was presented here today to Oskar Helmer, who was Austrian Minister of the Interior in 1956 when 180,000 Hungarians took refuge in Austria.

Legislation to allow steamship lines to use dual rate scales was urged here yesterday by Clarence G. Morse, Federal Maritime Board chairman. His plea was made at the opening of a hearing by a special House antitrust subcommittee on the ocean-freight industry.

A VERY-MUCH-SUBDUED Jerry Lewis made his dramatic debut last night in a short version of "The Jazz Singer," remembered chiefly as the Al Jolson vehicle that was the first commercial film to include sound. Mr. Lewis was seen on "Startime" over Channel 4.

EXETER, N. H., Oct. 13 -Intricate iron-brained machines solve all sorts of problems, but none has yet come up with a formula for the length of time required for a head football coach's hair to turn gray. Ted Seabrooke of Phillips Exeter Academy is willing to become exhibit No. 1 for any researcher.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Mr. Casey said today that establishment of a demilitarized zone free of both nuclear and traditional weapons would be a major objective of the conference.

The New York Times on Oct. 5 published an editorial entitled "The Panamanian Case" which contains a number of misstatements, three of which are of fundamental importance. Therefore I am compelled to request the hospitality of your columns in order to correct them.
It was with great interest that I read of Congressman John Lindsay's proposal to investigate the $100 million allocation of Title I funds to New York City.

Stocks went through a quiet session yesterday, with most of the list moving in negligible fractions and only a few speculative favorites showing more action. The market as a whole showed a small loss.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -Bernard Goldfine will be recalled by House investigators soon to clear up the case that led to his indictment for contempt of Congress.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 12 points (60 cents a bale) up to 3 points (15 cents) off yesterday.

Major engineering changes to provide greater fuel economy and better performance in the normal driving range have been incorporated in the 1960 Mercury line. There will be thirteen models in three series, which will go on sale tomorrow.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 13 -Cyprus will go to the polls Dec. 13 to elect a President and a Vice President of the republic, it was announced today.
The great post-war expansion program of the utility industries shows definite signs of slowing. This was borne out in the latest figures on new financing compiled by Irving Trust Company.

This is a week of decision on New York's Commuter Belt football circuit. Four of the five teams that compose this vigorous group are paired on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Labor Department reported today that unemployment stemming from the steel strike had accelerated and spread to new industries.

The New York Philharmonic returned to New York yesterday morning from its ten-week tour of Europe and the Near East. The tour was under the auspices of the President's Special International Program for Cultural Presentations, sponsored by the American National Theatre and Academy.
LAST December, King Mohamed V of Morocco summoned a 40-year-old intellectual who had been the leader of the Left-wing opposition to become his Premier.
The Chase Manhattan Bank will open its largest and newest branch today at 410 Park Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street. And nowhere on the main floor is there a teller's cage in sight.

Life really can begin at 80. This discovery was made nearly two years ago by Henry M. Neely, sometimes called the "dean of New York's star gazers." He reached the four-score mark and started a new career -- lecturing on astronomy for beginners.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- A New York Rabbinical scholar testified here today that forcing Jews to observe Sunday as a day of rest was the same as compelling them to recognize Christianity.

A former official of the Development Corporation for Israel was indicted yesterday on a charge of stealing $4,000 to cover horse-racing losses. Most of the money was alleged to have come from the sale of State of Israel bonds for a bondholder.
Edward R. Murrow's leave of absence from the Columbia Broadcasting System continues at a rapid pace.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -A ninety-one-and-a-half-pound satellite shaped like a gyroscope and squealing like bagpipes was sent whirling through space today to measure the radiation of the sun and to study how the earth's weather is formed.

The work of the eighteen branch offices in ten states of the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company will be supervised by Justin R. Toomey. He has been appointed a director of the company and head of its national division.
The president of the world's largest oil company said last night that the petroleum industry would be faced with a surplus capacity situation "for the next several years."
Al Lopez, who led the Chicago White Sox to their first pennant in forty years, was named yesterday as American League manager of the year by United Press International.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- The Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization (O. C. D. M.) issued a reminder today that Dec. 31 was the deadline to qualify new defense and atomic energy facilities for fiveyear tax write-offs.
An American company that is a major operator of foreign flag ships is disposing of a fifth of its fleet in a move to help States Marine Lines, Inc., qualify as a subsidized steamship company.

Francis W. H. Adams, a key figure in the Democratic reform movement in this city, disclosed yesterday that he had volunteered to work for the election of Samuel R. Pierce, a Republican, to the General Sessions bench.

A robber who watched eagerly yesterday while a Brooklyn bank teller stuffed what looked like a thick packet of money into a grocery bag discovered to his chagrin, when the police caught him a few minutes later, that the $5,000 he had demanded was mostly paper stuffing.

What would be the maximum cost to the taxpayer if the enlarged borrowing power for school construction granted New York City by passage of Amendment No. 4 were as fully and promptly used as law permits? We think the voter who will act on this amendment Nov. 3 deserves as clear an answer to this question as can be given, in view of the cloudy, imprecisely stated and sometimes conflicting estimates that have been published.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Ireland and Malaya asked the General Assembly today to express itself as "gravely concerned" over reports that the people of Tibet had been denied their fundamental rights by the Chinese Communists.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service paid tribute today to Joseph Jackson Lewis who was responsible for much of the income tax system.

A warning against a bear in sheep's clothing talking peaceful coexistence was given yesterday by Adnan Menderes, Premier of Turkey. He spoke before 1,200 persons, at a luncheon meeting of the Foreign Policy Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Dr. George W. Taylor, President Eisenhower's chief emergency fact-finder in the steel strike, declared today that no end to the ninety-one-day dispute was in sight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Brazil won its second international jumping title in the finale of the six-day Washington International Horse Show tonight when Nelson Pessoa guided Relincho to two faultless performances and the $1,000 stake victory.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- Negotiations resume tomorrow in the five-week strike of mold makers against the glass container industry following a week-long recess.
THE William Zorach retrospective, opening today at the Whitney Museum, is a full-dress affair honoring an outstanding contemporary American sculptor.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- President Adolfo Lopez Mateos of Mexico received a warm welcome in Chicago today. Mayor Richard J. Daley made him an honorary citizen of Chicago and pledged the city's "love and affection" for the President's family and the Mexican people.
BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- An investigation of the Federal highway program that will last at least two years and possibly four was announced here today as in prospect.

The presidents of most of the nation's independent colleges started a fund-raising campaign last night that was believed without parallel in higher education. They hope to raise $9,000,000 for their non-tax-supported institutions by spring.
FORT BELVOIR, Va., Oct. 13 (AP) -- A small airplane with a large whirling fan extending from each wingtip performed alternately like a helicopter and a plane today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 13 -- The state police today filed three complaints, including one of manslaughter, against the truck driver whose empty oil tanker rammed a chartered bus Friday killing nine co-eds and a college professor.
TRENTON, Oct. 13 -- A jury of eleven men and one woman was selected here today to try the Federal Government's antitrust suit against five major drug concerns in the sale of Salk polio vaccine.

The big unknown quantity at the start of Rudolf Firkusny's Carnegie Hall piano recital last night was the Carlisle Floyd Sonata. Mr. Floyd, known internationally as the composer of "Susannah" and, more recently, "Wuthering Heights," had not been previously represented here by a large-scale instrumental work.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Mr. and Mrs. Pat Cici of Lido won the qualifying medal in the fifth annual mixed Scotch open golf championship at the Dellwood Country Club today.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Procter Gamble stockholders were told today that 70 per cent of the company's sales were in products created since the end of World War II.
PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Premier Michel Debre restated today France's cautious approach to a meeting of heads of government on East-West issues.
THE year 1959 should go down in the record books as the year when British women outshone and outstripped British men in every facet of fashion.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -The crew of a B-47 bomber fired a ballistic missile into space today near the Explorer VI paddle-wheel satellite.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- A substantial rise in United Kingdom dollar-producing exports to the United States for the first nine months of 1959 was announced today by the Board of Trade. Volume was 39 per cent higher than in the corresponding period of last year, the board noted.
Volusia County, Fla., sold yesterday $5,000,000 of serial bonds of Special Tax School District 1 to a syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. at an interest cost of 4.284 per cent.

About 110 former German scientists, headed by Dr. Wernher von Braun, are the core of the 4,300-man space and rocket team at Huntsville, Ala., which is now once again a pawn in a new conflict in Washington.
The Automobile Club of New York announced yesterday that it was urging its members to vote "yes" on proposed constitutional amendments 1 and 2 this year.
The City Council adopted three measures yesterday intended to curb the rising tide of juvenile delinquency and prevent the further growth of street gangs.

Plans have been announced for a complete alteration of the building that formerly housed the Russeks store at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street. The nine-story structure will become an office and showroom building with stores on the street floor.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 13 -Ingemar Johansson and Wilt (the Stilt) Chamberlain will be the attractions at a basketball extravaganza tomorrow night. It is designed to raise $81,000 to provide a major league playing floor for the Minneapolis Lakers of the National Basketball Association.
LINDEN, N. J., Oct. 13 -- The transfer of its New York aircraft service division to new and larger quarters here at 1611 West Elizabeth Avenue was announced today by the General Electric Company.

United Air Lines will officially open its gleaming $14,500,000 passenger terminal tomorrow at the New York International Airport. This will be the first of the country's major airlines to leave the old Idlewild terminal building for new separate quarters.

John Drew Barrymore, son of the late John Barrymore, has quit the touring company of "Look Homeward, Angel." He had been rehearsing with Miriam Hopkins, co-star of the Ketti Frings dramatization of the Thomas Wolfe novel, for a week and a half until last Thursday.

ALBANY, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A plan to form Democratic party clubs in high schools was announced today. However the State Education Department said that no meetings could be held on school property without official assent.

The Greater New York Fund yesterday elected Hermann G. Place president and Howard C. Sheperd board chairman. Mr. Place succeeds Norman S. Goetz and Mr. Sheperd succeeds J. Stewart Baker.

Bond prices receded again yesterday in another trading session in which selling predominated.

Washington's Arena Stage, which has demonstrated the advantages of decentralization in the theatre, has growing pains. NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 14 -- India and Pakistan will begin a high-level series of conferences tomorrow in a renewed effort to resolve outstanding financial issues and border disputes.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Oct. 14 -- The Special Senate Committee on Unemployment Problems was told today that the distressed Uniontown-Connellsville area of southwestern Pennsylvania could not recover without Federal assistance.

Ward Melville, chairman of the board of Melville Shoe Corporation, was honored last night at a dinner at the University Club for his fifty years of service with the company.

Dunhill International, Inc., distributor of smoking articles, men's toiletries, women's cosmetics and other gift items has been an active buyer of other companies' stocks recently.

The fund-raising campaign of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 East Seventieth Street, New York 21, is under way with Dudley F. Cates as general chairman. This valuable organization must raise $508,000 by Dec. 31 if it is to carry on its tradition of "no call unanswered."

Last December the late Meyer Berger wrote an article concerning Operation Handclasp in his column "About New York," relating how its inception, in 1957, was a direct result of the slaying of Michael Farmer in Washington Heights. Operation Handclasp is a nonprofit organization dedicated to the improvement of urban society through sociological methods, financially supported solely through contributions of business, philanthropic foundations and individuals.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Medical evidence to prove that Malcolm R. White suffered brain damage that affected his sight, thinking, memory and calculation was offered today by the defense in the executive's first-degree murder trial here.
LONDON, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- A rush of business since the Conservative election victory last week has brought the London Stock Exchange the biggest boom in its history.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Bill Goldbeck, the home-club professional, shot a one-under-par 35, 36 -- 71 on his own ball at Mount Kisco Country Club today and won with two partners in the pro-amateur event.
OLATHE, Kan., Oct. 14 (UPI) -- A 15-year-old schoolgirl told the police today that she had poisoned her mother and father last night. Both parents died.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that it had begun fireproofing subway and elevated track ties and other wooden structures on the rapid transit system two months ago.
ROME, Oct. 14 -- The Soviet Union has asked members of the Atlantic Alliance for credits totaling hundreds of millions of dollars. Italy alone has been asked for a commercial credit of $100,000,000.

Independent American oil companies that bought exploration concessions in Venezuela during 1956 and 1957 can expect no sympathy or assistance from the present Venezuelan Government, according to Dr. Juan Pablo Perez Alfonso, Minister of Mines.

Directors of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad ordered payment yesterday of an extra dividend of 50 cents as well as the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents. Both distributions will be made on Dec. 11 to holders of record of Dec. 4.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A substantial increase in both the nuclear and conventional strength of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was recommended in a report made public today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14 -The United Automobile Workers rallied today to the cause of the striking steel workers.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 2 to 14 points (10 to 70 cents a bale) yesterday, with strength most pronounced in the new crop months.

SMOOTH is the word for Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University. He is impeccably groomed; he speaks extemporaneously in an even flow of parsed sentences; his temper does not have a rough spot on it, and he runs a perfectly smooth operation.

Directors of the Ford Motor Company declared yesterday the usual quarterly dividend of 60 cents and an extra dividend of the same amount. Both are payable on Dec. 10. This is the first extra paid by the manufacturer of cars since its stock was placed on public sale in 1956.

The inauguration of a new college president is always a stimulating event, reviving interest in traditions and looking to new horizons. At Smith College today Dr. Thomas Corwin Mendenhall, of distinguished record in teaching and administration at Yale, will formally take office as the sixth president. His intellectual qualifications are manifest: he has others, his mother having been a Smith graduate in 1895, Dr. Dorothy Reed Mendenhall, a physician.

On Oct. 14, 1958, the stock market had a prime case of the jitters. The nervousness was caused by pretty well-founded rumors that margin rates were to be increased. Margin is the minimum percentage of the market price of a security that an investor is required to pay in cash when he makes a purchase.

THE Orchestra of America, newly organized under the guidance of Richard Korn, musical director, is on the side of the angels. At its first concert at Carnegie Hall last night it concentrated on American music, and in the remaining four this season it will continue to explore this area.

In 1948 Farley Mowat made a 1,200-mile canoe trip through the interior barrens of the Canadian Arctic. There he met the Ihalmiut Eskimos, about whose desperate situation he wrote in "People of the Deer." Last year he returned to the tribe and found that of the nearly fifty men, women and children he had met earlier there were only a dozen survivors.

ALTHOUGH William L. Laurence claims no final word on the fission, fusion and alarmed confusion that shake our society, he has an uncommon fund of knowledge about these unsettling matters. G.W.U. has announced that all its affiliates here in New York and elsewhere have been directed to bargain collectively for a program of fire drills and safety inspections by "fire wardens" in every union contract.

Zanuck Productions, Inc., producers of a movie based on the work.

The dampness in the air and the mud on the field at the Yankee Stadium yesterday did not interfere with a two-hour practice session of the New York Fotball Giants. Branch Rickey, the president of the proposed Continental Baseball League, said yesterday that a third major league was "inevitable."

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Attorneys for Caryl Chessman pleaded today with California's Governor -- over the convict-author's vehement protest -- to commute to life imprisonment the death sentence he has faced since 1948 for sex crimes in Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon discussed today domestic and international problems -- and possibly, the White House said, the 1960 Presidential race.

The eighty-two member hospitals of the United Hospital Fund not only care for millions of the city's sick annually, but also push back the health frontier each year through research and preventive and curative medicine.

The stage has been set for the automotive battle of the year -- and of many years. It's a three-sided contest, involving the American industry's "Big Three" manufacturers, independent domestic producers and foreign manufacturers. The prize is the rapidly growing small-car market.

ELEGANT is the word for "The Evening Room," Saks Fifth Avenue's new salon devoted exclusively to evening wear. The salon, which is on the fifth floor, opened this week. It enables customers to shop in spacious surroundings with a European air of opulence.
Crewmen, and terminal personnel of the Sixty-ninth Street Brooklyn Ferry voted, 88 to 31, yesterday to accept a city-sponsored formula for settling a contract dispute.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Five top-rank Russian composers, led by Dmitri Shostakovich, will arrive a week from tomorrow to tour the United States under the Soviet-American cultural exchange program.
LULUABOURG, Belgian Congo, Oct. 15 (Reuters) -- Terrified African refugees poured into this guarded jungle capital tonight ahead of war-painted tribesmen on a murder rampage to avenge an old feud.

HAVANA, Oct. 15 -- About 400 children have been picked up from the streets of Havana and are living on two luxurious estates of Wajay just outside the city. " Turandot" of Puccini will be performed for the first time this season on Sunday at the City Center with Flaviano Labo, Italian tenor, making his debut with the New York City Opera Company as Prince Calaf.

The attention that juvenile delinquency has been getting recently has obscured for many New Yorkers the fact that only a fraction of our youngsters are involved in such activities. ALTHOUGH Walter Scott's "Ivanhoe" is one of its great author's inferior books, until recently it was his most widely read. Thousands of schoolteachers, who evidently knew no better, forced it upon generations of pupils. And that is why many people, who know nothing else about the Knights Templars, know that Brian de Bois-Guilbert, the villain whose attentions made Rebecca threaten to throw herself out of a tower window, was a member of that organization.

Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman.

K. L. M., Royal Dutch Airlines, is celebrating its fortieth birthday. The carrier will enter the jet age when it begins flying the DC-8 jet-liner between New York and Amsterdam in March.

Representative Edith Green urged yesterday that Congress support a program to identify prospective juvenile delinquents in kindergarten and follow up with work that would forestall the prediction.
Increased sales and earnings were reported yesterday by R. H. Macy Co., department store chain, for the fiscal year that ended on Aug. 1.

Factory sales of the electronics industry this year will reach a record of more than $8,000,000,000, John G. Forrest, financial-business news editor of The New York Times, predicted last night. PARIS, Friday, Oct. 16 -- The French National Assembly gave President Charles de Gaulle an overwhelming vote of confidence early today in his attempt to settle Algeria's future by the free choice of its inhabitants.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The unsuccessful attempt on the life of a prominent Left-wing politician early today has lent credibility to recent warnings that French extremists are preparing a wave of assassinations to block a liberal settlement in Algeria.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Directors of the International Monetary Fund today authorized Peru to resume drawing upon a $13,000,000 stand-by fund.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- A Senate-House economic subcommittee was told today that atomic power could not be expected to become a competitive source of electricity before 1965 and possibly 1970.

The Committee on Slum Clearance will advertise next week that the corporate set-ups and other data about rival developers for the Hammels and Seaside housing sites in Queens are open for public inspection.

RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 16 -- Algerian nationalist leaders were authoritatively reported tonight to be mapping strategy for contacts with the French Government to negotiate a cease-fire in the Algerian war.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Covering by nervous shorts raised wheat futures on the Board of Trade today. Soybeans and corn showed additional losses on continued favorable weather for harvesting.
When George C. Marshall retired as Army Chief of Staff after World War II he received an Oak Leaf Cluster to the Distinguished Service Medal he had won in World War I.
When George C. Marshall was Secretary of State, his prescription for dealing with the Soviet Union was "firmness."

Directors of Wisconsin Bankshares Corporation, Milwaukee bank holding company, are recommending an increase in authorized capital from 2,000,000 to 5,000,000 shares of common stock and a change in the company's name. William G. Brumder, president, said the increase would make additional shares available for expansion of present subsidiaries, acquisition of new ones or increased capitalization.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that the lack of Congressional action this year on immigration legislation was a "default in United States foreign policy."
Tickets are still available for the benefit theatre party at Monday's performance of "The Gang's All Here" at the Ambassador Theatre. Proceeds will aid the Citizen's Housing and Planning Council.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Scattered light frost early this morning started tinting the foliage in autumn colors.
Thousands of Protestant clergymen over the country will step from their pulpits tomorrow in honor of Laymen's Sunday. In their stead lay members or guest speakers will address the congregations.

The United Steelworkers of America, with 500,000 members idle in basic steel mills, iron ore mines, warehouses and Great Lakes ore carriers. The strike began July 15 after the old three-year contract had been extended for two weeks at the request of President Eisenhower.

Not everybody believes that George Washington was the first President of the United States. There are still a few diehards who cast their vote for John Hanson of Maryland, who was "President of the United States in Congress assembled" for one year, starting on Nov. 5, 1781, some eight years before George Washington took his oath of office.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Improvement of relations with the Continent has been given high priority by the new British Government. This project could be described more accurately as improvement of relations with Dr. Konrad Adenauer.
Hopes that the steel strike would end without application of a Taft-Hartley Act injunction ruled the stock market yesterday. Volume and prices rose briskly.

The career of George C. Marshall in diplomacy had far-reaching results. On June 5, 1947, as Secretary of State, General Marshall made clear President Harry Truman's policy of military and economic aid to free nations standing against any threatened Soviet aggression.
ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 16 -Hollister Hall, a $2,000,000 engineering-education building, was dedicated today at Cornell University, here.
ALTHOUGH Robert Penn Warren has told the story of "All the King's Men" several times, he need not tell it again.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -Every Government, large or small, has a spokesman, but only the United States Government has a spokesman who is a virtuoso on the musical saw. Today this phenomenon, Andrew Henry Berding, was showing his talent by playing a cadenza on the newest theme of the Department of State -the responsibility of the Soviet Government for the behavior of Communist China.
Two 750-foot Dutch liners performed an intricate maneuver shifting back and forth between piers here yesetrday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- A broadcasting industry spokesman said today that the industry "has proved, in its four decades of service, it can clean its own house when necessary."

Call it rubber-stamp or not, the French National Assembly took the only conceivable action it could reasonably have taken in approving by a 19-to-1 majority General de Gaulle's position on Algeria. KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Plans for the sale of the Dewey Portland Cement Company of Kansas City to the American-Marietta Company were abandoned today.

In one of the more hopeful developments in Soviet Russia orders have gone out from the Kremlin to all Soviet industry for an immediate increase in the production of consumer goods and a drastic improvement in their quality.

MOST of the excitement of "Person to Person," which returned to its usual niche on Channel 2 last night, took place behind the scenes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Average wholesale primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 119.1 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Francis Cardinal Spellman arrived at New York International Airport from Rome last night after a seven-day visit during which he attended the Centennial of the North American College.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 16 -- Religious tensions in the United States will be increased next year by the prospect of a Roman Catholic candidate for President, the National Association of Intergroup Relations officials agreed today.
A new anti-noise measure that requires airlines to give full pre-flight details to the Port of New York Authority on all jet take-offs at New York International Airport went into effect this week.
Applications to the Federal Housing Administration for mortgage insurance on new construction rose nearly 10 per cent in September from the August level, the F.H.A. reported yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- An international declaration of the rights of the child was completed here tonight.
The Metropolitan Council on Housing will begin today to distribute 100,000 leaflets calling on Mayor Wagner to remove Robert Moses from the chairmanship of the Committee on Slum Clearance.

VICTOR BORGE last night played Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto that summarizes his hour - long show over Channel 4. The period was so labored and so frequently in dubious pace that it was hard to believe the program was the work of the artist justly noted for his one-man shows.

WHEN John Steinbeck's "Burning Bright" first was produced on Broadway in 1950 it had the tremendous asset of a luminously lovely performance that gave it a strength it did not actually possess. In its revival at Theatre East last night it failed to receive that sort of luminously lovely performance, with the logical result that its weaknesses were only too painfully evident.

Mike Todd Jr., who produced "Scent of Mystery" in his new Smell-O-Vision process, is now faced with a little mystery that was not in the script. Will a New York theatre operator beat him to the punch in getting a "smell-movie" process before the vast and presumably breathlessly waiting American public ?
The students of Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn honored former Senator Herbert H. Lehman yesterday for distinguished service to the city.
Treasury bills and other prime short-term investments of Government issue were in broad demand yesterday, furnishing leadership to a market that ended the week on a firm note.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Tom Strafaci of Dyker Beach and Patricia Tiernan of Wheatley Hills, playing selected drives and alternate shots, won the fifth annual Scotch open mixed golf championship today.

Americans are always willing to send money to help churches anywhere in the world, but seldom willing to embrace them in fellowship, the executive director of the East Asia Conference of the World Council of Churches said here yesterday.

Robert Moses, speaking as chairman of the State Council of Parks, announced yesterday his approval of the Northway route that would carry the proposed Albany-to-Canada highway through the fringes of the Adirondack Forest Preserve.

A lonely feeling often overcomes the young men and women in our military service away from home, many for the first time. Stockholders of Consolidated Electronics Industries Corporation yesterday approved consolidation with Central Public Utility Corporation and Philips Industries, Inc. The surviving company will be known as Consolidated Electronics Industries Corporation.

CESARE VALLETTI gave another atypical recital last night in Town Hall. An Italian tenor of the Metropolitan Opera is supposed to sing arias, culminating in a throbbing "E lucevan le stelle" or something like that. Mr. Valletti had different ideas.

COUNTLESS inexpensive gadgets that can add to the success of a party are inundating New York stores this fall. Homemakers planning an active entertaining schedule might well check their cooking equipment and fill in the gaps.

The Atlas Corporation polled shareholders several months ago to find out whether they preferred cash, stock dividends or no dividends at all. Of those who replied, more than half indicated that they would prefer cash.

The Kroger Company, operator of one of the nation's largest retail food store chains, reported yesterday that its net income in the forty weeks ended on Oct. 3 rose to $18,797,129 from $16,129,054 in the 1958 period.

The week-long Jewish Festival of Succoth, or the Feast of Tabernacles, began at nightfall yesterday with services in synagogues and temples. It marks the gathering of the harvest and also symbolizes the wanderings of the ancient Israelites.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 11 to 21 points yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Clyde Belin, 54-year-old selfstyled educator charged with mail fraud in the promotion of his defunct Belin University at Chillicothe, Mo., was sentenced today to serve a year and a day in a Federal prison.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- General of the Army George Catlett Marshall died tonight. He was 78 years old.
East Orange, the defending New Jersey State high school football champion, meets Irvington today in a game that may decide this year's title.

The Howard Stores Corporation announced yesterday that it had entered into an agreement with stockholders of Ripley Manufacturing Company and its affiliated companies to acquire Ripley Clothes, a manufacturing and retail clothing organization.
Commodity future prices traced an upward course yesterday on most New York exchanges in quiet trading. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Five Government officials gave the Music Critics Association a rundown today on what the United States was doing for music. The associate minister of All Souls Unitarian Church praised social workers yesterday as "'do-gooders' who clean up the dirty work left by the 'do-nothings.'"
For its local debut late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall, the New York String Quartet tackled four handsome pieces, all big in musical stature if not in actual size.

IN a time of crisis one can learn from any source, even opera. Here is Puccini's "Turandot." which returned to the City Center last night, offering not only original lyric theatre but also a hint at how to deal with quizzes.
Associate Justice James B. M. McNally of the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division commended the "impartial medical panel" plan to a group of doctors yesterday.
IF it is not illegal to say so, Shaw's "Heartbreak House," as acted last evening at the Billy Rose Theatre, is only moderately interesting.

The recent letter from Edward N. Perkins raises the pertinent question -- "Why should wages necessarily go up every time a wage contract expires?" Another pertinent question is, Why should employes of public utilities and other essential industries be allowed the right to strike?

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., hospital-bound for surgery, warned the Democratic city Administration yesterday that there would be "most serious repercussions" in 1960 and 1961 if Harlem's needs were ignored.
HARPERS FERRY, W. Va., Oct. 18 -- The centennial observance of John Brown's raid on Harpers Ferry ended today with prayers and gunfire.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 18 -- In the face of Arab pressures, the French manufacturers of Renault automobiles have stopped supplying parts to the Israeli concern that was assembling the automobiles in Haifa.
The post of executive director of the Committee of American Steamship Lines will be assumed by Tom Killefer, a Washington partner of the California law firm of Lillick, Geary, Wheat, Adams Charles.
The city's Marine and Aviation Commissioner disclosed last night that his department had signed leases for two East River wharf terminals that the City Planning Commission is opposed to building.

DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct 18 -- Harold (Kid) Gore, the new head football coach at Deerfield Academy, was playing for the Massachusetts Aggies in the era of Jim Thorpe and the Carlisle Indians. He replaced Bobby Marr, who had coached the Big Green for seven years, last summer.

The first of nine volumes reporting on the past, present and future of the New York metropolitan region improves the understanding of great changes already accomplished, confirms apprehensions about the central city and states the challenge to government and people for control of the migratory tides of employment, industry, commerce and residence.

Many people in the television industry believe that organized religion has "fallen flat on its face" in its approach to religious programs, a television publication editor said yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany.

A notable defeat of Vassily Smylov a former world chess champion, enabled Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union to increase his lead last night in the world challengers' tournament at Belgrade, according to a report from Yugoslavia.
Shipments of refined copper to domestic fabricators rose to 92,501 tons last month from 90,123 tons in August, the Copper Institute has reported.
The Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., will officially open its nuclear research center at Stony Brook Farm, near Princeton, N. J., today.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 18 -- Severe floods and drought in eastern India are being officially described as a "major disaster."
Work is scheduled to start this week in Fort Pierce, Fla., on a terminal project that its backers hope will make the East Coast city a major Florida port.

Robert E. Barnes, Republican candidate for Borough President of Queens, offered last night to debate both John T. Clancy, the Democratic incumbent, and Mayor Wagner on issues of the campaign "at any time, any place, any forum."
Marian Anderson, the Negro contralto, received yesterday the Rector's Award at St. Philip's Protestant Episcopal Church, 134th Street west of Seventh Avenue.
Gustav Swensson, a correspondent in Moscow for The Associated Press since last November, was forced to leave the Soviet Union last Monday.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams tore through the previously unbeaten Green Bay Packers for a 45-6 victory today before a crowd of 36,174.
" TO be a collector of antiques, you must be a student first." This is Jay Dorf's advice to neophyte anti-quarians who, with the trend toward mixing styles, are becoming more numerous everyday.

OCTOBER is the time when tans turn pallid and sun lamps are dusted off for winter action. Westinghouse has introduced a new kit with an ultraviolet bulb, a holder and a metal reflector. It is designed to start a tan in less than a minute.
The twelfth annual Blue Grass Ball, a dinner dance for the benefit of the New York Travelers Aid Society, will be held on Nov. 17 in the Persian Room of the Plaza.

LIKE actors who fluff their lines during tryouts on the road but are letter perfect for the grand opening, the Giants returned home to the Yankee Stadium yesterday on a glorious afternoon and delivered a smash hit. Only in the early minutes were there uncertainties. That's when the Philadelphia Eagles, the villains in the cast, whirled off to a 7-0 lead.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- In the area that extends from Pernambuco down around Cape Horn and up the West Coast to the Isthmus of Panama, Uruguay is now the South American country best equipped to deal with the important operations of marine salvage. So says Comdr. J. N. Bathurst, a Canadian expert, who had much to do with making it that way.
Last week's successful test of a booster rocket for the Nike-Zeus defensive missile inaugurates a six-month test period that may determine the fate of the Army weapon.
LuCretia Ferre, soprano, made her debut at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.
Cotton prices in the domestic market continued last week to move into firmer ground, with some interruptions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -The plan to establish a base for intermediate-range ballistic missiles in Greece is no longer a matter of active negotiation and probably has been abandoned.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- The United States and the Soviet Union are near agreement on a plan to expand the cultural and scientific exchange program, State Department sources said today.

A new series of historical dramas, entitled "Our American Heritage." made its bow last night with a study of the differences between Thomas Jefferson and Alexander Hamilton that led to the establishment of the two-party system. The program was seen over Channel 4.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 -- Steel shortages were interferring seriously with construction jobs, manufacturing schedules and future plans of steel users last week. Even if steel production should resume quickly, the entire steel distribution and production outlook is bleak -- more so than at any time in modern industrial history.
The prophets and the betting odds, along with a score of favored teams, took one of their worst beatings of a particularly flabbergasting football season on Saturday.
Members of New York Typographical Union 6 yesterday ratified a new two-year contract covering 5,500 workers employed in commercial (job) printing plants in the city.

Industrial production in September, as measured by the monthly index of the Federal Reserve Board, continued to reflect the steel strike and work stoppage in the nonferrous metal mining and manufacturing industries that first made itself felt in the index for August.
Dr. Clarence Dickinson, organist, composer and author, was honored yesterday for his fifty years as organist and choirmaster of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Ninety-first Street.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Oct. 18 -- By far the most spectacular feature of business last week was the turbulent demand for long-neglected Argentine electro stocks. They changed hands in very large volumes. C.I.A. rose from 37 to 44 1/4 and Sodec from 67 1/2 to 77.

United States Senator Jacob K. Javits appealed to the voters of the state yesterday to approve Amendment 4, giving the city permission to go outside its debt limit to borrow up to $500,000,000 for school construction.
The Eastman Kodak Company reported over the weekend a 32 per cent rise in net income for the three months to Sept. 6. Sales rose 12 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The United States is considering expelling a Soviet diplomat in retaliation for the ouster of the security officer of the United States Embassy in Moscow, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- For connoisseur vacationing this fall, follow the lead of William McChesney Martin Jr.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 18 -- The Western, democratic concept of the welfare state is politically and philosophically sound and should be implemented more strongly in this country. Senator Eugene J. McCarthy asserted here today.
MOSCOW, Oct. 18 -- The Soviet Union said today its third lunar rocket had succeeded in photographing the side of the moon hidden from the earth.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 18 -- Several thousand persons gathered at the cemetery of Herrlingen near Ulm today to commemorate the fifteenth anniversary of the death of Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, commander of the German Africa Corps in World War II.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- After a period of unparalleled frenzy and exuberance, the stock market settled down toward the end of last week to a condition of normal buoyancy.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- President Adolfo Lopez Mateos of Mexico ate barbecue beef and beans on a riverbank today with Mr. Truman at the central Texas ranch of Senator Johnson. The ranch is not far from the Alamo, where Mexican army killed everyone in the fort in the Texas-Mexican War in 1836.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -The Administration is poised for swift legal action tomorrow to end the steel strike if the waning hopes of settlement fail.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 18 (Reuters) -- Archbishop Makarios, Greek Cypriote leader, and Dr. Fadil Kutchuk, head of the Cyprus' Turkish community, conferred today amid reports of growing Greek-Turkish strain over the coming inedependence of this British island colony.
Governor Rockefeller has praised a new Puerto Rican Community Self-Help Program here as promising "real progress" in combating juvenile delinquency.
The most important task for laymen today is to rediscover "a sense of direction for America." Dr. Louis Webster Jones, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, declared yesterday.
Five adolescent panelists on yesterday's New York Times Youth Forum discussed "Our Responsibility Toward World Refugees" without reaching any clear conclusion as to what it was.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The steel war is still on but the mutiny in the Waldorf is over.

TROY, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- Ch. Cudhill Kalypso of Harham, a 3-year-old imported wire-haired fox terrier belonging to Mrs. Harold M. Florsheim of Chicago, became best in show tonight in the twenty-sixth event of the Troy Kennel Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- The Washington Redskins fumbled seven times today in bowing to the Pittsburgh Steelers, 27 -- 6. The four bobbles recovered by the Steelers led to three touchdowns and a field goal.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 18 -- After nearly a quarter century of excavations, archaeologists from the American School of Classical Studies at Athens this summer finished clearing three complete sides of the Athenian Agora, the civic, cultural and intellectual center of the ancient Greek city-state.

The site of the proposed $250,000 Protestant international chapel at New York International Airport in Idlewild, Queens, was formally dedicated yesterday. Mayor Wagner and religious leaders attended the ceremony.
Three judges appealed to the public yesterday to support Mayor Wagner's seven - point program to combat juvenile delinquency.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Steel contract bargaining came to a bitter end tonight. A strike-stopping injunction appeared to be the next order of business.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Republican office holders throughout the land have been asked once again for their cooperation in a task no sane politician would refuse -- filling jobs for the 1960 census.

There is a nightmare quality reminiscent of Franz Kafka's most morbid writings in the story of what happened in Moscow last Friday to the security officer of the United States Embassy in Moscow, Russell A. Langelle, A man alights from a bus. He is seized by five unknown persons and hustled off to a strange building. There he is accused of espionage, with faked chemical abracadabra.

This Javanese city is the birthplace of the Afro-Asian bloc, a disorganized group of nations bound neither by ideological, economic nor military ties. Some of its members have no diplomatic relations and others, such as India and Pakistan or Iraq and the United Arab Republic, are in a state of cold war.
Who hates advertising? Not the American people.

MORE and more American children are outfitted each year in clothes from countries whose names they are just beginning to learn to spell. From toddlers to teen-agers, European imports are assuming an increasingly important place in youngsters' wardrobes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Senator Morton said today he expected a Rockefeller-Nixon floor fight for the Presidential nomination at the G. O. P. national convention next year.

DETROIT, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Terry Sawchuk, the goalie, registered his second shutout of the season as the Detroit Red Wings scored a 3-0 victory tonight over the Toronto Maple Leafs. The Wings remained the only unbeaten team in the National Hockey League.
America, a national Catholic weekly, has proposed a common English translation of the Bible for Catholic and Protestant churches.

Trustees and wives of trustees of International House are serving on a committee for a theatre party that will aid the programs of the thirty-five-year-old residence and program center for American and Foreign graduate students.
No home-opener -- and this was their thirty-fifth -- ever was so successful for the New York Football Giants in so many ways as was yesterday's at the Yankee Stadium.

MOSCOW, Oct. 16 -- Pravda printed today a page full of letters it said were among "several thousands" received from ordinary Americans on Premier Khrushchev's visit to the United States. These were said to have applauded the visit and to have apologized for the rude treatment he received on occasion.

Two different high-level conferences between representatives of Pakistan and India are now going forward simultaneously in the two capitals. One group of officials is discussing further adjustment of fiscal and monetary differences between the two countries. The other is making further exploration of ways in which to reduce small tensions and frictions on the common borders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Music critics had a taste of their own medicine this weekend. They heard criticisms of their reviews delivered in the unsparing terms they often use themselves in criticizing musicians.

POCANTICO HILLS, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- A seafaring man, his face weathered by salt spray and many a harsh Norwegian winter, stood today amid the gently rolling countryside here, now in splendor with the gold and russet hues of autumn.
FORMER President Harry S. Truman appeared on Jack Benny's show last night over Channel 2; it was a period of fun and charm.
Two 17-year-old youths who were on week-end passes from an institution for delinquents were held in $2,500 bail each yesterday on charges of attacking two brothers in the Bronx Saturday night.
TOKYO, Oct. 18 -- A powerful right-wing faction broke away from the Japan Socialist party today in a long-simmering rebellion against the party's domination by pro-Communist labor groups.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 18 -Harry S. Truman, speaking as a Baptist at a Methodist church here today, advised Americans to "make it your business to find out what the Bible says about government." The former President told more than 600 Methodists at the Elmwood Methodist Church here that the Constitution of the United States and the Declaration of Independence were both based on the Bible.
Dore Schary, writer and theatrical producer, was saluted last night for courage in politics by Paul M. Butler, the Democratic National Chairman.

TRENTON, Oct. 18 -- Sir Pierson Dixon, chief British delegate to the United Nations, said tonight that solutions of the world's "overridingly important problems" have to be sought outside the United Nations in "face-to-face" meetings among the top world leaders.
Guiomar Novaes is not only a magnificent pianist but she is also a master of the art of giving piano recitals.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- The sixteenth American Assembly agreed here today that the best bar to communism in the Western Hemisphere was to help Latin Americans develop their countries and raise their living standards.
Defense Minister V. K. Krishna Menon of India accused Communist China last night of adopting an aggressive and intolerant attitude.
PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Investments in France from abroad, except those from Italy and the dollar zone, have increased since the turn of the year.

Dr. Moshe Prywes, Associate Dean of the Hebrew University-Hadassah Medical School of Jerusalem, last night deplored the fact that Israel's health and medical programs could not be applied at the present to neighboring Arab countries.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 18 -- Greater attention will be given to the "human side" of urban renewal, local housing and redevelopment officials agreed today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- A draft resolution calling for expansion of the Security Council is expected to be introduced here tomorrow by a large group of Asian and African nations.

May a British visitor have the hospitality of your columns to endorse the most interesting contribution concerning Eastern Germany by Sydney Gruson which you published Oct. 12. It is the first sensible and constructive writing on this subject that I have seen.

The complexities of modern' day leasing, which involves long-term contracts w, th aggregate rentals running into millions of dollars, have changed the broker's job from a penciland-paper operation to a sliderule task.
When you walk into a department store, bank or warehouse these days, there is an increasingly good chance that an electronic eye is watching you.
The spectacular growth of suburban areas here has been achieved in great part at the expense of New York and the other older cities they surround, a Harvard-directed survey reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has decided to make another attempt to send a payload to the moon.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Frank Cousins, the most powerful of Britain's trade union leaders, assailed today those Labor party members who want to trim their sails to catch the prevailing political wind.

NANUET, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- A car that took off without its driver wove through heavy traffic today and crashed into another car that was stopped for a red light. The owner of the runaway car suffered cuts trying to catch it.
It's going to cost more to clean the windows of the United Nations, the Empire State Building and other large office structures around town.

Five United States Navy carriers are en route to Japan, in tow. Three of them fought against the Japanese in the Pacific. Two served against the Nazis in the North Atlantic. They are now on their last mission. They have been sold for scrap, needed by the rebuilding Japanese steel industry.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- A jobless ex-convict, fleeing the police at speeds up to 100 miles an hour in a stolen car, lost control of the vehicle today and crashed into a group of thirty children waiting for a school bus, killing three and critically injuring a fourth.
The counsel to the state's Little Hoover Commission confirmed yesterday that the commission had begun a study of the organization of the office of Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- The marine section of the National Safety Council opened its most extensive annual meeting here today since its formation forty-two years ago.

The plan for a permanent New York Shakespeare Festival in Central Park refuses to die. In the words of Robert W. Dowling, chairman of the citizens' committee that has been working on the project, the idea is to have a "smoothly coordinated and well-planned Shakespeare Festival each year which will rise above personal conflicts and individual considerations.

We of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State agree with Arthur G. Draper, whose letter appeared in your issue of Oct. 12, that there should be "wise use" of our natural resources. But we do not agree that a Northway, over the proposed route through the Adirondack Mountain area, would constitute "wise use" of such resources.
There are some ceremonies that the Mayor of New York must find rather tiresome -- like staging two ceremonies in the same month for new buses that turn out to be identical.

EDGEWATER, N. J., Oct. 19 -- The arrival of the freighter Alma of the Cunard Lines at the Edgewater Terminal Corporation's pier here this morning marked the resumption of overseas shipping at the old Ford assembly plant after a four-teen-year lapse.

Bobby Fischer, facing Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union for the fourth time in the world challengers' chess tournament at Belgrade, drew a well-played game in thirty moves at Belgrade last night, according to a report from Yugoslavia.
The Liberal party announced yesterday that it supported the school bond amendment. This would authorize New York City to borrow $500,000,000 outside its debt limit for school construction.

Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, last night strongly attacked proposals that would require recipients of public assistance to live in their communities a certain period of time before being eligible for relief.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 19 -- President Sukarno's new Government is facing a barrage of criticism on both domestic and foreign policy issues.

" The Communist Persuasion," a description of a method by which the Chinese Communists rose to power, will be published Thursday by P. J. Kennedy. The author is Eleutherius Winance, a Benedictine missionary and university professor in China for more than sixteen years, four of them under Red rule.
Nelson Fox, the Chicago White Sox' fiery little second baseman, was an overwhelming choice yesterday as United Press International's 1959 American League player of the year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A majority of the Senate Small Business Committee urged today a Justice Department investigation of the "dangerous monopoly" it said was developing in the scrap steel industry.

Three specialists in psychosomatic medicine said yesterday that distress around the heart was likely to indicate emotional stress rather than heart disease. However, they agreed that if heart disease were present, the emotional stress could cause sudden death.
ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- The State Education Commissioner said tonight that it was up to Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature to open up new sources of revenue for hard-pressed local school systems.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Davey Moore, the world featherweight champion, today was rated a 3-1 favorite over the British champion, Bobby Neill, in their non-title fight at Wembley Stadium tomorrow night.
Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenue for the nine and twelve months ended on Sept. 30. Net income for both periods also were above the 1958 levels.
KARONGA, Nyasaland, Oct. 19 -- Flaz Msopole, a leader of the African National Congress, went on trial today on charges of rioting, cattle theft and intimidation.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Dr. Neal said at the Conference on Distribution that a split in Europe between the common market nations and those outside, which he called the "outer seven," was dangerous from the standpoint of this country's economic competition with the Communist world.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) Ten scientists and laymen have been appointed to a special committee to study the Federal Government's participation in medical research.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- The Right Rev. Angus Dun, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Washington, said here today that he saw little likelihood that a Roman Catholic would be nominated for the Presidency in 1960.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- A Church of England committee recommended today that attempted suicide no longer be considered a crime in Britain.
Many of the scientific, engineering and technical problems of providing the nation with a defense against ballistic missiles are beyond the frontiers of present knowledge.

If present plans of the Erie Railroad and the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad to merge are approved, the consolidated company will abandon about ninety-five miles of Erie's present trackage and eight and one-half miles of Lackawanna track.

Thomas Scherman opened the Little Orchestra Society's thirteenth season last night at Town Hall. The program's chief feature was Mr. Scherman's fifty-seven-minute concert version of Haydn's comic opera, "The Apothecary."
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19 -- A little knot of steel strikers glowered tonight at a headline announcing that President Eisenhower had moved to obtain an eighty-day injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19 -- That amorphous but indisputably variegated community called Hollywood is showing signs of recovery from an allergy to public affairs acquired during more than a decade's hue and cry against left-wing leanings.

%Varning Note: Installment loan delinquencies at banks increased in August, the first full i month of the steel strike. The American Bankers Association said yesterday, in announcing the increase, said it wa the first since February.

NICE, France, Oct. 19 -- Mme. Claude Kogan left here by air Aug. 9 on the first leg of the journey to The Himalaya, to Cho Oyu, the sixth highest mountain on earth. Two members of the expedition she was to lead had already gone by boat from Marseilles to shepherd three tons of equipment to India and from there overland to Nepal.

OTTAWA, Oct. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Four major oil companies bid a total of $1,239,500 for oil and gas exploration rights near the boundary of British Columbia and the Northwest Territories, it was announced today.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19 -- Most big steel producers in this area estimated it will take three to five weeks to reach 90 per cent of production.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Russell A. Langelle said here tonight he had "pretty rough treatment" in the incident that led to his expulsion from the Soviet Union.
WARSAW, Oct. 19 -- The Polish Government is facing one of its most important psychological tests since the upheaval of 1956.
ZELIENOPLE, Pa., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Mr. Webster's parents expressed shock and amazement today that he was renouncing his citizenship.
LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- One of Britain's oldest fox hunts put the aristocratic sport of riding to hounds on the installment plan today.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 19 -- Indications are that it will take two or three weeks for Youngstown district steel producers to approach normal operations.

The breakdown of negotiations between the steel companies and the union has been a calamity for free collective bargaining in this country. Never before has a situation given more encouragement to those who believe in direct Government intervention to end strikes which damage the entire nation's economy.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 19 -- This village's experimental shopping mall was termed successful today by enthusiastic merchants and the Hempstead Chamber of Commerce.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 19 -- High in the Connecticut hills behind thick trees is a large restaurant that once catered to the rich. But two years ago its owner went bankrupt, and left a legacy of empty glasses, dusty dance floors and a piano nobody plays.

This is my first letter to the editor of any newspaper. I feel impelled to write it because on Tuesday afternoon, Oct. 20, I am attending the funeral of the most selfless man I have ever known, Gen. George Catlett Marshall.

Antonino Rocca and Miguel Perez, heroes, defeated the Tolas brothers, villains, in the feature tag-team wrestling exhibition last night at Madison Square Garden. The Latin-American duo was ahead, one fall to none, when the 11 P.M. curfew struck.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today its approval of a merger of five affiliated companies of Atlas Corporation, a New York investment company.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Representative Richard M. Simpson of Pennsylvania predicted tonight that 1960 would be "the greatest Republican year in history."
The coldest weather in six months brought a wintry chill to the city yesterday. It was expected to lay a coating of frost in some suburban areas this morning.

TO men inside and outside the world of sport, George Stanley Halas, owner-coach of the Chicago Bears, is many things. Halas, the chairman of the National Football League's expansion committee, may be the wealthiest coach who ever diagnosed or diagrammed a play.
It took twelve policemen to quell a disturbance yesterday in one of the city s schools for girls in lower Manhattan.
PARIS, Oct. 19 -- A Gaullist leader confirmed tonight reports that Right-wing forces in Algiers and Paris had plotted to overthrow the Government of Premier Michel Debre.
The National Labor Relations Board began hearings yesterday on a petition by a local of the teamsters union for a representation election among taxicab drivers in seventy-two companies here.
MOSCOW, Oct. 19 -- Three United States Senators left the Soviet Union today with the "regrettable" conclusion that it was assuming world leadership in the development of hydroelectric power.

A continued improvement in earnings during the third quarter pushed profits of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company for the first nine months of the year to a new high, company officials reported yesterday.
Good luck and added experience have helped Yale's football team remain undefeated, untied and unscored upon this season, said Jordan Olivar, the Eli coach, yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 19 -- An article highly critical of Communist China was published today in The Statesman of New Delhi. It told of the entire Chinese population's having been pressed into a "vast army" wearing blue uniforms.

Born Rich of the Poltex Stable, a 6-year-old mare with an unpretentious record, was so well regarded by the fans at Aqueduct yesterday that they made her the favorite in the feature event. The race, a mile-and-an-eighth race called the Sagaponack, turned out to be formful, for Born Rich, guided by Bob Ussery, scored a neck victory over the King Ranch's Chistosa.
MONTREAL, Oct. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Jean Marie, chairman of the French Line, said here Saturday that his company was thinking of starting a Montreal-Continental passenger liner service.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Laotian Government circles are showing growing resentment at what they term vexatious control of aid funds by American officials.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Supreme Court was chided by two of its members today for taking time away from more important matters to worry about injured railroad workers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- David Ormsby-Gore, British Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, declared today that the Western and Soviet positions on disarmament had come closer together on important points.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art is planning to build a new $2,000,000 library with twice the book capacity of its present one.
UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 19 -- New evidence has turned up in Operation Hawk Watch here to indicate that the birds may be unexpectedly choosy about their migratory routes.

" Art Carney Meets Peter and the Wolf," a musical fable first televised last November, will be repeated by tape recording over the American Broadcasting Company network on Nov. 29 from 5 to 6 P.M.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- The prosecution in the Malcolm White murder trial narrowed substantially today the time the defense estimated Alfred F. Dugan could have lived after he had been fatally shot by the Chester manufacturer.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The Duke of Edinburgh formally opened a new 2,000,000 ($5,600,000) ship-testing laboratory at Feltham, Middlesex, today.

In a dressing room under the Downing Stadium grandstand last Sunday, Bill Krywicki, the Cardinal Hayes football coach, taped the ankles of his starting team. He did it with the methodical ease of a man who had unwound miles of adhesive.
MERRICK, L. I., Oct. 19 -- A young mother killed her two daughters here today by placing them in a food freezer. She then hanged herself from an attic beam.

MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Investigators established today that cyanide poison killed Stepan Bandera, anti-Communist guerrilla chief from the Ukraine. The mystery that surrounded his life continued in death.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Philadelphia's Charley Scott scored a knockout in twenty-eight seconds of the ninth round over his neighborhood rival, Garnet (Sugar) Hart, tonight in a bruising battle of top-ranking welterweights.
Senator John M. Butler returned here yesterday aboard the liner United States from a one-month fact-finding trip during which he visited eleven European shipyards.
Althea Gibson, one-time queen of the tennis world, signed a "near $100,000" professional contract here yesterday to make a cross-country tour with Karol Fageros of Miami.

The One William Street Fund, Inc., reported yesterday a gain of $25,000,000 in net assets in the twelve months ended on Sept. 30. The latest figure, however, was $11,700,000 below that on June 30.

Senator Jacob K. Javits urged last night that the Government expand its program of personnel training, research and demonstration projects to increase the rate at which the handicapped are rehabilitated.
Helen Hayes has agreed to star in a two-hour drama for station WNTA-TV's "The Play of the Week," the taped program that presents each play in the series for a week.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 20 -- Two Yale alumni have been elected Fellows of the Yale Corporation, the university's governing board of trustees. Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale, announced the choices today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -El Salvador proposed today postponement until 1960 of current efforts to expand the membership of the Security Council and other United Nations organs. The proposal was made in a resolution to be taken up tomorrow by the General Assembly's Special Political Committee.

Tight money is causing the traditionally independent commercial finance companies to cooperate in the handling of accounts that are too large for the average concern to manage alone, it was indicated yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- The United States told the General Assembly today not to be swayed by "arguments of intimidation" from thorough consideration of charges that Communist China had violated human rights in Tibet.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 20 -Communist Chinese survey parties have crossed into Bhutan and Sikkim, according to reports reaching the West Bengal State government.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 20 (UPI) -- The Soviet Embassy in Washington today informed Laurel officials that two Soviet Union thoroughbreds would be flown from West Berlin to the United States on Oct. 28 to compete in the $100,000 Washington D. C. International on Nov. 11.

BUFFALO, Oct. 20 -- The American Psychiatric Association reported today that 30 per cent of all patients in mental hospitals were more than 65 years old. A leading psychiatrist declared that many of the older persons did not belong in such institutions and should be cared for by their families.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Government's leading space and missile officials will meet with President Eisenhower at the White House tomorrow morning.
Clashing ambitions may upset the Moscow-Peiping alliance but probably only in the far future, Under Secretary of State Robert Murphy said here last night.
The West German Government will decide in a month whether it will offer a $140,000,000 guarantee in the construction of two large trans-Atlantic liners.
Two large-sized illustrated volumes about philosophy and philosophers will be published six days apart next month.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the short interest on Oct. 15 was 3,421,641 shares, 335,940 above the 3,085,701 on Sept. 15. The increase was the largest since May, 1958, when there was a rise of more than 700,000 shares.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 20 -- An effective live virus vaccine to control influenza has been developed in the Soviet Union, a Russian scientist reported here tonight.
Industry and labor spokesmen in contract talks involving 13,000 milk drivers and 311 dairies denied yesterday that there had been any talk of a strike.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -General of the Army George Catlett Marshall was buried in Arlington National Cemetery today after simple funeral rites -- among the simplest ever conducted for a man of his rank and prestige.
LITTLE ROCK, Oct. 20 -- The Broadmoor Baptist Church, of which the key. Wesley Pruden a segregationist, is pastor, was expelled last night from the Pulaski County (Southern) Baptist Association.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- A Security Council subcommittee of inquiry has found evidence that the Communist Government of North Vietnam has supplied a certain amount of small arms and uniforms to the Communist rebels in Laos.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Oct. 20 -- Joseph P. Pollard has given $4,000 to the town of Litchfield, Me., and today he explained why.

Harry Canelstein, New York and Florida realty investor, has sold the shopping center at 220-02 to 220-16 Horace Harding Boulevard at Springfield Boulevard in Bayside, Queens. The Edison Savings Bank, the buyer, plans to open a branch office there.
Sharp rebukes were given by the Board of Education to Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa and the Kings County grand jury yesterday.

METUCHEN, N. J., Oct. 20 -- Emery Thomas of Forest Hill and Otto Greiner of Knickerbocker teamed for a seven-under-par 65 at the Metuchen Country Club today and won the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association best-ball championship with a 133.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Both defense and prosecution rested their cases unexpectedly today in the trial of Malcolm R. White, Chester manufacturer, on first-degree murder charge.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Britain's television companies, having already experienced the scandal and investigation of a rigged television quiz show, now work under stern self-regulatory measures.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 20 -- Mrs. Robert E. Webster, whose husband announced in Moscow that he was taking steps to renounce his American citizenship for life behind the Iron Curtain, is ready to forgive everything but another woman.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 -- The American trucking industry was urged by Robert F. Kennedy today to adopt a code of ethics barring side deals with Teamster Union officials.

The United Hospital Fund maintains a staff of professional consultants who conduct volunteer training courses, plan forums and institutes and coordinate hospitals auxiliary services in city-wide planning The City Hospital Visiting Committee also is an integral part of the fund, with volunteer visitors who inspect regularly in municipal hospitals and report to the Department of Hospitals on problems and conditions.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- The explosive population growth in many parts of the world was examined here today in the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the General Assembly.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- The Protestant Episcopal Church will build a seminary in San Juan, P. R., to train priests for work in Latin America, it was announced here today. To be called the Episcopal Theological Seminary of the Caribbean, it is scheduled to be opened in the fall of 1961.

Blood will be given today at New York Typographical Union No. 6, at 62 West Fourteenth Street, for the New York Regional Red Cross program.
A merger-bound railroad president wants other carriers to get on the consolidation route.
A Syracuse attack that rolled up 138 points in four winning games owes much of its sharp edge to what Coach Ben Schwartzwalder describes as a "scissors play."
I wonder how many of your readers, like myself, have had their egos resuscitated by the TV quiz show disclosures?
A prompt and strong effort by the apparel industry to stem imports from countries where wages are low was urged yesterday by Donald Cooper, executive vice president of the Imperial Shirt Company.
A report that the European potato crop would be less than expected touched off heavy buying yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
NOT that it is news, but Julie Harris is a charming actress.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover said today that the damage discovered aboard the Nautilus would not result in any delay in returning the submarine to sea after overhaul.

MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP, N. J. Oct. 20 -- A Hunt Dance at the Rumson Country Club will follow the twenty-ninth annual five-race hunt meet of the Monmouth Hunt Racing Association on Saturday. The hunt will be held on the Woodland Farm Estate of Amory L. Haskell.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP) -Prices for grain futures moved higher in fairly active dealings on the Board of Trade today.
