Steel and strikes are synonymous in recent American industrial history.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- David I. Mackie, chairman of the Eastern Railroads Presidents Committee, served notice on unions today that the railroads were out to end featherbedding.
Death from cancer may be almost wholly eliminated within seventy-five years, a speaker yesterday told a seventy-fifth anniversary observance at Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- French official circles regarded today with a notable lack of enthusiasm but without overt opposition United States proposals for a meeting of Western heads of government in Paris in the immediate future.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 20 -- Brazil won a second international jumping event tonight when Maj. Renyldo Ferreira captured the Pennsylvania Police Trophy at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show. The competition required one rider to complete a course of ten obstacles twice with a different mount each time.

Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan decided yesterday that the members of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers should express their views on amendments to a consent decree by a referendum.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following films as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown Friday through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 20 -Juvenile delinquency is rising in Puerto Rico. The increase was partly attributed, today to teen-age migrants who return, having picked up anti-social habits in New York.
LONDON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A too-pretty bull plaintively-tossed his horns at millions of Britons tonight in an eleventh-hour appeal against losing his head.

Paul Keres of the Soviet Union, second in the challengers' chess tournament in Belgrade, defeated the United States champion, Bobby Fischer, last night in the twenty-third round, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- C. Leo DeOrsey, a former director of the Washington Senators, said tonight that a "certain" American League club owner would ask permission to move his franchise to the West Coast in 1961.
Sara (Toothpick) Jones, sidearming workhorse of the San Francisco Giants, was named the National League's pitcher of the year yesterday by United Press International.
A new, self-policing steamship conference system was described here yesterday at a special House Antitrust subcommittee hearing on the ocean freight industry.

Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for nine and twelve months ended on Sept. 30. Sales of electricity in the first nine months rose 11 per cent to 8,480,615,710, and gas sales of 563,425,971 therms were 9 per cent above the 1958 level.

A TOUR of mid-Manhattan executive offices decorated by eight designers will be held tomorrow, beginning at 11 A. M. All the offices will be on view through 4:30 P. M., except those in the Seagram Building. These can be seen only at 1 and 4 P. M.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 20 -- A radical departure from the traditional method of shifting theatrical scenery was displayed here today at the Hofstra College Playhouse.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 20 -- A proposal by the Connecticut Light and Power Company to double the capacity of its uncompleted $15,000,000 harbor generating plant here was opposed today by both the city and residents of the area.

Formation of a new holding company, the Whitney Communications Corporation, to control and hold the various publishing and broadcasting interests of John Hay Whitney. United States Ambassador to Britain, was announced yesterday.

Halsey, Stuart Co. Inc., and associates are offering today $70,000,000 of Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company 35-year 5 1/2 per cent debentures at 102.36, to yield 5.35 per cent. The debentures are to be redeemable at optional prices ranging from 108.36 per cent to par.

The appointment of Robert K. Farrand as a vice president of the Curtis Publishing Company, was announced yesterday by Robert E. MacNeal, president. Mr. Farrand has been director of public relations for the company since last May.

On behalf of some twenty voluntary agencies may I offer heartfelt commendation for the excellent and timely article by Seymour Topping (Oct. 12) regarding the fine adjustment made by displaced persons who came here eleven years ago.

HOUSTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Branch Rickey today said the three remaining franchises of the new Continental Baseball League would be awarded to three of the following cities: Montreal, Buffalo, Atlanta and Dallas-Fort Worth.

New England's smaller independent colleges, which play football with great zest and considerable skill on the purest level of amateurism, will present two of their season's prime offerings on Saturday.

Net income of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad plummeted last month to about $231,000 from $1,653,000 in September of last year, Howard E. Simpson, president, told directors of the road at their regular monthly meeting here in New York yesterday.

I should like to advance a semantic proposal in the interest of a gradual thaw in the cold war -- namely, that we abandon the words "communism" and "capitalism" to describe current economic systems. Neither word now means what Karl Marx or David Ricardo meant.
The International Longshoremen's Association asked for more time yesterday to study a set of principles suggested by waterfront employers in connection with automation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Some French circles here are quietly spreading the idea that it would be well to put off debate on Algeria -- tentatively scheduled for the latter half of next month -- until the very end of the General Assembly session.

Ch. Bettina's Kow-Kow, a Pekingese who will be 3 years old next month, became best in show yesterday in the all-toy event of the Progressive Dog Club. The competition was at The Livingston in Brooklyn.
THE aim of Yehudi Menuhin and his sister, Hephzibah, was to make music at Carnegie Hall last night, but their reunion as a violin-piano sonata team was also a sentimental journey into the past.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 21 -- Two off-Madison Avenue advertising men chided the industry today for its failure to reflect reality in ads and for its reliance on operation by committees.
A power failure on a Port Washington-bound train in a tunnel under the East River delayed 7,000 Long Island Rail Road commuters last night. Thirteen trains were affected.
A British realty concern has bought a one-half interest in Grand Central City, New York's most ambitious postwar office building project, for $25,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -The Supreme Court granted a stay of execution today to Caryl Chessman, California kidnapper -rapist, who has been in a death cell more than eleven years.
Reports of minor political disturbances in Cuba touched off buying in world sugar dealings yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

The First Boston Corporation and White, Weld Co. and associates are offering $8,000,000 in Western Massachusetts Electric Company 5 3/8 per cent first mortgage bonds, series D, due Oct. 1, 1989. The bonds are being offered at 101,875 to yield about 5.25 per cent.
An offer by city, state and Federal mediators to assist in milk industry negotiations in the metropolitan area was refused yesterday by five teamster locals.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Government was reported today to have altered its thinking about the timing of a summit meeting following President de Gaulle's disclosure that he prefers that such a gathering be held next spring.
The Di Carlo bill, which aims to increase the number of trees on our city streets, is scheduled for a hearing before the City Council on Oct. 22.

It is no crime to use school children to promote the $500,000,000 school bond issue, District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Brooklyn said yesterday. But, he added, whether the practice is morally right "is another question."

Elia Kazan stage and film director, was named yesterday as Robert Whitehead's associate in the development and direction of the repertory theatre to be established at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. Mr. Whitehead is the center's consultant on drama.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- A contestant who won $40,000 in prizes on a current nationally televised television quiz show said today that he had been told the limit of bids to make on merchandise and other prizes offered on the program.
The biggest organizing drive of American maritime unions formally began yesterday.
Experts in the fields of art and architecture had extravagant praise yesterday for the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum as an architectural structure of historic importance.

At 7:30 yesterday morning Bob McCool, Columbia's first-string center, stepped out of blue pajamas and into khaki trousers, sports shirt, sweater and three-button jacket. He washed his face quickly. He was ready to start another sixteen-and-a-half-hour day in his life as an Ivy League football player.

The new and controversial Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on upper Fifth Avenue was officially dedicated yesterday.

The Development Loan Fund is introducing "a major policy innovation," it has just announced. Fordham freshmen have come up with an answer to one of the oldest of political puzzles -- what happens to campaign buttons when the campaign ends?

AN attractive and beautifully dressed woman entered the library of the Alfred A. Knopf offices. She had come to discuss her new cookbook "Cook, My Darling Daughter," (Knopf, $4.95), published earlier this week.

Two new films open at first-run theatres today.
Governor Rockefeller praised the Young Women's Christian Association of New York yesterday for "helping our young people to lead clean and wholesome lives."

QUOGUE, L. I., Oct. 21 -- The busiest land bird banding station on the East Coast at the peak of the fall migration is on a narrow barrier beach near here.

THE brawling splendor of a great tradition lights Mary McCarthy's new book, "The Stones of Florence."* No one has ever written about the town with quite her combination of fierce partisanship and measured detachment. Her pages make many other books on Florence seem either underdone or overdrawn. And her triumph is that she keeps these ancient occupational hazards of writing about Florence in balance.

A committee drawn from seven Connecticut College alumnae clubs in the metropolitan area is planning a luncheon to mark the fiftieth anniversary of the college. The fete will take place at the Biltmore on Nov. 18.

Chemicals now account for about 45 per cent of the earnings of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation, John E. Bierwirth, chairman, disclosed yesterday. The company started in the chemical business in 1950.

Inventories of all major petroleum products moved upward in the nation last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Production of crude oil and the rate of refinery operations also rose, the report said.

An international triangular senior team golf match, the first to be staged in this country since 1936, will be held at the Pine Valley Golf Club, Clementon, N. J., Nov. 5-6.

The net income of the American Tobacco Company reached a high for the third quarter and for the first nine months of this year, it was announced yesterday by Paul M. Hahn, president. The quarter ended on Sept. 30 was the third consecutive period in which net income set a record for the quarter.
GIOVANNA FERRAGAMO looks like an average bright young girl. But, being her father's daughter, she is far from average. At 16, she has embarked on a career as a designer of distinctive sportswear.
"TAKE A GOOD LOOK," the panel show that made its debut over Channel 7 last night, had Ernie Kovacs as its star.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- For the last three days George Cochran Doub has been in his element. There is nothing he would rather do than stand in a courtroom and argue a great case for the United States Government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) --Secrecy is a secret in the Agriculture Department.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- The Soviet Union criticized the United Nations today for failure to use Soviet experts in under-developed areas.

The special House Antitrust subcommittee investigating the steamship industry will turn over to the Department of Justice as possible shipping law violations some thirty incidents it has uncovered during the first two weeks of its inquiry.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -Pending further studies, the Army has deferred plans to supply troops with food preserved by radiation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild today renewed an appeal to the Justice Department to investigate the guild's charges of a deal between the Hearst and Scripps-Howard organizations to divide their newspaper markets.

Senator John F. Kennedy and Governor Rockefeller, who could become rival Presidential candidates in 1960, both declared last night that the United States must improve its example of freedom at work before the world.
Harry Canelstein has moved his real estate investment office from Kew Gardens to 192-15 Union Turnpike, Flushing, Queens.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Peru will make its debut in the Washington, D. C., International horse race Nov. 11 with today's entry of Col. C. J. Tippett's Lightning.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Clemson crushed South Carolina's football team, 27-0, today to retain its lead in the Atlantic Coast Conference. This game closed the rivals' 63-year-old State Fair week series.

PARIS, Oct. 22 (AP) -President Charles de Gaulle and a glittering political, society and theatrical audience showed up last night for a peek at Andre Malraux' revolution in the French national theatres.
The Public Service Commission ended hearings yesterday on the "full crew" provisions of the state's railroad law.
The American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday that its reporting newspapers used a record of 448,999 tons of newsprint in September, or 8.7 per cent more than in the 1958 month.

Dmitri Shostakovich and four other Russian composers arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 11:15 o'clock last night from Amsterdam to begin a month's tour of appearances with leading American symphonic orchestras.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 22 -- Space exploration and missile development will require "something more" than the $530,300,000 he requested of Congress for the current fiscal year, President Eisenhower said today.

Check turnover in the twentysix major cities in the nation in the week ended last Wednesday soared to $28,035,892,000 for the second best weekly level in history. Dun bradstreet reported yesterday. The latest level, slightly below the record figure of $28,591,599,000 set in the week ended on June 18, 1958, was 33.9 per cent above the S20,939,183,000 of a week before, and 14.9 per cent higher than the 1958 figure of $24,398,657,000.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- The voters in this residential city were in sharp disagreement today on whether to hire a fulltime city manager or continue under a part-time, nonsalaried Mayor and Common Council.
ALBANY, Calif., Oct. 22 (UPI) -- Frederick Rose, a Panamanian jockey, underwent brain surgery today after being thrown from Hy-Gain in the first race at Golden Gate Fields.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 22 -One hundred four Americans who have driven 7,500 miles from Capetown, South Africa, to Nairobi since July 14 in a caravan of forty-one house trailers arrived here today. They plan to reach Cairo by Christmas.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 22 -A 6-year-old girl whose parents forbade a blood transfusion on religious grounds died here today from injuries suffered in a highway accident.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 22 -- Right Time, winner of the Jubilee Stake on Oct. 9, is a 5-to-2 favorite to repeat in the $25,000 Invitational Governor's Cup for 3-year-old pacers at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night. Johnny Patterson is slated to drive the favorite from the No. 2 post position.

With sales running 18 per cent ahead of last year's, the Royal Crown Cola Company, Columbus, Ga., will have earnings of about $1.50 a share this year, compared with $1.19 last year, Wilbur H. Glenn, president, predicted yesterday.
In preparing for the Columbia game at Baker Field tomorrow, the Holy Cross football squad has been emphasizing pass defense in practice.

Average member bank borrowings dropped $229,000,000 to $819,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Average excess reserves increased $14,000,000 to $489,000,000 from a revised figure a week ago.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and a group of investment bankers will offer today $12,000,000 of Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation first mortgage bonds series S due in 1989. The bonds carry a 5 per cent interest coupon and, selling at 100.777 per cent, will yield 4.95 per cent. The bonds are not refundable at a lower cost before Oct. 15, 1964.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The British Government believes a Western summit meeting is necessary to reconcile "alarming" differences over the timing and character of the coming conference with the Soviet Union, a highly qualified source said tonight.

York Associates bought the one-story taxpayer containing twelve stores and bowling alleys at Flatbush Avenue, Park Place and Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn. The building is assessed at $265,000. It was sold by Flora Willson through Raymond R. Stetson of Tutino Co. and William J. Ryan of the Harrison Black Corporation, brokers.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 22 -An air of tension prevailed in Nicosia today following the action by Archbishop Makarios, Greek Cypriote leader, in suspending talks with the Turks on a constitution. The new republic of Cyprus is due to be proclaimed in February, and Makarios heads the provisional cabinet preparing the changeover.

ALBANY, Oct. 22 (AP) -Governor Rockefeller said today that $81,500 in additional state funds would be allocated to continue a special investigation into official misconduct in Republicancontrolled Suffolk County.

Mayor Wagner has asked chambers of commerce and other business and tirade organizations in 142 upstate areas to support Amendment 4 on the ballot Nov. 3. The amendment would give the city permission to borrow up to $500,000,000 outside its debt limit for school construction.
United States policy in Latin America was assayed last night by former President Galo Plaza of Ecuador. He found elements both approved and disapproved by the twenty other American Republics.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Brook Mandore, the British bull with a face like a cow, may eventually find a home in the United States.
Despite an intimation earlier this week that he might be replaced if his play didn't improve, Lorne (Gump) Worsley will remain as goalie of the victory-starved New York Rangers.
The bond market generally remained strong yesterday. Enough irregularity appeared among Treasury securities, however, to administer a check to the upward surge of recent trading sessions.

DETROIT, Oct. 22 (UPI) -The Detroit Red Wings fired three last-period goals tonight, two of them on an open net, to score a 4-1 victory over the Boston Bruins. The triumph stretched their unbeaten string to six games in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 ( UPI) -The Department of Agriculture announced today an increase from 3.25 to 4 per cent a year in the interest rate paid by the Government to banks and other lenders who finance Federal farm price support loans.

Mortimer H. Lyons, realty operator, has bought the threestory garden apartment building at 133 to 141 Terrace Avenue, Hempstead, L. I., for cash over mortgages amounting to $124,000. The property, 100 by 100 feet, contains thirty apartments.

The Presbyterian Hospital will receive a legacy of $1,000,000 and several other charitable organizations will get large sums under the will of Dunlevy Milbank, philanthropist. The document was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

Sun Dog of the Sanford Stud Farm won the fifty-ninth running of the Grand National Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The race was contested over the grueling distance of three miles, and of the nine horses entered, eight succeeded in negotiating the course.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The British Ryder Cup golf team members today teamed with three amateur partners each in a pro-amateur tournament at Atlantic City Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The median income of families rose slightly last year despite the recession, but higher living costs ate up the gain.
The nation's steel strike has caused the Republic Steel Corporation to lose money "at a perfectly horrible rate," Charles M. White, chairman, said last night.
Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney imposed a sentence on a tenement agent yesterday that, in effect, transferred to the probation department the enforcement of the multiple dwelling law in the building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -Does the Constitution permit civilian employes and dependents of the armed forces overseas to be tried by courtmartial?

THE most intriguing game on tomorrow's football calendar in the effete East unquestionably is that between Navy and Penn at Franklin Field. It's appealing because it arouses curiosity. An unbeaten Quaker contingent that may be heading dreamily toward the Ivy League championship will be rudely exposed to the facts of life.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 22 -President Eisenhower still thinks there should be an East-West summit conference before the end of the year.
The National Maritime Union was certified by the National Labor Relations Board yesterday as the collective bargaining representative for the unlicensed foreign crew of the cable vessel All America.
CHILDHOOD preferences condition adult selections of furnishings for the home, according to Richard Gump, president of Gump's of San Francisco.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 22 -- Frank Chapot of the United States Equestrian Team gained the Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower Trophy for international jumping at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight. The victory was the second for the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Senate Democratic leader, ordered a preliminary Congressional inquiry today into the national space program. The program, he said, seems to lack "coordinated authority" and "a driver."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- Bill Rigney today signed to manage the San Francisco Giants again next season. The signing ended speculation that he was finished because of his team's collapse in the final stages of the National League race last month.

WITH strong liberal convictions, he is an implacable foe of racial discrimination. ... Was instrumental in shaping many of the strongest attacks made by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People against segregation in education and public service. . . .

Reports of continued political unrest in Cuba spurred buying of world sugar futures yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
A standard set of emergency signals has been adopted by the New York State Civil Defense Commission for visual communications between distressed parties and passing aircraft.
When Billy Hunter, a rising young heavyweight from Detroit, steps into the Madison Square Garden ring tonight to face Tony Anthony, he will be an even choice to win.
PARIS, Oct. 22 -- The Renault auto company said today that it had canceled its car assembly contract with Kaiser-Fraser of Israel for purely commercial reasons.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 22 (Reuters) -- If Danes want to know what old Copenhagen looked like, they soon will have to visit New York, Chicago or Los Angeles, the evening newspaper Ekstrabladet complained today.
PARIS, Oct. 22 -France detected today no sharp conflict between President Charles deI Gaulle and President Eisenhow-! er on the basis of their latest declarations.
A walrus danced a "Beer Barrel Polka" (or perhaps it was a waltz) at the Aquarium at Coney Island yesterday.
WESTFIELD, N. J., Oct. 22 -- This all-residential community near Newark will vote for the first time on Nov. 3 on whether to permit restricted industrial development.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A Government hearing examiner today recommended that trading in the common stock of Cornucopia Gold Mines on the American Stock Exchange be prohibited permanently. It has been suspended by the exchange since May, 1958.

Jeaneane Dowis, a young pianist from Texas, gave a Town Hall recital last night. Her program consisted of four works -- Mozart's "Ah, vous dirai-je, Maman" Variations, Beethoven's A flat Sonata (Op. 110), the Barber Sonata and Schumann's "Carnaval."

Colorado State University is an unfamiliar name to Eastern football fans. The Aggie team that plays Army at West Point tomorrow never has appeared on the Atlantic seaboard before. Moreover the school was officially known as Colorado A. and M. until a couple of years ago. However, C. S. U. rings bells, loud and clear, in the vigilant listening stations of professional football.
WARSAW, Oct. 22 (AP) -- An attempt to kidnap the private secretary of Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski was reported in an official church protest to the Government, informed sources said tonight.

By unanimous vote the Board of Estimate approved a $170,000 appropriation yesterday for preliminary engineering plans for the construction of a $15,000,000 sports stadium in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens.
Eleazar de Carvalho, Brazilian conductor, will lead the New York Philharmonic for the first time at the annual United Nations Day concert tomorrow afternoon.

POMFRET, Conn., Oct. 22 -- There's going to be an old-fashioned barbecue at the Pomfret School Saturday. The picnic will be part of a Parents Day program during which Pomfret's athletes will entertain four teams from St. George's of Newport, R. I.

Chamber music was allowed to return to Greenwich Village yesterday after Magistrate James Comerford had been assured that the Cafe Figaro was a center for music lovers who drank French or Italian coffee -- but never Irish coffee.
Final arrangements have been made for the theatre party to be held for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York at the Nov. 5 performance of "The Gang's All Here" at the Ambassador Theatre.

Now that National Wine Week here has passed into history, attention can be paid to the exultant intelligence which reaches these shores from France. There, it is reported, this year's wine harvest will probably be "great," a special, awesome adjective which is reserved for the rarest use among wine-tasters.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 22 -President Eisenhower deplored again today "the longest steel strike in this generation."
TRENTON, N. J. Oct. 22 (AP) -- State rules on the sale of variable annuities by life insurance companies in New Jersey will take effect on Nov. 2.
The $100,000,000 West Side urban renewal plan, with revisions, was unanimously approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 22 -- Within the next several decades the Great Lakes ports may operate on a year-round schedule.

Frederick A. Jambes, realty investor, purchased the fivestory store and apartment building at 1114 Second Avenue, southeast corner of Fiftyninth Street, in the first change of ownership of the property in fifty years.

Loans to business by fifteen large New York City banks, members of the Federal Reserve System, declined $108,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The two leaders in the challengers' chess tournament in Belgrade each played games of less than twenty moves in the twenty-fifth round, according to a report received last night from Yugoslavia.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 22 -- It has been a long time since Princeton had three tailbacks of the ability of Dan Sachs, Hugh Scott and John (Silky) Sullivan on the same team. And for the first, time all three of them will be in shape to play in the game here with Cornell.
A subway train jumped the tracks last night on the East Side line of the IRT. The derailment disrupted downtown local service, but no one was injured.
A battle for the Borough Presidency is building toward a climax in Queens, with the Republicans' hopes high for their entire slate.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -George F. Kennan, former Ambassador to Moscow, said today that the West must build up its conventional forces before it could afford to negotiate nuclear disarmament.

The directors of the Shell Oil Company proposed a two-for-one split of the company's stock yesterday. H. M. S. Burns, president, said that Shell planned to increase the dividend on the present shares from 50 to 55 cents a share in the fourth quarter.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point down to 4 up yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)

The Board of Education voted yesterday to convert Benjamin Franklin High School, East 116th Street and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, from a boys' to a co-educational school with special courses in government leadership.
Philadelphia announced plans yesterday to borrow $24,780,000 in the public bond market on Nov. 19. The securities to be offered will be secured by the general taxing power.

Any action by Mack Truck, Inc., on plans for closing its main plant at Plainfield, N. J., and relocating remained a board secret.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Premier Michel Debre announced today the prosecution of two Left-wing weeklies on charges of undermining public confidence in the French Army. At the same time he warned the army that it must remain obedient to the Government and to President Charles de Gaulle.
BOMBAY, India, Oct. 17 -Twenty-five old street cars from the Bronx are still actively in service in Bombay.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- A Federal District Court order to end the steel strike was stayed today until at least Monday or Tuesday. The delay was granted by three judges of the Court of Appeals to give them time to decide whether to uphold the back-to-work mandate or to cancel it.
The strike-bound Kennecott Copper Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the quarter that ended Sept. 30 dropped to $10,936,217 from $14,811,203 in the corresponding period last year.
Formal hearings on the Glendale-Ridgewood school controversy in Queens County Supreme Court were postponed until Oct. 29 yesterday by Justice Charles Margett.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A tentative agreement to settle the seven-week strike of 18,000 Swift Co. employes was announced today.

Leonard Bernstein introduced the three new assistant conductors of the New York Philharmonic at last night's preview concert of the orchestra at Carnegie Hall.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 22 -- The fifth annual Musee de Noel of the Vassar Club of Fairfield County will be held Monday through Oct. 30 at the Humpty Dumpty Restaurant in Old Greenwich. Proceeds will aid the Vassar Club's scholarship fund.

The Marine Products Division of the McCulloch Corporation, Minneapolis, is building an experimental outboard motor called the R-120, which it does not intend to place on the market. JAMESBURG, N. J., Oct. 22 -- Shortly before 7 o'clock tomorrow night when old No. 2509 pulls out of the Pennsylvania Railroad Station here, an era in American railroading goes with it.

ROME, Oct. 22 -- Seven hundred and three delegates representing 1,600,000 card-holding members will meet in Florence tomorrow for the seventh congress of the Christian Democratic party. The party has dominated Italian politics since the end of World War II.
Diana Lynn, Mary Astor and Gig Young will star in "The Philadelphia Story," a romantic comedy to be televised Dec. 7 from 9:30 to 11 P. M. by the National Broadcasting Company.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Southeastern Conference today levied a $1,000 fine -- the maximum penalty -- against the University of Mississippi for violation of athletic recruitment rules.

TRENTON, Oct. 22 -- Bishop Alfred L. Banyard of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey announced today his "unqualified" support of a referendum to provide funds for the expansion of state institutions of higher education.
The Howe Sound Company, which operates cobalt-copper mines in Idaho and owns lead, zinc, silver, copper and gold properties in Mexico, is going into business as a service company for the railroads.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Tax Court held today that a taxpayer was not entitled to claim money spent for dancing lessons as a medical deduction even though it had been recommended by his physician.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Russell A. Langelle reported to his State Department superiors today on how he was manhandled by Soviet authorities before being expelled from the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- If modern men, like those of ancient times, were named according to their talents and characteristics (Eric the Red, Ethelred the Unready, Richard the Lion Hearted), Arthur Joseph Goldberg would probably be known as the Formulator. Perhaps even the Great Formulator.

BENEATH the hard surface of Manhattan's sophisticated life exists another kind -family life in small, closely-knit neighborhoods. This mode of city living thrives in a number of scattered areas and nurtures the kind of warm, neighborly relationships and informal group activities more often associated with suburban or country life.
The United States is suffering from "moral cancer" because it is bankrupt in leadership, Kings County Judge Samuel Leibowitz said yesterday.
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Federal Judge Walter E. Hoffman told Virginia's Pupil Placement Board today that it must assign four Negroes to white schools in Norfolk or face contempt proceedings.

The election of Arnold H. Maremont, Chicago industrialist and patron of the arts, to the board of directors of the New York City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., 131 West Fifty-fifth Street, was announced yesterday by Newbold Morris, chairman of the board.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Wheat futures finished steady on the Board of Trade today with the near December and March deliveries moving up to new highs for the season.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower got in some golf today after having said he believed he had developed chronic bronchitis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson announced today that vesicular exanthema, a disease of swine, had been wiped out in the United States as a result of a seven-year campaign.
President Eisenhower said yesterday that he had asked Attorney General William P. Rogers to study the fixing of television quiz programs.

Billy Hunter, a two-fisted puncher from Detroit, established himself as a solid heavyweight contender by stopping Tony Anthony of New York in the seventh round of a scheduled ten - rounder at Madison Square Garden last night. The bout topped the first fight card in the Garden in ten weeks.
Budget Director Abraham D. Beame declared yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's "qualified" endorsement of the school bond amendment was being exploited by those opposing the proposal.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 23 -- Foreign oil companies operating in India have agreed to a further price reduction in petroleum products, K. D. Malaviya, Minister for Oil, announced today.

THE investigator behind yesterday's state - wide gambling raids is a gray-haired, soft-spoken veteran of the New York State Police who was picked fourteen months ago for just that job. He was named by Governor Harriman to head a new gang-breaking unit after the Apalachin gangster convention of Nov. 14, 1957.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- The third anniversary of the Hungarian revolt occasioned a sharp exchange here today between the chief permanent delegates of the United States and Hungary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that old-crop, or carryover, stocks of corn, sorghum grain and soybeans stored in all positions Oct. 1 were at new record levels for the date.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Washington Board of Trade is apparently the main moving force in this city's bid for the world's fair.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 23 -- Under Secretary of State Douglas Dillon, arriving here from Taiwan on a three-day visit, heard South Korean officials' views on the need for continuing substantial United States military and economic aid.
The Humboldt Bay Municipal Water District, Calif., will receive bids Nov. 4 on $10,700,000 of water bonds due serially on Nov. 1 from 1964 to 1998.

A generation has matured since the gifted and controversial Mexican painter, Diego Rivera, has had a one-man show in New York. Today, pictures that will be "new" even to many of an earlier generation will be put on exhibition at the Parke-Bernet Galleries before their auction next Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Secret Service agents with submachine guns raced through the Treasury Department building today. They were looking for a hold-up that didn't happen.

Two theatre parties are being planned for the benefit of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York, a federation of fifty settlements and neighborhood centers in the city's most troubled and overcrowded areas.
PARIS, Oct. 23 -- In the game of French politics, the Rightists have scored a point and wore triumphant smiles today to show it.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- A group of right-wing conservatives met here today to launch a national third party dedicated to the proposition that the old parties do not give voters a clear-cut choice.
More than 300 schoolboy harriers will toe the starting line today in the Eastern interscholastic cross-country championship race at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
DETROIT, Oct. 23 -- The General Motors Corporation disclosed today that more than a third of its 320,000 hourly rated workers had been laid off because of the steel shortage.

NEWARK, Oct. 23 -- Two men pleaded guilty today before Federal Judge Mendon Morrill to a jury-fixing charge in the 1956 income-tax evasion trial of the late Abner (Longie) Zwillman, an underworld figure during the prohibition era.
THE "Bell Telephone Hour" saddled up and went West for its music last night on Channel 4.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A tentative agreement was reached today between the last of three unions involved in a dispute that has tied up the bulk of the nation's inland waterway traffic.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The United Nations Command in South Korea charged today that more than 1,000 prospective spies were being trained in three espionage schools in Communist North Korea.

Among her recurring complaints is the mournful one that deals with ashtrays. There never seems to be enough of them around the house. She remarks on this as she darkly watches the first cigarette ground out in the after-dinner coffee saucer.

BERNARDSTON ,Mass. Oct. 23 -- Aesop said 3,000 years ago that a hunt never is over until the hunter is back in his automobile driving homeward eighteen miles above the speed limit. History has proved him right many a time since then, as it did again today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- The United States and the Soviet Union were reported today to be approaching an agreement on a joint resolution on disarmament.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 23 -- President Mohammed Ayub Khan said today Pakistan's disputes with India must be settled, and the sooner the better.
WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 23 -- Right Time had a hard time before winning the $25,000 Governor's Cup at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Four men bailed out of two Oregon National Guard jet fighter planes that collided in darkness high over Mount Hood last night. All survived.

Germain Bazin, curator of the Louvre in Paris, has spent his lifetime in the world of art. He has distilled this lifetime of experience in a survey of painting, sculpture and architecture from earliest times to the present. The work, called "A History of Art," has 668 illustrations from public and private collections throughout the world. It will be published Monday by Houghton Mifflin.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The new border clash between India and Communist China followed by four weeks a letter from Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru to Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China. The Indian leader called for a Chinese withdrawal from Indian territory to open the way for negotiations on specific differences about the frontier.
HONG KONG, Oct. 23 -- The Chinese Communists filed a protest today with the Indian Ambassador in Peiping, charging Indian attacks on Chinese troops in Tibet.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Oct. 23 -- Two members of the East Rutherford Board of Health pleaded not guilty today to charges of misconduct in office, extortion and conspiracy in connection with alleged pay-offs for the illegal dumping of cesspool waste.
" Tic Tac Dough," one of the television quiz shows that admittedly had been rigged, was canceled yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company.
BOSTON, Oct. 23 -- Boston University's football team almost became an upset victim on its home field tonight before staging a last-period rally to defeat the Huskies of Connecticut, 8 -- 7.

MODERN painting and sculpture used in conjunction with architectural and interior design is increasingly finding favor in new office buildings and banks, which become, so to speak, corporate Lorenzo de Medicis, directly patronizing contemporary artists.
Developments in the metal markets yesterday indicated unsettled conditions in producers' prices of zinc and copper.
Coach Aldo (Buff) Donelli told a group of Columbia alumni yesterday that the chief fault with the Lions' football team is inexperience.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Good wishes have come from Antarctica for the success of a twelve-nation conference negotiating here on a treaty to bar military activities from that area.

The state Liquor Authority lifted three liquor permits in Manhattan last night. This brought to ten the number of establishments closed by the authority in its campaign against taverns that permit catering to prostitutes, homosexuals or criminals.

MIAMI, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Auburn. strictly a running football team in the past, shocked Miami with a 78-yard touchdown pass on the opening play tonight and continued to use its new aerial game to whip the Hurricanes 21 -- 6.
HAVANA, Oct. 23--A vitriolic attack on the United States was made early today by Premier Fidel Castro.

THIS seems to be the season of the big migration. Unlike the birds, the instrumental ensembles are heading toward New York as the cold months set in. They are coming from all over Europe and from many cities in this country.
Separate matters involving Sugar Ray Robinson, Cus D'Amato and Charley Scott were taken up by the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday.
RYE, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- A mild-mannered, little-known lawyer from Maine was honored here today for leaving to cancer research a $13,000,000 estate that few persons even knew he had.
Edward G. Fischer, who retired as general station master at Grand Central Terminal last year after a forty-nine-year stint, is back again -- this time as a news dealer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A Federal judge upheld today the right of Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover to copyright public speeches and thereby prevent their publication without his permission.

Penn State, Pennsylvania, Oregon, Northwestern and Mississippi are looking for the stiffest opposition today of the major college football teams that have come through the first half of the season without defeat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Pan American Airways protested today that to grant Northwest Airlines sole authority to fly between Honolulu and Washington and Oregon would "deny the public the advantages of competitive service which it has enjoyed for eleven years."
CEDARHURST, L. I., Oct. 23 -- Mrs. Edna Grossman, the Democratic candidate for Treasurer in the Town of Hempstead, today promised to recommend the abolition of her post if she were elected.

Texaco, Inc., reported yesterday that its earnings set records in the quarter and nine-month periods ended Sept. 30. The oil company also declared an extra dividend of 20 cents a share and a 2 per cent stock dividend on the common stock.

Events today: United Nations Day Concert, New York Philharmonic, conductor, Eleazar de Carvalho, General Assembly Hall, United Nations, 3:15 P. M.; Margot Rebeil, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; Marie Vogler, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Seymour Lipkin, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Carlos Ramos, flamenco guitarist, Town Hall, 8:30.

The advertising account for the institutional, international and trust departments of the Chase Manhattan Bank has followed Anderson Fowler Hewitt to Compton Advertising, Inc., from Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 22 -- Indonesian Communist leaders are reported to have differed over whether to follow soft or tough tactics in combating official curbs on their party's opportunities.
CHESTER LUDGIN sang the part of the elder Germont for the first time with the New York City Opera in last night's performance of "La Traviata," the final one of the season at the City Center.
Prices of commodity futures moved generally upward yesterday on most New York exchanges in quiet trading. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A former vice president of the steel worker's union proposed today new fact-finding procedures designed to prevent economically damaging stalemates, such as the present steel strike.

Tom Lockhart wore four hats at a luncheon in Ruppert's Brewery yesterday -- owner of the Long Island Rovers, general manager of the Long Island Arena, president of the Amateur Hockey Association and president of the Eastern Hockey League. It remained to be seen whether he was talking through them when he said:

The election of George H. Struthers as vice president in charge of merchandising of Sears, Roebuck Co., giant mail-order and department store organization, was announced yesterday in Chicago by Charles H. Kellstadt, president.
One of the biggest sensations in the film business this year is the phenomenal success of a raucous and conglomerate spectacle film called "Hercules."
Paul Keres beat Mikhail Tal, the leader, last night for the third time in the world chess challengers' tournament, according to a report from Yugoslavia. Both are from the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Government said today that it now takes $12.52 to buy the same quantity and quality of goods and services that $10 bought ten years ago.
John Adams, all but ignored by pre-season sages, can clinch at least a tie for the Public Schools Athletic League Division II championship today by defeating Flushing.

Financing for new capital in the public market will move along at a strong pace next week. Major bond issues of more than $200,000,000 are scheduled to reach the market. Nine major fixed-interest security offerings average nearly $20,000,000 each.
A bookmaker was shot and crtically wounded last night in gangland style as he sat at the wheel of his car at Thirtieth Avenue and Thirtieth Street in Astoria, Queens, the police reported.

Sales and earnings of the Corn Products Company in the first nine months of 1959 were higher than those in the 1958 period, according to a report to stockholders issued for publication today by William T. Brady, president.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 23 -- India and Pakistan have reached agreement on several controversial issues relating to the demarcation of boundaries in the eastern region of their subcontinent and the restoration of peaceful conditions.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 23 -- Sir Patrick Renison, who was sworn in today as Governor, appealed tonight to the people of this British colony to make "a working model of the interracial partnership which stands so high among the purposes" of the British Commonwealth.
Charles Van Doren and Hank Bloomgarden, two of the big money winners of the television quiz show "Twenty-one," made "substantial changes" yesterday in earlier...

LIVER is an extremely nutritious food, containing considerable quantities of iron, plus Vitamins A and B. In this country, variety meats are not too popular, but much prejudice may be overcome if they are attractively dressed up.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 23 -- A variety of oddly shaped vehicles that scoot along several inches off the ground on self-produced cushions of air was displayed here today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 23 -- The United States scored a double triumph at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show today. American riders won the Prix des Nations international jumping event tonight and William Steinkraus of Westport, Conn., the United States team captain, captured the international jumping individual championship in the afternoon.

Mrs. O'Connell Tansill, chairman of the Bal Militaire, has announced that a junior committee has been formed under the co-chairmanship of Mrs. Thomas Bancroft Jr. and Christopher F. Lindsay to aid in plans for the event at the Astor on Thursday.
BASKING RIDGE, N. J., Oct. 23 -- A church here is welcoming a Dutch family to its first real home in two years.

Directors of the Detroit Steel Corporation yesterday declared the usual quarterly dividend of 25 cents and an extra of 25 cents. Both are payable on Dec. 15 to holders of record of Dec. 1. This brings to $1.12 1/2 paid this year, compared with 50 cents last year.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Industrial share prices came back heavily in early dealings in the stock-market here today mainly because of the recent weakness on Wall Street and a cut in interim dividend by Babcock and Wilcox, a leader in the commercial nuclear power field.

To the extent that it is possible, hospitals operate on a businesslike basis. They are not dealing with inanimate products or production lines but with human beings who are ailing, injured, unconscious, perhaps dying.
Physicians researching new drugs in their practice for pharmaceutical companies were advised yesterday to keep one eye on the patient's physical symptoms and another on his legal symptoms.

IN the minds of many, the typical teen-ager is a carefree youngster who is concerned solely with rock 'n' roll, tunes, current singing idols, the newest fads in clothes, the latest heart throb and not much else.

A Democratic Congressman from Brooklyn told 200 leaders of the investment company field here yesterday that their industry "may well be the counter-revolutionary force [that is] injecting a new vitality into our way of life."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Most women shop for hats or for upholstery fabrics. Mrs. Alene Holt, an alternate delegate from Canada to the fourteenth General Assembly, shops for industries. She seeks new ones for her community and region when she is at home in Peterborough, Ontario.

Armino A. Compagna, realty investor and builder, who recently contracted to buy the twelve - story and penthouse apartment building at 823 Park Avenue, adjoining the northeast corner of Seventy-fifth Street, has resold his contract to a client of Lindenbaum Young, lawyers.

Europe's "Little Four" have been meeting at the city of Vaduz in Liechtenstein to consider problems that are just as important to them as similar ones are to the Big Four statesmen and people. The combined populations of Liechtenstein, Andorra, San Marino and Monaco are somewhat less than the population of Stamford, Conn. The combined areas of these four statelets are somewhat less than the area of New York City's five boroughs.
Vice President Richard M. Nixon will participate in the opening broadcast of "The Hidden Revolution" over the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Laos is joining the Asian swing away from parliamentary democracy in favor of stronger executive control.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 23 -- John Gerard of Inwood and Pat Cici of Lido scored a 36, 36 -- 72, one under par, and won the play-off for the Long Island Professional Golf Association Pinehurst senior-junior pro-pro championship at the Garden City Golf Club today.
ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- State officials agreed today on a program to ease the burden of some -- but not all -- nonresidents who must pay the New York income tax.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration left it in doubt today whether it would accelerate development of the super-thrust Saturn rocket. Such an acceleration has been advocated as part of an all-out effort to overtake the Soviet Union in space-rocket propulsion.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- In the Great Hall of the Philadelphia Museum of Art tonight, more than 800 persons attended the Crystal Ball and sipped champagne in one of the world's most rarified atmospheres.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 23 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek and leaders of the Administration parties resolved today to try to form a coalition with the Opposition to block the election of Janio Quadros to the Presidency.

THE agreeable blandness of rice makes it an ideal accompaniment to many dishes. This versatile cereal is particularly good as a base for the creamed dishes and curries that are popular as colder weather sets in. It also has its use as a side dish.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board accuses Capital Airlines today of having failed to relay a rough-weather warning to the pilot of an airliner that broke up in flight near Baltimore last May, killing all thirty-one aboard.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 23 -- Associates of Chancellor Adenauer said today that he expected a Western summit meeting to be held in Paris in the first two weeks of December.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 23 -- The Government announced today that Chinese Communist troops had attacked an Indian force in Kashmir, killing seventeen Indians.
Daylight Saving Time will end in New York, New Jersey, New England and some other places at 2 A. M. tomorrow.
DETROIT, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that labor troubles in and out of the auto industry cut car production 16 per cent this week.

There's an old saying in Wall Street: "Never sell on strike news." The theory behind this is that stocks may be unduly depressed by a strike, but will rebound vigorously after a settlement. The prolonged steel strike has proved a striking exception. As the stoppage has dragged on, steel companies' stocks have been sold repeatedly.
I hope I can, if I may, make an amplification of a quotation of mine, which appeared in an editorial in your Oct. 17 issue.

Two brothers of the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, expressed thanks yesterday for the aid sent to Tibetan refugees in India through Church World Service, a department of the National Council of Churches.
LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Yakov A. Malik, Soviet Ambassador to Britain, told Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd today that the Soviet Union still wanted an early summit meeting and was prepared for it.

When Man o'War, the most illustrious thoroughbred in American racing history, retired in 1920 he had earned a total of $249,465 in his two years of competition. Today at the New Aqueduct race track the Man o'War Handicap will be run for the first time, and the money distribution for the race named in his honor will approach his complete track earnings.
THE most glittering enigma in our history is the central character in Francis F. Beirne's excellently readable new book, "Shout Treason: The Trial of Aaron Burr."*
The erratic price swings that convulsed the Government securities market during much of the week's trading disappeared yesterday as the market quieted in a firm mood.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The President's National Committee of the Golden Anniversary White House Conference on Children and Youth recommended today creation of a permanent committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- President Harry W. Von Willer of the Erie Railroad said today he would consider it reasonable if the Interstate Commerce Commission acted in six months on the proposed Erie merger with the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad.
LONDON, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- The London Daily Mirror announced tonight that it had bought Brook Mandore, a gentle-eyed bull who faced possible doom because he was too pretty.
More than 100 Barnard College alumnae will participate in the second day of the eighth annual Alumnae Council conference on the Barnard campus today.

CAIRO, Oct. 22 -- It is a shock sometimes to meet old friends after ten years -- the graying about the temples, the lined face, the paunch. But seeing Cairo after ten years is a shock in a different sense.
A proposal to underwrite what may be the costliest organizing drive in maritime labor history will be put before the membership of the National Maritime Union on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Two hundred and twenty-five paralytic polio cases were reported by the states last week. That was a drop of five from the revised total of 230 for the preceding week, ended Oct. 10.

Tickets still remain for the performance on Tuesday of "Golden Fleecing" at Henry Miller's Theatre, which will benefit the Presbyterian Home for Aged Women. They may be obtained at the home at 49 East Seventy-third Street.
VADUZ, Liechtenstein, Oct. 23 -- Europe's Little Four expanded to six today and expressed a readiness to become seven if the Dame of Sark honored them with her presence.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 23 -- The strike against independent movie producers by 3,000 screen and television writers in the Writers Guild of America threatened tonight to extend to the major studios.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday gains over the levels of the year before in operating revenues and net income for the September quarter and for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30. Clifton W. Phalen, president, pointed out that operating expenses and taxes for the three months ended on Sept. 30 rose 7.8 per cent while operating revenues went up 6.7 per cent.

The Federal Government may consolidate two Internal Revenue Service districts that serve about 4,000,000 taxpayers in Manhattan, the Bronx, Richmond, Westchester and Rockland Counties. The districts collect hundreds of millions of dollars annually.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves announced tonight that Charles (Chuck) Dressen, coach of the Los Angeles Dodgers had signed a two-year contract to manage the baseball club.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 23 -- Greek and Turkish Cypriote leaders were cautiously hopeful tonight that the island's latest dispute would eventualy be resolved.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Shortcomings of the international narcotics control system were denounced in committee debate here today.
IT was reported here recently that statistics have indicated that a part-score is worth 220 points when both sides are vulnerable -- not the 50 points given by official contract bridge scoring.
OPENING today at 109 West Tenth Street is a charming shop called Stark Valla Emporium, a cross between an old-fashioned general store and a modern shopping center.
A midnight supper, to be enhanced by the added sparkle of champagne-tasting, will be held Nov. 5 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for Guideposts for Children.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell tonight called on the steel workers union and the steel companies to "bargain around the clock until an agreement is reached" to end the marathon steel strike.
A New Zealander who has lost virtually all of both arms demonstrated remarkable mastery of artificial limbs yesterday by operating an electric drill, a jeweler's lathe and other devices.

County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz accepted a motion yesterday to dismiss a first-degree murder charge against 15-year-old Peter Manceri. He agreed to instruct the jury, probably early next week, to return a verdict on a charge of second-degree murder or manslaughter.
Amid the furor over quiz shows, a South African housewife arrived here yesterday on a round-the-world trip she had won on a quiz show.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Two teams of New York politicians came to Washington today in the role of nonpolitical boosters for the home town. One was led by Governor Rockefeller, the other by Mayor Wagner.
PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Reports that Premier Khrushchev would visit France were officially confirmed tonight.
Revenues of American Airlines, Inc., during the third quarter this year were the best in the company's history, C. R. Smith, president, disclosed yesterday.

Mack Trucks, Inc., which last Monday notified employes it planned to close its main plant at Plainfield, N. J., and consolidate operations elsewhere, disclosed yesterday that the new site might possibly be Allentown, Pa.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Foreign demand for bread grain steadied old crop wheat futures on the Board of Trade today.
ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- More people were killed in automobile accidents in the state last month than in any September since 1941.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.1 per cent to 119.1 per cent of the 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

The office of the State Attorney General moved in Supreme Court yesterday to dissolve a Long Island company that allegedly defrauded a number of persons seeking to supplement their income with part-time work. The company was accused of a scheme of "bait" advertising.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 23 -- The middle-aged man who is lean, takes exercise, avoids too much fat in his diet, does not smoke and keeps his blood pressure down apparently has a good chance of avoiding a heart attack.

DETROIT, Oct. 23 -- A struggle for national economic and political power has become the dominant influence in collective bargaining today, George Romhey, president of American Motors Corporation, said here tonight.
A special Air Force group convened in the Pentagon this week for a month-long review of the long-range requirements and missions of the Air Reserve Forces.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation said tonight that Major Diaz Lanz was responsible for the leaflet bombing Wednesday.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- The prosecution closed its case against Malcolm R. White today by asking for his conviction in the killing of Alfred F. Dugan, independent union organizer, last Nov. 13.

Protestant churches over the country tomorrow will observe Reformation Sunday, marking the 442d anniversary of the day Martin Luther nailed his ninety-five theses to the door of the castle church of Wittenberg.
The United Taxpayer party was ruled off the ballot in Queens yesterday.
New stirrings of hope for a settlement of the steel strike added a final fillip to a technical rally yesterday and allowed the stock market to close with a strong gain.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 23 -- Anastas Mikoyan, Soviet First Deputy Premier, said today that "the Soviet Union with its military power will guarantee the security of Finland and Finland can live in peace without fear for her destiny."
The threat of a milkmen's strike today at 4 P. M. was deferred for at least twenty-four hours yesterday. Union and management negotiators agreed to extend their contract until tomorrow afternoon.
The trouble with the "Buy American" decision of the Development Loan Fund is that it violates a rather important principle for so little gain to the nation's balance of international payments.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- Many persons who have had rheumatic fever are being needlessly restricted from leading normal lives, according to a report offered here today.
MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (AP)--A Soviet scientist said today that man would have little to fear from cosmic radiation when he ventured into space.
OTTAWA, Oct. 23 (Canadian Press) -- The St. Lawrence Seaway has apparently reversed the St. Lawrence River's customary role as a predominantly export route.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., research affiliate of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, received a patent this week for a "picture phone," through which people can be seen as well as heard.
New York political leaders are following the Queens election campaign closely in search of city-wide implications for the Mayoral race of 1961.

I should like to join Senator Joseph S. Clark, whose letter was published on Oct. 11, in congratulating you and Edwin L. Dale Jr. on Mr. Dale's imaginative and informative reporting, especially his article "Old Fashioned Fiscal Soundness Gains Adherents Around the World."

TOKYO, Oct. 23 -- Use of the electronic computer in industry has been brought to its greatest advancement to date, it is believed here, by a giant Japanese cement manufacturing concern. The big nation-wide enterprise employs a huge computer to link it directly to the concern's seventy-two branches throughout the country.

Net earnings of ACF-Wrigley Stores, Inc., for its first fiscal quarter, ended on Sept. 30, were about $680,000 or 17 cents a share, against $1,215,000, or 30 cents a share, in the quarter of last year, it was announced yesterday.
The State Police struck simultaneous blows against organized gambling in twenty-nine communities in upstate New York yesterday.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Lieut. Anthony de Grazio of the Chicago police department said today his suspension from the force for associating with a man regarded as the head of the city's rackets "makes no difference at all to me."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold made public today a United Nations Day message in which he urged all nations to dedicate themselves to the principles of international cooperation set down in the Charter.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23 -- Industry and union leaders in the steel strike agreed tonight to resume peace talks here tomorrow afternoon.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Thirteen unionists on strike at the Standard Oil (Indiana) refineyr at near-by Sugar Creek were found guilty of contempt of court today and sentenced to jail.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied today a motion for a writ of habeas corpus for Leslie Irvin, condemned for six slayings in Indiana and Kentucky five years ago.
GENEVA, Oct. 22 -- About 1,500,000 Swiss men and 137,000 Swiss women are eligible to vote in Swiss elections Saturday and Sunday.

The political, social and economic progress achieved by South Vietnam in its four years as a republic was hailed yesterday by a group of specialists at the opening of a two-day conference sponsored by the American Friends of Vietnam.

Local government bond issues totaling $1,366,734,270 will be put up for the approval of voters at the general election on Nov. 3, according to a survey made by The Daily Bond Buyer, municipal finance newspaper.

Five apartment houses at 624, 628 and 632 East 189th Street, 2477 Belmont Avenue and 2476 Hughes Avenue, in the Fordham area of the Bronx, have been sold by the Belmont-Hughes Associates to Irving Walsey, realty investor.

MONTREAL, Oct. 23 (Canadian Press) -- The Reader's Digest Association (Canada), Ltd., magazine publishers, will challenge in court next Monday the validity of a tax imposed by one Federal regime and repealed by another.
THE really unconventional number in Leonard Bernstein's by no means conventional Philharmonic program yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall was "The Unanswered Question" by Charles Ives.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 23 -- President Eisenhower played golf in the rain today less than twenty-four hours after saying he had had chronic bronchitis for the last three years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The drain on steel inventories during the steel strike has made the first post-recession dent in the nation's output of goods and services.
HONG KONG, Oct. 23 -- Communist China today termed the United Nations resolution on Tibet illegal, unlawful and slanderous.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 -- The proposal for a world's fair in Los Angeles, while it has been nominally approved by city and county officials, is not something about which the community as a whole is excited or even informed.
Prices of cotton futures were unchanged to 6 points (30 cents a bale) up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will collect blood today at the Masonic Temple, 137-70 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- The annual Election Day bazaar of the Scarsdale Congregational Church will be held on Nov. 3. from 10 A. M. to 9:30 P. M. Known as the Harvest Bazaar, it is being sponsored by the Women's Guild of the Church.
RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 24 (UPI) -- A burly guard, Arthur (Jug) Browning, kicked a 23yard field goal today to give a 17-15 victory to Duke over North Carolina State in the mud before 14,000 fans.
Milk dealers in the metropolitan area warned yesterday that there was "little likelihood" of a settlement with their unionized workers before a 4 P. M. deadline today.
Commercial banking management in this country in general is not concerned seriously at this time at the way United States spending abroad is outstripping foreign spending here.
BOMBAY, India, Oct. 17 -Ornithologists and medical researchers here are planning a joint attack on a fatal disease that they suspect is carried by birds.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 24 -- The teamsters Union is claiming victory in its struggle for a beachhead in Puerto Rico.

Rolf Christopherson, the first director general of the recently organized International Legal Aid Association, was first trained in the inflexible code of the military. But he completed his education in the elastic code of the law.

THE 1958-59 season in Paris turned out to be an "American" season. During the year twelve American plays, many of them adapted by important French writers, were performed in Paris, almost all at large theatres.

A FAIR way to review a roman a clef is the way the author asks you to read his book. "Though this novel confessedly has its point of departure in reality," says Haakon Chevalier in a note, "it is a work of the imagination, and elements that have been borrowed from reality have been so transformed that any resemblance to actual persons or events is unintentional and fortuitous."
New missile bases in Turkey and eventual abandonment of our air bases in Morocco appeared to be forecast last week.
The new $3,300,000 classroom-library-administration building on the Bronx campus of Hunter College will be dedicated tomorrow at noon.

The House of the Holy Comforter, Grand Concourse and 196th Street, the Bronx, a hospital for the care of women suffering from chronic illnesses, will receive the proceeds of a fair to be held there on Saturday afternoon.

HOW much of television is phony? The question inevitably arises from the current investigation by a House subcommittee of quiz shows that induced good minds to assume the roles of carnival shills.

THIS Southern exposure is of the low country -- where, over the centuries, the marshes and the sea have influenced the lives and fortunes of Georgians and South Carolinians. The focus is on a gently bred family, or what is left of it, living in Pocosin, a once-grand mansion on the edge of a Georgia swamp.

COMMUTING, like snuff-dipping, is an unattractive but not necessarily an unbreakable habit, according to Jerome Beatty's book-length, non-sectarian, and pleasantly informative tract. Even a commuter may ultimately win his way back to a non-dichotomous human dignity, it seems.
The 1960 census slated to provide jobs for more than 7,000 Republicans in New York City. And 8,000 more will find census-taking employment under the Republican Administration elsewhere in the state.

The outlook on a summit conference, after appearing for a time to brighten, clouded over again last week. This was due to the emergence of differences of attitude among the Western allies. At the same time there came renewed pressure toward the summit by Russia.

THIS newest collection of short stories by Daphne du Maurier is a curious and uneven affair. The stories are claims the author in an introductory note, concerned with the moment of truth that comes in the life of each individual, the moment at which "it is as though the link between emotion and reason is stretched to the limit of endurance, and sometimes snaps."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- The Government will enter railroad labor disputes Monday determined to avert a nation-wide rail tie-up early in 1960.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 24 (AP) -- George Fleming kicked the only conversion of the game to provide a 13-12 victory margin for Washington against previously undefeated Oregon today.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 24 (UPI) -- Mel West sparked Missouri to a 9-0 victory over Nebraska today and kept the Tigers' hopes for a post-season bowl bid alive.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 -- Steel companies will have enough iron ore to operate through the winter even if an early freeze halts lake shipments before the first of December, officials of steel plants reported today.

THE post-election position of the film industry is well up front in the queue of applicants for prompt and sympathetic action on their special problems from the new -or restored and confirmed -Government.

MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 24 -- Tufts turned enemy fumbles into touchdowns in the course of a 23-0 victory today over Williams College the Little 1958 Three champion. The triumph avenged a 37-8 loss to the Ephmen last year.
DETROIT, Oct. 24 -- An old issue -- the merits of the metric system for American industry -came under new but indecisive discussion here this week at the tenth National Conference on Standards.

Columbia provided little more than a muddy showcase yesterday for an explosive display of power by the Holy Cross foot-ball team. There was not enough weight or wallop in the Light Blue and the Crusaders romped to a 34-0 victory.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Gary, Ballman, a sophomore playing with a finger in a cast, scored the two touchdowns today in Michigan State's 14-6 Big Ten victory over Indiana.

The Vacation Camp for the Blind, which gives vacations and service to blind adults and their families, will be the beneficiary of the Dec. 17 performance of "Silent Night, Lonely Night." The play, by Robert Anderson, opens Dec. 3 at the Morosco Theatre.

WITH unadorned, deceptively simple sentences that cover only 176 pages Elizabeth Land has written the exciting story of the co-pilot who last year single-handedly landed his crippled B-47 jet bomber rather than abandon an unconscious crew mate.

MONTE CARLO, Oct. 21 -- If a golfer stands on the seventh tee of the Monte Carlo Golf Club and peers cautiously over the edge, he can see almost all of Monaco -- 2,500 feet straight down.

Meteorites spend some five billion years at temperatures of around 120 degrees below zero Fahrenheit before they make their thirty-million-year trip to the earth, it was suggested last week. The theory was advanced by Edward Anders, assistant professor of chemistry at the University of Chicago, at the university's autumn Conference with Industrial Sponsors.

Jack L. S. Snead Jr., whose company and industry have fattened under a system of regulation that emphasizes the difference between forms of transportation, thinks it is now time to bring the different forms closer together.

IF you wish to celebrate this week's Festival of Mysteries with some highly enjoyable reading in the field, at an impressive bargain rate, you can buy yourself almost 400,000 words (or as much as six or seven average suspense novels) for only $5.95, in two collections, the hard-cover ALFRED HITCHCOCK PRESENTS MY FAVORITES IN SUSPENSE (Random, $4.95) and the paperback ELLERY QUEEN'S 1960 ANTHOLOGY (Davis, $1).

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 24 -- An open rebellion by Southern Presbyterian laymen against an "ecclesiastical machine of liberal ministers which has gained control of the leadership of the church" has been revealed here.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 24 -- Stockholm newspapers named two United States physicists today as probable winners of the 1959 Nobel Prize in physics for their work in discovering the antiproton.

The complete outsider and the popular favorite won the respective divisions of the Man o' War Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. Dotted Line of the King Ranch took the first half of the rich race at a mutuel return of $57.50 and Mrs. Herbert Herff's Tudor Era took the second half, at a pay-off of $6.40.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 24 (UPI) -- Mississippi routed Arkansas, 28 -- 0, today and remained unbeaten.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Oct. 24 -The fifty-fifth annual Long Island Fall Flower Show, presented by the North Shore Horticultural Society, will open for a five-day exhibition on Friday at the Dosoris Lane showplace of the Glen Cove Neighborhood Association, formerly the estate of George Dupont Pratt.
Tenants on the site of the Riverside-Amsterdam slum clearance project have begun organizing in its support.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The in a contest with officialdom. It will soon move into a new headquarters building on the very block it was ordered to the very block it was ordered to leave two years ago.

Add to these qualities the background of difficult years in China before and during the dangerous moments of the Kuomintang's march to the north and we have that rare thing -- an adventure story which is all the better for being true.
MOSCOW, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's first "wedding palace" is open for business in Leningrad, the Communist Youth League newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda reported today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- A framework for a federation of independent political parties at the state level was set up here today by a national conference of conservatives. The aim is to establish a third national party.

TENDER bulbs are the house plant grower's best bet for winter color. Many kinds can be brought into bloom indoors without the special facilities and prolonged low-temperature conditioning needed to force tulips, daffodils and other hardy spring-flowering bulbs.

AMES, Iowa, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- A closed circuit television network helped Iowa State find the weaknesses in the Kansas State defense in the Big Eight conference clash between the schools today. Iowa State won, 26 -- 0.

ANY home owner who has trees on his land knows what can happen at this time of year. Falling leaves can drift into and clog the rain gutters around the roof of his house. Trapped water may back up under the overhanging shingles, causing rotting of roof boards and seepage into rooms below, or water may overflow the edge of the gutter, causing unsightly streaking and staining on house walls.

Your Oct. 18 picture article, "Emblems at the U. N.," reproduces a number of national coats of arms which, you say, appear on invitations to U. N. receptions and dinners. Included in this display is the eagle emblem of West Germany.

THIS year New England enjoyed its second-best summer in thirteen years of postwar record keeping, as far as vacation business was concerned. The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston survey revealed that occupancies in 1959 trailed by only 3 per cent the record set in 1957.

IN 1929, when Leon Trotsky was in exile in Turkey, a shooting gallery was opened in the Park of Culture and Rest in Moscow; the targets were figures of Neville Chamberlain, Chiang Kai-shek and others. The face of one was covered by a mask; when a marksman hit this target, the mask fell off and revealed the face of Leon Trotsky.
OTTAWA -- In an effort to speed up the formalities for passengers crossing the United States-Canadian border, Canadian authorities have eliminated one piece of red tape for their own nationals.
