Despite the steel strike, total employment in the eight-county Philadelphia labor market rose to 1,691,800 at mid-September. This was an increase of 11,500 from the month before, according to the Pennsylvania State Employment Service.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 20 -South Korea expects the biggest rice crop since World War II this year, despite heavy damage from recent typhoons and floods.

W. T. CUMMINGS, a new author-artist, has dressed up a durable old theme with interesting modern pictures. Like the heroine of an old-fashioned fairy tale, Annabelle, an up-to-date little girl, stumbles upon the talisman -- a floppy, big old hat stashed away in the attic -- which will give her everything she asks for.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 -- Negotiations to settle the crippling steel strike resumed here today under the double spur of a court order and an expression of hope by President Eisenhower that the talks would lead to a prompt accord.
New York Medical College plans to build a $5.000,000 institute for heart and lung diseases, to be headed by Dr. Charles P. Bailey, an Internationally known heart surgeon.

THIS column's mail has recently been enlivened by the arrival of a batch of ten letters from teen-age readers. Because all came from Brooklyn and dealt with the same topic (teen-age reading). I strongly suspect that they were written, not out of addiction to "Speaking of Books," but because the writers were prodded into expressing their views by their high-school English teacher.

The Youth Consultation Service of the Diocese of New York, Inc., will benefit from a theatre party at the Dec. 1 performance of "The Sound of Music," the musical starring Mary Martin. Reservations also are being accepted for a pre-theatre buffet dinner in the Crystal Room of the Plaza, after which transportation to the theatre by bus will be provided.

NINE-YEAR-OLD Janet Sandison's life was so full that when the women of her Scottish Highland village asked her if she "never thought long up on that hill with no other bairns to play with," she was sure they were weak-minded.

BERCHTESGADEN, Germany, Oct. 19 -- October is the time when the milch cows are brought down from summer pastures in tile high Alpine meadows, when shutters close on the woodcarvers' shops along the Koenigssee and the winter's quiet settles upon the country side.

FROM a window high above Central Park, mezzo-so-prano Giulietta Simionato looked down at the bright-colored jackets of the skaters and observed that they looked like marionettes going round and round on a record-player.

A HAYDN festival which began in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, has recently concluded in Budapest with a number of concert and operatic performances. The Metropolitan Opera Association has released the names of the box-holders for its seventy-fifth opening night tomorrow at the Metropolitan Opera House. Verdi's "Il Trovatore" will be sung.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 24 -- A few days ago Coach John Stiegman said his Rutgers team "was up in the clouds" when losing to Bucknell last week. Today Rutgers seemed right at home on the soggy turf of the Scarlets' stadium in shutting out Lehigh, 23 to 0.

The tenth annual art show and sale of the Walden School, the largest and the most varied since the event was first instituted, will open Wednesday at 7 P. M. at the school, 1 West Eighty-eight Street.

LONDON -- The first material reward of the British for re-electing a Conservative government was the announcement that from now on they may travel abroad without government restriction on the amount of money they can take with them.

Thirty-three years ago John D. Rockefeller Jr. authorized the late Dr. W. A. R. Goodwin, rector of Bruton Parish Church in Williamsburg, to undertake preliminary studies for the restoration of the colonial capital of Virginia. Today the restoration is virtually complete. The Williamsburg of today looks much as did the colonial capital known by Thomas Jefferson, George Washington, Patrick Henry and George Mason.

The United States will launch ten rockets during the week of Nov. 16-22, designated as International Rocket Week. The planned series will be the highlight of the United States program for International Geophysical Cooperation-1959, the continuation of the International Geophysical Year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24--The Federal Government's powers to deal with inflation and economic growth have been "seriously compromised," a Cabinet committee reported today.

Thirty years ago this week, the stock market collapsed and the Great Depression was in the making. Black Tuesday, Oct. 29, 1929, was one of those milestones in history. A record 16,410,030 shares were traded -- 5,000,000 in a single hour -and billions of dollars of values were wiped away.

THE barber, who used to be accused of nothing more serious than talking too much, has had a brush with the law. New York State's Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz recently announced that the barbering industry was possibly violating antitrust laws, and that the Anti-Monopolies Bureau would investigate. The charge: local price-fixing of haircuts under union-employer contracts.

THIS is a pleasing selection from an enormous wealth. Its originality consists in being "the first anthology to present only medieval poetry in translation in a broader than national scope." Hubert Creekmore's claim is, I think, justified.

AN international exhibition, "Photography at MidCentury," representing about 250 contemporary photographers, and celebrating the tenth anniversary of George Eastman House as an international museum of photography, will open at the museum on Nov. 9, the anniversary date.

CAIRO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- An intensive search is under way for two Americans, two Frenchmen and their local guide who have been reported lost in Egypt's vast Nubian Desert. The Aswan police said the guide was ignorant of the area.

The Society of Actuaries, most of whose members are in the field of life insurance, published last week a report on its twenty-year study of body build and blood pressure. The survey, described by the Institute of Life Insurance as "by far the most extensive statistical investigation ever undertaken in the health field," is based on vital statistics provided by several million insured individuals.

NIERSTEIN, Germany, Oct. 24 -- Man, woman and child are working toward the last rows of the golden vineyards of Rhenish Hesse this week-end confident that they are harvesting one of the great grape crops of the postwar years.

GREENWICH, Conn. Oct. 24 -- Mrs. Hawley T. Chester Jr., president of the Greenwich Exchange for Women's Work, has announced that the annual Christmas sale will be held Nov. 18 and 19 at the Round Hill Club here.

IN her review of "The Choice to Love," Anne Fremantle finds it hard to understand my title and a few other choices of word. She finds "the choice to love" ambiguous, and asks, "to love what?" Well, it's like the choice to eat.

SINCE tuna is so familiar on most of the nation's tables, it is surprising to realize that the food was almost unheard of in this country until the turn of the century. One source says that not until the Federal Government became interested in creating a new industry did tuna come into general use.

There is a direct relation between religion and the United Nations, the Rev. Dr. David B. Kahane asserted yesterday. Both, the rabbi said, seek to lift man's vision above self-centered nationalism to ideals that are "nothing less than universal."

The number of American high schools teaching Russian has grown from "practically nothing" in 1957 to 313 in 1959, according to Dr. Fan Parker, director of The Modern Language Association of America. ARTHUR GODFREY, who returned to television last month with a special onehour program, may star in a second show to be presented in January by the Columbia Broadcasting System. After the star recovered from his cancer operation, he said he would do at least one, and possibly four, shows this season. Now there are reports that he may consider even more.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -The popular agreement that the Taft-Hartley Act's emergency procedures failed to meet the country's needs in the steel strike has started this capital groping once more for a substitute.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 -- Is the fifteen-week-old steel strike a threat to the national health and safety? That is the pivotal question of fact involved in President Eisenhower's effort to halt the costly tie-up through an injunction under the national emergency provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Morgan Phillips, secretary of the Labor party, advised trade unionists tonight to show "greater self-discipline" if the labor movement was to overcome the political exploitation by its enemies of unofficial strikes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24--The Secretaries of State, Defense and the Treasury met at the State Department today to discuss critical problems of overseas military costs.

LAST Nov. 25 The Christian Science Monitor, which finds a place on almost anybody's list of good newspapers, celebrated its fiftieth birthday. The event was celebrated by publication of a history of The Monitor by its current editor, Erwin D. Canham.

THE large-flowered hybrid gloxinias, with their velvety leaves and neat growth habit, are finding their way into more and more house plant collections. They are available in shades ranging from soft pink to dark red, pale orchid, honey, near-blue, purest white or white edged with pink or red -- some are speckled, some ruffled.

IF anyone has the impression that the makers of American films have surrendered to excesses of violence and the fatal influences of Brigitte Bardot, he should take heed of four new pictures that were additions to the screen fare here last week.
A manufacturer in Illinois decided recently to open an export sales agency in Nassau, the Bahamas. Within two weeks he was in business.

THERE is a growing library of books by former Communists disillusioned with their dreams, and to this library "The Undefeated" is a significant contribution. In it one can read of the smashed aspirations of those liberal Hungarian intellectuals who, in revolt against the feudal ugliness of pre-war society in their country, hitched their wagons to the Marxist star.

MILTON CRANE'S review of George Goodman's "The Wheeler Dealers" contains the phrase, "If the American Edward Johnson had to become Eduardo Giovanelli in order to obtain a hearing at the Metropolitan * * * ." The Canadian tenor Edward Johnson (18811959) used the pseudonym Edoardo di Giovanni toward the beginning of his career in Italy.

Two theatre parties will be given this season for the benefit of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, which is celebrating its sixty-fifth anniversary.

MONEY is a commodity that people in Hollywood seem to enjoy talking about almost as much as they enjoy earning. No other art form has been so concerned with economics. This week money talk was a particularly difficult subject to avoid with the announcement that Elizabeth Taylor would receive $1,000,000 against a percentage of the gross for her role in Twentieth Century-Fox' "Cleopatra."

FOR Maurice Edelman this has been a good month. Good month? It has been extraordinary. In the first place, in spite of the Conservative landslide in Britain, Mr. Edelman was returned as Labor M. P. by his constituents in Coventry- -he has been that for the last fifteen years.
The techniques of a craft that has made a large public feel apprehensive will be exposed at a panel program tomorrow at 8 P. M. by two veteran "who-dunit" writers, Hugh Pentecost and Rex Stout.

College teachers are becoming a scarce commodity. As this happens, the economic law of supply and demand begins to go into effect: the professors' value goes up, both in public esteem and on the price tag. But as usually happens when shortage hits an important item, those who can afford it are ready to pay more; those who can't try to get along with less expensive substitutes.

THE young British popular historian, Christopher Hibbert, has written a fresh and vivid short account of the capture of Quebec in 1759 by the 32-year-old James Wolfe. Mr. Hibbert, a disciple of the Lytton Strachey school of historical writing, has combined the story, of the decisive battle in the Anglo-French war for empire in North America with a new psychological interpretation of the young general whose oddity gave rise to rumors of madness.
TRENTON, Oct. 24 -- The referendum on the use of surplus funds of the New Jersey Turnpike to aid distressed commuter railroads has seized the spotlight in the political campaign in this state.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 24 -Landlords seeking to rent living quarters to Yale students must sign nondiscrimination agreements before their properties will be listed by the university's housing bureau.
JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 24 -The State Board of Education's temporary ban on circulation of a film on tolerance donated by the Mississippi branch of B'nai B'rith was made permanent this week.

AMONG the horse stories that just won't stay on library shelves because of the children's demand are C. W. Anderson's "Billy and Blaze" books, and this Western sequel to "Blaze and Thunderbolt" is bound to have its following even though it does not do justice to its material.

JUST about six years ago, a medical research team investigating children's fitness issued a report that caused considerable concern among many who read it. The report indicated that America's children, judging on the basis of standardized tests of muscular strength and flexibility, were far less fit physically than European youngsters.

It is a little less than eleven years since Puerto Rico chose its first elective Governor. This was Luis Munoz Marin, who still holds the office. Senor Munoz Marin, in conference with excellent advisers in Puerto Rico and here, worked out what is known, for lack of a better term, as a commonwealth status. This arrangement was overwhelmingly accepted by popular vote in 1952 and continues to this day.

At first glance, there would seem to be no clear connection between a professorship of geography at the University of Puerto Rico, and the skyscrapers of Wall Street. But that would be an optical illusion if one knew Dr. Rafael Pico.

ARCHAEOLOGY is a science which, at the outset, seems beyond the reach and even the comprehension of the average man. The first great archaeologists were far from average men, and their discoveries and conclusions raised questions for which even trained historians often had no answers.

FEW men can lay claim to so many qualifications for writing about hunting and fishing as Larry Koller, whose "The Fireside Book of Guns" (Simon and Schuster, $9.85) is just out. In his way, Koller is a nonpareil.
Liberty was sounded for crew members of the Maury before noon yesterday at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.
HAVANA, Oct. 24 -- About forty persons were arrested in Havana as the Government began a round-up of anti-Castro elements throughout the island.

THIS long, lively, often witty novel will hold almost any reader, and will disappoint many. It shows how Bascomb McGoslin, a product of the New York slums who chose to become a priest, found himself mistaken in his vocation.

IT has become almost impossible to discuss communism in American education with any degree of realism and objectivity. It may have been partly the heat of the topic, partly the American weakness for oversimplification; the fact is that it was "liberal" to deny that Communist infiltration existed, just as it was "patriotic" to proclaim every blackboard a Red menace.
PARIS, Oct. 24 -- Twenty-two of the thirty-four Senators representing Algeria and the Sahara expressed full support today for President Charles de Gaulle's policy of self-determination in Algeria.
GENEVA, Oct. 21--Every needy Jew in Poland is assured of a daily supply of food, Charles H. Jordan, director general of the American Joint Distribution Committee, said here.
The Roman Catholic hierarchy of Colombia reportedly has advised parishioners of La Plata, Huila Department, to make restitution for damage they caused to Protestant church property there.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 24 -- Sparked by the ever-dependable Hugh Scott, Princeton ground out a convincing 20-to-0 victory over Cornell this afternoon and thereby remained in the running for the Ivy League title.

Department store sales in the nation in the week ended on Oct. 17 were 10 per cent above the 1958 level, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. This compared with a gain of 3 per cent in the prior week from the year before.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -Premier Fidel Castro's latest attacks upon the United States have created apprehension in the State Department. Yet the reaction is more one of sorrow than of anger.

Present attitudes of college students are far from inspiring, and the colleges are doing little to improve them, according to a survey by Dr. Edward D. Eddy Jr., vice president of the University of New Hampshire. He also found that many colleges are "just not delivering on their exaggerated claims."

THE first value we should teach, I think, is the value of an individual, which is infinite and infinitely increasable. Someone has pointed out that a pig of iron is worth $5.00; if it is made into horseshoes, it is worth $10.50; if it has been refined and tempered and shaped into needles, it is worth $3,500; but if it has been fashioned into balance springs for watches, it is worth $25,000.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Social agencies in Northern Westchester will benefit from proceeds of the annual Holiday Ball of the Junior League of Mount Kisco, Inc. The bail will be given on Dec. 12 at the Fox Lane School in Bedford. Special entertainment will be provided by the Yale Alley Cats, a group of undergraduate singers.

IN many ways Andre Derain (1880-1954) was an artist's artist. His swift succession of styles, his rampant eclecticism and his volatile temperament puzzled and irritated art critics. Not so the artists. They understood Derain's vagaries and, above all, admired his extraordinary skill.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- The Central Intelligence Agency, so hush-hush that it once would not give out its telephone number, is getting ready for the biggest public splash in its thirteen-year history.

In the dozen years that the Taft-Hartley law has been on the books, its emergency provisions have been invoked seventeen times. In the first sixteen of those cases the Federal courts granted the injunctions sought by the Government; never did the Government face a definitive challenge.

RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 24 -Luther H. Hodges. Governor of North Carolina, who is looked upon here as North Carolina's first salesman, plans to lead a group of sixty-five Tar Heel business and political leaders on a two-week trip to Europe for the purpose of improving business ties between European countries and this state.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 24 --Pakistan's military regime will celebrate its first anniversary Tuesday in an atmosphere of satisfaction and hope.
CAIRO, Oct. 20 -- The diplomatic cocktail party has become the most sensitive barometer in Cairo of international cordiality.

The Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New York will hold its sixty-second annual banquet on Nov. 12 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria DeWitt Lounsberry is chairman of the committee arranging the event, which will be followed by a ball.

IT is dark and eerie. The shadow of a tree is a looming witch; the scraping of a branch, a sure sign of prowling ghosts; a black cat means danger. Why, of course, it's Halloween! This is the time of year when young children want to believe in magic, and this season's crop of Halloween tales abounds in magic.

LIBERTYVILLE, Ill., Oct. 21 -- The quietest corner of the Democratic party these days is Adlai Stevenson's farm. It looks like an English gentleman's park, and the squire, who will be 60 in February, looks more and more like an English gentleman.
NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Oklahoma became the top team in the Big Eight Conference by gaining a 7-6 victory over the Kansas Jayhawks before 50,000 fans at Owen Stadium today.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 24 -Champ Volo, a Canadian pacer driven by Philip Dussault, scored a three-quarter-length victory over Grand R. Volo before 27,610 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

FOR THIS WEEK: The leaves are coming down; keep the rakes busy and build the compost pile higher and higher. . . . Store the jack-o'-lantern pumpkin in a cool, dry place until its face is carved. . . . Finish cleaning up around perennials. It is much too early to put on a protective mulch. . . . Finish potting up bulbs for indoor forcing.

WE expect a good deal of Nicholas Monsarrat, author of "The Cruel Sea," whatever he may offer us. This time it is a collection of ten short stories, most of which originally came out in magazines of wide circulation in this country and England.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- Yale's perfect record -- unbeaten, untied and unscored upon -- remained intact on a muddy and messy gridiron today. Before 11,000 fans at Yale Bowl, the Bulldogs gained their footing late in the second period and rolled to a 21-0 victory over Colgate under the worst weather conditions of the season.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 24 -- The United States team won its fourth straight event and the international jumping team championship of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight.

LISBON, Oct. 18 -- From 500 to 1,000 Portuguese a day have been crowding into the United States consulate here to request visas under eased regulations covering close relatives of persons already in America.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 24 -Mrs. Frank A. Genter's 2-yearold chestnut filly, My Dear Girl, the 4-1 third choice, won the $13,215 Gardenia Stakes at Garden State today. She led all the way and scored by five lengths.

Retailers aired some of their problems last week at the annual Boston Conference on Distribution. This was only fitting and proper inasmuch as retailers represent the show-case and consumer-contact phase of distribution.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 24 -- To his several lineal titles Jeffery John Archer Amherst added today the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws.

VENICE, Fla. -- The Florida Quadricentennial, celebrating 400 years of history under five flags, which was inaugurated at Pensacola last summer, moves to Sarasota County this winter. It will reopen there on Dec. 13 and run until next April, when it will shift to a new site.

Employment in Illinois during August declined sharply from July as the impact of the strike-bound steel industry more than offset seasonal gains in the food processing and construction industries. State Employment Service totals showed 3,411,800 persons employed in other than agricultural pursuits, compared with 3,426,000 in July.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 24 -- A two-day election that is expected to bring white-haired Olafur Thors back into office as Premier of Iceland will begin tomorrow.

IF the Metropolitan Opera continues to ride the tide of prosperity in the new season opening tomorrow night, it may surpass last season's triumph, when it reduced its operating deficit to $528,873.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Oct. 24 --The famed brigantine Yankee is at its berth at Island Service Wharf being serviced and supplied for what may finally develop into another trip around the world -- not as a passenger carrying cruise ship but as a student-manned yacht.

The Association for the Help of Retarded Children will benefit from the Nov. 11 evening performance of "Take Me Along" at the Shubert Theatre. The musical stars Jackie Gleason and Walter Pidgeon.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 25 -- The American Bankers Association will not ask that commercial banks be permitted to pay a higher interest on savings deposits, Lee P. NEW DELHI, Oct. 25 (Reuters) -- Growing public anger here over Chinese Communist actions on India's northern borders was reflected in newspapers. Several editorials have urged the Government to stand up to the Chinese.

Reformation Sunday was observed yesterday by Protestant churches over the city. The observance, sponsored nationally by the department of evangelism of the National Council of Churches, marked the 442d anniversary of Martin Luther's ninety-five theses.

Before the mill can get to any semblance of balanced steel output, regardless of what developments follow the Kaiser Steel Corporation's separate peace with the steelworkers, the country will be at the bottom of the barrel as far as steel supplies are concerned.
The leaves on the trees that grow in New York aren't falling quickly enough to suit the Department of Sanitation.

Two days after the opening of "The Miracle Worker" last Monday, William Gibson, still glowing from the unanimous praise showered by critics on his new Broadway drama, plunged into rehearsals for an off-Broadway play.
James H. Curtis, president of the Chemical Construction Corporation, is in Tokyo building a big new plant. Mr. Curtis is a man on the go at the head of acompany on the go.
Final steps toward the long-term storage of whole blood have been outlined by the leading scientists and engineers in the work.
Seventeen chanting, bearded bishops consecrated a former Park Avenue mansion yesterday as headquarters of the Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia.

Continuing Chinese Communist pressure on India's frontiers has put Prime Minister Nehru in an increasingly difficult position. After last week's border foray, in which a number of Indians were killed, Mr. Nehru has felt obliged to state even more forcefully than previously that such outrages could not be tolerated and that India would be obliged to "stand firm."
A poll of 1,700 business executives revealed today that 76 per cent of them favored Vice President Richard M. Nixon for President in 1960 and 11 per cent favored Governor Rockefeller of New York.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 -- A two-year contract providing for a minimum wage of $125 a week for members of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra was announced today.

NEWARK, Oct. 25 -- Bob Watson scored both touchdowns as St. Benedict's defeated Mount St. Michael of the Bronx, 14 -- 12, today. The visitors had been undefeated and unscored upon in three games, while the victory was the fourth straight for St. Benedict's.
About 10,000 persons turned out yesterday to see for themselves the startling building that Frank Lloyd Wright designed to house the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on upper Fifth Avenue.
HAVANA, Oct. 25 -- The Government continued today to whip up anti-United States sentiment as Cubans prepared to demonstrate in protest against an "air attack" said to have originated from Florida.

Considerable space has been devoted to Morne (Gump) Worsley and his chances to remain the New York Rangers' goalie. In the New Yorkers' 3-1 National Hockey League victory over the Chicago Black Hawks last night at Madison Square Garden, Gump proved he was the Worsley of old.

NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Boston College rushed Marquette's passers relentlessly and utilized the quick kick today for a 16-0 football victory. The loss was the sixth straight for Marquette.

Mitch Leigh, creative head and president of Music Makers, Inc., composers of television music and jingles for commercials, can't afford to be superstitious. Two of the most important assignments of his career take place on Nov. 13 and Dec. 13.
DETROIT, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Bernie Geoffrion's goal with less than two minutes left won for the Montreal Canadiens, 2 -- 1, tonight and knocked the Detroit Red Wings from the unbeaten ranks.
Cotton moved irregularly and grains rose generally last week in commodity futures trading.

The Soviet Union has begun to produce some machine tools more cheaply and quickly than the West, an American researcher reported yesterday. If current trends persist, he said, the Russians could capture the markets for basic machinery in Latin America, Asia and Africa.
The Department of Welfare said yesterday that it had received a letter last week enclosing a check for $4,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A Roman Catholic group urged today that Americans never be lulled into forgetting that the essential difference between the United States and the Soviet Union was the amount of freedom each offered its citizens.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 25 -- Some 5,167 commercial banks in the United States have subscribed $670,000 to the 1960 National Advertising Campaign of the Foundation for Commercial Banks, Morris H. Brownell, chairman, reported today Mr. Brownell, vice president of the Philadelphia National Bank, said the campaign Would stress the theme of a commercial bank as a "full service bank" in contrast to institutions that offer savings and mortgage services only.

There is no doubt that some persons were hurt in the streets of Havana last Wednesday night at about the time that an airplane passed over the city dropping anti-Castro leaflets. There is some question as to whether the damage was done by the intruding airplane, by gangsters who fired indiscriminately on the crowds from speeding motor cars or by the efforts of the Cuban Air Force to bring the trespasser down.
GUATEMALA, Oct. 25 -- There is widespread concern here that President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes is overplaying his hand in attempting to break up his Leftist opposition.
The Waterfront Commission has drafted new regulations-designed to furnish for the first time an accurate accounting of theft at piers in the Port of New York.

JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 25 -- Economic experts from the twenty-one nations and colonies that are members of the Colombo Plan will open fourteen days of meetings here tomorrow. The aim is to bring a better life to the 700,000,000 people of South and Southeast Asia.

" The World of Carl Sandburg," co-starring Bette Davis and Gary Merrill, was presented over the week-end at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The program, consisting of selections from Mr. sandburg's poetry, prose and song collection, was adapted and directed by Norman Corwin. Clark Allen, guitarist and vocalist, assisted Miss Davis and Mr. Merrill.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 25 -- The bitter protests of Left-wing student nationalists have forced a halt in the United States-financed technical assistance program to Argentina's national universities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The International Monetary Fund told the nations of the non-Communist world today that they no longer had any financial justification for maintaining special restrictions against the import of United States goods.

WHEN the world series reached California for the first time a few weeks ago, a Los Angeles baseball writer turned to a San Francisco baseball writer and pointed at the sprawling sunbowl that is O'Malley's Alley.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 -- Put into command in the first half by the offensive platoon and kept there in the second by the detense, the New York Giants today overcame stubborn resistance and defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers, 21 -- 16, before 33.596 in the rain at Forbes Field.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 25 -- Somewhere in Hollywood men are at work under tight security wraps preparing the latest weapon that movie producer-director William Castle will use in his battle for the public's entertainment dollar.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Lanky R. C. Owens leaped high and hauled down a 46-yard touchdown pass from Y. A. Tittle with sixty-one seconds remaining today to give the San Francisco 49ers a 20-17 victory over the Chicago Bears.
The State Thruway Authority will provide limited free emergency service to stranded motorists by the end of this year.
The recent announcement by Mayor Wagner that a study would be made of the feasibility of establishing central relocation bureau in New York City is gratifying news.
Significant changes in the control of power by both major political parties can result from this year's upstate elections, even though the offices involved are primarily local.

Giuseppe Verdi's "Il Trovatore" was the opera chosen for the third performance at the glittering-new Metropolitan Opera House on Oct. 26, 1853. Now, precisely seventy-six years to the day of its first Met production, it will open the house's new season tonight.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 -- Carson/Roberts Incorporated believes in practicing the advice it gives to clients -- it advertises itself.

An auxiliary group of younger members has been organized to aid with the planning of two theatre parties which will benefit the Play Schools Association. They will take place at the evening performances on Dec. 7 and 16 of Robert Andersons "Silent Night, Lonely Night," which opens at the Morosco Theatre Dec. 3.
GREENVILLE, S. C., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Jackie Robinson was involved in an incident in the white waiting room of the Greenville airport today.
The city will be able to balance its expense budget for the next fiscal year without any new or increased special taxes, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.
OSWEGO, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Although Oswego was not one of the upstate communities where the State Police staged gambling raids on Friday, crime and police corruption dominate the political talk here.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Still riding the momentum given investment buying by the election results, the stock market closed last week strong and active.
ALBANY, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Hunters by the carload piled into the Adirondacks today for the opening of the annual open season on deer and bear.
Seven houses on a plot 135 by 100 feet at 212 to 224 East Sixtieth Street have been purchased by a syndicate of investors represented by Riker Co.
ALGIERS, Oct. 25 -- The solid front of European opposition here to President Charles de Gaulle's plan for Algerian self-determination is beginning to crumble.
The United States Post Office is considering expanding its limited test program of moving first-class mail by air.

THE first words of Latin most of us learned when young were "Amo, amas, amat." But what those words mean in either an ancient or a modern tongue has never been certain. Leaving aside love of God, country, beauty, relatives and filet mignon, it is still plain that one man does not love his wife (or his secretary) in the same way as he loves another.
The strength of the Soviet Union as a tin producer has been emphasized by the recent construction of what is probably one of the world's northernmost tin processing plants.

This continent, as large as Europe plus Australia, is the world's last laboratory for devising a code to govern the international rule of space. Several nations claim slices of Antarctic land but these titles receive no formal recognition. Neither the United States nor Russia, the two superpowers, has filed specific territorial demands and neither acknowledges the claims of other countries.

New York's lengthy and detailed State Constitution will grow longer and more detailed through voter action on nine amendments Nov. 3. A built-in need to amend is one of the major defects of the Constitution, referring back to the people many questions of government that should be the responsibility of the Legislature or of local government.

IN one of New York's myriad Chinese restaurants Gerald Clark, a Canadian, dined on Chinese food prepared American-style and discussed its equivalent in Communist China. Mr. Clark is a correspondent for The Montreal Star.

Complaints filed with the State Commission Against Discrimination in the last nine months increased 9.4 per cent over the same period a year ago, Elmer A. Carter, commission chairman, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Administration is about to assemble the microscope it will put on the steel industry to find out what, if anything, basically ails its union-management relations.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25 -- (UPI) -- A Soviet surgeon, Vladimir Demikhov, who has produced a two-headed dog, said today that he was preparing to give a second heart to a human patient suffering from heart disease. Dr. Demikhov has already given two dogs extra hearts in preparation for the surgery.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- The International Atomic Energy Agency reported gains in its program and increased usefulness to member states in its third report issued here today.

CAIRO, Oct. 25 -- The United Arab Republic accepted today an apology by Communist China for an incident that two weeks ago further strained relations between the two countries.

MEDFORD. N. J., Oct. 25-Urchin, a 3-year-old white-and-black English setter owned and handled by Dr. Pillip J. Kunderman of New Brunswick. N. J., won the Amateur all-age stage as the English Setter Club of America completed its annual fall field trial today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Eisenhower returned to the White House late this afternoon after a two-hour flight from Augusta, Ga., where he enjoyed a five-day respite from official routine in golfing and relaxation.

IT is usually the parents who establish a youngster's standards of speech, according to William Finkel, speech therapist at the Edenwald School of the Jewish Child Care Association. Parents who take a dim view of their children's speech often have only themselves to blame.

TOKYO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Gen. Nam Il, who represented Communist North Korea in the negotiations at Panmunjom that brought a cease-fire in the Korean War, has been relieved of his job as Foreign Minister.

A DUMMY-PLAYER in the vernacular of bridge experts, is one who has special aptitude for playing both deceptively and perceptively when he is declarer. He must, of course, be a finished technician, but that is not considered as one of his special qualifications. Every bridge expert is supposed to be that.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Two enterprising commodity brokers here have decided that there is enough interest in the United States markets to justify their staying open until closing time in New York, which varies, but is not now later than 8:30 P. M. in London.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Politicians expect to get a good indication in January on how seriously Senator Lyndon B. Johnson intends to pursue the Democratic Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas cited a General Accounting Office report on disposal of Government surplus goods today as proof that there was "scandalous" waste in Federal procurement and surplus property disposal.

Theodore Roscoe, author of detective stories and histories of the Navy, has a work of nonfiction and another of fiction scheduled for publication six days apart. ZINO FRANCESCATTI gave his only recital of the season on Saturday evening at Hunter College. The eminent French violinist built his program around three works -- Beethoven's "Kreutzer" Sonata, the Bach Chaconne and the Debussy Sonata.

Fundamental Investors, Inc., reported over the week-end that its net assets on Sept. 30 were more than $100,000,000 above those of a year ago, but some $20,000,000 less than on June 30. The New York Central Railroad sustained a net loss of $2,305,746 last month. The September loss reduced the system's profits for the first nine months of this year to $3,403,765, or 52 cents a share. In September, 1958, the carrier cleared $1,907,498, but incurred a deficit of $8,443,064 in the first nine months, largely because of the recession.
The Massachusetts Investors Trust, oldest and largest openend investment company in the country, had net assets of $1,497,272,607 on Sept. 30. This compared with $1,295,283,816 a year earlier.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Economic circles were confident tonight that by next week Britain would scrap virtually all remaining restrictions on importation of dollar goods.
A young man who waged a court battle to give up a $350,000 legacy from his father and then petitioned successfully to get it back, yesterday received the right to spend it.

Joe Cronin, president of the American League, formally notified Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick yesterday that his league "planned to expand in the future." WITH honorable intentions, the "Hallmark Hall of Fame," offered a live television production of the late Maxwell Anderson's drama "Winterset" on Channel 4 last night.

The most pressing problem facing colleges and universities in this country is to attract adeuate financial support, Dr. Carroll V. Newsom said last night in his annual report to New York University's board of trustees.

LANSING, Oct. 26 (UPI) -Michigan faces lay-offs of at least 7,500 state workers and a "catastrophic" reduction in services if new revenue is not found, a cash-disaster plan presented to Gov. G. Mennen Williams revealed today.
The International Brotherhood of Longshoremen, once hailed as the one hope pier workers had of clean trade unionism, will meet this week, probably to vote itself out of existence.

DETROIT, Oct. 26 -- Consumers are buying cars as if the manufacturers weren't going to make them tomorrow, which is almost correct. Ward's Automotive Reports said today that the selling rate during the middle third of October exceeded that for any ten-day period in October, November or December since 1955.
Fifteen-year-old Peter Manceri, accused of punching and kicking an elderly man to death in a Brooklyn park last summer, was acquitted last night Kings County court jury.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- (UPI) -- Two Washington State University professors won today Supreme Court consideration of their challenge to the state's loyalty oath requirement.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 27 -The United States demanded today that other nations take immediate steps to end trade barriers.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 26 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner came out today for a new lam aimed at curbing securities funds. Addressing the eleventh annual National Mutual Fund Dealers Conference in the Traymore Hotel here, Governor Meyner said his administration would back "a uniform securities bill to modernize our existing law which was passed thirty-two years ago."

RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 26 -The Moroccan Government plans to establish a permanent free port at Tangier and to develop the port facilities to make this former international city Morocco's main gateway to Mediterranean trade.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Oct. 26 -- A suit for $2,500,000 brought by the Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission against six contractors was dismissed today by Bergen County Judge Arthur J. O'Dea.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) reported yesterday estimated consolidated earnings for the first nine months of 1959 at $477,000,000, equal to $2.22 each on the 214,967,000 shares outstanding. Total revenues were $6,020,000,000.

With all four of the games adjourned in the twenty-seventh and semi-final round of the chess challengers' tournament last night, no changes took place in the standing, according to a report from Belgrade. The games will be played off today.

THOSE planning to entertain this fall, be it a sumptuous Thanksgiving dinner or an informal luncheon, might cull a few tips from the Tiffany table settings that go on view today. All were designed by New York hostesses well versed in the art of party-giving.
