PLAINFIELD, N. J., Oct. 26 -- New Jersey overwhelmed Philadelphia, 89 to 28, in the third annual professional golf challenge matches at the Plainfield Country Club today. New Jersey won eleven of the thirteen matches.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (UPI) -Membership in the Methodist Church in the United States increased by 1.27 per cent to a total of 9,815,459 members during the last year, it was announced today. The church's annual statistical report also showed that the number of organized Methodist churches in the United States, Cuba and Puerto Rico had dropped to 39,236 -- eighty-one less than a year ago.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 26 -Antonio Cardinal Caggiano took the Constitutional oath as eighth Archbishop of Buenos Aires today in a civil ceremony that was boycotted by the Papal Nuncio, Msgr. Umberto Mozzoni.
Three colleges in this area put their newest additions on public display yesterday. One of them surprised its president by giving his name to a new $3,300,000 library-administration building.

A group of residents in the Cooper Square area said yesterday they would seek the help of the City Planning Commission to force major changes in the slum redevelopment proposed for their neighborhood.

Louisiana State and Northwestern remained one, two yesterday in United Press International's major college football ratings for the fifth straight week. Mississippi moved into third place prior to its Saturday night clash with L. S. U.

The New York Rangers, in an effort to bolster their defense, yesterday acquired Noel Price from the Toronto Maple Leafs. To obtain the 23-year-old player, the Rangers traded three skaters to the Maple Leafs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: From your Oct. 18 edition, reporting on the recent conference of the American Assembly, it appears that I did not make myself clear on the subject of United States intervention. A short written statement, issued at Arden House, was quoted out of context.
MANHASSET, L. I., Oct. 26 -- The 133-year-old Little Brown School in the Valley, Long Island's oldest remaining public elementary school building, was reopened here today as a shrine.
An unsigned, unwitnessed document purporting to be the last will and testament of Errol FIynn was filed with Surrogate S. Samuel Di Falco yesterday.
Sponsors of radio and television programs were urged today to adopt a "hands-off entertainment code" to prevent further deceptions such as those recently uncovered in TV quiz shows.
Eddie Arcaro and Willie Shoemaker were fined $200 apiece by the stewards at Aqueduct yesterday for taking an impromptu Caribbean vacation last week.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 27 -The Soviet Union released today what it said was man's first picture of the hidden side of the moon.

PIRAEUS, Greece, Oct. 26 (Reuters) -- Greek shipowners and the National Maritime Union of the United States agreed today to submit a dispute on union representation rights to the International Transport Workers Federation.

To centralize its research, Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday plans for a university-type quadrangle around a central court and ornamental pool ten miles outside of Pittsburgh's metropolitan area, in Churchill Borough.
With poise and with serious-faced humor, two boys were the show stealers here last night as the Young Men's Christian Association opened its 1960 fundraising campaign.

The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy has ordered a reappraisal of the American contribution toward the "atoms for peace" program, launched by President Eisenhower, that found its first fruition in the creation of the International Atomic Energy Agency. The agency ended its third general conference in Vienna recently on a high note of confidence that it will become the clearing house for peaceful atomic knowledge and materials for all nations.
The "Person to Person" television show will begin presenting interviews from England early in December.
The National Steel Corporation and the Armco Steel Corporation reported yesterday declines in sales and earnings in the third quarter as a result of the steel strike.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -Two economists testified today that the-growth of the national economy should be stimulated largely by measures other than increased spending by the Federal Government.

Space for a branch office has been leased by the Chemical New York Trust Company in the Mid City Center office building now under construction at Sixty-fourth Road and Queens Boulevard in Rego Park, Queens, it has been announced by Julien J. Studley, Inc., renting agent for the building.

The Metropolitan Opera opened its seventy-fifth season last night at its old home on Broadway, and Rudolf Bing, the general manager, estimated that there would probably be at least three more such openings at the maroon and gold Victorian opera house.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A spokesman for the President's Committee of Government Contracts said today that qualified Negro workmen were being denied jobs on three major Federal projects in Washington.

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa yesterday renewed his attack on the school bond amendment by asserting that the city could provide $100,000,000 a year for school construction without exceeding the debt limit.

The nine-store taxpayer building on the block bounded by Grace, Strang and Baychester Avenues and 233d Street in the Bronx has been sold by Woodbury Estates, Inc., to a client of Milton Gerber, lawyer.

The National Biscuit Company (Nabisco) voted yesterday to increase its quarterly dividend from 50 cents to 60 cents, effective Jan. 15. The 50-cent quarterly dividend had been in effect since April, 1950.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 26 -- Kenson D. Merrill, a former member of the Brookhaven Town Board, was fined $15,000 and received a suspended prison sentence here today for having taken bribes to rezone property through special uses.
A lack of steel has halted construction of the new lower deck of the George Washington Bridge.

There is an interesting coincidence in connection with the present opening of the Eleventh Conference of the Consultative Committee of the Colombo Plan. At the same time that these economic experts from twenty-one nations are meeting in Indonesia to discuss how to make aid plans work more effectively there is word from Rangoon that Burma will discontinue present Soviet aid projects as being too luxurious.
The nation's most-traveled football player was in town yesterday to arrange for television appearances. He is Brad Hustad of Luther College, Decorah, Iowa.

How is it feasible for New York State, under Rockefeller policy, to move toward a pay-as-wego basis on capital construction and be applauded for it, while New York City must seek borrowing power enlarged beyond constitutional limits for school construction and be encouraged by those who endorse Amendment No. 4?

FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- A third court hearing will be held to determine whether an American-made phonograph record of Nazi songs and speeches can be put back on sale in West Germany, court officials said today.
The Department of Buildings began inspecting a part of the northern fringe of the Ninth Assembly District in Manhattan yesterday at the request of the Lexington Democratic Club.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- General of the Army George C. Marshall fought with the White House over the way secret, decoded messages were being passed around during World War II.

AUBURN, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Governor Rockefeller made a flying four-hour visit to this Central New York city today to bolster the election chances of the Republican candidate for Mayor, a business man he had personally induced to accept the nomination.
CAIRO, Oct. 26 -- An Egyptian frontier patrol reported today that it had found the bodies of one American and two Frenchmen missing in the Nubian desert of upper Egypt since July.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 26 -- The Writers Guild of America has received support from among the ranks of independent movie producers in its two-week-old strike against fifty-six independent movie producers.

The formation of the Burlington Yarn Company as a new division and the appointment of E. A. Hamrick Jr. as division president were announced today by Walter E. Greer Jr., senior vice president of Burlington Industries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The United States had only two atomic bombs when the decision was made to drop them on Japan in World War II, according to a posthumously published interview with General of the Army George C. Marshall.
JOHN STEINBECK'S poetic drama, "Burning Bright," was given an impressive, tender performance last night on Channel 13.
PEIPING, Oct. 26 (Reuters) -- Communist China declared today that it had told India it was prepared to release ten Indian border policemen captured in a Chinese-Indian border clash last week.
The general public as well as business men soon will be able to send, by Western Union, facsimiles of full page correspondence, letter size documents, drawings and other recorded data.
The city's largest medical society offered its advice and help yesterday to labor unions in their plans to become sponsors of hospitals and medical schools.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Garden State Park officials disclosed today that $3,000 in counterfeit $10 mutuel tickets were passed at the track Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Interest rates on today's shortterm borrowing by the Government showed further evidence of the recent strength in the money market.
Investment bankers headed by Cruttenden, Podesta Co., Chicago, are offering today 250,000 shares of class A common stock of the Buckingham Freight Lines The price is $10 a share.
A machine to read handwritten words has been built at the Bell Telephone Laboratories.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 26 -- President Mohammed Ayub Khan promulgated legislation today that he hopes will soon give Pakistan a democratic government.

That pedestrians live dangerously, assuming they live at all, is nothing new. It may be that, ever since the invention of the wheel, living dangerously has been one of the occupational hazards of pedestrianism.
The Manhattan Consort is a group of musical and versatile young men and women who perform on a variety of old instruments.
The Air Force Academy football team will have a lonely end offense to match Army's when the service teams clash in Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

Sales and earnings of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company in the three months that ended on Sept. 30 were the highest for any quatrer in the company's history, according to a report issued today by F. G. Carter, president.

HAVANA, Oct. 26 -- Premier Fidel Castro, armed with a rifle, dropped out of the skies in a helicopter late this afternoon at the Presidential Palace, where between 300,000 and 400,000 persons had gathered to protest "aggression" from the United States.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 26 -- President Rajendra Prasad has been urged to summon an emergency session of Parliament to discuss Chinese pressure on India's northern border.

JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 26 -- The eleventh Colombo Plan conference, dedicated to aiding the one-quarter of the world's population inhabiting South and Southeast Asia, opened today in this historic Javanese city of 300,000 people and a subsistence-level standard of living.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 26 -- Advocates of economic austerity scored gains tonight in first returns from the two-day Icelandic parliamentary election.
A negotiating session yesterday between metropolitan milk dealers and teamster unions produced "slow progress" toward a new contract, a union spokesman said.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 26 -- President Eisenhower's chief economic adviser urged the nation's bankers today to help prevent a great new expansion of consumer installment credit similar to the one that, he said, led to the downturn of 1957-58.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- The Western powers asked the Soviet Union today to join them in sponsoring a revised General Assembly resolution on disarmament.

VIENNA, Oct. 26 -- Hungary is expected to demand the return of part of the Hungarian crown jewels that are believed to have been thrown into an arm of the Danube on the AustrianCzech border near the end of World War II.
Sales of the Continental Can Company rose to new highs in the quarter and nine-month periods that ended on Sept. 30, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman, reported yesterday.
It would seem that the New York horse racing enthusiast is indifferent as to the starting time for the first race. All he's concerned with is a chance to get some "action."

TWO museum shows of exceptional interest appear in this week's heavy program of exhibitions. One is "Five Centuries of Drawings" at Cooper Union Museum, and the other, a retrospective of work by the printmaker, Gabor Peterdi, opens today at the Brooklyn Museum.
Two hundred educators and representatives of foreign governments attended a demonstration of the language laboratory at Columbia University yesterday.
A program of increased benefits to golf professionals was endorsed at the annual meeting of the Metropolitan Section of the Professional Golfers Association yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was tempted to write after reading James P. Warburg's letter in the Oct. 7 issue of The Times commenting on Dean Acheson's statement from Bonn on the German problem. Perry Laukhuff's provocative letter on the same subject published Oct. 16 has tempted me too far, for different reasons.

Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, has recently returned from a five-week visit to Australia, New Zealand, the Philippines and Japan. In the Big Board's quarterly report, issued for publication today, Mr. Funston said his trip had convinced him that nations in the Far East were extremely interested in creating a favorable economic climate for attracting private American investment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -President Sekou Toure of Guinea arrived here today with an appeal that the United States help all African people realize their dream of freedom, sovereignty and well-being through economic, technical, and cultural aid.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The thirteen-member International Development Advisory Board resigned in a body today.

The near-by rubber futures rose sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The volume -- 1,900 tons -- was the third largest of the year Final quotations rose 55 to 321 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).

The meeting of the Supreme Soviet (Moscow's legislature) which begins today will be watched closely by the rest of the world for the clues it may offer as to Premier Khrushchev's plans for Soviet domestic and foreign policy. The Premier himself, whose trips to this country, Communist China and Rumania have been the center of world attention, may use this forum to answer some questions.

OFTEN it is good play to trump partner's trick in order to get the lead, but when the play may sacrifice a trump trick the chance of gain is too slight. In today's hand, over-hasty trumping cost a trick.
A residential and resort community of 800 homes in various price brackets has been planned for Coral Harbour, a 2,500-acre section on the southwest shoreline of Nassau in the Bahama Islands.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Too often voters are unfamiliar with the records of candidates for judicial office. As a result we vote a straight ticket instead of choosing candidates based on their qualifications. I would like to call attention to the candidacy of Amos S. Basel for justice of the City Court (Manhattan).
In a move to expand further outside of the textile industry, Courtaulds, Ltd., and its American and Canadian subsidiaries have jointly formed two new companies.
Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey gives some insights on the 1948 Presidential campaign in an interview he granted for use in a new book, "Out of the Jaws of Victory," which is being published today.
A dual-control automobile was presented yesterday to the first all-girls' high school in the city to provide driver education.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A late flurry of selling lowered most wheat futures prices today on the Board of Trade, but other grains and soybeans finished steady to strong.
CHRISTMAS may seem remote with Halloween and Thanksgiving still to get through, but for those who would order the specially made or personalized gift the time to do it is now.

FLORENCE, Italy, Oct. 26 -Today's meeting of the Christian Democratic congress was shaken when Premier Antonio Segni was accused of having planned armed Italian intervention in the Suez crisis of 1956 when British, French and Israeli troops invaded Egyptian territory.
Steel mills not affected by the nation-wide strike last week operated at their highest level of production for any full week since the strike began on July 15.

The economic situation in the Dominican Republic is reported to have deteriorated so greatly in the last six months that diplomatic observers see in it a serious threat to the stability of that country's dictatorial regime.
A new move was made at City Hall yesterday to try to prevent tenement houses from degenerating into slums.

THE television industry, for the moment somewhat bruised by the scandal over quiz shows, is nursing a small resentment against the press. Not because of the headlines that inevitably are part of the exposure of the fixed quizzes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A United States official who was expelled from the Soviet Union said today that Soviet efforts to "penetrate" the United States Embassy in Moscow increased in the last six months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- During his week-end electioneering in downstate Illinois Senator Kennedy of Massachusetts repeated his oftenexpressed view that the American people are yearning for "new ideas" among this nation's elect. The people also, he said, long for "new action and new faces."

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 26 -- The advance in the Aqueduct post time apparently proved a minor boom to the Roosevelt Raceway attendance and handle figures. They showed a definite improvement tonight for the first time in several weeks.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 26 -For the nineteen days since the attempt on the life of Premier Abdul Karim Kassim, Iraq has been quiet and tense.

YESTERDAY in New York when people talked about the ups and downs of the market they didn't mean Wall Street. It was Seventh Avenue, the heart of the American clothing industry. Spring collections were being seen by the toughest audience of all: store buyers who must decide what will appeal to the public.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- The State School Boards Association enthusiastically endorsed today the proposed $500,000,000 school bond issue for New York City.
The first game of a new rivalry between the United States Military and Air Force Academies brings the Army football team to New York this week for the first time since 1956.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -Following are the texts of a joint statement by David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, and Edgar F. Kaiser, chairman of the Kaiser Steel Corporation, on the contract settlement agreement between the union and the corporation today, and of a separate statement by Mr. Kaiser:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- United States exports made an important gain in the third quarter of this year, according to preliminary estimates published today by the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of a news conference held today at the State Department by Russell A. Langelle, the United States Embassy security officer who was ousted from the Soviet Union:
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 -- Some time ago a New York advertising man here on a research project hired a plane to look over the area.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The State Department has been aware for some time that the Dominican Republic was struggling with a balance-of-payments problem.
GENEVA, Oct. 26 -- The traditionminded Swiss voters returned in yesterday's general election a National Council almost identical to the one it replaces.
NICE, France, Oct., 26 -Pressure to build a 100,000-seat stadium in France is growing more and more intense. But it cannot transcend the animosity remaining from World War II.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 26 -- The Swedish Academy of Science announced today the recipients of Nobel Prizes in science, confirming reports last week that two American physicists and a Czechoslovak chemist were to be honored.

The selection of a jury in Federal Court began yesterday in the case of twenty-two men accused of conspiring to obstruct justice by concealing from a grand jury the true nature of the 1957 Apalachin meeting.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- Coach Mike Nixon dropped two experienced players from the slumping Washington Redskins today and signed a new end in an effort to shore up his offense.

South Carolina is planning to borrow $10,000,000 in the bond market to finance school construction. Bids on the securities will be taken on Nov. 17. The issue will come due serially on Dec. 1 from 1960 to 1979.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- British Government securities continued to advance strongly in the stock market today and rose as much as 15 shillings ($2.10).

The will of Mrs. Lillian Guyer Timken, a rich 78-year-old widow who was found dead in her vast, dusty Fifth Avenue duplex on Saturday, was uncovered in her library filing cabinet yesterday. It will be filed for probate this morning in Surrogate's Court.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 26 -A jury in Orange County Court deliberated nearly eight hours today on the innocence or guilt of Malcolm Richard White in the shooting and killing of a union organizer.
The translation of an ancient document purporting to contain 114 sayings of Jesus Christ will be published Saturday by Harper Bros.
In the heaviest buying surge in more than two months, stocks yesterday added more than $2,000,000,000 to market values on the New York Stock Exchange.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- Lieut. Gen. E. C. Itschner, chief of the Corps of Engineers, said today it would cost at least $4,000,000,000 over the next twenty years to develop adequate flood control, navigation and water Supply systems in the Ohio River Valley.

The seeming absence of craters and seas across much of the far side of the moon, as revealed yesterday in a Soviet photograph, was viewed here with interest, in view of a theory that predicted that the far side would be largely smooth.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 26 -The West German press bemoaned today what one newspaper described as a "deplorable lack of unity" among the Western powers on the question of an East-West summit meeting.
DETROIT, Oct. 27 -- "Either you have wheels on all four sides after your arrival, or you run screaming out of town in two weeks."
Scads of pre-season all-America football teams were published in September. In various smoke-filled rooms, scads of post-season all-America teams soon will be selected for December publication.
DETROIT, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Five General Motors plants announced today new lay-offs that will increase the number of automobile workers made idle by the steel strike to more than 125,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Instantaneous coast - to - coast transmission of facsimile first-class mail by an electronic-eye scanning device was foreshadowed by postal authorities here today.
A single-engined, open-cockpit biplane that made one of the first globe-circling flights in 1924 went on display yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where it fitted neatly into the lobby.
Prices of prime debt securities marked time yesterday in deference to a trio of major unanswered questions. These might be summarized as follows:
Blyth Co., Inc., and associates are offering to the public today $25,000,000 of 5 1/8 per cent, twenty-year sinking fund debentures of the Northern Natural Gas Company. The price is 100.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27--Robert Murphy was reported tonight as about to resign as Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs and enter private business.
Five spectacular birds from Africa made their camera debut at the Bronx Zoo yesterday.

The phenomenal growth in the last year of "pee wee" automobile racing, with thousands of youngsters as well as adults driving karts and one-quarter and one-half midget cars, has created a problem and some controversy.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Following is the text of the State Department's report on the call made by the United States Ambassador, Philip W. Bonsal, on the President of Cuba today:
SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Plans were revealed today for an Australian challenge in America's Cup yachting.
Michael J. Quill set $100,000,000 yesterday as the price for labor peace on city and private transit lines in the next year.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 27 -- A group of mutual funds salesmen and executives were told here today that the years ahead promised to be the "Golden Sixties." The forecast was made by William A. Parker, chairman of Incorporated Investors and Incorporated Fund.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Virgilio Alvarez Sanchez, Governor of the Dominican central bank, denied tonight reports that the regime og Generalissimo Rafael Leonardas Trujillo Molina was threatened by an economic crisis.

June de Toth, a pianist from Pittsburgh who has been appearing abroad, made her Carnegie Hall debut last night. Her program consisted of Beethoven's D minor Sonata, the Bartok Sonata, Chopin's D flat Nocturne and B flat minor Scherzo, and pieces by Liszt, Debussy and Harris.

In 1920 Robert Dean Frisbie went to the South Seas to write. On Danger Island he set up a trading post and met and married a 15-year-old Polynesian. She died in 1938 after the birth of their fifth child. His eldest daughter, "Johnny" (Florence), tells the story of her island childhood and of her father and his two careers of novelist and father-mother in "The Frisbies of the South Seas."

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., Oct. 27 -- With the increase of golfers in outlying areas of Long Island, more golf tournaments will be held in Suffolk County during 1960. That was decided tonight at the annual meeting of the Long Island Golf Association at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 27 -- The crisis of the inflated metropolis is the most important domestic issue in the country, a public affairs specialist said today.
TOKYO, Oct. 27 -- Spokesmen for a number of leading trading nations agreed today that countries with enough dollars should lift their restrictions on the purchase of dollar goods.

The directors of American Steel Foundries, Inc., proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock yesterday. The company also reported that earnings in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 showed a sharp increase over those of the preceding year.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 27 -- Election returns today revealed surprising strength for Iceland's Communist-led Labor Alliance.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Sears, Roebuck Co. announced today it was selling its investment in Waltons-Sears, Ltd., Australian retailing concern, because of differences over expansion and dividend policies.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Air Force junior varsity ran Army plays against the first and second units today. Sam Hardage, a first-string end and a strong defensive performer, sat out practice because of a severe cleat cut received in the game against the University of California at Los Angeles last week.

THE wobbly legged foal blinked in the bright California sunshine as he stepped into the little paddock outside the barn where he had been born only three days before. One caretaker had led out the mother, War Whisk, on a halter but the son, Warfare, followed before the other caretaker had slipped a guide line on him.
Bob Shaw, the Chicago White Sox' pitcher who thrives on exercise, milk and American batsmen, is back home doing push-ups. He hopes they'll help lift his victory total to twenty next season.

Rich Mayo, the Air Force Academy quarterback, was named The Associated Press' back of the week yesterday. Mayo's running, passing and ball-handling produced one of last week-end's biggest upsets -- a 20-7 victory by the Falcons over the University of California at Los Angeles.

Mayor Wagner has a great deal at stake in next Tuesday's vote on the $500,000,000 school bond issue. The outcome could determine whether he becomes the state's principal spokesman for the Democratic party or just another officeholder.
TRENTON, Oct. 27 -- Federal Judge Phillip Forman denied today a defense motion to quash the price-fixing and conspiracy indictment of five major manufacturers of Salk polio vaccine.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- Following are the texts of the majority and minority opinions in today's decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit upholding the Taft-Hartley injunction in the steel strike:
Three prominent men received medals yesterday from the Deafness Research Foundation for contributions to the problems of deafness, as well as for their own achievements.
TOKYO, Oct. 27 -- Japan has halted her barter imports from Communist China, made through Hong Kong.
A bill making it illegal to smoke in any elevator in any building in the city was approved yesterday by the City Council. The vote was 18 to 6, with one abstention.
WARSAW, Oct. 27 -- Poland's Communists, faced with an economic crisis, ordered an important shake-up of the country's Government today.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan warned today of the dangers that might result from a further delay in a summit conference with the Soviet Union.
Herbert H. Lehman endorsed the school-bond issue amendment yesterday and charged that some of its opponents had sought to defeat it by deliberately creating "confusion and misunderstanding."
NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Faultless Speech and Rocky Royale were listed as joint 8-1 favorites today for tomorrow's running of the Cambridgeshire Stakes on the Newmarket course.

PURCHASE, N. Y. Oct. 27 -- The annual bridge, tea and fashion show sponsored by the student relief committee of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart will be held on the campus here next Tuesday evening.
PARIS, Oct. 27 -- The French Government restated today the view that an East-West summit conference should be held next spring after careful preparation and an "improvement of the world climate."
Joseph Luberda, a former police sergeant who is awaiting sentence in New York County for criminal contempt, was indicted yesterday on a similar charge by a Kings County grand jury.
A group of reform Democrats who fought Carmine G. De Sapio in the recent primaries will be asked tonight to back a Republican-Liberal candidate for General Sessions judge.

Despite President Eisenhower's call for Western unity, the Allied disagreement over an East-West summit meeting has hardened as a result of formal statements made by Premier Debre and Prime Minister Macmillan.
The history of the American musical theatre will be traced in a new program series to be televised by station WCBS-TV in cooperation with the New York City Board of Education.

Major league baseball, which has been spinning around in circles with talk of expansion covering practically every point of vantage from Flushing Meadow to the far side of the moon, finally came to rest yesterday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 27 -- The Soviet Government proposed today a record peacetime budget with major new outlays for science and heavy industry. Industrial gains this year also led Soviet planners to decree a quickened pace toward fulfillment of the 1959-1965 seven-year plan. They seemed to be leading up to a slash of as much as a year from the long-range goal.
FLORENCE, Italy, Oct. 27 -- The Christian Democratic party's congress that has been meeting here since last Friday came virtually to an end late tonight.

The turbo-fan engine, which has become something of a ray of hope for airport operators facing jet noise complaints, was the subject of a special meeting held Monday between the Port of New York Authority and leaders of communities around New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
MIAMI, Oct. 27 (AP) -- This city's swimming pools, parks and all other recreational facilities that had remained segregated were opened to Negroes today.

ALTHOUGH summer is the time for most vegetables, some stalwarts are with us the year round. These hardy specimens include most root vegetables, many of which are sadly neglected by the American public.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller opened the first five and one-half miles of the Northway today with a plea to the voters to permit its extension along the proposed Adirondack route. The section opened today is at the Albany end of a superhighway to extend to Montreal.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 27--Malcom R. White, Chester manufacturer who shot and killed a union organizer, was acquitted today.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Warfare, Bourbon Prince and Bally Ache, leading candidates for the year's juvenile championship, have increased the tentative field to twelve for Saturday's Garden State, pushing the possible gross for the world's richest horse race to $287,075.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Charley Bassler of Ellicott City, Md., ignored chilling winds and snowy flurries today and shot a par 71 for a one-stroke lead in the Middle Atlantic Professional Golfers Association tournament.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- At the age of 43, Francois Mitterrand, Senator, former Deputy and Minister and a major figure of the French Left, has already had enough political struggle to last most politicians a lifetime.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27--Following is the text of a disarmament resolution agreed upon today by the Soviet and Western delegations to the General Assembly:...
Horace M. Albright, conservationist and industrialist, warned last night that minerals were "becoming scarce." He called for "prospection on a grand scale" both here and abroad.

The Federal Court of Appeals' six-day stay yesterday of the steel strike injunction it approved should not stay the negotiators in their duty to come to an agreement. Quite the opposite. The impasse has now reached a point where the whole structure of free collective bargaining is threatened as the pressure for government-imposed settlements of industrial disputes gains strength.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board refused today by a 2 to 2 vote to stay its order permitting American Airlines to fly non-stop between New York and San Francisco beginning Sunday.
" THE BELLS OF ST. MARY'S" tolled pleasantly, if gently, on Channel 2 last night.
To avoid further error, it seems desirable to clear up the misunderstanding which seems to have inspired Philip Marshall Brown's letter of Oct. 21 criticizing your editorial of Oct. 13.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Premier Michel Debre indicated to the Senate tonight that "excesses" had been committed by political groups against his Government and said he would never permit the Republic to be smashed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Children's Convalescent Hospital will receive the proceeds of the fifth International Ball, which will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Sheraton Park here on Nov. 7. Mrs. Poe Burling is chairman of the fete.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Stock market prices advanced here today after overcoming early weakness.

With Columbia's two top sophomore halfbacks, Tom Haggerty and Russ Warren, not fully recovered from minor injuries, the Lions' first-string backfield was not set as the team practiced yesterday at Baker Field.
TO avoid a hazardous Halloween for their youngsters, parents should take a few simple precautions.
Management and union spokesmen differed yesterday on the progress made under a week's extension of the contract between metropolitan milk dealers and five teamster unions.
The Consumers Public Power District, Nebraska, borrowed $23,300,000 in the bond market yesterday on serial obligations due from 1963 to 1992.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Sekou Toure off Guinea and President Eisenhower talked for an hour today.

The Erie Railroad has been hard hit by the nation's steel strike. The carrier announced yesterday it incurred a net loss of $1,569,041 in September and a $5,191,812 deficit in the first nine months this year. Because of the losses, directors of the road voted to omit the fourth quarter dividend on the company's $5 preferred stock.
Two new film premieres have been announced as forthcoming attractions at first-run theatres in the midtown area.

Fashion trends for spring are taking shape as Seventh Avenue designers present collections, the American equivalent of the Paris openings. The New York Times has been barred from some showings because of its policy to report trends immediately.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- There were only a few firm spots in a mostly weal: grain futures market today on the Board of Trade.
Louisiana State, No. 1 in the weekly Associated Press college football poll for the thirteenth straight time, will get a chance to solidify its position this Saturday night.

Net income of Merck Co. in the quarter ended on Sept. 30 rose to $8,084,000, or 75 cents a common share, from $7,073,000, or 68 cents a share, in the 1958 period, John T. Connor, president, reported yesterday.

A sharp dispute developed in Brooklyn yesterday between public officials in the wake of the acquittal Monday night of 15-year-old Peter Manceri, who had been charged with fatally beating an elderly man in a park.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- The nation's union railroad employes plan to strike back at a series of published advertisements calling them "featherbedders," a union spokesman said today.

The five-story apartment house for twenty families at 1219 Union Street, between Nostrand and Rogers Avenues, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Unio Realty Corporation to the Estate Securities Company. representing Alvin Levy and Irving Magot, realty operators.
On the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, the December contract rose 3 points while the cotton futures market in other months declined 1 to 6 points. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller, expanded his political journey to the West Coast tonight from a two-state to a four-state venture.
The City Council called on Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday to order patrolmen to carry nightsticks on the 8 A. M. to 4 P. M. shift.

ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 27 -- The Black Star Line, Ghana's merchant shipping line established jointly with the Zim Navigation Company of Israel about two years ago, plans to acquire twelve more new ships by 1962. It has four now.

Joseph Beruh made his managerial debut last season with a revival of Jerome Kern's musical, "Leave It to Jane," which is still flourishing at the Sheridan Square Playhouse. But his next project will be the sponsorship of a new and serious drama, "Tall Green Grass," by Louis C. Adelman.
GROTON, Mass., Oct. 27 -- 2:40 this afternoon, the chimes of Groton's old school house scunded. Groups of students emerged from their classrooms and walked briskly to the gymnasium.
A large property in the Chelsea area of Manhattan has passed to new control with the sale by Dewey Carver, realty operator, of the southeast corner of Ninth Avenue and Twenty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Employment, personal income and production have leveled off in the major part of industry not directly tied to steel, according to an analysis by the Commerce Department.
NEWARK, Oct. 27 -- The Newark Chamber of Commerce has been ordered to show cause on Nov. 6 why it should not be declared insolvent.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 27 -- John Warner Remington, the first man from New York State to head the American Bankers Association in fifteen years, has been president of the largest bank in Rochester, the Lincoln Rochester Trust Company, since 1954.
Premier Abdallah Ibrahim of Morocco said yesterday he had become convinced during his first visit to the United States that "there are no insoluble problems between our two countries."

The New York Philharmonic last season grossed more than a million dollars, the first time it has done so in one season. This was announced yesterday by David M. Keiser, president of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York.
JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 27 -- The United States told the eleventh Colombo Plan conference today that Washington was attempting to encourage private investment in underdeveloped countries.

Representatives of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, usually referred to by the more convenient title of GATT, are assembled in Tokyo. This thirty-seven-nation group, whose long-term objective is the reduction of tariffs among the trading nations of the world through reciprocal agreements, faces challenging problems on this occasion on several fronts.
ALBANY, Oct. 27 (AP) -- About 1,600 families of striking steelworkers are receiving welfare benefits in the state, the State Social Welfare Department said today.

PARIS, Oct. 27 (Reuters) -- The 1945 Yalta conference saw a huge piece of Europe sacrificed to Franklin D. Roosevelt's mistaken idea that the United States and the Soviet Union could cooperate after World War II, President Charles de Gaulle asserted in a book of wartime memoirs published today.

THE so-called two-way finesse, which occurs when it is possible to finesse through either opponent for the same card, is not limited to situations in which the opponents have the queen and declarer has A-J-x in one hand and K-10-x in the other.
Next on the list of opponents for the New York Giants are the Green Bay Packers, who will be encountered Sunday at the Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The United States told Cuba today that it was deeply concerned that Cubans were seeking to replace the traditional friendship between the two countries with "distrust and hostitity."
The American Can Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter had declined slightly from the level of the 1958 period, despite a gain of 11.3 per cent in sales.

Before taking to the streets to patrol the city's 50,000 parking meters, New York's "meter maids" will undergo a rigorous training program ranging from the manly art of judo to the womanly art of applying make-up.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Piccadilly Circus, hub of the Empire and London's equivalent of Times Square, is about to undergo a drastic alteration.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit upheld today, by a 2-to-1 vote, President Eisenhower's petition for an eighty-day back-to-work order in the steel strike.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Montreal's Dickie Moore and Henri Richard led the Canadiens to a 2-1 victory over Chicago tonight for the Black Hawks' sixth straight defeat in the National Hockey League.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday a net income of $67,928,817, or $3.87 a share, for the twelve months that ended on Sept. 30. This compared with a profit of $63,492,797, or $3.62 a share, in the 1958 period.

An electronic guard system with a single guard monitoring a closed-circuit television system watching every portion of a big plant was demonstrated yesterday by the Minneapolis - Honeywell Regulator Company.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that the city would pay the United States Military Academy $15,000 for bringing Saturday's football game with the Air Force Academy to Yankee Stadium.

On Oct. 23 you printed a letter by Victor F. Condello, vice chairman and general counsel, New York State Association of Railroads, urging a negative vote on Amendment No. 6, the proposed canal amendment which would make it possible for the Legislature to consider the lease or transfer of the obsolescent upstate waterway to the Federal Government.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Doug Sanders took the lead in the Sahara pro-amateur tournament today with a 6-under-par 66.

County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz and Stanley H. Lowell exchanged bitter telegrams yesterday in a dispute over the judge's contention that Mr. Lowell had done attempted to deter Puerto Ricans from coming here.
The world's fourth-tallest office building, the seventy-story tower at 40 Wall Street, was sold at auction to William Zeckendorf yesterday for $18,150,000.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- A busy session was foreshadowed today by the legislative program presented to the new Parliament by the Conservative Government of Prime Minister Harold Macmillan.

LUSTROUS enamelware and beautifully wrought silver from Oslo go on sale today in the Exhibition Hall at Norway House, 290 Madison Avenue. These Norwegian wares make up the most extensive collection from David-Andersen Silversmiths ever shown in the United States. The exhibit closes Nov. 13.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- The Army football team drilled behind closed gates today and cadet bed-sheet art broke out across the barracks. As it has done for years over the Navy game, West Point is working up a fever of enthusiasm over Saturday's contest with the Air Force Academy at the Yankee Stadium.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 27 -- The new building of the Dallas Museum for Contemporary Arts was opened tonight with a preview of a major loan exhibition entitled "Signposts of Modern Art." At the same time, the museum's first fulltime professional director, Douglas MacAgy, recently associated with New York's Museum of Modern Art, was formally introduced.
Overwhelming approval of a resolution favoring the establishment of a committee to organize foreign-flag ships has been given by the membership of the National Maritime Union.
HAVANA, Oct. 27 -- Cuba rejected the United States protest tonight.
FONTANA, Calif., Oct. 27 -- About 1,300 strikers returned to their jobs at the Kaiser Steel Corporation today. happy to be back and generally full of praise for Edgar F. Kaiser.

To play an entire program of unaccompanied music for violin and 'cello the performers must have abundant confidence in their power to sustain interest without the support of a piano. Gerald Tarack, violinist, and Jules Eskin, 'cellist, played such a program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, and the event proved that their confidence was not misplaced.

PARIS, Oct. 27 (Reuters) -- Following in unoffical translation, is a French Government statement on foreign policy, read by Premier Michel Debre to the French Senate and by Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville to the National Assembly today:

The X-ray treatment of children for disorders of the upper chest or neck is an invitation to the later development of thyroid cancer, two specialists said yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Cancer Society.
STRATFORD, Conn., Oct. 27 -- Ten women helicopter pilots, among them the wife of a United States Senator from Michigan, took turns soaring over Fairfield County today.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 27 (AP) -- A wing snapped off a Braniff airliner that crashed and killed thirty-four persons last month, a Government expert said yesterday.

The first comprehensive exhibition of the works of Cezanne in New York for many years will be held at the Wildenstein Gallery from Nov. 5 through Dec. 5 for the benefit of the National Organization for Mentally Ill Children.
A LUCID and enlightening study of the life and death of a ballistic missile was presented last night on "C. B. S. Reports" over Channel 2.

THERE are several good reasons why the so-called "Lost Works" of Eugene O'Neill have never been done before in New York. The production of three of them at the Key Theatre last night does not invalidate any of these reasons.
GENEVA, Oct. 27 -- The United States ruled out today any agreement to ban nuclear-weapons tests that contained loop-holes endangering its national security.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following programs as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown Friday through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.

Your United Hospital Fund dollars support free and below-cost care in eighty-two voluntary hospitals. What does this mean to individuals? A member hospital reports on two operations that were recently performed on children.

BOSTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association Council tonight reprimanded the University of Mississippi for using improper recruiting practices, and placed the school on probation for one year.

ALEXEY KONSTANINOVICH TOLSTOY (no relation to the great Leo, but a count also) began to study the life of Peter the Great in 1917. When he died in 1945 he still had not finished his massive historical novel, "Peter the First."* This gigantic panorama of the Russian past at a period when an absolute ruler was ruthlessly forcing his country to adapt Western ideas and Western techniques is generally considered the finest Soviet historical novel.
Queens, which so often complains of being the "forgotten" borough, will be the center of citywide political attention Nov. 3 when it will elect a Borough President.

Mikhail Tal and Paul Keres, Soviet grand masters, were still first and second, respectively, in the challengers' chess tournament at Belgrade last night after the completion of twenty-seven rounds, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 27 -- Financiers and industrialists representing five Central American republics opened today a four-day conference here to determine the role to be played by investors in a five-country common market project.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The balance of power is shifting again in the Eisenhower Cabinet. With the retirement and death of John Foster Dulles, Secretary of the Treasury Robert B. Anderson has emerged as the most powerful figure in the President's official family.
Eric Guerin completed a riding triple in the Aqueduct mud yesterday by driving the 2-1 favorite, Whitley, to a three-quarter-lentgh victory over Nimmer in the featured seventh race.
It is pleasant to be living in an old house at this time of year. Getting an old house ready for winter involves a ritual that occupants of brand new homes of modern construction do not always enjoy.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 27 -- This has been a phenomenal year for woodcock in these big woods along the St. Croix River and bids fair to be a good year for deer. Right now the weather is very warm for either, but particularly for deer.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Britain is expected to show a surplus of 142,000,000 ($397,600,000) in her balance of payments for the first half of 1959, it was announced today.

Major sales finance companies followed the lead of C. I. T. Financial Corporation yesterday in slicing by 1/8 to 1/2 per cent the rates paid on commercial paper placed directly with investors. The cuts followed a slight easing of the Treasury's short-term borrowing costs on its ninety-one-day bills.

Under the sponsorship of the Community Council of Greater New York a major effort is under way to recruit several thousand volunteer workers who will devote spare time to community health and welfare projects and keep the public informed about the wide range of volunteer service. Recent news stories about the shortage of hospital workers have highlighted the need for these volunteers.
American scientists who had their first look at the other side of the moon yesterday were both delighted and puzzled over what they saw.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan paid tribute to his old patron and mentor, Sir Winston Churchill, during his first speech to the new House of Commons today.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- For years John Dunn had vainly sought fame as an author, as an architect and as a painter.
Philip Cortney, president of Coty, Inc., yesterday called on sponsors of "fraudulent" quiz shows to donate to charity the money they had made as a result of the programs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Justice Department announced today the recovery of $1,505,250 excess profits from McDonnell Aircraft Corporation of St. Louis.
Colleges throughout the country were urged yesterday to issue a statement of principles for an ideal national financial-aid program.
ALBANY, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The State Thruway Authority recognized a labor union today as bargaining agent for some workers on the highway but refused to enter a union-shop agreement.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y. Oct. 27 -- Civic groups will meet Saturday to combat a threat to Kirby Plaza, a $35,000 expression of the horticultural tastes of commuters, their chauffeur-wives, shoppers and merchants.

Wall Street was in a surprisingly ebullient mood yesterday. Prices of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange advanced smartly, although notable profit taking showed up in the "glamour," or electronic-missile group.
The French Government terminated unused yesterday a $200,000,000 stand-by credit arranged last January with twenty-one United States banks to help stabilize the French franc.

Cocoa futures climbed the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit in the December and November positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Liquidation and profit taking lowered quotations from the highs of the day.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 27 -- Despite tight money, banks in the United States are extending a record volume of credit to small businesses, the American Bankers Association's eighty-fifth annual convention at the Fontainebleu Hotel was told today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- John A. McCone, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, expressed surprise today at the "remarkable" speed with which atomic research projects could be carried out in the Soviet Union.

The will of Mrs. Lillian Guyer Timken, who was found dead in her Fifth Avenue apartment last Saturday, presents a problem for two museums.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 27 -- The Indian Government has accepted a Communist Chinese offer to return ten border policemen held by Chinese forces in Ladakh and the bodies of nine policemen killed in a clash there last week.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Two means of dealing with the problem of South-West Africa were laid before the Trusteeship Committee of the General Assembly today.
A proposal to merge Consolidated Electrodynamics Corporation with the Bell Howell Company has been approved in principle by directors of both companies, it was announced yesterday.
A machine to accept coins or bills -- singles or fives in combinations up to $9 -- was put on display yesterday. It was said to introduce a new departure for the vending machine industry.
LONDON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- One of the worst storms in six years hit northern Europe today, battering ships at sea and causing deaths in Scotland.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Two New Jersey electric companies have asked the state Public Utility Commission to let them join in an experimental nuclear generating project.

Eleven-year-old William Sicari, who borrowed $5 from a major New York bank, has no doubt learned a lesson. In financing the cost of his football jersey over five months, he has discovered the advantages of the "play now, pay later" system.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Army today chose Maj. Gen. August Schomburg, a weapons specialist for years, to succeed Maj. Gen John B. Medaris as head of its missile command.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 27 -- Delegates representing two comparatively small but influential religious bodies began debate here today on a proposed merger. The groups are the American Unitarian Association and the Universalist Church of America.

States Marine Lines has carried 100 passengers a year free on its cargo ships, the president of the unsubsidized company told a special House Anti-trust subcommittee yesterday.

IN Jean Anouilh's "Legend of Lovers" the style is all The production that opened at the Forty-first Street Theatre last evening represents a second look at the bittersweet drama M. Anouilh wrote during World War II. Another English version of it was performed here in 1951.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 27 -- Pakistan celebrated Revolution Day today, the first anniversary of President Mohammed Ayub Khan's military regime.

West European exports of steel to the United States in recent months were likened yesterday to "a pinprick in an elephant's skin."

New York State has moved to take over some of the regulatory functions now exercised within its borders by the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Government moved tonight for a quick Supreme Court decision on the steel case. Attorney General William P. Rogers announced that the Justice Department would ask the high court tomorrow to make the United Steelworkers of America move immediately for Supreme Court review or else lose a six-day stay of the injunction against the union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Cuba can terminate the agreement providing for the Navy's base on Guantanamo Bay only by breaking diplomatic relations with the United States, the Pentagon warned today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Detroit Steel Corporation, which had not been struck, fell into line behind the Kaiser Steel Corporation today and signed a contract with the United Steelworkers of America.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- A state education official chided school board members and administrators today for conducting public business as a private matter.

At this season the sun circles perpetually overhead, disclosing the handful of Quonset huts, half hidden by drift snow, in which dwell the seventeen Americans at the United States polar station.

FLORENCE, Oct. 28 -- The Christian Democratic party was bringing its seventh congress to a close tonight after debating for a week its future political course. The continued stay in power of Premier Antonio Segni and his Cabinet was one of the points at issue.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Stock market prices forged ahead here today.
There's little wrong with the home building industry that advertising and promotion in the country's newspapers and magazines can't cure, a leading builder said yesterday.
Two more jurors were picked yesterday for the trial of Frankie Carbo. There are now eleven for the trial, which began Monday.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Because of a courteous request on behalf of President Charles de Gaulle, it is likely that few in France will know tomorrow about an important theatrical revival, apart from tonight's audience and the actors.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- Sixteen countries offered a joint resolution today expressing hope that India would become a voting member of the Intergovernmental Maritime Consultative Organization "at an early date."

More than sixty persistent traffic violators, who face the loss of their driver licenses if they are arrested for one more violation, were sternly reprimanded by Wililam S. Hults, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, yesterday.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 28 -- Edgar F. Kaiser, board chairman of Kaiser Steel Corporation, said here this afternoon that he had signed an agreement with the United Steel-workers of America because he did not believe in forcing people back to work under a court injunction.

ONCE upon a time the Green Bay Packers were the glamour boys of the gridiron. The little Wisconsin town on the shores of Lake Michigan was more than a match for the titans from Chicago, New York and elsewhere as a pro football power. It had the greatest of all pass receivers in the incomparable Don Hutson and it had spectacular, resourceful performers to go with him.
NEWARK, Del., Oct. 28 -- It rained here last Friday before the University of Delaware football team met Marshall. Coach Dave Nelson canceled practice and held a squad meeting.

MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Oct. 28 (AP) -- United Auto Workers Local 155 and nine unionists were held in contempt of court today in mass picketing and violence at the struck Cross Company in near-by Fraser. The nine individuals were fined and sentenced to jail.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28 -- City managers must take a positive approach toward directing policy in their communities, delegates to the annual conference of the International City Managers Association were told here tonight.

KEY WEST, Fla., Thursday, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The disabled sailing vessel crystal anchored here early today and reported all hands safe. There were twenty persons including a woman aboard the 445-ton craft.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- Viktor G. Bakayev, Soviet Minister of Merchant Marine, disclosed today that a group of American shipowners and longshoremen from the West Coast had accepted an invitation to visit the Soviet Union.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced plans yesterday for the commercial production of its elastic textile fiber, "Lycra." A plant will be built at Waynesboro, Va., where du Pont now makes Acele acetate yarn and Orion acrylic fiber.

Fashion trends for spring are taking shape as Seventh Avenue designers present collections, the American equivalent of the Paris openings. The New York Times has been barred from some showings because of its policy to report trends immediately. Reports on those showings are based on information from other fashion authorities. Most of the clothes will be in stores by January.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- President Charles de Gaulle called on the French Army and the civil administration in Algeria tonight for "devotion" and "discipline" in seeking an end of the five-year-old rebellion and paving the way for a political settlement.

The New York Knickerbockers must give up Frank Selvy to the Syracuse Nationals. Maurice Podoloff, president of the National Basketball Association. ruled yesterday that the Knicks could not rescind their request for waivers on Selvy and must let Syracuse have him.
A jury of eight men and four women was chosen yesterday to try twenty-two men accused of obstructing a Federal investigation of the 1957 Apalachin meeting.
GENEVA, Oct. 28 -- Britain supported today a United States appeal to the Soviet Union to join in a study of the problem of detecting underground nuclear explosions.
A giant burglar, accused of raping and robbing a hat-check girl in her West Side apartment, was denounced in court yesterday and held without bail for grand jury action.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Louisville Nashville Railroad officials today won stockholders' approval to buy the Interstate Railroad Company, an important coal carrier, for $15,000,000 in L. N. stock.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower said today the United States Government was using "every single facility that is available" to prevent illegal flights from this country to Cuba.
The City Council's proposal for policemen to carry night-sticks on daylight tours was rejected yesterday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy as "phony" and "frivolous."
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 28 (UPI) -- A telephoned bomb scare tonight cleared the downtown theatre in which Maria Callas was giving her first United States performance this season.
This is the time of the year when retriever folk in the metropolitan area who have been bragging about the merits of their dogs have a chance to put them into competition.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 28 -- Difficult negotiations toward forming a new Icelandic Government appeared in prospect today as the counting of votes from the election last Sunday and Monday ended.

PSYCHIC bidding is to be the subject of a book tracing the history of "psychs" and analyzing their purposes and uses. Fred Karpin of Washington is writing it and Harper Bros. has contracted to publish it in the fall of 1960.

TOKYO, Oct. 29 (Thursday) -- Asian and African countries that depend upon the export of raw materials for their major foreign exchange expressed grave concern today that new European trade blocs might hurt their markets.
A lingering mystery persisted yesterday in the murder trial and acquittal of Peter Manceri, 15-year-old Brooklyn youth charged with fatally beating an elderly man in a park last summer.
A lawyer and a former inspector for the State Liquor Authority were indicted yesterday on charges of bribery in a scheme to get a retail beer license for a grocer.

In a triple-barrelled move yesterday, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock, increased the dividend rate on the present stock from $2 a share to $2.40 each year and reported record earnings for the third quarter.
Two ginkgo trees, popular since ancient times for decorating temple grounds in China, were planted by one woman and eleven men yesterday in the plaza of the Seagram Building, 375 Park Avenue.
A 17-year-old boy who had quit a teen-age gang three weeks ago was beaten seriously by the gang members last night. Four alleged assailants were arrested.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- A regional Indian-Pakistani defense pact is a possibility, according to knowledgeable diplomatic sources here.

A new professional soccer league, with teams from at least ten nations, will begin operations next summer. It will be known as the International Soccer League and will have one playing field -- Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

In preparation for the twenty-eighth and final round of the world chess championship challenger's tournament in Belgrade scheduled for tonight, the eight competitors rested yesterday. Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union, leading by one point, needs merely to draw in the final to finish in first place.

Two former customs inspectors were sentenced to three years in prison and fined $2,500 each yesterday by Federal Judge George H. Boldt for smuggling $120,000 worth of Italian haberdashery into this country.
ARLINGTON, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- An experiment in adult education here has grown into an attempt to get modern public planning for all the 816 square miles of Dutchess County.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct 29 -The economic development of less advanced countries "will require the combined energies and abilities of the entire free world for many years to come," Under Secretary of State Douglas Dillon said today.

Governor Rockefeller announced last night that he was sending personal letters to each of the 137,000 enrolled Republicans in Manhattan urging them to vote for Judge Samuel R. Pierce and all the other Republican judicial candidates.

The July, September and October world sugar positions climbed to new highs for the life of the contracts in early trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. However, the market turned down sharply and closed at or near the lows of the day.

The two-story taxpayer containing fifteen stores, offices and a garage at 160-66 Dyckman Street and 70-84 Sherman Avenue, the northwest corner, has been sold by the Guide Realty Company, in liquidation.
Borough President John T. Clancy made peace yesterday with Robert Battipaglia and three other Democratic district leaders who had fought him in the primary.
The usual autumn build-up of light fuel oil stocks -- used mainly for home heating -- accelerated last week, the American Petroleum Institute said today.
SOMETHING that resembles an Army obstacle course has been built by a group of Queens fathers in the backyard of the International Nursery School of Parkway Village. They call it a Playground.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad experienced a net railway operating loss of $6,080,206 in the first nine months this year and its revenues fell $5,581,656 short of covering the period's fixed charges of $4,989,658.
The Pennsylvania General State Authority borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public works to be leased to governmental bodies supported by the taxing power.

MASSENET'S "Manon" is as smooth and pretty as the silks and satins its heroine adores. In its genre it is a skillfully made opera. Though it is not one of the indispensable perennials of the repertory, there are those who treasure it, and they were on hand to welcome it back to the Metropolitan last night after an absence of five seasons.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 28 -- The mutual funds' positive contribution to the economy will be felt over the next ten years, a top spokesman for the industry said here today.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 28 (AP) -- By unanimous vote, the City Commission reversed today the order of City Manager Ira F. Willard to open municipal swimming pools and other recreational facilities to Negroes.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- A new motion picture in color, a new postage stamp and a new film biography of Premier Khrushchev have been added to the campaign of propaganda about the Premier's trip to the United States.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28 -- The Eisenhower Administration today set midnight Sunday as the deadline for successful completion of direct union-management negotiations to end the steel strike.
NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Rexequus, a 25-to-1 shot who nearly didn't start, won the 117th running of the Cambridgeshire Handicap today.
BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., Oct. 28 -- An advertising agency here has solved the commuting problem for its employes by moving the agency to the suburbs.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 28 -- The West German Cabinet decided today that any showing of the new East German flag in the Bonn republic would be regarded as a violation of public order.
Today the United Hospital Fund begins its outdoor campaign collection. Hundreds of volunteers will be on busy street corners, outside big buildings, to ask every passer-by to contribute.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 4 points (10 to 20 cents a bale) yesterday.
IZMIR, Turkey, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Two United States sergeants were freed on bail today after having spent eighty-eight days in jail on charges of blackmarket money deals.

New York was tardy in establishing a state university, although many of the scattered institutions of learning that were gathered into it had a long history of usefulness before the State University of New York was created by 1948 act of the Legislature. This evening, in a ceremony to be attended by many educators and public officials, a new president of the university will be installed at Albany, Dr. Thomas Hale Hamilton.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- British circles welcomed tonight President Eisenhower's statement that he expected a Western summit conference in mid-December.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -President Eisenhower will enter a hospital this week for his annual physical check-up, the White House said today.
The power of the mind to influence the well-being of the body should be more thoroughly studied in the war against cancer, the president of the American Cancer Society said yesterday.

Hans Richter-Haaser, the German pianist who made his Town Hall debut last night, is a big man with a big style. Sometimes his pianism is apt to be overwhelming, and not pleasantly so, with fortissimo piled on fortissimo to the point where the listener's eardrums begin to flap. But at his best he is a musician of culture and a pianist of inner force.

As a result of demands by colleges that freshmen show more proficiency in English, the College Entrance Examination Board approved plans yesterday to include essay writing as part of its entrance tests.
During the past weeks three former Governors have supported the Northway Amendment (No. 2) because "only 254 acres" of forest preserve land were involved.
Net new orders and shipments for the machine tool industry rose in September, with foreign orders leading the new business. The advance halted a two-month decline.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower suggested today that the best answer to the Soviet leaders' arguments about the superiority of the Communist system was a smile.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- The Soviet Government's highest constitutional authority, the Supreme Soviet, had its first full day of debate of the year today. The talk ranged from poor plumbing in the Urals to too much furniture in the Ministry of Culture.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller conferred with President Eisenhower for an hour and ten minutes today and said afterward the discussion had dealt in part with politics.

A woman who lives on the Lower East Side withdrew her complaint against a neighbor's laughing crow yesterday after finding her own solution; She turns her kitchen radio on louder than the bird can laugh.
Stocks went through a jittery session yesterday, with spectacular swings for a few specialties but with little net change for the list as a whole.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers today opened an inquiry into the fixing of television quiz shows that had been asked by President Eisenhower.

Pan American World Airways has flown 210,000 passengers in jet aircraft in its first year of jet operations, which began Oct. 26, 1958, according to Willis G. Lipscomb, vice president for traffic and sales.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The third volume of the war memoirs of President Charles de Gaulle, just published, concerns his struggles with politicians, foreign and domestic, to recapture French grandeur between 1944 and 1946.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 28 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was reported to have indicated today that his Government would have to act more firmly toward Communist China.

DENVER, Oct. 28 (AP) -Floyd E. Dominy, Federal Commissioner of Reclamation, called on the National Reclamation Association today to adopt a forward-looking and positive attitude to further Western irrigation development.
Civil Defense filed exercises Brooklyn and Staten Island tonight from 7:30 to 10 o'clock.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Coach Dale Hall of Army faced the possibility today of having to start a fourth-team halfback against the Air Force Academy in Saturday's football game at New York's Yankee Stadium.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 28 -- The success of Nassau County's major political parties in getting voters to the polls next Tuesday may determine whether the Democrats will achieve a breakthrough in this traditionally Republican county.
The producers of "Billy Barnes Revue" said yesterday that they would ask Actors Equity to take "severe disciplinary action" against the company for "breach of contract."

DETROIT, Oct. 28 -- John L. Burns, the president of the Radio Corporation of America, said today that television and modern electronics offered important new tools for upgrading the quality of education.

The Wicksedge Realty Corporation, a syndicate of investors headed by Robert S. Breitbart, has taken title to the apartment house for fifty-eight families at 2734 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx. The property was sold by the Benedict Realty Corporation in a deal negotiated by Armstrong Brothers and Wishnow Horowitz, brokers.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A fight to wrest control of the Lutheran Brotherhood, a billion-dollar insurance society, from its management was quelled tonight when four pro-management board members were elected.

A day-by-day account of the battle of Stalingrad will be published tomorrow by Coward-McCann. Called "Stalingrad: Point of Return," it has been written by Ronald Seth after a year's study of the archives in the Defense Museum of that city.

There are at least as many boys as girls in this country yet the dollar volume of girls' apparel is about double that of boys,' according to Miss Bernice Fitz-Gibbon, advertising and fashion consultant.
ALBANY, Oct. 28 -- The state will take a smaller amount from paychecks for income taxes beginning Jan. 1, but this does not mean that annual taxes are going down.
Two more leading steel companies announced yesterday that they operated at a loss in the strike-ridden third quarter.

ALMOST everyone concerned knew better than Sam Houston how the Battle of San Jacinto (April 21, 1836) should be fought. But he, after all, ran the show. And it was his victory that assured the independence of Texas from Mexico.

Mayor Wagner and representatives of the taxicab industry will meet at City Hall tomorrow to discuss ways to relieve the city's 35,000 taxicab drivers of hardships imposed by the 10-cent-a-ride tax. It has been in efect since July 1.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Oct. 28 -- Gov. and Mrs. Luther H. Hodges of North Carolina entertained Guinea's President Sekou Toure and his wife tonight at a dinner on the University of North Carolina campus.

Frederic W. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, will become chairman next Monday. In making the announcement yesterday, the company said he would continue as chief executive officer.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The British Labor party's efforts to repair its machinery followed several courses today.
Proceeds of a dinner dance in the Gold Suite of the Savoy Hilton on Nov. 13 will aid in the upkeep of the new quarters of Girls Town, Inc., at 4316 Van Cortlandt Park East in the Bronx.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 28 (AP) -- A Circuit Court jury today convicted Jesse R. Perry, 24 years old, of bombing the Little Rock school board offices. It fixed his punishment at three years in the penitentiary.

Anyone who has dealt with matrimonial controversies recognizes in the present steel muss what might be a useful analogy. Love flies out of the window and a husband and wife carry on a bickering contest, each repeating ad nauseam claimed grievances. At times if they quit talking the problems can be resolved.
