Pierce Jr., candidate for re-election to the Court of General Sessions on both the Republican and Liberal party lines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The White House, which administers an $80,000,000,000-a-year enterprise known as the United States Government, is finding its influence powerless to loose the purse strings of the big private foundations.
The City Housing Authority will soon ask the Board of Estimate's approval for 1,700 low-rent public housing apartments on the site of the Polo Grounds.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- The Special Political Committee voted today to recommend the establishment of a special group to negotiate an agreement among member nations for the enlargement of the United Nations main bodies.

FROM scenarist to art scholar is a long road that winds from the Louvre, through the museums and churches of Europe and ends at 17 East Sixty-fourth Street, where a new shop devoted to Gothic and Renaissance antiques opened yesterday.
Senator Kenneth B. Keating yesterday joined those urging approval of the school bond issue at next Tuesday's election.

Taking full advantage of her thirteen-pound margin in the weights, Mrs. Harry Curland's 4-year-old filly Nushie drove to a neck victory over the favored Idun in the six-furlong Interborough Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.
TORONTO, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- A third-period goal by Dick Duff enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to tie the Montreal Canadiens, 1 -- 1, in a National Hockey League contest tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -Robert Murphy -- the only Foreign Service officer ever to reach the exalted rank of Under Secretary of State -was 65 years old today. He marked the occasion by announcing he was closing the books on thirty-eight years in the Foreign Service to enter private business.
Experts in narcotic addiction clashed yesterday over whether to treat the addict as an offender against society or as its victim.

The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company has leased 10,000 square feet on two floors in the office building being erected at 80 Pine Street by Samuel Rudin. The bank plans to open a branch there next summer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 --The House space committee announced today that it would begin hearings in January to determine why the United States was "lagging" in space exploration.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 -- The Writers Guild of America, which is on strike against fifty independent producers and is readying a strike vote against the major studios, was the center of another controversy today. It was touched off by a speech last night by William Wyler, the director, at the Greater Los Angeles Press Club.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 28 -- In the face of unfavorable reaction abroad, Chancellor Adenauer appears to have drawn back from his stand that disarmament should be the only item for an East-West summit meeting.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

SYRACUSE, Oct. 28 -- The omission of any mention of Jesus in a proposed plan to merge the American Unitarian Association and the Universalist Church of America loomed here today as a major stumbling block to union.

The Austrian Chamber of Commerce in the United States will hold a "Musicale et Soiree Dansante" at Hampshire House on Nov. 19. Proceeds will benefit a scholarship fund for Austrian students to attend the Columbia University Graduate School of Business.

BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association today placed Wyoming and Montana State College on probation for violating rules on recruiting and financial aid to athletes. The action brought to five the number of schools disciplined by the N. C. A. A. during its three-day meeting that ended today.
The bond market continued quiet and hesitant yesterday, with Treasury securities repeating Tuesday's general drift to lower levels.
Representative Chester Bowles called yesterday for the formation of a commission to appraise the broadcasting industry.
Committee members for the tenth annual Fan Ball met yesterday at 14 Beekman Place the home of Mrs. William B. Leeds, chairman of the patrons and patronesses committee.
The United States Court of Appeals held yesterday that arbitration clauses in commercial contracts involving interstate business and maritime transactions are valid and enforceable in Federal courts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- Kenny Lane turned near-defeat into victory tonight with speedy, in-and-out tactics that won a majority decision over Virgil Akins, a former welterweight champion, at the new Capitol Arena.

Regina Safarty and Barbara Meister entered the cast of Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte" last night at the New York City Center. The young singers were so charming that one regretted more than ever that the City Opera was not giving the opera again this year.
Counsel for seventeen present and former Municipal Court justices entered a judgment for $227,500 against the city yesterday for back pay from 1933 to 1946.

A projected acquisition of two Milwaukee banks by a new bank holding company, the Bank Stock Corporation of Milwaukee, has been delayed until Dec. 3, by order of the Department of Justice, it was learned yesterday.

Last night's Carnegie Hall recital by the soprano Elisabeth Schwarzkopf was superbly expressive singing by a great artist in top form.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower said today that the Government was examining "our whole system of extending credit" to other countries to see whether the United States could require that some of the money "be used to buy our products."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -President Eisenhower accepted today with "deep regret" the resignation of Robert Murphy, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington has canceled his scheduled speech at a state Democratic dinner here Friday night because the affair will be segregated.

Net income of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company rose to $14,049,031, in the quarter ended Sept. 30, from $12,055,562 in the period of last year, according to a report issued today. The latest earnings were equal to $1.42 a common share, compared with $1.22 a share a year earlier.

If Mickey Mantle has been having trouble sleeping these autumn nights because of his admittedly lack-luster season in 1959, this piece of news should enable him to rest more comfortably. A proposal to consolidate several city agencies into an over-all Department of Housing and Real Estate was sent to the Legislature yesterday by Assemblyman Samuel A. Spiegel, Manhattan Democrat-Liberal.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28 -- Fears that the long strikes in steel, copper and other key metals would spread to the aluminum industry were reduced today.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 27 -- The West German wine industry, shaken two years ago by a domestic faking scandal, is moving now to wipe out similarly dubious export marketing practices.

As special aid to refugees in a dozen countries. American gifts through CARE will total more than $5,000,000 in the two fiscal years from 1958 to 1960.
ROME, Oct. 28 (AP) -- More than 15,000 persons, gathered in St. Peter's Basilica today, cheered John XXIII on the first anniversary of his election as Pope.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- A daring sea rescue of 500 passengers and crewmen of a burning Soviet motor vessel was reported here today. They were saved from a raging three-day fire that swept the ship Dvina two weeks ago.

Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad, the leader of the industry, apparently decided yesterday that the time had come to stress the maintenance and the day-by-day train performance throughout the system's 9,900 miles of line.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- John Hay Whitney, United States Ambassador to Britain, unveiled today a memorial statue to Sir Walter Raleigh. The envoy described him as the "man who, more than any other, was responsible for the discovery of Virginia, and for the settlement of the first colony in America."
The Whitney Museum of American Art yesterday attracted far more than its usual complement of visitors when it opened its exhibition of American art that had been shown in Moscow last summer.

The 400 parishes of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will be staff Nov. 22 to 29 to receive donations of clothing, shoes and blankets for distribution to people in refugee camps and poverty-stricken areas around the world.

The Detroit Red Wings and their star goalie, Terry Sawchuk, had the New York Rangers hanging on the boards for two periods last night at Madison Square Garden. Then the Rangers, trailing by 3 -- 0, put on a third-period spurt for a 3-3 tie in the National Hockey League clash before 10,834.
Earnings of the Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa) in the quarter ended on Sept. 30 declined from year-ago levels despite a gain in sales.

Honorary patrons have been announced for Art to Live With, the first annual art show and sale sponsored by members of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Decorators. A comprehensive selection of American and European paintings and sculpture will be offered for sale at prices ranging from $20 to $40,000.
Representatives of more than a score of organizations pleaded here yesterday for increased Federal aid to the handicapped.
IN the second half of John Dos Passos' "U. S. A." which was acted at the Martinique Theatre last evening, Sada Thompson tells the story of Isadora Duncan.

ONCE again Louise Nevelson, grand mistress of the marvelous, illumines her fabled world at the Martha Jackson Gallery. 32 East Sixty-ninth Street. In this sculpture exhibition Miss Nevelson surpasses everything she has done before.
General Electric has developed a laboratory model of a new generator without moving parts that may play an important part in the operation of space vehicles.

A devoted trustee of the American Shakespeare Festival at Stratford, Conn., Katharine Hepburn occasionally finds time to become an intergral part of the program. In 1957, she interpreted Portia in "The Merchant of Venice" and Beatrice in "Much Ado About Nothing."
Branch Rickey, for all his 77 years, still can throw a sharp verbal barb with plenty on it. He let fly with one yesterday.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., Oct. 28 -- A new $50,000 laboratory designed to help relieve the acute shortage of technicians in the electronics field will be inspected at the Division Avenue High School here tomorrow by representatives of industry who assisted in its planning.

DETROIT, Oct. 28 -- The steel strike is causing heavy cutbacks in newspaper advertising by automotive makers here, according to a check at various companies.
SAYVILLE, L. I., Oct. 28 -- Four hundred persons attended the opening convocation of the Suffolk County branch of Adelphi College at the former Sayville Junior High School building tonight.

RISOTTO, in North Italy, is a broad term describing any one of many dishes in which rice is the principal ingredient. Il Talismano, one of Italy's most comprehensive cookbooks, gives thirty-five recipes for risotto. And the list could have been expanded more than a hundredfold.

Electric power production declined to a six-month low of 12,762,000,000 kilowatt hours last week from 12,861,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This was 4.8 per cent above the 1958 figure of 12,174,000,000 kilowatt hours.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 28 -- The failure of Congress to remove the 4 1/4 per cent interest ceiling on Government securities of five years' or more maturity has been "self-defeating," the American Bankers Association said today.
Investment bankers are offering today $30,000,000 of Hilton Hotels Corporation twenty-five-year sinking fund debentures carrying warrants to purchase shares of Hilton common stock.

For some centuries the Spaniards and the French have been making, perpetuating or breaking peace along the little river flowing into the Bay of Biscay that is called the Bidassoa. A few days ago the Foreign Ministers of the two countries came there to celebrate the anniversary of the Treaty of the Pyrenees, signed in 1659 on small Pheasant Island in the middle of the river.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- Proponents of two draft resolutions on South-West Africa clashed today. The resolutions are substantially the same in their operative parts but differ in details.

ALGIERS, Oct. 28 -- France's highest representatives here are determined to tolerate no resistance, passive or otherwise, from their subordinates to the policies outlined by President de Gaulle Sept. 16.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Air Force announced plans today to close Ethan Allen Air Force Base in Vermont and to inactivate three fighter squadrons in Vermont, Ohio and New York.
HONG KONG, Oct. 28 -- Optimism over major gains this year in agriculture, industry, transport, production and communications was expressed today from Peiping.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 28 -- In about three years the Canouse Flowage has been transformed, at small cost and effort, from a blank stretch of water visited only occasionally by ducks into the residence of a duck population.

The Village Independent Democrats last night endorsed Joseph A. Sarafite for judge of the Court of General Sessions. At the same time, the reform group declined to make any recommendation for the second vacancy on the General Sessions bench.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Supreme Court rejected late today the Government's plea for a speed-up in the consideration of the steel case.
John T. Clancy, Queens Borough President, swore in an eleven-member City Charter Revision Commission yesterday. The group will examine the borough's role in city affairs as limited by the document.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- A sphere as big as a ten-story building was inflated 250 miles above the Atlantic Ocean today. Glistening in the evening sun, the huge space balloon was visible for hundreds of miles.
The New York entry in the new American Football League, still in swaddling clothes, was formally named the Titans yesterday.
Spokesmen for metropolitan milk dealers and five teamster unions said that both sides had made concessions yesterday in talks on a new contract.

Mitchell A. Cotter, who was found repairing his sports car on Sunday, Sept. 20, and thereupon was charged with violating the State Sabbath Law, was ruled not guilty yesterday by Magistrate Maurice E. Downing.

Charles Van Doren and Hank Bloomgarden have admitted to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan that they received both questions and answers prior to their appearances on the television quiz show "Twenty-One." Altogether the two men won $227,500 on the program.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 28 -- Administration leaders decided today to continue their support of Marshal Henrique Lott, Minister of War, for President rather than to seek a coalition with the Opposition.

The bond market went through another defensive session yesterday. Pricing specialists marked time until they could appraise the implications of the terms chosen by the Treasury for refunding $8,895,000,000 of notes and certificates of indebtedness due on Nov. 15.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The danger of war has been "considerably dissipated" but it would be a mistake to interrupt personal contacts with Premier Khrushchev, Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd declared today.
Graham-Paige Corporation announced yesterday that it had increased its ownership of Madison Square Garden Corporation to 84 per cent of the outstanding stock.

A woman science teacher in an East Harlem school was hospitalized with a possible brain concussion yesterday after she had been beaten by a husky 14-year-old pupil.

Stocks thrashed about yesterday in a tangle of tax selling, profit taking and short covering. There were wide gains and wide losses, but the market as a whole moved hardly at all. Some indicators had it up at the close; some had it down.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)--President Eisenhower chose Robert A. Forsythe today to be an Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

WARSAW, Oct. 29 -- Prof. Julian Hochfeld, a social historian and an intellectual spark of the 1956 liberalization, has been dismissed as head of the institute that is one of this country's political showcases.

Cornell will realign its football squad for the Columbia game at Ithaca, N. Y., tomorrow. Coach Lefty James of the Big Red said yesterday he would have five new starters.

CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 29 -- Fun-loving Dan Stuckey, head football coach at St. Paul's School, said today that his squad was the only "undefeated, untied and ungained upon" prep school eleven in New England. He also expressed confidence that this record would remain intact for at least another week.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd suggested today that the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union hold a joint series of underground nuclear tests to help them arrive at an agreement to end nuclear tests.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The American Trucking Associations reported today that the intercity truckloadings last week were 0.5 per cent ahead of the preceding week and 5.1 per cent above the level of a year ago.

FLORENCE, Italy, Oct. 29 -- The seventh congress of the ruling Christian Democratic party, just concluded, has resulted in a victory for the wing that wishes Premier Antonio Segni and his Cabinet to continue in power.

The voters of New York will shortly have an opportunity to approve a constitutional amendment which will be the first step toward a state tax reform long overdue. Amendment No. 8 would add a provision to the New York State Constitution making explicit the authority of the Legislature to permit the incorporation, by reference, of Federal definitions of income for purposes of computing the New York State income tax.

The two top executives of General Mills, Inc., sponsor of several television shows, starred in a TV show of their own yesterday.
ALBANY, Oct. 29 (UPI) -Governor Rockefeller said today that the state has gained economically through its program of rehabilitation of handicapped persons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- State Department officials welcomed the proposal of Foreign Minister Lloyd today for an international series of underground test explosions. They said it supported a suggestion already made by the United States.

The selection of committee members has been completed by the Girls Club of New York for its theatre benefit at the Dec. 15 performance of "Saratoga." The musical is expected to open on Dec. 7 at the Winter Garden Theatre.
" PLAYHOUSE 90" elected last night to revive George Bernard Shaw's "Misalliance'' on Channel 2. One can only wonder what on earth for.

MOSCOW, Oct. 29 -- A Soviet publication accused Walter P. Reuther today of being a "traitor" to the workers' cause and a "lackey" of monopolists.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Eisenhower played a round of golf in brisk autumn weather this afternoon and then checked into Walter Reed Army Medical Center for his annual physical examination.

Mayor Wagner gave his Police Commissioner a light rap on the knuckles yesterday for characterizing as "phony" and "frivolous" a City Council resolution urging that policemen carry nightsticks on a twenty-four-hour basis.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the United States Communist party, engaged in a shouting match today with Senator Roman Hruska at a hearing on Communist activity here.

The editorial "Aspirin Not Indicated" in your Oct. 22 issue and Prof. Richard Gardner's letter published Oct. 26 berate, as entailing trade restriction and the discredited "Buy America" principle, the Development Loan Fund's policy decision that henceforth its loans must normally be spent in the United States.
Canadian Pacific Air Lines has ordered four 159-passenger Douglas DC-8 jet airliners. It has an option to buy five more. Each costs $6,000,000. The first delivery is scheduled for early in 1961.
The group of four five-story store and apartment buildings at 1710 to 1716 Third Avenue and 179 East Ninety-sixth Street, the northwest corner, has been resold by Harry Horwitz, realty operator.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A death toll of more than 1,000 may be counted in the hurricane and flood that swept two Pacific coast states in central Mexico, the Government said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The resignation yesterday of Under Secretary of State Robert Murphy was something more than the end of a long and notable diplomatic career. It was the beginning of the end of that brilliant generation of Foreign Service officers who helped guide the nation through the convulsive transition from isolation to world leadership.
The intelligence quotient, which is widely viewed as an infallible guide for determining mental capacity, has been highly overrated, a leading educator said yesterday.

WILFRED THESIGER, author of "Arabian Sands,"* may be the last of the great explorers. Other men, equipped with a dozen varieties of scientific machinery, will continue to be hailed as explorers. But men of Mr. Thesiger's vanishing breed will continue to regard them with lofty condescension.
PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin has been told by his civil superiors to stay out of politics.
WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 29 -- A seven-foot-square sign with huge block letters reading "Like a Hole in the Head" hung this morning on the second story of a building in the center of town.
Interference with the nation's top professional men by administrators of "substantially lower intellect" was deplored last night by Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover.
New York's first publicly sponsored industrial park would give the city a $95,000,000 modern factory area on ninety-five acres in the Flatlands-Canarsie area of Brooklyn.
Earnings of the General Motors Corporation in the third quarter of this year were more than double those in the 1958 period, according to a report issued for publication today.
Reports of additional labor trouble in the strike-bound copper industry raised copper futures prices yesterday on the Commodity Exchange.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Britain repaid to the United States Export-Import Bank today a $250,000,000 loan that was not due until April, 1965.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Rocky Marcian a former heavyweight champion, received encouragement from Gov. Leroy Collins today and went ahead with plans to arrange a title bout in Miami's Orange Bowl.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 29 -- Edward P. Larkin, presiding supervisor of the town of Hempstead, said today he was filing a $250,000 civil libel suit against his Democratic opponent in next week's elections.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Broad general selling hit the grain futures market shortly before the close of the Board of Trade today and at the finish there was not a single plus sign in the list.

THE first dates of the season from Arizona recently arrived in various New York stores. Unbelievably plump, juicy and tender, these fruits make a delicious between-meal snack or a most acceptable hostess gift.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Railroad freight loadings rose last week to the highest point in four months, according to the Association of American Railroads. Carloadings totaled 607,347 units, the highest since 697,726 cars were loaded in the week ended on June 27.
Two Long Island school districts borrowed a total of $5,053,000 in the bond market yesterday. A third Long Island district announced plans for a $2,000,000 bond financing on Nov. 10.
Many persons entertained last night in connection with the Bal Militaire in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor. The fete was a benefit for the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club, Inc.

Fountain House, at 412 West Forty-seventh Street, a rehabilitation center for patients discharged from mental hospitals, will receive the proceeds of the Fountain House Foundation's annual theatre party on Jan. 14.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Air Force launched its advanced Mace-B guided missile on the first of a new series of tests today.
The City Housing Authority is looking for $2,500,000 with which to keep the sixty-eight community centers in municipal housing projects open on weekends. The centers are now open five days a week.
The Senate Small Business Committee will send its counsel here next week to gather data on businesses threatened with dislocation by Federally aided slum clearance and highway projects.

THE speed with which the twentieth century has consumed art movements is demonstrated in Sidney Janis' "New Acquisitions" show at 15 East Fifty-seventh Street. All the "isms" are there, and nearly all the great practitioners are represented.
HOUSTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Rice Institute refused today to rent its football stadium to a possible Houston entry in the professional National Football League.
Baby chimpanzees, like human toddlers, discover that walking is a knack one is not born with.

A new kit for converting six-cylinder automobile engines of the Chrysler line to marine use has been brought out by the Barr Marine Products Company of Philadelphia. The bolt-on device fits Plymouth, Dodge, DeSoto and Chrysler engines built between 1936 and 1959. Barr says it is the only manufacturersup-i plying conversions for the line.
The Long Island Rail Road got into the black last month for the first time this year. "And it is probably the last," a spokesman for the carrier said yesterday.

Fashion trends for spring are taking shape as Seventh Avenue designers present collections, the American equivalent of the Paris openings. The New York Times has been barred from some showing because of its policy to report trends immediately. Reports on those showings are based on information from other fashion authorities. Most of the clothes will be in stores by January.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29-Harold E. Stassen insisted today that he was exempt from municipal taxes on his salary for 1953 through 1956.

" Gizi," which will terminate a one-year run Sunday night at the Sutton Theatre, will have earned $543.927 in rental for its producer-distributor. Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, for the fifty-two-week engagement. This is the largest film rental ever earned by any film in a single engagement at regular prices, according to Donald S. Rugoff, president of the Rugoff Becker Theatres, operators of the Sutton.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Walt Alston, who led the Dodgers to world series championships both in Brooklyn and Los Angeles, today accepted a one-year contract for 1960 with a good rise, the club's general manager, E. J. (Buzzie) Bavasi, said.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the city planned to increase its financial assistance to private hospitals by $4,000,000 next year, but added that he never wanted "to see the day when government takes over the care of the needy sick."
Add oe-half cup of raisins toI the boiling salted water in which you cook rolled oats for breakfast. Serve hot, topped with cinnamon sugar.
The defense of the New York Rangers has not been performing in strong fashion and Coach Phil Watson has taken steps to correct that shortcoming.
PARIS, Fri day, Oct. 30 -Frenchmen will have slightly lower taxes to pay on personal incomes next year, according to a fiscal reform bill approved by the National Assembly early this morning.
A leader in the American Cancer Society last night urged a "clean-up" in fund-raising to curb the growth of demands on the public's time and money for worthy causes.
A legislative committee that investigated the tapping of the telephone of Charles E. McGuinness is considering amending present laws to give more protection to individuals thus spied on.

A former combat infantry sergeant won a victory yesterday in Federal Court over the Government, which had sought to rectify a seventeen-year-old bookkeeping error in his World War II pay. It was a case of a "little man" becoming enmeshed in bureaucracy.
ALBANY, Oct. 29 (AP) -Registration for next Tuesday's election totals 6,878,947, the highest in the state's history for any but Presidential election years, the Secretary of State reported tonight.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation reported yesterday that it lost $16,465,000 in the strike-affected third quarter. The company, which has the fourth largest steel-making capacity in the country, cleared $6,698,000, or 81 cents a common share, in the period last year.

Halsey Stuart Co., Inc., and associates will offer today, subject to clearance from the Securities and Exchange Commission, $8,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of the Wisconsin Public Service Company with a 5 1/4 per cent coupon. The bonds, which will mature in 1989, are priced at 101.519 to yield 5.15 per cent.

The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation reported yesterday new highs in operating revenues and net income for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30. The pipeline company is the principal supplier of natural gas for the New York-New Jersey-Philadelphia areas.

The president of States Marine Lines told the special House antitrust subcommittee investigating the ocean freight industry yesterday that in his opinion there was a difference between favors and entertainment of shipper clients and a flat rebate.
BOSTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Bronco Horvath proved too much for Terry Sawchuk and the Detroit Red Wings tonight as the Boston Bruins scored a 2-1 National Hockey League Victory.
Gaspar Ortega is on the war-! path.

Attendance at "The Gang's All Here" has given clear proof that a political play can be a hit, although the notices were only four to three in its favor. Another drama of the same genre, Gore Vidal's "The Best Man," is in the offing.
I LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 29[ (AP)--Sponsors of Arkansas' Democratic harmony dinner are catching it from both sides over the question of where Negroes Iwill sit.

MOSCOW, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Pushkin Gallery, one of the most noted in the country, opened a month-long exhibition of American painting and sculpture today with 140 works of art dating from early to modern times. It included no real abstractionists or primitives, however.
CASTRO VALLEY, Calif., Oct. 29 -- Two surgeons have grafted an almost-severed leg back into place, it was revealed today.
JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 29 -- Communist China's actions in 1959 have caused concern in neutralist Asian nations, interviews with a cross-section of officials from these countries indicate.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- The United States intends to establish contact with the Soviet Union in the next few days in hopes of reaching agreement on a General Assembly resolution on outer space.

Yesterday we summarized our recommendations regarding candidates for judicial office, state-wide and in Manhattan and the Bronx. Today we summarize similar recommendations for Brooklyn and Queens, basing our choices on the reports of the city's leading bar associations and the Citizens Union. (There are no judicial elections this year in Staten Island.)
" I may become the losingest coach in history and they may want to send me to sea. But that doesn't concern me. I took this job because I wanted to get lost."
Many of the United Hospital Fund's member hospitals are famed as leaders in new ideas for health. Their schools also supply the ever - increasing demand for new physicians, surgeons and nurses.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Roy W. Johnson, retiring director of the Advanced Research Projects Agency, urged today spending $240,000,000 next year for the Saturn heavy-thrust rocket booster.
Two stations will join the QXR radio network on Sunday, raising to seventeen the number of stations in the FM chain.
ONTONAGON, Mich., Oct. 29 (AP) -- More than 1,000 White Pine Copper Company workers struck today to back their demands for a new contract.

The crucial congress of the Italian Christian Democratic party in Florence ended yesterday in victory for everybody concerned. Only in Italy, with its subtle, complicated and artistic game of politics, could such a result be achieved.
Ed Kovac, a 195-pound University of Cincinnati halfback, has taken over major college football's scoring leadership with a two-week point-making spree.
OPPORTUNITIES for the winning play in today's deal may occur rarely, but they happen just often enough for the play to be worth learning. It can be figured out at the time, but it seldom is.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Eleazar de Carvalho, conductor, Westminster Choir, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; "The Marriage of Figaro." Metropolitan Opera, 8; "Madama Butterfly," New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15; Detroit Symphony Orchestra, Paul Paray, conductor, Lorin Hollander, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Larry Adler, harmonica player, Town Hall, 8:40.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Willie Shoemaker today told trainers and owners in Toronto he thought his colt would prove tough to beat Saturday in the Garden State Stakes -- the world's richest horse race. The race has a gross value of $285,075.
Mikhail Tal, a 24-year-old Latvian member of the Soviet team of four in the challengers' chess tournament, emerged last night as the winner, according to a report from Yugoslavia.
A part-time shopping mall in the city's congested financial district is under study, Hulan E. Jack, Borough President of Manhattan, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today that the Federally sponsored rural development program "is successfully attacking the age-old and chronic problem of low incomes" in farm areas.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Eisenhower has accepted President Charles de Gaulle's suggestion that a summit meeting of Western powers be held in Paris beginning Dec. 19.

Several things come to mind immediately with the news that Robert Murphy has resigned from the Foreign Service and from the State Department. The first is consciousness of the fact that the nation has reason to be deeply grateful for his long and distinguished service. We are in his debt for skillful handling of difficult situations, for devotion to duty, for self-effacement and for getting real results.
Nearly 275,000 New York City voters who failed to go to the polls last year face the cancellation of their registration unless they vote this year.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (UPI) -Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation entered today the widening search for a Federal appeals court judge who disappeared in Chicago three days ago.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation sustained a record loss of $38,926,913 in the third quarter of this year, when production was limited to two weeks by the nationwide steel strike.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- There has been a good deal of skull practice with a recently expressed view by a majority of the company executives who responded to a National Industrial Board questionnaire on the subject of business men in active politics. This view was that "companies, acting through their executives and employes," should seek directly to influence the trend of political affairs.

Trading in the stock of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation has been pretty heavy in recent weeks, but yesterday it came near the spectacular. The stock opened on a block of 25,000 shares. In the first hour of trading alone volume was 239,500 shares, compared with 970,000 for the entire market.
Maurice Stern was the emperor of China in last night's "Turandot" at the City Center. It was his first time in the part.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Government announced today that it would buy only three items for the strategic stockpile during the present fiscal year, which ends Next June 30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 8 per I cent above the level of a year ago.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 29 -- Every decent deer-hunting region has a monstrous buck, generally called Ol' Crookjaw or Ol' Stub-toe, that nobody is able to kill, and this region is no indecent exception. The monstrous buck here is known as Ol' Mose.
An acute shortage of neurologists is holding up the wider application of recent discoveries in the treatment of nervous disorders, a Congressional subcommittee was told here yesterday.
ALGIERS, Oct. 29 -- Officers commanding the French Army in Algeria are confident that a cease-fire, if it occurred, would not shake the army's control of Algerian territory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Diplomatic sources expect the United States to reprimand South Korea's Ambassador, You Chang Yang, for what it regards as undiplomatic and unacceptable efforts to put pressure on it in an international dispute.

Starlet Miss raced in front all the way to win the feature at Aqueduct yesterday. With Eddie Arcaro guiding her, the filly owned by Jules G. Krams beat El Peco Ranch's Penumbra by more than two lengths in the one-mile race.
A New York State legislative committee yesterday explored means of applying the insurance principle to dental costs. It found something of a cavity in the field but no clear consensus how to fill it.

In a television debate with Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa yesterday, Mayor Wagner declared that rejection of the proposed $500,000,000 school bond issue could convert New York City into "a second-class town."
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that there "may be additional questioning of other television quiz show contestants" by his office.
The four good musicians of the New York Quartet made their debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

Traditional Halloween trappings promise to be plentiful and reasonable in cost this week-end. Apples head the list and are many and various. Ornamental Indian corn is in good supply and all shapes and sizes of pumpkins and gourds adorn fruit stands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29-Twenty-nine business associations and nine labor organizations have objected to the Government's proposals for new definitions of deductible and nondeductible lobbying expenditures.

The Trans Continental Industries, Inc., a corporate shell, has signed a contract under which it will receive 100 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Republic Appliance Corporation in exchange for its own stock.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Israel proposed today that the United Nations consider the possibility of regional programs of arms limitation while negotiations on complete disarmament went forward.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- An increase in employment in the Chicago metropolitan area by 1965 was forecast today as a result of the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

Readers of The New York Times who have long memories may wonder at the sameness of things, for October is the month when gambling and vice seem to flourish at their most outrageous. In the first nippy days of fall the zeal of public officials swells mightily to combat evils.
HAVANA, Friday, Oct. 30--The right of habeas corpus was suspended yesterday by the Cuban Cabinet.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 -- An American who made good in Paris returned to Hollywood this week after twelve years abroad. Eddie Constantine, who left Hollywood as a chorus boy and returned as the "top male box-office draw in France," is here to perform on the Dinah Shore television show Sunday.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Tides of the Delaware River will be used to help take down and then replace a section of the Pennsylvania Railroad's bridge between here and Delair, N. J.
The Westchester Pleasantville League, Inc., will hold its annual dinner dance Nov. 14 at the Plaza. This year's fete will be called the Beaux Arts Ball.
The president of the Board of Education yesterday invited voters to visit the city school system's older buildings and decide for themselves whether the structures should be replaced.

" Face the Nation," which usually features interviews with political leaders or other figures associated with issues of the day, has decided on a change of pace by booking Dmitri Shostakovich, Soviet composer.
DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 29 -Guinea's President Sekou Toure ended a one-day visit to the South today "very, very happy" over his reception and what he had seen.
THE new president of the State University of New York read with interest in a Lansing, Mich., newspaper recently that he was "dynamic."

VIENNA, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Frank Sedgman of Australia maintained his hold on first place in the European professional Grand Prix tennis tournament tonight, defeating his countryman, Lew Hoad, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3.
A baseball event moved into New York yesterday and for a pleasant change it involvec lfallplayers. In fact, many players were present, 'some of them coming from as far off as California.
Yesterday morning was another bad time for railroad and subway commuters.
Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad elected Edward James Hanley and Allen J. Greenough board members at their meeting on Wednesday, it was announced yesterday.

Getting works of art into the American home has occupied the minds of a great variety of people over the years. Artists, decorators, printmakers and upholsterers have struggled with changing tastes and stubborn opinions through each generation only to have their efforts relegated to the attic, the rummage sale and the charity collection in the next.
The General Motors Corporation, largest manufacturer of motor vehicles, moved yesterday toward a total shutdown of its nation-wide operations as a result of the 107-day-old steel strike.

The letter appearing in The New York Times on Oct. 13 which encourages widening, the gap between the Russians and Chinese peoples and aligning the Russians with the "Western bloc" implies the desirability of thus turning the world into two hostile camps.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 --The Trusteeship Committee voted tonight to ask the General Assembly to "invite" South Africa to negotiate with the United Nations the status of the territory of South-West Africa.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 -- The East Berlin city government has warned Evangelical Bishop Otto Dibelius that it will bar him from future activities in East Berlin unless he issues a "declaration of loyalty" to the Communist authorities, it was disclosed today.

Lumber production rose last week to 258,824,000 board feet from 256,666,000 in the preceding week, according to reports by regional association. This compares with output of 264,733,000 board feet in the like 1958 week.

The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday a net income of $180,114,501, or $2.85 a share, in the first nine months of this year. This compares with $187,743,514, or $2.97 a share, in the 1958 period.
The highly touted new freedom of the movie screen has run into its first major snag since the film Production Code was loosened three years ago.

Chief Assistant District Attorney Alfred J. Scotti told a General Sessions jury yesterday that he would prove with "devastating clarity" that Frankie Carbo had acted as an unlicensed manager and match-maker of professional boxers.
The Ford Foundation announced grants totaling $1,927,000 yesterday for internships to improve Federal, state and municipal public services.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 29 -- India's ruling Congress party has suffered a sharp setback in a traditional stronghold, Uttar Pradesh.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York announced its support yesterday of a proposed constitutional amendment to make it easier for the Legislature to align the state income tax law with Federal practice.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 29--The United States, Britain and France have agreed that their troops will be used if necessary to prevent the flying of the new East German Communist flag in West Berlin.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Share prices continued to advance in the stock market here today. The demand was not as aggressive as yesterday and still focused on second-string industrials offering a higher-than-average yield.

THE holiday whirl is on at Gimbels. Although the third floor Resort and Holiday Shop doesn't open officially until Nov. 15, some of the clothes have already filtered into the store and the rest can be ordered in advance.

A critique of this country's dealings with other nations is presented by Emmet Hughes in "America, the Vincible." Mr. Hughes examines our relations with the Communist bloc and the uncommitted nations and what he considers are the errors we are making in regard to our allies.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville confirmed today that France had agreed to a meeting of Western heads of government here in mid-December and that Premier Khrushchev would visit France sometime during the first three months of next year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Government declared war today on college-degree mills.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 29 (Reuters) -- Sports fans debated the propriety today of using witch-doctor charms and juju ritual as aids in soccer strategy.

TOKYO, Oct. 29 -- Spokesmen for thirty-five nations subscribing to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade have agreed with the United States position that countries that can afford it should abolish restrictions on imports.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- New York City was assured today of a world's fair in 1964.
Mayor Wagner said last night that a 1964 world's fair here, as approved by President Eisenhower, would be a "tremendous thing" for the city.

The liner Israel and the freighter American Press collided here last night under a clear, moonless sky just north of the Statue of Liberty in one of the busiest crossroads of the harbor. One crewman was reported missing, but no passengers were injured.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 -- A third steel company was added tonight to the list of signers of the strike settlement accepted by the Kaiser Steel Corporation.

Not so many generations ago a man from what is now the Republic of Guinea came to this side of the Atlantic only as a slave. That is not, however, how President Sekou Toure has come to this country, and especially to North Carolina. M. Toure is the Chief Executive of a nation which has been free only since September, 1958, and which is now considering what to do with its freedom.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration appeared surprised today by the stir caused when it inflated a light-reflecting balloon 250 miles above earth.

LAST year "Tosca" opened the Metropolitan Opera season. This year the popular Puccini opera was saved for the third bill, and Rudolf Bing presented it at the opera house last night with largely familiar elements in the re-studied version that Dimitri Mitropoulos took over four seasons ago.
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 29 -Seven hundred pupils enrolled in the Department of Parks' evening recreational program were locked out of six public schools here last night on orders of the Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Treasury today offered new one-year and four-year securities to the holders of almost $10,900,000,000 of outstanding issues.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Gov. John Patterson said tonight that agents of the Federal Civil Rights Commissionwere investigating new Negro registration complaints in Alabama. He urged state officials not to cooperate.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Bethlehem Steel Company submitted the apparent low bid today for building three 14,000-ton cargo-passenger vessels for Grace Line, Inc.

Army and the Air Force Academy will present strikingly similar styles of attack in tomorrow's big football game at Yankee Stadium. Their basic formations are much the same and both stress forward passing.

THE practice squadron from the Naval Academy anchored in the Hudson off West Point and the midshipmen, going ashore, challenged the cadets to either a baseball game or a boat race. The non-athletic cadets of that era politely said they had the equipment for neither sport. But they would condescend to a rousing game of marbles.
At 4:45 A. M., yesterday a lone figure strolled in out of the morning dark to become the first customer in Eastern Air Lines' $20,000,000 passenger terminal at New York International Airport.
LANSING, Mich., Oct. 29 -- The Michigan Legislature grappled with the state's financial crisis today but failed to act with the speed sought by Gov. G. Mennen Williams.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the three months ended Sept. 30 dropped to $2,014,000 from $6,905,000 in the 1958 period.
ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- Dr. Thomas Hale Hamilton, a 45-year-old educator from the Middle West, was installed tonight as the third president of the State University of New York.
ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- The Court of Appeals refused today to restore two Queens candidates of the United Taxpayers party to the ballot for next Tuesday's election.

On Tuesday, Oct. 29, 1929, just thirty years ago yesterday, came the worst break in New York Stock Exchange history. Like many another dramatic occasion, the collapse meant many things to many people.

Loans to business by the fifteen large New York City banks increased $1,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the preceding week they declined $108,000,000 and in the 1958 week they increased $25,000,000.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 29 -- The Government's difficulties with a Congress controlled by a hostile Opposition are at an end, President Mario Echandi said in an interview today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- More than 1,000 employes at three Wilson Co. meat-packing plants went off the job today in a dispute over work schedules.

An investigation of the dispute between two Brooklyn judges over the Manceri murder case was ordered yesterday by Chief Judge Albert Conway of the Court of Appeals, the highest ranking judge in the state.
A $40,000,000 proposal for rebuilding a Williamsburg slum area was revived yesterday by the Seafarers International Union.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 29--Unitarians and Untversalists were Iwarned here today to accept or reject without equivocation a proposed union of the two I bodies.

The young addict who succeeds in breaking his drug habit finds few helping hands as he tries to achieve a normal life, speakers declared yesterday at a conference on narcotic addiction and the teen-ager.
Four youths accused of beating and stamping on a 17-year-old boy who tried to quit a street gang called the Sinners were held in $5,000 bail each yesterday.

THE word "lounge" has a lazy connotation. That's why the Bloomingdale's collection called "loungewear" is misnamed. There's nothing listless about these robes, which are intended "to live in the living room."
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 29 -- India's Vice President, Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan, has declined an invitation to visit Peiping, his office said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Following is the text of the report by the President's commission on a world's fair:

SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 29 -- Financiers and industrialists met here today in the First Reunion of Central American Investors. They are gathered to come to grips with the problem of "ruinous competition" within the five-country area.

You can lead an alcoholic to a clinic and make him not drink, experts on the illness agreed yesterday. The secret, a physician told an industrial symposium on alcoholism, is the early detection of symptoms and the threat of losing his job.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 30 -- This state's Democrats sat down tonight to a "harmony" dinner but the absence of a key speaker and numerous party members gave mute testimony to the lack thereof.

With horse-of-the-year honors at stake in the $111,600 Jockey Club Gold Cup, Willie Molter, Kerr Stable trainer, said late yesterday that he would defer the naming of a rider for Round Table until today.
A shipping man who told a Congressional committee that a law was poorly written will have his chance next week to show if he can do any better.
MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- The Soviet press continued today its scathing attacks on Walter P. Reuther.

NEWTOWN, Conn., Oct. 30 -A suit by a citizens' group against a state law permitting public transportation for private school pupils is scheduled to go before the state's Supreme Court of Errors in January.
TECHNICALLY speaking, yesterday afternoon's Philharmonic concert might be regarded as the official debut of Eleazar de Carvalho with the orchestra.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30 -- Dartmouth, the defending Ivy League champion, will face Yale, one of the aspirants for its title, tomorrow at the Yale Bowl.

Ben Schiller, who has a radio in the rear of his greetingcard store at 147 East Eightysixth Street, said yesterday he had been astonished to learn that he was expected to pay $5 a month to a music society for the privilege of playing the radio.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 30 -The richest horse race in the world, with a gross value of $283,075, will be run tomorrow when the Garden State Stakes will be contested.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Notre Dame faces Navy tomorrow in college football's longest continuous intersectional rivalry.
A two-year study to determine whether the nation's high schools are teaching students to think or merely to pass tests is being planned by the Educational Records Bureau.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 28 -- Nicaraguan rebels are reported to have raided seven towns and to have killed at least 100 Nicaraguan National Guard troops in the last two weeks.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Oct. 30 -- Saudi Arabia challenged today a suggestion by Israel that a regional arms limitation plan for the Middle East be considered while negotiations over world disarmament were proceeding.
Sixty pastors of Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island have declared their churches open to everyone "without regard to race or color."

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Viscount Alanbrooke wrote in his diary that shortly before the Battle of the Bulge General Eisenhower was "on the golf links at Rheims -- entirely detached and taking practically no part in running the war."
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 30 -- The Jersey City Board of Education today ended its two-night lockout of 700 children from an evening recreational program in the schools.
The Air Force Academy eleven had more trouble getting off the ground yesterday in Denver than it is likely to have against Army at Yankee Stadium today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Albert S. Samuels, a San Francisco jeweler for sixty-two years, has put the classification of diamonds on a scientific basis. His method of examining the stones was patented this Week.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Continued strong demand for industrials, particularly those offering higher - than - average yields, heavily outweighed customary week-end profit taking in the stock market here today. Shares again closed with long list of gains.
THE deal shown today produced some of the most varied scores in the first session of the Metropolitan Championships, which began yesterday afternoon at the Statler Hilton Hotel.
Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller received an award for her services to nursing yesterday and she immediately began to earn another one: She told nurses they needed better salaries and working conditions.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Battles for control of companies by other interests are indirectly attacked in a report issued today by a committee representing leading financial institutions.

MAX PERKINS, greatest of modern book editors, believed that a man could either write a book or talk a book -- he couldn't do both. Which is all too true, as we all know. Yet it seems to me that in "I Have Known Many Worlds"* Roger Burlingame presents a fine variation on the Perkinsonian Law.
The Coast Guard opened an investigation yesterday of the crash between the Israeli liner Israel and the American freighter American Press.

Chinese vermilion and gold flake trimmings, a cashier's cage in the shape of a Chinese pagoda, and brightly lit gas chandeliers bedecked a store opened at 31 Vesey Street, here, in October, just one hundred years ago.

A closed-circuit television monitor for automatic elevators was demonstrated yesterday in an apartment house at 316 West Seventy-ninth Street for Joseph Goldberg, Rent Administrator for lower Manhattan.

SHORTLY after 11 o'clock this morning, a dimpled, pony-tailed 12-year-old who likes stuffed animals, television whodunits, a Siamese cat named Ilyitch and a parakeet named Sebastian, is due to walk onto the stage of the Hunter College Assembly Hall, seat herself at a Steinway and indicate to Thomas Scherman, the conductor, that she is ready to proceed.
The thirty-fifth anniversary of the first flight around the world was celebrated here last night.
The Transport Workers Union opened negotiations yesterday with the city's two largest private bus lines.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct. 30 -- The Government has initiated a move to cut back the size and privileges of the Soviet diplomatic mission here.
ALGIERS, Oct. 30 -- Paul Delouvrier, French Delegate General in Algeria, vowed in a tough speech today that France and her army would stay in Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- An authority on inter-group relations reported here today that the last five years had witnessed a steady decline in social discrimination practices "in the residence, the fraternity, and even the town and city social club."

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -Soybean futures dealings accounted for more than half the total volume on the Board of Trade again today as dealers bid prices up two cents or more a bushel, the strongest advance since Monday.
Paul Paray, by now an old friend to New Yorkers, came to Carnegie Hall last night with his Detroit Symphony Orchestra. His program was a careful blend of the old, the new and the unfamiliar.
The scheduled airlines serving La Guardia Airport will cut their flights in and out of that airport by one-sixth starting Dec. 1 to reduce congestion during La Guardia's modernization.

With October trading just ended, Wall Street is already abuzz with conjecture about what November will be like. That is because, in many ways, October was a "month of indecision" with no clear trend emerging. Stocks moved back and forth, although there were a few good advances and some days of sizable losses.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The case of the man in the air-conditioned crane cab has become a whodunit in the steel dispute. So far, everyone has given the wrong answer.
MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- Soviet astronomers reported today that they had further confirmation of volcanic activity on the moon.

PALM DESERT, Calif., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Jock Hutchison, Paul Runyan and Harry Cooper have been elected to golf's Hall of Fame. Harold Sargent of Atlanta, president of the Professional Golfers Association, revealed today.
Specialties continued their leaps and pirouettes in yesterday's stock market but the rank and file of stocks plodded on without much change.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 30 -Trial balloons are aloft over Baghda for the formation of a new political party in the name of Premier Abdul Karim Kassim.
A new contract extension--the third in a week--kept negotiations going yesterday between metropolitan area milk dealers and five locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

New York City proved its case convincingly, and the 1964 World's Fair will be held here. There are several reasons for gratification at this decision, made by President Eisenhower's site selection committee. We believe, first of all, that because of our resources, our experience, our available leadership the fair itself will be better for being staged here.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 30 -- The Dominican Republic has spent $50,000,000 to buy arms abroad this year because of threats of invasion from Cuba, Vice President Joaquin Balaguer said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to hear the steel case.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Sales of manufacturers last month increased about 1 per cent over the August level, with virtually all the rise reflecting heavier deliveries of soft goods.

The musty archives of the Library of Congress and the New York Historical Society are serving as valuable sources for helping to create an atmosphere of high realism in Saul Levitt's Civil War drama, "The Andersonville Trial."

The net income of CooperJarrett, Inc., a leading long-haul trucker, jumped 77 per cent in the first nine months of this year, Robert E. Cooper Jr., chairman, told members of the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday. He spoke at the group's regular luncheon meeting at 54 Broad Street.
Florentino Fernandez of Havana scored a hard-earned split decision over Gaspar (Indian) Ortega of Mexicali, Mexico, at Madison Square Garden last night.
The defense in the Apalachin trial yesterday challenged the legality of the indictment that accuses twenty-two men of obstructing a Government investigation of the upstate gathering in 1957.

TWENTIETH century art's effort to break through the conventional limitations of media has given sculpture a tremendous impetus. Whereas oil painting has somewhat enriched itself by the addition of paper, sand and miscellaneous odds and ends to the picture surface, sculpture has been able to take advantage of a wealth of new materials and techniques. Plastics are only one of the former and welding only one of the latter.
Samuel Fry Jr. of New York and Albert Rice Leventhal of Mamaroneck won the men's pair championship of the annual Metropolitan contract bridge tournament yesterday.

Sales and earnings of The Borden Company, big dairy products concern, set records for the third quarter and for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, Harold W. Comfort, president, reported yesterday. He said that year-end results were expected to set other records.

Murray-Allen Imports, Inc., importer of confections, has leased the former J. J. W. Williams Building at 135 East 144th Street, the Bronx, and will use it for executive offices and storage. The property is owned by Mrs. Paul B. Williams of Tenafly, N. J., and J. Palmer Williams Of Cheshire, Conn.

LET it be understood that in this space "The Marriage of Figaro" ranks as the supreme musical comedy of all time. As a thing of beauty and a joy forever, it deserves the tenderest and most lavish attentions.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 30 -- A Piedmont Airlines plane with twenty-seven persons aboard was missing and presumed to have crashed tonight in the vicinity of this north central Virginia city. Charlottesville was the next scheduled stop after the plane left Washington.
The volume of trading in copper futures was heavy yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. A total of 768 lots changed hands, the highest since June 24, when 908 lots were traded.

THOSE who want the outdoor garden brought indoors for Christmas -- or for that matter all year round -- might be interested in a new shop called the Gazebo. It is run by an interior landscape designer, Joseph McDonnal.
A West Side reform Democratic club announced yesterday its endorsement of Judge Samuel R. Pierce Jr., Republican -Liberal candidate for General Sessions.
The transfer of some pupils from overcrowded schools in East Harlem to under-utilized schools in neighboring Yorkville is under consideration.

A $3,100,000 damage suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court by Hearst Consolidated Publications, Inc., against the American Newspaper Guild, its officers and the editors of the union's national publication, The Guild Reporter.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., -- A moderately optimistic outlook for business in the coming year emerged today from a conference of 100 of the nation's business leaders. They make up the Department of Commerce's Business Advisory Council.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- The Board of Governors of the American Bar Association approved today a compromise report on passport control. It called for creation of a passport hearing board in the State Department.
MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 30 -The ease with which students fall asleep in the classroom is one criterion of success in an adult education course being offered in this school district.
One of the first police reports in the fatal beating of an elderly man in a Brooklyn park last summer quoted the victim as saying that he had been attacked by two men.
Camden, N. J., sold Thursday night bond issues totaling $4,589,000 to finance sewerage and water supply systems and school construction.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 30 -Robert A. Glasser, chairman of the New York State Harness Racing Commission, announced tonight that Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways had submitted a proposed schedule of racing dates for the 1960 and 1961 seasons.
Gracie is a takin, a creature native to Burma and distantly related to mountain goats, antelopes and Arctic musk oxen. She seems to be fondest of human beings, particularly small ones.

Kenny Sears, the New York Knickerbockers' leading scorer, will miss the team's next five games, it was learned yesterday. Sears suffered a severe Charley horse in his right calf while scrimmaging earlier this week against a National Industrial League team at Iona College.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 30 -Sometimes it seems as if it is an ill-planned world, containing little that is reasonable and nothing that is fair. An expert misses a large, standing deer four times and while he is bellowing about it, an ignorant woman tumbles a small running deer at 300 yards.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -Britain's repayment of a $250,000.000 United States loan will make a welcome dent in this nation's budget and balance-ofpayments deficits.
TOKYO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The United States, now asking other nations to admit more American goods, was urged today to lower barriers against foreign farm products.
On average the stock market barely broke even this month in slow trading. Prices firmed in the last week of trading to enable the market to end the month with a small net gain.

A plot at the northeast corner of Second Avenue and Sixtyninth Street on Lenox Hill has been assembled by the Mayfair Management Corporation, builders, for improvement with a twenty-story and penthouse apartment building.

A concert series with an intriguing format and featuring Nancy Cirillo, a talented young violinist, gave its first program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
Prices of cotton futures moved 6 points (30 cents a bale) up to 1 point (5 cents) off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
OTTUMWA, Iowa, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Seven young children, trapped by fire inside a onedoor house, died early today while their mothers were away at a private club.
HAVANA, Oct. 30 -- The Cuban Government sealed the files of oil companies here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -(UPI) -- Four cardinals in the United States and prominent Roman Catholic leaders will take part in three-day ceremonies next month dedicating the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception.

A "National Study Commission on Teacher Education," to raise education standards in the United States and to meet the challenge of Soviet science, was suggested yesterday by Senator Kenneth B. Keating.

BARRE, Vt., Oct. 30 -- A bowling alley, undergoing its third year of weathering on Millstone Mountain, high above this city, is a symbol of industrial alertness to changing times. Today, as winter chill began overspreading the area, the alley was as smooth to the touch and true to the eye as when it was set in place outside the new manufacturing plant of Rock of Ages Corporation in 1957.
The Sanitation men of District 4 won again yesterday in their three-month feud with Patrolman Michael Smith of Traffic Precinct A.
For the first time in its threeyear ownership of the Roxy Theatre, Rockefeller Center, Inc., is assuming operational control.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A core of Negroes in at least three state prisons is trying to get other Negro inmates to join an anti-white movement under the banner of "The Muslims," the State Correction Department said today.

The guests of honor at a luncheon to benefit the National Council on Alcoholism will be Dr. Robert H. Felix, director of the National Institute of Mental Health, and Dr. Frank FremontSmith, former president of the World Federation for Mental Health.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 30 -Israel will strive with every means at her disposal for general disarmament throughout the Middle East, Premier David Ben-Gurion declared today.
One of the first prospective sponsors required to make his affairs public under the "fulldisclosure" law designed to block slum-clearance scandals withdrew yesterday.

TONIGHT lanterns will be bobbing and children hobnobbing in the general excitement of Halloween. While the young expend energy in doorto-door trick-or-treat activities, adults will be busy trying to keep pace with their demands.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Juvenile delinquency is a world disease and must be treated as such, a United Nations group found today.
Joseph T. Sharkey, the majority leader of the City Council, threatened yesterday to force Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy to direct patrolmen to carry nightsticks on daytime tours of duty.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 30 -The American Unitarian Association and the Universalist Church of America agreed today to merge.

OTTAWA, Oct. 30 (Canadian Press) -- The Federal Government ordered today a halt to the flow of Government money into mortgage loans. Works Minister David Walker announced that Federal funds earmarked for these direct loans had run out two months earlier than expected.
TRENTON, Oct. 30 -- The New Jersey Business Development Corporation was chartered today to help finance the expansion, rehabilitation and development of industry and business.
That extraordinary harmonica virtuoso, Larry Adler, played a Town Hall recital last night that ranged from Bach to Gershwin and demonstrated impressively the range and versatility of his playing.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Complaints by John D. Rockefeller Jr. over high tax assessments of Tarrytown and Greenburgh on property recently added to his Pocantico Hills estate are near full settlement.
The carefully tailored package of new securities fashioned by the Treasury to replace up to $10,900,000,000 of outstanding debt slipped smoothly into the market yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- The South African delegation walked out of the Special Political Committee today when it started a debate on apartheid (racial segregation).
New capital financing in the public market next week will taper off considerably from the pace of the last two weeks. Bond issues amounting to about $70,000,000 are scheduled to reach the market.

Desmond Flower, in his letter published Oct. 19, correctly points out that industrial production and standards of living have been rising in East Germany and that, of course, not everybody would leave East for West Germany even if the border between the two parts of Germany were to disappear tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey called tonight for another one-year suspension of nuclear tests.

Your editorial of Oct. 23 on Amendment No. 2, whose approval would permit the use of 254 acres of the forest preserve for the Adirondack Northway, compares this situation to the controversy over Panther Mountain Dam, which would have required over a thousand acres of the forest preserve.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 30 -The nine airlines with flights on the European-South Atlantic run are locked in a furious fare war that is producing ticket discounts up to 55 per cent.
A tough, well-rested New Dorp football team will make its bid for the Public Schools Athletic League Division IV championship today against a battered and tired Lincoln squad.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Dr. David A. Lockmiller was inducted in formal chapel ceremonies today as the tenth president of Ohio Wesleyan University.
A $30,000,000 proposal for a sports and convention center and an eleven-story parking garage on the site of the Polo Grounds was made public yesterday by Jay Coogan.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- The Soviet Union served notice today that it would oppose United Nations efforts to set up a permanent border-watch in Laos.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 30 -Max Graf, 52 - year - old former convict who had been charged with first - degree murder, was freed today when a Suffolk County grand jury failed to indict him.

Three new volumes will be added by the Indiana University Press to its Civil War Centennial Series on Nov. 23. One will be "Wearing of the Gray," by John Esten Cooke, edited with a biographical introduction and explanatory notes by Philip Van Doren Stern. Long out of print, it is an account of Cooke's experiences in the Army of Northern Virginia.
The national chairman of the Medical-Dental Committee on Evaluation of Fluoridation took issue yesterday with the theory that artificial fluorides in the water supply reduce tooth decay.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The Carnegie Hero Fund Commission voted bronze medals today to thirty-five persons, including nine school children.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Danny Murtaugh, Pittsburgh's cheerful manager, signed his 1960 contract today for a reported $30,000 and said he was confident his Pirates would make a run for the National League pennant next year.

All New Yorkers, we are sure, will join in congratulating the Roosevelt Hospital, 426 West Fifty-ninth Street, New York 19, on the celebration of the ninetieth anniversary of its founding. This great institution serves an area of Manhattan which, with the advent of the Lincoln Square slum clearance project, is undergoing considerable change.

A sharp increase in flotations of public utility bonds and stocks were a feature of the new securities marketed here in October. The volume of all offerings was the largest for any month since spring.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Yale presented its first Addison Emery Verrill Medal today to Dr. Alexander I. Petrunketvitch, who is regarded as the world's leading authority on spiders.
A State Supreme Court justice here has refused to accept the "conviction" of a Brooklyn resident for drunken driving in Virginia.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 30 (AP) -- A Harvest-time dip has pulled farm product prices down to their lowest purchasingpower level since August, 1940. The Department of Agriculture reported today that price declines for some livestock and livestock products, corn and grapefruit put mid-October farm prices as a whole about 1.66 per cent below the mid-September figures, and 6 per cent below the 1958 month.
MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Oct. 30 (AP) -- A United Auto Workers local and its president were held in contempt of court a second time today as a result of picket line incidents at the Cross Company.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -Spreading work stoppages involved more than 4,000 employes of Wilson and Co. today at five of its seven plants.
John W. Hanes, former Under Secretary of the Treasury and a corporation executive, was named chairman of the finance committee of the New York World's Fair 1964 Corporation yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 30 -Government sources expressed grave concern today about what appeared to be increasing Chinese Communist claims to territory in the northern Indian province of Ladakh.
Ten freighters operated or owned by a New York trampship agency were reported idled in ports around the world yesterday, with crew members charging that they had not been paid.

ROME, Oct. 30 -- The ecumenical or universal council of the Roman Catholic Church, which Pope John XXIII summoned soon after his elevation to the pontificate, will not be held for at least three years.

CAIRO, Oct. 28 -- Economic experts met here this week to start working out Egypt's second long-term industrialization plan. The first plan, begun late in 1957, is expected to be nearly completed late next year, many months ahead of schedule.

ST. CATHARINES, Ont., Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Foreign vessels, trying to reach the Gulf of St. Lawrence before the winter freeze-up, may be tied up in the Great Lakes by a pilots' dispute with the Transport Department.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Justice Charles Hughes of the State Supreme Court today sealed two reports handed up by a grand jury that had been held in session for nearly six months to investigate the Schenectady County Highway Department.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- South Korea's Ambassador received a mild reprimand today from Secretary of State Christian A. Herter for his efforts to change United States policy on Japanese repatriation of Koreans to Communist North Korea.

The problem presented by this country's more or less chronic condition of payments deficits is not, by any stretch of pessimism, an insoluble one or one that would not respond to a firm and intelligent reorientation of approach. WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- American Airlines won a go-ahead today in the United States Court of Appeals to start its New York - San Francisco nonstop run on Sunday.
Alan Neuman has been named producer of "Person to Person" by the Columbia Broadcasting System and the network now will produce the show for itself.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct 30 -The month-old Government survived a vote of no confidence tonight after Prime Minister Wijayanda Dahanayake and members of his Cabinet had been accused of conspiracy in connection with the investigation of the assassination of Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike, his predecessor.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 29 -- Authorities here are confident that full achievement of the European common market will take only eight to ten years, instead of twelve to fifteen as provided in the basic treaty.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The move launched eleven months ago by the William Zeckendorf interests in New York to acquire the Outlet Company, southeast New England's largest department store, and its radio-TV stations in a $12.000,000 deal ended today.
The American Cancer Society's board of directors adopted a resolution yesterday calling for more research to find better ways of increasing public participation in cancer prevention and control.

THE New York Chapter of the American Institute of Decorators has taken a rest from room settings and devoted its newest show to an exhibit and sale of works of art. The show, which will benefit the chapter's scholarship fund, will open Thursday in the OwensCorning Fiberglas Fabric Center, 717 Fifth Avenue, and will continue through Nov. 11.

Memories of the Golden Twenties and the Thirties, when the Army-Navy and ArmyNotre Dame games had New York in a hysteria of football excitement, are brought back today with the staging of the contest between the West Point cadets and the Air Force Academy at Yankee Stadium.
