JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 30 -- The Colombo Plan, scheduled to end June 19, 1961, will be extended at least until mid-1964, informed sources said here today.

They call it "Halloween." That is a word -more especially a night -- that evokes images of ghosts, witches and black cats. It is a time when everyone pretends to be superstitious, whether he really is or not. Some may think of the day's heroes as harbingers of evil. But it should not be so. Today is the eve of AllHallows, or All Saints' Day, which is followed a day later by All Souls' Day.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A return to the International Longshoremen's Association by local unions who had joined the International Brotherhood of Longshoremen was virtually assured today.
Schenley Industries, Inc., one of the nation's largest distillers, and the advertising agency of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., have terminated their relationship of nine years standing.

The American and Foreign Power Company halved its quarterly dividend yesterday as a direct result of the uncertain outlook for a subsidiary concern that operates in Cuba. The official statement said that the new 1 1/2-cent rate was attributable to "the drastic rate reduction imposed on a Cuban subsidiary by the Cuban Government on Aug. 1."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The wholesale price index of average primary market prices rose 0.2 per cent to 119.3 per cent of its 1947-49 average during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

What happened to a Henry James story in London recently would have delighted its author had it only occurred seventy years ago. For James' story, "The Aspern Papers," adapted for the stage by Sir Michael Redgrave, is now a hit play there.

Michael J. Quill, the Transport Workers Union impresario, is always in an expansive, expensive mood as he prepares to enter contract negotiations. He was at his dreamy best as he stated his demands upon the New York City Transit Authority and the private bus lines. He is willing to settle for $75,000,000 a year more for employes of the city and $25,000,000 more for workers on the privately owned lines.
A study by three Baylor scientists casts doubt about the proclaimed safety of two oral, live-virus poliomyelitis vaccines.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 -- The Government's chief labor peacemaker rejected today a steelindustry plea that he come here Monday for strike settlement talks, instead of summoning union and company negotiators to Washington.

A would-be bandit who later apologetically explained that "everybody is robbing banks these days" tried to hold up a Thirty-fourth Street bank with a cap pistol yesterday. He was seized by a policeman after a block-long chase through lunchhour crowds.
Protestant, Eastern Orthodox, Roman Catholic and Jewish welfare services embarked this week on their annual Thanksgiving appeals to aid needy people over the world.

The Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday sizable gains in operating revenues and net income for nine and twelve months ended on Sept. 30. The giant Chicago utility also showed a gain of 11.7 per cent in sales of electricity in the nine months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities announced today that it would hold hearings in New York City on Nov. 16 and 17 and in San Juan, P. R., from Nov. 18 to 20 on "interlocking Communist activities" among Puerto Rican nationality groups.

The third Holiday Hop, inter-preparatory school benefit dance of the junior committee of the Brooklyn Division, New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation, will take place at the St. George Hotel on Nov. 25.

George Stevens Moore, who steps up today to the presidency of the First National City Bank of New York, wasn't always determined to be a banker. For some time, he entertained seriously the thought of becoming a newspaper man.
MADRID, Oct. 30 -- A shortage of rain is not news in Spain, but a dearth of Havana cigars is.

" NEARER, my God to Thee Nearer to Thee." With those words, his last, William McKinley faced his final ordeal on earth, serenely confident, as in moments of trouble he had always been, that his crisis would resolve itself satisfactorily. His confidence, so much a characteristic of his time, and his serenity, so rarely a quality of politicians, helped to evoke the extraordinary affection the American people lavished upon him.

Miss Alice Margaret Sigel daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Sigel of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday evening to Dr. David Jonathan Goldsmith of Detroit. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Goldsmith of Flushing, Queens. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi David Silverman at the Sigel residence.

" IN a year's time, the Cinematheque Francaise will be as well known throughout the world as the Comedie Francaise," declared Andre Malraux, Minister for Cultural Affairs, at the closing session of the recent Cannes Film Festival.

KINGSTON, Jamaica -- A happy combination of circumstances has led Jamaicans to anticipate a record-breaking tourist season next winter. First, the opening of new hotels will provide an additional 800 beds for visitors.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Relief supplies poured into the hurricane and flood-devastated states of Colima and Jalisco today. The death toll continued to mount.

NOWADAYS rockets, artificial satellites and space probes dramatically direct our attention to the heavens. Consequently, it is not surprising that many young people have become interested in astronomy and want to learn about it.

" Start the Sixties Right" will be the theme for the forty-ninth annual convention of the National Retail Merchants Association, to be held at the Statler Hilton Hotel here Sunday, Jan. 10, through Thursday, Jan. 14.

TO THE EDITOR: Mr. McGill reveals that an amazingly small percentage of Southern churchgoers are die-hard segregationists (fifty-three out of 2,000 in one congregation) and that those in high financial positions, members of the church boards, "the major contributors," compose most of this reactionary group.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Six Western European countries decided a few years ago that it would be economically and politically advantageous to form an economic unit called a common market. They set forth their objectives, which included the lifting of trade and other barriers among themselves, and drew up a treaty for attaining them.
SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 31 -The first Central-American conference of industrialists and financiers closed here today on a note of harmony and optimism.

The Supreme Court will decide in the next few days whether to uphold a Federal Court injunction ordering 500,000 striking steelworkers back to work. What follows is the sequence that brought the steel strike to the Supreme Court:
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 31 -- The six nations of the common market in Europe have begun preparing a Joint foreign aid program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- James C. Hagerty, press secretary, said today that there "never is going to be" any White House comment on British Field Marshal Viscount Alanbrooke's criticism of President Eisenhower's World War II leadership.

A National Football League rivalry of long standing that has furnished many thrilling moments for New York's pro gridiron followers will be seen again today when the Giants meet the Green Bay Packers.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Lehigh proved to have the better mudders today and upset its Middle Atlantic Conference rival, Bucknell, 14 -- 0.

CLIMBING miniature roses are the latest novelty in the tiny fairy rose group. These new climbers -exact replicas of the standardized plants -- now complete the types of roses available for planting in a miniature rose garden. Though delicately formed, the tiny roses are rugged, bear a generous amount of blooms and, with reasonable care, are hardy and long-lasting.

Maverick has been confirmed officially as the American Power Boat Association's highpoint champion for this year in unlimited hydroplane competition. Unlimited hydroplanes are the glamour boats of motor boating that attract thousands of spectators in various parts of the country.
AS the sponsor of two of the best recent arrivals on the non-theatrical scene, the spotlight falls once more on the Rembrandt Film Library (267 West Twenty-fifth Street).

ST. THOMAS, V. I. -- Ever since World War II, when the building of military airfields here opened up these islands to outside visitors, the American Virgin Islands have been tagged as being "on the threshold" of the big-time tourist business.
An Allentown, Pa., department store owner has admitted paying $10,000 to get a contestant on the "$64,000 Question" television quiz program.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago Sarah Gertrude Millin, in her finest novel, gave a name to the Cape colored people of South Africa. "God's stepchildren" she called those bar-sinister descendants of white and black, accepted by neither and despised by both.
BUFFALO, Oct. 31 -- Erie County voters will write the final chapter Tuesday in a bitter election campaign.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Tom Matte, a quarterback who earned the starting job this week, threw three touchdown passes today as Ohio State defeated Michigan State, 30 -- 24, and blasted the Spartans' Big Ten title hopes.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 31 -- The Indian Army took over direct control of the frontier with China today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 31 -Brazilian authorities acted today to relieve the meat shortage by ordering government operation of packing plants, including those of three American companies, along with seizure of cattle.
Coach Ben Martin of the Air Force had extreme confidence in his team to the end, figuring his charges would win.

THE authors of the documentary account of "The Trial of Mary Todd Lincoln" have turned to fiction (based upon a slender store of facts) with their present novel about a lad who was probably the youngest to serve with the armed forces throughout the Civil War, or any other major war as far as the records show.

THE setting is the frontier along the Minnesota River; it's the time of the American Revolution. The plot centers on a group of traders who push up the Minnesota to barter with the Yankton Indian tribe. The narrative is full of good characterizations and it builds suspense and drama with great skill.
Italian shipping interests introduced the Fassio Line to the Pork of New York last week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The board of directors of the American Society of Newspaper Editors said today that it had found "no concrete charges" of biased press coverage of tariff and trade developments that would warrant an investigation by any agency.

AT the Michigan ice pond where 10-year-old Becky Osborn spent the last afternoon of the century miserably floundering on her Christmas skates, she met a Fairy Child. When Fairy Child, learning Becky's family name, impulsively gave her a wishing ring, and helped her skate, it seemed perfectly natural to imaginative Becky.
Seven firemen were injured early yesterday while fighting a blaze that destroyed the Sidney Perlow, Inc., men's clothing store at 883 Manhattan Avenue in Brooklyn.

JUST the book for all little girls who love horses! Deborah persuaded her parents to board Mollie, the little black pony from Playland Park, for the winter. During the warm fall everyone was eager to help Deborah clean the stall, carry the water, and groom Mollie, but when bad weather came, everyone deserted and Deborah had the chores to do alone.

NEGRO bondage was the terrible incubus of antebellum America; its banishment provided the central drama of our nineteenth-century history. Some of the largest issues that the struggle left unresolved remain lively and perplexing.

MERMAIDS, dragons, peasants, kings, a haunted forest and a magic ring -- all play a part in these age-old tales of enchantment and adventure. They are fresh and unfamiliar, collected from Europe and the Orient and retold in the best story-telling tradition.

THE same warmth and gaiety which flooded the pages of "The Happy Orpheline" are evident in its sequel. There is the same sense of security for every one of the twenty little girls in the Paris orphanage in spite of leaking roof and crumbling walls.
The political unrest and the anti-American feeling in Cuba, the world's largest sugar exporter, are having several important effects on the sugar market.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 31 -Not all African politicians are extremists. There are moderate leaders, too, who are striving quietly to achieve the same goal of self-rule as their more vehement brothers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- In Tokyo this week Under Secretary of State Douglas Dillon delivered a blunt warning to the other contracting nations in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade: Stop discriminating against United States imports or Congress will get SmootHawley after you.
MOSCOW, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A former marine from Texas told the United States Embassy today that he had applied for Soviet citizenship.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 31 (AP) -- La Fuerza, a non-winner from Robert J. Kleberg's King Ranch made her first triumph a big one by scoring by a head today in the $63,650 Selima Stakes.
PARIS, Oct. 31 -- The address by Premier Khrushchev before the Supreme Soviet was viewed by press and here official circles as generally moderate, conciliatory and "objective."
The New York Knickerbockers made their second National Basketball Association start of the campaign last night in Madison Square Garden, and they are still looking for their first victory.

ARDEN, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Fld. Ch. Greatford Meadowcourt Pin triumphed in the cocker spaniel open all-age stake as the two-day meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association began today on the estate of E. Roland Harriman.

Wind and weather move more swiftly now. Dakota's storms come whirling east with little pause along the way, and the Midwest's frostedged winds sweep up and over the Alleghenies. Summer's mildness and leisure are things of the past, memories of July and clover and bee-hum. November is the fallen leaf, the bare branch, the early setting sun. And the hurrying wind.

BREATHES there a writer who has not fussed and fussed with an idea for days, weeks, months and given up in despair only to have the idea pop up again -- years later -- and almost full-grown? Listen to Liam O'Brien, who once made Broadway laugh with "The Remarkable Mr. Penny-packer," and learn.

THEY are a daring breed of men, those Air Force operatives. They gamble on fourth down passes and get away with it. One such risky operation set up the touchdown that enabled the Falcons to gain a smashing 13-13 tie with Army in the beginning of a historic service rivalry in mist-shrouded Yankee Stadium yesterday.

COMPARATIVELY few persons realize the wealth of old master drawings at Cooper Union, now celebrating its centenary by showing the crown jewels of the collection, a selection of 100 drawings out of 25,000.

During the last two years the timing of Soviet space feats, seemingly so that Moscow might gain from them maximum political advantage, has been so striking that a number of people have wondered if we were not being hoodwinked.
WARSAW, Oct. 21 -- Poland's physicians seem to be the most sharply discontended professional group in the country.
The world tanker industry presented a series of seeming paradoxes last week.

CANNES, France, Oct. 29 -- In English it's called skin diving. But the French, who claim to have invented the sport here on the Riviera just before World War II, certainly named it more aptly. They call it La Chasse Sous-Marine -- The Underwater Hunt.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sunday, Nov. 1 -- Search parties hunted fruitlessly last night and early today for a missing Piedmont Airlines plane with twenty-seven persons aboard.

A BOOKLET on bidding by Oswald Jacoby, published this week by Arrco Playing Card Company, says in its preamble: "THERE IS SOMETHING NEW . . . The requirements for opening no-trump bids have been reduced one point to 15-17.
TO THE EDITOR: "The Other Puerto Ricans" is a splendid article. But, it seems to me, Mr. Wakefield does not draw the logical conclusion from his own evidence.

I meant to write to you earlier this. year, after Arthur Daley's wonderful article on Lou Little and his honorary degree. Lou means a great deal to those who played for him and who came under his fatherly guidance.

WHOOSH! Clang! Bang! Kpow! Translation: Brotherhood never had it so good. Its message, along with others of noble motivation, has in the past decade gained a circulation undreamed of by crusaders for worthy causes -- through the pages of 10,000,000 comic books.

ABOUT this time every year millions of men and women armed guns and bows swarm into the woods and fields, an under the impression that they are making use of a peculiarly American hunting heritage. Indeed, there are so many that it is no longer possible to describe a man or woman merely by saying he or she is a hunter -- now they must be divided into castes.

THERE is a pleasant Chinese habit of nibbling at steamed and fried tidbits called tien hsin, "dotting the heart." The finely chopped meat or seafood and vegetable fillings are wrapped in thin dough or pastry; delicious, they indeed dot and enliven the heart. In a like manner, these sketches of the Chinese way of life are heartwarming.

THESE are the years of high tides in the sea of children's books. A decade ago 800 new titles were thought a good figure for a year of children's book publishing. This year the figure will be close to 1,500, and the constantly rising tide shows no sign of ebbing.

SOME thirty years before "Doctor Zhivago" made him world famous, Boris Pasternak was acclaimed by admirers as the greatest Russian poet of the post-revolutionary era. His audience, however, was limited to a group of young poets and some refined readers and discerning critics.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 -- A Filipino veteran wounded in the Battle of Corregidor has lost the American citizenship granted him early last year.
A Harlem tailor yesterday received a plaque honoring him for his "service to the community" for a half century.

THE life of a genius has long been a topic of interest to both writer and reader, and in many cases a famous man's life has been crystallized by an intelligent biography. In the last few years figures in science and medicine have become favorite subjects.

PARIS, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Orson Welles said today that he had been offered as much as $170,000 to start as a genius on a fixed TV quiz show three years ago. He said that when he had told acquaintances about the offer "they just laughed" it off as nothing to get upset about.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 31 -- The former director of the National Probation and Parole Association in New York has taken a $7,000 reduction in pay to help develop a correction program based on an integration of State facilities.
The Matson Navigation Company is planning to expand and speed up its cargo-container program on the West Coast-Hawaii shipping route.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- France has prepared an elaborate scientific dossier with which to rebut African charges in the United Nations that the explosion of the first French atomic bomb in the Sahara would menace the surrounding territories.
IOWA CITY, Oct. 31 (AP) Iowa in the middle of a disnial season against Big Ten rivals, found Kansas State a softer touch today and routed the Big Eight Conference team. 53-0.

THREE newly released sets of disks bring home with stunning force the vitally important role in the development of jazz that John Hammond has been playing since the early Nineteen Thirties, a role he continues to pursue with undiminished vigor.
TRENTON, Oct. 31 -- New Jerseyans will elect twelve of the twenty-one members of the State Senate sixty Assemblymen and numerous county and local officers on Tuesday.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 31 -- A new team of experts will represent West Germany when the Western powers begin their detailed consultations in preparation for an East-West summit meeting.

ONE of the more engaging ideas in children's books is Random House's "Legacy" series, a retelling, in simple form, of classical myths, of nonclassical sagas, and of later legends and folklore ranging in usefulness from the valid Aladdin and Robin Hood to the synthetic and spurious Paul Bunyan.

ONE evening in October, 1958, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences made its first award of the EmersonThoreau Medal to Robert Frost. According to an editorial note in this fall's issue of Daedalus, the academy's quarterly journal, the atmosphere that evening, at Mr. Frost's request, was informal "and the ceremony simple.
SIDI KACEM, Morocco, Oct. 31 -- Turbaned peasants in ragged cloaks bowed and kissed the hand of King Mohamed V today at a ceremony opening the Government's new program of land distribution.

Advance contingents of buyers were in the city last week for the preopening showings of spring lines. Reports from resident buying offices indicated that the buyers liked what they saw. They viewed such lines as boys' apparel, better dresses and sportswear.

THE writer of children's books joins a fellowship, in which, aside from inevitable currents of commercialism, publicity, cliques and fads, there is a common purpose that unites the members. This fellowship is made up of writers, illustrators, editors, publishers, librarians, teachers and booksellers.
The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art will celebrate its 100th anniversary tomorrow.

Richard Kahn of Manhattan and Ivar Stakgold of Washington led a field of 224 pairs last night after the first of two sessions of play in the open-pair contest of the Metropolitan contract bridge tournament at the Statler Hilton Hotel. The tournament was in its second day.

Two proposals were made last week to increase the use of essay tests in both undergraduate and graduate school admissions. According to the report of a committee on testing presented to the eleventh annual conference of the Association of Graduate Schools at the Rockefeller Institue, "admissions must be more discriminating lest the quality of graduate work deteriorate still further under the stress of the mounting university-bound population."
THE nine symphonies of Beethoven, incessantly played and copiously written about, nevertheless remain the most fascinating works in the symphonic repertory.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 31 -Nassau County residents will vote Tuesday to elect two county-wide officials, three Supreme Court Justices, a State Senator, an Assemblyman and many town and city officials.
NOT long ago in Moscow I was talking with some average Soviet citizens about American cars. A middle-aged Russian woman interrupted, shouting from the edge of the group of listeners.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla. -- This pleasant little resort to the north of Miami Beach and long considered part of it, although separated by the village of Surfside, is now in the process of establishing its own identity as a tourist community.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Dartmouth's resurgent 1958 Ivy League football champions swept Yale of all its distinctions today with a mighty second-half uprising in the rain-lashed Bowl.

THE best first book for man or child in any field is that written especially for the beginner. When such a book is done by a master scientist and writer, as this one is, the result is a delight to people of any age. "People and Places" can be read by young people of high school age and to children still younger.

CHILDREN love animals, which of course is why birds and bears, pigs and 'possums, and so many other varieties pop up as characters in picture books. Little children find nothing incongruous, so strong is their affection, in seeing animals talking, singing, reading or performing any of the hundreds of impossible acts they do in books.
BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 31 -- Billy Cannon, an AllAmerican back, sprinted 89 yards for a touchdown in the fourth quarter tonight as Louisiana State's national champions toppled Mississippi, 7 -- 3.

Los ANGELES -- Mr. Khrushchev's tour has been belabored extensively, but before it goes into historical moth balls, one final undiscussed aspect is worth noting: the way he dealt with the perennial question of Los Angeles versus San Francisco.

TO THE EDITOR: My wife, some students, and myself spent the past summer in East Africa doing research on various primates in a bush laboratory. The poaching situation is, indeed, tragic and I must say I think the situation is far worse than Mrs. Huxley indicates.

At 11 A. M. this Tuesday the nine Justices of the Supreme Court of the United States will file to their places behind the long bench in the pillared courtroom. The clerk will raise the traditional cry of "Oyez! Oyez!" The court will then begin a session the outcome of which will determine the course of one of the most damaging strikes ever to hit the U. S. economy -- the 110-day shutdown in steel.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 31 -- Hunting deer, grouse, woodcock and ducks in this region of big thick woods is no great problem of personal logistics for the car owner and it seems to be well within the means of a surprising range of people.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The International Motor Show closed here tonight with British automobile manufacturers joyfully appraising it as the best ever. After a slow start last week, attendance passed the 500,000 mark today, comfortably higher than the approximately 458,000 admissions to last year's show. In 1953, attendance was 612,953.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Tennessee's ball-hawking defense swooped on four North Carolina fumbles in the second period today and the Vols flashed to a 29-7 football victory before 30,000 rain-soaked fans
CHAMPION, Ill., Oct. 31 (AP) --Johnny Counts running and Bill Burrell's remarkable line-backing today inspired an underdog Illinois team to a 7-7 tie with Purdue.

Maneuvering in the steel controversy and gyrations in some speculative favorites in the stock market held the attention of investors last week. It was a case of "off again, on again, Finnegan," with the steel negotiations and the accompanying court battles to end the strike.

IN 1952, several young Americans sitting in a bar in Montparnasse founded The Paris Review. Some of them were the sons of prominent figures in American publishing, arts and criticism; some had already begun to accomplish serious things of their own; they were not really expatriates -- but they were joyously playing out the role of being young and full of ideas in Paris in the spring.

MANY Yugoslav readers and some critics regard "Bosnian Story" as the masterpiece of the Serbo-Croat novelist Ivo Andric, whose "The Bridge on the Drina" was published in a fine translation earlier this year.

A committee of Queens lawyers recommended yesterday that the city speed its property-condemnation procedures to ease hardships on property owners, especially small home-owners and small-business men.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -The twin cities of Florida's West Coast, Tampa and St. Petersburg (not identical but slightly fraternal), will gain a new bond this winter, a third bridge across Old Tampa Bay, the Frankland Bridge.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 31 -Warfare of the Bellehurst Stable won his third stakes in a row by taking the Garden State Stakes today. And the third victory proved by far the most opulent, for the event he took was the world's richest horse race.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 29 -- Maj. Gen. Moshe Dayan, former Israeli Chief of Staff and one of the leading personalities of Premier David Ben-Gurion's Mapai party, visited the Katamon quarter of Jerusalem last week.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 31 -As Tuesday's election nears, the Mississippi Democratic organization is fighting hard to "crush" the attempt of a Republican, running as an independent, to win the State Senate seat in Hinds County.
ADOLESCENCE, as modern novelists never tire of delineating, is a pretty trying time for many youngsters. It is frequently a pretty difficult period for their parents, too.

On Oct. 26 you published an excellent letter from Prof. Richard Gardner deploring the recent "Buy American" decision by the Development Loan Fund. Reports in The Times since he wrote, and the importance of the foreign policy issues involved, prompt this letter, emphasizing some points he had space only to touch upon.

THE name, "poundcake," is more literal than most people think. If the dessert had been created within recent memory, the chances are that it would bear another nom de cuisine. It originated in an age when "butter the size of a walnut" was common cookbook phraseology. It was also an age when weight, rather than the cup, was the standard method of measurement.
GUATEMALA, Oct. 24 -- Newspapers here have been publishing advertisements offering for sale the properties of the InterAmerican Educational Cooperative Service for Agriculture.

This is the time of a number of conferences and reports in the field of education. As might be expected, there have been several suggestions and recommendations that are stimulating and provocative. NOT since mercantilism and nationalism condemned to obsolescene the moated castle and the medieval walled city has so revolutionary a change in man's patterns of urban living emerged as that which is now in progress in America.
BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- For the first time in ten years voters of this city will elect Tuesday a man other than John B. Hynes as Mayor. He has decided against running this year after a decade in office.

WESTERNERS are likely to be doubly confused when they hear that Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's daughter is named Indira Gandhi and is president of the Indian National Congress. Mrs. Gandhi is not related -- even by marriage -- to the late Mohandas K. Gandhi, and Congress is not a parliamentary body, but India's leading political party.
This country's tough Preventive Detention Act, passed last fall, has resulted in the imprisonment for up to five years of about forty-five persons, without hearings, trials, or appeals.

BRONZE FEATHER, an Arapahoe Indian boy of today, watches in anguish as an airplane swoops at a herd of wild horses in a futile effort to round them up. The boy manages to save most of the terrified animals but some die of fright, and a mare who stayed behind to protect her new foal is killed by coyotes.

BAMBOO belongs primarily to the tropics, but Northern gardeners can display some of its Iush growth on their grounds by planting the hardy bamboos. Certain species will thrive along the Atlantic Coast as far north as Philadelphia and New York.
TOKYO, Oct. 31 -- Ali discriminatory restrictions by Japan on the import of United States goods will be lifted by April 1, 1961, "at the latest," a Japanese official said today.

London, Oct 31 (Reuters) -- Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from a speech today by Premier Khrushchev at the final session of the Supreme Soviet, as made public by Tass, Soviet news agency.

FOUR French children are visiting their aunt in her old mill house at the edge of a forest. Foxes raid Aunt Tatie's chickens and the children become more and more involved with the fox known as Old One-Toe.

Michael is treed by an angry bear, plucked out of the air by a friendly eagle; he discovers the world's highest mountain, is forced off a cliff by a fierce mountain lion and move through other ordeals and accomplishments.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- Two major openings of the type that Florida loves best are set to take place here within a month of each other. The first is the opening today of a 100-unit motel at Pier 66.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 31 -- Nebraska defeated Oklahoma, 25 to 21, today, ending college football's longest unbeaten streak in conference play. The Sooners had not lost in seventyfour Big Eight games dating to 1946.

The nation's hotels, motels and the mass feeding industry are expected to purchase a record amount of new equipment at the National Hotel Exposition. The show opens tomorrow at the New York Coliseum.

ONE sunny Saturday afternoon a 9-year-old picked up "The Promised Year" and disappeared into her room. Her family and friends didn't see her again, until she emerged exclaiming, "Gee, this was good!" -- a well deserved tribute.

IN "Zulu Journal" Raymond Cowles has written that very rare thing, a travel book that gives you a real picture not only of the country, but of the people and animals that inhabit it. Quite apart from the fascinating natural history material it contains, the book is of particular interest as it shows the great changes that have come to one corner of Africa during the last fifty-three years.

Can the future of American education be left in the hands of over 50,000 local school boards? A few years ago, the question itself would have been considered un-American. "Local control" had become a motto to be intoned, not a theory to be debated. It is an indication of the seriousness of the current reappraisal of the American public schools that unchecked local control appears to be on trial.
The Government's new cotton-marketing program, which went into effect on Aug. 1, has stirred mixed reactions.

IN the public mind, Jesse James has been supplanted by a little old lady with a note. When a note-passer -- the newest kind of bank robber -- took the much publicized glass-walled bank on Fifth Avenue for $6,277 one recent Friday afternoon, the episode generated a lot of commuter-train and lunch-hour conversation that invariably began: "Banks are getting to be real pushovers these days."
" Carmen" was yesterday afternoon's opera at the City Center, with Robert Rounseville, as Don Jose, making his first appearance with the New York City Opera Company this season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -Debutante daughters of distinguished families throughout the United States will make their bows to society here at the tenth annual Debutante Cotollion and Thanksgiving Ball. The fete will be held on Nov. 26 at the Sheraton-Park Hotel.

Heroism THE characteristic of heroism is its persistency. All men have wandering impulses, fits and starts of generosity. But when you have chosen your part, abide by it, and do not weakly try to reconcile yourself with the world. The heroic cannot be the common, nor the common heroic.

BEFORE he died in 1947, Julian Street wrote and published from time to time a small, four-page pamphlet for the New York wine merchant firm of Bellows Co. In it he included anecdotes, maxims and random monographs collected or composed through a lifetime of unslaked interest in the world of food and wine.

DETROIT, Oct. 31 -- The General Motors Corporation, collectively, so to speak, is the nation's largest advertiser. But that is oversimplification, for it has thirty-three divisions that advertise through thirteen agencies.

Trudi Buxton, 12-year-old pianist from St. Louis, was soloist with Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society yesterday morning at the Hunter College concert that opened the orchestra's twelfth season of children's programs.
Western diplomats and intelligence specialists spent a good part of last week analyzing the new Soviet budget for 1960, which was unveiled before the Supreme Soviet in Moscow.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Oct. 31 -- Cuba was viewed today as an acute trouble spot in the international business picture by a panel of national business leaders.

For pageantry and color nothing quite compares with a first night at the Horse Show. It is a spectacle presented with gaiety yet controlled dignity. The formal opening, in which the international teams parade and their salute is taken by the Commanding General of the First Army, has often been likened to the initial ceremonies of the Olympic Games.

Lincoln Hall, a residential training school for delinquent Roman Catholic boys at Lincolndale, N. Y., will benefit from the Dec. 1 performance of "Ben-Hur." The motion picture opens Nov. 19 at Loew's State Theatre.

We heartily agree with Howard Taubman that it would be extremely worthwhile if some arrangements could be made to enable and encourage more foreign participation in the competition for the anual prize of the Edgar M. Leventritt Foundaton.

Compositions from the seventeenth to the present century, performed by the Orpheus Chamber Singers, will be heard in a program tomorrow at 8 P. M. in the Donnell Library Center, 20 West Fifty-third Street.

DUMONT, N. J., Oct. 31 -- The first meeting of ae four-part seminar on "the Nature of Nuclear Warfare" will be held for religious leaders Monday morning at the Calvary Methodist Church here.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 -- Industry and union negotiators abandoned today their direct efforts to settle the 109-day-old steel strike without Government help.

ALGIERS, Oct. 31 -- Five years ago, at 1 A. M. Nov. 1, 1954, a series of shots was fired at a French Army sentry in the village of Khroubs, near Constantine in eastern Algeria. The sentry returned the fire and the assailants fled.

THE United States Presidential election of 1948 -- the one incorrectly forcast by everyone (or nearly everyone) -- never will cease to be a cause of heated, passionate debate whenever and wherever the current crop of politicians, political writers and pollsters gather even in small groups.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -Mayor Richardson Dilworth was an odds-on favorite today to defeat Harold E. Stassen, Republican, in Tuesday's Mayoralty election.

CUB pilot on the fastest two-boiler packet afloat! Matt Harris, standing at the wheel in the River Queen's pilot house, fancied himself navigating up the broad Missouri, and he felt a good deal more than his 15 years.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Wisconsin's Badgers survived a mighty second half scare by Michigan today and kept alive their Big Ten title hopes with a 19-10 triumph.

Guest speakers for the twenty-fifth anniversary dinner of the Academy of American Poets have been announced by Mrs. Hugh Bullock, academy president. The dinner will be held Wednesday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The Moscow radio has announced the beginning of a campaign to end the private practice of medicine in the Soviet Union.

HAVANA, Oct. 31 -- Premier Fidel Castro, Cuba's one-man Government, has today the fanatical support of the majority of the workers and peasants who are the greater part of the republic's population. They support his revolutionary Government and they support his vitriolic attacks on the United States.
HAVANA, Oct. 31 -- The search continued today in Cuba for Maj. Camilo Cienfuegos, chief of staff of the Cuban Army, missing since Wednesday night on a flight from Camaguey to Havana.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -President Eisenhower named Livingston T. Merchant today to succeed Robert Murphy as Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs.
UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- Vice, gambling and official scandals are key factors in the forthcoming municipal election here.

IT'S a wonder some child doesn't hide away in a Massachusetts museum to see the historic dolls come to life after midnight. Mariana (Foster) has told in "The Journey of Bangwell Putt" of how Bangwell leaves her display case in the Deerfield Museum to go dancing with a toy Hessian soldier.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 31 -- Monty Stickles' right foot won another game for Notre Dame today.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -Harvard's underrated gridiron task force knocked Penn from the ranks of the undefeated in an Ivy League upset today. The score was 12 -- 0.

CANADA'S angriest young man is Farley Mowat, who writes out of a desperate concern for the vanishing Eskimo. At 38, Mr. Mowat is past youth's first blush, but he has kept his anger intact; it has been warming in a steady flame since he was 27, when he first encountered the Ihalmiut, a tribe of inland Eskimos.
Vilhjalmur Stefansson, explorer, historian and champion of the Arctic, will be 80 on Tuesday.
MOSCOW, Oct. 29 -- The reconstituted Kalmyk Republic has a small fortune running loose but does not know about it and does not like it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Defense Department plans to start construction soon of a model control station that could be used in an international system for the detection of underground atomic explosions.
A test that measures a person's "ear for language" was announced yesterday by Harvard University.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 -- The steel industry proved again this week that it can withstand extreme economic pressure better than the country can. The strike-bound steel producers were up against the severest test of ability to hold out that any industry ever had to undergo and they kept their ranks solid.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- Access to New Providence Island, where this capital is situated, and to the Out Islands in the 750-mile-long chain of the Bahama Archipelago, is being greatly stepped up by air services.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Sir Winston Churchill joined today the British chorus calling for continued Western initiative in meetings with the Soviet Union.
SOME of the most original and exciting telecasts of the season have been presented by New York's independent Channel 13 (WNTATV).
The Soviet Union has announced that its latest hydrofoil river craft, the 150-passenger Meteor, has successfully completed her trials on the Volga River.

WASHINGTON Oct. 31--Government figures showed today that farm income had dipped $1,000,000,000 more than expected in the third quarter of this year. This darkens the economic and political outlook for Republicans in the Farm Belt.

Whatever may be the decision of the Supreme Court in the steel case, the opinions of the Court of Appeals sustaining the strike injunction have already done a notable public service. What the judges have said in their opinions raises two issues which no court decision in this case can settle: the purpose of the Taft-Hartley injunction provisions and their effectiveness in attaining that objective.

SCARSDALE, N. Y. Oct. 31 -- The Holly Fair of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. James the Less will be held Nov. 11 in the church house. The annual event is being sponsored by the church's Women's Auxiliary, the church School Guild and the Garden Club. Funds realized will further their plans and activities.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 31 -- Unbeaten Hofstra downed Muhlenberg, 18-0, today for its fifth triumph of the season.

IT may seem downright implausible for an Englishman to come to New York in search of John Bull. The cartoon figure of John Bull is familiar enough -- cylindricalbodied, gouty-legged, jowly, extrovert.
RIMINI, Italy, Oct. 28 (Reuters) -- One of the world's smallest Bikini bathing suits will be displayed alongside edicts of a century ago about beach costumes in a museum here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -President Eisenhower's physicians pronounced him today to be in excellent health, with the exception of persistent but mild bronchitis.

For the last eight years, the Junior League of the City of of New York annually has crowned a queen -- a queen, not honored for her beauty, although many of them could have been, but rather for her service to the community.

MOST young people have at one time or other observed the operation of a spinning top or gyroscopic toy, but they probably have never connected the principle of the spinning top with the stabilizing devices used in ships, airplanes, guided missiles and rockets.
COMMON reed grass (Phragmites communis) often becomes a nuisance in seaside gardens. But chemical herbicides -- amitrol plus dalapon -- are available now to eliminate this aggressive marsh plant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- At long last, a timetable for the journey to the summit has begun to take shape. The first stop will be Paris. The leaders of the United States, Britain, France and West Germany agreed this week to meet in the French capital beginning Dec. 19.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 31 -The American Unitarian Association and the Universalist Church of America dramatically reversed themselves today by restoring mention of the JudaeoChristian heritage to their merger plan.

UNLIKE many flowers which are thought to be as old as history itself, the miniature rose is a comparative newcomer, dating back only to the early nineteenth century. Other types of roses and any number of present-day flowers may be found in old paintings, woodcuts and sketches in early garden books and old herbals, but not the little rose.

THIRTY-FIVE photographers present in "ASMP Picture" (New York: Pocket Books, Inc. 192 pp. $1.50), the revived annual of the American Society of Magazine Photographers, an approximately representative showcase of contemporary photojournalistic achievement.

TO THE EDITOR: Salvador de Madariaga, in "Disarmament? The Problem Lies Deeper" (Oct. 11), states that "the only way to disarm would be to remove the cause which makes the evil and nuisance of armaments necessary."

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Oct. 31 (UPI) Jim Mooty led Arkansas to a rallying 12-to-7 victory over Texas A. M. today with a brilliant running display. The triumph kept the Porkers in the thick of the Southwest Conference title fight.

THIS lively book is a sampling of Norman Mailer's career, from youthful stories to fragments of a novel in progress. Besides the fiction, written in what the author calls a "creative rage," he includes a dozen essays that have a contentious rage of their own.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 31 -More interest is being shown in next Tuesday's off-year election in Rockland County than is usually displayed in a Governorship or Presidential year. The control of the County Board of Supervisors with its important appointments is the reason.
The Jan. 15 performance of "The Fighting Cock" will benefit the Deafness Research Foundation. The play, starring Rex Harrison, opens Dec. 8 at the ANTA Theatre.
ALBANY, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Republican leaders of the Legislature called today for approval of the Northway amendment in Tuesday's election.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Governor Rockefeller has called for a review of all state highway plans to make certain they do not destroy sites of natural beauty and historical or cultural significance.

SONIA and Tim Gidal are a highly gifted husband-andwife team who have traveled to many parts of the world and set down a living record of them in skillfully combined texts and photographs. In these two books they deal with the Israelis and the Lapps.
WARSAW, Oct. 31 -- Polish television quizzes are honest enough, but the fix is on in the state lottery.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 31 -The ballots will be longer and the issues will be fewer than usual on Tuesday when Westchester elects a Board of Supervisors, mayor of the six cities, a county judge, a State Senator, an Assemblyman and other officials.

DORE SCHARY, whose new drama, "The Highest Tree," opens on Broadway Wednesday, says he hates violence. He thinks everyone should be indignant and articulate about violence. INTO the pleasant, romanticized, predictable world of teen-age fiction comes "That Archer Girl," and she should cause quite a stir. She is beautiful, rich, an A student, an aristocrat in her community and a thoroughly hateful person.

A HANDY wheel mounting kit which contains two short axles, two bushings and two snap-lock caps is designed to simplify the mounting of rubber tired wheels (available at many hardware stores) on the bottom of any object.

GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- On this first anniversary of the threepower conference seeking a treaty to ban nuclear tests, the United States negotiator, Ambassador James J. Wadsworth, refrained from taking either an optimistic or a pessimistic stand.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A nation-wide $1,000,000,000 program to expand and extend medical schools -- or face a hazard to the public health -- was urged today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The number of workers drawing unemployment benefits spurted by 73,500 to 1,286,500 in the week that ended Oct. 17, the Labor Department reported today.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 -- Senator Frost avenged last week's loss to Jamin today by winning the second leg of the $75,000 American Trotting Classic at Hollywood Park. It was the first loss in this country for the French horse.

The first week of November and part of the second almost always finds New York City the horse center of the country. It is true again this year. The National Horse Show will begin in Madison Square Garden on Tuesday and run day and night until Nov. 10.
Five locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters granted another contract extension to milk dealers in the metropolitan area yesterday to allow the continuation of wage talks.

EXOTIC plants add rich color to the indoor window garden. Their colorful foliage provides a point of interest, whether interspersed among green plants or used alone as a focal point. There are many dependable house plants that deserve more widespread use because of their colorful leaves.

AFTER Queen Victoria's death in 1901, her 110 photograph albums containing approximately 1,000,000 photographs survived the wholesale housecleaning that destroyed the thousands of loose photographs treasured by the Queen and the Prince Consort.

CAIRO, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- A trial of sixty-four persons on charges of attempting to overthrow the regime of President Gamal Abdel Nasser ended Thursday in Alexandria, the Cairo weekly newspaper Akhbar el Yom reported today. The court is considering its verdict.

MIAMI BEACH -- This resort's hotelmen and allied tourist interests are speaking of the approaching winter with high optimism. HAVANA -- Early in the life of the Castro Revolutionary Government, someone touched off a fire in the passenger terminal building of Jose Marti Airport, the gateway to Havana. HANOVER, N.H , Oct. 31 -The Dartmouth Outing Club is undertaking a study of emergency search and rescue procedures. The findings may lead to new state legislation.

THIS fairy-tale tells of a lonely sea-witch, a melancholy and neurotic sprite, who, having no children of her own, determines to have someone else's: Vicky Doyle and her brother Little Thomas, whom she has spied playing on the beach. One night, by means of a spell, the sea-witch lures the children from their beds and takes them with her on an underwater tour of the seven seas.
HARTFORD, Oct. 31 -- All major cities in Connecticut are holding mayoral and municipal elections Tuesday. Some have state political ramifications.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 25 -Birth control tests aimed at easing population pressures in this overcrowded island are going forward.
WINCHESTER, Mass., Oct. 31 (AP) -- The bodies of Dr. Francis H. L. Taylor, a biochemist, and his wife, a physician, were found today in a bedroom of their home here.

Teachers College at Columbia received a record $2,685,499 in gifts, grants and bequests in the twelve months ended June 30, Dr. Hollis L. Caswell, president of the college, announced yesterday. The figure was $285,313 more than for the previous fiscal year.
MONTREAL, Oct. 31 (UPI) Maurice (Rocket) Richard scored a third-period goal tonight that left the Montreal Canadiens to a 2-2 tie with the Detroit Red Wings.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 31 -Princeton squeaked out a 7-to-0 victory over Brown today and went into a tie for the Ivy League lead with Penn and Yale. Each has won three games and lost one. Dartmouth is only a stride behind with two victories, a tie and a loss.

ONE forgets how bland most of the books written for teen-age girls are until one picks up a story by Mary Stolz. This one, like her others, doesn't have much plot. Miranda Parish, 19, an unambitious and overaccommodating girl, is, with thousands like her, dissatisfied both with her secretarial job in a small knit-goods business and with her meager social life.

ONE uncle is poor, dishonest and happy. The other is rich, famous and miserable. When Pablo comes to the Mexican village of San Miguel to learn to read, he finds his problems hinge on those of his uncles. Because he understands people so well, 9-year-old Pablo accepts the two men for what they are rather than for what they do, sadly realizing that the world is filled with illogically behaved adults.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 31 -Roya Direct, a 6-year-old mare owned by Clarence M. Alles of Flemington, N. J., tonight scored a length victory over Copermite before 20,345 fans in the $3,150 Monitor Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Undefeated and untied Texas shocked Southern Methodist with a touchdown in the first three minutes that was set up by a 51-yard pass from Jack Collins to Monte Lee and scored a 21-0 victory today.
ATLANTA, Oct. 31 -- The president of the Atlanta school board says the board intended to submit a desegregation plan to the Federal District Court here before a Dec. 1 deadline.

Four American scientists have been honored as the winners of the 1959 Nobel Prizes. Complete radio coverage of election results will be provided by The New York Times Tuesday night over the facilities of WQXR and WQXR-FM. A number of affiliates on the QXR network also will carry the returns.

MEXICO CITY -- Several signs point to the development of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula as the next important tourist area in this country. Tourists, as a matter of fact, have beat the planners to the program and are making their way to the peninsula in rapidly increasing numbers.
