PLANTS in glowing autumn colors will be featured at the New York Botanical Garden's Chrysanthemum Show, which opens on Saturday at the conservatory, Bronx Park. The display can be seen from 10 A. M. to 4 P. M. daily through Dec. 13.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 -The Writers Guild of America announced today that agreement had been reached with three independent movie production companies ending a twenty-day strike against those companies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- India's bid to gain full voting rights in the International Maritime Consultative Organization was bolstered by the adoption today of a resolution expressing hope that India's status soon would be "regularized."

IT is a pleasure to observe that Gerald W. Johnson's highly regarded craftsmanship as a writer of history has at last been enlisted in the creation of a juvenile. This book, composed in the form of a letter to his grandson, Peter, covers the years of our history to 1787.

TRANSLATED from the German, honorably listed by the International Hans Christian Andersen Awards, published last year in England and now slightly revised for America, this book shows its European origin. It is ever so subtly more serious and moralistic than we expect of our Juveniles.

TO THE EDITOR: There is still one area for hope in an otherwise dismal picture. Mrs. Huxley states that there are two parks, the Tsavo and Serengeti, where game can roam freely and be reasonably well protected. Unfortunately the animals must leave the park at certain times of the year when the water supply dries up.
Two grants for study at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism were announced yesterday.

Thanks for printing Harold C. Schonberg's piece on E. E. Cummings ("At 65, Our Rebel Poet Still Rebels," Oct. 11). But why did he say, in effect, that Cummings can lick Whitman ? "Cummings is perhaps much the better poet; a more precise workman and a far subtler master of imagery, rhythm and language.

Casita Maria, said to be the first and only settlement house in this city especially dedicated to the needs of the Puerto Rican community, will receive the proceeds of the annual Autumn Festival, a cocktail party and dance. It will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 20.
New York's place in higher education was underlined last week by reports from the city's Board of Higher Education and the state's Commission on NonTax Supported Colleges and Universities.

Having brought to America dancers from Great Britain, the Soviet Union, Spain, the Philippines, Israel, India, Japan, Yugoslavia, France, Germany and Switzerland, impressario S. Hurok adds a new nation to his list when he presents the Polish State Folk Ballet at the City Center on Tuesday night.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 31 -- An undefeated University of Delaware football team made few mistakes today and swept to a 34-to-14 triumph over Rutgers before 10,500 persons.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 31 (AP) Joel Arrington zipped 83 yards for a touchdown and Art Browning kicked a fourthperiod field goal as Duke upset Georgia Tech's ninth-ranked football team, 10 -- 7, today.

WHEN Bethea's ministerfather dies suddenly of a heart attack, family life ends abruptly for the 15-year-old girl. Her mother, brother and sister are sent to live with relatives; Bethea's one dream is to reunite them. She persuades an affluent uncle to enroll her for the year (it's 1859) in the Western Female Seminary at Oxford, Ohio, where she can train to be a schoolteacher.

A leveling-off trend in the economy is visible. It was expected to come later, but it appeared at the end of the third quarter, mainly because of the steel strike. The Department of Commerce has pointed out, however, that even those segments of the economy not related directly to steel have leveled off.

TUCSON, Ariz -- Few Europeans arriving in New York still expect to see Indians as soon as they get off the boat, but a good many American tourists, arriving in the Southwest now, are almost as naive as the Europeans used to be.

HONOLULU -- Hawaii, which officially became the fiftieth State on Aug. 21, will hold a fourday Admission Day Celebration during the coming Thanksgiving season. Vice President Richard M. Nixon has been invited to give the keynote speech at the formal Admission Day observance on Sunday, Nov. 29.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- With building programs, actual or projected, estimated at over $10,000,000, and tourist traffic this year running ahead of 1958 by almost 9 per cent, Bermuda is going to wind up its 350th year as a British colony in a confident gallop.

CLARENCE, the dog who likes television, returns here with a third set of adventures, this time on Cape Cool. In one month, Clarence -- is he so adaptable because of his varied ancestry? -- makes a random collection somewhat based on maritime life, fetches dead fish till he routs an obnoxious guest, gets his picture drawn, joins a fishing party, saves a drifting boat, and makes a raft of friends.
GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- The American Joint Distribution Committee, the principal agency for assisting needy Jews outside the United States, will open its annual overseas conference here Monday.

COLLABORATORS on what many cherish as their happiest musical show memory, "South Pacific," Mary Martin and Rodgers and Hammerstein are bringing to Broadway, ten years later, a new collaboration, "The Sound of Music." The inspiration for the show came from a young director, Vincent J. Donehue, remembered for "Sunrise at Campobello."

ONE astronomical phenomnon of recent years has been the shifting of stars Eastward each autumn from the firmament of Hollywood to New York's Milky Way. Students of the home screen realize that this is the first harbinger of the new television season.

ACCORDING to the jacket copy, "time is the principal actor" in this first novel by Mavis Gallant, well-known to New Yorker readers for her short stories. The protagonist designation is highly debatable: what people do with time, not what that indifferent element does with people, would seem to be the issue here -- as in all fiction and in life.

FOR Tom Long, quarantined in his uncle's flat in a converted mansion, time ticked drearily until the night he stole downstairs to investigate the antics of an unpredictable grandfather's clock, and opened a door which led him back into the late Eighteen Hundreds.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Thirty thousand troops will patrol tiny Ecuador tomorrow to bar violence while half a million voters cast ballots in municipal elections.

MOST of us have given little thought to what a child should, or should not, read when he is sick. Like getting red spots or falling off a bicycle, it is without plan. In most cases, what we choose or what the child asks for is good enough.

NO river in America has a richer history than does the St. Lawrence. This factfilled volume sets forth the life story of the majestic Canadian stream, from its geologic beginning to the recent opening of the Seaway project.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- The coming tourist season, during which jet planes will service the island for the first time, will, as usual, be the best in history for Puerto Rico. But it could also turn out to be the worst in terms of headaches for travelers and for the managers of the island's hotels.

FROM the director of the New York Public Library, Edward G. Freehafer, comes the official announcement that some 100,000 items in the Dance Collection have now been "processed" in a three-year project made possible by a grant of $37,500 from the Rockefeller Foundation in 1956.
Tax laws are usually not very palatable, but a new one this year is benefiting three classes of taxpayers -- insurance companies, employers and employes in business organizations.
STANLEYVILLE, Belgian Congo, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- Warpainted Africans battled Belgianled troops today in riots that killed at least twenty-four persons.

ONE obvious way of judging poems for children is to try them out on some real live children. In our household last weekend we had, with two visiting cousins, a juvenile audience of six, aged 1 to 16, with the usual varieties of sex, temperament and literacy.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 31 (AP) -- President Chiang Kai-shek celebrated his birthday today amid clamor for him to continue to lead the nation when his present term expires next May. The leader of the Chinese Nationalist Government was 73 by his own reckoning, a year less by the Western calendar.
A large business concern here is paying an annual retainer for psychiatric services to emotionally disturbed employes.

THIS is a year of celebration for Johnsonians. Dr. Johnson was born 250 years ago, and "Rasselas" (his philosophical romance) 200 years ago. Lichfield and Birmingham have honored his birthday; and the University of Cairo -- the city where Rasselas went to acquire wisdom, a long time ago -- has greeted the book's anniversary with a collection of essays.

" YOUR grandchildren will live under socialism," says Khrushchev to us. "We will bury you [capitalists]," he predicted to an American visitor in Moscow. Both comments capsule a major ingredient of Communist propaganda the world over: capitalism is doomed. It is self-destructive.
The New Art Wind Quintet showed what a really fine children's concert can be at their program yesterday afternoon in the Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum.

TO the many grown-ups who say, "Children today do not have as much fun as we did," this book will come as positive proof. What fun Nancy and the Crimson Rambler Club had! What leisure their elders found for the quiet, lovely things to do.

THERE is considerable appeal in this adroit re-telling of the story of the composer Rossini's impoverished youth. The lad's ambition, his evident good nature, and his genius, manifesting itself early in life, combine with boyhood adventures to produce an attractive narrative which is presented with charm and with subtle touches of authenticity.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold may go to Laos shortly to look into the troubled situation there.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Administration is planning to reduce considerably its request for foreign aid funds in the budget it will send to Congress next January.
ST. PAUL, Oct. 31 -- The growth of "agribusiness" in Minnesota has helped to counterbalance a trend away from the farm because of fewer jobs and lower personal income in farming.

A SUDDEN increase of 15 to 20 per cent in his fuel bill would make any home owner sit up and take notice. Yet it is possible that he may be easily wasting that much if the windows and doors in his house are not weatherstripped.
Eight private art collections will be on view in the homes of their owners on Nov. 14 for the seventh annual tour of the American Federation of Arts.

TO THE EDITOR: What is so sacred about the Puerto Rican? Every time justified criticism, heated by the crimes of this race, arises writers gush out why the Puerto Ricans should commit crimes, but should not be blamed.

AS one of the only two current Members of Parliament recognized as novelists -- Winston Churchill once wrote a work called "Savrola" -- Maurice Edelman has managed to parlay his knowledge of politics and foreign intrigue into side careers as playwright and television dramatist.

A proposed 1960 capital budget of $658,933,792 was adopted yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The commission also adopted a proposed 1961-65 capital pro gram of $1,934,932,055. A capital budget covers outlays for permanent improvements while an expense budget is for operating costs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -When counsel for the United Steelworkers of America first announced that he would oppose the Government's move for an injunction against the steel strike, most observers seemed to believe he was making a futile legal gesture.
PARIS, Oct. 31 -- The heavy human and financial cost of the Algerian war was examined by the authoritative newspaper Le Monde today on the eve of the conflict's fifth anniversary.

Recently an envelope postmarked Brooklyn reached the national headquarters of the United Service Organizations in New York. Inside, folded in a torn piece of draftsmen's graph paper, was a single bill -- a five-spot -- with a note reading: "From an exG. I.., Anywhere, N. Y."

TOKYO, Oct. 21 -- A marked increase in the productive population and a sharp drop in the death rate post a difficult employment problem in Japan, according to a survey by the Government's Populatiton Problems Research Institute.
Leaders of the nation's electric power industry are impressed by the growth of the Russian power industry, but they aren't worried.
THE first thing to understand, if you are going to watch the 1960 Presidential campaign, is about candidates.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -European arms dealers have thwarted United States efforts to maintain an embargo on the shipment of arms to the restive Caribbean region.

AT a time when we seem to be becoming a nation of conformists, it is refreshing to read about the six nonconformists in this book. John Quincy Adams, the only son of a President of the United States to become President, ended his long, courageous and thorny career of service to America by taking up the cause against slavery.

IF Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, finds his hands full these days, he should not be too surprised. His announced policy that a television schedule should be what it purports to be goes far beyond a mere review of the operations of quizzes, canned laughter and interview shows.
ALBANY, Oct. 31 -- On the basis of past records, only about half the voters who go to the polls next Tuesday will express their preference on nine proposed amendments to the state constitution.
A danger exists that the wiretapping report "The Eavesdroppers" issued by Samuel Dash will lead to further confusion and emotion in a critical area desperately needing clarity and reason.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Joe Gomes, a halfback, grabbed a short pass for one touchdown and sped 12 yards for another today to lead South Carolina to a 22-6 Atlantic Coast Conference victory over Maryland before 20,000 dampened Homecoming Day fans.

In 1941 Jim Parkinson was waiting for call-up in the armed forces of New Zealand. He took a truck-driving job in the interim to help out in the war effort. The truck overturned and both his arms had to be amputated. One was removed at the shoulder; only a two-inch stump was left of the other.
Community resources were mobilized yesterday at all-day conferences in Harlem and Queens to meet the problems of the city's youth, particularly juvenile delinquency.

HOPE is one raw material of moviemaking that the seasoned visitor to the Hollywood studios will note is in surprisingly abundant and even excess supply these days. Optimism appears to be as rampant as pessimism was a few years ago.

A MAINE lobstering village is the fascinating setting of this junior novel -- so fascinating in fact it almost overshadows the heroine and her problems. The story centers on Mindy, a senior at the large regional high school attended by young people from a wide, and diversified, area.

The mileage-pay system of recompensing railroad train service employes is an "outrageous'' imposition on common sense, according to Daniel P. Loomis, president of the Association of American Railroads.

GETTYSBURG, Pa. (AP) -With twenty seconds to go, Earl Little, Gettysburg sophomore quarterback, kicked a 27yard field goal, as Gettysburg upset Lafayette, 16 -- 13, today. A homecoming crowd of 5,000 watched the game.

In The Times of Oct. 25, Helen Rich accuses the present "Leave It to Jane" company of murdering a song entitled "The Crickets Are Calling"; we have "jazzed" it up, she states. The "Cricket Song" in "Leave It to Jane" is being played in the exact tempo -- allegro -- as was marked on the original manuscript by Jerome Kern.
Sales of new cars are roaring along -- but they may soon slow to a near standstill. The growing steel shortage, of course, is the reason.
Army fumbles allowed the Air Force Academy to score both of its touchdowns yesterday as the teams played to a 13-13 tie in a fiercely waged football game in the rain and mud on Yankee Stadium.
SMOOTHLY, professionally, without fanfare or social trappings, the New York City Opera tonight completes another fall season that is a credit to itself and its parent organization, the City Center.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 31 -- Vice President Radhakrishnan declared today that the aggressive moves by Communist China were making other Asian nations suspect China threatened their independence.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31 -- The academic segment of this university city is hopeful of holding the "college chair" on the Cambridge School Committee in the municipal election Tuesday.

The flood of red-ink figures reported in the last two weeks by leading steel companies and the rising tide of employe layoffs in allied industries seemingly place the Government's precarious budgetary surplus further in jeopardy.

Mr. Schonberg, admirer of E. E. Cummings, writes in his article about the poet: "He is a virtuoso, like all superior poets, and he can shape ordinary words and phrases into moments of shimmering rapture.

THIS fictionized biography begins in 1832 as Clara Wieck, the wunderkind of the musical world, is setting out from Leipzig for her debut in Paris. Her father, a renowned music teacher, has devoted ten years of his life to the development of her talent; now he is about to see the fulfillment of his dreams.

" A LAND of ice and fire," Erick Berry calls Iceland, a country of opposites, a country of live volcanos, geysers and, at its center, a great icecap. (We got the very word from the most famous one, Geysir.) The capital Reyjkavik, she says, has somewhat the charm of a sleepy, outdated old frontier town; it has the brisk determined air of a city that is going places in a rush.

AFTER a gap of twenty years, plans are afloat for a new world's fair in this country in 1964. Whether the site will be New York, Washington or Los Angeles -- whether, in fact, there will be an "official" fair at all -is to be determined by the three-man Presidential commission which has been exploring the question.
Eighty-nine Negro youngsters from two junior high schools in Harlem got a taste of college life yesterday. Their sampling ranged from lectures by two professors to a football game, but no classes.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 31 -- A three-party coalition, including the Communists, was indicated today as Iceland's next government.

These are uneasy days. It is one thing to watch a manmade "star" shooting across the heavens, silently, swiftly, in a few seconds out of sight. It is another to read, almost daily, newspaper reports about man-made forces which are unseen, unfelt, but omnipresent and perhaps more powerful than most of us know.

Ch. Chik T'Sun of Caversham, a Pekingese imported from England, became the holder of the world record for best-inshow victories last Sunday at Enid, Okla. The dog, owned by Mr. and Mrs. C. C. Venable of Atlanta, achieved his 122d top award to exceed by one the previous record held by the late great Ch. Bang Away of Sirrah Crest, a boxer.

THE "new novel" in France is no longer a curiosity for avid avant-garde readers. It is rapidly reaching the status of the classics and will, thereby, soon be in need of another label -- how long can it remain "new"? The present qualification nevertheless has a real advantage.

THIS is a fifteenth-century triptych in prose. On the left stands Saint Joan, her humanity no more obscured than usual by the halo, not so much of her holiness as of her popularity, her fatal charm for literary men.

MIAMI -- A seven - story hotel atop the new Miami International Airport Terminal building will be opened officially on Nov. 11. What makes the event notable for both residents and visitors is that it marks a shift in construction of tourist accommodations from the near-by Gold Coast resort centers, none of which will have a "this year's hotel" to spark the start of the annual winter season
Existing school problems, related to a ten-year building program in the city, are set forth by the Board of Education as follows:

Between now and March or April, thousands of college seniors will be hoping to be among the few to be favored with fellowships for graduate study. There are several thousand grants which cover the total expense of graduate training for a year's period and many more smaller ones, offering partial aid.
The 1959 output of Air Force pilots will total only 2,500. The output was 3,600 in 1958 and 5,300 in 1957.

THE attic of a stodgy Victorian house in Ridgefield, Conn., has been put to work with most exciting results. Once a stifling, dusty dumping ground for unloved objects, it has been transformed into an airy studio for the artist-owner by Alexander Kouzmanoff of the architectural firm of Batir. He peeled the area down to its bones, laid cypress wood on the sloping lines of the roof and opened out the walls with huge glass inserts.

LINCOLN, R. I., Oct 31 (AP) -- Alexander J. Ostriker's Catapult, a Bernborough colt, today scored a thrilling victory in the $29,000 Old Colony Stakes before 17.379 as Lincoln Downs closed its twenty-seven-day fall meeting.

WHEN Paddy Chayefsky was a boy in the Riverdale section of the Bronx not very many years ago, he learned that mention of a dybbuk -- the soul of a sinner that has entered the body of a living person -- could still send a shiver through superstitious Jews who had brought a belief in dybbuks with them from Eastern Europe.

The first installment of a dinosaur skeleton that will measure seventy feet from nose to tail left New York Friday for its new home in the Cleveland Museum of Natural History. It will be Cleveland's first dinosaur and its nickname is Happy.

Soviet provincial newspapers and reports of travelers recently in the Soviet Union indicate that there has been a sharp increase in Soviet attacks against Judaism and religious Jews. Anti-Semitic violence was reported to have increased.

The committee of the New York Chapter of WAIF, which earlier announced plans for a motion-picture benefit and supper dance, has now released the name of the movie. It will be the world premiere of "Happy Anniversary" at the Victoria Theatre on Nov. 10.

An "Evening with Robert Frost" on Saturday will benefit the Planned Parenthood Center of North Suffolk in Ht/ntingtori, L. I. The poet will read from his own works in the Village Green School, Huntington.
DETROIT, Oct. 31 -- The United Automobile Workers Union has completed extensive constitutional revisions made necessary by the Labor Reform Act of 1959.

THOMAS MASARYK, first President of the Republic of Czechoslovakia, will be added to the United States Post Office's "Champions of Liberty" series next March 7, the 110th anniversary of his birth. He was the principal founder of the republic which emerged after World War I, on the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Empire.

NOT so many years ago, military history had seemed in danger of becoming an archaic subject of study for the general public. The threat has passed, for reasons not difficult to perceive, and it is now appropriate and possible even for youngsters to become intimately familiar with the unusual skill and luck that have blessed American arms in battle.

ELSA PEDERSON, who has conducted a lifelong love affair with the Alaskan wilderness, conveys in "Victory at Bear Cove" much of the grandeur and fascination of that rugged frontier state. Miss Pederson's moral is uncloyed her prose brisk as a frost-edged hunter's dawn and her story uncomplicated; Bear Cove had been the unquestioned domain of the Kalgin family for several hundred years; with the arrival of homesteaders and a predatory townsman, however, serious questions arise.

A CANADIAN newspaper man, Gerald Clark, has written one of the most shattering and forceful books about contemporary Red China to have reached the public. One may not agree with some of his conclusions, but he is a reporter, not a political scientist. His reporting is superb.

On the night of July 30, about 9 o'clock, Edward Butler, 65, staggered out of Highland Park in Brooklyn, his head and clothing covered with blood. Two passersby drove him to a hospital. He had a fractured skull and died the next day.
American and English antique furniture and decorations wil be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

In the fine tradition of the other academies Naval and Military the cadet wing of the United States Air Force Academy made a smart entry into the Yankee Stadium yesterday. The phalanx of Air Force blue, 400 strong. showed Fasterners that midshipmen and Army cadets no longer were the only groups that could astound crowds by marching precision.
Mayor Wagner conducted an intensive drive in the city yesterday for voter support of the proposed $500,000,000 school construction bond issue in next Tuesday's elections.
A letter from Martha Washington to her dentist, ordering a set of false teeth, has been bought by a Boston collector for $1,400.

THREE high-ranking officials of Intourist, the Russian travel organization, are in the United States arranging through American Express for travel in 1960 by Americans in Russia and by Russians in this country.
The Friday performance of "Heartbreak House" at the Billy Rose Theatre will benefit the Park Association of New York.

Four supernovae, great bursts of light believed to be the result of the explosion of stars, have been detected so far this year at the Palomar Observatory, it was announced yesterday at Pasadena by the California Institute of Technology. A supernova is characterized by a sudden flare-up that can illuminate an entire galaxy, an island universe of billions of stars.
Lufthansa, the West German airline, has announced the appointment of George Stoecker as general manager for North and Central America with headquarters in New York.
When does high become too high?
FRANKFORT, Ky., Oct. 31 -The closing stage of the Kentucky election campaign finds Bert T. Combs, Democrat of Prestonsburg, the favorite to win the Governorship next Tuesday.

No crystal ball is needed to determine that the United Nations General Assembly will refer the Khrushchev disarmament proposal to the new ten-power group which was established by the Big Four in August.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- Despite a fairly dismal tourist summer, presumably the result of news of political unrest here, authorities, hotel people and others interested in welcoming visitors to this old French-Creole republic are going ahead with building and refurbishing hotels, restaurants, beach clubs and night clubs for the coming season.

A decision in Washington last Thursday answers one question. There is to be a world's fair in New York City in 1964. Other questions are not so easy to answer. What kind of world will this be in 1964? What will there be to exhibit? What will there be to celebrate?
BONN, Germany, Oct. 31 -- West Germany is bracing for an expected United States demand that more of the financial burden of manning Western Europe's defenses be shifted onto European shoulders.
Production of the first synthetic penicillin for medical use, the culmination of a ten-year research program, was announced last week by the Bristol Laboratories in East Syracuse, N. Y.

LAID in New Mexico, close by the Arizona border, APACHE WARPATH (Signet, 25 cents) by George Garland tells of cavalry posts and painted Indians in a good, solid story. Civilian Scout Gillette Todd has most of the limelight; he is torn between a brace of sirens and the unearned resentment festering in both troopers and officers -- which climaxes in a last-ditch fight inside the crumbling walls of an abandoned fort.

Fordham Prep of the Bronx swept top honors in the New York division of the Catholic High School sectional crosscountry championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. Chaminade of Mineola took the team title in the Brooklyn-Long Island division.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Holy Cross barely staved off a fourth-quarter comeback by Colgate today for a 14-12 football victory. A 2-point conversion pass from Ken Komodzinski to Bernie Buzyniski provided the margin.

THERE has been no greater variety in the Presidents who have occupied the White House than there has been in the pets they have chosen for companionship. In his new book, Carl Carmer tells the stories of ten of the Presidents and their pets, and in a final chapter gives brief mention to more than a dozen other White House occupants and their pets.

PEIPING, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- Communist China asked Britain and the Soviet Union today to take "emergency measures" to stop the trial, due to open in Laos Monday, of Prince Souphanovong, Laotian Left-wing leader.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Not so many years ago this famous resort virtually locked its doors during the summer months. The beginning and end of its winter season was dictated by the social colony and lasted no longer than about eight weeks.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Belgian authorities rushed an armored column and two infantry companies into Stanleyville today to combat the bloody outbreak by African nationalists demanding immediate independence.
France is not the only country for which this was a vintage year for growers of wine grapes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Of all the noble patriots now vowing to rescue the nation from the attitudes and platitudes of the Republican party, the one with the most interesting role is the right honorable gentleman from Massachusetts, Mr. John F. Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- A step-by-step revision of United States policy that would add Communist China to the United Nations and recognize Nationalist Taiwan as a new republic was recommended by private researchers today to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Last-minute arguments for and against the city's $500,000,000 bond issue were presented here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The State and Justice Departments and the Federal Aviation Agency took new steps today to prevent trouble-making plane flights from the United States to Cuba.
The Linnaean Society of New York made known yesterday its opposition to the proposed constitutional amendment permitting the Northway through the Adirondack forest preserve.

Dr. Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, told a Reformation Festival congregation yesterday afternoon that Christians should not "stand idly by while our fellow human beings are deprived of the opportunity of realizing their highest potential because of race, color or creed."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The following is the text of the statement by Earl W. Kintner, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, on the commission's drive against deceptive television advertising:

WAYNESBORO, Va., Nov. 1 -- A Piedmont airlines DC-3 missing since Friday with twenty-seven persons aboard was found shattered on a heavily wooded ledge in the Blue Ridge Mountains today. E. Phil Bradley, 33 years old, of Clifton Forge, Va., was the only survivor. tossed clear of the wreckage, scattered over an area no more than seventy-five yards long. C.A.B. experts were sifting through the ruins, seeking the cause of the crash.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 1 -Ch. Zamitz Jumpin' Jack, an English setter from the Waseeka Kennels of Ashland, Mass., gained best-in-show honors today in the Union County Kennel Club's twenty-first annual event.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 1 -- It looks very much from here as if American exporters are going to have to live indefinitely with two separate trading blocs in Europe.
Representative Victor L. Anfuso, Democrat of Brooklyn, last night urged the Government to shift funds from the foreignaid program to the space effort.

SAFETY plays are far less often made in tournaments than in rubber bridge. In tournament scoring, an overtrick is so important that a player may risk his contract to try for one. In rubber bridge, making the contract is paramount.
Western economists are agreed that Soviet capital investment resources for economic expansion will increase as Soviet output rises in the years ahead.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -International agreement has been reached on permissible radiation exposure for the general public.
The Western Hemisphere needs a common market, such as the one in Europe, for the mutual economic, social, political and military advancement of all its member countries, including our own.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -The United Packinghouse Workers of America said today that it was considering strike action in a dispute with Wilson Co., meat packers.
Five films are slated to arrive in local theaters this week. The programs follow:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -Senator Paul H. Douglas declared today that Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, the majority leader, would be "unacceptable" to the North as the Democratic Presidential nominee in 1960.
A new, long-range community program to combat juvenile delinquency here will be announced soon, Mayor Wagner said last night.
We summarize here our recommendations regarding questions and candidates in tomorrow's election.

It is doubtful whether Antarctica has much military importance in this nuclear-missile age. Our leading generals are convinced that the great south polar land mass has far less strategic value than the great north polar water mass. For it is in the latter icy wastes that our Polaris submarines can find their most convenient hiding places.

The fifteenth annual conference of the Metropolitan Council of B'nai B'rith drew the largest attendance in its history yesterday. More than 1,500 men and women from 310 lodges and chapters in New York City, Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties attended the allday meeting at the Astor Hotel.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1 -- "Mutiny on the Bounty," one of Hollywood's classic sea pictures, is the object of a production race by two major studios.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 1 -Barlovento II, the new seventythree-foot ketch owned by Pierre S. du Pont 3d of Rockland, Del., was the winner today of the ninth and biggest Skipper invitation distance race for cruising yachts.

J. Anthony Panuch, special housing adviser to Mayor Wagner, urged yesterday that any proposal for an urban renewal project include a relocation plan and that plans be approved as a package by the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Navy has asked for $1,900,000,000 to carry out its program for Polaris missile submarines and their weapons during the next fiscal year. This is more than three times as much as the $600,000,000 that was invested in these weapons this year.

Does he mean it? This is the question which immediately arises upon a reading of Premier Khrushchev's foreign-policy speech in Moscow last Saturday. The secretary of the American Unitarian Association said yesterday its merger agreement with the Universalist Church of America was a compromise.

A Champagne Preview of the second Metropolitan Young Artists Show being sponsored by the National Arts Club will be held Dec. 9 at the club, the Samuel Tilden Mansion at 15 Gramercy Park South. Proceeds will be used to defray the costs of the show and toward rehabilitating the fifty-year-old gallery on the main floor of the clubhouse.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 1 -An increasing number of thoughtful West Germans are beginning to worry out loud about what a leading editor described today as the "tired democracy" being practiced in the Federal Republic.
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 1.-Official quarters feel that two positive steps forward have been achieved on the threeyear-old problem of United States military bases in Morocco.

The second volume of Sir Arthur Bryant's history of World War II, based on the war diaries of Field Marshal Lord Alanbrooke, will be issued Nov. 19 by Doubleday. Called "Triumph in the West," the book begins with the events of September, 1943, and carries Lord Alanbrooke's story through May 8, 1945, V-E Day.

I believe that John Canada is justified in saying in his story of Oct. 21 on the opening of the Guggenheim Museum that it fails both as architecture and as a place to show paintings and sculpture. I am truly sorry to be in agreement, as I was one of those architects genuinely glad that our city was finally to have a Frank Lloyd Wright building.

Harland Svare, a Giant linebacker who would rather "blitz" than eat, sleep or miss pre-season practice, whispered the words "Blitz Wanda" to Andy Robustelli early in the first quarter at Yankee Stadium yesterday.
Twelve Jewish community leaders received Louis Marshall Medals last night from the National Patrons Society of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America at a dinner in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
Business education at American colleges and universities is put under a double-barrelled attack in two independent studies published today under the sponsorship of an educational foundation.

Five young students replied "Yes" yesterday to the question, "Can There Be International Agreement on Outer Space?" They could not agree, however, on whether, it should be achieved through the United Nations.

TRENTON, Nov. 1 -- The curtain will descend tomorrow on New Jersey's election campaign, with both Republican and Democratic candidates taking to the radio and the stump in lastminute appeals for support.

In a sense the shortcomings of every capital budget proposed by the City Planning Commission in recent years were an argument, express or implied, for voter approval of Amendment No. 4 tomorrow. The 1960 capital budget just forwarded to the Board of Estimate is no exception, but the message accompanying the budget shows with fresh urgency how important it is that the city's borrowing power for school construction be enlarged.
The Museum of Modern Art again has a large painting of water lilies by Claude Monet, a replacement for the Monet that was destroyed in the museum fire on April 15, 1958.

The Joint Economic Committee of Congress made public last week a number of papers it had received in the course of its inquiry into the question of the rate of growth in this country, with particular stress on the comparison of our own rate with that of Russia.
The Lecomte du Nouy Foundation at 1 East End Avenue has named Dr. Michael Polanyi winner of the Lecomte du Nouy Award for 1959.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 1 (UPI)--Mr. Bradley said he had nothing to eat or drink during his ordeal but that this had not bothered him "because I'm on a diet." But he said, "I missed the water."

With all the headlines about delinquency it is important to remember that this is only one of many juvenile problems, only one possible reaction to the difficult atmosphere created by rapid technological development, population changes and world tensions.
The city's expense budget revenues for the fiscal year ended June 30 exceeded expenditures by $3,169,787, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa made known yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 1 -- A session of the Nordic Council of Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Finland, and Iceland opened in the Parliament Building here today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -Weather was the most significant guiding factor in grain futures dealings last week on the Board of Trade and it was mostly bullish in so far as corn and soybean transactions were concerned.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov 1 (UPI) -- An assembly of Texans applauded and cheered here today as demands were made that Senator Johnson receive the 1960 Democratic Presidential nomination.

" CARMEN" came to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday evening. It was the first presentation of the Bizet opera this season, and it also had a trio of principals new or near-new to Met audiences. The two seen for the first time were William Olvis, who sang his first Don Jose at the house, and Maria Nache, the Spanish soprano who made her debut as Micaela.

The husband of a science teacher who was severely beaten by a 14-year-old pupil in an East Harlem school Thursday said yesterday that his wife would "certainly" return to her classes as soon as possible.
S. J. Kessler Sons, architectural firm, blacklisted by the city from work on slum clearance projects has the contract to design two such projects for which the city will sell the land today.

Lois Hartzell, soprano, appeared in a song recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, singing a program that included such unusual items as arias from Respighi's "La Fiamma", and Zanbonai's "Conchita."
With his new experimental production of "U. S. A." valiantly fighting for life at the offBroadway Martinique Theatre, Paul Shyre is once again turning to his first love, Sean O'Casey.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 1 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said tonight that India was making "adequate military preparations" to meet the challenge of aggression by the Chinese Communists.
The nation's major railroads will present today to the five brotherhoods of operating employes a program for revising work rules. Some of the rules date back four decades and more.
The "treat 'em rough" school seems to have a definite place in getting people to invest regularly in mutual funds.

The glossier, more sophisticated side of folk song held the stage for most of Saturday evening at Town Hall in a program offered by Sister Rosetta Tharpe, Ed McCurdy. Josef Marais and Miranda and Sonny Terry and Brownie McGhee.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- African exploration has been extensive for decades, but localized. Now the so-called Dark Continent is to be blanketed by an army of explorers of a different type, dedicated to banishing much of its mystery.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Gleaming with brass and puffing proudly, 213 cars built before 1905 completed a fifty-six-mile run from London to Brighton today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -President Eisenhower and the heads of government of Britain, France and West Germany are preparing actively for their meeting in Paris next month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that he thought President Eisenhower had placed himself on the side of the steel companies long before the present strike began.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Union will be able by 1965 to spend more than the United States does in building up economic power, a National Planning Association study said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Eagles staged a goal-line stand in the last minute today, took over the ball on downs on the 6-inch line and thus saved a 30-23 victory over the Washington Redskins.

The Metropolitan Opera will open its third week next Monday with the season's first performance of "Aida." Lucine Amara, singing the role for the first time at the Metropolitan, will be the Aida. Other principals will include Dimiter Uzunov, Nell Rankin. Robert Merrill and Cesare Siepi.
Management and teamster negotiators in the metropolitan area milk industry narrowed their differences yesterday in an effort to avert a strike at 6 P. M. today.
A man dining in a restaurant was wounded and a man seated near a window in a near-by tavern cut by flying glass from stray bullets during a chase of a gunman last night on the West Side.
With a light turnout expected in tomorrow's off-year election, Mayor Wagner expressed fear yesterday for the chances of the city's $500,000,000 school bond issue.

" La Boheme," with several new faces in the cast, was Saturday evening's attraction at the City Center. Making first appearances with the company were Elizabeth Carron as Mimi and Richard Verreau as Rodolfo.

BAGHDAD, Iraq., Nov. 1 (UPI) -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim, recovering from an assassination attempt Oct. 7, said in an interview today that Iraq was a friend of all countries. But he warned that Iraq would not tolerate interference from any outside forces.
Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, asserted yesterday that automobile traffic was "killing the subways."
The Quartetto Carmirelli of Rome played a program of charm and vivacity late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.
An automobile plunged out of control yesterday in a Queens cemetery, killing a woman who was standing beside her husband's grave and injuring eleven other persons.

The recent signs of easing of the "cold war" among the great powers has not been duplicated in the Middle East, Jacob D. Herzog, Minister Plenipotentiary of the Israeli Embassy in Washington, said yesterday.

The team-of-four contest in the metropolitan contract bridge tournament at the Statler Hilton Hotel ended last night. Dr. Kalman Apfel, Murray Schnee and Fred Bickel of New York, and Ronald Rosenberg of Atlantic City won with 35 1/2 points out of a possible 52.

Just about one person in ten in this country suffers from serious impairment of the hearing function. For many of them complete cure is possible. For most of them there is great help available. A really concerted drive against this enemy to happiness has barely started, but already much has been done. More work is needed.

NOEL LEE and Ezra Sims were the two young American composers on Saturday night's first Composers Forum of the season at the Donnell Library and their music revealed considerable talent and some striking parallels.

" CONQUEST," the weekly series devoted to science, resumed over Channel 2 late yesterday afternoon with an account of the scientific measurement of mother love. It was an unusual and fascinating half hour.

JOHNSON CITY, N. Y., Nov. 1 (AP) -- A retired business man announced today the formation of a national committee that he said would help members of Congress it believed were attacked unfairly by "special interest and pressure groups."
Following are sketches of some of the victims from the New York area in the plane wreckage found near Charlottesville, Va., yesterday:
THE chairman of the Federal Trade Commission speaks softly but readily uses a big stick to protect the buying public.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Buyers of still-rising industrial equities began last week to shift their demand from the leading blue chips to the good second-class shares with a higher yield. But there was no loss of the extraordinary buoyancy the market has shown since the end of September.
A CHILD'S intense fears, especially those that plague him for years and follow him into adulthood, are usually those that he has been led to conceal or deny.

Two years ago Oklahoma came to the end of the longest winning streak college football has known. The Sooners bowed by 7 -- 0 to Notre Dame. Oklahoma had won forty-seven games in succession after losing its 1953 opener to the same Fighting Irish and tying Pittsburgh the following week.
WHERE home appliances are concerned, the progress made in Parisian kitchens within the last five years has been prodigious.
FILBERTS, often called hazelnuts, can be .chopped and added to many everyday foods to introduce an element of surprise and a unique flavor that changes the ordinary into the exotic.

WARSAW, Nov. 1 -- Kielce looks like any of a dozen Polish cities -- gray, a bit down at the heel, spottily raw with new construction. But these days it is the center of a controversy between the Roman Catholic Church and Poland's Communist Government.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 1 -(AP) -- William S. Moscrip, 82 years old, of St. Paul, an authority on livestock, dairying and agricultural affairs, was killed today in a car-truck collision on the outskirts of St. Paul.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 -- What happens when the team with the best running back in the National Football League meets the team with the best passing quarterback? According to the result at Memorial Stadium today, the team with the top runner has the advantage.
Cotton prices in the domestic market continued in a narrow trading range last week.

TOKYO, Nov. 1 -- Asian and African countries have voiced a firm demand at the meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade here for a more generous share of the prosperity enjoyed by the industrialized nations of the West.

STANLEYVILLE, Belgian Congo, Nov. 1 (Reuters) -- The security police restored calm today and arrested Patrice Lumumba, an African nationalist leader, after a hunt that touched ed off two Gays of rioting.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- When Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd goes to Paris this month to begin rebuilding Britain's bridges to France and West Germany, he will have the enthusiastic support of the Government and Parliament. Apparently, and unfortunately, the man in the street, in his own phrase, "couldn't care less."

ALTHOUGH memories of last summer's record heat wave linger long and painfully, it seems a safe bet that cool weather is here to stay. Some energetic optimists already have put away their summer clothes. Here are some tips for those who have delayed action.

The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts announced yesterday that it expected to receive more than $9,000,000 from a trust fund originally set up by John D. Rockefeller Sr. in 1917.

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Nov. 1 -- Mickey Shuman, the Peddie School's head football coach, was up to his elbows in hot towels this morning. His starting T-quarterback had suffered a wrenched knee in yesterday's Pingry game and the coach was treating it.
A VIVID reminder of one of the most disastrous Allied waterborne missions of World War II was shown last night on Channel 2's "The Twentieth Century."
Fifty-four men will contend for thirteen posts in the forthcoming election of officers for Local 88 of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots.
Judas Iscariot was a "rank amateur" compared with the manipulators of rigged television quiz programs, the Rev. Dr. John Ellis Large said yesterday.

Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel and U Nu, former Burmese Premier, agreed yesterday in the course of a television program that widespread poverty rather than the threat of war was the real danger to the world.

A seven-story residence hall, made possible through a $500,000 gift, will be dedicated next Sunday afternoon at Yeshiva University, Amsterdam Avenue and 184th Street.

Twice yesterday before 67,837 fans at the Yankee Stadium Alex Webster scored shortyardage touchdowns for the Giants and twice Pat Summerall booted long-yardage field goals against the Packers. Add a couple of routine conversions by Summerall and -- here and there -- a completed pass by Charley Conerly and that just about accounted for the victorious offense as the New Yorkers beat the visitors from Green Bay, Wis., 20 -- 3.

MOSCOW, Nov. 1 (AP) -Erskine Caldwell, the novelist, said today he had collected some royalties on his works published in the Soviet Union, but only enough to pay the expenses of his visit here. He and his wife are leaving tomorrow after a week as guest of Soviet writers, librarians and teachers.

Waterfront employers are studying a new proposal by the International Longshoremen's Association on the so-called "containerization" of cargo.

" Friday the Thirteenth." a dance sponsored by the New York Chapter of the Alumnae Associatiton of the Newton (Mass.) College of the Sacred Heart, will be held in the St. Anthony Club, 16 East Sixtyfourth Street on Nov. 13.

GOING to a Yiddish musiis not so simple as it once was. Now you have to bring your own ending.

General Telephone Electronics Corporation's gross revenues for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 topped $1,000,000,000 for the first time in any similar period, according to the report issued over the weekend. The report includes operations of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., which was acquired on March 5.

Stan Kenton's band churned up a great deal of noise at Carnegie Hall last night to very little purpose. The band plunged ponderously through a program made up largely of selections drawn from Mr. Kenton's repertory of the last fifteen years, some items of which once had vitality and spirit when they were played by the earlier Kenton bands that originated them.

DUSSELDORF, Germany, Nov. 1 -- A capacity audience gave Eugene Ionesco a tenminute ovation here last night after the world premiere of his new play, "The Rhinoceros." It is the first work by the RumanianFrench playwright on a purely political theme.
The second-ranking prelate of the Anglican Communion denied yesterday that there was any significant drift among Anglican clergy toward Roman Catholic forms of worship.

IF New York is a dead sports town, the ghost was dancing in exceedingly lively fashion, whirling merrily with the witches on this Halloween week-end. The Yankee Stadium was the scene of a double demonstration of how premature are the cries of the doomsday prophets.
The cost of education in the state is expected to reach $2,400,000,000 in 1963, the Board of Regents said yesterday.
NYACK, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- The police arrested two New Jersey men early today and confiscated $5,010 in counterfeit bills.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Export-Import Bank has entered the nuclear field.

The Roman Catholic Church "admits and rejoices in the fact that many others besides Catholics share the Beatific Vision in heaven," the Rev. Bernard Donachie said yesterday at the 10 A. M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The "supermarket" system introduced in 1957 at New York International Airport for Customs inspection has speeded the processing of arriving travelers, but it still needs considerable improvement, according to officials at the airport.

When a company buys insurance for its employes, it is a tax deduction. When a man buys insurance for himself, it is not.
Modern furniture, sturdy as a dyke and trim as iceskates, is the latest Dutch offering in the American market.
THE laundering of wash-andwear fabrics "can never be a completely automatic process." Jules Labarthe of the Canargie Institute of Technology said Friday.

The news of arms shipments to the Caribbean, reported yesterday in Seymour Topping's dispatch to this newspaper, makes one think of the bad old days when one of Shaw's characters in "Major Barbara" could boast that he sold weapons without discrimination to "burglar and policeman, to black man, white man and yellow man, to all sorts and conditions, all nationalities, all faiths, all follies, all causes and all crimes."
What is in some ways one of the most interesting educational institutions in the world celebrates its 100th anniversary today. It is the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art.

The American Smelting and Refining Company announced over the week-end that its earnings in the nine months ended Sept. 30 declined to $10,365,300 from $11,218,500 in the 1958 period.

The Empire State Building fulfilled yesterday the expectations of members of the Polish State Folk Ballet, for whom it was about the first and biggest thing they saw after their arrival in New York for a three-week engagement at the City Center.
European governments have sold far in excess of 1,000,000 surplus military weapons on the international arms market this year, munitions dealers said yesterday.

Sgt. Edgar D. Croswell of the New York State Police told a Federal Court jury yesterday how he and other law agents had broken up the 1957 Apalachin meeting.

Five of the seven club-owners in the new American Football League were reported yesterday to favor Edgar E. (Rip) Miller, assistant athletic director at the United States Naval Academy, as the league commissioner.

During this century our heroes have come in bunches. First there were the polar explorers. Then came the pioneer aviators. Soon we will be tense with excitement as the first travelers venture into space.
MADRID, Oct. 30 -- Spain's new economic stabilization plan, announced with international fanfare three months ago, is beset by Cabinet divisions and public uncertainty.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- The Government today won its first tangible victory in the present phase of the ten-year-old anti-trust suit against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. The election of Paul R. Frohring as a director of the American Home Products Corporation has been announced by Alvin G. Brush, chairman. Mr. Frohring is president of General Bio-chemicals, Inc., Chagrin Falls, Ohio, manufacturer of chemical and biological products for research uses.

Charles Van Doren, his television reputation tarnished and his $129,000 quiz winnings spent, learned last night that he had lost his post as a teacher at Columbia Univer sity. Amid the public debate on Mr. Van Doren's confessed role as a fixed contestant on the quiz show "Twenty-one," the university trustees announced that they had accepted his offer to resign.

Advertisers, agencies and the networks were understandably less than elated over the announcement Sunday by the Federal Trade Commission that it intended to increase its vigilance in ridding television of so- called illegal and deceptive commercials.

HOOKED rugs, Danish pasties, Swiss cuckoo clocks -- there is a little of everything at the thirty-sixth Annual Women's International Exposition, which opened yesterday at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at Thirtyfourth Street.

NEWARK, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Seventy-one violations of Federal safety rules were charged today against the owner and renters of a truck that rammed a bus in North Brunswick and fatally injured twelve passengers.
The Career and Salary Appeals Board recommended yesterday that the nearly 4,000 registered nurses employed by the city receive pay raises averaging $500 a year each.
TORONTO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Racing was called off after the fifth race at New Woodbine Park today when jockeys refused to ride, claiming the track was unsafe.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan disclosed yesterday that a "great number" of television quiz show contestants had lied in their testimony before a grand jury.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Eight Columbus policemen were under arrest today on theft charges.
Goodman A. Sarachan of Rochester presided yesterday for the first time as chairman of the State Commission of Investigation.
NEWARK, Nov. 2 -- Three New Jersey men were arrested today on charges of distributing counterfeit currency. Two others had been arrested earlier.

TOKYO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Prospects for eliminating certain trade barriers maintained by the United States, Italy and Japan were aired today by nations of GATT, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Richard A. Mack and Thurman A. Whiteside asked the Supreme Court today to block a second trial of them on charges of conspiring to rig a Miami TV channel award.

A belated action by the United States Government to block a $10,000,000 repurchase agreement made in 1955 between the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and a New York-Chicago investment banking group was upheld yesterday by the Court of Appeals here.
BUFFALO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Community demands on professors are making it hard for schools to keep faculties at work on their primary job of education, a university head said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Government announced today changes in its lists of items that require special licenses before they can be shipped abroad.
Mayor Wagner will fly to California tomorrow on a trip announced as principally in the interests of tree-planting in Israel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Harmar D. Denny resigned today from the Civil Aeronautics Board, effective Nov. 15. President Eisenhower chose Whitney Gillilland, now chairman of the Foreign Claims Commission, to succeed him.
Throughothe-wall air-conditioning units are proving most popular with builder of apart[/nent houses, according to a survey by the Fedders Corporation, manufacturer of air-coolhag systems.
The contract renewal talks involving 13,000 delivery and processing workers in the milk industry here will continue this morning in the Biltmore Hotel. A twelve-hour session was held yesterday.

Fashion trends for spring are taking shape as Seventh Avenue designers present collections, the American equivalent of the Paris openings. The New York Times has been barred from some showings because of its policy to report trends immediately. Reports on those showings are based on information from other fashion authorities. Most of the clothes will be in stores by January.

The Litter Basket Further evidence that ours is a thinking civilization comes now from one of the more commonplace institutions around us: the litter basket. Only the other day we read how Sanitation Commissioner Screvane, reporting to the Citizens Committee to Keep New York City Clean, announced the contemplated purchase by the city of 14,587 litter cans, which would bring the city's total to nearly twice the present number.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The raid Friday by United States Treasury agents on what they called a multi-million-dollar gambling ring allegedly operating in the shadow of the East Boston Police Station has brought an investigation of the station.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Caryl Chesman formally entered his twelfth appeal to the Supreme Court today, asking either a new trial or outright freedom. He has spent eleven-and-a-half years in San Quentin's "death row."

The New York City Chapter of the New York State Society of Profesional Engineers has presented its 1959 awards for distinguished service to Frederick C. Gardner and Max H. Foley.
