Madison Square Garden was a busy place yesterday for today's opening of the eight-day National Horse Show. The busy ones included carpenters, bunting drapers and the haulers and spreaders of black earth for the arena floor.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Industrial shares opened the week in a buoyant mood on the stock market here. They came back heavily later but small rises again predominated to lift the Financial Times index of industrial common stocks 0.2 point to 302.6, the fourth peak in as many days.

This is Election Day, when the people decide what they want in public office, on the judicial bench and in determination of issues. It is an "off-year" election in New York City, meaning that we are not electing a Mayor, or helping to elect a Governor or a President. But this does not mean that today's election is unimportant.

IT happened at Stern's: Up to the opening of Stern's new fashion third floor today, customers and carpenters have been mingling in democratic cameraderie. Last week, as an architect strode across the fur department bulging with plans and blueprints, a customer commented drily, "There's so much construction going on in New York that every time I cross Park Avenue, I get an edifice complex."
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 2 -- India is becoming increasingly concerned over the fact that Communist China has not returned ten border policemen who were captured in Ladakh nearly two weeks ago.

Plans are being completed for the theatre party to augment the scholarship fund of the Town School at the Nov. 17 performance of "The Gang's All Here" at the Ambassador Theatre. The event is being sponsored by the school's Parents Association.

Sometimes a single remark will flash out of a discussion like lightning across a murky sky and give an unusual illumination. A good example comes from the last address of Indian Prime Minister Nehru. Explaining why India's borders had not been better fortified, he said:

Every so often reports come from free Europe about growing concern among leaders and students of public opinion with what they regard as increasing political apathy among the European peoples. Thus German publicists begin to talk about "tired democracy" in their country; British opinion surveys speak of popular indifference and complacency, and most European pre-election reports register fears of a popular political disengagement.
The pilots of the liner Israel and the freighter American Press asserted yesterday that they had sounded the proper whistle signals but had failed to hear any response before the ships collided here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Charles Van Doren confessed today that he had lived a lie for three years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- New homes have been found within the last year for half of the refugees living in camps in Europe. However, 22,000 still are in camps in Austria, West Germany, Italy and Greece.
"Tosca" was last night's opera at the Metropolitan, with Cornell MacNeil singing Baron Scarpia for the first time with the company.
Ray Lev's piano program last night at Carnegie Hall was much in the spirit of her previous recitals here.

DAN MAHONEY, who died in retirement in Florida in 1956, was one of the colorful old-timers of the game, especially in his devices for committing petit larceny at the bridge table. His forte was inventing bridge rules that never existed and solemnly citing them to inexperienced opponents, such as the "two little old ladies" who appear in countless bridge legends.
Columbia University announced yesterday that Benjamin J. Buttenwieser and Alan H. Temple, banking executives here, had been elected to the board of trustees.

NOWHERE is England's newfound prosperity more apparent than in the spectacular displays of fine food at Harrod's of London and at Fortnum Mason. It is a vicarious thrill for anyone with a gastronomic turn of mind to merely stand in the midst of such a magnificent plenty from the British Isles and the four corners of the world.

The National Basketball Association, with Chicago already included in its 1960 plans, will probably expand to twelve teams in 1961 and eventually to fifteen, President Maurice Podoloff said yesterday.

Sales of the eight major department stores and their branches in the New York area last month rose 3.5 per cent above those in the 1958 period, according to a survey made yesterday by The New York Times.

The big investment companies, which now play such a vital role in the stock market, have their decided favorites. By and large, they tend to stick with them, but, from time to time, there are some notable shifts in their stock preferences.
A model of Grand Central City, the most ambitious postwar office building project here, was placed on view yesterday in the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- President Eisenhower called today for support in the fight against inflation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The discount interest rate on the Government's short-term borrowing rose this week, offsetting half of the last two weeks slide from the record established in mid-October.

BALBOA, C. Z., Nov. 2 -- The United States authorities and the Panamanian police were planning measures today to avoid a dangerous clash tomormorow, when nationalists intend a "peaceful invasion" of the Canal Zone.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- History will record this as "the generation of hucksters and suckers," the Rev. Charles E. (Stoney) Jackson told Congressional investigators today in an epilogue to the confession of Charles Van Doren.
Directors of the BristolMyers Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 10 cents in addition to an interim dividend of 20 cents on the common stock. Both are payable on Dec. 1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Atomic industry officials painted a bleak picture today of no business, no profits and undue Government competition and regulation.
THE New York State Police sergeant who sprang the trap at Apalachin in 1957 has advanced a formula for dealing with crime:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Mr. Cohn testified that the day after Miss Bernstein had called, the advertising director of Revlon, a sponsor of the program, called him, saying someone had overheard Mr. Cohn or a friend say that he planned to sue.
STANLEYVILLE, Belgian Congo, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- African unrest was reported spreading outside this riot-torn town today on the eve of a Belgian parliamentary debate on the Congo's future.

ROME, Nov. 2 -- Dr. Arnold Toynbee told the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations today that it must persuade millions throughout the world to improve their diet and to keep population growth under control.
NICE, France, Nov. 2 -- Television in Europe may still be limited in audience and scope, but in sporting coverage it seems hardly limited at all.

Five consecutive musical smashes -- "Where's Charley?", "Guys and Dolls," "Can-Can," "The Boy Friend" and "Silk Stockings" -- were introduced by Cy Feuer and Ernest H. Martin until they stubbed their toes with "Whoop-Up" last season.

Muzz Patrick, the general manager of the New York Rangers, said yesterday that the use of a molded Fiberglas mask by Jacques Plante, the Montreal Canadien goalie, Sunday, might spur a demand for more protective equipment for National Hockey League players.
The voters today will have nine proposed amendments to the State Constitution to approve or reject. Following is a description of what each proposal would do if approved:
LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 3 -- A Rumanian campaign to terrorize Jews there who have shown a desire to emigrate to Israel was reported today in The Times of London.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Britain's horse-players were promised licensed betting shops in the Government's Betting and Gaming Bill published today.

ST. STEPHEN, N. B., Nov. 2 -- At least three things have happened recently to arouse hope that Canada and the United States will act soon to re-establish sea-run Atlantic salmon in the St. Croix River, which runs between Maine and New Brunswick.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Reynolds Metals Company said today it had cut its primary aluminum operating rate to 80 per cent.
Mayor Wagner has been invited by the state's Nelson Commission on City Governmental Operations to be its first witness when it starts public sessions on Dec. 7.

The unexpected value given by the Treasury's November refunding offer to the 1957 issue of "2 1/2 by 5" notes served as a mild boomerang in the Government securities market yesterday. Otherwise the trading session, sandwiched as it was between a week-end layoff and the Election Day holiday, was a rather listless affair.
There may have been a sharp nip in the air for most New Yorkers yesterday, but one group of visitors found the city as balmy as spring.
The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway reported yesterday that its earnings plummeted last month to $4,030,000 from $6,222,000 in the 1958 month.

Delaware is planning to borrow $16,350,000 in the bond market to finance public improvements. The money will be raised on Nov. 17 by the sale of serial bonds dated Dec. 1, 1959, and due on Dec. 1 from 1960 to 1979.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 2 -- Israel's fourth general election since statehood will take place tomorrow.
Intelligent design, space-planning and merchandising have converted a rubbish room in the Webb Knapp building on Vanderbilt Avenue into a thriving pharmacy.
THE ironic humor of British playwright John Mortimer was demonstrated on television last night as two of his works were presented on "The Play of the Week" over Channel 13.
Foreign vessels plying the Great Lakes are taking NO chances of getting caught by an early freeze-up this year, a United Press International survey showed yesterday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 2 -- The week-end rioting in Stanleyville brings the death toll in the Belgian Congo from such outbursts this year to more than 350.

Samuel (Chico) Rollins, a New York lightweight, scored a knockout over Steve Haywood of Baltimore in the sixth round of their scheduled ten-round main event last night at the Academy of Music. It was Rollins' ninth victory in ten professional fights.

Until early afternoon yesterday the stock market showed slight gain. Then traders began to talk of the bleak outlook for steel and steel users and prices fell until the close. There was a moderate net loss on the day.

DETROIT, Nov. 2 -- United States automobile manufacturers built 507,590 cars in October. This figure was substantially above that for October of 1958, when 261,701 cars were built. Every maker increased his production, but the big gainer was General Motors, which jumped from 56,773 cars in October, 1958, to 224,162 last month.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 2 -- The United States has concluded a barter deal by which it will get $6,000,000 of Haitian bauxite, basic material for aluminum, for its strategic minerals stock-pile. It will give in exchange an equivalent value in surplus wheat.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 12,010 pints of blood from donors during October. It received 11,196 pints in September of this year and 13,565 in October, 1958.

THE size of New York's guitar audience was demonstrated afresh last night when almost 800 persons assembled at Town Hall for the New York debut of Alirio Diaz, a guitarist from Venezuela who has had very little advance fanfare here.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 2 -- Israel will admit some 200 Bedouin refugees from Jordan, according to an agreement signed in Jerusalem today by representatives of the two Governments.

Potato futures climbed 6 to 20 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The sharp advance pushed the March, April and May positions to new highs for the life of the contracts. The volume was 1.761 cash lots (50,000 pounds to a car), the sixth largest of the year.
Many persons of prominence are planning to attend the theatre party at the Nov. 19 performance of "Take Me Along" at the Shubert Theatre for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club.
Net income of the National Dairy Products Corporation if the three months ended on Sept. 30 rose to $11,394,001 from $11,110,102 in the 1958 period, E. E. Stewart, chairman, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Two former contestants told a Congressional hearing today that the television quiz show "The $64,000 Challenge" had been fixed.
Voters in New York City have three main interests in today's election: The school bond referendum, the choice of a Borough President in Queens and the filling of judicial vacancies in Manhattan.
The American Communist party is beginning to feel some benefits from Premier Khrushchev's visit here and from recent Soviet space achievements, the party's leadership declares.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 2 -- A newspaper that often reflects the views of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer spoke out sharply against Britain today, just two weeks before he is to open talks with Prime Minister Harold Macmillan on British-West German relations.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Bitter controversy flared in Pacific Coast football today after Coach Pete Elliott of California charged a Southern California guard, Mike McKeever, deliberately fouled a California halfback.

Steel production in mills not affected by the strke continued for the second straight period last week at the highest level since the walkout began on July 15, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

OTTAWA, Nov. 2 (Canadian Press) -- The Government today brought the National Energy Board Act into force and at the same time outlined the requirements that must be met before export of natural gas and electricity and import of gas will be permitted.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Leon Keyserling, in his letter which you published Oct. 2, questioned my statement that the United States' rate of economic growth substantially exceeded that of Soviet Russia. In the first place, he questions my figure of 3 1/2 per cent per annum for the average rate of growth of the United States' real national product.

First Landing will be shooting for the big money again today. Christopher T. Chenery's colt, who was the big winner among the 2-year-olds last year with record earnings of $396,460, will try to get back to his old form in the Roamer Handicap at Aqueduct.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 -- Members of the Writers Guild of America will meet here tomorrow night to consider a strike vote against major movie studios.
Cities Service Company reported yesterday declines in gross operating income for three and nine months ended on Sept. 30.
Charley Conerly, passing ace of the Giants, has a twisted ankle and it is not known whether he will be available for Sunday's game with the Chicago Cardinals at the Stadium.
MADISON, Wisc., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire charged today that Lyndon B. Johnson and other Southerners had reduced the North's influence in the Senate to "second-class status."
DENVER, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Federal trial of eleven members of the International Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union opened today.

Scientists of the Army Signal Corps at Fort Monmouth, N. J., have discovered that two shells of energy, not just one, were thrown up around the earth by the detonation last year of atomic bombs high over the South Atlantic.
Bowlers may get a more equitable set of conditions from one establishment to another and from lane to lane if a new machine works out as expected.
Leading contenders for the championship of the East, the Ivy League and the Big Ten will meet this week as the college football season heads into its final month.

WHEN Vincent Richards was only 15 years old, he paired with Bill Tilden to win the national doubles championship in tennis and he never quite lost the label of boy wonder even when his blond hair turned gray. Vinnie was a popular figure along the sports scene over the decades and it just doesn't seem right that his passing be unmarked by the farewell he deserved.
LEVITTOWN, Pa., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Carl Sandburg today dedicated a school in this city of 70,000, which is only seven years old. The school is named after the 82-year-old poet.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Following is the official transcript of the testimony of Charles Van Doren today before the Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight of the House of Representatives:
Your Oct. 29 editorial "Judicial Candidates: I" does an injustice which I wish to set right.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Randolph Churchill said tonight that the "never twigged" (guessed) that the television quiz show on which he made a short and calamitous appearance in the United States was rigged.
HAVANA, Nov. 2 -- The Cuban Government has tightened its grip on foreign-controlled agricultural and mineral lands by seizing nearly 75,000 acres in Oriente Province, official sources said today.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Members of the International Typographical Union have voted to move the union's headquarters from Indianapolis to Colorado Springs, Colo., a spokesman said today.
TRENTON, Nov. 2 -- The New Jersey election campaign ended tonight with eleventh-hour appeals by candidates for voter support. Light to moderate balloting is expected tomorrow.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Battle lines were drawn today as union leaders attacked railroad proposals for work-rule changes that would permit management to trim payrolls.

St. Luke's parish hall at 487 Hudson Street will be transformed into a Greenwich Village Street of 1820 for the annual fair and bazaar on Friday and Saturday. Scenery, costumes and games will be keyed to the social life of the period for the event which will be a benefit for the school scholarship fund.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 2 -- Another agreement under which India will help bring remote and primitive Bhutan into the twentieth century was announced today.

DARJEELING, India, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The Indian Army is strengthening its defense system along the Chinese frontier, including areas forbidden" by the Peiping Government. The move injects a new seriousness into the tense situation.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The first seventy-two miles of Britain's "no-limit" London-to-Birmingham superhighway M-1 was opened to the public today.

SALEM, N. H., Nov. 2 -There's a get-rich-quick betting operation at Rockingham Park that New England harness racing fans are finding hard to resist. It's an intriguing piece of business known as Pic Six.

WASHINGTON Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Indian Claims Commission was asked today to put an 1832 valuation of at least $1.25 an acre on nearly 4,000,000 acres that Wisconsin Indians contend was taken from them by the Federal Government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Federal mediators took charge of the steel dispute again today, but after a futile day they recessed meetings until Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A three-year program of promoting research in the field of the interaction of heart and brain systems was started here today.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The controversial Pupil Placement Board, threatened with a contempt citation in Federal court, agreed today to the assignment of four Negroes to previously white schools here.
New York City representatives flew to Paris last night to press their bid to hold a World's Fair here in 1964.

American Export Lines reached a tentative agreement yesterday with the American Banner Lines, Inc., for the purchase of the 18,100-ton Atlantic, the United States' main entry in the North Atlantic tourist-class trade.
The city sold the land for two slum clearance projects yesterday to a developer who has engaged an architect blacklisted by the city from such projects.

Chile received the largest grant awarded by the Rockefeller Foundation in the third quarter of this year. The Ministry of Agriculture was given $400,000 of the $1,556,082 in awards announced yesterday by Dean Rusk, the foundation's president.
As part of a city plan to bring more sporting events to New York, efforts will be made to induce United States Military Academy officials to shift a 1960 Army football game to Yankee Stadium.
A Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice condemned the practice of sending senile aged persons to mental institutions as "scandalous" and "pernicious" yesterday.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- An F-104 Starfighter jet crashed in a red brick house in a Dayton suburb today. A 12-year-old girl getting ready to go to school and her sister, 2, were killed and their mother critically burned.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- President Eisenhower will visit Italy in December for meetings with President Giovanni Gronchi and Premier Antonio Segni, reliable sources said today.

WHAT would happen if we applied the critical standards of avant-garde painting to avant-garde writing? We should find, I think, that these two arts are engaged in a curiously contradictory contest to reflect the spirit of the modern world. No wonder the public at large is occasionally bewildered.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- The Political Committee of the General Assembly gave its unanimous endorsement today to a resolution referring proposals for disarmament to a ten-nation disarmament group that will meet in Geneva early next year.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 -Senator John F. Kennedy said today that the United States should continue its suspension of nuclear tests indefinitely as long as the Soviet Union complied.
Many landlords and tenants in Greenwich Village have been indifferent to a campaign to rehabilitate old Brownstone and tenement buildings there, the Greenwich Village Association reported yesterday.

The steel strike dragged past another gloomy milestone yesterday. The completion of its 111th day meant that it had now run more than twice as long as any previous national shutdown in the industry's turbulent history.

When Charles Van Doren first heard cries of fix about the television quiz show on which he had won $129,000, he declared, "It's enough to shake your faith in human nature." That was fifteen months ago, in August, 1958.

At dawn three years ago today Premier Imre Nagy of Hungary notified the world that Soviet troops were attacking his country "with the obvious intent of overthrowing the legal democratic Hungarian Government." A few hours later the official radio went off the air with cries of "Help, help" and S O S signals. Fighting continued for several days, but flesh and blood were no match for Soviet tanks and might triumphed over right.
President Sekou Toure of the new African republic of Guinea said last night that his country's independence was of significance to colored people everywhere.

THE oldest player among the forty-eight Americans, Britons and Canadians who will tee off in the senior international golf tournament at the Pine Valley Club tomorrow is an 81-year-old barrister who finds an ancient Latin law text no trap at all.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 3 -- A proposal that West Germany be permitted to build large destroyers and acoustic mines is under consideration at Allied Supreme Headquarters in Paris.

The seventieth National Horse Show began in Madison Square Garden yesterday with the pageantry, the glitter of social graces, the hot fire of equine competition and victory for some. It was an old tale and a new one, differing from others mainly in those who climbed to the peaks.

CINCINNATI, Nov 3 (AP) -- The Methodist Conference on Christian Education was told tonight that in the next twenty years the church must conduct the greatest building program for education facilities in its history.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that a Pan American World Airways jet airliner fell 29,000 feet toward the Atlantic Ocean Feb. 3 because of the co-pilot's lack of attention.

THE Irish Players appear to have a special place in their hearts for Paul Vincent Carroll's distinguished play, "Shadow and Substance." Several years ago they played it with distinction at an off-Broadway temple on East Fourteenth Street. Last night they moved a bit uptown to Madison Avenue and Thirtieth Street, at the Tara Theatre, to be specific, and played it again with an equal amount of distinction plus fervor.
BOSTON, Nov. 3 -- John F. Collins, Register of Probate for Suffolk County, scored a surprise victory today over John E. Powers, President of the State Senate, to be elected Mayor of Boston.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- A television producer testified today that a sponsor had dictated the rigging of two quiz shows.
Democratic candidates captured both seats on the Court of General Sessions that were at stake in yesterday's election.
PARIS, Nov. 3 -- A delegation from New York City sought at least informal international backing today for the projected 1964 world's fair.
Charles Van Doren was dropped yesterday from his $50,000-a-year job with the National Broadcasting Company.
The defeat of the proposed $500,000,000 school bond amendment was hailed by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa last night as "a great victory for the people."
BALBOA, C. Z., Nov. 3 The five manufacturing concerns that submitted bids to supply new electric towing locomotives for Panama Canal locks were notified today that their offers had been rejected.

In a recent twelve-month period more than 42,000,000 visits were made by G. I. 's to the 267 clubs and lounges of the United Service Organizations in all parts of the world for drinks, tickets to theatres counseling, snacks, soft and sporting events.

HARTFORD, Nov. 3 -- Former Mayor Edward D. Bergin, a Democrat, made an election comeback in Waterbury today by recapturing the mayoralty from the man who defeated him two years ago, Mayor Raymond E. Snyder, a Republican.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Business inventories dropped another 350 million dollars in September to an estimated $88,200,000,000.

Maria Callas, the prima donna whose name has made the headlines several times, is the subject of an intimate biography by her mother, Mme. Evangelia Callas. Tentatively titled "My Daughter, Maria Callas," the book has been scheduled for spring publication by the Fleet Publishing Corporation.

TOMS RIVER, N. J., Nov. 3 -- A major expansion of the Ocean County jail here was recommended today. The present building, erected in 1924, was the scene of a fire in which eight prisoners died last August.
Shepard Traube, president of the recently organized Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers, declared in an interview yesterday that Broadway directors were undervalued and underpaid.

Edwin L. Dale Jr., in your Oct. 20 issue, described under the heading "Broader Relief for Needy" a proposal now being considered by the Administration for possible inclusion in President Eisenhower's legislative program for next year.

Howard Aibel made his debut yesterday afternoon in Town Hall under the auspices of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation. The young New York pianist played four works -- Bach's Prelude and Fugue in B flat minor from the first book of the "Well-Tempered Clavier," Beethoven's "Waldstein" Sonata, the Barber Piano Sonata and Schumann's "Carnaval."
The Federal Maritime Board will investigate the relations between travel agencies and the Trans-Atlantic Passenger Steamship Conference.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 3 -- Three men, one of them a patrolman for nineteen years, were released on $10,000 bail each today on charges of operating a numbers lottery racket with an estimated gross of one million dollars a year. The three will face a Hudson County grand jury.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused two large baking companies of giving discriminatory price discounts to large food chains and other favored customers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- President Eisenhower laid the cornerstone of the new Central Intelligence Agency building today, dedicating it to the "undecorated and unsung heroes" of the intelligence forces at home and abroad.

A PACKAGE from home, especially if it holds something good to eat, is always welcomed by youngsters away at college. Brownies, which travel and keep well, are one good choice. Frosted with a rich chocolate icing, they are sure to make a hit on campus.
A new union organization representing men who work on floating dredges operating east of the Continental Divide is negotiating a contract with major employers in the industry.
MOSCOW, Nov. 3 -- The tradition-minded may not approve, but Russians seemed to be enjoying their newspapers today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Supreme Court began considering the steel case late today, after it had heard four hours of argument for the United Steelworkers of America and the Government.
The 18,100-ton Atlantic yesterday ended her brief career as the only United States tourist -class liner on the North Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Democrats are planning two $100-a-plate Washington dinners for next year, one to help finance the Presidential campaign and the other to help in the Congressional campaigns.

MADRID, Oct. 31 -- The minority of Spanish Cabinet ministers who are defending the new economic stabilization program begun here last summer see the country's present trade doldrums as the first fruits of new "stability."

Fashion trends for spring are taking shape as Seventh Avenue designers present collections, the American equivalent of the Paris openings. The New York Times has been barred from some showings because of its policy to report trends immediately. Reports on those showings are based on information from other fashion authorities. Most of the clothes will be in stores by January.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 3 -- Accidents have been reduced by center barriers on the hazardous Cross County Parkway between Pelham and Yonkers, but Westchester highway engineers were in disagreement today over the types of barriers to use in the future.

PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Nov. 3 -- Rampant nationalism and inflation are issues in the state-wide election here in Rio Grande do Sul next Sunday. They are issues that hold significance for Brazil's Presidential contest next October.

NEWARK, Nov. 3 -- Newark voters today rejected a referendum that would have given most city employes, including policemen and firemen, a 15 per cent pay increase. The vote was 21,700 for and 46,633 against.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Janacek's "Jenufa," a work that had an abortive whirl at the Metropolitan Opera repertory in the 1924-25 season, was revived by the Lyric Opera last night and turned out to be impressive in its power.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The United Packinghouse Workers of America announced today an immediate strike of 5,400 union workers against Wilson Co. plants in eight cities.
Newspapers across the country commented widely yesterday upon the revelations Monday by Charles Van Doren before the House Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight.
Following is the text of the statement issue yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company in announcing its dismissal of Charles Van Doren:

GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- The Soviet Union announced today its readiness to participate in a new evaluation of the problem of detecting and identifying underground nuclear tests. This seemed to be a major concession to the United States.

The most remarkable overseas installation of the United States is the McMurdo Sound Base on a volcanic island by the shores of frozen Ross Sea. From there we support inland stations right up to the pole. This endeavor represents our national foot in the Antarctic door, kept there until world statesmen can decide how that bleak continent shall be administered.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- The International Atomic Energy Agency soon will re-enact a major nuclear laboratory accident with everything present except Yugoslav technicians injured in the accident. The people Will be replaced by machines, which will measure the extent of the blast and the danger of the radiation.
A shortage of about $7,000 exists in the Department of Welfare Commissioner's Fund Account, city officials said yesterday.

THE International Festival of S. Hurok, which has given us thus far a Spanish and a Philippine program, both at the Winter Garden, moved over to the City Center last night to open a three-week Polish season.
A Civil War monument that has become a traffic hazard in the middle of Hillside Avenue in Jamaica, Queens, will be moved before Jan. 1, Borough President John T. Clancy predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- For a television quiz-show rigger, life in the late Nineteen Fifties was no bed of roses.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- The Democrats gained 4-to-1 control of the Rockland County Board of Supervisors today. The Republicans had had a 3-to-2 margin on the board.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- The United States was said today to be ready to back a resolution by the General Assembly that condemns apartheid, or racial segregation, in South Africa. The resolution contemplates no United Nations sanctions against South Africa.

New York University's Henry (Hank) Levin, running away from all competition in the last mile, retained the title yesterday in the thirty-third annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 3 -- Nassau County Republicans continued their political domination of this county by winning all county and town offices in today's elections.
Blood will be given today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at the Baruch School of Business and Public Administration of City College, 17 Lexington Avenue.

Too much often is made of statistics in football. First downs and yards gained don't mean a great deal unless a team has the something extra it takes to register its superiority on the scoreboard. In that case, statistics have real validity.
OMAHA, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Missouri River navigation season closed officially at Omaha today with a record of 800,000 tons moved.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- One of the most unusual conferences in the history of diplomacy has progressed to the point where a treaty on Antarctica may be signed here late next week.
Among the big winners in yesterday's election were the city's department and specialty stores. Volume was up 5 to 10 per cent over the 1958 level.

DETROIT, Nov. 3 (AP) -- American Motors today announced plans to increase production of car bodies by 35 per cent within the next seven months by leasing and converting the Simmons steel furniture plant in Kenosha, Wis.

TOWNSHIP 28, Hancock County, Me., Nov. 3 -- Everybody sits around Bob Kirkpatrick's camp here on Upper Lead Mountain Pond in the evening and whines about that deer Philip Nile killed in the town of Strong a few days ago. That deer had eight antlers and weighed 274 pounds field-dressed.

TORONTO, Nov. 3 (Canadian Press) -- An issue of $24,357,000 of 6 per cent installment and sinking fund debentures of the Municipality of Metropolitan Toronto is being offered by a group of investment dealers headed by Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd., Dominion Securities Corporation, Ltd., A. E. Ames Co., Ltd., and McLeod, Young, Weir Co., Ltd.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The United States put Cuban refugees on notice today that it would not tolerate attempts to set up a "government in exile" in this country.
The proposed $500,000,000 school bond amendment went down to defeat in yesterday's election, swamped by a heavy adverse vote in New York City.
The story of "Operation Handclasp" in this column on Oct. 15 is another heartening example of the help a local community can give to its troubled youth when it works together toward that common goal.
Dr. Henry T. Heald, president of the Ford Foundation, charged yesterday that educators were ignoring modern progress made in teaching and teacher training.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower has selected Allan Boyd, a Democrat of Miami, to fill a vacancy on the Civil Aeronautics Board. A White House announcement was expected soon.
Beveridge Webster, pianist, appeared at Town Hall last night. It was the first of three recitals that he will play there under the auspices of Town Hall and the Friedberg Management.
CHICAGO. Nov. 3 (AP) -- The report of today s livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A general, an admiral who served in the Boer War, a legal antiquary and assorted bankers, brokers, lawyers and business men converged on the Yale Club from three nations yesterday with golf in mind.

THE annual "Cooks' Tour" of New York homes, for seven years restricted to the kitchen, this year will encompass the entire apartment or house. Organized for the benefit of the Yorkville Youth Council and Parents League, the tour will take place on Tuesday, Nov. 17, and Wednesday, Nov. 18, from 1 to 4:30 p.m.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- The largest football crowd to see Pennsylvania play at Franklin Field since the Notre Dame game of 1955, 32,000, is expected here Saturday for the all-important Ivy meeting with Yale.

ENCOUNTERED not very long ago was Charley Grimm, the new manager of the Chicago Cubs. By a quirk of circumstances, he also happens to be the old manager of the Cubs, not once but twice. He served one sentence from 1932 to 1938 and then was paroled until 1944 when he was grabbed again. Five years later he escaped. Now he's been nabbed once more.

A chief steward of the American President Lines and a couple from Hong Kong were taken into custody yesterday on charges of smuggling $84,000 worth of gold into this country in violation of the Gold Reserve Act.
A stalled New Haven Railroad train made a New York Central train forty-six minutes late in arriving at Grand Central Terminal yesterday from Brewster, N. Y., where it had left at 7:58 A. M.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 - Mayor Richardson Dilworth was re-elected to a second four-year term today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Soybean futures forged ahead today and approached their high levels of the season on gains running to 1 5/8 cents a bushel.

CAIRO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The United Arab Republic will pay the Sudan 15,000,000 Egyptian pounds (about $43,200,000) for Sudanese lands in the Wadi Halfa area that will be flooded by the Aswan High Dam, the newspaper Al Ahram reported today.
HAVANA, Nov. 3 -- The United States manager of the ranch El Indio in Camaguey Province described today how it was seized by agents of the Agrarian Reform Institute late yesterday.
Democrats won large majorities yesterday in the balloting for District Attorney in Bronx and Richmond counties.
TOKYO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- European trade officials opened secret talks today on possible extension of intra-European trade concessions to the rest of the world.
Both Republicans and Democrats found cause for rejoicing and reason for regret in New York State's municipal elections yesterday.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Wednesday, Nov. 4 -- Suffolk County voters delivered an unexpected and shattering blow to the powerful Republican organization here yesterday.

Shipyards on the Continent and in the United Kingdom "have caught up" with Japanese competitors in offering favorable contract terms for new building, Harley, Mullion Co., British shipbrokers, reported this week.
New Jersey Democrats failed in their effort to capture control of the State Senate in yesterday's election, and their margin in the Assembly was cut by at least six seats.

LUANG PRABANG, Laos, Nov. 3 (AP) -- French military authorities here have complained officially that United States instructors have been overstepping their duties in training Laotian soldiers, an authoritative military source reports.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 3 -- A proposal to establish a metropolitan district for St. Louis and St. Louis County was defeated by a 2 1/3-to-1 margin in a special election today.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 3 -- Work is about to begin on laying the deepest telephone cable in the world. It will link the United States and Puerto Rico. The cable ship, HMTS Monarch, is scheduled to leave San Juan today for West Palm Beach, Fla. The cable will run between those two points, a distance of 1,250 miles.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 3 -- A year ago the New York Knickerbockers started the season by losing at home, then took to the road and whipped up an eight-game winning streak. This was important in getting the Knicks to the play-offs in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association last season.
THE case of Charles Van Doren is bound to be discussed for a long time. The educated young man inevitably is going to pay a high price for his sordid participation in the rigged game of "Twenty-One."

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 3 -- The president of the National Association of Frozen Food Packers predicted today that "in the next three to four years, total frozen food production should be between eight-and-a-half and nine billion pounds, an increase of one-and-a-half to two billion pounds."
The Girls Club of New York will benefit from the twenty-fifth season of the Avery Lectures, which will open tomorrow morning in the ballroom of the Cosmopolitan Club, 129 East Sixty-fifth Street.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon was back with the home folks today, quietly non-campaigning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Two programs to bring new medical discoveries more quickly to the people have been announced by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- Maj. Gen. Barksdale Hamlett, United States commandant in West Berlin, has called on his Soviet counterpart to inform him of the Western Allies' determination not to tolerate the flying of the new East German Communist flag in West Berlin, it was disclosed today.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The president-elect of the American Dental Association said today that his organization was urging the Federal Government to curb the "reckless claims" of many of the major dentifrice makers.
If the Election Day odds on Aqueduct's big board yesterday could be construed as a vote of confidence in William Shoemaker, the 46,595 voters present certainly chose him as their leader.
Pee Wee Reese is expected to become a television baseball commentator for the Columbia Broadcasting System, thus ending a twenty-year career as a player and coach.

As Arthur Krock says in his Oct. 29 column: "The area [Western Europe] is now selling us more than it is buying from us * * *." But this may be due in part to the sales efforts of Western European exporters in the United States market -- which seem to be more aggressive than our own selling efforts to importers in Europe.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 3 -- Dade County voters defeated today five proposed amendments to the metro home rule charter.
A group of sixty-five educators returning yesterday from a three-week tour of the Soviet Union was said to have found the educational system there as regimented as other phases of life.

MADRID, Nov. a (Reuters) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco reviewed the achievements of his twenty-year-old regime today and indicated that he had every intention of remaining in power for a long time.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 3 -- The Republicans rolled up heavy pluralities in Westchester today to retain control of the county government for the fiftieth consecutive year.

Negotiations for a new milk contract were recessed at 11 o'clock last night with both sides reporting progress toward an agreement covering 13,000 milk processors and deliverers in the metropolitan area.
The voters approved the barge canal amendment to the state constitution yesterday by an indicated majority of more than 200,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The United States will sell Poland 200,000 tons of fodder grains as long-term help in overcoming her drastic meat shortage.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 3 -- The Government declared today that the United States should halt what it said were plots being carried on in the United States against the regime of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Wednesday, Nov. 4 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion's Mapai party took a substantial early lead this morning in Israel's parliamentary elections.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A new offer to buy the Boston and Providence Railroad Corporation was made today by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company. The offer is $16,500,000 in bonds.

Stellar performances in upset victories last Saturday earned back-of-the-week honors for two Ivy League athletes yesterday. League officials were unable to choose between Chet Boulris of Harvard and Bill Grundy of Dartmouth.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- A Federal judge today dismissed a suit charging improper White House influence on the Interstate Commerce Commission in the 1954 fight for control of the New York Central Railroad Company.
ALL that glitters on a motion-picture screen is not merely entertaining. A picture, to be truly "moving," is also educational and even cultural.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Democratic Mayor Anthony Celebrezze easily won a fourth term as Mayor of Cleveland today but Republicans replaced Democratic mayors in a number of cities.

BELLEVILLE, N. J., Nov. 3 -- A funeral service will be held here Saturday at 2 P. M. in the Fewsmith Presbyterian Church for John Hunter Armstrong, a 27-year-old linguist whose body was found last week in the Nubian desert of Egypt.

TORONTO, Nov. 3 -- Lows inspired by bureaucrats have made union members second-class citizens in the United States, Elmer Brown, president of the International Typographical Union, warned here today. He said that legislators would soon try to regulate and control management.
A Roman Catholic nun who has devoted the last twenty-two years to caring for cancer patients was named the Catholic Woman of Achievement for 1959 last night.

Variety Clubs International announced yesterday the names of six journalists appointed to its humanitarian award committee to serve with representatives of educational, medical and religious institutions in selecting next year's award winner.
Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens staged a surprising runaway victory in a three-way race yesterday to keep his office for two more years.
The opening of the seventy-second National Horse Show brought some of the glamour and sparkle of the fashionable East Side to Eighth Avenue last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- President Eisenhower will visit six countries in Europe, the Middle East and Asia before the four-power Western summit meeting in Paris next month, informed sources said tonight.

In the latest month for which figures are available, September, consumer prices as measured by the monthly index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics advanced four-tenths of a point, or slightly more than three-tenths of 1 per cent from their August level, to 125.2 (using the three-year period 1947-49 as 100).

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 3 -- Jasper McLevy, 81-year-old Socialist candidate here, failed in a comeback attempt today, ingly for Mayor by Samuel J. Tedesco, the 42-year-old Democratic incumbent, 29,567 votes to 14,479, a margin of 15,088.
LANSING, Mich., Nov. 3 (UPI) -- A Republican Senator proposed a temporary state income tax today as a solution to Michigan's financial crisis, but other G. O. P. legislators quickly rejected it.
New York voters, downstate and upstate, approved yesterday an amendment to the State Constitution to permit the Albany-to-Canada Northway to cut through seven miles of the Adirondack Forest Preserve.

Net income of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing (3M) Company in the third quarter of 1959 was $15,145,895, equal to 89 cents a share. This compared with $11,991,415, or 71 cents a share, in the 1958 period. Sales came to $112,377,309, against $95,104,809 a year ago. Sales in the third quarter of this year were described as the largest for any quarter in the company's history.

BOMBAY, India, Nov. 3 -- A spokesman for Air India International said today that the line was "very happy" to obtain White House approval of its request to start service between India and New York by way of London.
New Jersey voters crowded the polls yesterday to trounce a transit proposal that had been backed to the hilt by Gov. Robert B. Meyner.

ALTAMONT, Tenn., Nov. 3 -- The State of Tennessee will seek to close permanently the racially integrated Highlander Folk School by asking the courts to revoke the school's twenty-five-year-old charter.
A five-alarm fire destroyed a rubber factory in Long Island City, Queens, last night. No injuries were reported.

WITH sufficient knowledge, perseverance and luck, one might be able to assemble a bad Cezanne show. However, the people at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, have taken the easy way out and assembled a good one.
LOUISVILLE. Ky., Nov. 3 -- Bert T. Combs, Democrat, won Kentucky's Governorship by a landslide today. The election had implications for the 1960 Presidential contest.
Many quiz stars who won fortunes in television's isolation booths insisted yesterday that they had won honest dollars and had worked hard to win them, an Associated Press survey showed.

RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 3 -- Premier Abdallah Ibrahim returned tonight from a month's visit to the United States. He expressed satisfaction at the "clarification" achieved in Washington on the question of United States air bases here.

There is an Australian legend concerning the brown snake, which, when teased, seizes its tail and devours itself. Though a bit far-fetched this story seems to be applicable to present-day conduct of Sports Car Club of America racing.
PANAMA, Nov. 3 -- Repeated mob attempts to invade the Canal Zone were broken up this morning by Canal Zone policemen using clubs, tear gas and high-pressure hoses.

The program notes of the Philadelphia Orchestra's concert at Carnegie Hall last night were headed "Second Program." Nevertheless it was the orchestra's first New York appearance of the season. The explanation is that a strike of the orchestra prevented the ensemble from getting here for its "first program" on Oct. 6.
HAMBURG, Germany, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Pan American World Airways wrote another entry today in its list of troubles over the flight of Boeing 707 jet airliners to Germany.

A telephone answering association whose member companies handle 90 per cent of such service in the city was charged in Supreme Court yesterday with illegal price fixing and other monopolistic practices.
The New York Public Library has taken title to the six-story building at 521-31 West Forty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Supreme Court Chamber is still the most magnificent public the room with the most miserable acoustics hereabouts.

The one - story industrial building containing 20,000 square feet of floor space at Plant Road and Railroad Avenue, Hasbrouck Heights, N. J., has been purchased by the Berliner Motor Corporation, formerly of New York. The Rothman Realty Corporation of Englewood was the broker.
When the oil industry celebrated its centennial not long ago one of the picturesque events was a parade of antique automobiles down Fifth Avenue from Sixtieth Street to Rockefeller Center.

A three-year moratorium in changes in working rules that govern more than 800,000 workers on the nation's railroads ended last week and the issues between the unions and the railroads that employ them are now joined. For months the Association of American Railroads has been telling the public of labor "featherbedding" which they charge involves an unnecessary expense of $500 million a year.

Now that Louis Malle's "The Lovers" has settled down to what looks like a long and respectable run at the Paris Theatre, the French film industry can justifiably reassert its traditional claim as the world's leading exponent of explosive sex on the screen.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Princess Alexandra launched today the 40,000-ton Oriana, which is to enter the Orient Lines service to Australia late next year.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 3 (Reuters) -- Belgium announced today plans for conferences later this month with political leaders of its violence-ridden Congo colony.

Yesterday's election proved, before the polls ever opened, what every election has proved in New York State when constitutional amendments and judges for our courts were to be voted on. This is that a new, rewritten Constitution is gravely needed, and secondly that judges should be appointed rather than elected.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 3 -- Bergen County maintained tradition today by keeping its all-Republican Assembly delegation and its all-Republican Board of Freeholders.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- The General Assembly failed again today to break the deadlock over the choice between Poland and Turkey for a seat on the Security Council.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The United States expects within the next decade to achieve economic atomic power and to send a nuclear-powered rocket deep into interplanetary space.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Derick Heathcoat Amory, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced tonight that Britain would remove import restrictions on many goods from the United States and other countries.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Norman Mercier; a 28-year-old Pawtucket jockey, today was suspended for the remainder of the Narragansett Park meeting and two other jockeys were fined $100 each for infractions of racing rules during yesterday's opening-day card.
A Transit Authority worker was killed early yesterday when a broken water main on the lower East Side disrupted service on the BMT Broadway - Jamaica subway line between Manhattan and Brooklyn.

THE use of a jump five no-trump bid as a "grand-slam force," which was first proposed by the late Ely Culbertson in 1937, has lately won a respectable following among leading players, although as far as most bridge players are concerned it is still almost an unknown bid.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 3 -- (UPI) -- Mississippi Democrats tonight crushed a Republican effort to elect a man to the State Legislature for the first time since reconstruction days.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was told today that replacing 1960 and 1961 maturities of the Boston Maine Railroad with short-term bonds was the only alternative to bankruptcy for the railroad.

"AN executive," said H. S. M. Burns, "is a guy with ulcers. Work doesn't do it -- he can delegate that. It's over-worry, not overwork." This definition may not be either precise or comprehensive, but it is authoritative. Mr. Burns acquired his own ulcer worrying about his job as president of the Shell Oil Company.

ONE of the most widely discussed of London's restaurants has a Polish host and a French kitchen. The Mirabelle, a fashionable establishment in Mayfair, combines English table service with French cuisine and the result is altogether admirable.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- The University of Southern California officially apologized tonight "to the extent we are responsible" for injuries suffered by a California halfback, Steve Bates, when in contact with a Trojan guard, Mike McKeever, in last Saturday's game.
Family life in old Wyoming, about 140 million years ago, is recreated in the dinosaur halls on the fourth floor of the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street.

KENT, Conn., Nov. 3 -- Jack Sapoch, Kent's new head football coach, said today that he was the most puzzled man on the school's campus. He said that he couldn't understand how his team lost to Hotchkiss last Saturday by the one-sided score of 22 -- 0.

At the polls on Amsterdam Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street yesterday the Democrats got only one vote -- but scored a landslide victory. Only one man voted in the entire district. And he had to be bodily escorted to the polls by a Democratic captain. 295 had already moved. Nonetheless, promptly at 6 A. M.[ yesterday a pliceman and four lady election workers were seated near the voting machine] Iwith their records out, hooks[ [

Eight five-story apartment houses at 404 to 420 East Seventy-second Street, 113 feet east of First Avenue, have been purchased by the 404 East Seventy-second Street Corporation, representing Philip Lipstein and Bernard Gordon.
The Long Island Rail Road warned last night that it would have to raise fares if its 1,500 unionized trainmen won their demand for a five-day work week, higher wages and other concessions.

Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced yesterday that consolidated net earnings for the first nine months of this year were $106,189,113, or $2.97 a share. This compared with a net income of $86,449,-150, or $2.42 a share, in the 1958 period.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Democrats swept every major city in today's mayoral elections, leaving only a handful of scattered communities across Indiana in Republican hands.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 3 -- Virginia Democrats won at least three major contests for the Legislature today but were trailing in a fourth in a election marked by few contests.

Three weeks ago the United Nations General Assembly elected Ecuador and Ceylon for two-year terms on the Security Council. The Assembly then deadlocked in attempting to choose the third non-permanent member slated to go on the Council next January. The required two-thirds majority is 54. Poland, with Russia's backing, rolled up 48 votes.
A marketing reorganization at Mars, Inc., has resulted in the dropping of Knox Reeves Advertising, Inc., which had handled the candy maker's $3,000,000 advertising budget.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Nov. 3 -- "What can I, a 9-year-old, do to help promote world peace?" That question was asked by fourth-grade pupils at the Manorhaven elementary school here in letters to statesmen, world leaders, government officials and educators.
NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- Governor Rockefeller and his wife and their son Steven voted at the fire station in the Municipal Building on Beekman Avenue here today.

Joe McGovern and his Fordham Prep team-mates duplicated the sweep they scored in last Saturday's New York Division Catholic High Schools meet by taking top honors yesterday in the thirty-sixth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
PARIS, Nov. 3 -- The French Communist party acknowledged tonight that it had been in error in denouncing President Charles de Gaulle's plan for self-determination in Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Following are textual excerpts of testimony released yesterday that was given at closed sessions to the House Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight by Martin Dowd of New Milford, N. J., on Oct. 8, and by John Ross, business manager of Patty Duke, child actress, yesterday:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- Mayor Richardson Dilworth accepted his re-election victory over Harold E. Stassen, Republican, today as a mandate to complete the revitalization program that had brought Philadelphia national recognition.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 4 -The Big Three football round-robin starts Saturday with the Princeton-Harvard game at Cambridge.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The United States hopes shortly to give its weather men a global perspective by placing a pair of cloud-scanning television cameras in orbit.

FROM California, which produces 90 per cent of this country's walnut crop, comes the heartening word that supplies are excellent this year. Slightly below last year's record-breaking harvest, the current output of about 63,000 tons is great enough to assure enough walnuts for all sorts of delectable uses.

Billy Cannon's 89-yard return of a punt that enabled Louisiana State to gain a 7-3 triumph over Mississippi last Saturday lifted the fleet-footed halfback to the top among the major college football punt-return leaders.
Timken Roller Bearing Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 60 cents and an extra of 30 cents on the common stock, payable on Dec. 10.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 4 -- The bitterness felt by some whites in Kenya over African progress received a fresh airing here last night.
Nuclear explosions hold the for greatest promise at present expansion of American energy resources, Dr. Edward Teller, University of California physicist, said yesterday.

The development of a machine said to make possible construction of one-piece, weld-free rocket and missile cases of record size and high strength was announced yesterday by the Pratt Whitney Aircraft division of United Aircraft Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4, (UPI) -- Catholic Bishops of the United States, Canada and Latin America are meeting in private here this week to consider measures for reviving and strengthening the Catholic Church in Latin America.

A chance to look at and learn something about foxhounds developed from the meet that the Goldens Bridge Hounds ran one bright Sunday. The event, involving several New York and Connecticut foxhunting clubs, was on the lands of Carlo M. Paterno and R. Laurence Parish at North Salem, N. Y., in upper Westchester.
The Apalachin trial in Federal Court was adjourned yesterday until today at 10:15 A. M. because a juror was reported ill and unable to attend. She was Mrs. Sylvia Fisk, a medical assistant.
ALBANY, Nov. 4 -- The Democrats emerged from yesterday's mayoral elections still clinging to a majority of the city administrations in communities that hold partisan contests.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 4 -- United States authorities jailed Maj. Pedro Diaz Lanz today on Cuban charges of murder and attempted murder. He is being held pending an extradition hearing.

Avon Products, Inc. i Avon Products, Inc., has vot-! ed a quarterly dividend of 20 cents a share and an extra of 5 cents on the new common, payable on Dec. 1. The dividend is equal to 60 cents on the old shares, recently split three-for-one. Avon had been paying

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 4 -- The banks of Venezuela have agreed to adopt "persuasive measures" in their sales of dollars, Dr. Jose Antonio Mayobre, Minister of Finance, said today. No controls or restrictions on exchange would be imposed by the central bank, the Government institution that sells dollars to the banks, he said.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4, (UPI) -- Evelyn Rudie, 9 years old, who won television fame as the precocious "Eloise," was taken in tow today after a jet-propelled "runaway" from her Hollywood home.
THE American home was a healthier place in which to live in grandmother's time than it is today.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 4 -- Leaders of both major political parties today publicly viewed the results of yesterday's elections in Nassau County with satisfaction.

WHEN the bidding stops at a contract of one in a suit, some bridge players find themselves too bored to play the hand out. In some games there is a gentleman's agreement that such hands will be thrown in unless the one-bid is doubled.
ALBANY, Nov. 4 -- The State Public Works Department announced plans today to proceed immediately with the construction of the Northway along the Adirondack route.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Patty Duke, this season's child star on Broadway, was added today to the list of television quiz contestants who earned large sums for rigged performances. The 12-year-old Patty, according to secret testimony released today, received $32,000 from "The $64,000 Challenge'' for reciting answers given to her only minutes before show time.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The disclosures on television-quiz fixing have dismayed and bewildered President Eisenhower.

A $21,000,000 contract has been signed between two Italian companies and the Neyveli Lignite Corporation Private, Ltd., of India, for the construction of a big urea plant, the Indian company announced yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- James P. Warburg, financier, author and lecturer, charged today that collective bargaining in basic industry had become a ritual in which both parties actually conspired to "fleece the consumer."

The Old Farmer's Almanac for 1960 has hit the newsstands. This issue -the 168th consecutive annual edition -is not much different from its predecessors, except, according to its editors, for "a certain amount of updating."

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Utah Republican leaders face a problem today. Former Gov. J. Bracken Lee, a former Republican who now terms himself an independent, became Mayor of Salt Lake City in last night's municipal election.
All three political parties here took encouragement yesterday from the results of Tuesday's off-year election.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- A Jupiter intermediate range missile was fired 1,500 miles down the Atlantic missile range tonight -- the third launching of a United States ballistic weapon within twenty-two hours.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The rising price of steel in recent years has had a "strongly inflationary'' impact on the entire national economy, according to a Congressional staff report published today.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Stock market prices retreated sharply here today as selling increased and buyers became more selective.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 4 -- The Indians warmly welcomed today the news that President Eisenhower would visit New Delhi next month.

Prices of high-grade debt securities of all kinds were firm yesterday in inactive trading. The session was enlivened mostly by transactions related to the Treasury's $10,895,000,000 refunding, on which subscription books closed yesterday at midnight.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Democrats scored a sweep in Chicago and Cook County elections yesterday, winning six judicial contests and achieving victories for $75,500,000 in bond issues.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Nov. 4 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that the international effort to help refugees during World Refugee Year had brought in only $3,000,000 so far. He said two-thirds of this sum had come from one country -- meaning the United States.
Mrs. Samuel R. Walker, benefit chairman, and her committee have planned two theatre parties to aid the Graham School, the Orphan Asylum Society in the City of New York.
Waterfront employers yesterday rejected union demands for royalty payments on cargo handled in shipping containers, unless the union would agree to reductions in the work force.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Canada is seeking a world-wide survey of atomic fall-out, plus the establishment of a standardized system of analysis, the vice chairman of the Canadian delegation said in a news conference here today.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- A Florida legislative investigating committee has ordered contempt proceedings brought against two Miami Negroes who refused to testify about the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People or furnish membership records of the Miami branch.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller contributed $500 to the Republican National Committee during the third quarter of 1959.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 4 -- The Democratic victory in yesterday's Suffolk County elections "calls for a complete reorganization of the [Republican] party," R. Ford Hughes, the Republican county leader, said today.

The Minneapolis-Moline Company, Hopkins, Minn., has entered the "space age" electronics field, it was announced yesterday. The large construction and agricultural machinery manufacturer has purchased for cash the Hymac Electronics Corporation, Culver City, Calif. The purchase price was not disclosed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The United States, Britain and France have agreed not to ask for Security Council action on the rebellion in Laos pending an on-the-spot study of the situation by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Daniel F. Rice announced today that he is dissolving his big grain brokerage house, Daniel F. Rice Co., so he can be free to work for elimination of "unfair practices'' on the Chicago Board of Trade.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 4 -Gay Yankee, owned by an exYankee ballplayer, Charley Keller of Frederick, Md., scored a one and one-half length victory in the feature trot before 14,649 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
DAVID MONTAGU, a Chicago-born violinist who has played extensively through Europe, made his New York debut last night in Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The appointment of Msgr. Thomas J. Riley, former rector of the Boston Archdiocesan Seminary, as an auxiliary Bishop to Richard Cardinal Cushing was announced today.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Nov. 4 (AP) -- A group of Californians and Canadians has bought control of Tanforan race track for $1,500,000. A track spokesman said today the payment would give the group of four about 30 per cent of the stock in the track, which sold for $5,000,000 last August.

The appointment of Klaus J. Hendricks as general manager for a new South American organization was announced yesterday in an organizational realignment in Latin America by the I. B. M. World Trade Corporation, a subsidiary of the International Business Machines Corporation.

The two-way mobile radio business of the Aria Products Company, Los Angeles, Calif., has been purchased by Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., Clifton, N. J. Avia concentrated on the design and production of rugged, compact and weather-
Gov. Robert B. Meyner sought yesterday to minimize the losses that he and the Democratic party suffered in the New Jersey elections on Tuesday.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Nov. 4 -- The Malayan Government announced today the establishment of two organizations to oppose corruption.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Wendell B. Barnes resigned, today as head of the Small Business Administration, effective Nov. 21.

A plot of land 200 by 100 feet occupying the blockfront on the south side of Allerton Avenue, between Paulding and Hone Avenues, the Bronx, has been assembled by clients of Joseph Howard Katz, lawyer.

In a precedent-shattering expansion of personal diplomacy, President Eisenhower proposes to embark on a strenuous nineteen-day tour to nine countries in three continents next month in the interest of peace, friendship and good-will among nations.

Digging deeply into Ivy League statistics yesterday, Coach Bob Blackman of Dartmouth found some psychological ammunition he hoped would create more respect on the Hanover campus for Columbia's football team.
Proposed cuts in the Federal interstate highway program pose a serious threat to the nation's security, the chairman of the Port of New York Authority warned yesterday.
HONG KONG, Nov. 4 -- Two local Communist Chinese newspapers attacked today the Indonesian Government's plan to take over Chinese stores in rural areas.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The New York Giants and the San Francisco 49ers are proof of the adage that a good defense is the best offense.
The general who commanded the Hungarian revolutionists in 1956 asserted yesterday that a Soviet drive to complete the communization of Hungary, with an accompanying new wave of terror, was impending.
The City Housing Authority filed plans yesterday for the first vest-pocket project to be built under its new program of putting public housing on small, scattered sites.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 4 -- Virginia Democrats, running strongly in the close races, cut Republican legislative strength from 8 to 6 in yesterday's election.

The Taft-Hartley national emergency panaceas have not worked. Instead of the compulsion inherent in many current proposals, reason, education and expertise implemented by public disclosure are suggested.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The first setback of the week down most soybean futures prices moderately today while corn extended its gains despite increased selling pressure.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Following, in unofficial translations, are excerpts from speeches today in the Political Committee by Ahmed Taibi Benhima of Morocco and Jules Moch of France on the question of French nuclear tests in the Sahara:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The development of an antibiotic effective in infant diarrhea was announced here today at the seventh annual Symposium on Antibiotics.
Thirty-five million years ago a small bird, ill or injured, toppled from a branch and into a stream in what is now southwestern Montana.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Dr. Charles L. Critchfield was named today director of the Advanced Research Projects Agency at the Pentagon.

PANAMA, Nov. 4 -- Panama rejected today a United States note of protest over yesterday's nationalist attack on the United States Embassy and presented a counter-protest. The incident marked a new low in Panama-United States relations.
OTTAWA, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's office said today that construction of two passenger-cargo ships for the West Indies Federation would start at an early date.

TOKYO. Nov. 4 (AP) -- Japan Airlines, following two United States carriers, today announced a substantial cut in its freight rates between Japan and North America effective Jan. 1, subject to approval by the Transportation Ministry.
The Beneficial Finance Company reported yesterday that its net income in the first nine months of 1959 rose to $17,053,422 from $16,152,593 in the 1858 period.
TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 4 (AP) -A jet bomber with four men aboard plunged into the Gulf of Mexico during a training exercise today. A helicopter pilot rescued the navigator, but the others were missing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 28:

FRED ASTAIRE conquered last night the problem of trying to follow his prize show of a year ago. His second evening on television could hardly hope to have the novelty and excitement that went with his premiere.

Capt. Jacob F. master of the Israel, was on the stand yesterday in tile third day of the Coast Guard investigation of the collision last Friday between that liner and the cargo ship American Press just north of Liberty Island.

A spectacular record of American-flag participation in one of the nation's essential trade routes has been achieved within the framework of the Merchant Marine Act of 1936, an Anti-trust subcommittee of the House Committee on Judiciary was told yesterday.
President Sekou Toure of Guinea made a strong plea here yesterday for American understanding of Africa's struggle against colonialism.

The movie industry's self-censorship Review Board, which yesterday temporarily reserved judgment on whether to lend its stamp of approval to a racy comedy called "Happy Anniversary," may have another hot potato on its hands.
Sparks from a welder's torch started a four-alarm fire yesterday in a loft building in lower Manhattan that was fought by 100 firemen for three hours. Two men were overcome.
CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Walter Blum booted Outline under the wire a nose before Little General in the featured Bakers Purse at Garden State today. Little General had rallied from last place.
The labor member of the Transit Authority said yesterday that Michael J. Quill did not have an "Irishman's chance" of increasing the authority's labor costs next year by $75,000,000.

"Face the Nation" has canceled a scheduled appearance by Dmitri Shostakovich and Dmitri Kabalevsky, Soviet composers now touring this country. They were to be interviewed Sunday on the Columbia Broadcasting System television and radio program.

Leaders in the installment credit field said yesterday that if tight money conditions persisted in 1960, they would have to be more selective and require larger down payments in financing sales of automobiles and other durable products.
Outside of New York State, voters generally gave their approval to proposed bond issues up for referendum vote in Tuesday's election.

Take it from an ex-soldier: "The U. S. O., by continuing to perform its innumerable services to our men and women in the armed forces, is making a solid contribution to our national security -- the more so because it is a volunteer response in one of our finest traditions; namely, that our nation cares deeply for those who serve its colors."
When President Eisenhower referred in his news conference yesterday to the "Say it ain't so, Joe," anecdote he was recalling baseball's darkest hour.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Representative Charles A. Boyle, 52 years old, was killed early today when his car smashed into an elevated train pillar.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Joey Giardello evened the score with Dick Tiger of Nigeria tonight by winning a unanimous decision in their ten-round middleweight bout. But it was a close one, just as when Tiger outpointed Joey in Chicago five weeks ago.

The British Government has announced another long forward step in its steady progress of recent years toward complete dismantling of the system of trade and currency restrictions that, as in the case of other countries of Western Europe, was forced upon it in the years of World War II and the period of recovery and reconstruction that followed.

Electric power production climbed to 12,978,000,000 kilowatt hours last week from a six-month low of 12,762,000,000 kilowatt hours in the week ended Oct. 24, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This was 5.3 per cent higher than the 1958 level of 12,330,000,000 kilowatt hours.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Drama critics and theatregoers went to a mid-afternoon "opening night" today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The head of the European Atomic Energy Community predicted tonight eventual success for the atomic power program in Western Europe despite a slow start.

A new issue of $25,000,000 of sinking fund debentures of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., was placed on the market yesterday. The securities will bear interest at 5 1/2 per cent and will mature in 1984.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

ALGIERS, Nov. 4 -- Paul Delouvrier, French Delegate General, announced today that the French Government intended to spend the equivalent of $506,600,000 in 1960 for the economic and social development of Algeria, an increase of 38 per cent over the current year.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 4 -- The Westchester County Republican pluralities of 45,000 in yesterday's election caused more wonder than elation in the party today.

Louise Hall Tharp, author of "The Peabody Sisters of Salem," has a new biography scheduled for publication by Little, Brown next Thursday. It is "Adventurous Alliance: The Story of the Agassiz Family of Boston." It tells of Louis Agassiz, the renowned geologist and zoologist, and his wife, Elizabeth, who became the first president of Radcliffe College.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A strike against Wilson Co. by the United Packinghouse Workers of America was officially on today, but the company reported that all its struck plants were operating with reduced crews.

Stockholders in the Motor! Products Corporation voted yesterday to split the company's stock two-for-one and approved the election of Robert Todd Lang as a director and secretary. The split will be the second this year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The State Department will have the last word on whether Major Diaz Lanz will be extradited to Cuba.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Ernie Banks, the Chicago Cubs' hard-hitting infielder who set a major league fielding record for shortstops this season, today was named the National League's most valuable player of 1959.
Three leading banks here announced the appointment of new executives yesterday.

The Belgian Congo and Ruanda Urundi announced yesterday that a $20,000,000 credit had been arranged with a group of nine American banks headed by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York. The credit, to be guaranteed by Belgium, will have maturities of three to five years and will bear interest ranging from 5 1/2 to 5 3/4 per cent.
