Something new has been added to the 1960 gas ovens that should reduce the number of overcooked roasts in the nation.

The rather strenuous evening's work that the pianist Geza Anda cut out for himself at Town Hall last night can be listed briefly -- Haydn's Sonata in F. No. 26, the Brahms F Minor Sonata, Op. 5, and the twenty-four Preludes of Chopin's Opus 28.
The 1960 New March of Dimes national poster child is Mary Beth Pyron, 2 years old, of Florence, Ala., a lovely, laughing girl, who can neither walk nor stand.
IF only Dore Schary would come to the point!

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -The widespread expressions of disgust for the comments on Charles Van Doren's testimony by some members of the House subcommittee are both encouraging and comprehensible. But before the judgment becomes final some consideration should be given to the fact that the comments of these politicians reflect a point of view frequently displayed by their electors.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Eisenhower said today he was disturbed and puzzled by yesterday's anti-United States riots in Panama.
THE pendulum of public opinion has swung and today the housewife rather than the working wife is on the defensive.
American Export Lines announced yesterday the appointment of W. Lyle Bull as executive vice president.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Federal Trade Commission charged today that "camera trickery" was employed in television advertisements of safety plate glass used by General Motors.
Charles J. Bensley, one of the leaders in the Board of Education's fight for the $500,000,000 bond issue, said yesterday that at least fifteen projected schools would not be built next year.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 4 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion's Mapai party has won at least six new seats in Israel's Knesset (Parliament) and polled the largest vote in the state's eleven-year history.

The sordid history of corruption and political malfeasance that has been undergoing a long process of exposure in Suffolk County, ancient stronghold of Republicanism, was sufficient reason for the voters of eastern Long Island to give control of that county's Board of Supervisors to the Democrats for the first time in more than a quarter of a century.

President de Gaulle's insistence that a top level East-West meeting should not take place until next spring is more than a means of asserting France's independence and the revival of her "grandeur" as a great power. It is more than a means of buying time until she can explode an atom bomb to qualify as a member of the nuclear club.

Fashion trends for spring are taking shape as Seventh Avenue designers present collections, the American equivalent of the Paris openings. The New York Times has been barred from some showings because of its policy to report trends immediately.
An Edwardian decor of red, gold and white provided a background in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last night for guests at the Britannia Ball.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Is the Administration going protectionist?

THE season's first "Traviata" at the Metropolitan Opera last night was noteworthy for the quality of its individual singing and the rare refinement of its ensembles. It reflected in every measure the pains that had been taken with a work that could easily be slapped together.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- House investigators raised the question of perjury today after a former executive of Revlon Inc., had sworn he did not know that two nationally televised quiz shows were rigged.
The Women's Medical Association of New York City celebrated its fiftieth anniversary yesterday, recalling the battles women physicians had fought to be able to practice.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Indiana Republicans learned today that they had salvaged only one of the state's twenty-six largest cities from the municipal election wreckage. They won that one because of a Democratic factional fight.

BONN, Nov. 4 -- For the first time in seven years the West German Government will go to the private capital market tomorrow for cash to meet its budget expenses. A 300,000,000 mark [$71.000,000] issue of twelve-year Treasury bonds will be opened for subscription.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Capt. Asbury (Red) Coward, Naval Academy director of athletics, said today the middle football team would play where the most people would pay to watch.

GENEVA, Nov. 4 -- The Soviet nUion, having agreed to a new study on underground nuclear tests, sought today to limit the work of experts in that study. It would be conducted in connection with efforts here to attain a ban on tests of nuclear weapons.
Frankie Abbatemarco, described by the police as "a big policy banker," was killed last night by two masked gunmen in a dimly lit Brooklyn tavern.

Specialties made large but isolated gains in every group except the oils, but stocks on the New York Stock Exchange moved generally downward yesterday. Brokers blamed tax selling and disappointment over the lack of progress being made toward settlement of the steel strike.

ALTAMONT, Tenn., Nov. 4 -- Issues for the jury to decide in the charter revocation proceedings against the Highlander Folk School were narrowed today from nine to two by Circuit Judge Chester C. Chattin as the trial moved into its second day.

TOWNSHIP 28, Hancock County, Me., Nov. 4 -Robert Kiah of Brewer, Me., has two things to brood about at night here in Bob Kirkpatrick's camp on Upper Lead Mountain Pond-3 when somebody slaughters him at cribbage.
Seventy policemen from two Bronx precincts will begin a sixteen-week course in conversational Spanish tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Eisenhower announced today that he would visit nine countries in Europe, the Middle East, Asia and Africa in connection with his trip to Paris for the Dec. 19 meeting of the Western Big Four.

IN two distinct exhibitions at the Este Gallery, 32 East Sixty-fifth Street, the pleasures of drawing are elaborated: twenty ink sketches by the modern French draftsman Andre Dunoyer de Segonzac and twenty drawings by artists working during the French rococo period in the second half of the eighteenth century.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- An invitation to Premier Khrushchev to visit Scandinavia still stands.
The Outlook brightened for Coach Jim Lee Howell yesterday as he prepared the injury-ridden Giants for their National Football League game with the Chicago Cardinals at the Yankee Stadium on Sunday.
LONDON, Nov. 3 (Reuters) -- Herbert Morrison, son of a Cockney policeman and a housemaid, is now Baron Morrison of Lambeth.
"In an age of doubt and anxiety, the poet can take us where the statesman and the commentator cannot venture," Sir Pierson Dixon, British Ambassador to the United Nations, said last night.
LONDON, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, quoted Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today as having said Premier Khrushchev's recent United States tour had immense value.

The latest insiders' list issued by the New York Stock Exchange shows that John C. Udd, a director of the Western Auto Supply Company, sold 40,000 shares in that concern toward the end of September, reducing his holdings to 10,000 shares.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Supreme Court remained silent today on the decision that could determine the course of the 113-day steel strike.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Postal inspectors have smashed an oil-and-gas-lease confidence ring accused of having bilked $200,000 from four elderly western New York residents.

Although there has been much informal talk in agency circles recently about a greater emphasis on the creation of ads and less on "over-all marketing," talk of the latter was more in evidence yesterday.

TORONTO, Nov. 4 -- If the Rangers are to find their way out of the wilderness that is the National Hockey League race, they will have to make their move soon. They skidded again tonight by losing to Toronto at Maple Leaf Gardens, 4 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The United States' gold reserves have been bolstered in the past two months as the International Monetary Fund (World Fund) has sold $300,000,000 of its gold to buy that amount of Treasury bills -- the shortestterm Government security.
The Archbishop of York, second - ranking prelate of the Church of England, said here yesterday that he thought it was "right" to use contraceptives "as part of the Christian fulfillment of marriage."

OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 4 -The smallest weight class in boxing is the biggest thing in Japanese sports this week, with a former Tokyo newsboy given a fair chance to bring the flyweight championship of the world back to this country tomorrow night.
The City Planning Commission yesterday endorsed a novel plan to build a $14,000,000 middle-income housing project over a depressed roadway leading to the George Washington Bridge.

Directors of Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company voted yesterday a three-for-one stock split, a 12 1/2 per cent increase in the cash dividend on the common and a 2 per cent stock dividend on the split shares.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The United States and the Soviet Union started negotiations today on the establishment of a permanent United Nations body to encourage the peaceful uses of outer space.

The voters of New York State have decisively expressed their wishes on the nine proposed constitutional amendments that were before them for ratification in Tuesday's election. Eight of these amendments were approved, among them No. 2, which will permit use, we are sorry to say, of a part of the Adirondack forest preserve as the route for a new superhighway, the Northway.
WARSAW, Nov. 4 -- The case of the Roman Catholic bishop boycotted by the Polish Government caused an international diplomatic incident today in Warsaw.

At a time when the public is much concerned over youth crime in New York it is a pleasure to note and commend the constructive service given by youth-serving agencies to the city's young people. The Young Women's Christian Associations of both New York and Brooklyn offer craft classes, camping, dancing, hobbies and other activities.
BERKELEY, Calif, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Despite an apology from Southern California, the McKeever-Bates football incident is far from closed.

Continued expansion of the motor hotel industry for the next ten years was forecast yesterday at a meeting of motel executives here. The greatest growth, they were told, will take place among new motels containing fifty or more guest units.
The Public Service Commission yesterday denied the application of the Consolidated Edison Company for a temporary increase in the rates charged to large commercial users of electricity.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Yesterday's election in Ohio was just about as barren of future political clues as any election in recent memory.
PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The two opponents of Senator Francois Mitterrand in the case of the allegedly faked assassination attempt against him were ordered placed under arrest today.

The election of Clinton B. Burnett as president and chief operating officer of JohnsManville Corporation, a leading producer of industrial products and building materials, effective on Jan. 1, was announced yesterday.

The Long Island Rail Road, commenting on union demands, notified its passengers yesterday that it would not be "stampeded into any shotgun settlement that will greatly inflate the fares people must pay to ride the railroad."
Several job offers, some firm and one indefinite, yesterday raised the possibility that Charles Van Doren might be able to continue his teaching career.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A military attache at the Czechoslovak Embassy has quit and asked for asylum in the United States.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 4 -- While Mississippi Democrats were busy blocking a Republican from winning the Hinds County Senate post to prevent a wedge for establishment of a two-party system in the state, a long-time Republican leader slipped by in Holmes County to win for coroner and ranger.

HAVANA, Nov. 4 -- A report of finding Maj. Camilo Cienfuegos, chief of staff of the Cuban Army, missing since last Wednesday night on a flight from Camaguey to Havana, has proved false after hours of excitment and intensive search of the Caribbean waters south of Las Villas Province.

KANSASVILLE, Wis., Nov. 4 -- A two-man subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee entered today the controversy over the cancellation of construction on the Bong Air Force Base on the edge of this hamlet of 100 persons.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today he could see no reason for using -- or misusing --military talent to explore the moon.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 4 -- Four persons were indicted today on charges of attempting to bribe a detective and a newspaper reporter in the case of a union official scheduled to stand trial for juke-box racketeering.
In the future voters who are challenged and have to take court action to exercise their right to vote will not be required to pay the $6 filing fee, Supreme Court Justice Jacob Markowitz has ruled.

Having served more than the requisite apprenticeship as an actor and off-Broadway producer for a number of attractions, including "Guests of the Nation," Paul E. Davis feels he is ready for the next step -- entry into the Broadway managerial ranks.
LITTLE ROCK, Nov. 4 -- A third person was convicted today of having participated in the Labor Day bombing at Little Rock. Two others have yet to stand trial.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower reported today that he and Governor Rockefeller of New York had "talked politics all across the board" at the White House. He said they had "found it interesting."
Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz suggested last night that the television networks set up a "conscience fund" to fight juvenile delinquency with the proceeds from rigged quiz shows.
A $290,000 grant to help Americans stationed overseas provide better educational facilities for their children was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.
The American President Lines announced yesterday the establishment of a fellowship for advanced training in physical medicine and rehabilitation for Japanese physicians.
Following is a statement commenting on the defeat of the $500,000,000 school construction bond issue in the Tuesday voting, as issued yesterday by Mayor Wagner through his City Hall office:
ROME, Nov. 4 -- Celebrating the first anniversary of his coronation, Pope John XXIII said today that "praise be to God, the atheist and materialist conceptions of life and history shall not prevail."
Atlanta, Ga., borrowed $8,335,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance airport and other public improvements.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The growth rate of the American economy has shown a strong long-range tendency to return to a consistent upward trend despite fluctuations, according to a "growth reckoner" published today by the staff of the Committee for Economic Development.

It was getting along toward the height of the afternoon at Aqueduct yesterday, and 19,260 fans felt that someone was missing a cue. With five races already spun off, Willie Shoemaker hadn't been to the winner's enclosure even once.
Academic standards are to be tougher and academic rewards higher at Columbia University's School of General Studies, Clifford L. Lord, dean of the school, said yesterday.

MANCHESTER, England, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- A nationally circulated newspaper said today that Governor Rockefeller might endanger East-West relations in campaigning for the Republican Presidential nomination.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Syracuse football fans moaned last September when injuries sidelined the varsity quarterback, Bobby Thomas, and the team's top-ranked end, Dave Baker, for the 1959 season.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Britain will remove on Monday most of her remaining quantitative import controls on goods from the United States, Western Europe and nearly all other countries except Japan and those in the Communist bloc.

CAIRO, Nov. 4 -- According to President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic, if Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq "would just give a sign, the people would follow him" against the Communists.

Canada's team scored its second victory in international jumping at the National Horse Show last night. Before a crowd of 8,000 at Madison Square Garden, the Canadians took the opening event of the Low Score Competition Challenge Trophy.

DETROIT, Nov. 4 -- Coach Fuzzy Levane of the New York Knickerbockers said today, "As long as Kenny Sears is out we're dead ducks unless Richie Guerin plays like he did last night." The Knicks then met the Detroit Pistons at the Olympia and were live ducks as Guerin once again was in rare form.
Leonard Bernstein, the conductor, and Dr. Jonas E. Salk, the discoverer of the poliomyolitis vaccine, were honored last night at the City College Alumni Association's seventy-ninth annual dinner.
The city's plans for a 1960 capital budget of $658,933,792 were thrown into confusion by the defeat of the $500,000,000 school construction bond issue on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Eisenhower is tidying up before the end. He is realizing old dreams and implementing plans he talked about in his first campaign for the Presidency. Ever since he entered the White House, he has been talking about going to India and seeing the new world of the independent nations.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Record prices for 2-year-old trotters and yearling fillies sold at public auction were established today at the annual standardbred horse sale here.
BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- The unexpected election of John F. Collins as Mayor of Boston was seen today as part of a taxpayer revolt throughout Massachusetts.
The Hugo Stinnes Corporation announced yesterday the election of Joseph V. Santry as a director. Mr. Santry is chairman of Combustion Engineering, Inc.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 4 -- India firmly rejected today Communist China's claims to large parts of her territory. She also rejected Peiping's charges that Indian troops provoked a clash in Ladakh last month in which nine Indians were killed.

Virtually complete returns from Long Island's Tenth Judicial District showed last night that the winning Democratic margins for the three Supreme Court posts at stake in the Tuesday election ranged from about 10,000 to 35,000 votes.
Is your golf game shot? Have you broken 100 yet? Are you still missing those two-foot putts?

George L. Bagby, chairman of trustees of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, will give a cocktail party this afternoon at his apartment in the Waldorf-Towers. The event will honor members of the subscription committee and the artists for the organization's benefit to "La Traviata" at the Metropolitan Opera House on Nov. 19.

On some airline routes it is impossible days ahead to get space on certain flights. At the same time people are encouraged to come to the airport as "standbys." The reason given is that by experience practically every plane in the end leaves with a few empty seats.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange held steady yesterday, closing unchanged to up 7 points. July was strongest month. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)

"Restrained optimism" induced by the longer-than-expected steel strike is reflected in fewer-than-expected extra dividends this year, according to the Standard and Poor's Corporations, statistical service.
CAIRO, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- A medical report said today that the inexperienced guide who led two Americans and two Frenchmen on a fatal trek across the Nubian Desert had died by violence.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A new wave of extreme nationalism, directed as usual at the United States, appears to be rising in Latin America.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A man-in-space capsule was fired out over the Atlantic Ocean today in a successful test of the capsule's emergency escape system.

The near copper positions were strongest yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Prices climbed 15 to 86 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 566 lots of 50,000 pounds each. Trading was influenced by higher London quotations and the continuance of strikes in the industry.
A couple and their 2-year-old son were killed in Queens last night after their car was struck by a stolen car being chased by the police. The couple's 5-year-old son was critically injured.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- France announced today that she was determined to hold a nuclear test explosion in the Sahara unless the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain "renounce their nuclear armament."

THE story of the House of Revlon is the story of the Revson brothers. It began in loft in midtown Manhattan twenty-seven years ago and now has reached the latest of a series of climaxes in a Congressional hearing on television quizzes.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 4 -- Democrats surveyed their greatest election triumph in Kentucky history today, and saw straws in the wind for the 1960 Presidential contest.

Thomas E. Deegan Jr., chairman of the New York World's Fair 1964 Corporation, returned from Paris last night, elated over receiving the "green light" from the International Bureau of Expositions to go ahead with plans for a fair in Flushing Meadow, Queens.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said last night the United States would stay ahead of the Soviet Union only if Americans were "true believers."

EVENTS of the last few days in the television industry have brought home to countless parents and teachers a shocking awareness of what can happen to values and ethics in the face of problems of the bank account or pressures from the advertising industry.
Three manufacturers of copper products announced price increases yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4 -- The screen writers have authorized their union, the Writers Guild of America, to call a strike against the major film studios.
A closing rush by Henry Cohen's Last Slam enabled the mare to score in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The White House said today President Eisenhower never had a golf club in his hands from the time of the invasion of Normandy until the defeat of Germany.
BEING a genuine writer, Paddy Chayefsky can make the impossible happen.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Nov. 5 (AP) -- Premier David Ben-Gurion is expected to form a three-party coalition Government with an eight-vote majority in the Israeli Knesset (parliament).
MOUNT VERNON, Nov. 5 -- The school board tonight voted to build a $7,500,000 high school and to ask the voters to approve a thirty-year bond issue of $7,200,000 to finance it.

W. R. (Bob) Ballard, a former captain of the Canadian international team, paid $40,000 yesterday for Windsor Castle, one of the leading contenders for the open jumper championship of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A merchant seaman who refuses to answer questions about communism cannot be denied security clearance by the Coast Guard without a hearing, the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The National Guard announced tonight it had repulsed a band of invaders from Honduras after a battle in which four of the intruders were killed and ten captured.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 3 -- Maj. Delio Gomez Ochoa, once one of Fidel Castro's bearded rebel chiefs in Cuba, has become a Dominican Republic exhibit of disillusion and distaste for the Cuban Premier.

THE television quiz scandal continues to lead to depressing developments. The National Broadcasting Company advanced yesterday a rather frightening proposal to hire an experienced "prosecutor" to take over supervision of some forms of TV programming.
ALBANY, Nov. 5 -- New York National Guard units are taking over full-time operation of the Army missile bases guarding New York City and Buffalo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- An executive of a Pennsylvania department store told Congressional investigators today that his company had regularly paid New York agents for mention on some of television's most popular shows.

Loans to business by the fifteen large New York banks rose $107,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with an increase of $10,000,000 in the 1958 week.

The rock-ribbed defensive platoon of the New York Football Giants put in overtime practice in Yankee Stadium yesterday. The Giant defenders have special problems to solve in Sunday's National League game here with the Chicago Cardinals.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Methodist Church must identify itself more fully with the so-called common people, a leader of the denomination said today.

Circus In Piccadilly With the news that part of the north rim of London's Piccadilly Circus, now a confusion of unsightly old houses, is to be replaced by a tall, modern office building comes also the assurance that practically nothing else there will be changed.
Bill Steinkraus, the captain of America's equestrian team dominated both international jumping events at the National Horse Show yesterday.

RALPH ROSENBORG belongs to an ageless painting family of mystic intimists. In his small glowing oils at the Albert Landry Galleries, 712 Fifth Avenue, at Fiftyfifth Street, Mr. Rosenborg explores simple motifs -- creppuscular landscapes, seascapes, trees and floral bouquets.
OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 5 -- Pascual Perez of Argentina retained the world flyweight title by knocking out Sadao Yaoita of Japan in fifty-five seconds of the thirteenth round tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 5 -- The year 1960 promises to be a record-breaking one for sales of cooling, heating and refrigeration equipment and products, George S. Jones Jr., managing director of the Air-Conditioning and Refrigeration Institute, Washington, D. C., forecast today.
A 15-year-old boy, who is charged with driving a stolen automobile that struck another car and killed three persons while being chased by the police, was held in $50,000 bail yesterday.
WARSAW, Nov. 5 -- The United States will sponsor a program of research aimed at increasing the productivity of Poland's hard pressed agricultural system.
Profit-taking, liquidation and hedge selling weakened potato futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. The decline was termed a technical reaction to recent strength.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 5 -- A draft treaty for establishing a free trade area outside the European Common Market has been completed.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- It has been a lifetime of dedicated work in the field of international relations and devotion to the cause of disarmament, not any one act or exercise, that won the Nobel Prize for Peace for Philip John Noel-Baker today.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Industrial shares continued to decline in the stock market here today. However, late demand at the lower prices helped most stocks recover most of their losses.
ATLANTA, Nov. 5 -- A conference marked by fisticuffs and knife play has brought a promise of a state investigation into an alleged traffic trap in the south Georgia piney woods.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that of 150 persons who testified before the grand jury that investigated TV quiz-show rigging here, "maybe fifty told the truth." He said he would consult with a grand jury on the question of untruthful testimony given under oath in jury investigations.
The Production Code Review Board here granted a seal of approval yesterday to the film "Happy Anniversary," reversing the decision of the Production Code Administration in Hollywood.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -The General Electric Company announced today that it would proceed almost immediately with the construction of a $14,000,000 space technology research and development center near here.
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- President de Gaulle has assured Chancellor Adenauer of French support for full participation by West Germans in the conference here Dec. 19 of the Western big powers.
Are Americans over-extending themselves on installment credit?

NEW DELHI, India. Nov. 5 -Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru ruled out today the possibility of a "real war" with Communist China. He warned, however, that he would be ready "for strong action" if it became necessary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters disclosed today that it would work to unseat fifty-six House members next year because they had backed strong labor-reform legislation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -Following are the texts of a statement read today by Robert E. Kintner, president of the National Broadcasting Company, before the House Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight and of excerpts from his testimony:

A quiet bond market put the Treasury's $10,895,000,000 refunding behind it yesterday with the conviction that the Government's financial deal had been well planned and executed. Few of the Government securities due this month or redeemable by holders in February will go unexchanged, it was predicted.
OSLO, Norway, Nov. 5 -Philip J. Noel-Baker, British Quaker, statesman and author, won the 1959 Nobel Peace Prize today.
WILSON, N. C., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Shots were fired into the homes of two strikers last night in a new flare-up apparently resulting from a strike at Swift Co.'s meat-packing plant here.

LONDON, Nov. 5 (UPI) -The Western world warmly welcomed today President Eisenhower's planned nine-nation tour. Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India said he hoped to use the occasion to discuss Communist Chinese incursions over the Indian border.
A large number of the city's socially prominent persons attended the dinner dance for the benefit of the Speyer Hospital for Animals last night in the St. Regis Roof.
Spanish-speaking New Yorkers earn nearly $1,000,000,000 a year, pay $132,000,000 in rent and spend $240,000,000 on food, according to El Diario de Nueva York and Radio Station WHOM.
RYE, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- This city began operating today under a city manager, as authorized Tuesday by the voters.

TRENTON, Nov. 5 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner pledged today that the state would do all it could to block the further curtailment of essential railroad passenger services. And he called again on the Federal Government to help solve the problem.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Nov. 5 -- Sir Roy Welensky, Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, rejected today an appeal by the British Labor party to defer the 1960 review of the federation's Constitution.
St. Vincent's Hospital plans a ten-story building from 133 to 141 West Eleventh Street, adjoining the hospital's Cardinal Spellman Pavilion. The project will cost about $4,000,000.

The dean of the Columbia University Law School said yesterday that new students there were so deficient in basic writing skills that the school had been forced to "operate, at first, as a species of correctional institution."

DETROIT, Nov. 5 (AP) -Chrysler Corporation is considering entering the auto financing field, along with General Motors Corporation and Ford Motor Company, Byron J. Nichols, a Chrysler vice president, said today.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Senator Francois Mitterrand -- and with him the French Left -- scored a major point today when former Premier Maurice Bourges-Maunoury disclosed that he had received assassination warnings from the man now opposing M. Mitterrand.

The union democracy provisions of the new Landrum-Griffin labor law were invoked for the first time yesterday in an effort to protect rank-and-file members of a Jersey City local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The surge of public resentment against certain trade union practices that forced the Landrum - Griffin bill through Congress over the opposition of organized labor leaders may recur in the next session in consequence of the protracted steel strike.
The airline passenger who has endured the frustrations of lost reservations, creeping ticket lines and oversold flights can look forward to a new era of electronic efficiency, starting in 1962.

OXFORD, England, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- Pete Dawkins, a former All-America football player at West Point, rambled for three tries and converted two kicked goals yesterday to lead Oxford University to a 47-9 rugby rout of Bristol University. After the game he declared, "I haven't enjoyed myself so much for a long time."

Ailing athletes traditionally make remarkable recoveries on Thursdays. Yesterday was no exception as the exodus from the Ivy League sick bay hit full stride. Colds were burned up in fevers of anticipation. Old wounds were given a lick and a promise of attention after tomorrow's football games.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- Philip Cortney, president of Coty, Inc., and former president of the International Chamber of Commerce, again called upon American business men today to adhere to a "hands-off entertainment" code.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A $60,000,000, five-point major expansion project at the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company plant in East Chicago, Ind., was announced today by Gov. Harold W. Handley.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The establishment of special low-altitude routes for jet bomber training missions has drawn protests and praise from civil aviation.
A $4,500,000 plant for production of automotive transmissions, said to be the first of its kind in Latin America, was opened on Wednesday at Valinhos, Brazil, forty-five miles northwest of Sao Paulo.

New York's Board of Estimate must now begin revision of the 1960 capital budget that was deliberately drafted on the assumption of voter approval of Amendment No. 4. Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, only member of the board who opposed No. 4, declared the day after defeat of the $500,000,000 bond issue for school construction that the city, nevertheless, would still be able to provide $100,000,000 in capital budget funds for the schools.
NEWARK, Nov. 5 -- A major reorganization of the Newark police department went into effect today with the swearing in of thirty-eight new superior officers.
DETROIT, Nov. 5 -- Lay-offs in the automobile industry because of steel shortages soared above 200,000 today, threatening to cut off a sales splurge by the industry.
The two top maritime union leaders of the United States asserted yesterday that they had broken the "solid front" of Greek shipowners at a recent meeting in Athens.
WARSAW, Nov. 5 -- "Everyone talks about him," said a Polish Communist. Then he added with a mixture of wariness and exasperation: "But who can talk to him really? So few."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Defense Department is taking its budget problems to sea Saturday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MUROC, Calif., Nov. 5 (AP) -- A test pilot had a narrow escape today in an emergency landing of the X-15 rocket plane.
CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 5 -- The Soviet Union expects to be generating about 600,000 kilowatts of power through atomic power stations by the mid-Nineteen-Sixties, a Soviet expert said today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- The television industry, as the result of Congressional disclosures, is at the crossroads and what it does now will determine whether it will recover public confidence, the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission said today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The bullish trend in soybean futures ran with the brakes on today but it managed some fairly uniform small advances. Most grain futures were off.

Structural steel work on three Manhattan skyscrapers has been halted or delayed by the steel strike. The builders have been able, however, to shift temporarily to other work on the buildings. There have been some delays on interior finishing of other structures nearing completion in the city.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 5 -- A Nassau County detective surrendered today on an indictment for attempted bribery. He was charged with trying to bribe a detective in the District Attorney's office in the case of a union official charged with juke-box racketeering.
The advertising industry, operating these days with its eyes on the television quiz rigging hearings in Washington, received a bit of cheer yesterday.

The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday praised the House subcommittee investigating television quiz shows for avoiding the "witch hunt" atmosphere of Congressional investigations in the early Nineteen Fifties.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Baptist General Convention of Texas advised its 1,600,000 members yesterday to consider carefully before voting for a candidate who is a Roman Catholic.

An issue of $10,000,000 of fifteen-year, 6 1/4 per cent subordinated debentures of the General Acceptance Corporation was brought to market yesterday by investment bankers headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis and Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co.
A substitute for the recently defeated school bond exemption is being drafted by the state's Nelson Commission on City Governmental Operations for submission to the next session of the Legislature.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, tonight promised railroad labor all-out support in its current dispute. He declared that if the dispute ended in a strike it would be management's fault.
Theodora Andrews, a Minneapolis-born soprano, made her Town Hall debut last night with the assistance of Paul Meyer at the piano.
WASHINGTON Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Government today accused fourteen leading rug manufacturers of giving their biggest customers discriminatory price advantages.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 5 -President Arturo Frondizi lectured Argentines for fifty minutes tonight on the seriousness of the country's under-development. He asserted that his Administration's unpopular economic stabilization plan was the only solution for the problem.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday announced the establishment of a special task force on narcotics addiction and an experimental research center in a state mental hospital.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The National Pilots Association said today that it had chosen Max Conrad as "pilot of the year."

Tickets are still available for Monday's performance of "Take Me Along" at the Shubert Theatre, which will benefit the Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children in Farmingdale, N. J. They may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved up 11 to 15 points yesterday in the widest trade participation in dealings for many months. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

Lumber production dipped to 256,037,000 tons last week from 258,824,000 tons the week before, according to reports by regional associations to The New York Times. This compared with the output of 252,903,000 tons in the similar 1958 week.
The problems that continue to frustrate mankind's hope for relief from the crushing armament burden and the dread of atomic annihilation are emphasized anew by the latest developments:
A family of three in Little Neck, Queens, was found dead yesterday in a case of apparent murder and suicide.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 5 -- Although the people in twelve counties voted Tuesday in favor of banning Sunday sales of certain items, proponents and opponents of the measure girded today for further battle.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- The Federal Power Commission has been ordered to issue a certificate of public convenience and necessity under which the Consolidated Edison Company of New York would be enabled to buy natural gas in Texas.
Hawaii, the newest state in the Union, is the subject of three books, one a novel, that will be published this month.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 5 -- Any person or concern wishing to make deposits in Venezuelan banks will be guaranteed convertibility at the present rate, the National Bankers Association announced here today.

Recently the United Service Organization's director of building services described the conditions in Seoul, Korea, this way: "Sanitation, as we know it, is nonex istent * * * the majority [of Koreans] live in the most primitive of conditions, in flimsy tin and tar paper shacks we wouldn't raise chickens in * * * a great number appear to exist only by their wits, that is, by begging or stealing."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, said today that the United States was second to the Soviet Union in missile and space development chiefly because President Eisenhower had failed to give the program "the priority it should have."
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Guenther Fritz Podola, 30-year-old German photographer, was hanged at 9:45 A. M. today for the murder of a London police detective July 13.

UNTIL only a few years ago almost nothing was known about the long history of Africa south of the Sahara -Black Africa. Not much is known yet because the Africans had no written language in which to preserve the record of their story. But modern archaeologists, anthropolgists, ethnologists and various other assorted scholars have recently been prying into the African past with considerable diligence.
MONTREAL, Nov. 5 -- It is becoming increasingly difficult to describe the shortcomings of the New York Rangers, but it's a pleasure to extol the clever Montreal Canadiens.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 5 (AP) -- When he was 46 years old, Mark Twain dreamed of being a boy again but only on condition that summer always reign, that he be a cub pilot on a Mississippi boat and that the magnolias always bloom.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- The International Typographical Union went on strike tonight against the three major newspaper plants in this city. Publishers immediately closed down all operations for what one of them described as "a very long time."
World Community Day will be observed today by several million Protestant and Eastern Orthodox women in this country.

Ground was broken yesterday in Muncie, Ind., by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for a new plant to make power transformers. The company said the installation would be the most advanced of its type in the world.
TRENTON, Nov. 5 -- The State Supreme Court granted the State Division Against Discrimination today the right to hold hearings in three cases involving alleged racial bias.

Sgt. Edgar D. Croswell's account of how he and other state policemen broke up the Apalachin meeting was challenged in Federal court yesterday by a lawyer acting for twenty-one men who attended the gathering.

The nation's stocks of gasoline dropped by 1,870,000 barrels in the week ended on last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 176,147,000 barrels, compared with 178,017,000 a week earlier and 168,476,000 a year ago.
Interscholastic competition ranging from English to sewing and bricklaying was suggested yesterday as a means of channeling student energy now consumed by less worthy extra-curricular activities.

John G. Clock of Long Beach, Calif., has been nominated for the presidency of the United States Golf Association. The nomination, which is regarded as tantamount to election, will be presented and voted upon at the organization's annual meeting at the Biltmore Hotel, on Jan. 30.

An issue of $4,000,000 of serial bonds of Independent School District 89 of Oklahoma County, Okla., was sold yesterday at public bidding to a syndicate headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. at an interest cost of 3.3404 per cent. The issue will come due from 1961 to 1970.
MUSKEGON, Mich., Nov. 5 (UPI) -- The 500-foot ore carrier William A. Paine was prepared today to unload a "steaming hot" cargo of 7,000 tons of coal that threatens to catch fire.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov 5 -- A final unofficial recount of ballots late today showed that H. Lee Dennison of Port Jefferson Station had been elected Suffolk's first County Executive.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- A compact electronic version of the iron lung, required by many paralyzed victims of poliomyelitis to enable them to breathe, was unveiled in Cambridge today.
ABRAM CHASINS, musical director of radio station WQXR and the QXR network, insists that he is only an amateur at bridge but admits that he loves to play with the pros.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -Mothers who think their children are always sick are right.
CLEMENTON, N. J., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Britain, the defender, scored 11 points on the Pine Valley Golf Club course today to take the lead in the international triangular senior matches.
Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz of Kings County Court was accused in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday of illegally charging a grand jury to study and report on matters affecting Puerto Rican migration.

I should like to congratulate Jack Gould on the extremely intelligent appraisal of the Van Doren affair appearing in The Times of Nov. 4. It covers phases of this shameful situation which perhaps have been overlooked by many commentators up to now.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 4 -- The Dominican Government hopes its economy is ready to turn upward again after a period of strain from drought, low export prices and heavy defense spending.

THE quest for the ultimate in neatly tailored upholstery led the designer for the Helikon Furniture Company to develop a new construction for chairs. The concern, which opens today at 543 Madison Avenue, offers designs for the office. It deals through decorators.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The Labor party's "shadow cabinet" elections brought into the Opposition's Parliamentary leadership tonight a strong representation of moderates regarded as close to Hugh Gaitskell, the party leader.
The portrayals of Canio and Nedda in last night's "I Pagliacci" at the Metropolitan Opera were sharply contrasted in style.

Robert Moses, chairman of the Committee on Slum Clearance, said yesterday that the public housing project that the City Housing Authority has planned for the Polo Grounds would ease the relocation problem of two Harlem slum clearance projects.

One of the most interesting and perhaps significant aspects of President Eisenhower's proposed visit to Pakistan and India is its timing. It is so perfect as to be almost uncanny. This is the moment at which the President's trip can do the most good.
The six-story commercial building at 33 West Fifty-seventh Street has been sold by the Callanson Realty Corporation to the Morgan Securities Corporation. Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers.

FLORHAM PARK, N. J., Nov. 5 -- The Esso Research and Engineering Company's multimillion dollar center was dedicated here today. It is on part of the former 1,000-acre Twombly estate in the sloping hills of Morris County.
Pilot (making pre-flight check) to organist: "Check your keyboard."

The Electric Bond and Share Company reported yesterday that its net income rose 5 per cent in the first nine months of this year. The report went on to point out that a decline in its share value from the 1959 level was attributable to the action of Cuban authorities in "drastically reducing" the rates of the American and Foreign Power Company's Cuban subsidiary.

PAINTING children's portraits is enjoyable work, but it requires a patient, nimble artist and sometimes very strenuous exercise. This is the opinion of William Gillies, president of The Portrait Group of Westport, Conn., Inc.
ROME, Nov. 5 -- The admission of twelve countries to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization was approved today.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Coach Frank Bell, a University of Illinois end two decades ago, will have an all-Illinois quartet in the backfield when his Hotchkiss eleven meets The Taft School here on Saturday.
PANAMA, Nov. 5 -- President Ernesto de la Guardia Jr. said last night that he deplored the violent demonstrations here this week against the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Sekou Toure, President of the young republic of Guinea, told the General Assembly today that Africa would not be "taken in tow" either by the West or by the Soviet Union.

In the current controversy over quiz shows some of the reasons advanced for their indictment are quite surprising and somewhat irrelevant. We understand, of course, the motivations of a popular reaction we share to a certain extent. It makes us feel good to know that, after all, the contestants were not all as erudite as they sounded and that our ignorance of so many apparently important facts is not so appalling.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Some of the parents in this village are taking a dim view of the first "go-home" air-raid drill for the 1,550 public school children here. The unrehearsed drill is scheduled for an unannounced hour next Tuesday.
Directors of American Radiator Standard Sanitary Corporation yesterday increased the quarterly common dividend to 20 cents and voted a special dividend of 10 cents, both payable on Dec 15.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -Rail freight loadings declined slightly and truckloadings held virtually steady last week. The steel strike continued to dominate both.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Justice Department said tonight that it would convene a Federal grand jury in Mississippi to consider the lynching of Mack Charles Parker.
HAVANA, Nov. 5 -- Three men fired last night at the residence of Maj. William A. Morgan, former United States citizen who now is a follower of Premier Fidel Castro.

The gold outflow from the United States to foreign countries this year has been $200,000,000 larger than previously suspected. Figures published yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York put the United States monetary gold stock at $19,585,000,000 on Wednesday, up $99,000,000 from the week before.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Speakers before the General Assembly's Budgetary Committee urged Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today to take further steps to improve the geographical distribution of members of the Secretariat staff.

The Masters Children's Center and the Masters Nursery will gain from a theatre party to be held at the Feb. 1 performance of "The Pink Jungle." The new comedy by Leslie Stevens, starring Ginger Rogers, with incidental music and lyrics by Vernon Duke, is scheduled to open at the Fiftyfourth Street Theatre in midJanuary.
WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 5 -The Harness Racing Commission approved tentative dates today for the 1960 and 1961 racing seasons at Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways.

The Xavier Award of the Jesuit Seminary and Mission Bureau was presented last night to Msgr. Edward E. Swanstrom, executive director of the Catholic Relief Services-National Catholic Welfare Conference.
TOWNSHIP 24, Washington County, Me., Nov. 5 -- A nine-point buck and four fat does hang off the crosstree outside Dan Hartford's camp here.

If rainy weather prevails for the Columbia-Dartmouth game tomorrow at Baker Field the Hanoverians will not be disturbed. The team that has beaten Harvard and Yale on heavy fields on successive Saturdays is regarded as the Ivy Leaguer's "best mudder."
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 5 (AP) -Managed Funds, Inc., a St. Louis investment concern, has been reorganized through election of eight new directors at a special meeting of stockholders.

COPENHAGEN must be the most civilized place on earth. What other city would invite the 200 members of the International Bartenders Association to town and take them to the ballet? Copenhagen did and the bartenders loved it.

ALBANY, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- The number of arrests in New York State for the first nine months of 1959 was slightly higher than for the same period last year, Paul D. McGinnis, Commissioner of Correction, said today.

WHEN the Ivy League ban on spring football practice was deplored in this space a fortnight ago, there was no intention here to belabor the point or continue the discussion later on. But that one shot must have been filled with shrapnel. It stirred up too many people to be ignored further, especially when comments were to have a bearing on the entire structure of intercollegiate football.
Reading and writing and arithmetic were prescribed yesterday as specific treatments in adolescent narcotics addiction.
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- France opened the door wider today to importation of a wide range of products from the United States, Canada and Western Europe.
More than $7,000,000 worth of cargo is known to have been stolen or missing from piers in the Port of New York in 1957, it was reported yesterday.
The Administration, evidently under the urging of Secretary of the Treasury Anderson, has indicated that it will ask for $700 million less in foreign aid in this year's budget than in last year's.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, demanded today that the Western Big Four hear the views of the smaller powers in the alliance on a summit meeting.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 5 -The Government of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer offered today to accept any kind of arms control that other nations would be willing to take upon themselves.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell said today that unions and management should make it a habit of talking over their mutual problems once in a while -- even when there is no labor strike.
A material witness in the murder of Frankie Abbatemarco, a 59-year-old ex-convict who was shot by two gunmen on Wednesday evening in a Brooklyn tavern, was held in Kings County Court yesterday.
A ten-year program to develop two campus areas of Yeshiva University at a cost of $30,000,000 was announced last night by Dr. Samuel Belkin, university president.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 5 -- The annual issue of Daily Variety, the West Coast entertainment industry publication, tries to explain, with figures, the discrepancies between the pessimism of many theatre owners and the optimism of some moviemakers.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 -- The City Council, after more than three hours' debate, today approved the necessary commercial and parking zone changes for the Dodger baseball stadium site in Chavez Ravine.

GENEVA, Nov. 5 -- The United States and Britain prepared today for hard bargaining with the Soviet Union over the proposed meeting here of experts to deal with technical problems stalling an agreement to ban nuclear weapons tests.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Eleazar De Carvalho, conductor; Robert Casadesus, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; "The Marriage of Figaro," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Samson Francois, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Jeannette Haien, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30.

PALM DESERT, Calif., Nov. 5 (UPI) -- Sam Snead and Dr. Cary Middlecoff were paired today with Harry Weetman and Dave Thomas of England in the feature match of the Scotch foursomes in the Ryder Cup competition tomorrow.

GENOA, Italy, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Christmas comes Sunday to the village of San Marco d'Urri near here. Santa Claus is coming on foot, with a bagful of shares in one of the biggest banks in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The House General Education subcommittee turned over to the House legislative counsel today the task of drafting a bipartisan school construction bill that would presumably be received favorably in the White House.
Birth control will be discussed at length by Roman Catholic and Protestant leaders when "The Population Explosion" is televised on Wednesday from 10 to 11 P. M. by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Under Secretary of State Robert Murphy will delay his departure from the Federal Government, scheduled for Dec. 3, to accompany President Eisenhower to Europe, Asia and Africa. The President will leave Washington early Dec. 4 by jet and arrive in Rome the same day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Declomycin, an antibiotic requiring only half the dosage and capable of staying in the system twice as long as others in the tetracycline group, was announced here today.
Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner were asked yesterday to seek legislation that would keep property owners from tearing down good housing occupied by middle-income families.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Congressional investigators hear today that a new policing unit established by the National Broadcasting Company had already uncovered a kickback system on a current network show.

Third-quarter earnings of the Phelps Dodge Corporation slumped because of strikes in the copper industry, according to a report issued by the company for release today. It is the nation's second largest copper producer.

Directors of the Utah Southern Oil Company, Denver, approved yesterday a proposal to sell the company's properties to the Texas National Petroleum Company of Houston for $19,200,000.

Earnings of Sterling Drug, Inc., in the three months ended on Sept. 30 were the highest for any quarter in the company's history, James Hill Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of the pharmaceutical concern, reported yesterday.

Taking advantage of the widened posts, collegians are kicking field goals as never before. Cus D'Amato's fight to prevent the revocation of his licenses opened yesterday before the New York State Athletic Commission. The hearing became so entwined in legal bickering that D'Amato never reached the witness stand.
American Export Lines acknowledged yesterday it had been paying illegal rebates to preferred clients since 1954.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 5 -- A Sao Paulo farmer jabbed a finger at today's commodity quotations in the morning newspaper.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, Nov. 4 -- Demands for greater self-rule will be heard by the House Subcommittee on Territories when it arrives early next month to discuss changes in the Organic Act under which these islands are governed.
A partnership in world market development for products of the Bon Ami Company through world-wide operations of the Kiwi Polish Company, Pty., Ltd., of Australia was announced jointly yesterday.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 5 -- The appointment of Msgr. John J. Dougherty as president of Seton Hall University here was announced today by the Most Rev. Thomas A. Boland, Archbishop of Newark.

Columbia College students held a rally last night for the return of Charles Van Doren to the faculty, but many attending were anti-Van Doren. Still others were concerned only with beating Dartmouth Saturday.

CHICAGO Nov. 5 -- Mrs. S. J. Kupperman, the mother of Joel Kupperman, one of the "Quiz Kids" on the former 'Quiz Kid's' program, said her son had been under "controls," but she added that she did not believe the show had been "rigged."

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Prudential Insurance Company awarded a construction contract today for completion of the $10,000,000 Millburn Plaza Shopping Center at Short Hills, N. J. The contract went to the John W. Ryan Construction Company of New York.
Wide swings in individual stocks but small net changes for the market as a whole characterized yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The development of an electronic pacemaker that can be sewn up inside a person's chest to keep his heart going was reported here last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Bernard Goldfine, Boston industrialist, will get a new chance Dec. 9 to answer the questions involved in his conviction for contempt of Congress.
Defense counsel in the Apalachin trial yesterday continued their attacks on the credibility of testimony by Sgt. Edgar D. Croswell of the State Police. He led the raid on the 1957 gathering.
Christopher Plummer, Ruth Roman and Don de Fore have been added to the cast of "The Philadelphia Story," to be seen on the National Broadcasting Company television network Dec. 7.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 6 (AP) -- A bitterly contested small-loan bill passed the State Senate early today after the administration had broken a filibuster through a parliamentary maneuver.
Hope put sparkle into the Wall Street air yesterday. The result was a lift of speculative excitement that brought general gains to every major group except the oils.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -The Supreme Court put in an unusually long conference day today and adjourned without announcing its decision in the steel injunction case.
WASHINGTON, Non. 6 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States questioned today the consistency of George Meany's attitude and policies on communism.
City Administrator Charles F. Preusse promised officials of the International Bureau of Exhibitions this week to do what he could to have the United States join the international agency.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Superintendent of the United States Military Academy said today that Admiral Hyman G. Rickover was ignorant of the facts in criticizing educational standards of service academies.
Harrods, Ltd., big department store in London, will expand its buying of American-made goods in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -Following is the text of the statement made today by Representative Oren Harris, Democrat of Arkansas, at the conclusion of the current hearings by the Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight, of which he is chairman:
DETROIT, Nov. 6 (UPI) -General Motors announced plans today to lay off 8,100 more workers, increasing the total made idle for the duration of the steel strike to 212,865.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- The French Government promised today to eliminate special discriminations against trade with the United States "within the shortest possible time" and lift all quota restrictions on European and United States goods within two years.

Raising a "clear and vigorous" voice in behalf of the smaller nations in the North Atlantic alliance, Paul-Henri Spaak, secretary general of the treaty organization, calls for full consultation of all the allies and not just the big ones in formulating a European policy for the projected EastWest summit meeting in the interest of Western unity.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Researchers reported on the stubborness of staphylococcal infections at the final session of the seventh annual Antibiotics Conference today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -Eighty-five per cent of the publicly held Treasury notes and certificates maturing this month and 81 per cent of a note issue maturing later have been exchanged for new issues, the Treasury announced today.

Reinzi, J. Frederic Gagel's good distance horse, found the Market Wise Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday quite to his liking. The race, at a mile and five-eights, attracted six starters and enough of the 21,859 fans knew Reinzi's capabilities well enough to make him the favorite.
PANAMA, Nov. 6 -- Panama has submitted another note to the United States over Tuesday's rioting.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- Hopes for a review of a union vote that set off a Boston newspaper strike glowed faintly tonight. But spokesmen for the union, Local 13 of the International Typographical Union, and for the publishers said that so far they saw no change in the situation.

The United Nations fact-finding committee on Laos has now made its report. It is, as was predicted, half-hearted and inconclusive. The committee was hamstrung from the start. It could not even pretend to make a recommendation, because that would have incurred the Soviet veto. It cannot make a recommendation now. It obviously did not get the "facts," and there was no intention on the part of the Communists that it should.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Lawyers of the Federal Communications Commission substantially backtracked today on a demand they made last July that Television Channel 5 be taken away from WHDH, Inc., subsidiary of The Boston HeraldTraveler.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -Average wholesale primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 119.2 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

CONCORD, N. H., Nov. 6 (AP) -- A campaign to win the Republican Presidential nomination for Vice President Richard M. Nixon got under way today in New Hampshire, which holds the nation's first Presidential primary of 1960.
Members of the Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance read in their newspapers yesterday morning about a slum clearance project "to be proposed by the committee" that they had yet to discuss.

BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- The Supreme International Restitution Court in Berlin ordered West Germany today to pay damages to the heirs of a Jewish business man for the loss of a writing desk that once belonged to Frederick the Great.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 6 -- The Colombo Plan conference endorsed today a draft annual report highlighting the economic progress made by the fifteen countries and 700,000,000 people of non-Communist south and southeast Asia.
WARSAW, Nov. 6 -- Poland's writers, squeezed economically and politically, are debating whether to use one of the few weapons at their command: the intellectual boycott.

A 72-year-old Staten Island laborer was killed last night when he was struck by two cars and a bus while crossing Hylan Boulevard between Jefferson and Stobe Avenues in Dongan Hills, S. I. Pelting rain hampered visibility at the time of the accident, shortly before 6 P.M.
BELTSVILLE, Md. TO this nation's homemakers the 11,000 green acres here are the most fertile in the nation.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 6 -- President Francois Duvalier is proposing new taxation and is cutting Haiti's budget 14 per cent. His aim is to show that Haiti can help herself.

The medical breakthrough in the battle against disease is told in "Virus Hunters" by Greer Williams. It will be issued Nov. 16 by Knopf. The volume discusses the nature and treatment of such scourges as yellow fever, smallpox, polio, rabies, hepatitis, mumps, leukemia, influenza, cancer and the common cold.
WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Luckenbach Steamship Company moved today to set aside an Interstate Commerce Commission ruling on railroad rates for the shipment of canned goods.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 7 -Lower lake supplies of Lake Superior iron ore were increased slightly in October when lake vessels delivered 273,344 tons. The total compared with 8,043,664 tons in the 1958 month.

THE art of portraiture, given a body blow by the invention of photography in the nineteenth century, has received still another in recent years. That is the fact that, for a variety of sociological reasons, people have developed "status" rather than individual faces.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 6 (AP) -- The last of the ten foreign entries in the $100,000 Washington D. C. International at Laurel next Wednesday, Midnight Sun and Mi Carina of France, were in their barns at the track today.

Port Chester High School -unbeaten, untied and unscored upon this season -- will meet a fast Mamaroneck team today for the Westchester CrossCounty Conference football championship. Mamaroneck will be the host.

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 6 (UPI) -- A new stalemate developed today in Michigan's fiscal crisis. Republicans adjourned the Legislature for the week-end after Democrats had refused to co-sponsor five tax bills drafted by Republicans.
For the second time within a month a 22-year-old Brooklyn man was freed yesterday after being tried on a charge he could not possibly have been guilty of.
Directors of Sterling Drug, Inc., yesterday increased the quarterly dividend on the common shares to 45 cents and declared an extra 10 cents, both payable on Dec. 1.
MUSKEGON, Mich., Nov. 6 (UPI) -- Bad weather slowed plans today to take the Great Lakes carrier William A. Paine on an emergency run to unload her "hot" cargo of 7,000 tons of coal.
The leader of 10,000 teamsters in northern New Jersey bowed yesterday to a temporary restraining order issued under the union democracy provisions of the Landrum-Griffin labor law.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- One of the Government's top scientists said today that Americans were getting an "overdose of soap operas, shoot-'em-up Westerns and glib-tongued emcees of empty entertainment" on television and radio.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- The Literary Supplement of The Times of London reached out today and gave the United States a warm pat on the back for its creative talents.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- More help for the world's refugees was urged today by the General Assembly's Social Committee. It called international attention to the plight of the 180,000 people reported to have fled Algeria since fighting broke out there five years ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- State health departments reported 763,094 cases of measles last year, the highest total since 1941, the Public Health Service said today. It cautioned, however, that the reported cases probably represented only a small fraction of all that had existed.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Syracuse sends its "Sizable Seven" after Penn State's Richie Lucas tomorrow in a battle of unbeaten football powers for the unofficial Eastern title.

Next Monday, Anita Ellis temporarily will take over the leading role played by Pat Suzuki in the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical hit "The Flower Drum Song." The substitution will allow Miss Suzuki what a show representative regards as "a well-earned oneweek vacation."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Republicans now have a 1,000 Club to match the Democrats' 750 Club. The plan is to get $1,000 donations for the party.
The Mexican national anthem rang out at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night for the first time since the show began on Tuesday.
Five "disappointed" railroad executives met here yesterday and decided to seek "a constructive and practical substitute" for the revenue plan defeated Tuesday by New Jersey voters.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 6 -- The chief negotiator for the major steel producers said today that the 115-day-old steel strike "is a dispute between two parties having vastly unequal powers," with the union much the stronger.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- Twenty thousand party stalwarts and Government officials attended a rally in Moscow's giant Luzhniki Sports Palace tonight to extol success achieved in the forty-two years since the Soviet Union was founded in the Bolshevik Revolution.
A stowaway said to be a fugitive from racial and political prejudice in South Africa won a last-minute stay of deportation yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Representative Chet Holifield, Democrat of California, said today that the staff of the House Government Operations Committee was studying a possible conflict of interest in the appointment of a Convair scientist to a high administrative post in the Pentagon.

PALM DESERT, Calif., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Capt. Sam Snead sank a key putt of 9 feet on the final hole to stave off defeat and enable the United States to take a 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2 lead over Britain today in the opening of the Ryder Cup professional golf competition.
ROBERT CASADESUS, who played the Beethoven Piano Concerto No. 4 with the New York Philharmonic yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, was also the recipient of a little surprise.

A BRIDGE player develops certain habits that are good habits on the whole, such as drawing trumps, leading toward high cards, and so on, and these habits pay dividends; but at the same time they can cause occasional losses on off-beat hands.
At an age when retirement is the lot of most. Mrs. Frances Jackson, a 64-year-old great-grandmother, has begun her first years as a permanently licensed teacher.
DETROIT, Nov. 6 -- Michigan's desperate financial condition will not affect unemployment benefits for idle auto workers.
DETROIT, Nov. 6 (UPI) -Officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters denied today that the union had drawn up a black list of House members that the union would seek to defeat.

A woman lawyer brought suit yesterday for $1,200,000 against the National Broadcasting Company and five other defendants. She charged in Supreme Court that she had been "fraudulently eliminated" from "Twenty-one," the now-defunct television quiz show.
Cotton futures moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) off to 2 points up in quiet trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Once a month an all-male group of lawyers, editors, physicians, engineers and others gather at the Shelburne Hotel and talk about their favorite hobby -- gardens.

ALBANY, Nov. 6 -- The Police Conference of New York State, a federation of local Police Benevolent Associations, asked Governor Rockefeller today for an investigation of some activities of officials of the State Police.
