" The officers and men of the First Army are keenly aware of the invaluable serv ices rendered to the personnel of the Armed Forces by the United Services Organizations," says Lieut. Gen. B. M. Bryan, Commanding General, First Army.

DENVER, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A Michigan resident who said he had been a member of the Communist party for seventeen years was the first Government witness today in the trial of eleven men accused of conspiring to defraud the Government.

The Motion Picture Association of America took exception yesterday to what it called "erroneous published reports" that the Production Code Review Board here had reversed the decision of its Production Code Administration in Hollywood in the case of "Happy Anniversary."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower asked his fellow Americans today to give thanks for their bounties on Thanksgiving Day and to pray for divine guidance in "the great unfinished task of achieving peace among men and nations."
LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Literary Supplement says:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, former Army Chief of Staff, has written a book sharply attacking the Administration's military and strategic policies.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- M. Dedijer was invited by the University of Manchester to take up a Simon Research Fellowship in Social Science two years ago. The fellowship is for one year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The president of the StudebakerPackard Corporation predicted today a declining share of the United States market for foreign-made automobiles.
BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 6 (AP) -- A court, two physicians and volunteer food donors acted today to help a Greek crew marooned on a freighter that is tied up in the Mississippi River.

The man who goes to work at night and consequently is home for much of the day often cannot help feeling that he is something neither fish nor fowl. Ladies of the neighborhood, dropping in to discuss a P. T. A. event -though not immediate neighbors, who are vaguely aware of his peculiar schedule -- are likely to exclaim as they encounter him in his working clothes: "Oh, what are you doing home?

Fashion trends for spring are taking shape as Seventh Avenue designers present collections, the American equivalent of the Paris openings. The New York Times has been barred from some showings because of its policy to report trends immediately, reports on those showings are based on information from other fashion authorities. Most of the clothes will be in stores by January.

NOTHING in Samson Francois' previous American appearances prepared this listener for the playing heard from the French pianist last night in Carnegie Hall. In a case like this, one throws the past performance charts out of the window and starts a revaluation, for his was an extraordinary, exciting concert.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -Walter C. Dowling, a career diplomat, has been selected to be the new United States Ambassador to West Germany, authoritative sources said today. He will succeed David K. E. Bruce, a Democrat, who has been in the Bonn post since March, 1957.

E. ARNOT ROBERTSON'S "The Spanish Town Papers"* holds material for any number of gaudy historical novels. It is a collection of personal letters and public documents impounded by the Vice-Admiralty Court of the British Government in Jamaica during the years of the American Revolution.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 6 -- A dispute in the coalition government of President Romulo Betancourt has been resolved by postponing action on three Cabinet resignations that were offered this week.
CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 6 (AP) -- First Landing returns to Garden State Park tomorrow favored to regain the form that skyrocketed him to fame and fortune here a year ago.

It will be one of the curious ironies of New York politics if the Wagner administration, struggling with the problem of an outmoded legal limitation on borrowing for schools and other construction, gets its first substantial help from a state commission created by the Legislature in a mood of Republican hostility to the city.
When the St. Lawrence Seaway is closed to navigation for the winter on Nov. 30 it will have handled in its first season 6,600 ships carrying 20,000,000 tons of cargo.

SHOPPERS can buy anything from a garden to an art niche at the Jasmine House, the newest addition to the number of Japanese shops that are popping up all over town. It is at 1044 Madison Avenue, near Eightieth Street.
The Los Angeles, Calif., Department of Water and Power is planning the sale of $12,000,000 of revenue bonds on Nov. 18. The issue will come due serially on Dec. 1 from 1960 to 1989.

The Board of Higher Education's report on the contribution by our municipal colleges in giving scholars and scientists to the nation should make New Yorkers proud. From 1936 to 1956, City, Brooklyn, Hunter and Queens Colleges produced twice as many graduates who went on to receive doctoral degrees as would be expected on the basis of their percentage of the national college enrollment.

The balance of payments position of the United States -- the ratio of international disbursements to receipts -- has steadily deteriorated since the beginning of last year. Now there is a sizable deficit. Can it be corrected?

There are several cruise boats that take sightseers around the island of Manhattan. Why not an uninterrupted walking path that circles the island for the lonely pedes trian who likes to take his daily or weekly constitutional? At present the pedestrian can walk the scenic path along the riverfront for only a few short blocks, except for several isolated stretches.
Commodity prices closed mostly irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was dull. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

Richard Greene of Army crossed the finish line yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx with his mouth open. He had just run five hilly miles in 24 minutes 42 seconds, won the Heptagonal cross-country title and led Army to its second straight team success in the event.
IF the indomitable people of the Living Theatre want to undertake the labor of staging Pirandello's "Tonight We Improvise," many thanks.
BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- This city is so accustomed to crises that its people have hardly noticed the latest one over the flying of the new East German Communist flag in West Berlin.

CLEMENTON, N. J., Nov. 6 (AP) -- The United States won the two-day triangular senior golf championship competition for the Lord Derby Cup by beating Britain, the defender, and Canada in today's singles matches at Pine Valley.

ALGIERS, Nov. 6 -- The French Army announced tonight the death of Major Mira, nationalist rebel commander in the Kabylia area of northern Algeria. It asserted that all six rebel zones now were without field commanders.
ALTAMONT, Tenn., Nov. 6 -A jury decided this afternoon that the Highlander Folk School has been operated for "the personal gain and enrichment" of its president and founder, Myles Horton.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -Soybean futures, on their longest and strongest bullish trend in several months, added further gains today on the Board of trade after overcoming their first general setbacks of the week in early dealings.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Gioacchino (Jack) Parisi, reputed member of the notorious Murder, Inc., and bodyguard for the slain New York mobster, Albert Anastasia, told an immigration officer today he would rather die now in the United States than be deported to Italy.
The New York Philharmonic will sponsor summer pops concerts at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, according to George Judd, manager of the orchestra.
Senator Lyndon B. Johnson has accepted an invitation to address a nonpolitical dinner in Brooklyn that is likely to attract wide political attention.
Alexander L. Guterma bilked the Dominician Republic of $750,000 while the financier was head of the Mutual Broadcasting System, Federal Referee Asa S. Herzog found yesterday.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Nov. 6 -- Thirty-two of the thirty-four members of a Japanese expedition are missing and feared dead on the 23,440-foot Gauri Sankar peak west of Mount Everest.
CAIRO, Nov. 6 -- A British cotton mission has been receiving the red-carpet treatment in Egypt this week as the United Kingdom and the United Arab Republic sought to put new life in lagging trade.
A four-alarm fire roared through the top floors of three loft buildings in downtown Manhattan last night. The flames reached heights of thirty-five feet and smoke billowed over a half-mile radius.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- A United Nations inquiry group has found no clear proof to support charges by Laos of "flagrant aggression" by North Vietnamese forces.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 6 -- Proposals for a strong federal government for the eighteenmonth-old West Indies Federation were repudiated yesterday in the Jamaica House of Representatives.
President Sekou Toure of Guinea, nearing the end of his United States tour, canceled yesterday a week-end visit to Canada.
A glowing autumn flower show will open today at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. One of the conservatories is devoted entirely to a garden of 2,500 chrysanthemums.

The twenty-two-story office building at 25 West Forty-third Street, the adjoining parking lot at 15-21 West Forty-third Street and the sixteen-story office building at 25 West Fortyfifth Street have passed to new control in a series of sales and leasebacks. The three properties are assessed for a total of $5,300,000.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand. During the autumn of 1956 New Zealand developed an acute case of schizophrenia when the Suez crisis temporarily pushed Britain and the United States into opposing policy corners, for this country is the most bullish of John Bulls, more English than the English, but it depends for its security upon an American alliance.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Former Premier Maurice Bourges-Maunoury said today he was warned last September that extremists planned to assassinate several former Premiers of the Fourth Republic, Premier Michel Debre, Minister-Delegate Jacques Soustelle and Jacques Chaban-Delmas, Speaker of the National Assembly.

Your Nov. 3 editorial "Symptom of a Sickness" deserves high praise for placing most of the blame for the personal tragedy of Charles Van Doren squarely upon the radio-television industry. But why stop there? Why not place at least equal blame on the sponsors?
An address by Governor Rockefeller will be a feature of the thirty-first annual meeting of the National Conference of Christians and Jews to be held here Wednesday through Friday.

HONG KONG, Nov. 6 -- Mayor Peng Chan of Peiping, a member of the Politburo of the Chinese Communist party, said today that Communist China had always stood for settlement of all international disputes "by peaceful means."
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -The Iron Curtain was never soundproof. Even when the "cold war" was most forbidding, the music of the Soviet Union surmounted the barrier and reached this country. Now that we are exchanging visits up to the highest level, the composers as well as their music are spanning physical and political distances.

TOWNSHIP 24, Washington County, Me., Nov. 6 -- People keep on missing deer around this camp, and it is getting pretty mortifying, but the great old Maine sport of bear-pondering keeps everybody busy and prevents panic.

LIKE their fathers before them, New York men are cautious in their dress. Nowhere is this more apparent than in evening attire. In Texas, according to a report from After Six Formals, one of the country's largest manufacturers of men's evening wear lame is the latest word in dinner jackets; proper Bostonians prefer paisley; adventurous Californians take to madras.
The last game of the college football season between major undefeated teams the country over will be played today in the East.
Charles R. Keller of the John Hay Whitney Foundation advised educators yesterday to make buildings conform to the changes being made in curriculums.
RIVERTON, Wyo., Nov. 6 -- Built in record time, a $6,000,000 uranium mill with a minimum capacity of 522 tons of uranium ore a day has begun producing "yellowcake," or uranium concentrates.

DMITRI SHOSTAKOVICH, now on an American tour with several of his colleagues as part of the Cultural Exchange Program, is not looking at this country for the first time. He was here once before, in 1949.
HILLSIDE, N. 5., Nov. Haverford (Pa.) School scored in every period to rout Pingry School, 31 -- 0, today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A Russian scientist predicted today that rocket-borne television cameras would soon supply man with pictures from Mars that would enable him to see the earth of the distant future.

Lieut. Gen. Gar Davidson, the superintendent of the United States Military Academy, said yesterday that Army would consider holding next year's football game with Syracuse in Yankee Stadium rather than Michie Stadium.

TOKYO, Nov. 6 -- Japan has decided to produce 200 Lockheed F 104-C jet fighters to bolster her defense capabilities. The decision was made tonight by the National Defense Council on the basis of reports by a group of Japanese jet fighter pilots headed by Lieut. Gen. Minoru Genda, the air chief of staff.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville described as "absurd" today assertions that France, in opposing a hastily convened EastWest summit conference, was opposing a relaxation of international tensions.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 -Mayor Wagner of New York has clarified his attitude toward becoming a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Vice President.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 6 -- American colleges were urged today to clarify their roles and redeploy their resources to meet a greater demand for higher education in the next twenty-five years.
Jeannette Haien, a pianist who is also a published poet, gave a recital in Town Hall last night.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., announced yesterday that its net earnings in the first nine months of 1959 dropped to $2,796,735 from $6,246,715 in the 1958 period. Operating revenues rose to $224,466,424 from $205,605,239 a year earlier, and operating expenses increased to $213,763,694 from $193,676,084.

Although some academic high schools in the city have classes of more than fifty pupils, the average is 31.7, the Board of Education said yesterday. This compares with 31.8 last year and with 32.4 predicted by board officials last spring.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov, 6 (UPI) -- The Justice Department petitioned a United States court today for a Federal grand jury to investigate the lynching of Mack Charles Parker.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Dr. Walter G. Muelder declared here today that only 18.9 per cent of 7,000 Methodists polled in a national scientific survey believed that all racial discrimination and enforced segregation should be abolished.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -The president of the American Bar Association offered tonight a plan for dealing with ill-tempered or discourteous judges.

Events today: "Carmen" at 2 and "Madama Butterfly" at 8, Metropolitan Opera; Henri Honegger, 'cellist, assisted by Walter Robert, piano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; New York Philharmonic, Eleazar De Carvalho, conductor; Robert Cassadesus, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; San Francisco's Gateway Singers, program of folk songs, Town Hall, 8:30; Ellen Parve, soprano, assisted by Bela Szilagyi, pianist, and Martha Strongin, violinist. Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
MIAMI, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Fran Curci, Miami's 152-pound quarterback, scored one touchdown and broke up two North Carolina drives tonight to help the Hurricanes post a 14-7 football victory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -Steel imports rose again in September, presumably because of the steel strike. September imports -- 366,000 tons -- were far short of the record of 430,000 tons set in July, but were double the volume of September, 1958.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- A Greek Cypriote gunman, jailed here today for four years, was drawing 20,000 ($56,000) for his services as a British informer in Cyprus.

Cooper-Jarrett, Inc., long-haul trucker, announced yesterday that it had bought the Atlantic Freight Lines. The purchase price was $750,000 cash for both rights and equipment, which includes eighty tractors and 150 trailers.
The foreign freight forwarding industry, which grosses $35,000,000 annually, appealed to a Congressional subcommittee yesterday for protection from the Federal Maritime Board.

COFFEE-MAKING seems to be the cause of many a homemaker's headache, and the cure is not an aspirin. The first step is to diagnose the source of the trouble and treat it accordingly. Bad coffee may be due to a number of factors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A Washington lawyer proposes to let an American audience read a translation of what a Russian speaker says while he's talking. The system, which was patented this week, would avoid the usual interruptions by an interpreter and substitute a silent television screen.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- This is holiday time in Moscow, the eve of the anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917, a time for politicians to orate and people to celebrate.
The Horse Show Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria last night was the highlight of the social activities in connection with the seventy-second National Horse Show, which opened Tuesday for an eight-day run.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -President Eisenhower plans a brief visit to Augusta, Ga., before Thanksgiving.
Cardinal Spellman began the Catholic Bishops' Thanksgiving Clothing Collection in this area yesterday at a meeting of fortyfour regional directors of the drive for the Archdiocese of New York.
Scientists at the Rockefeller Institute yesterday reported a successful advance into the inner nature of proteins -- the "building blocks" of the body.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 6 (Reuters) -- The inhabitants of the Northern Cameroons, heirs to some of the most picturesque and difficult terrain in the world, vote tomorrow in a United Nations plebiscite on their political future.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- The Government has fined an airline pilot $100 for flying a four-engine plane over an offlimits Washington area that includes the White House.

Columbia's football team will face Dartmouth in an Ivy League contest today at Baker Field before a homecoming alumni gathering. The kick-off is scheduled for 1:30 P. M.

May I congratulate you on your editorial of Nov. 4 entitled "After the Voting." Although the entire editorial is worthy of the most favorable comment, I want particularly to commend you on your comments relating to our present method of selecting judges by popular election.

OTTAWA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Federal Government announced tonight a delivery stretch-out plan to keep Canada's multimillion-dollar uranium industry going at least until 1966. The move was taken after the Government failed to persuade the United States to buy more Canadian uranium after present contracts expire in 1962 and 1963.

MISS JESSICA, Bergdorf Goodman's high priestess of millinery, designated by no less an authority than Cecil Beaton, has a new acolyte. He is "Halston," a remarkably inventive young man she has introduced to the store's Custom Millinery Salon.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 7 -Sir Arthur Bryant denied today that his book based on the war diary of Field Marshal Viscount Alanbrooke accused General Eisenhower of playing golf at a crucial stage of the war.

Substantial write-offs of costs of the Electra transport program resulted in a loss of $2,840,000 for the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in the third quarter, the company announced yesterday. In the 1958 period, the company had a net profit of $3,629,000, or 57 cents a share. Sales in the latest period rose to $324,800,000 from $218,800,000 a year earlier.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- The second world championship of the International OneDesign Class of sailing craft will be held in Norway next summer, Cornelius Shields, chairman for the event, said tonight.
Six detectives were promoted and two patrolmen were appointed to the detective division yesterday for their work in solving crimes.

The city government may still be inadequately dealing with the smoke nuisance, but it is good to note that the public is becoming increasingly aware of it. The Department of Air Pollution Control reports that in the first nine months of this year more residents registered complaints of excess smoke and other violations than during any similar period since the city agency was formed seven years ago.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 (AP) -The United States and the Soviet Union opened negotiations today for a new scientific, technical and cultural exchange agreement in a friendly atmosphere.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 6 (AP) -The Laclede Steel Company, which employs about 3,500 production workers in near-by Alton and Madison, Ill., reached a tentative agreement today with the steel union on a new contract.
